No accidents, etc
No Sherpas or oxygen
Team was on Cho Oyu at same time as Germans and C2's in same place.

Were ahead of Germans but moving slowly.
3rd member never reached BC had made at least C3 at 7000m

BC at 5400m road - on main trading route from Tingri across Nangpa La to Khumbu
C1 at 6300m south of point 6446m
C2 at 6700m at just below icefall
C3 just below yellow band.

Left C3 at 8:00 am Chinese time. Engl, Schmatz, Zembsch at 8:15 and Woerner at 8:30. Engl and Schmatz on top at 3:00 pm; Zembsch turned back after 1 hr because thumbs freezing and half-way Woerner turned back sometime later (late morning) but 1st 2 didn't realize it. Engl and Schmatz returned to C3 at 6:00-6:15pm and found other 2 there and Woerner said his problem was hyperventilation that night. Strong winds that night and very cold next morning. 

Zembsch not willing to go up but Woerner started making tea. Woerner started up on 11th at 9am alone while Engl and Schmatz got ready to go down. Engl from C2 saw Woerner at yellow band 12:30-1:00 pm and thought Woerner coming down, then thought still going up; Engl and Schmatz down to C2 while Zembsch awaited Woerner at C3. From C2 Engl saw Woerner going slowly up last ice field. Woerner reached top 6:00 pm and back to C3 at 10:30 pm in dark and seemed normal. 12th morning Woerner's speech irrational and was unable to get up to put on boots. Zembsch left him at 3 pm to get help; reached BC 13th (where Engl and Schmatz were) at 10:00 pm. Zembsch took oxygen, etc up on 14th morning but could reach only 6500m because 30-40 cm snowfall, avalanche danger, couldn't see and back to BC. 15-16th bad weather. 17th Engl up but only to 6700m because of storm and slept in C2 and back to BC noon 18th. [Woerner stranded and not rescued.] Yak men had come 17th evening to clean BC so we had to start on 18th and we took down tent and at 10:30 evening reached Chinese BC at Kyatrak. Goods at deposit at 5850m and BC at 5400m looted.

Woerner had helped two Britons when they were badly confused by high altitude. He was determined to go to summit himself as good for his expedition-organizing business.


Guenther Haerter (also on Cho Oyu) - 11 June 88

Members of Haerter's expedition found a body in a tent at 7300m - had been told by Tibetans there was a Japanese dead body up there so did not examine it closely but noted clothing and equipment made in Italy and Switzerland. Hood of down jacket was over his head, his face was brown and he appeared to be slumped over his backpack - his crampons and ski poles were neatly placed outside the tent.

No other tents of his expedition were found - others must have cleared mountain.
ACCIDENTS: Woerner stranded at C3 with AMS

ROUTEMEMO:
1st BC at 5400m at Summa Glacier, S of Nangpai Gosum
2nd BC at 5400m below Nangpa between g+p of Nangpa Glacier on Schneider map
ABC at 6000m at same site as ABC of 1986 spr Polish-Swiss-Australia
C1  at top of scree
C2  below icefall
C3  above all icefall
C4  at 7600m at summit slope.

Had permit for SW Ridge and went up Summa glacier to have look at but rock wall above 7000m looked too difficult as an approach; so crossed col to west and made new base at normal BC site below Nangpa La. 30 Apr two climbers [Sterritt and Morris] set out from C4 with Walsh; Sterrit reached very little higher before altitude sickness sent him back to C4; Morris went on 200-300m more because of altitude making him go very slowly; hoped to go to top on 1 May but in fact descended next day with slight frostbite. Walsh summited on 30 Apr. 

Alan Hunt failed to acclimatize and went home early. Sirdar also ill from altitude after having gone to C4 quickly (a young Sherpa).

Team had hoped to ski the mountain, but too much ice so skis not used past ABC.

LO with expeditions from Tibet normally stay well down and want to know about teams from south only if these present a problem to leaders from north, according to climbers on Cho Oyu at same time as British.


Schmatz, German Cho Oyu - 23 May 1988

Stefan Woerner of Germany-Swiss Cho Oyu from Nepal helped 2 British members when they were badly confused by effects of attitude.

ABC at moraine at foot of glacier 
C1  at 6000m near "a" in Glacier of Gyabrag Glacier on Schneider map
C2  at 6500m just before the icefall
C3  at beginning of snow slope.

Forno climbed from C3 at 1:00 am and on top at 9:00 am in beautiful moonlight and clear but windy weather and back to C3 for that night; then stuck in C3 for another day and night in big snowstorm. Other 2 members went only as high as C2 and skied down from there. Only difficulties are between C2 and C3 where same steep bits and crevasse below and above C3. Left BC 12 May.

Had intended to ski up and down mountain but yaks did not go as high as expected and 2 members left expedition early (20 April) and could see there was not so much snow. Fewer members to carry loads. Could see could ski up to 7600m only so skied only down from C3. Left skies at C3 on ascent and made no higher camp because not skiing higher.

May 1 summiters reached summit between 4 pm and 6 pm.

Italians were separate team from German-Swiss party on same permit; but otherwise a different group with different name, time table, camps and supplies.

Germans returned in storm on day before De Marchi left BC for KTM (he left on 5 May). Italians to top from C3, last camp in 8 hours and back to C3. Next day to BC. Forno started from C3 in night, went to summit also in 8 hours and returned to camp to descend with 1st party - others may try (except 2 sick men, who went home). Yaks ordered to beat BC on 9 May for Italians departure. German-Swiss party have more time.


Christine Kopp - Dec 2010 (by email)

Do you remember I had asked you about the ski descent of Cho Oyu in 1988 with the Oreste Forno expedition? I've now found out that Flavio Spazzadeschi is living not more than 10 km from where I live... Incredible!Just for your information: Flavio confirms that he and Lino Zani did NOT make the first ski descent ofCho Oyu. They took their skisup to about 7000m but then didn't use it todescend ("we were simply too tired, I didn't spend one thoughtin thinking to use them on our way down..."). Other mountaineers (of coursewith the permission of Zani and Spazzadeschi) used them to do some skiing, but definitely not a full ski descent.
ACCIDENTS: Forno slight frostbite on left foot; Benzoni and Gianola altitude sickness

APPROACH: From Xixabangma BC by truck same day
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 15 kms north of Nangpa La (normal site from truck)
Biv1 towards Nangpa La.

No fixed camps on Cho Oyu. 21st started up from BC & 6 to top. Started in 3 groups on 3 successive days carrying everything with them. 1st group of 3 went all the way to top from start of 26th May from BC. 2nd group of 9: 8 including Haerter reached 7700m & back in wind on 31st May. 3rd group of 4 from BC 28th May & 3 to top. 5th May all in BC & left BC 6th May. Route really not technically difficult although slightly more so than Xixabangma. 4 members left 31st & 3 on 2 June out of boredom. 

Team had acclimatized on Xixabangma.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to snowfall, avalanching, insufficient equipment in alpine-style attempt
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at junction of Hinku Nepal and Hinku Shar Glaciers (porters not going higher)
Biv 1 at junction of Hinku Nepal and Kangtega Glaciers
Biv 2 in icefall of Kangtega Glacier
High point at Kangtega Glacier at near "a" of Kangtega.

Climbing started 9th April. 11th April 200m ice climbing and then many big crevasses. Each member carried little equipment in alpine-style and encountered 10m crevasse, so turned back and slept at 5200m, 1st biv site. 12th April bad weather began with daily snowfall, so after 5 days gave up. Big avalanches coming down, climb too dangerous.
ACCIDENTS: Maeda bad altitude sickness at BC and did no climbing

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  above Gorakshep (higher and about 1 and 1/2 minute of it)
C1  at 5800m on ridge above Kalapattar
C2  just before horizontal snow ridge on SW Ridge
C3  at 6250m at east side of the rock towers
Biv series on ridge
Biv on ridge in ice cave.

Both White and Kopal stopped climbing early, both not feeling strong as were other two. White had chest infection and Kopal "burned out" on this mountain, went with sirdar to climb Pokalde. Kopal left BC 14th Apr while others remained at BC.

4 members started up on 11th Apr, 12th on up individually to start of ice on horizontal ridge while others, too slow and less competent, turned back from the climb after all 4 had established C2 on 12th. 

13th 2 members (Leibundgut and Tuckey) on up while Kopal and White down. Leibundgut and Tuckey crossed ridge, slept on ledge that night in tent. 14th around the rock, followed the ridge and what altitude reached don't know that night; same for following 2 nights. Had bad fire in tent last night it was used and 17th slept in snow cave at least at 22,000 ft on SW Ridge. 18th to top, took photo before top, continued to true top and more photos. Descended about 150 ft when Leibundgut said dizzy, not well, needed help. Decided to go down E Ridge, which seemed easier with same ropes fixed by Indonesians. Soon Leibundgut completely disoriented re-climbing techniques; darkness soon came and wind blew up (as much as 60 mph). Best to dig in which only Tuckey did and during pause in doing this, Leibundgut was gone and his pack on him gone but ice axe still planted and now very dark. Tuckey slept in ice cave and down to BC on 19th.

Leibundgut's girl friend and her sister were at BC when Tuckey came back alone.
ACCIDENTS: Tuckey frostbite; White chest infection; both White and Kopal stopped climbing early as both not feeling well; Leibundgut fatal fall

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5340m near Kalapattar (normal route)
C1 at 6000m at spur from East Ridge
C2 on East Ridge.

After C2 establised, down for rest. 2 summit bids: 

2 people [Marsana, Senapi] to C2 but felt unfit and stayed in C2. 

21 April 4 Sherpas and Miss Moeliono went up and reached 7000m but turned back in poor weather, late in day and no more fixed rope. 

3rd team of 5 left BC 24th April for C1, 25th to C2 and 26th to top. Climb not difficult except night of 25th snowfall so knee-deep snow on summit day; also big crevasse to cross and small icewalls on crevasses' upper side; very cloudy just on Pumori and windy. Left C2 at 9:00 am and on top at 6:00 pm (had expected noon) when clouds cleared suddenly. Returned to C2 at 9:30 pm except Sherpa down to C1 because 1 tent at C2 covered by snow. 

Gunawan and Djuandi began getting frostbite on summit and during descent but will be Ok; Nangdang Syamsudin very slight frostbite; Sherpas none.
ACCIDENTS: Frostbite only; Gunawan and Djuandi began getting frostbite on summit & during descent but will be OK; Nandang Syamsudin very slight frostbite; Sherpas none
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Indonesian ascent of any expedition peak; 1st woman from Indonesia to 7000m

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to poor weather, team not strong
ROUTEMEMO:
BC due west of Pheriche, SE of point 5110 and NE of point 5140m.

No fixed camps above BC. All members in BC on 8th April. Started climb on 12th April in 2 pairs. Duff and Black bived at 18,000 ft and others 18,500 ft on E Ridge/E Face. 13th Brindle and Moore climbed half the day, then storm coming and Moore not well, so they went down while Duff and Black to 19,000 ft on the undefined ridge on the face. 14th on up to 20,000 ft. Was snowing all the time while fundamentally rock climbing on this feature. 15th Duff and Black climbed one hour up to just below 150 ft granite wall, which would take time to surmount directly with aid-climbing, so traversed under it and then down Japanese Couloir route (which Duff climbed in 1987). Went down because by now had lost logical route and weather not good at all. Several avalanches went down couloir as they abseiled down its side. 

All in BC 15th and still snowing at BC on 18th when left BC. Needed at least a week of sunshine to clear the rock. Was difficult climbing with 2-3 inches of snow on the rock. Black fell off twice. No thought to go back up this "Mountain with a bad god." Brindle not keen and Moore slight altitude sickness. Duff today suffering from sciatica.

Team members arrived at BC on different dates. "This was more a holiday than a climb," but all were there by 8 April.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to lack of food supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC south-southeast of mountain
C1 at side of couloir
C2 at col at top of colouir
C3 at top of west facing hanging glacier middle of south 
C4 at central spur.

Turned out to be more difficult and dangerous than anticipated. To get from BC into cirque took 2 weeks to find way. Went up to 15,000 ft on one ridge and hauled loads there in meantime. Had to traverse cliff with 200 ft of fixed rope to ABC in the cirque on ridge of land just above a glacier. Above ABC route up snow couloir to C2. Above C4, steep bad rock or steep bad ice with avalanche face or steep blue ice traverse with many gendarmes. Now little food left and deteriorating weather.
ACCIDENTS: Andrasko carried 500m down by avalanche on 27 April at 4200m, but only bruised and scratched

ROUTEMEMO:
BC nearly as same as Japanese on moraine on great side of South Annapurna Glacier.

Route was basically as same as Japanese in winter 1987 and then variation of British 1970 spring route. Weather was not good with snowfall everyday. Quite difficult wall between C2 and C4 with some steep, even vertical pitches of bad rock, which British climbed. Below this was big serac above couloir above C2 under which had to climb; had to fix rope quite high because of avalanche danger; fixed about 1400m total. 

Dorotei, Rakoncaj and Boyer established C4 on 8th May and 3 others down to C3; Boyer to C3 next day. On 10th May, 3 French and Boyer started earlier and climbed through C4. Chamoux, Campredon and Boyer were on top within one hour of Dorotei and Rakoncaj (10-11 am), but Detry had been not well day before and turned back 100m from top when others coming down; he had 2 more hours to reach top but weather deteriorating. From C3 started at 11:45 pm on 9th and from C4 at 2:00 am on 10th. All six slept at C2 which was reached at 7 pm on 10th in descent.

TERMNOTE: Did not reach BC
ROUTEMEMO:
2 days beyond Lete on route to BC at 5000m, where same places are dangerous, 15 of 30 porters decided to go back. On 3rd and 4th days had bad hailstorms and porters asking for snow clothes, which team did not have or go back. BC route still difficult on ice where would have to cut steps in ice and porters. Should have hired porters from Lete who are experienced; porters were from KTM. 

Team had very limited funds, so expeditions abandoned. Planned to climb Annapurna, but went trekking instead. All members well.

SPONSOR: 1988 Korea Alpine Club Chung-Dong Churen Himal Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Kaphe Khola Glacier
1st C5 at SE Ridge of East Peak
2nd C5 at SW Ridge of East peak.

E Ridge from E Peak above C5 very steep knife ridge with 7 or 8 pinnacles without crusted snow on each side, so had to crawl this section. Reached 7180m before giving up because 10 hrs more climbing to summit (had climbed from 5 to 11:30 am on 21st April from C5). Then moved C5 down steep wall to new site with some difficulty via C4. 

2nd summit bid for E Peak on 28th April from new C5. 27 Apr reached 7200m on SW Ridge of E peak and biv there. 28th Apr down on north side of the ridge to 7130m when weather bad with snowfall and wind, so returned to C5. Now food finished in C5 so on down. 

3rd May summit bid: C6 pitched at biv place on 5th May, one day rest and 7th May to top via SW Ridge of E Peak to E Peak summit on somewhat difficult sharp ridge on which had to fix short ropes. On entire route fixed 1400m including last part of approach to BC, which placed at last year's C1 site, rock face of Ghustang's N Ridge, just above C2 on triangular rock face and down from 1st C5.

Kwon fell into crevasse just 10m in front of C3 after having unclipped from fixed rope and tried to cross narrow crevasse, but slipped and fell 90m and was killed. 2 members down near to him and could not reach him completely but already dark.


Ministry of Tourism Mountaineering Secition - Press Release

Two members of the 1988 Korean Chung Dang Alpine Club Churen Himal Expedition were successful to climb Mt Churen Himal at 10:20 hours on 7th May 1988.

They established C6 at 7210m on 5th May and stayed at the same camp. On 6th May they started from C6 at 04:55 hours and reached the summit at 10:20 hours on 7th May. The summiters hoisted the flags of Nepal and South Korea and photographed. They stayed about 55 minutes on the summit and returned to C2. There was strong wind blowing during their stay on the summit.


Expedition Report/Churen Himal East peak by the First Ascent route from Bulletin of Korean Alpine Federation:

Seven Jung-Dong Alpine Club members led by Chi Hoon-Ku set up camps on the West Ridge of Churen Himal East Peak.

The second attempt was tried by Jung-Dong Alpine Club (JAC). The first attempt was tried at premonsoon season last year, but compelled at the point of East Ridge 7200m.

Although Churen Himal East Peak was climbed by Korean Expedition party in 1970 for the first ascent, but Japan provoked doubts on their conquest for the lack of convincing evidence to prove their conquest.

JAC established BC at 4750m on March 26, and then C1, C2 and C3 at 5370m, 5760m and 6310m on March 29, April 7 and 10.

On April 11, Shin Jang-Sup and Kwan Dae-Sik started from C2 to carry loads to C3. Kwon fell in a crevasse near C3. Other members tried to rescue him even for 5 hours, they couldn't pull up his dead body.

They set up C4, C5 at 6610m, 6810m on April 16, 20. And then Shin Jang-Sup and Lee Heung-Sik proceeded towards the summit via East Ridge.

Two members confronted Pinnacle connected to East Peak at 1 km front of the summit. The prospective route situated in dangerous condition to pass only a keen and narrow pinnacle zone. The route passed steep ice and snow pinnacle. So they felt that they couldn't come back if they went forward continually and withdrew.

They depend upon 2 members and no Sherpas, they taking a detour route. On April 26, Shin and Lee moved C5 and set up 6680m on April 26. They approached the summit on the next day but the weather deteriorated when they arrived at the middle peak below 7280m. They made an unprepared bivouac at the point.

On April 20 they started to the top the ridge of Middle Peak connected to East Peak. The route from Middle Peak Col was pinnacle zone and the way after the route was mixed snow and rock in unstable conditions. They withdrew and came down lower camp. After laying in a supply of food and fuel from C2, they tried the 3rd attack, as the final attack.

On May 7, Shin and Lee proceeded towards the Summit at 4:50 am and stood on it 10:30 am.

To climb the route from C4 to the top, which was pinnacle and rock ridge route. They had to pass several rocks. Using 5 hackers and 20m fix rope used when they descended. It was a new approach to the West Ridge.
ACCIDENTS: Kwon killed in crevasse; 1 porter carrying to C1 injured by falling stone
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Korean ascent perhaps (not sure about 1970 Spring)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to snowfall, avalanching, bad visibility and poor health
ROUTEMEMO:
This mountain previously known as Ganesh III until re-surveyed in early 1990's.

BC northeast right underneath Ganesh IV at yak hut
C1 at moraine of branch Tarsgampa Glacier
C2 just below entrance ice fall to use NE Face
High point at NE Face.

Recced up NE Spur left of Japanese route but found it very dangerous from enormous avalanches, so moved to NE Face to left main NE Ridge. Recce 24th. Placed C1 for NE Face climb. Now only 2 climbers because Mothersele ill and never went beyond BC and Downs only litte way above BC (perhaps to 18,000 ft), found it hard going and gave up. From C2 climbed through icefall with water gushing from top if it while huge avalanching going on. 5th April descended to BC because of snow; full previous night. 7th up from BC to C2 and 8th up through "waterfall" but felt impossible to climb high without heavy aids and/or siege tactics. Had only 5 days food left for this push. Went down on 8th with hope of trying Japanese route (NE Spur) but poor weather and each got sick in turn. Donovan did try solo Japanese route on 17th but gave it up too after reached 19,000 ft when warm clouds obscured where he was going.

Ganesh II very avalanche prone and therefore very dangerous in warmer seasons - great bowl which means warmth and much snow melt - Japanese route probably is the safest route.

Downs - 23 April 1988

Abandoned just east route on 9th April - very technical by Donovan and Mathias.
Downs did recce to 18,000 ft on north side and others were to try this beginning 16th April. Leave BC 21st.
Downs left BC on 15th and leaves Nepal 28th.
Mothersele ill - chest infections which got before BC - in BC only 3 days and then left expeditions.
Donovan and Mathias should arrive KTM 27-28th.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st British and Americans on Ganesh II

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5400m due to heavy snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Japanese BC site
Biv 1 on glacier
Biv 2 on glacier.

Constant fresh deep snow with snowline well below Sama (perhaps at 3000m). 16th March went up to final loads but couldn't find it in deep snow so back to BC. Obvious would need wait at least 10 days to resume climb. 9th March started to Naike Col but couldn't reach (too late) & then that night snowfall began. 10th March retreated to BC & several days of snowfall.

Route variation seems interesting and plan to return to it in 1990.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7050m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site above Samagaon
C1 on glacier
C2 on Naike Col
C3 at glacier below North Col
C4 on NE Face.
High point at C4.

Good weather in early April but then bad weather began with snowfall after. Made 3-4 attempts to go high but always stopped by snow. Finally C4 pitched on 1 May but again snow (1m) avalanche destroyed tents at C3 16th April but no one hurt. Route is not difficult but dangerous seracs between C2 and C3; big danger from avalanching when snow falls.

BC  below East Ridge (really on East Ridge southwest of Samagaon)
C1  on East Ridge
C2  at beginning of plateau (slope between Ridge and NE Face)
Biv at 7500m at small saddle on normal route.

Team had planned to send more summiters on 2nd May but weather turned bad with stormy snow 1-2 hrs after 1st team reached top on 1 May. All down to BC. 

3 members went up to a bit higher than 7500m but windy and no shelter at 7600m on 10th May and back to C2. Now clouds moved in and on 11th fought way down to BC in heavy snowstorm. After that team had enough. One traverse of 150m was only difficult point; was at 6000m and ropes fixed there which made it easy. Also fixed section of 250m below C1 to make it easy climbing upper part of a steep couloir.

Calendar of Events - expedition report

25/3/88  Begin of approach march through the Buri Gandaki valley with
         54 local porters.
03/4/88  Sama - basecamp with 24 porters from Sama village
06/4/88  Reconnoitre of route on the East Ridge up to 5500m. Putting
         fixed ropes (250m) in the upper section of the big couloir
08/4/88  Establishing C1 at 5900m by Fuster, Levet, Spirig
09/4/88  Climbing on the East Ridge up to the begin of the steep 
         traverse clearing and fixing old ropes, which we found in place
         (Fuster, Levet, Spirig)
10/4/88  Climbing the steep traverse through the South Face 
         Hangelquergang and fixing 150m of rope (Spirig, Levet).
13/4/88  Establishing C2 at 6800m by Fuster/Ott.
         They turned back after the arrival of bad weather.
16/4/88  Establishing of gear and food deposit at 6500m. We had to 
         return due to bad weather (Levet, Spirig)
19/4/88  Attempt stopped in C1 by bad weather (Huber, Fuster, Ott). 
         After 1 day, they returned to BC.
22/4/88  Attempt stopped in C1 in heavy snowfall and bad weather (Levet,
         Spirig). Returned to BC after 3 days.
16/4/88  Attempt stopped in C1 in bad weather (Wille, Stahel). Returned to 
         BC after 2 days.
28/4/88  C1 reached by Huber, Fuster, Ott and Wille, Stahel.
29/4/88  C2 reached by Huber, Fuster, Ott.
30/4/88  Climbed up to 7500m and biv there (no tent) by Huber, Fuster, Ott.
         C1 reached by Levet, Spirig (Wille, Stahel still there).
01/5/88  Huber, Fuster and Ott started at 5 am and reached the summit of
         8163m high Manaslu at 1:20 pm. Bad weather arrived very soon. 
         They had to descend in snowfall and fog. Late at night they 
         reached the deposited tent at 6500m, after a short visit of 
         the other group at C2. Ursula Huber is the first Swiss woman 
         to reach the summit of an 8000m peak!
01/5/88  C2 reached by Levet, Stahel, Spirig weather got bad in the 
         afternoon and snowfall started.
02/5/88  The whole team descended down to basecamp in bad weather and snowfall.
08/5/88  C1 reached by Levet, Spirig and Wille, Stahel.
09/5/88  Levet, Stahel and Spirig reached C2 in bad storm.
         We decided to bring down the gear and to camp at a more protected
         spot at 6500m.
10/5/88  After one night with strong winds and much snow blowing around,
         we continued the ascend in still stormy conditions. In 7500m, 
         found the biv place of our friends. The site was storm beaten 
         and we couldn't find any protected spot or enough snow to dig
         and snow cave. Eventually, after reaching 7600m, we decided to
         turn back. Late at night we reached our last camp at 6500m.
11/5/88  Descending down to BC in heavy snowfall and poor visibility
         (Levet, Stahel, Spirig).
13/5/88  Returned from BC with 10 porters from Sama village. After 9 days
         Gorkha was reached.

APPROACH: Berni->GurjaKarni->straigt N and NW into Kaphe Khola
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to avalanche threat to route
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southeast of peak, east of a 6500m dome
C1 on South Ridge below rock tower
C2 above rock tower
C3 at base of ice tower (all blue ice)
High point at nice tower.

Clients had very hard time on blue ice of ice tower (above C3). Had fixed 850 ft on snow gulley tower to C2; above that on blue ice 900 more ft to C3; above C3 1000 ft on ice tower fixed but after snowstorm couldn't reach this last rope in avalanche-threatened area which had to cross. On 3 May tried to return to tower but too risky and turned back and climb finished. Did not actually reach S Ridge.

TERMNOTE: Termination reason unknown

SPONSOR: Korean Bong Am Alpine Club Ama Dablam Expedition Winter 1988-89
ROUTEMEMO:
SE Face had much rock fall so made no attempt to climb it. Team was only on normal route, following exactly route French had just climbed. After making BC, had altitude problem (first time in Himalayas for all 3 members - had many headaches). So went down to Pangboche twice, then got down to climbing mountain. 

1st summit attack 14th Dec by Cha and Kim from C2 and reached crevasse at 6500m and returned to C2 that evening. 15th Dec they rested in C2 (Bong in C1). 16th Dec Cha and Kim to summit and Bong from C1 to C2 and on to a bivouac at 6300m. 17th Dec Bong bivouac to summit and down only to C2 in cloudy and windy weather, which pinned him in bivouac all of 18th. Clouds made Bong's difficult because bad visibility; used others rope.


Sanak In - Spring 1989

All members are first overseas climbing. They arrived at BC on Nov 27. They rested few days because they suffered from the symptoms of high altitude and after they established  C1 and C2 until Dec 13th.

Upper the C2 blocked by mixed snow and rock face. Yellow tower was very difficult technic climb route which vertical and crack rock step 500m long.

They started for the purpose of attacking the summit but they could not reach the top because there appeared to have one night but they have no bivouac equipments. After all they retreat to C2. Food was knocked down by a huge birds on C2, so the foods also become to short.

They attempted 2nd attack on Dec 16 at 04:40 and reached the steep ice and passed the Second Step at 11:00. After they followed the summit ridge finally they got to the top at 12:50.


Hirsh, French, etc - 15 Dec 88

Korean Ama Dablam

Were trying eastern of 2 South Ridges but making little progress. LO left then to let them climb where they liked after that so may go onto SW Ridge where French had left their fixed ropes.

French left BC 10 Dec and Koreans were then giving up to their own C1. They didn't seem to be properly equipped or know what they were doing.

BC on plateau above Mingbo Glacier (usual site)
C1 near lake
C2 on ridge just before steep section.

Winds destroyed tents and food at C2 so had to rest back and prepare for early start for 2nd summit party. Garcia left C2 with 2nd party, was really sick but on antibiotics and stopped at 4 pm at 6400m in crevasse near route, sat on backpack all night and reached top next morning in strong wind and cloud; Laot stayed at C2 from 2nd Dec and went up again alone on 8th Dec followed later by 2 Sherpas. Left C2 5 am on top at 10 am. Down 12 noon.

1 summiter (LeBissonnais) lost leg to cancer at age 17 when was already very strong rock climber and goes climbing constantly with prothesis (leg off above left knee); another summiter (Rouys) has incomplete fingers and toes from birth.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6800m due to deep snow
ROUTEMEMO:
High point on South Face.

Did new route from C1 to C2 with 1200m fixed rope on very hard rock in couloir (up which Sherpas refused to go even after rope fixed). Very difficult but shorter and more stable than older route, more direct. At C2 joined Polish route.

In Nov made route and carried loads to ABC; did not climb any trekking peaks. In mid-Dec more than 2m fresh snow from 15th Dec and on 17th Dec all down to BC because already 1m snow; 23-25th Dec more heavy snowfall with 2-1/2m snow lying at BC now. 29th Dec up to ABC, where found more than 1-1/2m snow, restablished camp with new tents. 31 Dec remade route to C1, where over 4m snow and only 1 tent found but other tent had all supplies. 3rd Jan snowfall again and by 6th Jan over 1-1/2m new snow between ABC and C1. 7th Jan all down to BC. Between C1 and C2 couloir now mostly iced and impossible to climb so expedition finished. Almost constant powder snow avalanches but did no harm.

Many problems with Sherpas and with getting porters to evacuate BC.
ACCIDENTS: Ang Kami fell and injured leg but OK after 1 week; Tomov kidney attack in Nov and went home

SPONSOR: Masaki Matsumoto Cho Oyu Winter Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5700m due to wind, deep snow and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at west side Lungsampa Glacier
High point at top of Lungsampa Icefall.

16 Jan climbed up thick icefall to 5700m and turned back by strong wind; back to BC. 17 Jan to Gokyo because too much snow and wind no time. Lost a week's time because of no flights from KTM to Lukla and lost two more weeks getting to BC because deep snow in Khumbu made portering very difficult to BC.

SPONSOR: NTT Kyushu Alpine Club Himlung Expedition
APPROACH: Dudh Khola->Hampuk & small stream N of Hampuk
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6650m due to bad weather conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
Expeditions to Himlung prior to 1992 were probably climbing Nemjung.

BC at small stream moraine south of mountain
C1 at glacier southwest of summit
C2 below West Col on hanging glacier
C3 on snow plateau just east of West Ridge
C4 on West Ridge (Tibet side of serac)
High point at 2nd rock steep ridge.

"Very difficult mountain." From BC to C1 2 hrs walk; C1 to C2 8 hrs exposed to dangerous rockfall while climbing icefall. Fixed entire route (every day rock and ice avalanches). C2 to C3 icefall (again ice blocks falling). C3 to C4 on knife ridge with left leg in Tibet, right leg in Nepal. Very hard blue ice; again all fixed with ropes. Above C4 very sharp knife ridge on very hard blue ice (crampons slipped). To pass large hanging ice, Baba made hole through it. High point of 6650m was 50m high rock wall which had 3 rock steps, 1st one Baba passed but other two presented greater problems and so gave up this attempt in strong wind and need for rest for 3 days. Then 3 days heavy snowfall began 18th Dec which left 20cm deep snow at BC and no good weather coming.

Did not attempt S Face; many avalanches and "no route."
 
"It is miracle that all members alive." 1 member's rucksack has big hole from rock that fell.
ACCIDENTS: Moti Lal frostbitten cheeks and nose; some climbers hit by rock but not hurt

SPONSOR: Japan Kumamoto Star & Storm Climbing Club Winter Expedition 1988
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lirung Glacier.

Rock ridge grade 4 difficulty; snow ridge above C3 knife ridge and more difficult. Summit party started from C3 at 6:00 am. Nage got altitude sickness and turned back at 6500m while others went on top at 2:30 pm; no ropes fixed above C3. 2000m rope fixed between BC and C3. 

No other summit bid because other members not so strong. Climbers unable to manage difficulty above C2.
ACCIDENTS: Noge altitude sickness but quickly recovered by descending

ROUTE1: E Face up; E Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
Route was harder than they had expected; difficult technical rock, very steep, down-sloping rock-had to chip rock to make platform for sleeping-safe route. No rock fall, their climbing together very smooth, as though they had been climbing together all their lives. Took them 8-1/2 days from start of climb to summit, 1-1/2 days down.

Lowe and Roskelley arrived KTM from Lukla on 23 Feb and caught their flight to Bangkok few hours later. Houtan spoke with them very briefly while they finished packing at his house.

Up from BC on 6th and from ABC on 7th. Tried to get 2, sometimes 3 and 1 day 4 pitches in each day. Photo shows snow but this taken in earlier season: there was no snow and would take couple of hours to chip out rock for bivs." Fairly safe but has to be done in winter to be reasonable. We did have rock fall; on face one of our ropes was chopped in half." Fixed first 2 pitons up and just started climbing; climbing rope was cut in half; rock went through Jeff's biv. sack and sleeping bag, hit where Jeff's shoulder had been. Real steep, one of steepest climbs continuously either of us has ever been on." Very thin pitons called knife blades "only thing got up." Some good weather. Ice climbing but one difficult pure water ice tongue which Jeff climbed under and up around. Only at 7th biv site were able to find small cave and thus only place not exposed to all loose rock on this face (with more climbers would have sent rock down others below). Hardest climb Roskelley ever done.

Roskelley couldn't remember altitudes of bivouacs.


Report filed with Tourism Ministry:

Tawoche Winter 1988-89
Route of ascent: East Face
Arrived BC 25 Jan, climbed up 7 to 15 Feb.
Descended 15 and 16 in alpine-style from base of face to top.
Route of descent: "used 2-year-old Japanese route down SE Ridge to southeast gullies."


Report filed with Tourism Ministry: Tawoche Winter 1988-89

Route of ascent: East Face arrived BC 25 Jan
Climbed up 7 to 15 Feb, descended in alpine style from base of face to top.
Route of descent: "used 2 years old Japanese route down SE Ridge to southeast gullies."
Left BC 17th Feb.
ACCIDENTS: Lowe altitude sickness last couple of days

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5790m due to difficulty of route
ROUTEMEMO:
1st BC southwest of mountain
Biv C1 at bottom of West Ridge
2nd BC II Kyashar Glacier
2nd C1 at lateral moraine on west side of glacier
1st biv on a bottom between point 5991m and point 5652m
2nd biv at buttress
3rd biv on South Ridge
High point at the base of tower.

Found fixed ropes left by French in 1985 autumn on West Ridge when ridge covered with snow, but now snow gone and headwall to ridge entirely rotten rock. Climbed to 5365m on 4th Dec and then gave up intention to scale this ridge because of many rotten rock towers which would have required much fixed rope and time but intention was to climb rapidly, so descended to 4570m on 4th, dropped loads there and down to BC same day. On 5th tried another approach to ridge a little further east, but lot of rocks coming down so too dangerous to get close as back to BC. 

6th to Manje and 7th went east through Kyashar Glacier to try South Ridge with Sherpas carrying loads to C1. 9th Aprin and Culver began alpine-style push up 600m loose rock up a buttress on E Side of S Ridge and biv without tent. 10th to very small ledge on buttress. 11th had climbing continued but snow on rock now, which made for faster climbing and reached ridge at 3:30 pm at base of tower (5790m). 12th looked at rock to tower but did not have enough gear for 300m vertical distance to rappel down in descent so decided to descend and were in BC on 12th determined to return to route in spring 1989 making stocked camp at 5730m and fixing whole buttress and perhaps 1st tower with Sherpas.

TERMNOTE: Summited NW Smt
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at NSW of point 5456m, start of NW Ridge
C1 on NW Ridge
C2 before and below point 6686m
C3 on ridge beyond point 6686m
C4 at north side of ridge.

From BC route went round to north side of point 5456m and up side of NW Ridge. No C1 because too much of wind. 4 times tried to go to W Summit but very strong cold winds defeated 3 bids. On 4th did reach W Summit. Very difficult last section to W Summit. Fixed 4800m rope total from little below C1 to 200m above C4 where ropes finished and used climbing ropes. Climbed from C4 at 7 am; summited 14:05, C4 19 hrs. 23rd Dec 2nd attack from C2 by 2 members but again strong wind and Sherpas not willing to try, so reached only 200m above C4 and gave up. Climb finished and all members went down.

Frostbite Bae Hyun-Chul black fingers; same for Chun Bong-Gon and Kim Hwa-Gon deep frostbite and will loose finger tips. Phinzo Sherpa also same serious frostbite.


Winter Ascent and Tragedy by Cho Hyung-Gyu

The party planned to climb the mountain through west ridge. They set up C1 at 5800m on Dec 3rd. They advanced mixed snow and rock in dangerous section and then set up C2 at 6800m. The weather deteriorating and they were storm-bound for 4 days.

The partly led on the difficult route and fixed a rope in the long and steep snow slopes to C3. Finally, they set up two box tents at C3 on spot of 7400m on 16th.

It was changed to the worst weather on the summit day but 1st attack party started to the summit. However they backed without moving more advance because there appeared the crevasse on the upper plateau below the summit ridge. Severe winner winds and considerable snowfall defeated their 1st attack party.

They revised all plans and entered the 2nd attack on 22nd. The member Oh Sei-Chul, Chun Bong-Gon, Kim Hwa-Gon and Bae Hyun-Chul departed C4 for the summit at 07:30. 4 members reached cornice below the summit. They climbed and at last got to the top at 14:05. Actually they succeed first winter ascent of Nuptse West. Even all members were unexperienced with the Himalayan mountains though they have achieved a real remarkable success.
 
They had on epic descent. The team described the struggle as "Physically and mentally very demanding."

On Dec 23 the 2nd attack party had left C4 for the summit but they evacuated because the strong wind and poor visibility.

4 summiters and 2nd attack party come back BC on Dec 24.
 
3 members of summiters had to cut all hand and foot due to severe frostbite.
ACCIDENTS: Hyun black fingers; Bong and Hwa deep frostbite and will loose finger tips; 1 Sherpa also serious frostbite
ACHIEVMENT: 1st ascent of W Summit, 1st winter ascent of any summit of Nuptse; 1st ascent of Nuptse

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to fierce winds and snow
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Tseram 4 days for porters from normal BC
Normal BC at normal site
C1 at normal site
C2 at normal site.

Had to make route to normal BC (BC3) in deep snow and normal BC was actually third BC for this team; all porters had left expedition at Tseram but 2 Tibetans helped carry to normal BC. Very strong winds non-stop night and day everyday above 6500m during climb. This why reached early 7200m in clear sunny weather. Lost C2 on way to normal BC 2 tents and never found them (this on glacier at 4900m = "glacier BC") about 25th Feb and at normal BC, 2 tents destroyed. On 9 Feb Lwow ascended on hands and knees in terrible winds and had to retreat to BC for rest. Then came heavy snowfall again. Fixed 250m ropes only in short section to C1 and later not used. Reached 7200m without fixed ropes.

Lwow - 10 March 89

17 Dec 88 - KTM -> by truck
19 Dec    - Dhankuta -> Basantpur
20 Dec    - Basantapur
25 Dec    - Hellok
29 Dec    - Hellok
02 Jan 89 - Torontan
07 Jan    - Tseram
08 Jan    - Tseram
20 Jan    - BC, our third BC
01 Feb    - C1 - 6200m (Lwow, Jakubowski)
08 Feb    - C2 - 6900m (Lwow, Jakubowski)
09 Feb    - C2 - 7200m
14 Feb    - snow, 30 cm in snowfall lost C2 and deposit at 7200m for
            for fully stocked C3.
19 Feb    - snow 70 cm
22 Feb    - C1 (Lwow, Pankiewicz, Pichlak)
26 Feb    - all people in the BC (Tseram) arriving Russian expedition
            8 members and sirdar and 30 porters
01 Mar    - left Tseram
08 Mar    - KTM again
                

Rutkiewicz - 24 Feb 89

Arrived BC 20 Jan 5600m after 6 weeks aprproach march. Had first BC at about 10 Jan 3870m in forest at Sera and only 2 porters carrying loads beyond this. Left expedition 10 Feb. Made
  C1  6200m
  C2  6900m
and reached 7150m when she left.

OTHERSMTS: Attempted Lhotse S Face (LHOT-883-03), climbed Everest (EVER-883-07)
ROUTEMEMO:
Batard & Sungdare made probably the fastest ascent of Cho Oyu to date. They were entirely alone on the mountain & encountered nearly knee-deep fresh snow. On 27 Aug, 3 days after they had arrived at their BC (5700m), they pitched a bivouac tent at 6700m, their only tent above base, tried to go the top on the 28th, but they were not well acclimatized & retreated to base. On 31st they went again to 6700m. In the evening at 10 pm left for the summit, climbed all night in full moonlight & were on the top at 10 am on 1st Sept. By 5:30 pm the same day they were back in base, having carried their bivouac tent down with them. Batard had flu & was on antibiotics throughout the climb.

From BC went without camps higher. 1st climb therefore biv 26 Aug 6200m and 2nd night to 6700m. 3rd day (28 Aug) started for summit without tent and was too quickly reached 8000m and back to biv - were too tired, not acclimatized. Took more direct route than normal route way but not very difficult. Down to BC on 29th and stayed there 2 nights. 31st up again by normal way; left BC 1:30 pm and reached biv tent at 6700m on a plateau at 6:30 pm. Had food and drink and started up at 10:00 pm and climbed all night in full moonlight and on top at 10:00 am 1 Sept. When reached top were in fog but suddenly fully clear and could see were on highest point but found no metal flag. Much fresh snow made it almost knee deep. Stayed about 30 min on summit in warm sun. Down directly back to BC with biv equipment and arrived at BC 5:30 pm 1 Sept. Saw no other people's tents. "Physically it was very difficult for Sungdare and me." Sungdare very strong and when no track already made, he and Batard go at same speed. This climb was preparation for Everest, not a bid to scale all 8000ers but I am very happy to climb.
ACCIDENTS: Batard had flu from day of arrival at BC & on antibiotics to today 5 Sept

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8700m due to bad weather and Sherpa death
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at South Col
High point just below South Summit.

After C3 established bad weather. 3 times forced abandonment of climbing to col: wind and clouds. Finally on 11th Dec 4 Sherpas including Ang Rita carried up loads, 2 to Col (Ang Rita and Ang Jangbu) and other 2 an hour below col. 

On 21st Van Snick, Ang Rita and Ang Lhakpa Dorje (Ang Lhakpa of Everest 1985 spring summit) pitched camp at col. Left C3 8:30 and arrived 15:30. At midnight in bright moonlight left C4 for summit attempt by all three despite Ang Lhakpa's having been ill in evening twice. Van Snick and Ang Lhakpa used oxygen resting before start of climb on 21st night and during the climb above col Ang Rita carried full bottle for Van Snick. Was no wind, snow conditions very good. Ang Lhakpa had problem mask clogging with ice. 8 am arrived just below S Summit at 8700m and stopped to change Van Snick's oxygen bottle and drink tea. Ang Lhakpa fell on his back and slipped 8m, did not move, Ang Rita went to him and gave oxygen while Ang Lhakpa remained unconscious briefly then came around. Ang Rita spoke to him but Ang Lhakpa's speech confused. All three descended with Ang Lhakpa's walking roped between other 2; arrived at C4 9:30 am, rested 1 hrs, then Ang Lhakpa semi-conscious. Very strong wind and impossible to descend and had to return to tent almost immediately after they had started to descend; gave Ang Lhakpa more oxygen. By 4:00 pm it was clear descent impossible that day as wind stronger still. At night leg spasms; doctor thinks had cerebral thrombosis. At midnight Ang Lhakpa's oxygen empty and Van Snick stopped resting on oxygen and gave his to Ang Lhakpa. 2 am Ang Rita went out and found another bottle outside tent and Ang Lhakpa got new oxygen bottle. Ang Lhakpa found to be dead at 7 am while others trying to get radio contact with lower camps to ask 3 Sherpas come up to help. Still strong wind at col but on face not so bad and Ang Rita and Van Snick could descend and went to BC same day. Now decided Everest climb finished: exhausted and ill after 6 weeks on mountain, and strongest climbers, Ang Rita and Van Snick not in top condition. Soon afterwards came big storm which destroyed higher camps. No attempt to return to col for body.

If Van Snick and Ang Rita had gone to summit, would have gotten there at about 10:00 am and perhaps would not have survived descent.

Everest effort by Belgians failed - collapsed after 1st bid and Xmas at BC: 
1. No strong leadership - Detienne got sick and went to KTM; deputy leader Vreugde interest in scientific research for one month and not leadership; climbing leader Cornellissen not strong personality, too mild; Sirdar Ang Phurba's wife seriously ill and he left BC.
2. Psychological problem of first experience with winter's severe weather - Belgians not prepared for this
3. "Low altitude" sickness - Detienne would have died without use of 3 bottles of oxygen at and below BC.
4. Came too early in season - now is time to be mounting ascent, not Nov
5. Death (in this case Lhakpa Dorje's) is problem for young climbers and Tettelin, who is strong, took death very hard.
6. Few strong climbers: Miss Baeyeons (sick), Van Snick and Tettelin only.

Much money spent on expedition including 3 generators at BC for electric lights, 7 kitchen staff at BC, 2 Belgians at BC only for food and equipment, etc.


Detienne - 24 Dec 88

22nd early 1:00 am 3 start from S Col - 8:00 am reached just below S Col. Lhakpa Dorje sickness, lost control and collapsed in snow. Rudy and Ang Rita brought to South Col tent and gave higher flow of oxygen. Big snow and wind storm, stayed in col with sick man now in coma in late afternoon - 7:00 am died. Rudy and Ang Rita to BC late evening, leaving Lhakpa Dorje at Col; want to bring him down but winds preventing this.

Everest cancelled but 1 Belgian and 2 Poles try Lhotse. Stayed 10-14 days,
others leaving BC 23rd not so well; all others 27th leave BC. In KTM 31st.

On 22 Dec they started at 1 am from South Col toward the summit. At 8 am they reached just below 8700m. Sherpa Lhakpa Dorje collapsed to unconsciousness. Ang Rita and Rudy brought Sherpa to South Col. They put him on oxygen. That whole afternoon Sherpa was in coma. At early morning on 23rd Dec (7am) he died. In South Col there were no other member except summit party.

On 22nd due to very bad weather (storm, windy, snowfall) Ang Rita and Rudy cannot bring down Sherpa body.

After Lhakpa death two climbers left South Col and in the late afternoon, they reached base camp. It was not possible for them to bring down the dead body of Lhakpa due to exhaustion and bad weather.

Sherpa's are going to try to bring down the body if weather permits.

Everest expedition decided to abandon their bid due to this accident, but Lhotse bid be continued with Belgian lady climber.
ACCIDENTS: Dewaele exhausted, shocked, needed O2 and was brought down; much slight frostbite; leader's serious lung ailment; Ang Lhakpa fatal fall

ROUTEMEMO:
When came down to BC for Christmas suddenly Belgiums decided to quit. Waited few days for storm to pass, then had to prevent Sherpas from taking down C1 and C2. Wielicki on 28 Dec went up to Cwm to stop Sherpas, other 2 Poles and Ingrid to C2 on 29th but had bronchitis. 30th Wielicki took sleeping bag and equipment to see if C3 intact and try for top alone if good weather while others sick. 31st no clouds and wind and Wielicki went up quickly, not taking time for making C4. Started 4:20 am after having made a tent out of 2 torn tents; Cichy still sick but went up to C3 when saw Wielicki moving up from C3. Wielicki reached bottom of couloir at 10:15 am, 1-1/4 hours later than planned, but couloir was easy in good snow conditions in it. Reached summit 2:00 pm in little wind; returned to C3 at 5:00 pm, pushing and timing himself in descent not to rest too long each time and end up dead like Marcel Ruedi. Felt cold despite all warm clothing and one big toe frostbitten. 

No others to try Lhotse top: Ingrid sick throughout expedition; did not go above C2 for Lhotse (to C3 for Everest). Icefall in terrible conditions 40 ladders needed (1 place 4 ladders strung together) vs 2 in 1979-80. Belgians insisted on Everest attempt before Lhotse bid. After Poles prepared Cichy and Van Snick to make Everest bid and after they got to Everest top, Cichy and Wielicki (who would have come to Col) to go from Col to Lhotse summit (not on ridge but little below ridge) but Belgians determined to go home: pressure on Van Snick not to climb over Lhakpa Dorje's body.

Everest effort by Belgians failed - collapsed after 1st bid and Xmas at BC: 
1. No strong leadership - Detienne got sick and went to KTM; deputy leader Vreugde interest in scientific research for one month and not leadership; climbing leader Cornellissen not strong personality, too mild; Sirdar Ang Phurba's wife seriously ill and he left BC.
2. Psychological problem of first experience with winter's severe weather - Belgians not prepared for this
3. "Low altitude" sickness - Detienne would have died without use of 3 bottles of oxygen at and below BC.
4. Came too early in season - now is time to be mounting ascent, not Nov
5. Death (in this case Lhakpa Dorje's) is problem for young climbers and Tettelin, who is strong, took death very hard.
6. Few strong climbers: Miss Baeyeons (sick), Van Snick and Tettelin only.

Much money spent on expedition including 3 generators at BC for electric lights, 7 kitchen staff at BC, 2 Belgians at BC only for food and equipment, etc.


Detienne - 24 Dec 88

22nd early 1:00 am 3 start from S Col - 8:00 am reached just below S Col. Lhakpa Dorje sickness, lost control and collapsed in snow. Rudy and Ang Rita brought to South Col tent and gave higher flow of oxygen. Big snow and wind storm, stayed in col with sick man now in coma in late afternoon - 7:00 am died. Rudy and Ang Rita to BC late evening, leaving Lhakpa Dorje at Col; want to bring him down but winds preventing this.

Everest cancelled but 1 Belgian and 2 Poles try Lhotse. Stayed 10-14 days,
others leaving BC 23rd not so well; all others 27th leave BC. In KTM 31st.

On 22 Dec they started at 1 am from South Col toward the summit. At 8 am they reached just below 8700m. Sherpa Lhakpa Dorje collapsed to unconsciousness. Ang Rita and Rudy brought Sherpa to South Col. They put him on oxygen. That whole afternoon Sherpa was in coma. At early morning on 23rd Dec (7am) he died. In South Col there were no other member except summit party.

On 22nd due to very bad weather (storm, windy, snowfall) Ang Rita and Rudy cannot bring down Sherpa body.

After Lhakpa death two climbers left South Col and in the late afternoon, they reached base camp. It was not possible for them to bring down the dead body of Lhakpa due to exhaustion and bad weather.

Sherpa's are going to try to bring down the body if weather permits.

Everest expedition decided to abandon their bid due to this accident, but Lhotse bid be continued with Belgian lady climber.
ACCIDENTS: Wielicki frostbitten big toe (which should heal)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to wind (no snow in gully)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on SW Face 
C4 on SW Face
High point at C4.

Belgians made icefall route and charged $1200 and Rs 5000. In gully all ice, no snow so Sungdare and Park Jong-Guk say impossible to climb. Anyway very strong wind and rock avalanching. Stayed in C4 2-3 nights but made no attempt to go higher. Progress to C4 very slow because much snow as well as fierce winds. Fixed rope all way from C2 to C4. 2 members and 4 Sherpas to C3, 1 member and 2 Sherpas to C4.

SPONSOR: Chuo University-Nepal Joint Expedition to Langtang Ri
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on Langtang Glacier just west of Goldum as planned.

Not more on top because many spells bad weather that meant much extra work and food supplies finishing. Summit day very cloudy: left C3 7:20 am, on top 12:20.

C2 to top steep snow walls. Route condition different than Japanese in 1981: deep snow this year very dangerous, so had to vary actual route.


Shrestha, Tourism - 21 Oct 83

Success: summit reached 9 Oct at 12:20 pm. Put Japanese, Nepal and Cheo University flags on top (from C3 or elsewhere not said):
   Tsuchiya Yasunori, born 1953, sales manager
   Sundeep Gurung, 25
   Pema Sherpa, 35
   Pemba Lama

BC 11 Sept 5000m
C1 14 Sept 5760m
C2 and C3
All well and returned to BC (no date).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7700m due to high winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual NE Ridge route site.

Wind too strong; [Hasegawa and Ishii] were going for summit 3 Nov from C3, but went to ABC. After that Hasegawa tried alone for top on 5 Nov from ABC to top on same day. Left 1:00 am from ABC, but Chin coming down from C2 to ABC that day and Chin did not reach ABC and Hasegawa looked for him and thus diverted from summit bid. Waited for daylight, found Chin at 7:30 am in biv and came down with him. No other summit bid because 17th Nov time limit. 

Hasegawa did not try face because ridge route leader Yoshio was in bad condition (stayed BC a while then left 20 Oct), so Hasegawa had to take over as ridge leader. He hopes to make a solo ascent of an 8000er sometime in future. Main problem was snowfall in which lost temporary C1 and then high winds broke tents at C3.

Chin died below BC apparently from altitude problem. Had climbed very slowly throughout, though went to 7100m in carry intended for C3.

4 members in temporary C1 in avalanche but not hurt and went to ABC. This only avalanche. 2 members slight frostbite.

Yoshio sick (nature of illness not clear to other members).


Shrestha, Tourism - 14 Nov 1983

Chin died on Chambabarg Kharka hill on Nov 7 at 13:00 hours. Left BC Nov 6 with expedition but could not keep pace with group and left behind and spent 6 Nov night in glacier below BC. Nov 7 Kazumi Nishihira (1956, Hiroshima) and 1 Sherpa (Dawa Thundup) went to look for him and found him in bad condition and took him down (carried) but at 1:00 pm Chin died. Miss Kei Inoue massaged Chin's heart but failed to revive him. Body cremated on 8 Nov on C. hill.

Health of all others good. Ishii and Toba arrived KTM last night. 


Shrestha, Tourism - 24 Oct 1983

C1
C2 6600m (date?) established by Nobutaka Kusano and Masayoshi Utsumi.
All well. Weather continous snow, so climbing slow if necessary maybe ask 1 week extension [were granted 1 week extension].


Hasegawa & Chin - 16 Sept 1983

Hasegawa arrived KTM 15 Sept and leaves 19 Sept. Maybe waits for Chin's permit if leave KTM 19 Sept, arrive BC 1 Oct and climbs ridge first participating in making the camps and go as far as C3 at 7500m in perhaps 2 weeks to C3. Not to summit on this route then 1 week in BC and start solo ascent N Face maybe 25 Oct. 1 week to 10 days at first gate to about 6000m and return to BC. Finally push BC to summit with an summit 29 or 30 Oct and then descend via NW Ridge. 

N Face route - new, not Pear route
On face difficult rock band at 7500m area
As Hasegawa descends ridge, other members may be in camps on ridge.

Hasegawa has climbed Aconcagua South Face solo in winter in cold and very windy weather, so Dhaulagiri in late Oct "no problem." Also been to 8000m on Everest in great cold. He can arrive BC and go up immediately since he goes to 7000m twice every year (thus is acclimatized). This will be 2nd solo ascent of Dhaulagiri I. Kamuro made solo ascent but used Canadians C3 and fixed rope.

BC  at site of Japanese BC just vacated
Biv 1 above Col on NE Ridge
Biv 2 at end of NE Ridge (same as Japanese just before them).

This expedition reached Dhaulagiri I without permission.

Only 1 tent each, had 18 kg loads. from BC to top in true alpine-style. Had acclimatized on Dhampus (summit 3 Nov, 3 nights on French pass, 2 nights on Dhampus pass). Began Dhaulagiri ascent 9 Nov 1:30 am. 11 Nov started ascent (9:30 am cold wind before) thinking too see route only but weather so good kept on to top (had gas for only one night more) via ridge without going onto face at all. Reached summit 2:00 pm and biv at 6000m at 10:00 pm. 12 Nov arrived BC 12:00 noon. Used Japanese ropes on ridge also useful, but not necessary. Had to wait for Japanese to leave mountain since French had no permit.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6020m due to fresh snow and wind constantly (some avalanching & huge amount of snow)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at near Japanese 1982 autumn BC site.

Fresh snow and wind constantly. Did have some avalanching in abnormally large amount of snow. Really needed Sherpas to help make tracks in deep snow.

Difficult but not dangerous; not difficult to C2, difficulties came higher. In normal weather not much danger.

SPONSOR: Nepal and Hirosaki University Mt. Himlung Joint Expedition 1983
ROUTEMEMO:
Expeditions to Himlung prior to 1992 were probably climbing Nemjung.

BC at east of glacier (beside glacier).

No plan to put a C4 on ridge. Started from C3 on 27 Oct at 5:30 am and 2 from biv at 6590m at 6:30 am. On top 4:05 pm by all 4 summiters: biv men had to make route so moved more slowly then C3 men, who caught up with them. Strong wind but clear. Minami and Lama returned to C3 while other 3 to biv.

S Ridge would be terribly difficult: glacier at bottom "not so good" and then difficult rock face below ridge itself. East Ridge is only route.

From C3 to top along ridge difficult ice conditions (with soft snow over hard ice). Beyond C2 very sharp rock ridge which had to go round. Most difficult part of climb of climb was very steep final ridge.

No serious accidents. One Sherpa hurt finger with ice axe and could no longer bend it.

Leader did not take part in climbing at all.
ACCIDENTS: None serious; one Sherpa hurt finger with ice axe and could no longer bend it

SPONSOR: Kagawa Worker's Alpine Federation Himalchuli Expedition 1983
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to fatal accident
ROUTEMEMO:
BC south-southwest of main peak near glacier.

After Sept 30 bad weather (snow and avalanche danger) so all in C1. On Oct 6 went to make C3 and 4 members Fujita, Hase, Kanazawa and Morisato carried personal equipment to go to C3 and other 4 members in support carrying supplies of food and tents with 2 Sherpas resting in BC for 1st summit attack after 5-6 days.

1st team reached 6300m at flat place. 9:10 am one member slipped; all roped together and expected him to stop himself but he did not and pulled others (not strong belay because seemed safe place). All 4 slipped 200m. Hase died 9:15 am and Fujita 5 pm in tent near where he lay unable to move him.

Kanazawa injured unable to go down from where Fujita died, but Morisato went down to C2 on 7 Oct. Helicopter went to C1 on 9 Oct which evacuated Kanazawa.

Yes - want to do it [again] in 1985 or 1986.

Route followed is easiest routes on Himalchuli.


Mrs Otsu - 10 Oct 83

Kanazawa has some fractures and breathing problem. Morisato in better condition. Kanazawa in Otsu's house and stays here at least 3-4 more days.

Expedition abandoned. Others arrive KTM 18 Oct.

BC northeast of Meta village.

Between C1 and C2 big icefall and crevasses = most difficult part; ice wall above C2, then C3 to W Ridge long ice wall. Route more difficult than expected: icefall and ice walls took more time to surmount.

Noburo Ueno left team before BC because not well (58 years old).

Oxygen used by 1 member who reached C3 and had to go down (medical use).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to deep snow
ROUTEMEMO: C2 to C3 very deep snow and other 2 members in poor health for long time. Easy but long route - very safe and easy.
ACCIDENTS: None except 2 member's poor health: 1 old injury to back gave trouble after carrying many loads to C1, other had diarrhea long time

ROUTEMEMO:
BC probably at French 1971 C1.

Carlos Buhler (US-Canada Makalu) - 9 June 84

Buhler thinks it was foolish for New Zealanders not to have fixed rope in lower section of climb where they would have had to move often in carrying loads of rope, etc. up to higher parts. No wonder they lost a member here.


2nd death (of Moorhead) on 15th Oct - 2 out of 4 members gone.

Hard work making route from C2 to C3 because so much deep snow, it was necessary to excavate to get to rock for belays. By 14 Oct when reached 7600m had gotten to summit snowfields and were ready for summit push. Had climed all the hard part including great crack.


Fred From - 27 Oct 83

14 Oct Fred and Mark got to high point of 7600m fixing route to top of hard part of climb and just below French C5. No C4 even made as it would have been one a short distance above 7600m in final push.

14 Oct returned to C3 snow cave at 7000m. Peter was in BC. Went there on 14th. 15 Oct Fred and Mark continued descent to BC. At about 10:45 Mark fell (why no idea) on easy ground, good snow, clear weather and light wind. He was 40m vertically below Fred and about 100m away. He cart-wheeled in big movement suggesting he tripped or stumbled and his body fell about 600m vertically. From never got closer than 100m, so no idea exactly what killed him. Was lying peacefully on his back, head down, arms across chest.

Fred descended as quickly and safely as he could to find him since he'd disappeared from sight and to help him but from 100m could see no hope and too dangerous to go alone to him. Reached BC at dusk.
 
2 days later Peter and Fred tried to reach body but wind too strong. Went to C2 6580m and Mark's body at about 6280m. Necessary to go up to C2 and then try to reach him. Returned to C1. Peter said he did not go back above C2 and Fred's fingers and toes too cold-affected to solo it, which would have been possible; otherwise neither of us understood the accident, so we didn't trust our judgement any more.

Fred and Peter would like to return to West Pillar in pre-monsoon season when should not be so much snow and do climb alpine-style, not putting in fixed camps and rope as this autumn.

Peter returning to KTM with baggage; arrives in 10 days, possibly much sooner.


Makalu Expedition BC, 4 Oct 1983 - Peter Hillary

Fred, Mark and I have returned from the mountain where we have had a tragedy. While Fred and Bill Denz were descending from C2 to C1 on the 3rd of October at 2 pm. They were caught in an avalanche. Fred managed to extricate himself and Bill who was below, was swept one hundred meters into a snow basin below the ridge. There was a considerable accumulation of avalanche debris and there was no sign of him to be found. From the time of avalanche and until 6:30 pm (dark) we probed in the debris and searched crevasses but to no avail. Mark and I were at C1 and ascended to assist Fred in the search. The accident occured at 6400m and he was swept to the southern side of the ridge where he was buried under 3-4 meters of snow. The avalanche was 500 meters wide and Bill's body has not been found nor any of his equipment.


Report on accident involving the death of a member of the expedition.

Fred From, Mark Moorhead and myself have returned to BC today from the West Ridge of Makalu where we have had a tragedy. While Fred From and Bill Denz were descending from C2 to C1 on the 3rd of October at 2 pm, they were caught in an avalanche. From managed to extracate himself and Denz who was below, was swept one hundred meters in a snow basin below the ridge on the southern side. There was a considerable accumulation of avalanche debris (the avalanche break being 500m wide) and Denz was buried under 3-4 meters of debris and consequently, we could find no trace of him or any of his equipment.

The avalanche occurred at 6400m altitude. From the time of the avalanche and until darkness at 6:30 pm we probed the avalanche debris with a bamboo pole and ice axed and searched a nearby crevasse...but to no avail.

Moorhead and myself were at C1 at the time and observed Denz's fall in the avalanche. We ascended to assist From with the search. Denz died in the avalanche and was unrecovered.


Letter from Bill, Makalu BC - 13 Sept 1983

We are progressing with the route satisfactorily we are all getting on well and what's more, it the weather continues to be reasonable we have to make our summit bid towards the end of September. C1 is at 5900m and we have soloed the ridge to C2 at 6420m which is a snow cave at the foot of the really steep. (This camp is in the same vicinity as Roskelley's C2).

We hope to solo 1/2 way to C3 and fix the rock steps with rope. I expect to establish C3, at 7400m on about the 18th to 20t of September and then work on the main buttress done over the next 3 or 4 days. We hope to make a gear damp at the campsite sometime during the 21st to the 24th. Our C3 we hope to establish higher than the French/US camp so as to reduce problems for the summit day. Hopefully it will be at 7900m.


Letter from Bill - 13 Sept 1983

We have established C2 on the SW Pillar of Makalu at an altitude of 6480m. This is the same location as Roskelley's C2. We are using a safe roamy crevasse and have stocked it with food, fuel and rope. We go up to C1 tonight (amended height 5950m) and occupy C2 tomorrow. We hope to stay there for some time, working on the camps above.

We fixed no new rope to C2 and used only 10m of old fixed rope. The French "Khumbakarna" expedition arrived 4 days ago and are carrying loads to their C1 on Makalu II. They also have permission for Baruntse.

BC on glacier southeast of mountain, 20 minutes from Annapurna I BC.

Technical climbing between C2 and C3: fixed rope almost entire section. Steep and exposed, very sharp ridge or arrete and snow initially very soft in warmer weather than later on. 

Some rockfall in band just below face hit members on helmets.

Doctor ill and left early because of illness.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7135m due to strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on glacier southwest of Annapurna III
C3 at West Ridge.

After 8th Oct was snowstorm of 3-1/2 days and then had to dig fixed rope out from under meters of snow. 22nd Oct, after having fixed ropes for 2 days, attempted push to top, got to top of S Face. 3 bivouacked at high point that night to do easy "trivial" long slope to top but next morning strong winds prevented any upward progress at all. Then another snowstorm night of 24th Oct buried ropes and had 2 frostbite cases, McDowell and Teague, who needed helicopter evacuation.

Lot more technical than anticipated. C2 to C3 possibly variation of earlier expeditions.

Adrian Teague and Jonathan Chester came out in Austrian Manaslu's helicopter; Teague frostbitten when fell asleep in unprepared biv and Chester next morning and in descent in storm.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to fatal accident
ROUTEMEMO:
On 10 Oct started descent, came to bergschrund at about 6300m and went into crevasse here in very bad weather (white-out) and avalanches coming down mountain (1 buried both men and turning point in Uttley's health - middle night of 11th). 13th wind but clear and Pilling able get out but Uttley not. Left him with 5 days food and some fuel and met others at ABC on 14th. Very slow downwards because snow so deep and upwards movement even (on this frozen cover) and Pilling shattered. Again weather turned bad with avalanches and no actual effort made to go up. Uttley's condition when Pilling left was so bad he probably would just sink away.

Pillar Ok but need period of 10 days.

Were going halfway East Ridge as acclimatization and to put in snowholes with supplies in case needed to descend this way. Then would make ascent via SE Ridge Pillar. After Uttley accident never made try for Pillar.


Shrestha, Tourism - 26 Nov 83

Leader's reports death of Robert G. Uttley, born 1961, geology student, Sheffield, on approx 14 Oct due to pneumonia and related illness at 6300m on East Ridge of Annapurna III. He was accompanied by Trevor Pilling, born 1956, student, Worcester.

The 2 men were caught in 5-day storm at this alitude (6300m). "Uttley's condition gradually deteriorating to state where he was unable to function and even attempt retreat without further assistance of more members. Eventually on 13 Oct Trevor Pilling had to retreat in order to save his own life. Attempts to conduct a rescue were useless as the weather conditions were very bad (new snow) and this may have endangered further life."

All 4 members had reached altitude 6150m, but 2 numbers, Uttley and Pilling had reached 6300m on 8 Oct. In evening of 8 Oct weather broke and they tried to descend but due to heavy snowfall and wind they could not come down, they were in a crevasse at that altitude. It was decided to abandon expedition on 18 Oct and left BC on 20 Oct and arrive KTM 26 Oct (today).

All 3 survivors are well.

Very tired on Huh's return to C3. BC on 23 Oct.

Sherpas with him much of climb as far as C3. 2 Korean teammates went several times to C1.

No fixed rope at all.

Koreans coming back to KTM, should arrive KTM 16 or 17 Oct.


The Plan

The next mountaineer to come with hopes for a solo ascent was a South Korean, Huh Young-Ho, a 29 year old cement company clerk  whose climbing experience also included a successful ascent of an 8000-metre mountain, Makalu, in the spring of 1982 on an expedition of which he was one amongst 16 members under another's leadership.

Huh was to make the first solo climb of Manaslu, at 8163m the world's eight highest mountain. He would try an alpine-style ascent with no fixed camps, no oxygen cylinders and no companions. But one or two Koreans and two high altitude Sherpas would be with him at base camp, and if his solo attempt failed, then he would enlist their help, pitch three high camps and get to the summit on a non-solo ascent.

The achievements 

Meanwhile the South Korean Huh had tried his own solo assault on Manaslu. His base camp had been pitched at 4800m on 14 Sept, but a long period of heavy snowfall followed, for the monsonn had not finished here. At last on 28 Sept he was able to spend his first night at 5200m. Next day he was moving higher when snow began falling and he was forced to retreat to base. That was the end of his solo attempt.

In early October Huh and two Sherpas twiced above up to C1 at 5200m and in the second push Huh and Ang Jangbu Sherpa went all the way to C3, which they put at 7200m. On 8 Oct Huh managed to get to Manaslu's summit plateau at perhaps 7600m, but once again bad weather forced a retreat.

Huh's ultimate push commenced on 16 October. He and Ang Jangbu gained C3 again on the 20th, waited out the strong winds of the 21st and finally Huh, having climbed the very last part from C3 struggle against nearly 1000 vertical metres of mountainside in very strong wind with no artificial oxygen to make the climb on hard snow and blue ice any easier.

Not far below the summit Huh had been met by three West Germans, an Italian and two Sherpas from a predominantly German expedition on Manaslu's South Face. He preceded them to the very top and then returned to his own C3 in four hours descent. He too was very weary when he joined Ang Jangbu in C3 but next day he went all the way down to base camp safely while the Sherpa, who was not well, stopped that night in C1.

Very deep snow; had to cross very steep snow slope, was very cold; 200m above climbers were dangerous seracs and avalanche danger. Studer had very cold toes and feared more. Same day all C3 blown away. 2 summiters went down to C1. Frostbite to toes already partly lost on Eiger North Face.

Khadga, Tourism - 28 Oct 83

Mrs Maya Senn and Max Wettstein are seriously injured and helicopter requested in report yesterday. Mrs Senn died according to report today. Helicopter this afternoon went for Wettstein, met expedition representative below BC when Wettstein was not there, pilot instructed them to bring to same spot tomorrow morning.


Press Release

Climbing a difficult route on the north ridge of their 6812m mountain, which is near Mount Everest, four members reached the summit on Oct 22. They included the expedition's climbing leader, Hans Berger, 35, from Davos-Frauenkirch, Switzerland.

Wettstein managed to return to the team's highest camp at about 6200m at nearly 10 o'clock that night to tell others about their weak condition and need for help. But Miss Senn spent the night alone a little distance above the camp and its shelter. Both had frostbite and Wettstein slight head wounds from a minor accidents when Miss Senn fell on him and the steel spikes fitted to her boots cut him.

It was during their descent on Oct 27, the day after they had attempted to go to the summit, when Miss Senn was being helped down the mountain side by Bumann, that these two, who were roped together, fell, killing Miss Senn outright and so injuring Bumann so that he died a day later at BC.

Wettstein was not involved in this fall, but his condition required helicopter evacuation to KTM. Supersaxo came with him and said last night that Wettstein is not really seriously ill, although he is staying in hospital here for a few days.

The other surviving members are expected to return here on Nov 2 after having buried their two teammates bodies near base camp.

BC down south of Fluted Peak.

5 left C2 at 3:30 am 22 Oct on top. 4 at top 4:00 pm and Oelz at 4:30 pm. At 150m below summit Amann found very sick from altitude and thin clothing and 1 glove (was crazy) at about 5:30 pm. Oelz very exhausted and it was very cold (-35 degrees C). Had no rope because not difficult technically. Mayr and Kleissl down with Amann and arrived C2 at 8:00 pm in full moon despite Amann's fall into crevasse. 2 Sherpas arrived 9:00. Oelz having gone astray, partly because of German voice "heard" and fallen down steep ice, at 12:00 took biv in terrible icefall. BC saw him wave for help. Slept 2 hours then understood his position and went down SW Face to BC. Very steep and avalanching, went down with avalanche 100-300m flying and turning over: "I used all the luck" - stopped 400m above C2. Other Austrian summiters got him down to C2 at 9 pm on 23rd.

No more to top because 20 cm fresh snow fall night of 23/24 Oct. Very dangerous between C1 and C2 and a little higher overhung by huge seracs that avalanched. Icefall in this area not very difficult but more dangerous than Khumbu Icefall.

Oelz may loose tips of 3 left toes to frostbite, Amann only slight frostnip.

Nairz left Nepal on urgent business call from home.


Shrestha, Tourism - 23 Oct 83

BC - 14 Oct 4400m
C1 - 15 Oct 5200m
C2 - 17 Oct 6000m


Deepak Lama, MT - 11 Oct 83

Wolfgang Nairz received urgent Telex from his office and had to return to Austria; came to KTM on 9th and left Nepal on 10th.

Rudi Mayr authorized to lead expedition.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to lack of time and bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
Note: This team thought they were climbing Glacier Dome, but were actually climbing the 7069m peak east of Glacier Dome (now called Tarke Kang II).


BC a little below glacier north of face.

Had only 16 days BC to summit and back to BC because of members holidays. Thus only 4 days available from last camp to top and 3 of these days had snowfall depositing 2m snow on this camp. Muller could have gone to top on 8th but expedition was to put others on top.

Not a difficult climb no problems with route. Only weather and time. Big avalanche near summit: 1 small avalanche near C3 which destroyed 2 tents but had snow cave.

BC at Pangpema meadows.

No more on top because strong wind next day. Rieben went upon 22rd a little but back without success. Were also ready to go for Yalung Kang summit, but avalanche danger too great and all down to C1 that day and to BC on 23rd and left 26 Oct.

Had 2 long spells of bad weather and feared when had only gotten to C3 that would have no success.

Did not use Japanese route because too many avalanches onto 1st icefield.

From C5 route to Yalang Kang looked more difficult and more risky from avalanches than to main summit.

Bruchez has frostbite which will heal, but Michellod may lose some toes which froze while digging C5 snowhole.


Khadga, Tourism - 1 Nov 83

Report of members now in KTM:
C1 5450m
C2 5800m
C3 6650m 1 Oct and 4 members here 5 days because bad weather
C4 7250m 18 Oct
C5 7650m 20 Oct
21 summit 1) Marco Bruchez at 5:20 pm
          2) Vincent May and went down to C5 at 8:30 pm in moonlight
22 Oct - 2 summiters and 3 others left C5 to C2
23 Oct - all material to BC
24 Oct - strong wind destroyed BC. Bruchez and Dominique Michellod
         treated for deep frostbite in feet and hands
25 Oct - 3 left BC to come to KTM by helicopter from Ghunsa; others left
         BC and should arrive KTM 5 Nov

No attempt on Yalung Kang.
ACCIDENTS: Bruchez has frostbite which will heal, but Michellod may lose toes which froze while digging C5 snowhole

ROUTEMEMO:
BC a little below Japanese and French BC.

Left altimeter on top tied to Japanese oxygen bottle (later found by Swiss).

Started climb on 17 Sept and mode three carries 45-50 kgs total, fixed ropes on route. Down to BC on 24 Sept for rest and better weather. 27 Sept again in C1 and on 28 Sept to 7050m and again snow so to C1. On 29th to C2. 30th to gully at 7300m and to C1 and on 1st Oct to BC. Weather bad until 6 Oct. Left BC on 6 Oct for 1st summit bid and reached C2 on 7 Oct and took this tent on 8 Oct to 7700m. On 9th tried for top but got about 8000m before went back in snow and cloud on top, so back to BC on 9th more bad weather. 

14th started up again: 14th in C1, 15th in C2, 16th in C3 and 17th on summit. Started at 5:00 am and reached top at 3:00 pm and returned at 8:00 pm on 17th, in bright moonlight but had to search for about 1 hour for C3 (was very tired, no food and water and altitude). On 18th down to point where most others who came up to meet and help salvage equipment at about 7200m. At BC on 19th. No real help from others except to save equipment.

Had some route finding problems because of need to go around crevasse. Fixed 100m rope and again 200m (2 sections) below C1 and also used some old ropes; also 50m just below Great Shelf in seracs on very narrow ledge (most dangerous pass).

No injuries except slight frostnip of toes and fingers; fell twice into crevasse to waist.


Pierre Beghin - 5 Nov 1983
