In descent stayed in biv at 20,000 ft in bad weather. Back to BC on 13th. Route was a variation of 1884 autumn.

Canada-British team had underestimated mountain rock section between 18,500 to 20,000 ft had snow on it and 1000 ft rock and ice arrete above 20,000 ft to top.


Baskota, Tourism - 19 May 85

All 5 members reached top at 8:10 am 10 May; started from biv 6300m at 5:30 am and on top in fair weather; 1 hour on top; arrived C4 (6000m) at 4:30 pm; stayed in C4 on 11 May because of snowfall, 12 May to C1 and BC 13 May.

Nankervis left fingers and Harris right toes slight frostbite.

Planned to leave BC 17 May.


Banskota, Tourism - 7 May 85

All 5 members established C1 at 5600m on 1 May.

TERMNOTE: 2nd attempt aborted due to accident, bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on north side of East Ridge above Samagaon
C1 on East Ridge 
C2 on East Ridge
C3 east of Ridge at foot of NE Face.

New route: last 700m steep rock and ice, and the altitude and steepness is not known; have little information of details of route (do not know if Yugoslavs climbed face).

From C3 climbed to summit plateau crossing under NE Face. From plateau followed normal way to summit. On 23 April 1st summit bid by Studer, Ang Kami and Lhakpa (sirdar), but could not go above C3 on 24th because of heavy snowfall night of 23 April, so went down. 

On 29 Arpil again up (from BC on 29th to C2). Arrived C3 30 April. At 10:00 pm 30th started for top (night climb because always clear at night). Studer, Mayerhofer and Ang Kami set out, but Mayerhofer turned back after 100m because fingers freezing. Studer and Ang Kami climbed till moonlight gone at 1:00 am again moved up about 4:30 am and reached top 3:00 pm. Took longer than expected - spent night at saddle at 7400m waiting again for sun, 

Studer slight frostbite in feet on summit push.

Gabl, Juen, Ljubanovic and Schranz left BC to C2 on 1 May and C3 on 2 May. 3 May much snowfall. 4 May from C3 at 5:00 am (3 men, Ljubanovic to BC). Gabl, Juen and Schranz reached 7300m at 10:00 am, couldn't find way from there to plateau in cloud, turned back at 3:00 pm when now snowfall stopped. Juen at 500m from C2 (not vertical distance) slipped in vertical icefall above C3 and avalanche started at same time and he was swept away with no sign of where he went. No more attempts at summit.


Banskota, Tourism - 3 May 85

Studer and Ang Kami Sherpa summit from East Ridge to NE Face at 3:00 pm 1 May. Raised Nepal and Austrian flags and took photos. Cloudy and windy at top, 5 minutes stay. Started from C3 at 10:00 pm 30 Arpil. Studer returned BC 9:50 pm 1 May. Other 4 members intended to reach summit.

Studer leaves BC for KTM arrival 6 May; others leave BC after 1 week from 3 May.
ACCIDENTS: Studer slight frostbite in feet on summit push; 4 members left BC to camps due to much snowfall; Juen at 500m above C3 slipped in vertical icefall starting avalanche that swept him away

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to rock and ice pitches
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Tora Gompa Glacier
C1 at Tora Gompa Glacier
C2 on West Ridge
C3 on West Ridge.

Had to change climbing route: learned 2 days before 18th Oct departure from KTM that South Ridge from Nepal on China border [closed] and therefore must climb another route and change approach route to go from Trisuli Bazar via Arughat Bazar, up Buri Gandaki to Sirdibas, then Siyar Khola and Tora Gompa Khola. 

From C1 to C3 all vertical ridge of rock and ice so when Sherpas dropped load of pitons on 11 Nov and load lost in 1000m drop, had to stop climb. Climb was difficult and dangerous and perhaps "lost load intentionally." Very good weather everyday; very difficult for small team of Koreans when Nepal "members" didn't work, made trouble, demanded more money.

Expedition left KTM very late because baggage did not arrive on schedule.

TERMNOTE: 2nd attempt turned back by winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at east side of ridge coming south from West Peak
C1 at east side of South Ridge = South Face
C2 at east side of South Ridge = South Face
C3 on SW Ridge
C4 at north side of West Ridge near its junction with SW Ridge and South Ridge.

Heavy snow in first part of Oct. Broke tents at C1 and C2 and made new camps before establishing C3. Then to summit on 27 Oct. 

Another summit bid 30 Oct by Nam with 2 Sherpas but turned back because strong wind broke tents at C3 and had to descend. Now no food. 

High-very steep snow face from C2 to snow hole bivouac site at 6800m. Team fixed 1800m rope on mountain.

Villagers nearest to BC said they had never seen foreigners before.

Kim Euk-Suk went to C2.

ROUTE1: S Ridge up; SW Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 4600m next to Italians (not intended site because of fresh
    deep snow where yaks couldn't go)
ABC at 5300m south of point 5705m
C1  at 5600m on S Ridge at start of steep section
Biv 1 at 5800m on ridge
Biv 2 at 6000m on ridge
Biv 3 at 6300m on ridge
Biv 4 at 6500m in icefall on South Face (now joined standard route).

No tent sites above C1 because narrow ice ridge. To Biv1 spent 4 days fixing rope from C1 and 3 days fixing rope from Biv1 to Biv2. At Biv1 Kurtz was with 3 summiters but 2 Nov complained of shoulder pain and went down. technical difficulties same as on standard route but less rock and more exposed cornices, more snow.

Pete Athans on 25 Oct joined Italian-French, etc group and went to their C1 that day under agreement where by if he joined fixing rope he could go to top with them. Aprin thinks he thought S Ridge might be too difficult a route to be sure to get to summit that way.

No accidents except Kurtz's pulled shoulder muscle and some members illness from stream polluted by Italians carelessness.

[Ridge running south from summit, east of standard route SW Ridge and of S Face, says Pete Athans 26 May 1994]


Pete Athans - 20 Dec 85

Athans went to summit of Ama Dablam on 2 Nov. Had gone over to Italian/French party because they needed help to get fixed ropes in place for client climbers; had intended to rejoin Aprin and team, but time was running out (he had to join Roger Marshall's group for Cho Oyu in winter), so did not go back to American expedition.
ACCIDENTS: None except Kurtz pulled shoulder muscle & some members' illness from stream polluted by Italian's carelessness

ROUTEMEMO:
Not much information on the file. It has been noted that there were 4 deaths of Sherpas [Dickey  and Curtis refute this - see below]

Alpine-style ascent of N Face expedition sat out bad weather at base camp most of the month of October. Tom Dickey had to leave the expedition because of guiding commitments to other trekking peaks. The team returned in Nov and T. Pilling and Japanese teamed up to attempt a route on the N Face of the lower peak without success. John Ball and Tom Curtis climbed the face in 4 days and 2 days down the dangerous serac barrier between the peaks.


Tom Dickey (via email to Salisbury) - 19 Jan 2004

We only had the 4 of us. We had a few porters bring some stuff to base, but they all left. No one was hurt.

I don't recall when we got to base - probably early Sept. The weather was bad for a long time, and we were storm bound for a couple of weeks, so we left for a while. I had guiding commitments and had to meet my clients. The three of them went up to the Gokyo region to do some "trekking." I don't know what they did. They then returned and John Ball and Tom Curtis did an alpine ascent of the North Face (the first) over several days. I seem to recall it was 3 days, up 2 down - going down the NE Ridge with much difficulty. Trevor tried a different route with a Japanese guy left of the NE Ridge but didn't get very high. Trevor disappeared in the Annapurna Sanctuary with his girlfriend a few years later.
  
I tried the face the spring (May) before that alpine style with Steve Ruoss, after his attempt on the NE Ridge with Jim Traverso, Geoff Tabin and Dave Dossiter. We got a little way up the face (1/3?) before getting stormed off; we were almost swept off and down the runnel we were in, but managed to get down. The storm continued for another 4 days and we ran out of supplies.
ACHIEVMENT: Slight frostbite by Curtis and Ball

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to avalanche danger, bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  above Samagaon
ABC on a ridge
C1  at col above glacier
C2  on NE Face
High point at C2.

Much fixed rope from C1 to C2 and between ABC and C1, total 300m rope. 5th Oct down for 2 days in ABC before summit push but had to stay 15 days at low camps because very deep snow with great avalanche danger. 21st Oct started up again and spent one day digging out ABC. 22 Oct found one tent at C1 after digging and on 23rd Oct dug out C1 where much equipment. 24th Oct slept at C1 and 25th Oct checked equipment intending make summit push beginning 26th Oct, but 25th Japanese had avalanche taking away 4 Japanese and 4 Sherpas at their C3 so cancelled summit plans to help. Avalanche showed condition of Manaslu's wide face: risk of avalanche above very big, very strong wind.
ACCIDENTS: One member fell but not really hurt

SPONSOR: Busan Teachers College Alpine Club Expedition to Tukuche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at north end of Hidden Valley between point 5087 and North Ridge of little
   Tukuche Peak
C1 on North Ridge
C2 also on North Ridge past middle summit.

According to the Ministry of Tourism the summiters included two South Korean climbers and two Nepalese Sherpas.

The successful South Korean climbers are 22-year-old Yong Jeong-Hwan, student from Dai Jeong city, and 23-year-old Leon Doo-Hee, a teacher from Busan.

Similarly, the Nepalese summiters have been identified as Ang Dorje Sherpa, a 27-year-old sirdar from Sankhuwasabha district and 25-year-old Gelbu Sherpa from Khotang district.

The four had started from the C2 at the height of 5900m at 06:00 hrs on Sep 4 and spent 20 minutes at the peak. They hoisted the national flags of Nepal and the Republic of Korea at the summit and took photographs. They started descending at 08:00 hours and reached the base camp at 14:00 hours.

Health of all the successful climbers is reported to be good.
The expedition is led by 31-year-old primary school teacher Shin Jho-Jin.


Received 21 Aug 85 from Leader Shin Ho-Jin

Started from Pokhara in Aug 15. We were stolen [equipment] by the Nepalese Robber in Navadanda. That time Aug 16 2:30 am. My equipment is Sherpa's equipment. Now our caravan is very delayed. Our expedition's very sad now.
* While we were sleeping that stolen.
ACCIDENTS: None except leader's stomach trouble which kept him in BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7250m due to wind and lack of food
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Myagdi Khola 2 hours NNE of Puchbar
Deposit at 4300m at right side of West Face 
C2 at 5900m at right side of West Face
C3 at 6300m at right side of West Face
C4 at 6900m at right side of West Face.

2000m of difficulty between 4500m and 6500m on pillar towards South Ridge of W Face, very hard rock climbing. This is one of highest unclimbed lines on any mountain.

SW Pillar alpine-style team reached 6800m before weather turned bad. After 10th Oct, entire team concentrated on W Face route.

3 days without any rain, 10 other days half-day good weather, all other days from arrival to departure BC bad weather (rain/snow) plus strong wind towards end. Stopped climb on 26th because strong wind destroying all tents as 24th and 25th nights (so 26th party used snow cave at 7100m night before). On 26th all down in BC. 

Meanwhile from 2 Oct to 12 Oct another party Bozik, Demjan and Rakoncaj went to 6800m as French SW Pillar in alpine-style, but Demjan had infected foot and weather bad so descended. From 14 Oct only 10 members in BC while 8 not so strong sent to KTM to save food. On face very hard rock climbing for 1600m.

24th Sept between C1 and C2 (about 5600m) Krizo fell 50m with snow and twisted knee, needing to be brought down. "Same avalanches with people" but no one injured.
ACCIDENTS: 1 member fell 50m with snow and twisted knee (needing to be brought down); avalanches with people but no one injured
ACHIEVMENT: 1st attempt on this W Face route

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near west shore of lake south of Hinku glacier (below "k" on Schneider map)
C1 at West Col (little below col)
C2 at beginning of SE Ridge.

Group not strong enough for this climb in such deep snow. First part above camp 2 was 85-degree ice for 30-35m and required fixed rope. Ridge on right side extremely steep ice and left side steep rocks; knife edge ridge.

Only 11 reached BC: Bechler, Beer, De Bokx and Moenig turned back.
ACCIDENTS: One member mildly sick; nothing else

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 4950m due to dangerous conditions and lack of rock pitons
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Larkya Glacier
C1 at foot of wall below ridge
C2 near Larkya Pass (for going round to northwest side).

Zintl and 4 members went for recce to see a route to North Ridge, but found it required rock pitons on only safe route and made another camp here. Then went round to northwest side of mountain through Larkya Pass, but here chest-deep snow in approach. Had a second camp at 4900m near Larkya Pass. Never really on the mountain: in better snow conditions could have climbed couloir to ridge; in conditions as they found them, needed rock pitons which did not have (for fixing 500m rope on rocky section between two dangerous couloirs).
ACCIDENTS: One member got altitude sickness on way to Larkya Pass

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5700m due to bad snow conditions and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC west-northwest of Kagmara La
C1 1/2 hour before Kagmara La.

Dick Kortekaas and Hans Oostindien slept at C1 that night and then all down to BC. Snow conditions bad and running out of time and of food in this food-deficit area. Then saw Dolpa and this visit really the principal goal of Hebbelink and others.
ACCIDENTS: Appel sick at BC and left expedition

ROUTE2: SW Face up; W Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4150m on east moraine of Saipal Glacier;
   150m above Austrian, Japanese BCs and because from here can see mountain
C1 at 4950m at top of a pyramid
C2 at 5800m just above West Col on West Ridge
C3 at 6500m at West Ridge shoulder.

5th to 16th Oct heavy snow. 5 Oct C2 pitched but no one slept there. All in BC during this period with heavys snow breaking tents. Up again 18th Oct and actually slept in C2 for first time on 20th Oct. 1st summit success on 22nd Oct at 1:00 via West Ridge. C1 to 2 greatest difficulties: 1st 300m rock wall then up to 55-degree snow and ice couloir. Fixed 1600m rope from C1 to C2. Along W Ridge 400m of 45 degrees and then 200m of knife-edge to C3. Immediately above C3 easy until last 200m step of 45 degrees below summit. 22nd Oct team returned to C3 that night in good but windy weather. 23rd to BC. 21st Bros Busquet and Angeles Soler left C1 at 3 am, bivouacked at 6000m on SW Face, 22nd biv 6450m, 23rd bivouac in cave at 7000m at lesser summit. All 3 descended together to BC.

Wall starts at 45 degrees and most is 55 degrees in deep snow requiring tiring step-making; at 6700m blue ice only about 50m.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st traverse; new routes; 1st Spanish and French ascents

SPONSOR: First Greek Himalayan Expedition to Annapurna South
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to fatal avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Annapurna Sanctuary, NE of Himalchuli and under it
C1 at 4850m on a ridge where this small ridge joins East Face
C2 at 5400m on East Face where face becomes SE Face (on rock)
C3 at 6400m on face in middle of two couloir
High point on face.

After C2, 11 days of continious snow and had lost considerable C3 and C4 equipment in avalanche on 25 Sept so progress badly delayed. Gianakoulis and Tsilogiorgis left expedition before C3 established (Tsilogiorgis regarding his job). 22 Oct avalanche hit at 11:45 am: Bountolas and German hit first, then Lambris who was cooking at C3, Tsatsaragos sleeping in C3 and Tsoukias in sun at C3. No avalanche had never came down this section before. C3 completely destroyed.

Gianakoulis fell in glacier and injured toes; left expedition about 17 Oct; Dimitris badly injured in fall approach march on 17 Sept. Bountolas and Tsatsaragos killed by avalanche of 22 Oct; Tsoukias taken 200m uninjured while Bountolas, Lambris and Tsatsaragos and German taken 800m over rocks; badly injured by survived 1st avalanche but killed by 2nd one. Lambris moved by 2nd avalanche 4-5m and has broken knee from 1st avalanche.

West German 1 day behind Greeks on same route by agreement.


Kunga Sherpa - 22 Sep 85

Kunga went on rescue flight yesterday for member of Greek Annapurna South expedition, Sotarikis, who fell down 30m rock wall on approach to BC on 17 Sept; apparently injured spinal column: cannot move.

Expedition made BC on 19 Sept and C1 at 5000m 21 Sept.
ACCIDENTS: 1 member fell in glacier 7 injured toes; 1 member badly injured in fall on approach march; 2 members killed by avalanches, and 1 member had broken knee

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7450m due to disappearance of summit party
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  near Barun Pokhari
ABC at west side Chago Glacier
C3  under Makalu La
C4  possibly made by Demolombe and Margaine at Makalu La after others left them.

1st summit bid on 1st Nov by four members and two reached Makalu La, other two 100m lower. Turned back because late in the afternoon snow bad quality and 180 km wind and route now 50-55 degrees steep. All four returned to C3 and tent broken by wind icefall during night. 

2nd Nov two members again tried for top while other three to ABC (two climbers never seen again). Other members spent 2 days at ABC, and 2 days at low BC, then 8th Nov to BC and left BC on 9th Nov leaving cooks and porters but no French members. Demolombe and Margaine "very determined" to reach summit, may have made several attempts; left BC to meet four trekking members at Lukla.

Jeanvoine and Moutel came to KTM 15 Nov by helicopter, Baillet comes today by scheduled flight from Tumlingtar; Germain ex-Tumlingtar on 18 or 19 Nov. Trekkers have not returned to France.

Moutel and Jeanvoine wait at least several days in Kathmandu for others return and flights to France; may move from Tushita to another hotel if decide to wait very long.


Ashok Basnet, Great Himalayan Adventures Trekking - 26 Nov 85

Two members have a little frostbite in toes: Dominique and Christian Baillet. Came by helicopter which attempted search for missing men but helicopter could not go above 7000m; saw nothing. 

No more searches, no more hope for 2 missing men.
Dr. Moutel and frostbitten men have gone home.
BC staff have now returned to KTM as have other 4 climbers.


Messner - 13 Feb 86

Messner and Kammerlander found two bodies, one near the Makalu La and the other below it, during their own attempt on Makalu earlier this month. The one near the col was lying down but without backpack, down parka or gloves; one body remains where found, the other put into a crevasse.

Messner believes they are the two men missing on Makalu II in 1985 autumn French team.


Reinhold Messner - 14 Feb 86

I have a feeling they did reach summit before they died. it looked as though Demolambe died of exhaustion and freezing near Makalu La, the other man tried to make it down alone and failed.

Messner now knows the body near the col is Demolambe after having a telephone conversation with someone close to him and having described his clothing, etc.
ACCIDENTS: Demolombe and Margaine disappeared (bodies found later by Messner and Kammerlander early 1986)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 6 hours porters trek beyond Monjo, west-southwst of mountain
C1  at West Ridge to point 6346m 
C2  on this very long West Ridge
Biv on ridge.

Batard, Lhakpa and Pemba to Pt 6346m on 26th Oct and returned to C2. Before that had long period of constant heavy snowfall. 27th Oct 2 members tried to reach the peak but stopped between Pt 6346m and main because too difficult ridge (very sharp snow ridge). 

29th Oct 2 members up from BC to NW Ridge of main peak direct. Bivouac at 6250m on NW Ridge halfway to Pt 6346m and on 30th Oct at 5 am left bivouac and reached main summit at 12 pm and returned to biv that night, to BC 31 Oct.

No more summit attempts because others tired.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to bad weather (snow followed by wind)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  on glacier, northeast of mountain
ABC at East Spur
C1  on subsidiary ridge
C2  near North Ridge.

5-25 Oct sitting in BC or trying to break trail and stashing caches of gear (one of which was lost). Night of 28th tent blew apart and destroyed by fierce winds. 7:00 am 29th descended, found ABC tent also ruined. Spirig camped between ABC and BC at one of caches while Allan and Teare went to BC. Now winds very strong. No real technical difficulties. Never tried N Face as planned because of avalanching.

Woolums very ill and never reached BC, left expedition 3rd or 4th Oct. Teare developing altitude sickness at C2.
ACCIDENTS: Woolums very ill and never reached BC, left expedition 3rd or 4th Oct; Teare developing altitude sickness at C2

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at usual site
C2B at below Dutch rib
High point at top of rib.

Bad weather began 10 Sept when all down in BC. Heavy snowfall began then. Started up again 19 Sept and made new C2 29 Sept to avoid avalanches danger. Then concentrated on making route up Dutch Rib and 3 Oct reached its top. Then again heavy snowfall brought avalanching which carried away equipment beside rib above C2B. 5-13 Oct very bad snowfall but all down in BC where little food: food in C1 but cannot go up to it so all team leave BC for Lete 14 Oct. In Lete to 19 Oct and back to BC on 20 Oct only to bring down equipment. Cleared C1, which in 2m deep snow, on 21 and 22 Oct and salvaged same items (tents broken).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to fatal avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 3800m at Khyumnu Khola at base of glacier south of Annapurna South
2nd BC at 4200m at Greek's BC in Annapurna Sanctuary
1st biv at Greek's C1
2nd biv at Greek's C2.

Want to climb as high as possible, preferably no fixed camps & little fixed rope. Technical problems: difficult to get to ridge if very sharp. Ridge will be difficult and steep ice section is at about 6900m. 3 members at BC did no climbing.

Team scouted Central Spur of S Face, but too avalanche prone. Then attempted Greek route. Fatal avalanche terminated effort.

Had three weeks of bad weather after arrival at 1st BC except 2-1/2 days of days of sun. Went to peak of about 5500m to see S Face to look for route on 4 Oct (the 1st peak of SW Ridge) and decided to try central spur of S Face but weather closed in for 1-2 weeks and then had 2 weeks time left. S Face seemed too dangerous from avalanching and decided to go into Annapurna Sanctuary and climb from there, taking very little gear with them. On 20 Oct in alpine-style climb Fichter, Kuerschner, Storz and Wohlschlager went to Greeks C1, 21 Oct to Greeks C2 and 22 Oct to Greeks C3 (climbed mostly at night) and planned to go top 23 Oct. Only Wohlschlager went above C3 on 22nd and was killed by avalanche which all 4 Germans were caught in. Slept night of 22/23 Oct at BC because all gear lost in avalanche.

Uwe Bauer stomach trouble: Wagenhals carried by slab avalanche started by him or by Bountolas of Greek team and buried by the avalanche; body found but probably swept away by more avalanching.
ACCIDENTS: Bauer got stomach trouble; Wagenhals got bronchitis; Wohlschlager killed by slab avalanche (body found, but swept away by more avalanching)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to fatal accident
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near ruins of Meta village
C1 below ridge
C2 on flat part on ridge
High point on SW Ridge.

17-19th bad weather. On 20th made a low C1. On 21st fixed ropes trying to reach C2 and on 22nd again made low C2 with 3 tents after going to 6000m. 23rd 6:00 am accident. Every one devoted to bringing Arenz down and then no heart to climb again. Cleared camps on 25th Oct.

Bad weather = rainfall up to 4900m and above snowfall depositing very slowly snow preventing putting camps as high as wished. Too  warm; snow didn't freeze properly.
ACCIDENTS: Oct 23 Arenz fell 600m on snow slope, leader reached him at 7:00 am still alive but back of head injured, got him to BC at 8:00 pm still alive but died next day after (never regained consciousness)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual site, near US BC on SE Ridge
C1 at beginning of South Ridge
C2 at top of Yellow Tower.

All down to BC and Namche on 14 Oct to 19 Oct because of snow storms. 21st Oct back to BC. C1 and C2 tents destroyed and had to take 3 days to restore camps. 25 Oct fixed rope to 6300m (at usual C3 site but no C3 made by this expedition). 26th Oct tried for top and reached 6700m. 27th Oct to BC because of strong wind and cold (6700m reached by Marshall and De Camp). Moro and others left BC 28 Oct but 9 others still hoping for summit.

On 4 Nov Marshall alone from Pangboche to C2 on 3rd and to top on 4th (he ran up to C2) - "strong man" - 1 Canadian.
ACCIDENTS: None except Levegue extremely sunburned face and skin came off "like a smoke"

TERMNOTE: Never reached BC due to deep snow on approach to Baruntse
ROUTEMEMO:
Never reached BC. Lost 5 days in KTM waiting for flight, walked to Namche ex-Jiri, thus lost 11 days. Vincent tried to climb North Face of Amphu Laptsa with Sherpas but too deep snow, impossible to climb with porters. Went to Island Peak and succeeded there, climbed Kalapattar, success on Parchamo. Took Vincent's party 2 days to do 5 hours climb from Sukund at base of the pass to BC of the pass - too dangerous snow conditions.

Sharp ridge last 100m should be only techinical problem, but may have problem if snow 2m deep, danger of avalanching. Had permission but never reached base camp.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due C2 destroyed by avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near Spaniard's C1
C1 on plateau of snow near Naike Col before face
C2 on snow face (NE Face)
High point at NE Face (C3 site).

3 weeks to make C2 after C1 because "everyday snowing." 24th Oct very bad wind, so no successful carry to C3 site this day. 25th Oct rest day, good weather; avalanche struck C2 5:40 pm and 7 who survived had to bivouac. Early am 26th Oct, rescuers up from C1 and all members went down to C1 and BC, next day all at BC. Had planned summit attack for 28th Oct, but avalanche destroyed supplies and some victims battered, so climb finished and no one went again to C3 site. Some skiing up and down mountain side but "many places cannot ski."

Oct 25 avalanche hit C2 and carried 1 member into crevasse, 4 Japanese and 3 Sherpas also hit (Japanese tent slipped 100m and they only buried; Sherpas tent also slipped and Nima Norbu in sleeping bag could not get out and was killed).

SPONSOR: Joint A.M.A.-Royal Nepal Army Kirat Chuli Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6735m on Nepal Peak due to strong wind, heavy snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5400m edge of glacier north of Cross Peak
C2 at 6400m in crevasse under big seracs under S Ridge of Nepal Peak
Highpoint at 6735m at South Ridge of Nepal Peak.

Expedition attempted to reach Kirat Chuli (Tent Peak) via Nepal Peak along the very long South Ridge of Nepal Peak and thence Kirat Chuli's low long South Ridge. The Nepal Peak ridge was a steep slope with very big cornices; its problems and many days of snowfall and snow slides, one of which took away their route, forced a halt after having reached a high point of 6735m on the ridge before Nepal Peak's summit. Team never actually set foot on Kirat Chuli.

Snow above C1 was thigh-deep, unconsolidated powder snow on a 60-degree head wall. Then got onto South Ridge of Nepal Peak first on Nepalese side, then on Sikkimese side, 45-degree slope with very big cornices. First storm started 7 Oct by which time they had put in most of route to C2 and couldn't move till 13 Oct. 1st attempt to C2 on 9th but stopped by wind and thick spendrift. Again on 11th tried and retreated. More bad weather 12th, but 14th to C2 and 15th on up ridge, which again was vertical sugar, exposed to very cold wind for their ascent, fixing rope as they want. Had to climb down from high point of 22,100 ft but long distance from summit. Expected go to summit next day. 16th snowing heavily and strong wind. 17th tents destroyed and had to move down to BC. On 18th BC evacuated and down to Pangpema and those in C2 to abandoned C1 bringing own tents and digging under 3 ft of snow to find fixed ropes. 150m of snow slab went down but ropes fixed to ice underneath. Another slide took out route and covered one man. Still snowing, C2 doubtless destroyed, route gone and had little time left. 32 days on mountain, 17 actually climbing.

Successfully completed water supply project and plant collection plus good experience. 

North ridge of Kiratchuli very difficult climb for strong climbers.


British Kirat Chuli:

Expedition's attempts to climb Kirat Chuli and Nepal Peak now abandoned. Expedition defeated by extremely bad weather, deep snow and avalanche conditions high on mountain.

Williams/Kefford/Spencer reached 22,100 ft on South Ridge of Nepal Peak on 15 Oct before withdrawing and cold.

16th Oct plan to occupy C3 below Nepal Peak abandoned due combined bad weather and thick snow.

16-17th high winds and deep snow destroyed 3 tents and C1 (19,200 ft) and forced abandonment.


Letter from Royal Force Mountaineering Association - Jan 1986

AMA Expedition to Nepal 1985 by Chris Cordery. Chris Cordery represented RAFMA on last year's AMA expedition to Nepal. The expedition lasted for nearly 3 months and amongst its several items it included attempts on Nepal Peak and Kirat Chuli. These 2 mountains are satellites of Kangchenjunga and are linked by a mile long, knife-edged ridge. They had only been climbed once before, from the Sikkim side. The walk-in took 3 weeks before we were ready to mount our assaults on the mountain. Ideas of climbing a new route via the North Col were quickly quashed when a recce showed the vast distance and desperately difficult glacier to be beyond the ability of our team. We settled for the South Col route which had previously been climbed in 1939. The weather remained fine throughout the last 2 weeks of September and we made good progress. We established ABC on the glacier beneath Nepal Peak and we put C1, at 19,500 ft, in a snow basin just below a ridge leading to the summit. The route to C2 proved to be difficult, long and quite prone to avalanches, but after sitting out several days of bad weather we established 6 climbers at 21,500 ft. The news of 5 Indians dying on Everest only 50 miles away did nothing positive for our morale but our lead climbers continued to press on. They got to within 600 ft of the top of Nepal Peak before being driven back to C2 by deep snow and high winds. The next days consisted of a blizzard and winds of 100 mph which demolished several tents or buried them in snow. The route from C2 to C1 had become seriously avalanche-prone and retreats were made in desperate conditions to the relative safety of our 2 BCs. The expedition was very lucky indeed to get everyone back alive. Avalanches had ripped out our fixed ropes and there was not enough time to rebuild our route so it was decided to end our expedition. We were very disappointed but we were all still alive. On our return to KTM we heard that the Himalayas were having their worst post-monsoon weather for 18 years and that a vast majority of mountaineering expeditions had been abandoned - one expedition did not even get to its base camp before being defeated by deep snow.
ACCIDENTS: One Nepali, Yagya Bahadur, got sick on day 2 of walk-in and never reached BC

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5400m on ridge west side of south end of Chago Glacier
C1 at 5800m middle moraine of Chago Glacier
C3 at 7400m at Makalu La.

All camps at same sites at Italian early Oct in BC to rest for several days and then up. 9th Oct so bad weather no progress possible and all in C1 and C2. 10th Oct first party went to C3 in heavy snowstorm. 11 Oct good weather till 9:15 am, then snow fall again but went on to top and reached it 11:00 am. 13th Oct clear, beautiful day and all camps cleared and all in BC that evening. 14th Oct left BC and reached KTM 22nd Oct. Between C2 and C3 always deep snow but not difficult route.

Two members (Frank Merjenberg and Walter Roos) left expedition on the return trek and attempted to cross over into Khumbu via Sherpani Col, West Col and Amphu Laptsa. An unusually severe storm on Oct 16 trapped them just below Sherpani Col. They suffocated to death when their tents collapsed under the weight of 3 meters of new snow.

2 members failed to return from BC to KTM; it is assumed they perished in the deep snow of West Col-Sherpani Col region.

Walter Roos and Frank Merjenberg:

17-19 Oct trekking via Sherpani Col and West Col. Took with them no Sherpas, 3 days food only. Never turned up and now must presumed lost. Were due in KTM 4 weeks ago.


Hermann Tollemaar - 18 Nov 1985

All hope of finding them has been abandoned.


Naar - 6 May 1986

2 missing climbers were found recently dead in their tent on Sherpani Col. Probably died of suffocation under heavy snowfall.

Their bodies were found by a trekking party lead by Richard Salisbury in the following May 1986. The bodies were buried in a collapsed tent on the Barun side of Sherpani Col at about 5500m.
ACCIDENTS: 2 members failed to return from BC to Kathmandu (they perished in major snowstorm below Sherpani Col; bodies found by trekking group May 1986)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5200m at Dza camp
C1 same as Spanish autumn 1984 C1
C2 near point 6446m
C3 on West Face (center of face below).

Route not so difficult, but very long distances between BC to C1 and C1 to C2. Had problem on big summit snow plateau where snow had light crust on top of it: took 1-1/2 hours on plateau itself to reach summit (11 hours from C3 to top).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to Lee's sickness, all very exhausted
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on border northwest of point 5415m on Schneider map.

Route not difficult but more themselves out carrying loads. Snowstorms: 3 days snow, 1 day not. Delayed climb from BC to C1 and from C1 to C2.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5030m due to the death of climbing members
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 2 km down from North Face (same as in 1984)
ABC on a buttress of NE Ridge in a gully
High point at ABC.

Probably the 3 climbers got no higher than 5030m since weather again very bad on 16th Oct with heavy snowfall and occasional strong wind gusts. Urkien Sherpa met Newell, Spake and Gyalzen Sherpa on 15th below ABC site. Newell sent back with him a note to Leung saying they expected to reach ABC site in 1 or 2 days. All were well. They made bivouacs between BC and ABC as they moved up, probably reached ABC on 16th Oct and could go no higher because of snow fall.

Spake was supposed to be load and message carrier only.

Atkinson left team well before caravan reached BC; claimed his girl friend's bad knee prevented her from trekking.


Report of Mary E. Leung - 30 Oct 85

Oct 18 the three members of Langtang Lirung climbing party (Newell, Spake and Gyalzen) decided to come back to BC due to bad weather. They had been on the mountain since Oct 13. On 16 the weather again turned bad, continuing until Oct 20.

The morning they decided to come down it was also raining. The route from which they were descending was one we had not observed them climbing on before.

The members at BC including cook, kitchen boy, mailrunner, porter and sirdar Urkien Norbu saw three objects carried down by an avalanche. At the time of the avalanche they were at an altitude of approx 16,000 ft. They fell to an altitude of about 12,385 ft.

Immediately after the avalanche we went to the site. The sirdar and a few others saw a jacket sleeve, most probably of Elliot or Gyalzen, an ice axe and one mattress pad. We weren't able to approach them to offer assistance because of constant avalanching. After about 45 minutes we left the site to go back to BC. The rest of that day we were unable to go back because of constant eminent avalanching due to the falling rain and snow. The following day Oct 19, several BC members tried to go back to the site twice, but were unable to do anything because of the danger of more avalanching and a lack of digging implements. Snow and fog were quite heavy that day.

Oct 20 was a sunny clear day. We finished same digging tools out of wood and in the afternoon the BC members tried to dig where they had seen the items before but were unsuccessful. The snow was too deep after two days and nights of snowfall and avalanching.

On Oct 21 we departed BC to return to KTM. We were unable to recover any bodies or equipmment on the mountain since none of the BC members were equipped for high altitude climbing. Nor were we able to determine if they were abandoning the expedition or merely coming down to BC to wait for good weather.
ACCIDENTS: Fatal accident of two members and 1 Sherpa

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6250m due to daily snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southwest from Samagaon 3 km away (same as Austrian 1985 spring)
C1 on East Ridge
C2 on East Ridge
C3 on East Ridge.

After 4th Oct many days much snow. C3 covered by 2 meters snow. 8th Oct when climbers returned there to try going to C4 site. Took them 4 days including 1 bivouac to descend to BC. Then route making pair set off from BC on 16th Oct for 20-21 Oct summit bid by another pair. They reached C1 on 16th but snowfall 17-20 Oct and took 4 hours to excavate C2 on 17th Oct. Leader descended on 19th Oct. Impossible to reach summit and called route making party down to BC where they arrived 20th Oct. Left BC 22nd Oct. 

"Want to try again next spring."
ACCIDENTS: Sept 26 one Sherpa knee injured in snowslide in steep couloir halfway from BC to C1 (sent to Kathmandu hospital)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to strong wind, snow, lack of food
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Tsaurabong Glacier
C1 at upper part of Glacier
C2 on South Ridge of Snow Peak
C3 on East Ridge of Dhaulagiri II.

If weather fine, climb only "little difficult" but with heavy constant snowfall climb was difficult and dangerous. Daily avalanches near route, but luckily no one hit ("we very lucky").

SPONSOR: Nagasaki Worker's Alpine Fed Expedition 1985 to Langshisa Ri
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to snow conditions, supply situation
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at SSW of Main peak
C1 on ridge southeast of West Peak
C2 at snow field
C3 on SW Ridge
High point at 6100m on SW Ridge.

After C2 established, tried to reach SW Ridge but too much of snowfall and retreated from this route which was one actually used on 16th Oct. Reached ridge on 15th at 5940m, but from there up ridge is knifed and "no walking" so next day reached ridge higher up and there put C3. 16th Oct to 18th Oct, much new snowfall and "no moving" (stayed in C3). 19th Oct good weather but snow "bad" and food and fuel finished and time limit (Oct 20). 19th Oct went up ridge towards top "snow sliding" so attempt abandoned. Also sirdar injured. 3rd to 16th Oct also much snowfall during route making period burying new fixed ropes. Left BC 22 Oct.
ACCIDENTS: Sirdar Kirki injured knee Oct 19 in snow slide and could no longer climb (2 members helped him down, now OK); no other casualties

SPONSOR: Nepal-Zoki Joint Expedition to Dorje Lhakpa
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Langshisa Glacier
C1 at col between Dorje Lhakpa and Buddha Peak
C2 on West Ridge
C3 on West Ridge.

C1 1st occupied 14 Sept but next day 2 meters snow broke tents and 15 Sept evacuated camp; had to build new C1 and this done on 21 Sept when next occupied. Snow and blue ice all the way way, no rock at all, ice 60-70 degrees from C3 upwards.

Leader did not go above C3 because he had to go to village with sick Nepali members and was not fully acclimatized in early Oct.
ACCIDENTS: One Japanese member slight frostbite; one Nepali member chronic illness of several months

SPONSOR: Northern New Mexico 1985 Himalchuli W Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 4875m due to bad weather and time limitations
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Japanese BC of 1981
C1 at shoulder below icefall coming off SW Ridge.

7 Oct 4 sets off from C1 to base of rock climb, avoiding danger of icefall but involving 1500 ft of rock climbing. Visability became zero in clouds and became disoriented. At 16,000 ft cached equipment and returned to C1. That night snowing and spent next 5 nights at C1 hoping for better weather. Now would need 14 days to climb mountain, but had 9 days time left. Took 3 days to evacuate C1 and no one could reach cache. Was another week of bad weather (deep snow). Had gambled weather would permit climb but it didn't; avalanches off mountain every 15 minutes.

TERMNOTE: Climbers disappeared
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at glacier north of Hindung, south of Ganesh IV
ABC 
C1  before South Face
C2  on South Face (1 Nov had pitched tent at 6100m and next day moved it higher)
Biv on South Face.

3 climbers returned to BC 2 Nov after having pitched C1 at 6300m. They said after night avalanches, snow very deep and did not know difficulties in route above C2, but planned to climb steep section above C2 to col just east of summit and thence, alond East Ridge to top. Route above C1 was difficult because of big seracs and always steep; had fixed 2 ropes in this section between C1 and C2 and when they descended on 2 Nov, one rope had been taken away by avalanche. 5th noon, 3 climbers started up again and could be seen very short time because of fog. They planned to go to ABC, 6 Nov to C1, 7th Nov to C2 and 8th Nov to top, perhaps with bivouac in descent - could not be seen again.

10 Nov saw a trace of them and could see every day there after until left BC 19 Nov. 2 Sherpas from KTM went up to search reached C2 site on 23 Nov, but found no camps ABC to C2. Found a tent from C1 at 6700m. Searchers were nearly hit by avalanche and think camps and climbers taken by avalanche. Helicopter search of 20 Nov saw no traces.

Did not follow originally planned because more difficult, very steep, required more rope to be fixed than they had with them.


Ang Tshering (Asian Tkg) - 28 Nov 85

2 Sherpas climbed to 6700m on 21 and 22nd Nov, found tent, gas stove and food but no bodies.

Dr Bancer, LO and Sherpas arrived KTM this morning by taxi from Trisuli; no trace of 3 climbers.


Ang Tshering (Asian Tkg) - 22 Nov 85

Sirdar went up to ABC site but no tent there to be seen. Probably buried under snow. Mountain not visable from BC until 10 Nov because of clouds. On 10 Nov no tents visable at any campsites.

20 Nov helicopter search by LO and a Sherpa: took 4 turns around mountain but saw no sign of tents, people, anything. BC has been evacuated. 


Asian Tkg - 17 Nov 85

Members should have returned to BC 11 Nov. LO left BC 14 Nov to report they had not returned. 3 strong Sherpas leave KTM early tomorrow for search and perhaps helicopter will go later if Polish embassy say so. Doctor still at BC with sirdar.
ACCIDENTS: Camps and climbers swept away by avalanche; helicopter search on Nov 20 saw no trace

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  north of Merra Pokhari
ABC 2 hours from foot of SW Ridge
C1  on SW Ridge (did not use this camp later)
Biv 1 on SW Face above SW Ridge past C1, after 1st serac barrier
Biv 2 after 2nd serac barrier on SW Face.

6th Oct all down to BC with heavy snowfall. Twice tried to go to ABC but not possible in deep snow and avalanching. 16 Oct did reach ABC but back to BC with more bad weather. Decided to climb alpine-style. 26 Oct again to ABC and put new tent there replacing broken tent (crushed by snow). Could not see C1. 

29 Oct up alpine-style in one team of Panejko, Brys and Klincewicz and reached 5850m. 30 Oct big wind, tent poles being carried were lost and returned to Biv 1. Brys down on 30th and Jakubowski replaced him. 31 Oct crossed 2nd serac barrier in very hard ice climbing. 1 Nov Panejko fingers freezing so did not get to top; other 2 returned to biv at 2:30 pm [after summiting]. 

No more summit attempts because winter breaking, strong winds.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Polish attempt and ascent, new route

ROUTEMEMO:
BC in Annapurna Sanctuary
C1 on glacier west of Gabelhorn 
C2 on snow ridge
C3 on snow ridge
C4 on East Ridge in middle of Col between Gangapurna and Annapurna III.

1st C3 lost in deep snow (at least 3 meters) of early mid-Oct snowstorms and had to be replaced with new camp about 15m to one side of old site. No technical problems, just snow. Fixed 1000m rope but only 500m on rock just before C1 and between C1 and C2.

4 men got struck for 3 nights in C3 because heavy snowfall and 3 more nights in C2 again heavy snow.

Zobniow reached 7000m and returned to C4 before top: bad altitude sickness (was with 3rd summit party) and had to be belayed by others to get down mountain. There was avalanching but no one hit.

Mikokaj and Szpot left expedition 20 Oct to go back to work.
ACCIDENTS: 1 member reached 7000m and returned to C4 before top (bad alitiude sickness, was with 3rd summit party); there was avalanching but no one hit

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5400m on ridge on west side of Chago Glacier south of pt 6170m
C1 at 5850m on moraine stone just east of "h" in Chago Glacier on Schneider map
C2 at 6800m east of (below) Makalu La
C3 at 7400m on Makalu Col 
C4 at 7900m just east of NW Ridge.

Route from C1 to C2 kept to east of moraine south of Chago. Sept 9 descended to BC and then much snowfall. On Sept 14 tried to go from C2 to col but got halfway only and then again snowfall and again to BC for 1 week. Sept 22 C3 established. 24 Sept Giambisi and San Sebastian to C3. Then all down to BC because deep fresh snow. Finally up again Sept 28 by all 5 climbers. Slept C2 that night, in C3 on Sept 29, C4 on Sept 30 and Oct 10. Left C4 for top 6:30 am and on summit 6:00 pm. Returned to C4 11:00 pm in new deep snow. Oct 2 at C2 and Oct 3 BC. Left BC Oct 5 and arrived KTM Oct 12.
ACCIDENTS: Tamayo ill at BC in early Sept, left after 2 days and never took part in climb; most climbers have some frostbite including Man Bahadur Tamang but not disastrous

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5900m due to unstable rock, lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Bung Khola on trail east of Ghasa south of Pt 5595m on Around Annapurna map
ABC just under South Face
C1  on South Face
High point at face (2 pitches before C2 site).

ABC on 29th Sept only. Bad snow and rain delayed its establishment. Many snow avalanches covered ABC and buried camps and supplies, 2 meters deep and once broke tent. C1 on 18th Oct: again heavy snowfall. Above C1 100m vertical unsound rock which was very dangerous but possible to fix rope. Fixed total of 1000m rope.

Plenty of rocks fell, but all wore helmets.
ACCIDENTS: None; plenty of rock fall but all wore helmets

APPROACH: Seti Khola->E side of S Ridge of Annapurna III
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5000m due to heavy snow and difficulty of approach to BC
ROUTEMEMO:
East Ridge extremely long; 1000m icefall from 21,000 ft leads to this ice ridge. SE Pillar is one of hardest climbs in Himalaya: steep rock climbing but line.

Total 10 members out of which 5 are trekkers only.


Ewen Todd - 16 Oct 85

Never got to base camp. Went up Seti and then NW to east of Mardi Himal to a Col at about 5000m on 5th Oct. Then started snowing so much could not go on with sirdar and cook because now technical climbing involved. Camped there to see how weather developed.

But now porters had deserted (on 27th Sept) and LO had turned back. Scots had been ferrying loads themselves.

Were exhausted from carrying loads and feared snow conditions on mountain impossible. Dumped some gear and much food at col and left col on 7th Sept.

With continuing snowfall, could have gotten trapped in BC area.

Toyed with idea of northern approach but did not make actual request for permission because of lack of time and funds and still snowing.

Todd left team about 24 Sept because of miserable conditions apparently.


Cherry - 30 Sept 85

Cummings of Annapurna III returned to KTM 27 Sept before team reached BC. Said expedition would not come off - did not have enough money and not capable of climb.

Porters report Scots buying and smoking hash.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to ice cold winds and bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
BC east of glacier east of mountain
C1 at 5900m at plateau at bottom of face.

May put supply cache on NE Ridge, may go on ridge in acclimatization. Snow ridge on face will probably be route and this is very steep ice from 6200m to 7200m. Will join NE Ridge at 7500m.

2.8m deep snow at BC. Did not go to left of 1980 route because icefall is there. Only fixed rope was 200m very low on mountain. Most of climbing began midnight and climbed all night. 1st days in BC raining all the time and when climbing began were only 4 men (Beg and Brisar decided not to). At first was hard rock climbing, then heavy long snowfall and were on deep avalanching snow on same feature. After C1 established again much snow and 16 Oct started up to plateau. 24 Oct up from C1 for 1st time: to 7000m via normal route to acclimatize. 26 started up face and made biv at 7000m and 27 Oct to 7600m to ridge and [planned to] biv over on ridge but wind so strong had to descend at 3:00 am. Next 5 days terrible winds.

Fierce cold winds following many days of new snow and planned only 1 month on mountain. Now food exhausted went to Kalapani after 27 Oct but weather still bad and gave up).

Belak and Kregar got slight frostbite. "We are lucky men:" very big avalanche 26 Oct ice block just brushed one man. Another time huge serac fell 10 minutes after men crossed beneath. Many snow avalanches: climbed on small ridges as much as possible rather than couloirs for safety.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to deep snow (2 weeks of snow)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 4900m at Yalung Glacier (used only by Porters after ABC pitched)
ABC at 5300m at Yalung Glacier
C1  at 6200m at beginning of face on spur to left of icefall
High point at C1 site.

C1 never slept in. All was ready there by 12 Oct as highest fixed camp from which to go to summit in 4 days with tent on Great Shelf but weather turned bad with 3 meters snowfall. Spent days shovelling snow at ABC, sent porters who had stayed at BC for kerosene but porters never returned, so late and gave up attempt, but cleared C1 20 Oct in 2-1/2 to 3-meter deep snow.

Had planned to climb Kangchenjunga South Summit with American Dee Jackson, but at last minute Jackson unable to come, so changed to less difficult objective Central summit.


Kangchenjunga Central:

Gopal [Ganesh] Gurung claims he reached Everest summit on 1984 Dutch expedition and was only climber to do so on this team.

Juan charged with having climbed Island Peak, Parchamo and Cho Oyu in aut 1984 without permits.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5600m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at same as theirs in 1984 (below Messner's this spring)
Deposit just below face
High point at bottom of face.

Maximum 3 bivouacs up, one on way down ridge to NW Face. Route same as their 1984 attempt. Last time caught in storm and frostbite. This time will take more food so can stay longer and have special pills to dilate blood vessels in feet and hands to reduce threat of frostbite. Route is to left of Messner's successful 1985 spring route.

25th Oct 3:00 am started up face from deposit. Climbed 500m then Troillet not feeling well and wind blown snow unstable (could avalanche) and then turned back to BC. Too dangerous for only 2 men on this big face. No wind but every afternoon snow and sometimes had. Actually on mountain only few hours. Spent 20 days in a row BC waiting for improved weather.

Spent almost entire month at BC waiting for snow to stabilize. New snow almost every day. Got only to 5600m at foot of NW Face.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5400m due to constant snowfall and lack of manpower
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  south of French Pass
ABC along icefall south of BC (by Habeler, Dacher and Nima Tenzing)
High point at beside icefall.

The three men stayed in ABC two nights, then down to BC and visit to Czechoslovak BC. After returning to their own BC, Habeler packed up and left expedition (on 21st Sept, Nima says; on 23rd Habeler said on 27 Sept 85) while Dacher and Nima returned to ABC. 

Dacher and Nima tried to reach NE Col but in 4 hours climbing made little progress because difficult to cross icefall and much snowfall and returned to BC. They had no fixed ropes and plan had been for Habeler and Dacher to climb alone, leaving Nima at BC.


27 Sept 85

Put ABC at foot of French Pass, and was looking for way through glacier; made ABC 17 Sept.

Habeler left 4 days ago. No higher camp possible in so much snowfall. Dacher and Nima Sherpa will go to NE Col and then Dacher tries solo ascent. Has unlimited time.

Every day lot of snow. Have never seen avalanches like these on Dhaulagiri; every 2-3 hours
that mountain loses its snow.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6750m due to snow
ROUTEMEMO:
BC northwest end of Tilicho Lake
C1 at top of NW Ridge.

27 Sept porters left baggage at Tilicho Lake south end, one day before BC because deep snow so took expedition to ferry loads to BC seven days. Then 6 Oct began to snow heavily again and stopped only on 21 Oct. 

22 Oct tried to make fast push to top by Beltran, Granizo Maldonado, Roca Egea and Tenzing from BC in alpine-style, but too deep snow and turned back at 6000m. 

25 Oct a huge black bird pushed gas and food down mountain and team in C4 (where these supplies were) were unable to have hot drink. Despite this loss, they attempted summit but now very cold and wind very strong. 

Now expedition unable to mount new summit bid: no more time and with cold and wind, snow blown away leaving very difficult hard ice. Summer weather to winter weather (Tilicho Lake green grass on arrival: 4 days alter 1-1/2 m snow).

9th Oct big avalanche off NW Face came near BC, hurt no one but wind and powder snow damaged BC. Very slight frostbite in Tenzing's fingers 26 Oct.
ACCIDENTS: Very slight frostbite in Tenzing's finger

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to snow conditions and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC 300m below spring 1985 Polish expedition
C1 on centrol ridge of North Face (left side of ridge)
C2 on this ridge or pillar below its top
   Polish spring 1985 C3 site, she thought (but spring expedition said 5600m)
High point at 6200m traverse to West Ridge.

Very deep snow made central ridge/pillar very different from spring 1985 as described by Polish expedition of that season not climbing but wading. Spring expedition fixed ropes 1 meter under snow. Turned back because of deep snow on 12 Nov. Had hoped to make alpine-style climb and move quickly but snow conditions made this impossible. Had many avalanches to left of their route and stones falling across route in its traverse towards West Ridge.
ACCIDENTS: Some illness but not related to altitude: 1 heart problem, 1 serious infection requiring operation at BC; nothing else

ROUTEMEMO:
BC east of ridge coming south from West Peak
C1 at east side of South Ridge = South Face
C2 at east side of South Ridge = South Face
C3 on SW Ridge
C4 at north side of West Ridge near its junction with SW Ridge and South Ridge.

After C3, returned to BC for "holiday" and then when went back up to C1 and C2 very bad weather (much snow and much wind), so had spend 5 days in C2. Got to C3 13th Oct. On top 16th Oct at 11:00 am in clear weather that morning until just below summit. On top white-out and descent in "big trouble." Okamoto and Takeda 2-day bivouac at 7500m while others on 16th descending had 3-day bivouac at 7300m in traverse from C4. All safely below BC 22nd Oct. BC to C3 rock and snow C3 to summit was 4 km snow plateau of deep snow which took much energy. Technically not difficult.
ACCIDENTS: Moti Lal bad frostbite and Takiguchi less frostbite during 3-day bivouac; Saito bad altitude sickness in C4

ROUTEMEMO:
1st BC just below border on Schneider map halfway between O & L of Rolwaling
2nd BC east of 1st BC, NNE of L
3rd BC north of point 6037m on Tseringma Glacier.

Most difficult between 3rd BC and C1: very steep rock. Above this sharp ridge of ice, snow and rock mixed. Ridge better than Roskelley route because not his route all ice face. Followed exactly same line as Ang Kami and Culbreth followed in 1984 spring. Had lot of snowfall and had to send to KTM twice for more food and gas, and even so were running out of food and fuel by mid-January, so no other summit bids. Also had 3 days wind and snow about 27 Dec and tents broken. 

16 January Jangbu went with summit pair to 150m below top, then turned back because boots letting in too much cold.
ACCIDENTS: Lee Hee-Bong sick 10 days; Seong slight frostbite one finger

ROUTE1: NE Face up; SW Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Sanjo (near Dingboche)
ABC at bottom of face.

1st climbed Island peak then carried to ABC and watched the NE Face (Chhukung Face). Started up on 30 Nov and completed ascent at 10:00 am on 7 Dec spent 45-60 minutes on top and descended normal route, reached New Zealanders C1 at 8:00 pm (had difficult time seeing it in very dark night). Difficult route: delicate climbing upper section had vertical parts, very steep rock with a little bit of ice on it, "insecure, no protection." No possibility of survival in descending face, where had no fixed ropes at all. Was very very cold but got up more quickly then, feared night. Most days climbed 6-7 hrs.

Route would be too dangerous in spring and autumn from falling ice, rock and perhaps seracs and from got stuck in snowfall with all snow from sailing through one chute at bottom of face.


The Northeast Face of Ama Dablam Expedition Report by Carlos Buhler

Ama Dablam is among the most striking peaks on earth; a sheer, glistening tooth reaching 22,349 ft above sea level. My first view of the mountain was in April 1980, as I struggled to the summit of nearby Baruntse. Of all the peaks I could see on the jagged Himalayan skyline. Ama Dablam stood out. Its modest size, by Himalayan standards, was more than compensated for by its matchless profile.

In Oct, 1984, Michael Kennedy agreed to join me on this two person adventure. Within his comprehensive slide collection, we came up with our first and only photograph of the face. It was a view from fives miles away and did not show the bottom third of the mountain. But with this photograph, and a tremendous spirit of adventure, we departed on Oct 24, 1985 for KTM, Nepal.

Accompanying us on the 120-mile approach were Michael's wife, Julie, my mother, Julie Dougherty, and my brother, Roman. With such a closely knit group, here could hardly have been a better way to prepare for the unknown.

Well looked after by our Sherpa staff, we arrived in BC on Nov 20th. Our first view of the face was one we will never forget. We were sure there was a possible route to the summit; the paramount question, however was whether the winter weather and snow conditions would allow for a safe ascent.

We acclimatized as fully as possible by ascending Kala Pattar with all the family members and Island Peak accompanied by Michael's wife, Julie, before wishing them a safe return journey to KTM. After two days of rest, we moved up to an advanced camp at 16,400 ft beneath the North Ridge of Ama Dablam.

Our exploration of the Northeast Face's lower gullies and slopes during the next two days convinced us that a route was, indeed, feasible. On Nov 30 we set off with seven days of food and fuel and bivouacked at a small cache we had left the day before, at the start of the steepening wall.

Over the next seven days we enjoyed only about for hours of sun each morning. The temperature dropped well below 0 degrees during the shaded afternoons, and we found ourselves straining to keep our body core temperatures high enough to climb.

The terrain was predominantly snow and ice, interspersed with short bands of thin, delicate ice cover steep snow ribs we followed in the center of the face. Good bivouacs were essential, allowing us to consume enough fluids and calories to ward off frostbite, high altitudes illness and general exhaustion.

At 10:30 am Dec 7, we reached the summit of Ama Dablam. Despite some scary winds early in the morning, it turned into a perfectly clear, calm day. We photographed the spectacular peaks surrounding us for 45 minutes, and then began our descent of the Southwest Ridge. Utilizing some fixed ropes that had been left in place during the fall season, as well as those of a New Zealand team attempting a winter ascent of that route, we reached 17,000 feet on the same day. The next morning, Ang Jangbu and his father, Norbu, met us with prayer scarves, food and walking shoes for the hike down to their home in the Sherpa village of Pangboche.

That night, sheltered in the caccoon of warm Sherpa household, exhaustion from the past week's mental and physical pressure was overshadowed by an immense inner feeling of satisfaction and accomplishment. Slowly, the realization of our dreams began to dawn on us. We had done it: we had explored a new route, in winter, to the summit of Ama Dablam.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due bad weather and then end of season with 1 week's extension
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4200m at Annapurna Sanctuary
C1 at 5400m at ice cave
C3 at 6850m at ice cave.

Planned to establish C4 at 7750m and then to middle summit and main summit. Weather was "awful" from 24th Dec to 2nd Jan. Heavy snowfall and again 25th Jan to 22nd Feb with also strong winds and low temperature as well; more than 2 meters snow covered all camps. Technically route not so difficult: usual climbing but snow was main problem even between C1 and C2 with 2m snow causing avalanche danger, where none normally exists.

No accidents resulting in injury or serious frostbite or illness. 1 member went to Pokhara rest before climb finished including one with lung problem from altitude and cold (he is now recovered and will return to climb in spring season).
ACCIDENTS: None resulting in injury or serious frostbite or illness

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near Kangchung - as far as yaks could go Dzasampa.

All in BC by 29 Nov and all 6 to Dzampa on 30th. On 1 Dec set off in 3 pairs taking different lines looking for best way up. Czechs got 1/2-day ahead of Burgess and Marshall while 2 Americans lost 2-3 days on wrong approach. Czech pair reached summit while Canadian and American pairs, who were slower moving up mountain, did not and had to abandon climb because of lack of food and race against time, fearing more new snowfall would trap them and prevent their getting out alive. Had very difficult time getting load-carrying yaks to low BC in Nov.

Marshall froze several fingers and one toe on 6 Dec and was developing altitude sickness that day. 1 American getting sick on 7 Dec, Becik very slight frostbite on nose.


Marshall - 20 Dec 85

2 Czechoslovaks - Becik and Stejskal:

1 Dec - biv on Gyabrag Glacier
2 & 3 Dec - biv at 6400m on Spanish 1984 route
4 Dec - biv at 7400m on Spanish route
5 Dec - to summit and returned to 7400m
6 Dec - biv in descent
7 Dec - ABC

Marshall:

1 Dec - biv on Gyabrag Glacier, just below on Schneider map
2 Dec - biv just below ridge near Spanish 1984 C2 at 6000-6100m
3 & 4 Dec - biv at 6800m on Spanish 1984 route
5 Dec - biv at 7400m above Spanish 1984 C4 (on their route)
6 Dec - very cold (-40 to -50 degrees in the morning) and both men had headaches,
        Marshall blurred vision, so instead of going for summit as planned, 
        they descended

Marshall got frostbitten fingers and toe on 6th Dec; they had taken only 5 days food with them and had none above ABC so abandoned climb especially in light of Marshall's frostbite.


Athans - 20 Dec 85

2 Americans - Athans and Ballenger

1 Dec - made carry towards North Face and returned to ABC
2 Dec - at ABC
3 Dec - biv on moraine at 5900-6000m north of point 6446 and of rocky area
4 Dec - climbed due east to about 6400m just below col of 6517m south
        of Palung Ri, then returned to bivouac site of 3 Dec.
5 Dec - biv in moraine of Gyabrag Glacier sout of U on Schneider map, at bottom
        and south of triangular rock almost east of "c" in Glacier's name.
6 Dec - biv at 6800m on Spanish 1984 route at same site as Canadian pair
        biv of 3 and 4 Dec
7 Dec - descended (attempted abandoned)
ACCIDENTS: Marshall froze several fingers and one toe on Dec 6 and was developing altitude sickness that day; 1 American getting sick on Dec 7; Becik very slight frostbite on nose

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7520m due to winds that destroyed four tents
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Barun Pokhari
ABC just north of Chago Barun Glacier junction
C1  on glacier's east fork
C2  again east on next branch of glacier
C3  below Makalu La and southeast of it
High point at NW Ridge.

4 tent poles broken by winds in several camps and BC camp tent picked up by wind. Route easy, constant strong winds. Babu and Nishimura descended directly to BC on Dec 24 and no more climbing. Left BC Dec 26, but heavy snowfall that day made retreat very difficult, "snow-swimming." Had fixed 1000m rope from C2 to highest point.

BC at southwest end of Kyashar Glacier
C3 on South Ridge.

C2 and C3 vertical (80-90 degrees and overhung) rock and ice so very difficult and 1000m fixed rope needed and snow avalanching destroyed same of it. C1 to C2 and C4 to top fairly easy. Tents broken at C1 by avalanches from Thamserku and at BC by strong wind. No fixed rope left for use above C3 despite danger in not having it.

Delay making C3 due to extreme delay of baggage from Korea by ship and overland to Kathmandu. Leader and Roh arrived BC 20 Dec with this baggage; other members had taken purchases from KTM to make lower camps and await their arrival via Puma helicopter.

Had planned second summit attack, but bad weather (strong wind and snowfall) meant it was called off and expedition ended.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Korean ascent; new route; 1st winter ascent

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to bad weather, manpower depleted
ROUTEMEMO:
BC northwest of Lum Teng (between Lum Teng and point 4698 on Schneider map)
C1 at same site as Japanese 1982 on narrow ridge bet "g & G of Karyolung Glacier
C2 after traverse to northeast from C1 to site E of "H" of Shorang Himal
High point at north of summit.

Climb started late because leader had accident during autumn trek. Left KTM only on 3 Jan.

Three summit bids: 

20 Jan on Japanese route to 6200m, but blue ice turned party back. 

22 Jan on right side of Japanese route to north of summit, but again turned back this time by 3m wide crevasse and all to BC. 

23 Jan Ko and Ahn to C1, followed 24 Jan Pasang and Ang Tsering to C2. 25 Jan 4:00 am Ko and 2 Sherpas set out for summit and at overhang near crevasse Ko took hours to make route and Ang Tshering turned back early evening and in descent serac hit Ko's arm. 

26 Jan snowfall and all BC waiting better weather but now Pasang and Ang Tsering not in good condition and manpower depleted, bad weather.
ACCIDENTS: Ko arm broken; leader's feet not recovered fully from trekking accident; sirdar sick and did no climbing

ROUTEMEMO:
BC   half day above Samagaon
Biv1 near Naike col
Biv2 on NE Face
Biv4 in crevasse on face (no wind in crevasse).

9th Dec first summit attempt reached 7200m, then high wind and very cold and returned to BC same day. 10th Dec BC and 11th Dec up again to 6150m biv site of 7th Dec. 12th Dec little snowfall and did not move 14th Dec, 8-1/2 hours climb to top. Left biv at 3:20 am and on top 11:40 am in strong wind. Near top very cold wind. That night in 13th Dec bivouac which reached 3:30 pm but no food since had spent extra day on ascent. 15th Dec to BC, where only 1 tent and 1 Sherpa, and on to Samagaon, which left 17th Dec. Technically not difficult but too far from last bivouac point to top. Below 7000m not colder than autumn, but above very cold and windy.

No fixed ropes used, true alpine-style climb.

At summit found match box with names and date of 11 May 1956 summiters in Peace and cigarettes with stones (probably from Japan).


The Iwa-to-Yuki 

The author and Yasuhira made an alpine-style ascent of Manaslu in Dec 1985. This was the second winter ascent, following that of the Poles. Yamada climbed K2 in July and Everest in Oct, both without oxygen, and then made elaborate plans for the perfect alpine-style ascent of Manaslu. Yamada and Saito helicoptered to Sama on Dec 2nd to join the sirdar and loads, having caravaned beforehand. BC was made on Dec 5th. They set about climbing next day, but the weather deteriorated three days later and forced them to retreat from 7200m. Taking one day's rest at BC, they later resumed activity and after three bivouacs reached the summit at 11:40 am, Dec 13th. On the top they found a tin for cigarettes containing the register of the Japanese party which had made the first ascent of the mountain. This was a big bonus for their remarkable feat of this time.
ACCIDENTS: Saito some frostbite on side of nose on summit day

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at lower classical BC site
ABC at normal C1 at base of West Face
C1  at normal C4 site
High point at plateau.

Wind broke tents at ABC and had to retreat. On 3rd Feb went up again (Hans and Messner following Moro and Sherpas who pitched new tent at ABC). On 4th Feb Hans, Reinhold and 4 Sherpas to 7000m but no tents pitched because too strong wind (Hans buried in crevasse one Frenchman from Makalu II autumn 1985) and returned to ABC. 

On 8th Feb again up to 7000m early on the only really fine day of the climb. Slept there with 2 Sherpas and 2 film-team men. 9th Feb started 2-day push to top with 2 Sherpas carrying and cameraman following part way. At noon Hans and Reinhold reached Makalu 7410m col and 1 hr higher, saw no possibility of going higher still in cloud-obscured route and high wind, so turned back. Were on plateau mostly green ice. Returned to 7000m camp where now begining to snow and descended to ABC on same day. On 11th still snowing and descended to BC where more than half meter of snow.

No accidents, etc.
3 cameramen went above ABC

Found bodies of Frenchmen Pierre Demolombe and Marcel Margaine on Kangchungtse at 7100m and 7450m.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to wind, impending storm, bad health of members
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Mingbo (English went more slowly to BC on 30 Dec)
C1 at normal site east of South Ridge
C2 at end of horizontal section
High point at yellow step.

6 Dec Gabites and Staszewski were to go to top but had moved up too fast and Staszewski clearly sick from altitude and Gabites spent rest of day bringing Staszewski from C2 to 19,000 ft on horizontal section. Next day English and Perry joined in getting him to BC in bad condition. 

8 Dec English to C1 and on 9th Perry and Gabites joined him there. 10 Dec the three got to 19,000 ft on horizontal section when strong wind forced them to camp there at 11:00 am; 2:00 pm Perry decided to descend with chest infection while other two stayed all night in continued strong wind. 11 Dec big clouds plus up high strong wind, went along ridge to just below yellow step when winds struck and appeared storm coming up so English opposed to going on (were without sleeping bags and it appeared would have to spend 2 nights out) so turned back and by 4:00 pm English blown off ridge, fortunately clipped to fixed rope and camped again.  

12th Dec carried gear to C1 and to BC 13th Dec.


English - 22 Dec 85

English feels that Gabites and others rushed too fast to and on the mountain. They had rigid pre-set time table that required them to climb mountain very quickly (like Nairz's party in aut '85) and be finished by the time the wives, girlfriends and children arrived. Time table did not take into consideration the health of individuals the health of individuals and their time requirements for acclimatizing. English had booked return LUK/KTM for 4 Jan and was astonished to learn on 11 Dec when he and Gabites debated whether to continue push for top or go down in face of storm brewing up that yaks had been ordered to come to BC on 17 Dec.
ACCIDENTS: Staszewski edema (could never have been gotten down if had been no fixed ropes on horizontal section)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4700m Ramzar
AC at 5100m 200-300m below Japanese BC and same site as Polish, Yalungkang 1985
C3 at Great Shelf or a bit above it.

Kukuczka and Wielicki arrived BC 20 Dec. Team to BC for Christmas climb. Only 4 high camps because problem with tents which frequently broken by wind and heavy snow, but still summiters went to top and back from C4 in same day. Found 3 yellow oxygen bottles on top. Difficult last mixed limbing to top and old ropes were very helpful to indicate which way to summit. Were crevasses causing difficulty in lower part of climb. 4 men went to C4 but Czok coughing, not feeling well and on 11th he went down with Piasecki while Kukuczka and Wielicki to top. 

No more summit attempts. Kukuczka, Wielicki, Czok and Piasecki had on 3 Jan carried to C4, slept C3, and planned to occupy C4 on 4th, but weather bad on 4th and all 4 down to BC.


Kangchenjunga, Lorentz - 7 Jan 86

Base at Ramche yak huts 
ABC 5200m by advance party about 5 Dec
C1 6100m
C2
C3 on Great Shelf established about 20 Dec

Kukuczka and Wielicki arrived ABC about 22 Dec and would have taken only 2 days to get to C4.

Weather very good untll Xmas Eve; snow up to knees at Ramche on 27th and shoulder high 2 days later when he had left Ramche.
All well, no one ill, no accidents.
Surely going to succeed.
ACCIDENTS: Czok very weak (carried to C3 and died Jan 11 at about 10:00 pm of pulmonary edema); Wielicki some frostbitten toes which will heal

ROUTEMEMO:
BC   at 4100m very near Yugoslav BC Aut 1985
Biv2 at 7700m just 100m below where they joined ridge.

In last days of Nov, looked around glacier, found couloir as ascent route and did some training. Started up on 1st Dec and on 2nd explored in areas of Biv1. 3rd back to BC after deciding on 2nd that route wanted to follow to left of MacIntyre route because too exposed for light, fast climb. Up again on 6th Dec at 12:30 am and reached to Biv1 at 6:00 am. Next day left 00:01 hrs. Climbed at night because in day light looking up too depressing to see how far you still have to go. 8th Dec left Biv2 at 9:30 am and got to top at 1:24 pm and down NE Ridge till returned to Biv1 site at 5700m at midnight 9th Dec at BC.

Morani didn't feel well, not strong; left BC 5 Dec.

Only 2 bivouacs: 1 on Col and 1 on face at about 7000m. Will start climbing at night with head lamps. During acclimatization in Nov will cache equipment at bottom of face (down from Col on large plateau at bottom of face). May climb to left of MacIntyre-Kurtyka route and reach summit via SE Ridge. Technical problems not great: the problem is the wind, so lost part of climb at highest altitude most exposed to wind, most difficult.

BC   at Gorakshep
Biv1 on SW Ridge
Biv2 on East Face.

29th Nov carried load to SW Ridge and 1 Dec camped on this ridge at 5900m. 2 Dec to BC because Mike sick. Todd then decided he could solo East Face, which Japanese had just finished climbing. 4 Dec Bibler started up face without gear had left at SW Ridge. Had tent sleeping bag but no rope. No wind at all (slept with door of tent open). 5 Dec to summit and back to BC.

Dimitri still sick and left BC 6 Dec (an Everest LO had come to BC and said since mountain had been climbed by face, they could not attempt summit via ridge). 7 Dec Bibler up ridge to retrieve gear at 5900m (and at 6100m which Bibler had dumped on 2 Dec before descent that day).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to insufficient strength (gastro-intestinal illness)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at west side of Lhotse Nuptse Glacier.

Left BC on 22 Dec. Made only temporary bivouac camps between 5790m and 6700m from 22nd Dec to 1st Jan. Climbed without fixed rope or camps. Descended from 6700m to BC on 1 and 2 Jan. Abandoned climb due to insufficient strength to reach summit.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to bad weather, exhaustion and lack of food
ROUTEMEMO:
BC   just south of Barun Pokhari
Biv1 at South Col
Biv2 just below SE Ridge on variation of normal route
Biv3 on SE Ridge
High point at SE Ridge.

Until end Nov did acclimatization climbs from BC. 1st Dec started up first 3 days slept on S Col while went above and then down to BC leaving tent at Col packed up. 6th Dec up again in summit bid and slept at S Col. 7th Dec up by variation of normal route (descended normal way). 9th Dec to 7500m on ridge but not possible to go further because of wind (not terribly strong) and clouds that badly restricted visibility ("we could not see"), so returned to 7400m to sleep. 10th Dec stayed at 7400m, again windy (strong wind now) and cloudy. 11th Dec again to 7500m but down (now lightly snowing and cloudy) to 7200m. 12th Dec to BC in strong wind at 11:00 pm arrival. Waited till 19th (20th clear weather!). Not difficult route. Did not attempt S Face at all (original objective); decided impossible for 2-man team in winter.

OTHERSMTS: Climbed Island Peak (Sasahara and Takahashi) and Mera Peak (Aota)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at east side of small lake southeast of point 5527m.

First tried rock band to 5800 or 5900m and then abandoned this line as too steep, so descended 200m to line actually followed which was all ice climbing. This mixture meant lost time. Had planned only 1 bivouac at 6600m. Ice climbing was sometimes dangerous from avalanche. Knife ridge in area of 1st bivouac; also there was rock falling. This route for 2-3 days rapid alpine-style ascent. 3rd Dec went to summit and back to 2nd bivouac. 4th Dec to BC at Gorakshep. Descent route slight variation because seemed little easier.

Takashi caught cold on Island Peak and did not go to Pumori.

BC at 4900m at Lobuje Glacier
C1 at 5400m on East Face
C2 at 5700m on East Face.

Entirely alpine-style climb above C2 (i.e., no fixed ropes). Summit party left summit 12:50 pm and cleared mountain as they descended to BC, which reached 5:00 pm. BC to C2 600m fixed ropes.

No other summit bid after 30th Jan because when Lee arrived on 30th Jan at BC learned mountain had been climbed (had been badly delayed getting to BC because food supplies late clearing Calcutta). Expedition left BC 31st Jan. 

Above C2 is 500m of much crevassed area, face is quite steep and there were difficult ice sections.

ROUTE1: S Face (to right of Yugoslav rte)
SPONSOR: Lyon and Avignon Winter Expedition Nepal 1986-87 to Ama Dablam
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to wind, heavy snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at normal site for South Ridge above Mingbo
ABC near lake at bottom of South Face
C1  under 1st crevasse at bottom of South Face
High point on South Face.

Hoped to make C2 on South Face at about 6100-6200m in route directly up face to summit. Hoped to reach a small span (snow ridge) and put tent there since no place to camp on face at this altitude because very steep (50-80 degrees) but wind drove them back, broke tent at C1. Down to BC then on 12 Dec up again but again wind broke C1 tent and snowfall followed 13th evening. Lot of snow on 14th and 15th so abandoned idea of attempting Cholatse as well. Fixed 1000m on face. Should have made alpine-style ascent in fast climb. A good route.
ACCIDENTS: Massardier fell just above BC on unstable rocks of moriane & broke both the legs on Nov 30; no other problems

ROUTE1: S Ridge on right-side of S Face
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
Expeditions to Himlung prior to 1992 were probably climbing Nemjung.

Began actual climb on 18th and had series of bivouacs.
