On 18th climbed Ratna Icefall to 5200m where bivouacked; one tent crushed by avalanche that night and couloir avalanching constantly, but next day not so much avalanche and latter part of the day was ice climbing to 5600m where bivouacked on crest of W Spur of S Ridge (complete S Ridge not possible with so much snowfall). 20th fixed traverse back to main gully and slept at same bivouac. 21st climbed the W Spur to first hanging ice field and open bivouac at 5900m at point where joined S Ridge. Everyone had 60 lb pack on difficult climb. Very brittle ice climbing on 22nd by 2 members and down to 5600m that night. 23rd all to BC in bad weather and Rosso sick.

Swigert and Tenney could have gone on above 1st hanging glacier (there were 2) but others not able to descend alone on more than 20 300-ft rappels. Now weather had deteriorated and supplies in short supply - storm now broke. "It is beautiful line" up this South Ridge, which is very steep.

Climbed 6600 ft of mountain and most of it vertical rock and ice both; difficult rock climbing because it is featureless but good granite. Approach route should have been on east side of glacier, west side of South Ridge.
ACCIDENTS: Rosso altitude sickness and other illness (perhaps virus)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at junction of Barun & Chago Glacier
C1 near "o" of Chago Glacier
C2 west-northwest of Makalu La (Messner's C1)
C3 at Makalu Col
C4 south of "L" of Makalu La.

Climb above C2 the difficulty began and fixed rope this section with strenuous jummaring to col. C3 put in on 29th and first summit bid planned to start from there on 30th but 5-day storm began and virus attacked. 2nd May was summit date planned and C4 sited and started with gear. All down to BC. Up again on 7th onwards; had mixed weather conditions with fierce winds on 10th. Left C4 on 12th at 3:30 am and on top 11:15 am in lovely weather following French route basically above C4. Rotten snow on summit ridge down to C2 on 12th summit day. 

Neptune's party to summit on 16th from Makalu La; on top at 1:40 pm. Had to send people up to get Moti Lal down after got snowblindness and couldn't take care of himself on a mountain, fell several times.

Virus which ran through team took Read away early and Cooley didn't acclimatize and left early too.
ACCIDENTS: Moti Lal snowblindness on summit; Neptune frostbitten fingers; Porzak fell into crevasse

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to bad weather, disappearance of supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Kangchung (as far as yaks could go in deep snow)
C1 at Nangpa Glacier edge near "g" of Nangpa
C2 at Gyabrag Glacier moraine between "a" "g" Gyabrag
C3 (ABC) at upper part of Gyabrag Glacier near "c" of Glacier
C4 just east of point 6446m on ridge
C5 just below icefall 
C6 above icefall
C7 above rock band south of point 7530m.

At high point stayed 2 nights because of wind and snow. On 2 May down to C5 and down to ABC site on 3rd. Found ABC stripped clean presumably by Chinese, so down to secret Chilean BC2 at 5700m. 4th May to USA C1 and now climb over because of loss of all supplies at USA ABC. An easy peak: hardest section was scree slope 35-degree to C4 but high mountain with winds and storms.


Watters - 13 May 1987

April 25, Watters 15 minutes behind other 3 headed to C4, heard shouting and waving arms below at ABC turned back and found there 2 Chinese officials who asked for climbing permit. Watters went for it (and told to other 3 to go on up); then was asked for trekking permit and as he got it out, Chinese saw passport and took it and both permit (also took Chilean documents but not passports).

Chinese wanted him to come down with them to Chinese army camp near Austrian's BC. Pretended to follow Chinese but actually suddenly went south and left Chinese. Other 3 kept on up: Baker, Grant and Swanson. When they came down, were not caught by Chinese (Baker very early in morning, other 2 in storm).

See AAJ (1988) for further details of confrontation with Chinese officials.
ACCIDENTS: Tent fire at C5 burned Baker's hands slightly; Gerhauser ill (chest cold) and left expedition early when didn't recover (reached C1 once, was down below BC couple of times, finally left May 2)

SPONSOR: American Chamlang Expedition of the Juilliard Mountain Club
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6750m due to Deak's frostbite
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  near Shershon
C1  above major and minor icefalls where Chamlung Glacier meets Lower Barun
    (base of North Face)
Biv in ice cave in crevasse.

Took 3 carries to C1 which was difficult, dangerous and hard to find. "Incredible icefall" at gate between Chamlang and Peak 4. Between BC and C1-C2 avalanche slopes with hanging glaciers above route in this area. All climbing of N Face to ridge done on 30th April in 12 hours to small crevasse bivouac which gave protection from wind (had not carried tent, for reducing weight). Now late in afternoon and exhausted and one day from summit. Planned to eat and rehydrate on 1st May and go to top on 2nd; on afternoon of 30th spent most time sleeping and didn't eat. 3 am 2nd began ascent but weather deteriorating and Deak's toes had started freezing; at 5:30 got to 6750m, turned back in bad storm, paused at ice cave, then on down to C1. 4th went back up but Deak soon realized he could not go on: fell twice from "depletion" of strength and turned back at about 5800m. 4 days at BC but Deak could barely walk from frostbitten toes. Still went up to C1 to recover gear with some hope of continuing climb with Hartshorne. Down to BC on 11th and left BC 13th.
 
Route made left of Scott 1985 route but essentially same.
ACCIDENTS: Deak frostbitten toes (which should heal completely)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to bad weather and dwindling supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 1/2 hour from foot of South Face
C1 at others C2 (on glacier, 1/2 hour before couloir leading to a ridge)
C2 on next glacier in cirque at base of col 
Biv1 just below a subsidiary peak
Biv2 called "Tete de Butoir."

4 members climbed alpine-style from C2 in 2 days. Then heavy snowfall and avalanche danger and route from involved long traverse under heavily loaded snow slope, so 20th April down to C2 and 1 May to BC and climb ended. Hadn't enough fuel to wait much longer for snow conditions to be safe.

Aprin: C1 pitched 10th April but occupied only on 13th and again on 26th, when alpine-style attempt began. On 26th ran into technically hardest part on ridge and when ridge eased off, there was deep snow. Bivouacked that night at 6100m. 27th got to 6400m at noon and had to bivouac there. 28th down to C2.

Abandoned climb on 28th said Aprin, because daily storms with much fresh snow brought serious avalanche threat. Were running out of food and fuel and weather looked like getting bad again (it did).

BC at Kangchung
C1 at Messner's C1 south of Nangpa La
C2 at base of SW Ridge, east side of Gyabrag Glacier
C3 at base of icefall southwest of point 6446m
C4 on NW Face 
C5 on NW Face.

Porters crossed Nangpa La, but members followed Messner route across Sentu-Gua Pass. 2 members who did not reach summit on 29th were in C4 on 30th April and 1 May up to C5, waited there 3 days for good weather but it did not come and all met in BC 5th May. Bad weather wind and snow. Essentially were on Tichy route. Descended same way as Messner: came down across Nangpa La. Left BC 7th May. 

Had slight trouble with Chinese officials. 2 members at C2 that Chinese who had knives and took their trekking permits. Chinese came because Americans had camp on Tibet side; joined Chileans at C5, waited for them to find the way up yellow band.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6850m due to Ferrer's death
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4250m at normal site for N Face climb
C1 at 4800m below normal C1 site (because of much snow)
C2 below Dutch Rib
C3 at 6800m on French route below cycle
High point on North Face.

1st tried Dutch Rib for 3 days on left side of rib, but end of rib very difficult and went over to French classical route. At base of rib at 6100m above C2 put temporary camp for climbing rib. 

Day after C3 reached by 3 members, Ferrer decided to descend because of bad altitude sickness during night and between C2 and C3 he fell 300m while descending alone. People in C2 waited for him; in C1 people saw how he stopped after fall, but no one saw his fall. When did not reach C2 members in C3 came down and found him unconscious and brought him to C2 where doctor was and where there was O2 but he died of fractured skull. Climb abandoned: 2 members went clear C3 while others brought down body.

On 23rd Maldonado and Villa turned back when were asked by walkie-talkie to see what happened to Ferrer. Would have reached top making C4 on 23rd and C5 on 24th on the way. All difficulties had been surmounted. Ferrer was actually likeliest to have reached summit.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5500m due to serac danger on steep bare ice face
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 1 hour beyond Gorakshep
High point at bottom of face.

6th May at BC till 11 pm when had breakfast and set out at midnight for line had picked out, but saw 2 avalanches came off it on E Face. Decided to have closer look, reached foot of E Face at 2:30 am having seen another avalanche on the way there. Waited for light for good look and then saw upper part of face was bare ice with big threatening seracs and avalanche cone below. Decided exposure to big seracs too risky on bare ice too slow to climb; never took out crampons and rope. Left BC 8 and 9 May.

BC  at Lhotse Glacier west side, west of Island Peak
C1  same as Yugoslav C1 at small pass north of point 5700m
C2A at 6500m on SW Ridge (but very windy and tents destroyed)
C2B at 6200m near Yugoslav C2 on SW Ridge
C3  near serac near meeting of SW and SE Ridge.

Had permit for East Ridge before came to Kathmandu. In February took flight over area and decided too great danger of many seracs making constant passage through area below and also of avalanches. After arrival at BC sent 1 member and LO to Kathmandu and obtained permit for SE Ridge, same route as Yugoslavs. In early May 16 tried to put C4 at 7500m or 7600m, but wind prevented this (an in earlier days, also deep snow); so managed to dump supplies at 7300m. Decided on 14 May not to attempt C4 but go directly from C3 to Lhotse Shar. Very early May decided traverse not possible because:

  (1) were late on mountain
  (2) winds, which were factor in being late in their progress

Say Yugoslavs had come one month earlier and still only in C3. Also 3 traverses too difficult for relatively inexperienced French members. 

1st attempt for summit 17th May from C3 by Flematti, Sharma and Pasang Sherpa; when reached SE Ridge 8200m found wind too strong and decided to fix rope only and down to BC. 

On 18th Gramond went to deposit and then when little wind got to 8200m alone; then ridge dangerous and he did not want to continue solo and to C3. 

19th evening Tedeschi, Esteve, Royer and Sange Sherpa to C3 and awoke at 10:00 pm and started up at 11:45 pm. At 7600m Esteve and Royer turned back because frostbite threatening then and now there were no fixed rope. Sange stopped ascent at 8250m because he was afraid of ridges dangers. Tedeschi continued to top alone and to C3 very tired (to BC on 21st). 

On 22nd Mailly, Nima Norbu and Kikami Sherpa tried for top from C3; Kikami to 7400m (tired) and Mailly, Nima Norbu to 7600m (wind and cold). Climb finished: all members very tired and all camps empty of food and gas supplies.

8 May Esteve and Grammond (pilot and passenger respectively) flew from C3 (7000m) to near BC at about 5300m (NE of BC in parachute like a glider). 1st time from such altitude by this type of parachute.

Had obtained permit to climb East Ridge, but after aerial view of this ridge, team decided it was exposed to too much danger from avalanching and many seracs overhanging route they would have to follow. They sent a member and their liaison officer to Kathmandu to get permission for the Yugoslav's SE Ridge route. (They had also planned to make a traverse from Lhotse Shar to Lhotse's main summit via the unclimbed intermediate summit at the mountain, and traverse would be too difficult for the relatively inexperienced French members.) Between 6th and 13th May, team tried four times to pitch a C4 at 7500-7600m, but first deep snow and then winds prevented this. On the 14th they decided to go directly from C3 to the Lhotse Shar summit. Four attempts were made to reach this peak, but only one member of the third party succeeded because of strong winds, threatened frostbite and fear of the dangers on the ridge.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st French ascent; 1st parachute; 1st French army ascent of 8000m on summit

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5500m due to bad weather and avalanche danger
ROUTEMEMO:
BC east of Tent Peak and another ridge east of Tent
C1 at lateral moraine on edge of East Annapurna Glacier
C2 beneath large rock below snow slopes under Annapurna III below col between
   Annapurna III and Gangapurna
C3 on top of large rock
High point at C3.

Decided to go for East Ridge from col between Gangapurna and Annapurna III instead of attempting S Face because route across glacier too long, involved and difficult for attempt in poor weather conditions with poor visibility. Nine days between making C2 and C3: 3 days fixing rope after time spent finding route in bad visibility (mist). 28th April put tent and left loads at C3 but did not occupy it until 1st May in electrical storm which continued for 3 days. Stayed 2 nights, no sign of weather improving and avalanche danger threatened (40-50 cm new snow per day) so decided to abandon climb. Had planned to climb above C3 in alpine-style without fixed ropes.

BC at about 100m below Americans BC
C1 at same site as Americans
C2 at same site as Americans altitude according to map and others
Biv mushroom ridge
C3 at same site as Americans, who also made C3 this date.

After making C2, went down to BC for rest. Started up on 11th and spent time on 13th fixing ropes above C2 on two steps. Also fixed ropes on 14th and 15th. 4 members from 11th went up but on 15th Tsilogiorgis got stomach problem so summit team consisted only 3 members and 1 Sherpa. Went to summit with Americans with Tsoukias leading the climb from C3 to top and back to camp.

SPONSOR: Groupe des Moraines Dhaulagiri I Expedition 1987
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7955m due to bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 above big icefall, which skirted to right 
C2 above small icefall
C3 at left side of NE Ridge
C4 on NE Ridge.

After C5 established 29th April, down for rest at ABC. 7th May attack started from ABC by Mizukoshi and Sekiya with 2 Sherpas and slept C3 that night; not good weather on 8th May so stayed C3. 9th May to C5 and 10th May up in summit bid and reached 7955m (started 4:00 am and reached high point 10:30 am). Stromg wind and deep soft snow put end to this attack (soft snow very tiring). While ascending avalanche had hit Ang Phurba at 7900m and sent him down mountain: would have plunged 3000m down N Face if after 10m fall large rock had not broken his fall. He was able to resume ascent. 10th May attack party slept C5 that night and to ABC. 10th May Nakamura and Watanabe up to C4 for 2nd summit bid but 11th long period bad weather coming and supplies in ABC low, so Nakamura decided climb finished. Had planned for summit success by and May and now members morale not good enough for another attack plan, food and kerosene supplies not enough for still another long wait for better weather. "Route easy, weather bad."
ACCIDENTS: Ang Phurba hit by avalanche but not injured; 1 member slight frostbitten finger

ROUTEMEMO:
After central BC established, each member has his own with own tent, food, fuel, etc., but sometimes shared tents when 1st climbers reached a site. Had no Tibetan helpers even to get supplies to 5700m camp and most climbers had to shuttle loads 3 times. Robert Strouhal skied down from 7600 to 6000m (to glacier).

-35 degrees C at C3 in high winds turned some members back and gave 2 men frostbite.

Walters reached C3 then ran out of food and fuel and weather bad.

Schmuck has complained to Nepalese tourism ministry about American and Chilean expeditions crossing border and going onto his team's route. (Graf said on 5 May in KTM Chinese liaison officer was very angry about Chileans and Americans having crossed onto Tibetan side of Cho Oyu and seized several of their passports and trekking permits).


Eberhard Jurgalski - February 2012

Hans Pree told Eberhard Jurgalski by phone in March 2006 that he stopped at the summit plateau.
ACCIDENTS: Daum and Faessler frostbite; Obermaier altitude illness at 7600m in summit bid

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7350m due to serious frostbite
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Pangpema.

Japanese route followed from about 7200m after using German route and descending 100m by rope to do so. Carried loads to C2 site 11 April but slept there only on 16 April and then down. 21 April up again from BC. This time both members to C1 (Monier was alone above BC before). 22nd Monier to C2 in solo summit bid. 23 April stayed in C2 because bad snowfall. 24th up again up but had to give up and descend with bad frostbite, so back to C2 and 25th to BC. Miss Loscos stayed in C1 21-25 April.

No Sherpas, no fixed rope (or rappell rope). Solo above C1. Monier's plan on 24 April was to rest 2 hours at 7500m in afternoon, resume climb that night rest 3-4 hours at 7900m in sleeping bag, reach summit that night or early morning of 25th and descend to C2 on 25th.
ACCIDENTS: 2 toes frostbitten and will require surgery to remove tops of both toes (had insufficiently warm boots, boots were good for -25 degrees in Alps)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to continuous bad weather, illness
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at glacier's junction
C1 at moraine to east side of Chago Glacier on spur
C2 below Makalu La
High point at Makalu La.

After C2 established, 21st April down from C2 to BC for rest. 26th April up to C1 and 27th to C2. 29th to Makalu La [at 7400m] where arrived 5 pm and down to C2 to sleep. 30th down to BC for rest. Again after 2 days at BC Simonetta got sick from bad food. 3rd May both tired to go up and reached C1. 4th May Simonetta up only to 6000m because weak from illness and returned to BC while Righeschi reached C2. 5th May heavy snowfall and he down to BC that day and they decided to give up because of bad food and weather. Again all climbing done by Simonetta and Righeschi together except on 4th and 5th May.
ACCIDENTS: None except Simonetta stomach trouble; other 2 members headache and sight problems, went down from BC & never returned, left BC about Apr 22, had never been on expedition before, did not realize Himalaya not just like Alps

ROUTE1: SE Face-SW Ridge of E Smt
SPONSOR: Korean Alpine Club Chung Dong Churen Himal Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to difficult final Ridge
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Kaphe Glacier
High point on SE Ridge.

Final summit ridge knife sharp crystal ice; entire route very long. Fixed total 200m begining below C1 over rock and snow. Almost every afternoon new snowfall, after while very deep. 11th May 11:40 am reached very steep, very narrow ridge, dangerously exposed to wind, which most days was strong. Between C4 and C5 big crevasse which took much time to pass. Many avalanches came off Dhaulagiri VI which were not serious problem to Koreans. After 11th May weather bad and no more chance of success. 

Would like to try again but from C5 go to SW Ridge instead of route attempt this time. Expedition actually obtained permit for East Peak only.

SPONSOR: La Seda de Barcelona Tilicho Peak
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7050m due to snow conditions, destructive winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at northeast end of Tilicho lake (normal site)
ABC on North Ridge (300m above bottom of ridge)
C1  on North Ridge.

Waited in BC till 14 April but weather "not very nice" and on 11th April heavy snowfall. Needed one week of very good weather to launch new summit attack: 2m deep snow. ABC and C1 had been destroyed in 5 minutes on 5 April when bad weather (heavy snow and strong wind) struck and stopped summit attempt that day. But weather did not stabilize and more and more snow being added. 

First part of climb technically medium difficulty and last part not at all difficult, but the weather on Tilicho brings terrible wind (like at Jomsom) and fast new snow dumping.
ACCIDENTS: In the descent on Apr 8 summit party slipped twice (20m) but not injured, found camp destroyed and had to sleep in snowhole

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5600m due to Hall's accident
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal North Face site
C1 at normal North Face site
C2 at sites but never occupied (snowcave at normal site)
High point on North Face.

Planned to go to C3 on N Face and then decide whether to continue on French North Face route or go to NW Spur. On 5th April Hall and Atkinson reached site of C2 and began digging cave for camp, then down to BC for rest same day. 6th other 2 climbers went to C1, 7th to C2 site and worked some more on cave. C2 stores left in cave but it never occupied because on 7th Hall had accident and climb abandoned. 

"We were really going well on the mountain; we had no health problems & the weather was good."
ACCIDENTS: Hall and Atkinson during rest period were doing some photography and on 7th April at 11:30 am  and Hall fell 10m

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to exhaustion from winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4900m before Barun Glacier
C1 at 5800m east side of point 5860m
C2 at 6700m at top of snow ridge in ice cave
C3 at 7100m at same as Yugoslav C3
High point at 7600m at start of South Face.

C1 tent collapsed by wind 12-20 April. 4 members (Moerman, Oefner, Ubbink and Van Nieuwkerk) had reached site of C3 on 12 April but illness and difficulty of finding site on which to pitch tent sent them down to BC. Some members started up again on 18th April, repaired tent and slept in C1. 19th to C2 and 20th occupied C2 at "anxious" site as Yugoslav camp, which apparently had not been a problem for Yugoslavs in Autumn season with perhaps better snow conditions. Lack of hard snow on face was serious problem for Dutch. Oefner and Ubbink stayed at C3 on 20th while other 2 descended to BC; both sick (one altitude and 1 stomach). 21st Oefner and Ubbink fixed rope but not far because of big powdered snow avalanche rushing down mountain (no physical damage but brought very cold temperature and discouraged climbers). 22nd fixed more rope on difficult traverse and Oefner fell 5m but saved by well placed piton. "Were same tricky traverses" but rock very solid. 23rd down to BC because they tired and other 2 were sick and could not go up. Moerman and Oefner up to C3 in 3 days and tried to fix rope above previous high point but very windy and cold. 2 May Oefner to end of ropes at 7500m while Moerman down and Oefner also down. 4th May Ubbink and Van Nieuwkerk, one day behind other two, up to highest point 7600m (Yugoslav C2), but 5th May back to BC tired; had planned to fix rope to slightly above traverse and then go to top alpine-style, but illness and exhaustion defeated them. All in BC; decided now to make summit push from high point (7600m). All 5 members to C2 (9th May to C1, 10th to C2). Oefner and Ubbink supported by others to make summit bid. 12th May Oefner, Ubbink and Van Nieuwkerk reached C3 planning now to biv at top of fixed ropes, but too tired and descended instead. To C2 12 May, 13th BC. Lost too much energy fighting wind and not enough manpower because of illness (Moerman had continuing altitude problem).

With little more manpower and better weather, original climbing plan would have worked. Plan to return with six members in 1988 if can find financing so quickly.
ACCIDENTS: Moerman altitude illness; Oefner short fall but uninjured

ROUTEMEMO:
BC (A) below Mingbo Glacier
BC (B) closer to mountain on ridge
C3 above mushroom ridge.

Hardest part between C2 to C3. Snowfall in early April changed the mountain from rock route to ice and snow. Moved entire BC up on 4 April after realized had put base much too far away from the site for C1. Saw Greeks move supplies by yak all the way to 18,000 ft. Between C2 and C3 are the difficult steps. Fixed rope between C1 and C2 for load carrying and because of weather. Between C2 and C3 was enormous amount of rope from earlier expeditions. Descent took very long (got back to C3 at 2:00 am on 18th because Greeks whom they summited with, were very slow). Had left C3 at 5:30 am on 17th.
ACCIDENTS: Kamin slightly frostbitten tips and toes

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6800m due to difficulty of dangerous SE Face
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at bottom of East Ridge (above (left) of same)
High point at SE Face.

20 April started to Pungen Glacier and 1st night on moraine and then traversed glacier to 5000m on slope/ridge going to pk29 to see face. Spent 2 nights and then back to BC (39 days at BC, only 6 with no snowfall) did acclimatization climbs on NE Face route to 6300m and 6000m (2nd time in chest-deep snow). 3rd acclimatization climb to 7100m on normal route on 13th May in much better snow conditions. All 3 trips alone by climbing at night, sleeping in day. 14th May started 4 members from BC to Pungen Glacier for climb of SE Face and at 4800m rested till 11 pm when 2 members began upward real climb and reached 5200m at base of SE Face to 1 am 19th May. 10:00 pm started up very steep sugar snow which was very dangerous; climbed this terrible snow up to very sharp horizontal ridge with many pinnacles. Now hopeless; minimum 2 days dangerous difficult climb with no chance of retreat if bad weather. Reached 6800m and then gave up when 3 days more without food and fuel. Horrible descent with no protection in warm daylight and had to wait till sun moved behind mountain and snow hardened. 7 pm back in biv at 6200m, 11 pm at 4800m, 4:00 BC 21st May. In night big SE Face is climbed but perhaps best in winter.

20th May decided not to attempt SE Face anymore, but thought to try NE face (normal route); 24 May decided abandon entire climb.

SE Ridge attempt:

19 May 11:00 pm began going up from biv at 4800m
19 May 1:00 am reached 5200m and 7:30 am reached 6200m, where bivouacked
20 May 10:00 am reached 6800m
20 May 7:00 pm were back at 6200m bivouac
20 May 11:00 pm were back at 4800m biv
21 May 4:00 pm were back at BC and climb had ended
21 May at night big snowstorm began and lasted for 3 days, so now on 24 May 
   gave up idea of trying normal route since supplies of food, etc were 
   becoming exhausted.
ACCIDENTS: Scevlik developed unknown illness and left after only 3 days at BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5600m due to loss of gear buried in snow at C2
ROUTEMEMO:
BC above Samagaon
C2 on glacier
C2 at Naike Col (200m above).

8th April heavy snowfall; again 18th April heavy snowstorm and all gear in C2 buried deeply. After 1st storm down to BC 9th April. Stayed in BC till 21st April since Barcelona (and to lesser degree, leader) frostbitten toes from bivouac forced by 8th April storm. 21st April up again and reached C2 site but all camps gear deep under snow and lost; could not find it under deep snow and below it ice. Had planned alpine-style ascent from C2 but all gear buried and down to BC same day and climb finished since all gas rope, tents, etc were now left. Left BC 25 April.
ACCIDENTS: Slight frostbite in toes by both members

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7450m due to bad weather, low food supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual site on east side of Island Peak
C1 at col between Island Peak and Lhotse Shar
C2 on ridge
High point at C4 site.

20th April Bence looking for C4 site. He alone, descended and no one again that high because of heavy snowfall with avalanches and then strong wind. After that C2 sometimes reached, C3 sometimes but then came snow and wind. Were in BC 60 days and not 1 day it would have been possible to traverse to Lhotse Intermediate because of wind and snow. Left BC 13-14 May. Yugoslavs fixed 1500m of own ropes and some old 1986 Spanish rope. All fixed by time French army arrived.

BC at Langtang Glacier halfway between Dragnarpo Ri and Goldum Peaks
C1 at snow plateau between 2 cols
C2 on SW Ridge 800m above Tilman's Col
C3 on SW Ridge.

Used fixed rope only last part to C2 below Tilman's Col where was hanging glacier and from Col to C2 to C3 difficult knife-edge ice ridge and here all fixed rope. From C3 to summit 600m fixed rope. Total 2300m rope fixed. After C3 had one week bad weather. 1st summit party left BC 14th April and 2nd attack party next day. 

Much deep snow this spring even in BC area, where 2 years ago there was none when Fukuzawa did recced-route from BC included crossing a col down to snow plateau and up again to Tilman Col. Any other route very difficult and have hanging glaciers threatening them.
ACCIDENTS: Yaguchi left BC Apr 10 with stomach trouble; same time Ang Kami also left BC sick

ROUTEMEMO:
Clemenson left Renard at BC on 11 or 12 Sept very early in morning leaving note in his tent saying not motivated; had conquest in 1984. Now Clemenson tells police he never saw Renard before and did not go to Nepal with him, has not repaid Renard for air ticket. Clemenson agreed to go to Cho Oyu with Renard: Renard did not want to climb alone and did not know Ang Rinji would join him and Clemenson had already been to summit so knew the mountain and was happy to return. Renard paid his airfare in the rush of departure but all other expenses shared equally between them.

Renard skied down from summit to 6200m (C1).

They had no permit for Cho Oyu.


Michel Vincent - 13 Aug 88

Tierry Renard did not reach Cho Oyu summit in 1987. Vincent knows he has been closely questioned about this and Japanese wrote letter saying they did not see him near summit on 21 Sept.

Renard had one Sherpa and one Frenchman (name unknown) with him at BC and one climbing Sherpa who did not go to summit. French had no permit for climb. Renard, who did ski descent of Gasherbrum II in 1985, claimed to have skied down Cho Oyu on this climb, but Japanese saw him descending much of route on foot: they believe he skied only from C2 to C1.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to unsafe snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC northeast of Tilicho Lake
High point at start of NE Spur.

4th Oct went up with loads to 5600m and back to BC across moraine. 5th brought up more loads to 5800m but unstable snow still there and decided this condition unsafe: couldn't fix route, so carried down loads. Strong wind also starting (120 kph).

SPONSOR: 1987 Jugal Himal Expedition of Chonnam Univ Medical School Alpine Club
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Langshisa Glacier on line between Urkinmang and Langshisa Ri
ABC on glacier east of BC 2 kms
C1  above ice wall
C2  on West Face almost at West Ridge
C3  on West Ridge.

Between 3rd and 19th Sep bad weather, so waited for improvement. Impossible to climb SW Ridge because so many avalanches so went over to West Face; most difficult section was below C2 very steep (60-70 degrees, some vertical) snow. Lee led most of route: very strong and technically excellent; Kim even stronger. 1600m from ABC to C1 and steep part below C2. Summit party left C3 at 6:20 am and on top at 8:15 am without problem in good weather.

Did not send another summit party because there were frequent small avalanches below C1 and small team. Leader did not reach C1, Cho stayed at ABC directing logistics and climbing, Hang and Khon were support climbers only.


Expedition/Leonpo Gang by Cho Seok-Phil

The other route toward Langshisa Glacier, opposite side of East Ridge, was only once attempted by an English expedition team 30 years ago, but, regretably, 3 members of them happened to die in avalanche. After that accident, our approach is the first trial through this route.

When enter into the Langshisa Glacier, there exist 3 routes in theory: West Ridge, SW Ridge, West Face and our choice was the West Face.

We established BC on Sept 3, and through an Advance Camp of Sept 3, and moved up to a Deposit Camp on Sept 15 on the way to approach. The climbing to Leonpo Gang really came in earnest.
Parties were completely divided for climbing and support, and the climbing pary decided to proceed with the alpine style.

In the face of pressing dangers from avalanche of ice and snow as well as collapse in spots, we had great difficulties in this West Face route. To minimize the risks, we had to reduce the time of our staying as short as possible.

The way to C1 was a snow face of 60-80 degree in 500m long, which we named "The Toh Wang Gil" after 2 days of climbing by member Lee Jeong-Houn, almost by himself thoroughly, C1 was secured on Sept 19.

Advancing toward C2 was also blocked by more giant slope snow face, named by "The Haneul" of 70 degrees in 600 meters long. Struggling through the ice and snowfall, Lee Jeong-Houn overcame this route and then, he established C2 (6200m) of 1 tent on upper band of snow face by using 2 snow bars.

Due to bad weather, all members retreated to the Advance Camp and waited till the weather to be better.

Finally on Sept, members Lee Jeong-Houn and Kim Soo-Hyeon started for a route of attack with 2 Sherpas, Pemba and Gombu. On that day Kim and Pemba arrived at C1 and Lee and Gombu came up to C2 at 5:00 pm and then, the four established C3 (6650m) on Sept 26.

It was Sunday Sept 27. After 2 hours from C3, they all 2 members and 2 Sherpas climbed up to the summit at last at 8:15 am. Even all the members of expedition were unexperienced with the Himalayan mountains though, they have achieved a real remarkable success - the first summit through the West Face route of Leonpo Gang.
ACCIDENTS: None except one Sherpa sprained foot; another Sherpa bad cough and left expedition

SPONSOR: 1987 American Ama Dablam N Ridge Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6370m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC west lateral moraine of Ama Dablam Glacier (foot of ridge)
C1 on North Ridge where spur and North Ridge proper meet
C2 at shoulder on West Ridge
High point at C2 site.

Reached C1 via spur on right side of N Ridge (ridge all rock, spur 95% snow). 2 went to establish C2 fixing rope and making route in hard climbing; fixed 1700m from 5275m to 6370m. Jeff Alzner, Fred Ziel and Tshering Lhakpa made C2 and left dump there. Storm hit and never slept in. Storm hit and "we ran for our lives." Descended and couldn't go back. Jeff came down in on avalanche Fred turned his anke. Mick Holt tried to go back up twice: what before was all boulders was now inside deep snow. Also running out of time. After storm lot of snow did not avalanche and was dangerous.

APPROACH: Thami valley->Chula last village and Sumna Phug (cave)
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to difficult 70m ice-cliff (as reported to HMG)
ROUTEMEMO:
18th Oct big storm came up and those who wanted Tichy route realized Japanese with Chinese permit would leave mountain (and they did) and 5 left ABC for Tibet on 24th Oct; had not returned to BC (sent word to sirdar to evacuate BC, 5 would be behind) but took direct route to Nangpa La. "Quite an adventure" at this stage. Camped one night before pass, one night on Nangpa Glacier, crossed Nangpa La 29th Oct and camped around the corner (to E). 30th Oct were at traditional C1 on Tichy route and camped there. 1st Nov Berg took rest day at 21,800 ft just below Hillary's icefall in 1952, while Mark Udall and Gustke (these 2 were exhausted and very cold) they returned met other 2 and all 4 descended to 21,800 ft. Berg kept on up to highest point ("about as alpine-style a climb as you can make it"). No fixed lines. From 10 days carried all gear they had. Berg climbed 5000 ft in 8 hrs 45 minutes, broke his own trail, reached 21,800 ft at 2:30 pm, had to erect tent collapsed by winds that had actually made ascent possible by blowing away snow. All 5 returned to Namche on 6th Nov (in Thami midnight of 5th and woke up tea shopkeeper for boiled potatos). Were unsupported on this adventure and Berg especially so.

Dump site at 17,700 ft of point 5885m at base of glacier. On 1st route got to 6500m and then route looked very hard for load carrying: horizontal knife-ridge into large snow feature which seemed to be shifting. So tried another approach and on this appeared difficult section above. They went to C1 for rest and storm hit and it ended all thought of discovering whether section above was negotiable. Big snowstorm hit 18-20 Oct and had to dig for 3 days to keep tents Ok and to ferry loads to place below BC. 

Climbing route: South Arrete/Ridge and South Spur, well west of Polish route.

Did not admit in 1987 to ascent because:
  (1) Wanted to protect name of Udall's father, a US Senator, and
  (2) Did not want to encourage others to violate rules (get into trouble).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5640m due to bad snow, lack of motivation
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at end of Lhotse Nuptse Glacier
High point at base of South Face.

Waited for Italians to go for it as they were there first and were well acclimatized. Also problem of LO who did not agree to abide by ministry's oral permission to be on same route as Italians. When LO did get radioed permission from KTM, big snowstorm had hit and snow buried gear at BC and did not consolidate. Went to base of the wall only on about 12th Oct, saw clouds coming and retreated to wait a couple of days for expected minor storm to pass (Yoder). 

Actually Newson and Yoder were not a good team. Yoder got various ailments because he didn't like the climb he found himself faced with. If both had been well motivated, they could have done the climb.

Climbed SW Face in semi-alpine style without Sherpas or oxygen. 

On descent their vision became blurred and thinking badly affected. As result they did not realize that an avalanche had wiped out their tracks and they could not see their camp at 7900m. Unable to find C4 in dark, Groom fell into crevasse. Both members spent the night out without equipment at 7900m. Next day they found their tent 100m away. This was the cause of serious frostbite to Groom's feet and Coulton's fingers and feet.
ACCIDENTS: Frostbite (both men will lose parts of fingers and toes)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at lake above Mingbo (near Drangka Khola SSE of Mingbo village)
C1 at point 5705m on Schneider map.

27th Sep 4 to C1 and 28th 2 of them to C2. 29th same 2 while Todd and Simmonds to C2. 30th Perkins and Cave to 6400m and then same morning down because of very bad snow conditions with steep section ahead with no belays to BC to Mingbo (BC had been moved). Other 2 met descending of men and also down (to C2 only). 1st Oct Todd and Simmonds in descent met Swift and Richmond coming up from C1 and they too descended. 

Heavy snowfall followed. 9th Oct BC struck: all left mountain except Todd and Perkins who went to C1; slight snow. 11th Oct to C2 and 13th Oct up to 6100m. Now snow much harder and again snow dangerous with no belays so down to C1 same day. 14th Oct to Mingbo (end of climb). All old fixed ropes under snow, no rope for fixing.

BC at 4700m at normal BC side
C1 at 5350m at middle of glacier
C2 at NE Col (snow cave)
C3 on NE Ridge
C4 on NE Ridge
C5 at 7500m on NE Ridge.

E Face did not have as much snow and ice as expected: was rock face up MacIntyre route planned to climb and water running down it. After reached col, there was snow storm so down to BC. Reoccupied C2 on 24th Sept. 30th Sept caught in avalanche at 6600-6700m and took them 200m down N Face pulling out most of pitches of Japanese fixed ropes; no broken bones but bad knee and hip and rope burns so back to Col and on to BC. 6th Oct again up to col, C3 on 8th, so now up to 7500m on 15th summit bid from 7500m at 8:45 am in cloudy weather but not windy; went up couloir on N Face instead of right on ridge. James turned around at 7800m because didn't like snow conditions which looked dangerous. To 7500m on 16th, col on 17th and BC 18th.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5700m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at old Mingbo helicopter pad
C1 before pinnacles on South Ridge (2 rocky platforms)
High point at C1.

BC too low but at normal site lake had disappeared. Snow began falling that night had dumped 4 feet snow. All day 20th dug out BC tents. Now got colder and colder everyday and snow didn't melt and didn't consolidate. 

Down to Pangboche for 1 week of waiting for snow to improve but had changed very little. Went up to C1 but in very deep snow and there was snow on polished rock slabs. C1 one tent destroyed and other collasped and they found on 28th where reached it. 2 members had placed an intermediate camp on 28th in case needed in descent. Spieczny left expedition after snowstorm: thought climb hopeless and his wife trekking in region.


O'Connor, Ama Dablam, Thyangboche - 22 Oct 1987

On the walk-in we passed a spring of nobbling climbers from the New Zealand expedition and a host of hollow-eyed Spaniards.

Our own base went up on the 14th and Camp 1 was in place by the 17th and then the bombardment began. Twenty four hours later we were under 4 ft of snow and spent the next couple of days digging out, rather than in.

Right now we are back in Thyangboche waiting for the snow to melt and hopefully for a chance at the climb, but the storm has been devastating.

Camps on Pumori have been wiped out. Lhotse Shar and the Burgesses likewise are buried and I understand are pulling out.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to winds, 1 member becoming ill, etc.
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  near icefall (the west of 2 icefalls) the south of peak
ABC on SW Ridge at top of icefall
C2  on SW Ridge 
High point on SW Ridge. 

ABC hit by 2 big avalanches which destroyed camp at night both times. No one hurt but very frightening. Changed route to C1 as a result and thus C1 took time to establish. Sherpas did not want to go to ABC for days. 9 Nov Berger sick and down to BC so only 3 members now on ridge and winds fierce above 6000m (100 km/hr) and very cold. Ridge is now knife-edged and dangerous from falling rock. 13 Nov summit bid but again only to 6300m and climb finished because food in C2 finished.

Had avalanching off South Face daily, usually at about 8:00 pm.

6 members to BC only (trekkers?).
ACCIDENTS: Fauret stomach trouble; Berger also sick; no accidents or frostbite

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to member's death, difficult climb
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 2-1/2 hours from Samagaon at start of East Ridge
C2 on East Ridge after having climbed couloir
C3 on end of East Ridge at glacier and below big rock pinnacle
High point at west side of pinnacle.

Route BC to C1 on north side of E Ridge (BC also north of E Ridge). Big snowstorm of 19th Oct dumped 1.20m snow on BC. 28th Oct Ichigi Kudo died at BC of presumed apoplexy: while eating supper, suddenly fell over and became unconscious. All members came down to BC and decided continuation of climb above C3 very difficult. Had planned ascent of pinnacle; after start climb, thought to go to west side of it but still rock and ice climb here very difficult. So decided not to continue after accident, not enough time with sudden death of Kodo. This route is possible: 50-50 chance of success without Kodo's death.
ACCIDENTS: Only Kudo's death; Kamiharako could not acclimatize so he and Kiyokawa left expedition

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6350m due danger snow slabs and eventually to Duff's illness
ROUTEMEMO:
BC    in valley across river from Pheriche
ABC.1 southeast of mountain for SE Face attempt
ABC.2 at Tawoche Glacier for East Face attempt
High point 150m below final summit.

ABC at 5200m for SE Face climb and over next week got 2 clients to 6100m on route on which Duff and Black fixed rope for them but no higher camps pitched, then clients ran out of steam and they left BC 24th Sept leaving Duff and Black (no one from Ama Dablam joined them). 

Black and Duff went back up and started from ABC 11 pm 1st Oct, climbed all night and got to 6350m on the final summit slope at 8:30 am on 2nd. Did not climb final slope of 150 vertical meters because of danger smow slabs. Immediately descended to BC which reached at 6 pm on 2nd. On 4th moved tent for E Face attempt, 1 km away from old ABC and placed it at same altitude at foot of Tawoche glacier, but now Duff suffering from effects of huge tapeworm. Scrambled 300m upwards on 6th and stayed in a camp there. 12th heard some Ama Dablam climbers missing and went to see; they weren't. But Duff getting worse, so no further climbing.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5600m due to weather, dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC between two Ama Dablam lakes on meadow
C1 on NW Ridge
High point on NW Ridge 100m below summit.

Snowed 26 hours and at BC deep snow 18-19th Oct. Afterwards waited for snow to consolidate and 21st Oct 2 went up again (made scientific studies meanwhile). Defeated by powder snow which neither consolidated nor melted and not was blown away. Would have to wait 10 days for safe snow conditions, but not enough time and funds to do so. Studied new compounds with anti-hypoxia action made in Belgium which were effective for brain.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7080m due to bad weather, insufficient rope
ROUTEMEMO:
Every day clouds formed in late morning & snowfall in afternoon. However little avalanching on this route. 

White Peak scaled on 3rd Oct by all 4 members; 4th Oct by all 4 members; 
5th Oct by 2 Sherpas (C2 was placed on summit).

Schedule Catalonian Expedition Dhaulagiri V / Nepal 87

9 Sept   - started the approach March from Pokhara
21 Sept  - reached temporary BC at 3550m below Tsaurabong Glacier 
           beside right of Myangdi Khola
22 Sept  - started loads transportation to depot Camp, DC is 4300m to 
           the right of seracs
26 Sept  - BC was established at 4900m. At the Tsaurabong Glacier East
           of White Peaks East Ridge
28 Sept  - was established the C1 at 5400m.
29 Sept  - was established one depot at 5900m below the white peak at 
           site originally planned for C2
 4 Oct   - was established the C2 at summit of the white peak. At 6400m
           (site originally planned to be C3)
 6 Oct   - two members arrived below the C3 at 7080m and go down 
           because there was cloud and was snowing.
 7 Oct   - the party decided to go down because:
           - days of bad weather
           - the ridge was dangerous without fixed route - rope supply exhausted
           - much wind 
 7 Oct   - all the members returned to BC from C2
13 Oct   - started the return march from temporary BC with 13 porters of Bagar
19 Oct   - All the party arrived to KTM.

At first tried "Youngster's Spur", but too difficult above 5800m and turned back: very difficult ice mushrooms, too difficult for 2 climbers. Tried for 3 days and gave up on 27th Oct and returned to C1 for 1962 French route, which joined at this expedition's C2. Bivouac at 6500m to wait for better weather. Sigayret and Julliard to 7400m on 6th Nov at 4 pm and returned to C4 with slight frostbite; Vallet and Vincent summited and returned to C4 at 11 pm with only slight frostbite. Climb now finished: all other members had gone back to BC several days earlier.

From AAJ:
  BC(21/10,4500m),ABC(23/10),C1(24/10,5300m),C2(27/10,6000m),C3(03/11,6400m),
  C4(05/11,7000m),Smt(06/11)


Jannu Expedition Francaise, by Henri Sigayret

Ascent 

From Ghunsa to BC 1:
Tuesday October 20th:

Beautiful weather. We had some porters with some yaks. We had had snow at about 4000m high. At base camp 1 there was 50 cm of snow which had been settled by the sun.

BC 1 is the usual camp of expeditions on that side. In particular, it is that of the French expedition of 1962. It is located near a moraine lake on a grass space; it is very comfortable. The height is about 4500m.

The sirdar has thought it possible to have the expedition gear carried until base camp 1. We have also set up a further camp, i.e., base camp 2 [ABC].

Date: Oct 22nd:

It is situated in the middle of the Yamatri glacier. Its height is about 4800m. There is no difficulty between BC 1 and BC 2. From basecamp 1, one follows the lake on the south side, one goes down the moraine (very steep - be aware of stone falls). Then one goes up again easily the glacier.

In general there is water. There are small lakes, and some small glacial streams.

From BC 2 to C1:
Date: Oct 23rd:

All the team, besides Gerard Auger, went up to C1. 

Route: one follows the Yamatri glacier then one crosses it to go on the moraine which is alongside the Youngster's Spur. One then goes up the moraine, then, through a small corridor, one crosses on the right. Then one goes up a little to a shelf near some big blocks. This is on the right bank of the A Glacier. The altitude is about 5300m. No difficulty is to be found. We placed the tents on Oct 23 and Oct 24th. All the team goes down to BC.

Attempt on the Youngster's Spur:
Date: 25/26th Oct

An ice corridor may be seen in the middle of the Youngster's Spur. It's facing south and its foot is near C1. Its gradient is about 40 to 45 degrees, but in some points it may reach 60 degrees or more. In its upper part, it meets the ridge of the Youngster's Spur (passages are steeper). The Youngster's Spur is mixed: there are ice passages, cornices - rock passages. This spur is climbed with several lengths of rope.

The spur has been equipped by Elisabeth Julliard, Henri Sigayret, Frederic Vallet and Michel Vincent. Frederic Vallet is head-man in this part.

Beyond Point B, the ridge is snowed in. There is drifting snow and mushrooms cornices. Too much gear and too many days would be necessary to equip this ridge. The head team decided to find a new route which meets the French one. The team climbed down and took off the material which equipped the ridge and the corridor. The descent was done without any problems.

From C1 to the French route
Tuesday Oct 27th:

Dawa Sherpa and Mane Bahadur are head-man on the glacier. Its heavy going. They are followed by Elisabeth Juliard and Henry Sigayret, then by Frederic Vallet and Michel Vincent. Some days later the other members of the team reached C2.

A traverse, then a direct climbing up on a steep glacier (but without any difficulty) enabled the team to meet the rock ridge behind which the French route stands. One goes up a glacier (it is magnificient). The crossing on seracs in dangerous. One gets through an almost vertical passage in a serac (a fixed rope has been installed) on to the glacier shelf in front of an enormous crevasse (15 to 20m wide), which bounds the valley.

A rope system which joins the two edges of the crevasse may still be seen. (Perhaps was it left by the Spanish expedition). 

Installation of C2 - probable height 6000m.
Michel Vincent and Mane Bahadur went down to C1.

Wednesday, Oct 28th:

Days rest at C1 but for one of us who stayed at BC.

Thursday Oct 29th:

Elisabeth Julliard, Mario Paffumi, Henri Sigayret, Frederic Vallet slept at C2.

Friday, Oct 30th:

Michel Vincent joins the above team. Loads were carried to the Youngster's pass. The equipment of the first part of the ridge is done, until the foot of the "Buttress Head." The ridge is sometimes overhanging but without major difficulties.

Saturday, Oct 31st:

C3 is installed. Frederic Vallet as head-man equipped the remaining part of the ridge toward the Buttress Head. C3 is installed just under it. Michel Vincent, Elisabeth Julliard and Henri Sigayret followed F. Vallet and all of them installed C3.

Tuesday, Nov 3rd:

Elisabeth Julliard, Henri Sigayret, Frederic Vallet, Michel Vincent left C2. They carried the gear for an attempt to the summit (tents, ropes, food, gas). They slept at C3.

Wednesday, Nov 4th (camp 3):

The four mountaineers left for C4. The Buttress Head has been reached rapidly. Then we crossed down toward the foot of the Lace Ridge. At the foot of this ridge strong blast of wind and clouds prevent the mountaineers from going up. A tent has been installed. Bivouac.

Thursday, Nov 5th:

The wind was less strong. We went up the Lace Ridge, then crossed the throne glacier. We climbed up the glacier until 7000m (its the foot of the ice face which leads to the ridge which is the remainder of the ascent).

- In the Lace Ridge: some passages are steep and very steep
- Throne Glacier:    easy but tiresome.

The four mountaineers are in their tent at C4.

Friday, Nov 6:

It has been decided to attempt to reach the summit directly from C4. Unfortunately, we go up too late. We left at about 8:30. We climbed up the ice slope where the French set up their C6 in 1962 (no fixed rope has been installed).

Above this camp, at the end of the very fine ridge Elisabeth Julliard and Henri Sigayret decided to turn back. It is 2 am. They started to have frostbites. The wind was blowing strongly. We had no extra ropes. (Both roped parties used 7 mm ropes). They went down to C4 being roughly handled by the wind.

Frederic Vallet and Michel Vincent went on to the summit. They came back at night and they reached C4 at 11 pm. The four mountaineers had frostbites.

Saturday, Nov 7th:

Frederic Vallet and Michel Vincent came down to C2. Elisabeth Julliard and Henri Sigayret slept at C3 which they cleared the following day.

Sunday, Nov 8th:

All the four mountaineers, the two Sherpas, Dawa and Mane, who were at C2 went down to the upper base camp.

Monday, Nov 9th:

All the team headed toward Ghunsa.

Some Comments

The Youngster's Spur: this spur would have required some extra gear, more time, and another head roped party.

The route that we took: the French route of 1962 is a very difficult route; in case of bad weather it may be dangerous to turn back for a light team and if the route is not equipped properly.

This route is beautiful. The only dangerous passage is situated under C2 (passage in the seracs). This passage is rather short.

SPONSOR: Fukuoka Tozan Kemkyu Kai Dhaulagiri Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7050m due to lack of rope for fixing and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4650m at normal site below icefall
C1 near Col
C2 on NE Ridge
High point on NE Ridge.

Icefall very difficult this season and needed 1000m fixed ropes so took long time to reach C1. Fixed rope to 7050m on 6th Oct and down to C2 and C1 for rest. 11th Oct up from C2 to make C3 but snow bridge at 6750m broken and rope gone and down to C1 and climb finished: no rope, no time and only making route for E Face who also came to NE Ridge so "no heart" to continue climb. An avalanche on 30th Sep caused by Americans took out Japanese rope. Snow bridge probably broken by opening of crevasse: many crevasses this season, many opening up while team was on mountain. Planned C3 at 7400m but not possible to fix rope this high to make summit attack from this camp. 3 left BC 14th Oct. Had taken 2000m of rope but did not have enough.
ACCIDENTS: Sirdar pulmonary edema; others hurt hand; Mitoma sick 1st 2 weeks at BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to route too difficult for solo
ROUTEMEMO:
BC north of Gokyo for SE Face-Lungsampa Glacier
C1 at Lungsampa Glacier
C2 on S Ridge.

From BC cross glacier and saw 10 avalanches, on one day on SE Face. So LO agrees to change of route. Then came 1-1/2m snow in big snowstorm of 18-19th and waited 2 days before going up on snow ridge to difficult rock on Polish route. Much wind so from 7400m back to 6600m that same night (23 Oct). From 7400m very difficult long climb which can not climb alone to top safely and had sensitive toes from earlier climbs. Left BC BC 4 Nov but "alone is nice" solo climbing.
ACCIDENTS: Friedrich acclimatization problem and never reached BC

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near Kalapattar
C1 at SW Ridge Col (start of difficulties)
C2 at 50m west side of ridge in crevasse.

On 18th made depot at C2 site for acclimatization. Had to dig a little to find it after snowstorm 19-20th. Between C1 and C2 steep mixed climbing. Japanese had done German's route and fixed rope but cut the ropes in places, Germans did some fixing where Japanese ropes could not be used.

Had problems with Japanese who should have been on South Ridge (Germans saw permitted route in tourism ministry) but were on German's SW Ridge when Germans arrived. Japanese BC right next to Germans BC. At end of their climb, Japanese opened their big unused gas bottles making Knappe vomit. Japanese cut small pieces from their fixed ropes; were generally unpleasant. French were very friendly.
ACCIDENTS: Holzer had some illness in C1 on 22nd Oct & badly injured ankle on trek

ROUTEMEMO:
BC above Gorakshep
C2 at South Ridge col
C4 in snow hole.

After made C4, removed C3. Made C3 because was long route which was very steep mixed rock, snow and ice. Fixed 3000m rope from 5500m almost entire route to top (from snow hole to top put in rope so able to find route on descent in clouds). From C2 to C3 avalanche caused Nima Rita to fall and broke arm on 4th October.
ACCIDENTS: 1 Sherpa broken arm, 1 Sherpa stomach problem, so both left expedition early

SPONSOR: Hiroshi Aota Dhaulagiri S Face Solo Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 4300m due to dangerous avalanching
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  near Polish aut 1986 site
ABC on bottom of glacier.

After ABC established did acclimatization climb to 5500m on point 6620 on 9th Oct. Plan was route up center of S Face, but 2-3 big avalanches daily and many small avalanches, so no climbing on Dhaulagiri I at all and on 10th Oct returned to BC from ABC and left BC 14th Oct. Winter season would be better time to try this face, but not sure he wants to come to it again.

SPONSOR: Fukui Alpine Club Nepal Himalaya Expedition 1987 to Ganesh V
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at foot of South Ridge
ABC stone house
C1  on South Ridge
TC2 on South Ridge
C3  on South Ridge.

C2 to C3 very long way established needed C2 (tramp C2 which sometimes slept in). From C3 to top steep snow with overhanging rock face. Fixed rope above C1 to C2 1050m; TC2 to C2 750m; C2 to C3 750m; C3 to top 450m: total 3000m because could not climb on ridge itself much of the time but had to traverse back and forth across it.

500m fixed rope used by Sherpas. Route not difficult. Kazuyuki Takahasi made 10-minute parapente descent from very near summit to BC. The Kamoshika Dojin team, led by Michiko Takahashi succeded to climb the Cho Oyu summit from Tibetan side.

Summit Sherpas:  
  Nima Dorji (summited Lhotse spr 1985)
  Lhakpa Tenzing (summited Everest spr 1973)
  Ang Dawa and Mingma Tenzing (1st 8000m summit for both)
  Ang Phurba?

TERMNOTE: Had permit but did not climb
ROUTEMEMO: Did no actual climbing. Wanted to go around to NE Ridge but porters ill equiped and park officials made movement difficult and then snowstorm hit and that finished any hope of climbing. Did move around somewhat in waist-deep snow. Had no fixed BC. Had one Sherpa with them in exploration. Schmitz and Calonica were to be the only climbers; the others were support trekkers. Did some exploration of Jagdula Khola.

SPONSOR: Khatang Expedition of the University of Bern
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4800m at Isho Og Lake's SE end
C1 at flat place of glacier NE of peak
C2 at rock on ridge above col.

From C1 route goes over 5700m col to 20m rock on NE Ridge where C2 pitched. Next 10 days: fixed rope and explored C2 site (thought might be at 6000m). Very difficult 300m snow ridge from 6200-6300m altitude. Route mostly 20m on to East Face from ridge using itself only short sections because more difficult and slower going. Had to fix rope on easiest possible route because members were clients and not so experienced climbers. Kobler did all route making and rope fixing. Total 2000m rope fixed including 150m to C1 and from just below Col to 6320m and 120m above 6320m.
ACCIDENTS: Walter serious edema Oct 1, but recovered and returned to climb

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6145m due to lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC just above Langshisa Jhang (same as Japanese)
C1 near col at start of ridge
C2 at ridge running SE from summit 6145m and very near this summit
High point on SW Summit.

No time to go on to highest summit because had had to spend lot of time in KTM with govt routine and time running out. 2 members had chest problems and snowblindness and dropped out of climb. Jez had left on 20th Oct due to other commitments, so little personnel left. Had to fix rope on ridge above C1 and C2: 700m because very sharp narrow snow-ice and rock ridge between 11-22 Oct. 1.20m new snow in storm of 18-20 Oct followed by lot of avalanching but ridge route most affected except C1 covered by snow though tents not damaged. Beyond SW Summit it is posssible to reach highest summit but one 200m section vertical; there were serious seracs about midway between the summits. Perhaps only 2 more days climbing to highest summit and back to C2 in an alpine-style climb. All team members left BC 27th Oct except Jez, who had to leave early.
ACCIDENTS: Bartos and Paszek chest and eye problem

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7000m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal Lhotse Shar BC site beside Lhotse Shar Glacier
C1 at normal C1 site (platforms are there)
C2 on SE Ridge
High point on SE Ridge.

Above C1 had cave where had stash of supplies but not a permanently fixed camp. Occupied it 1st on 17th and down 18th. Back up to cave 26th. On 27th at 7000m, avalanched an hour before Spaniards were higher up. This was highest point. Down to BC, up to C1, down, up to C2 again 7th Oct and again very nearly to 7000m but snow conditions so very dangerous (unconsolidated snow with 4-inch slab above it) came down again and asked to change route to Spaniards' route.

Permit for route change took 8 days and then storm hit, dumped huge amount of snow at BC where Burgess's tent buried in 1-1/2m of snow and would not have survived. Others had similar devastation from avalanching that fatally hit Island Peak, so climb finished when learned of Island Peak disaster.

SPONSOR: Massana Expedition to the Himalaya - to Lhotse Shar
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to death of four members
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lhotse Shar Glacier east of Island Peak
C1 at Col between Island Peak and South Ridge
C2 on South Ridge
C3 on South Ridge
C4 at junction of S and SE Ridge.

Most difficult section was very steep ridge with much snow and ice with a little exposed rock between C1 and C4. Fixed 2500m between C1 and C4 and 1000m more needed to C5 at 7900-8000m where seracs were seen in this section. On 27th Sep 4 members who had pitched C4 went up from C4 with all equipment from C4 to pitch biv camp at C5 site while other four from C2 to C3 and to make new C4 so could not see higher foursome as they moved up; had radio contact in morning and higher group said they were moving up. On 29th searchers found steps to about 7450m and wind slab avalanches sign on right side of SE Ridge and others in BC saw bodies. Doctor went to them and buried bodies seen, 3 high searchers climbed to 7800m, called off due to grief.
ACCIDENTS: Death of four members by avalanche

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4600m at north side of Jannu Glacier
C1 at 5500m on river, on 1st steep rock section.

Oefner left Biv2 (7250m) 10-11 Oct midnight and on top 6:30 am 11th Oct, returned to Biv2 where Van Sprang was with frostbite on both feet. Other 2 summiters left Biv2 6 am 13th Oct and 1:30 pm on top, left top at 3:30 pm after making many photos and returned to Biv2 4:30 pm 11th Oct. On descent Oefner and Van Sprang bivouacked at about 6500m, 12th Oct Van Sprang and Oefner to BC. 

14th Oct 11:30 am De Koning and Friele left Biv2 and 6 pm last radio contact at 8 pm as per schedule and believe were hit by avalanche sometime before 7 pm. On 15th were seen by Ferry at about 5500m at bottom of N Face; must have been avalanche because they were abseiling down and when found were not on same rope. 

Technically difficult: Wall of Shadows steep ice - most difficult section below C2 and same difficult rock pitches below C1. Fixed about 1300m rope (French fixed rope of first part of route).
ACCIDENTS: Friele HAPE in C2; Van Sprang frostbite
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Dutch attempt and ascent; unclimbed route

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 5100m at west side of Lhotse Nuptse Glacier, east of a Col
Biv at 6000m on SE Spur (same route as Jeff Lowe)
Biv at 6100m on SE Spur
Biv at 6300m on SE Spur
Biv at 6500m on SE Spur
High point at SE spur.

1st attack on mountain 4 Oct and reached 5900-6000m. Slept there but bad weather and down next morning. 2nd attack 7 Oct started 1:00 from BC and arrived 6000m first day and 4 bivouacs above. 10 Oct climbed to 6700m but much snow on the rock above 6200m and snow was soft (Jeff Lowe had bare rock). In steep parts bad snow, not so difficult parts, snow waist deep. 12 Oct down to BC and climb abandoned in view of fact weather going to continue bad.

After made BC, made visit to Everest BC to look at north face of Nuptse for possible descent route.

APPROACH: Gokyo to and across Nangpa La
ROUTEMEMO:
Had acclimatization on Lobuje East to summit, then went straight through Gokyo to Cho Oyu climb 27th Sept. Slept at Lunag at 5070m on Lunag glacier before start of ascent on 28th Sept. Climbed to top in 2 days in very good weather with strong wind at summit (went to both summits). No problems at all during climb: no technical problems no ill health and good weather. Had 2 sleeping bags and Polish tent without cover, no rope at all.

It was an unauthorized attempt.

1500m rope fixed by Batard with 5 Sherpas carrying rope from 5700m to 6550m after storm on 21st. 24th Oct down to BC. 25th Batard and 3 Sherpas up the mountain climb from 4:45 am, on top 12:30 pm and back at BC at 4 pm in some difficulty because had been working on the day before. Other members got to 6200m and 6400m on 26th with Sherpas carrying tent to make a camp at 6200m, but at 6200m most members wanted to go back because of some illness and difficulty of climb. Route was as same as Americans last winter.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6800m due to snowstorm
ROUTEMEMO:
BC a little above junction of glaciers
C1 at Chago Glacier
C2 at 6550m Chago Glacier
High point at Chago Glacier.

Wanted to go to top from C2 several times carrying loads and acclimatizing. 13th Oct 4 members to 6800m in summit bid; too tired and down to BC for safety with decision to stop climb because of snow and not time enough for late attempt. 

Obert and Saint-Martin left BC on 15th to descend for they were tired. Went with head cook and Louis Dollo to go to Tashigaon. Reached Mumbuk on 18th; 19th morning raining heavily that became snowstorm at higher altitude. 1 porter with them lost his way and died of exhaustion and exposure. 2nd porter died on trail for same reason. Jacques Saint-Martin fell down from exhaustion and very cold wind and slightly ill. 20th his body found by trekking group and buried in cave with rocks over it.

** 1 Rai above BC
ACCIDENTS: Obert heart problem; 1 member and 2 porters died on return from BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to steep, rotten rock
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at left (east) moraine of Saipal Glacier
C1 below West Ridge on glacier (Firnkopf Glacier)
C2 below West Ridge on glacier
C3 on West Ridge after having ascended Firnkopf Glacier's face.

Tried for 1 week to climb W Ridge. Snowstorm 18-20th Oct made team descended to BC and waited there for it. Had to make new route in deep snow. 25th Oct from C3 to Firnkopf (named by Austrians in 1954, means snow hat) at 6630m and turned back to C3. 26th to BC. Porters ordered for 27th and left BC 27th. Had lost some time on approach march: expected it to take 8 days but took 14 days. This route easiest to climb Saipal from south but would take 2 more weeks via W Col. In to Saipal's immediate route: no avalanche danger even after snowfall via this route to Firnkopf. Returned from BC via Kandha and Dhuli to Chainpur from where flew to KTM on scheduled flight. Fixed 50m rope between C1 and C2 on glacier and 50m more from C2 to C3 on glacier.

Remaking route was difficult because of many crevasses covered by powder snow.


Following is from a letter to E. Hawley from Franz Kroell:

In 1987 we went to Nepal with the permit for climbing Saipal from the south: 2nd of October we start in Kathmandu (by plane to Pokhara, with lorry to Phurbe). From Phurbe (5th October) by foot (end of the road) to Chainpur (possible by plane) and to the BC 17th of October). 18th - 20th of October we climbed on the SW Face of Saipal up to 6200m (steep; rotten rock).

Then we focused our interest to the opposite side, to the West Ridge from Westlicher Firnkopf (Western Firnkopf) to Ostlicher Firnkopf (Eastern Firnkopf). The height of these two mountains is correct in your map (Austrian Saipal Expedition about 1950; Rudolph Jonas, Vienna).

On 25th of October we climbed Westlicher Firnkopf (Fritz Mross, Germany; Ang Chopal, Nepal; Franz Kroell, Austria). We climbed from BC up an easy icefall, crossed this icefall and climbed up to the main ridge and followed exact the ridge to the very top of Westlicher Firnkopf. We stopped climbing on the summit and did not follow the ridge to Ostlicher Firnkopf and to Saipal.

The climb up to Westlicher Firnkopf is an easy climb (Grade I and II/UIAA ice and snow up to 65 degrees, short fixed sections with few meters of rope crossing the glacier. 

Far more difficult is the walk in to BC, especially the last three days. Its extremely difficult to find a trail for the porters; bears and mountain sheep are living near BC.

There are some existing routes to climb Mt. Saipal:
  West Face of Saipal (Spanish)
  West Ridge (over Westlicher and Ostlicher Firnkopf)
  NE Ridge 
  (Maybe SE Ridge, East Face??)

We climbed Saipal in the autumn of 1990 by the NE Ridge, flying to Simikot and walking in by Chala and the Kherang Khola to BC.
ACHIEVMENT: Reached point known as Westlicher Firnkopf on W Ridge (unknown if Jonas' Austrian team reached this point in 1954)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to route impossible without rope
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  same as Dhaulagiri I BC
C1  on East Ridge of South Col (this ridge not followed all the way to high point)
Biv on South Ridge.
High point on South Ridge leading to East Ridge.

Before storm climbed Dhampus Peak, Delcasso, Rouys and Sirdar Kami Tenzing 17th Oct and 18th Oct. Delcasso and Sherpa to point 6227m on 18th Oct. Cabanne and Rouys for acclimatization and 5 other members had altitude sickness and went down below Dhampus Pass. 19th snowstorm so other 5 never joined climb. 

4 members went to Sita Chuchura. 26th Rouys climbed up alone, arrived East Ridge at 6100m to look for good route because big icefall problem. From down below could see good route: ridge descends to icefall and this icefall not possible for 4 members only and no fixed ropes. All down to BC, but on 27th all 3 (except Delcasso) and sirdar to dome while Delcasso went to look for others. This time saw good route on E Face on other side of icefall. 28 and 29th Rouys and Kami started early in morning with tent and 2 days supply to try this route: down to Dhamla Glacier to find icefall route - down to 4600m and find one way to cross icefall from Sita Chuchura south side. Climbed rock ridge and spent one night at 5400m on this ridge and next day (29th) reached end of rock ridge via difficult sector and top of big rock was ice, so crossed below the ice cornice; here slab avalanche danger. Arrived at pass just below Sita Chuchura summit but this last ice face not possible without fixed rope. Descended to BC. All in BC 30 Oct.

BC between Dhampus and French Passes on east side of start of ridge feeding NW
   Ridge
C1 at junction of North and NW Ridge
C2 on NW Ridge.

Weather very good. Snowed during acclimatization period only. Not difficult because snow good and skied up from C1 to C2 and skied down same sector. All members did this skiing and so did sirdar Wangchu Sherpa.

Did not ski to and from BC because no snow there nor above C2 because terrain too difficult for skiing.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8000m due to ice falling and slight frostbite
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 above icefall on plateau below Col
C2 on NE Col
C3 on NE Ridge
Biv on NE Ridge
Biv on NE Ridge
High point at snowfield.

All climbed NE Ridge because E Face too dangerous from big slabs of ice which broke and fell. C1 establish only on 21st Sept because 3 members had dysentery and C3 only 10th Oct because Terradez bronchitis. Summit push by Hernandez and Terradez from C2 on 10th Oct. 13th Oct reached big snowfield where Hernandez hit by block of ice and fell 50m rope together but not hurt. Decided to give up because of this and fact that on 11th was very windy and they got frostnip. Slept at 7400m bivouac that night. Next night at C3; no further attempt to scale mountain. 

Diez had foot infection for one month and Tejedor not well acclimatized.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Dyazumpa west side of Lungsampa Glacier near junction with Ngozumpa Glacier
High point at 4 biv by all three members.

From 8th to 16th bad weather. On 16th reached 6300m on region for acclimatization, but too much dangrous snow to go higher to top of point 6500m due south of Cho Oyu. On 17th started up Cho Oyu (all 3 members). Then as got high, encountered waist-deep snow: wind-blown powdered snow, also very hot. Climbed from 7400m to 7600m in night, and feared starting avalanches. On 21st down to BC. 30th Sept up from BC all 3 members and went to 6600m in night. 1st Oct 6:00 pm up to 7100m on same route. Slept till early morning 2nd Oct and then saw too dangerous from avalanching above and returned to BC. Then more snow and more wind from north so no further chance of success. Route is very good with less snow. Route to the right (as you look at mountain) of Nairz-Koblmueller-Messner route.

Joos feared he had pulmonary edema when descended on 21st Sept to 6600m and asked for helicopter but after slept there, was better, down to BC 22nd and called off helicopter and was strong enough after medications to resume climb, but still today not fully recovered so did not go Everest. Other 2 members went to Everest BC perhaps only to visit.

Climbed German 1980 route and kept under central summit. New variation of routes on face; not exactly to French route high on mountain. Did not send more to top because too dangerous from avalanches of snow and of rock which came very near climbers several times and because very cold. Not much wind problem. Problem about 2 Sherpas at time of summit attack: they should have moved to C5 to help summiters descend but on attack day went down to C2 instead, so 2nd attack team had to support 1st one instead of making own attack.
ACCIDENTS: None except stomach problems; 1 member hepatitis

ROUTEMEMO:
BC above Samagaon
C1 above yak herders huts
C2 on snowfield at bottom of icefall
C3 on col (very windy site)
C4 above rock ridge on face.

Bad weather (deep snowfall and avalanches) after C2 established so had to wait before making C3. From C2 to C3 problem then icefall and not possible to ski up through this area so all skies left in C2. Snow not good for sking. Summiters left C4 5:30 am and on top at 12:00 noon in very cold wind and down to C3 at 5:00 pm. 

No more summit bids because cold wind. 3 members sick in BC from altitude. Doctor not keen on climbing: team strength dwindling and Arthur Haid worried about old frostbite problem he has.
ACCIDENTS: Hauser little frostbite; 3 members altitude sickness; no accidents

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4500m at normal site
C1 at 5200m before plateau (normal site).

C2 pitched 28th Sep, but not slept in till summit push under way begining 5th Oct when pushed straight through through with series of bivouacs till reached summit on 11th. Had done acclimatization climbing before push. Technical problems between C2 and bivouacs at 6700m with danger of avalanche below 1st bivouac. Above 1st bivouac many seracs. 11th Oct very cold wind, crampons (coming off and while putting back on, fingers frostbitten) during descent. Perez and Kaji also toes frozen on 12th when took off snow boots (Gomez toes slightly frozen). Kaji (a friend) was member of team and ate same food, etc.
ACCIDENTS: All 3 summiters frostbitten toes and fingers; BC cook may have cerebral edema

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  west side of Lungsampa Glacier, north of a lake and SE of point 5360m 
    on Schneider map
ABC north of point 5420m, east of point 6088m, southwest point 5695m
C1  at plateau just NE of point 6073m and slightly lower
C2  east of point 6515m
C3  just below S Ridge of Ngojumba Kang II
C4  on South Ridge.

Route from BC led into Ngojumba Glacier. Ridge is 45-50 degrees steepness and real snow climbing with problem of wind. More technical problems between ABC and C2: rock 350m face above ABC which needed fixing rope and above C1 had abseil down from plateau to glacier couloir. Had thought to try to go to Ngojumba C3 on 13th Nov because of strong wind (Alikalfic was blown over twice on S Ridge). Route to C3 from C2 looked easy snow flank, quite broad.

Berljak left expedition early. He was organizer of expedition, is able to get funds, but now-a-days doesn't climb.

BC at normal site Yalung Glacier
C3 on Great Shelf.

Icefall and 2 snow faces above BC below C1. Above C1 there were not the expected crevasses and bridges not needed. Made new C4 because were able to place C4 so high. Between 18 and 27th Dec, snowfall, strong winds and difficult climbing around many crevasses. 2nd Jan summit bid from C4 over long distance: left C4 6:00 am and on summit 5:10 pm by Lee Jeong-Chel with oxygen and returned to C4 at 9:00 pm on 1st Jan. Lee Joo-I tried without oxygen starting 4 am but at 8400m 2 toes each foot freezing so turned back at 3 pm and toes okay with treatment. Lee Jeong-Chel used oxygen on 2nd Jan intermitently. 3 Sherpas with him carrying one oxygen bottle with last of them turning back at 8400m; Lee took switches of oxygen and continued to do so while alone above 8400m. After 2 Jan, Lee needed help to treat freezing toes and weather not so good, so all members descended 3 Jan and climb finished.

Lee Sung-Ho died from drinking bad water on approach march with "big stomach" and much diarrhea with blood and died below BC at Kunjari 11 Dec after 5 days illness; Dil Bahadur Rai died 10 Dec of altitude sickness after carrying load to BC on 9th Dec.
ACCIDENTS: Lee Song-Ho chest illness and never reached BC (sick at low BC and below)

SPONSOR: 1987-88 Korean Winter Cho Oyu-Ngojumba Kang Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lungsampa Glacier's west edge, NE of point 5360m
C1 near "west" of black type Lungsampa
C2 north (above) point 6515m on S Face
C3 on SE Face of Ngojumba Kang I
C4 on SE Face.

1st summit attack on 10th Feb, but very difficult with crevasses and icefall and strong wind and very cold; turned back at 7500m. 

11th 6 am start from C4 and on top 4:30 pm (stayed 20 minutes for photos) and back in C4 7:20 pm. Had tried from Ngojumba top to go to Cho Oyu 1 hour and clouds coming with weather change and were told to return to C4. 

12th 6 am Cho Oyu attack again tried but weather bad and returned from 7600m and down to C4 that day and on to BC 13th. All climbers to BC on 13th and 14th left BC. 
Total 2000m fixed rope (C1 to C3 and just below summit). Very very difficult: very steep-stone avalanching every day; rock band above C4.

Only attempt to go to Cho Oyu was made on 12 Feb from Ngojumba summit.
ACHIEVMENT: 1 winter ascent Ngojumba in 1st Korean attempt

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6115m due to shortage of supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4115m left bank of Annapurna Sanctuary Glacier
C1 at moraine foot of glacier of Glacier Dome
C3 on snow ridge at top of rock buttress.

Storm coming as made C3 and went down to BC. Then storm over in 2 days, were below avalanche slopes and had to wait for avalanching to stop, but were now running out of supplies so climb over. A dangerous face on which must pick route carefully.
