Canadian $28,000 total budget including airfare meant sparse supplies. Rather difficult rock climbing of 1200 ft on rock buttress - ice climbing not so difficult as the rock. Fixed 4000 ft (1300m) rope through icefall between C2 and C3 and then all of rock buttress and sections of snow and ice above buttress to C3 - icefall has unstable seracs. Fixed ropes cut 3 times a day: very dangerous icefall. 4 members got caught in avalanche between BC and C1 during storm on 15th in descent but not hurt though Reville had to be dug out. Adamson caught in rockfall but only bruised. No one really wanted to go through these dangerous areas. Reville left immediately after was dug out. Robertson left before climb was over, about 6 Dec; had not expected to do much climbing.

BC at Mingbo BC.
 
Tawoche was to have been attempted before Ama Dablam but was not because of deep snow at base of mountain and no ice in couloir which had planned to climb (all bare rock).

All summiters banned from Nepal climbing for 5 years because they climbed before winter season began.


Final Expedition Report - Dec 4, 1987

Report of Safety Conditions and Reports from other Post Monsoon Expeditions.

Chronology of Approach - Sept 29 Clay Wadman flew KTM to Lukla. Nov 3 Todd Bibler, Eric Reynolds, Sandy Stewart and Michael Dimitri flew to Lukla. On Nov 6 these five members banded together in Namche Bazar. Meanwhile, on Nov 6 Annie Whitehouse left KTM to Jiri by bus with 11 trekkers. She was leading a trek to Kalapattar. The group of five climbers proceded to Pheriche on the 10th of Nov. Our original plan and permit called for an attempt on Tawoche (6542m). Several days routes and conditions on Tawache made, on Nov 14-16. Plans for an ascent of Tawoche were abandoned as it was clearly unsafe. On Nov 17 the team decided to move on to our second objective, the ascent of Ama Dablam (6856m). First, we moved to Mingbo base camp on Nov 18-19. Then our intention was to conduct a reconnaissance of the route on Ama Dablam, in the hope of discovering safer conditions than on Taweche. Since we had already at this point forfeited our Tawoche permit and it looked like a similar situation was on Ama Dablam, all members were discouraged.

Immediately upon arrival in Nepal we heard about the huge 2-meter snowstorm of late October. Enroute to Pheriche we had the chance to meet and talk first hand to members of five expeditions to peaks in the near vicinity of our objectives. (South Face of Nuptse, South Face of Lhotse Shar, Ama Dablam North Ridge, Ama Dablam NW Ridge and Ama Dablam SW Ridge). All these expeditions had failed and had retreated in the face of many avalanches, deep unconsolidated snow, and the belief and these were among the most serious and dangerous conditions they had encountered. We also, of course, were very discouraged and saddened to hear of the deaths of twelve climbers and trekkers in the Khumbu and an additional ten in nearby Tibet - all as a result of the big storm and resulting conditions.

Todd Bibler and Sandy Stewart on the 14th to 16 on Nov found several approaches to Tawoche to have deep unconsolidated granular snow. This type of snowpack is familiar to us as being a particularly dangerous condition, know as temperature gradient snow. Several of the expedition members have Professional Avalanche Forecasting experience in Colorado. We have seen these type of conditions there frequently associated with major avalanches and also know that it is a condition that can take many weeks, even months, to stablize. To make conditions for climbing even more hazardous in our opinion was a period of sunny weather which causes a thin melted smooth glaze to appear on the surface of the snowpack. In this case, even a snowfall from a new storm or windblown snow, can cause avalanche as it is such a smooth sliding surface.

Summary of Ascent Details - Because of the above conditions we approached the mountain with great care, respect and even fear. On Nov 20 Sandy Stewart and Eric Reynolds as one party and Todd Bibler and Michael Dimitri as a second party left Mingbo base camp (15,000 ft) with full loads to break a trail through deep snow to C1. As our BC was lower than that used by many, we were faced about 10 km of hard trudging. We intended to cache loads and prepare the route for a later ascent. On the 21st of Nov, Michael and Todd descended because of Michael's feeling of illness. Stewart and Reynolds continued route preparation from C1 to C2. Upon reaching C2 they observing high winds blowing off the summits of the Thamserku and Kangtega, as well as "meretails" and large lenticular clouds building on the summit of Mt. Everest. Both knew from previous Nepal and MT Everest experience that this almost always meant a storm approaching. Believing that this strong wind would destroy any possibility of a safe ascent they decided to go for the summit as quickly as possible.

C3 was established by Stewart and Reynolds at 20,500 ft on Nov 22. They climbed to the summit and returned for another night at C3 on Nov 23. (It is important to say that the summit day of climbing is very steep and that there is no chance to belay or use safety anchors. Because of this it is especially vulnerable to the surface glaze avalanche conditions we described).

Meanwhile, Annie Whitehouse had arrived at Mingbo BC, having been delayed by poor road conditions to Jiri and the evacuation of an ill trekker. On Nov 23 Wadman and Whitehouse left BC and acclimatized a night on open snowfields at 17,000 ft. On the 24th Stewart and Reynolds met Wadman to immediately go on towards the summit because of the continuing threatening weather conditions. Ropes were in place, camp platforms dug, and key supplies left behind (tent, stove, food) to aid them. On Nov 25 Whitehouse and Wadman made their camp 3 at 20,000 ft. On 26th they summited at noon in very cold, windy extreme conditions. Their descent to BC was made on the 27th.

Todd Bibler seeing the deteriorating weather conditions made a bold quick solo ascent on the 25th and 26th.

All members assembled together at BC for celebration to a safe ascent on the 28th. BC was abandoned on the 30th of Nov.

C1 above NE Col at start of NE Ridge (in ice cave)
C2 on East Face just near ridge (again ice cave).

Took special ice cutting tool from Chamonix to make huge ice cave at C1 and C2; only little fixed rope in place so put over 2000m of rope from 6600m to 7600m for Sherpas and other French members. Batard to BC 29th Nov, rested at BC 30th Nov and 1st Dec and up from BC with 2 French and 4-5 Sherpas. Batard and Sungdare to C2 on 1st Dec, other 4-5 climbers to C1. 2nd Dec Batard and Sungdare at 5:30 am from C2 and reached top 12:30 pm and to C3. 3rd Dec down from C2 to BC. Other French did not go above C1 because of some illness and some not psychologically prepared to tackle seracs and crevasses of Dhaulagiri. Batard tried on 6th Dec for top but wind too strong to reach C2. Batard left BC 8th Dec and others on 9th Dec.
ACCIDENTS: Marcelot altitude sickness; Sungdare some frostbite (fingers & toes) but will heal

SPONSOR: Fernando Garrido Winter Expedition Cho Oyo
ROUTEMEMO:
1st BC at normal site (west of point 6296m)
2nd BC "g" of Nangpa Glacier
C1  at Gyabrag Glacier (near "a" of Glacier)
C2  at start of West Ridge, just south of point 6446m
C3  very little down on side of major sharp West Ridge.

"I did it" - Tenzing helped me to make C1 and then I climbed alone. I went slowly, took 4 days". 29th Garrido went alone with gear for C2 and slept there, came down to BC on 30th. 1st Feb started up from BC with Tenzing to C1 (Tenzing and runner carried food supplies while Garrido carried no load). (24th-26th new BC destroyed by wind). 1st Feb slept in C1. 2nd Feb Garrido started solo push leaving Tenzing to wait and take photos with long lens (route not visible from BC). Garrido slept in C2 2nd and rested there on 3rd because too windy to continue upwards. 4th Slept in movable tent at 7000m. 5th tried to go to top but too late start (at 9:00 am) and went only tp 7600m before returning to C3 at 7000m. 6th started up again, this time with sleeping bag (without food, drink, fuel) and left sleeping bag and rucksack at 7600m and taking only camera, headlamp and ice axe. Moved very fast towards top and reached summit at 6 pm (found empty oxygen bottle only, no poles. Went all way aroud rim of volcano-like structure). Getting dark at summit; in descent could follow own tracks to rocky barrier where had some trouble but reached sleeping bag at 10 pm. Had been very windy all day and throughout night but not too cold and had rock protection. 7th to C3 only beaues very tired. 8th to C1 and fixed no ropes so had problems descending to rocky areas - also had only ice axe.
 
Wants next climb also solo on 8000er: "I don't like to climb with people."

This was the first winter solo ascent of any 8000er and the first solo of Cho Oyu.

Garrido crossed the Nangpa La from Nepal into Tibet and scaled the standard (Tichy) route entirely alone from his C1 at 5850m on the Gyabrag Glacier near the site of advance base camps for many teams starting from within Tibet. Two Nepalis had helped him establish and stock C1, and one of them remained in that camp to take photos with a long lens while Garrido made his summit push. He started up on 2nd Feb, climbed to his C2 at 6400m to where he alone had previously carried its gear, and slept there two nights, waiting for the winds to abate. On the 4th he moved up with a tent to 7000m and slept there, and on the 5th tried to go to the summit. But he had made too late a start on the 5th (he did not move till 9:00 am) and went to only 7600m before retreatng to C3 at 7000m. On the 6th he left C3 at 7:30 am, took no tent, food or fuel but only a sleeping bag, which he left at 7600m. From there he continued up with only a camera, headlamp and one ice axe. He moved very fast towards the summit, went all the way around the summit rim to make sure he reached the very highest point, which he reached at about 6:00 pm. In his descent, although it was now getting dark, he could follow his own tracks until he reached a rock barrier, where he had trouble finding his way. He had fixed no rope, but managed at 10:00 pm to find his sleeping bag and bivouaced at 7600m. It was very windy all the day and the wind continued throughout the night, but he had protection from the rock, and the temperature was not extremely low; he did not get frostbitten. On the 7th he went down only as far as C3 at 7000m because of exhaustion, but on the 8th he rejoined his Sherpa at C1. He claimed the first winter solo ascent of any 8000m mountain and the first solo of Cho Oyu.
ACCIDENTS: No frostbite ("I was afraid of it but I got none")
ACHIEVMENT: 1st winter solo of any 8000er, 1st solo of Cho Oyu

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to lack of rope above high point
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Khyumu Glacier at head of Khyumu Khola, south of mountain
C1 on SW Ridge
C2 on SW Ridge
C3 on SW Ridge.

Tried S Face only one day and big ice avalanche came down when hanging glacier's top broke off leaving rest of it to threaten falling (no one hurt) so changed route to SW Ridge. High point at 5800m because fixed rope finished (had used up 3000m of rope) and needed 3000m more because of many rock pinnacles necessary to go up to top of and then down again. Ridge almost old rock with some snow. 

Had planned to follow Japanese 1978 Autumn route via ridge to S Face but did not get on to face (did not get to that point to that ridge).

SPONSOR: Gunma Mtng Federation Annapurna I S Face Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
Changed C3 site twice because stone and snow avalanche. 1st one pitched 6th Dec, but one member Sato hit in leg by big stone and stopped climbing.

Route above C2 was new and to left of Bonington route: Bonington team was on ridge but "that ridge's left which was a little risky" because of soft ice/hard snow. Difficult climbing was from C3 to C4 because very steep rock and loose rock and often stonefall. 45-50 fixed ropes of 50m from C1 to mini-rockband at 7700m; made route from C4 to mini-rockband in 2 days with about 400m rope here, then to top. 20th Dec 3 men left C2 at 3:40 am and Seagusa at 6 am because headlamp broken and he waited for daylight, joined others at 7700m at 9:40 am; above 7700m slow going (fixed only one rope).

The route was basically the Bonington route of spring 1970, but above C2 at 6100m. Bonington's ridge was "very bad" because of loose powdered snow, so team took a couloir to its left; the couloir itself was a "little risky" because of soft ice/hard snow which was difficult to climb. They rejoined Bonington route at section of all was very steep rock between C3 and C4 (6850m and 7400m); rock was unstable and loose pieces were frequently falling, injuring a member and a Sherpa. The site of C3 was changed twice because of stone fall and snow avalanches. No bottled oxygen was used because their entire supply was in C1 and was swept away by an avalanche early in the climb.

Kobayashi fell to his death at 7900m. Saito fell just 20 meters above C4. Apparently their falls were caused by fatigue.

Accidents besides the fatal falls and Sato's leg was Sherpa's shoulder and head struck by ice 3 Dec avalanche at C1 which took away all oxygen and much fuel, food and gear; but had 2 months supply of food and fuel and many spare pieces of equipment (but not oxygen).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
Had permit for Glacier Dome for acclimatization but made no attempt.

Saegusa had no headlamps so came quickly. Yagihara and Saito down together. 7900m Kobayashi slipped down; maybe snow some places hard and flat and some soft: slipped in bad snow.

Saito very tired; with Yamada on same rope and Yamada at C4 just waited 15 minutes and Saito didn't come. Saegusa saw him fall. Yamada called and Saito answered 2-3 times). Saegusa went to Saito and Saito asked for water and then fell in dark (he had no headlamp); searched but couldn't find him with headlamp.

Planned 2 summit bids but after accident all stopped. 2nd bid to be by Nazuka, Sato and Akuzawa on 22nd Dec.

3rd Dec avalanche lost much equipment and food but no one hurt.


Steve Adamson - 24 Dec 7

Japanese Annapurna I South Face

Adamson left 16 Dec. Japanese planning summit bid 21 Dec. Their C1 had been avalanched twice. Bonington route at higher part. Willing to lose 4 Japanese and 4 Sherpas before giving up - they will make it.
ACCIDENTS: Sato and 1 Sherpa injured by avalanching

APPROACH: Via Langtang Village and Kyanjin Gompa
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Kyanju Gompa lodge
ABC near moraine of Lirung Glacier
C1  at left side of snow couloir coming down from Col
C2  on SE Ridge
C3  on SE Ridge.

Difficult to find site for C2 on very sharp rock-snow ridge. Fixed rope from C1 to C3. Most difficult sector was between C2 and C3 where much moving rock on steep, sharp ridge with serac barrier just before C3. 

2nd summit team [Dudek and Papaj] on 5th Jan tried for top from C3 which they had established on 2nd, gone down to C2; went 100m above C3 on 5th but stopped by wind.

Did not attempt SE Face because not enough snow which meant much falling stone which too dangerous to encounter; perhaps fast alpine-style might be okay. 

Had fine weather throughout climb until 5th Jan. Route from ABC to C1 to left of Japanese 1986 spring route and C1 higher.
ACCIDENTS: Knapczyk hit by falling stone on shoulder and left BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  west of Barun Pokhari (protected from wind but no water)
ABC at mouth of Chago Glacier just north of junction
C1  at small rock rib between the 2 glaciers (standard site route)
C2  at snow cave in small cwm below 6500m Col
C3  at snow cave at beginning of steep section and couloir west of Makalu La
High point at start of NW Ridge. 

Made C2 west of Kangchungtse because too long carries and too much fixed rope for team of only 4 climbing members to go normal route. Above C3 climbed steeper of 2 couloirs by passing Makalu La. Intended to pitch C4 at about 7500m but never actually set up camp. Evans went up on 20th with camp gear and on 22nd retrieved it. In 1st half of January were terrible windstorms and on 12th Jan heavy snowfall. Even in late Jan when clearing mountain, often could not stand up. This is Machnik's 4th winter expedition and never such severe winds; even down to ABC 60-80 mph gusts and at C3 area up to 100 mph and below rocks off mountain. Had lost time early in expedition carrying up equipment for big expedition but only 4 members actually did serious climbing after others claimed illness and stayed on at ABC/BC. 4 members were the real climbers and Jedlinski got fed up and quit early. "Four-man expedition with big anchor behind" (anchor = members at base complaining about supplies and waiting to go home). Doctor not able to climb much because looking after sick men.

Evans went on 22nd from C3 to try for top with biv at 7700m or more and set highest point possible but terrible cold winds (-15 degrees F and constant 60-70 mph).

Sherpas: none above ABC till 3 went to C1 to help clear off gear.

Nine member team soon composed of only four climbing members, mostly because of illness. C2 was pitched in a small cwm west of Kangchungtse directly below 6500m col in ridge between Kangchungtse and Chago because for small team load carries would be too long and too much fixed rope would be needed if they followed standard route exactly. Above C3, they climbed the steeper of two couloirs bypassing Makalu La and intended to place C4 at start of NW Ridge at 7500m, but never actually pitched camp, although Evans dumped supply load at site on 20 Jan. On 22 Jan he returned to 7500m to try for summit with a bivouac at 7700m or higher, but fierce cold winds of up to 100 mph prevented him from doing more than retrieving supplies.
ACCIDENTS: Wesolouski had paratyphoid and Fligiel heart trouble, nothing else
ACHIEVMENT: Brondolin claims Brazilian altitude record of 7200m

ROUTEMEMO:
Face in bad condition: all rock and powder of rock which wind carried and went in to climber's lungs. Had already planned to go from face to NE Ridge at about 6000m and this they did. Did not intend this time to go high on face as in Autumn 1985. Followed 1985 route to 5900m plateau; most of rest of route above was 1981 descent route. Reached normal route at 6000m. Route followed was same as in Spring 1986 with difference, this time route completed. Last 200m was SW, winds up to 200 kph and climbers had to go on hands and knees. 

Belak and Kozjek tried for summit twice [4 Dec and 7 Dec].

Did acclimatization in Dhampus Pass-French pass area on small unnamed peak.
ACCIDENTS: Kozjek developed serious pulmonary edema and had slight frostbite

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to difficulty of route without fixed rope
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site (good: no snow, water is near)
C2 same as French C2
C3 well below French C3.

5th Dec reached 6100m and here route is ice wall and loose rock, but had no rope and pitons so turned back to C1 and 6th Dec to BC. Climb finished. 

Looked at other possible routes, but too difficult for 2 men only. 

Weather very good every day except 3rd Dec when strong wind and little snowfall which wind carried away. Very little snow was on N Face. Many crevasses, very dangerous C1 to C2, 14 big crevasses (1-3m wide with very small snow bridges) and C2 to C3, 3 or 4 big ones. Above C3 to French C4 very difficult ice, no snow at all. Left BC 18th Dec after waiting for porters (12 Dec heavy snowfall).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6750m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at NE Col
C2 on NE Ridge.

After establish C2 avalanching very bad and down on 27th to C1, where spent 5 days and then to BC. Up again 9th Oct to C1, 3 days and reached 100m below C2 on 12th, turned back because snow very deep (to top of legs) and very dangerous from slab avalanches.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m+ due to deep snow and avalanche danger
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 a series of bivs
C3 up West Face.

After initial acclimatization period, the 2 climbing members began their climb of W Face on 3rd Oct. No camps above BC. On 7th day (9th Oct) they reached 7600m, where face ends at ridge; there was a lot of deep snow on the mountain and grave avalanche danger; Jordi decided to descend via North Face (which Dalmases also intended to descend if not the NE Ridge). Jordi came down N Face and reached Lavier's BC on 14th Oct, exhausted and with badly frostbitten toes. Was helicoptered to KTM with Lavier from BC on 17th Oct. Dalmases not seen after Jordi left him; his girl friend waits for him at BC.


Esteve, French military expedition leader - 20 Oct 1989 

2 Spaniards started up on 5th Oct, reached 7600m on 9th. Feet of both men very cold for past 2 days and Jordi wanted to descend from 7600m across N Face whereas Dalmases said that would be fatal, that it would be safer to go to summit and down normal route. It took Jordi 5 days to traverse N Face in a diagonal crossing and was seen from French BC in morning of 14th. He had had with him a tent (which Dalmases did not) plus sleeping bag, stove, gas and food (which Dalmases did). Esteve thinks Dalmases probably became exhausted, rested, fell asleep and froze to death.


Swiss German-Austrian-Mexican Dhaulagiri I Expedition, Spring 1995 led by Norbert Joos

German summiter Albrecht Hamman died near the summit in his decent. His body lies on its back and is seen by most Dhaulagiri I summiters via the NE Ridge.

The father of a Spanish climber, Quico Dalmases, came to believe that this body was that of his son who disappeared when he was climbing alone in the autumn of 1989, and the father, Jaon Dalmases, appealed in the spring of 2007 to climbers that season to check various details to identify the body as that of Quico.

Inaki Ochoa, one of the climbers whom Dalmases asked for help, summited Dhaulagiri I on 26 April 2007, said that the body was that of the German on Norbert Joo's team in the spring of 1995. The kind of crampons worn by the body did not exist in 1989.
ACCIDENTS: Jordi frostbitten toes on both feet; Dalmases disappeared

SPONSOR: Gipuzkopako Expedition Himalaya - to Dhaulagiri I
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to dangerous snow conditions and wind
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at plateau
C2 at NE Col
C3 on NE Ridge near big serac at start of ridge 
High point at C3.

Try 3 times to go to C4. 1st time French Sherpa's fatal accident. Later too much snow and wind very dangerous even above C2. At mountain 40 days and only 2 days of sunshine all day. Glacier from BC to C1 very dangerous with crevasses opening (necessary to change the rope). Fixed 500m rope with French in this section.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site for NE Ridge
C1 just below NE Col
C2 just below steep part of NE Ridge
High point at NE Ridge.

C2 slept in on 24th Sept for first time; next day 2 members & 4 Sherpas up from C2 to reach C3 in snowy weather; at 7100m at 1:00 pm reported by radio they had deposited their loads here, 200m below expected C3 site, because snowfall increasing. 2 Sherpas in descent disappeared; little avalanche pushed 2 members 10-15m while on fixed rope; no trace of Sherpas. Now heavy snowfall; three times up to C1 but snow too deep at col to go higher; last time was 10th Oct. 11th Oct reached C2 in snow up to top of legs. Decided climb too dangerous so dismantled C2.
ACCIDENTS: 1 member Mailly edema; 1 member gastroenteritis (left BC Sep 19); 2 Sherpas fatal avalanche

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to snow conditions and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at col between Tukuche and Dhaulagiri
C2 at beginning of NE Ridge
High point at C2 site.

24th slept in C1; stayed C1 waiting for good weather but snowed everyday and French Military expedition had fatal avalanche. 28th tried to go to C3 to retrieve gear but at 6300m snow conditions too dangerous and descended. 29th to BC. Was snowing again on 28th and 1m deep snow. Left BC 1 Oct. 

Gave up attempt because had to leave Nepal on 12th Oct. Icefall had been well-equipped by time this team arrived.

SPONSOR: Lhotse S Face en Duo - to Dhaulagiri I
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to fierce wind and extreme cold
ROUTEMEMO:
1st attempt Nov up from C2 to see ridge, then down to BC. Placed C3 during 2nd summit bid. 10th Nov too much wind and had to go down after ascending only 100m above C3. 3rd attempt also defeated by wind and cold (-50 degrees).

Summit Attempts
1st:   3-6th Nov - Profit, Lucas and Tavernier (too much snow avalanche)
2nd:  9-10th Nov - Profit and Tavernier to 7200m (wind)
3rd: 13-14th Nov - Lucas and Profit to 7800m (wind and cold)

BC at Kaphe Khola (point 4100m north)
TC on main glacier east of point 4738 at feet of another glaced from Gustang north
C1 just west of base of South Ridge
C2 on North Ridge of Ghustang North - top of rock wall
C3 on West Face of Dhaulagiri III
C4 at top shelf above serac band, WSW of point 6921m
C5 on SE Face-Ridge SE from middle summit.

Very circuitous route because of huge threatening seracs. To get to C5 had to drop down and then go up again second shelf. Was difficulty between every camp and a bit of descent between each camp. Ravens stole food at C4 and C5 leaving 2 men with no food for 2 days.
ACCIDENTS: "We had the odd fall but all intact" though one cracked rib by Roger in descent from top
ACHIEVMENT: 1st British ascent of any Churen Peak

SPONSOR: Okinawa Pref. Ryukyu University Alpine Club Dhampus Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southwest of point 4905m between two ridges
C1 at bottom of small ridge leading to West Ridge.

Route lay on to small ridge leading to W Ridge and then to summit. Summit attack (there was only one) from C1 at 7:40 am and on top at 3:23 pm and stayed 15 minutes; down to BC at 7:10 pm.

SPONSOR: Objective 7000: French Expedition to Gurja Himal
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to cold wind and deep snow, no time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at point 4100m on Japanese Dhaulagiri map (Kaphe Khola)
C1 south of pt 4738m on lower Kaphe Glacier
C2 at same place as British Churen's C1 this season
C3 at plateau on N Ridge of Ghustung North
C4 at bottom of small ridge running west from Gurja's N Ridge
C5 on slope of west side of North Ridge.
High point on slope.

Tried to go to summit from C5 and reached 6400m but snow deep, cold and very windy and no time left.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5900m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
High point on NW Ridge.

C4 established in difficut, dangerous conditions: loose snow. 29th Kennard and others unable to get up on to ridge and bivouacked at 5800m on 30th. Had only 2 days really on mountain, which is very long way from BC. Left BC 5th Nov. 

Intention to climb South Peak, which had not been scaled. Appeared to be no other route than this NW approach.

Established BC (4040m) - 18th Oct
C1 established (4600m) same as Swiss - 20th Oct
C2    "        (4200m) Changda Khola - 23rd Oct
C3    "        (5000m) near Swiss pt - 25th Oct

Steve Powers, Dove Naylor recce to approx 5600m on NW Ridge - 27th Oct.
C4 established (approx 5900m) by Gombu Sherpa and Tenzi Sherpa - 28th Oct
NW Ridge of Swiss "Sisne North"
Biv by Garry Kennard, Steve Powers, Dave Naylor at approx 5800m - 29th Oct
Steve Powers, Dave Naylor, Gombu Sherpa spend night at C4. Garry Kernard
descends to C3 - 30th October

Decision to abandon climb 30th Oct. Climbers descended 31st Oct to C3. Loose and unconsolidated powder snow on loose rock and very low temperatures forced retreat (temperature at C3 midday -10 degrees approx temperature at biv  -20 degrees).

BC at north of a lake near Phoksumdo Khola
C1 at high pass at end of valley
C2 just before a steep slope to summit.

Kanjeralwa has numerous summits & team not entirely sure they climbed highest one, but believe so. Phoksumdo Khola & big lake towards north end of Kanjeralwa. Had rain/snow everyday but morning five. Route technically easy up snowslope to small ridge; difficult to C1. 

Nepalis on top: Iman Gurung, Man Bdr Gurung & Dunbar Gurung on 30th Sept; on 1st Oct Man Bdr & Dunbar again; went to north summit, which believe is highest, but possibly a middle summit is 100m higher. Will check photos they took when return to France.
ACHIEVMENT: 3rd & 4th ascent believed, but almost certainly climbed a peak north of highest summit

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at moraine northwest of mountain
C1 at moraine
C2 at North Face.

Bergschrund at 5900m. Lots of trouble with frequent snowfall and many minor avalanches, would have been dangerous to climb without fixed ropes. Had to go up and down between C1 and C2 often because of this, when snow consolidated and threatened slab avalanche. Also problem to get ropes out from under snow. Fixed 800m of rope at first. Another 300m of rope fixed from bergschrund to C2. 

1st summit bid by 4 (except Pusnik) when established C2, exhausted and bad weather, so turned back. 

2nd summit bid 28th Sept from BC. Only 29th Kolar and Misev to C2 in bad weather, improved campsite (1 member returned down on 29th). 30th many avalanches so stayed in C2; 30th night clear but -30 degrees. Started up at 5:00 am on 1st Oct with rope, came to rocks in total darkness but now getting light; 65-degrees to 72-degrees steep ice couloir (ice over broken rock - 400m long) and then longer snow field 60-degrees steep where used rope; arrived at summit 2:00 pm in deeper snow (above knee near top). Descended same route and arrived C2 6:00 pm, tired because of hard work in deep snow. No more summit attempt since summit success and left BC 4th Oct.

BC near Germans this autumn.

20th Oct from BC to deposit & see face; much dangerous ice falling so climbed only at night; no fixed camps. 

1st biv on 21 Oct at German's C1 site (German's left 22 Oct) at 5000m; 
2nd biv on 22 Oct at 5000m on glacier. 
3rd biv on 23 Oct at 5200m on glacier.

Oct 24th, searched for route above; midnight of 24/25th started up; at 8:00-9:00 am reached plateau above serac below pass; 4th biv here at 6000-6100m.
 
Oct 25/26th midnight left 4th biv, 4:00 am reached pass between Glacier Dome & Fluted Peak; slept 2 hrs at pass (6300m). After reaching top at 6:00 am, descended to tent below pass at 8:00 pm - very dangerous with many seracs; slept 27th at the biv.

Next problem was descent across icefall which did during night of 27/28th, abseiling all the way; here many new avalanches.

Team had no climbing permit.

SPONSOR: Alpine Group Peissenberg to Glacier Dome
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5400m due to extreme danger
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at west side of West Annapurna Glacier
C1 on glacier
High point on glacier.

3 times to 5400m and back to C1; couldn't see way 1st 2 times and 3rd time: seracs, icefall and constant snow avalanching. 3 times could see no sure route and too much danger, so abandoned climb. Left BC 22 Oct.

Intended route lay along east side of N-S Ridge of Tent Peak to W Ridge of Glacier Dome.

SPONSOR: 1989 Yeungnam University Alpine Club Annapurna II & IV Exp
TERMNOTE: Ascent claimed, summiters died in descent
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  south-southwest of Pisang village
ABC on glacier SSW of Pisang
C1  at top of vertical ice field
C2  200m below East-West ridge of Annapurna II and IV (last camp for Annapurna IV)
C3  on Annapurna II's West Ridge.

After C3 made all down to ABC because bad weather (daily snowfall and strong wind). Started up 18th Sept and Annapurna IV reached from C2; Annapurna IV not so difficult; fixed 3000m rope from ABC to C3. On 21st Sept 3 members [Kim, Jeong, Lee] and 2 Sherpas [Lhakpa and Pasang] from C3 at 5:30 am and 2 Sherpas felt danger from avalanche on Pokhara side and from 7500m to top route vertical so all returned to C3 at 7:30 am. 2 Sherpas down to ABC and 1 member [Lee] with headache stayed in C3 while 2 others left C3 at 8:00 am for top and reached top 5:30 pm. At 3:30 pm last walkie-talkie contact (were not seen after 3:00 pm) and Jeong said had stomach problem from altitude but Kim Ok and they would biv 600m below summit. When no contact next day, Chang and 2 Sherpas up from ABC early AM 22nd worried some accident and reached C3 at 11:00 am (no one in C3 now because member with headache had gone down on 21st to C2). Chang saw no sign of summiters and thinks they fell down south (PKR) side of ridge 21st or 22nd Sept. Chang reached ridge before turning back in bad weather (wind and coming snowfall).


Chong - 8 Feb 1990

Expedition's printed report says that at 2:00 pm on summit day, the summit party had their last walkie-talkie contact. They said "there is no big difficulty from here to summit. We are now at a rocky area just below summit and we will reach summit immediately. On the way back from the summit, we will make a bivouac for the night." They fell at 5:30 pm while coming down after having reached summit.
 
Chong talked with leadership after they returned to KTM. Has no idea where the time of 5:30 pm for their fall came from. Climbing leader told Chong summit was just a few minutes from top and he had no doubt they reached summit. He thought they might have fallen on the Pokhara side of mountain since no trace was found of them or the path of their fall on north side. In their last radio contact they said they would contact next from their bivouac but never did come on radio again.

Chong is Korean mountaineering journalist who runs a lodge in KTM.

Anna IV summited by Jo Won-Bae, Jeong Joon-Mo and Dawa Sherpa.

BC at normal site for North Face climb
C2 350m from start of Dutch Rib (normal site)
C3 slightly above Dutch Rib.

Did not attempt NW Face at all because of much unstable snow. Early Oct frequent avalanching (had accident on 1 Oct). 

2 summit attempts: on 26th Oct by 3 members [Valtchev, Iliev and Natchev] from C4 and reached 8050m, then very cold strong wind began to get frostbite and turned back to C2 (Natchev slightly serious but should heal).

2nd attempt on 28th Oct by other Ianakiev, Metkov, Stoykov, Panayotov and all except Metkov reached summit; left C4 2:30 am and on top about 11:30 am to noon (moved separately and reached summit separately). Metkov feet getting frostbitten and moved slowly, turned back to warm his feet, again up to 7500m, where he met Stoykov who was coming from summit (Stoykov last to descend, other 2 summiters already in C4). Metkov and Stoykov descended together from 7500m; at about 3:15 pm there was walkie-talkie contact; weather condition changed suddenly with thick clouds and they could not find their way, could see no recognition points; at 16:15 pm with group going from C2 to C3 they said saw many things falling from above them and going down below and 17:00-17:30 pm others in C2 found many personal belongings of Metkov and Stoykov (crampon, boot, clothing, etc.) but no bodies near C2. 29th Oct high camps evacuated. Helicopter for 3 members from BC to KTM because very bad frostbite Ianakiev and Panayotov fingers and toes, Natchev not so bad toes only. 2nd Nov left for Sofia.

1 Oct avalanche only other accident
1 member (Natchev) not serious frostbite when above 7800m
ACCIDENTS: Several cases of frostbite; avalanche accident on Oct 1; fatal fall by Stoykov Oct 28

SPONSOR: Keimyung University Alpine Club Himalchuli Expedition 1989
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6250m due to leader's death
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 never slept in. 2 parties totaling 9 men carried supplies to it's site and pitched tent, but slept in C1. 11th Sept all down to BC to say goodbye to sick leader; mailrunner left BC 11th Sept to summon helicopter to evacuate him. All stayed in BC till his death on 14th. On rainy 15th-16th Lee and 6 Nepalis went up to clear C2 and C1. 

Leader caught cold one week before arrival at BC; cold got better but developed bad headaches and got sicker and sicker, probably high altitude sickness; was 62 years old.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5600m due to bad weather (rain and snow)
ROUTEMEMO: Spaniards went to C1 three times but never above C1. Marin was 1st member to leave BC; he left on 25th Sept & others on 10th Oct.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7000m due to long route, no Sherpas on mtn, etc.
ROUTEMEMO:
ABC  at Tirolean BC (normal BC site)
High point at foot of ramp.

1st biv at 4700m for five nights fixing a rock pillar 4-7 Oct and then down to BC. Also did six carries each from BC to ABC, a distance of 7 miles with same carries; this really tired members considerably. 1st summit bid by Dixon and Parsons with 70-pound loads. Left BC 13th Oct, 14th stashed gear at ABC, 15th to base of pillar at 4850m and bived there. 16th up the pillar to 5300m at its top and bived. 17th into butterfly valley and bived in crevasse on edge of valley at 5500m. 18th up valley to 6400m and bived on glacier. 19th would have been summit day but rested, ready to start for top early on 20th. Left just after midnight and got to about 7000m at 4:00 am, decided moving too slowly to get to top and avoid very high biv without proper equipment and no feeling in toes, so turned back at 7000m and down to ABC same day. 

Thomas took Sherpas to ABC on 20th. 21st 3 members cleaned pillar. Team felt exhausted with long route and without Sherpa support (BC site where it was because Sherpas demanded higher pay above and budget couldn't stand this cost). Had expected to be team of 10 members but couldn't get sponsorship and was privately funded. Safe route: limited avalanche danger.

After reached BC, were many days of rain. During final part of climb snow conditions were good and no wind at their altitudes.

The long, seldom attempted SW Face route (Austrian 1972) exhausted this three-member team with no climbing Sherpas and no fixed camps. The route was safe with "limited avalanche danger."

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7350m due to fierce winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at snow field at bottom of face
C3 on snow face of NE Face
High point at C3.

Last half Sept much rain & snow. In Oct problem became the wind; also 10th Oct US members & Sherpas hit by avalanche which took them down 150m. Left BC 19th Oct. Had originally planned to go Makalu this winter, but this cancelled.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due to serious avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
While making route to C3 site on 10th Oct when avalanche carried 3 "Sherpas" (Tamangs actually) 150m down and sirdar buried in snow with foot sticking out and pulled out alive but unconscious by other 2 Sherpas and recovered. All members were in BC resting for ascent soon afterwards. Then leader and others decided too dangerous to continue climbing. 4 members left BC 11th and 12th Oct and Knoll with baggage on 14th. Plan was for "Sherpas" to make C3. Knoll made BC and C1 before other 4 members arrived by helicopter at Samagaon.

Nima Tamang, Dorje Tamang, Nima Dorje Tamang [= 3 Sherpas]

Knoll made BC and C1 before other 4 members arrived by helicopter at Samagaon.


Letter from Oswald Oelz - 20 October 1989

The base camp was established at 4750m on September 26th. On the 28th of September we established C1 above the Naike Col at an altitude of approx 5600m. Subsequently there was considerable snowfall; however, on the 3rd of October a preliminary C2 was established at an altitude of approx 6300-6400m. All this was much also a work of our 3 excellent high altitude Sherpas. During the next period there was again some considerable snowfall. On the 10th of October while [returning from?] carring equipment to the planed side of C3 the three high altitude Sherpas got into a huge avalanche at an approx altitude of 6600m. This slab started without without any prior warning signs directly on the tracks of the normal route. Miraculously two of the Sherpas were only partly buried and could rescue themselves. Subsequently they found their sirdar who was rapidly digged out and who was already unconscious. With the help of the American Lapkass of the British/American Expedition who had accompanied our Sherpas and had not been avalanched, they could resuscitate him and eventually all four got back to C2. They were no major injuries, but loss of equipment including one set of a walky-talky. On the following day we accompanied our Sherpas down to base camp and abandoned the expedition due to continued danger of avalanches and time pressure.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7060m due to winds
OTHERSMTS: Lakpass scaled a peak of 6790m near Manaslu
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at low BC
C1 at Naike Col
C2 in ice cave at usual site for C2
C3 300m above and slightly left of North Col
High point at C3.

From 8th to 25th kept going up to C2, waited for winds to stop and went down again. 3 Austrian "Sherpas" and Andy Lapkass were up breaking trail to 22,000 ft; Andy down to C2 and Sherpas coming down when slab 1000 ft high and 500 ft wide and 3 ft thick broke away just below N Col at 22,000 ft, a place where wind comes over N Col and leaves snow. Sherpas went down with it and ended up on tip of it unhurt. Lapkass and one of this team's Sherpas went up to rescue them; very, very lucky no one injured and this avalanche shook up Austrians so much they left 2 days later (18th Oct). This team then skirted "deposition area" but now winds had started up. Put 2 tents at C3 and slept one night, but wind so strong no question of making summit bid next day: Both Burgesses, Moores and Lapkass had intended to go to top from this camp and back within a day. Went down and waited for winds to ease. New plan for Burgesses and Lapkass to C2, from C2 overnight to summit (spending night in shaking tent useless) with winds not so strong at night; but at C2 on 2nd Nov winds were fierce. High BC, where Austrians had been, was devastated by huge ice cliff broken off by earthquake 20th Oct. This expedition's depot at this site was translocated and would have been catastrophic if occupied.

A crevasse below C2 was opening at route of 8 inches/day and was 20 feet wide by end of expedition; another reason abandoned climb because of this danger on edge of couloir that has to be crossed between C1 and C2; ladders have now became necessary for this area.

The normal NE Face route was a dangerous place to be: a great slab of snow 300m high, 150m wide and one meter thick broke away at about 6700m, a few hundred meters below North Col (in an area that is often avalanched), and carried another team's Sherpas with it; with great luck, no one injured.  About two days later, an earthquake dislodged a huge ice cliff which devastated the area around high base camp and would have killed anyone in it (no one was there at the time).  A crevasse below camp 2 at about 6000m kept opening at the rate of about 20 centimeters per day, was 6 meters wide when this team abandoned their climb chiefly because of fierce winds.

SPONSOR: Heo Young-Ho Family Expedition to Lhotse
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 in Western Cwm (used Korean Pillar Everest tent)
C2 on Lhotse West Face (used Japanese Everest tent)
C3 on Lhotse West Face.

Much snowfall at first after BC arrival. After making C1 to C3, down to Cwm on 5th Oct and 6th Oct to BC for rest. 12th Oct BC to Cwm, 13th Oct to 7300m. 13th Oct 8 pm up from 7300m with one O2 bottle and direct to summit in full moonlight; started using O2 at 7600m (above rock band) and on 14th 4:00 am on summit; not so cold and wind not strong. 14th down to 6500m at 1 pm (at 7300m 8:00 am). At summit time eyesight blurred in left eye; used O2 to 7500m. Did not use camp at 7800m, which was partly covered with snow. On 14th at 6-6:30 am met Japanese descending from Everest summit and descended with them to Cwm. 

One Sherpa went with Heo from Cwm on 3rd Oct to establish Heo's camp at 7800m, but not with Heo on 12-14th Oct.
ACHIEVMENT: Heo is 1st Korean to climb four 8000ers

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8350m due to fatal fall of Kukuczka
ROUTEMEMO:
C4 then 2 bivouacs at 7900m and 8300m
High point on South Face.

1st 200m on wall by Czech route safer from avalanches on this snow section; rest of route was Polish route. Between C3 and C4 very difficult and more dangerous than in 1985 with seracs more unstable: warmer and more snowfall in "terrible" Sept. Camps in about same places and in 1985 with C4 and C5 exactly same places. Total 4200m from base of wall at 5300m to 7800m not in climbing traverse from 7800m to 7900m where had 1st biv. Kukuczka's fall perhaps due to his hand reaching beginning of snow and it slipped; don't really know cause. 

On South Face of Lhotse "enough Polish people have died" so Pawlowski may not return to it. It can be climbed. Pawlowski and Kukuzcka had very good chance of success: Kukuzcka was sure that they would reach summit about noon. They both strong men had slept well, weather clear, no wind and temperature not bad in sunshine in day time and both well acclimatized.

Warecki: "We have not good luck on this wall - better to say good-bye." Also low "stock" of top climbers, only few left in Poland.


Information to be reported to the Ministry of Tourism after the completion of Expedition:

We started from KTM to Lukla on 30th Aug. We reached at BC on 6th Sept and at the same day we established BC on 5200m. We started climbing on 10th Sept and established C1 on 13th Sept at the height of 5600m and 2nd Camp on 16th Sept at the height of 6200m and 3rd camp on 28th Sept at the height of 6800m and Camp 4th on 5th Oct at the height of 7100m and C5 on 8th Oct at the height of 7800m and C6 established by Jerzy Kukuczka (leader) and Ryszard Pawlowski on 21 Oct at the height of 7800m and on 22nd Oct they established the first biv at the height of 7900m and slept there and on 23rd Oct they reached at the height of 8300m and established the next biv and slept there.

On 24th Oct they planned to got to summit and at the same day at 8:30 o'clock early in the morning they started their climbing from 8300m to summit. Kukuczka was climbing and he ascended approx 70m from the last biv. After a few minutes he fell down slightly at 9:00 o'clock from 8350m. After that he was falling down quickly as the rope had been broken near the last biv and he fell down badly one hundred and forty meters and he was dead. At that time the next member Pawlowski was near the last biv, when leader was falling down. Pawlowski was just behind of it when the rope was broken before him and he got protected.

So, after that Pawlowski never went up and abandoned his climbing and at the same time he started coming down and at that time he came down and slept at 7900m and on 25th Oct at 11:15 am he arrived at C5, where other two members [Kopys and Pawlikowski] were living at that camp for their rescue. He arrived at C5 and informed to BC about all the accident. So, at the same day at 4:00 pm. I informed about the accident in details to Ministry of Tourism. All three members camp to C4 and slept at that day. The next day they arrived at BC. Other members in BC at 10:00 o'clock morning on 26th Oct, went to the glaciers to search the dead body and after sometime they found the dead body of leader in a crevasse at the height of 5400m. They could tell from his clothing that it was the dead body of a leader. They left it there in the crevasse. On the next day on 27th Oct. All members and staffs of BC left the BC and started their return back to KTM and arrived at KTM on 31st Oct 1989.
ACCIDENTS: Kukuzcka fatal fall; Warecki had bad parapente landing

ROUTEMEMO:
C1 sited slightly different from plan to avoid soft deep snow and get onto rock. Route above C2 not changed from plan. Weather very bad: much snow and strong wind. Summiters started 6:30 am and on top 3:00 pm, very tired in wind blowing snow and fog (could see 3m only); on top 5-6 min only, could not stand in wind) back to C4 6:15 pm same day. Left on top a snowbar with carabinier and flag of mountain school. Had reached on East Peak at 12:30 pm also in bad weather and poor visibility and little tired, but after 10-15 mins weather better and decision taken by leader and team they should proceed to top. 

Route not difficult. Total 4575m rope fixed C1 to E Peak almost entire route (E Peak about 600m from C5). Many avalanches but very lucky and no one hurt (Rinji making route to C5 hit and fell 100m but after on hour's rest was Ok).

Oxygen was taken for expedition, but difficulties with it prevented its use.
ACCIDENTS: Rinji fell 100m after hit by avalanche on Sep 25 but after an hour's rest was OK

ROUTEMEMO:
Made steps at about 1-1/2 hour above Gorakshep at south end of large lake
C1 at behind summit of small ridge.

Made steps in very deep snow and after this, other expeditions used Hupfauer's steps made at 6200m on 3rd Oct and down to BC (saw at 6200m empty tent of Spaniards; did not know about their fatal avalanche). Rested at BC 4th and then went with surviving Spaniard to bodies of 4 dead, 5th brought them to glacier in next days with DAV members and buried in grave. After this not too keen to climb, but started up on 8th and fixed C1 and down again 10th slept in C1 and 11th thought could go to top, moved slowly up in deep snow and on to 6850m but now in cloud with no visibility. Down to C1. On 12th snow harder and slightly easier to move and on up despite clouds. Started at 6 am and on top at 2 pm in clear visibility for last 60m and at 5 pm back at C1.

BC at south end of large lake
C1 at same site as others this autumn.

Neuspiel and Sterritt on 18th went up towards C1 site. Sterritt got very ill on the way but continued to C1. Next morning Sterritt unable to descend alone or go up so Neuspiel went alone to summit. Left C1 6:40 am and on top exactly 6 hrs later and down to C1, fell into crevasse on the way and in C1 1:30 pm. Both to BC that afternoon/evening. 

Todd never reached BC. Thompson arrived at BC on 19th Oct with no one to climb with, unwilling to solo so never went above BC. All fixed ropes had been cleared the day before Neuspiel arrived at BC.

BC at south end, next to others
C1 at Germans's C2.

Arrived BC 9th Oct, but too many people on mountain and went to climb Lobuje to acclimatize (too dangerous snow) and returned to BC 11th Oct. 12th rested and 13th Harrington, Kaplan and MacKay to C1 while Springer stayed below C1 that day but arrived in camp 3:30 am of 14th. 14th Kaplan and Springer made summit bid and got 200m below top, where Springer felt unwell and they descended to BC. Three members then to top on 16th together.

BC at next to Germans
C1 at next to Germans.

Bertrand, Roy and Lhakpa Nuru Sherpa reached the summit on Oct 13 with members of the German (DAV led by Holzer) expedition.

The Base Camp and C1 was pitched next to Germans' camps.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to lack of time and member illnesses
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near lake (normal site)
C1 on SE Face
High point on face.

Had good weather, cold but fine but members and Sherpas sick. Fixed 600m rope to C1. 2 summit bids from C1: 1 Nov by Morris and Mehard and 2nd Nov by Richard with Tsharkey Sherpa and down on 2nd because Sherpa sick and weather cold - on 1st also not well. Then no time. Sickness was stomach. Left BC 5 Nov. Route difficult.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to avalanche which killed 4 members
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at southeast end of large lake due east of Kalapattar
C1 at bottom of ridge just northwest of Pt 5385m on NGS map
C2 at top of ridge ridge leads to SE Face
High point on SE Face.

2nd Oct 5 remaining members make C2. Snow very bad: knee deep soft snow after morning softens it: some days took 1 hr-20 mins to progress 25m. Many days snow falling. Arrived C2 2nd Oct morning 10:30. 3rd Oct 2 am 4 members go on up. Garcia stayed in C2 with stomach ailment. 4 planned to make summit and return to C2 same day. 3:30-4 am Garcia heard fatal avalanche near tent. 6 am Garcia down from C2 to BC noon same day. 4th Oct Garcia tried to go again to C2 but turned back by deep snow.

BC above (1 hour) Gorakshep near lake
Deposit C1 on rock ridge above lake (where snow began).

1st summit push 16th Sept by Giacometti and Santin. Reached 6400m and turned back because of bad snow conditions underfoot and was snowing. 

18th Sept 2nd summit push: Giacometti started from ABC at midnight of 17/18th, reached depot at 1:15 am and left here with them 2:10 am used no fixed rope but were roped together, climbed continuously, slowly to summit, while reached at 9:30 am. "Some tired" at top where stayed about 30 mins. Clouds coming quite foggy and warm with avalanche problem so descended quickly. Reached depot camp at 13:15 hrs. Giacometti stopped 15 mins and was in ABC at 14 hrs. Other 2 down to ABC later after clearing some of depot's gear.

Giacometti's 14-hr round trip beats Batard's 17 hrs in 1988.

BC near big lakes
C2 same as Spaniards and Hupfauer's camp site.

13th summiters were Bosshard, Pauer, Riches, Gimbel, Gruber, Buntrock and Doerrich members in Hupfauer's steps more or less; wind had blown away some of their steps; they down to BC on 14th (had slept in C2). 

15th Oct summiters Baier, Haas, Heisler and Pemba Tharke Sherpa. 

16th Oct summiters Wildensinn, Haas and Ang Dawa Sherpa.

Left BC 18th Oct.

Holzer helped Sigi Hupfauer to bury 4 dead Spaniards, who came down in avalanche more than 1000m over rock and ice; bodies were badly smashed and dismembered; were hit by serac falling down couloir.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6030m due to bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4700m at Duwo Glacier
High point on N Ridge.

No camps above BC. 2 climbing members together climbed in alpine-style after acclimatization around area (Island peak area, Kalapattar). Started up on 28th Oct for planned series of bivouacs. 28th Oct 6030m from 4900m, start of face. Tried to climb N Face direct but snow conditions very bad so went to via N Couloir to NW Ridge. Impossible to go higher because very soft snow on very steep rock. New route in couloir to ridge. 450m of new route, lower part Yugoslavs same route as Japanese Aut 1980. Steepness up to 85 degrees; no rope fixed; from bottom of face to ridge climbed in 17 hours.

BC above Mingbo (normal site)
C1 at normal C2.

Waited for Germans to evacuate their C2 before Americans finished establishing camp because not enough room for everybody. 23rd and 24th spent making camp and ferrying loads. 25th rested at the camp and 26th all 4 men went to summit in perfect weather: no clouds at all but some wind (gusts up to 60 kph). Took 2 men 6 hrs and others 7 hrs. Climbed most of distance unroped; used German's fixed ropes left for French to use in rapelling down. Nowack and McCormick returned from summit in 3-1/2 hours and others got caught in dark and much slower descent (had headlamps) and reached camp at 8:00 pm (Nowak and McCormick at 4:00 pm in camp). 27th cleaned up camp and down to BC in afternoon and left BC 28th with French expedition's arriving yaks.
No problem with climb, route well roped. Left BC 11th November.

SPONSOR: DAV Summit Club Ama Dablam Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC above Mingbo at start of SW Ridge.

Last 5000m not fixed with rope despite deep snow in slope of up to 50 degrees steepness. Climb entirely straightforward and without incident. Fixed 2000m on this long for safety and placed camps at usual sites.

SPONSOR: First Spanish Women's Expedition to 8000m - to Cho Oyu
ROUTEMEMO: Snow was very soft & Koreans had a route slightly different from Tichy route so Spaniards followed Korean's route. C1 was Tichy route but on same side of mountain. This route is not recommended - too many avalanches. It is better to stay on Tichy route. One avalanche hit C2 (avalanche which Italian lady rode down 800m) but no one hurt.

SPONSOR: Italians to Cho Oyu and Everest
ROUTEMEMO:
In August attempted N Ridge. 2 men put a tent at 6100m under N Ridge but turned back; then Bertoglio became sick and they moved on to normal route, on which Bertoglio went to C2 and Rosso to summit. 

Bertoglio is well-known runner who runs up an Alp's more than 3000m in 2 hrs, but he is used to careful regimen and excellent diet, but did not adapt to Himalaya expedition's food and altitude. Were supposed to be at Everest BC by Sept, so were not permitted to go Everest following Cho Oyu ascent.
ACCIDENTS: Only Bertoglio failure to adapt to altitude

SPONSOR: Italian Expedition to Cho Oyu from Tibet
ROUTEMEMO:
2-13 Sept much snow; made deposit at 7000m in this period. 15 Sept avalanche hit at 7900m Valentina and Thirtha Tamang but not injured; carried by it 800m. Mountain was loaded with snow and were very lucky Valentina and Thirtha Tamang not hurt. Summiters lucky that avalanche took away much dangerous loose snow; was much snow.

Avalanche that carried Valentina Lauthier 800m deposited her beside a tent and she crawled into it; other members started probing for her when someone looked in the tent and found her there.

Eberhard Jurgalski - October 2005

Mr. Yang of the Korean Alpine Federation reported to Jurgalski that Hong and Lee told him [Yang] that they did not summit.


Initial Report (later changed, see below):

Went up mountain via Messner route, i.e., did not cross Nangpa La (Mingma Norbu of Karikhola was on this expedition and also Messner's in 1983) and like Messner descended normal route which meant crossing Nangpa La from north side. All members and Sherpas followed same route; some Sherpas met people from this expedition on normal route from Tibet: this Korean expedition's C3 was next to USA and Italian C2; it was at C3 that Koreans joined normal route. All the way to C3 route was on glacier without snow; at C4 was deep snow. 

Wangel knows Messner route from Mingma Norbu, who was on this climb and also with Messner.

5 Sept 2 members and 1 Sherpa high porter from C4 and biv at 8050m at foot of couloir in only biv sack, 1 piece of chocolate, no food or fuel. Some stonefall and ice particles coming down couloir, broke Hong's goggles and slightly pains, very faint but leader ordered them to summit and on they went to summit. Left biv 6:00 am 6th and on top after 8:40 minutes climb. Oxygen supplies arrived late at BC while climbers already high and weather very good. 8 Sept weather turned bad with wind and sometimes snow. 6 Sept summiters sleep C3 with other members and Sherpas (no people or provisions in C4) - and "almost dire" with weakness and hunger: next day C1. No more attempts for summit. Difficulties between C1 and C2 where crevasses need fixed rope (740m); C2 and C3 same stone and icefall. Used snow route all the way; no fixed rope in couloir.

At 1:45 summiter Hong, thought he was at summit but when cloud disappeared realized not highest point and went onto to true summit in clear weather.

First campsite list:
  BC1(4900m),BC2(5000m),C1(01/09,5600m),C2(02/09,6500m),C3(03/09,7000m),
  C4(04/09,7700m),Biv(05/09,7900m),Smt(06/09)

Another campsite list:
  BC(19/08,5300m),ABC(31/08,6000m),C1(01/09,6600m),C2(02/09,7200m),
  C3(03/09,7500m),C4(04/09,7860m),Biv(05/09,8050m),Smt(06/09)


Cho Oyu Expedition, Korean Autumn 1989 - by Kwak Gyu-Youl

The expedition member was ten persons led by Park Sang-Yul. They started for Kathmandu on July 22. Starting up caravan at Jiri on August 2. BC was established at 5200m on August 17. 

C1 was established at 5950m under the Nangpa La. They ascended the so-called traditional SW Ridge from Nepal, which is in actual the NW Ridge. C2, C3 and C4 were established at 6300m, 6700m and 7500m on Aug 22, 29 and 30. 

On Aug 31, Dong-Yon Lee, Gyong-Pyo Hong, Sirdar Wangel started for the summit at 3 am, but descended on the first rock band at 1:50 pm. They arrived at C4 at 6:20 pm.

On September 1, they started at 7:15 am and established a tent at 8100m which is the highest point arrived the day before. They started at 6:50 am on Sept 2. After 6 hours they arrived at the second rock band with abundant snows.

They have mistaken the summit for heavy fog at 3:23 pm. But when the fog lifted, they found the true higher summit. Since that time about one hour they reached the summit.


Chong - 5 Oct 89
Villa Everest prop.

Korean Cho Oyu team "confessed" to Chong just before they left KTM (and his lodge) that they had climbed the normal route, not SW Ridge as claimed at first. Had intended all along to climb Tichy route. They began climbing on 20 Aug and reached summit 2 Sept.


Magda King Nos Loppe & Ang Phuri - 1 Oct 1989

Met Koreans at Spanish ABC 30 Aug. They made summit 2 days later 1 Sept. Spanish had already been in on above Nepal BC 15 days.

Koreans C3 = Spanish C1, just below icefall. Next camp was where Italian woman landed after riding an avalanche 800m. Went up straight up instead of making a left traverse above C2, as Tichy route would have taken them. Sherpa is sure Koreans did not ascend via Messner, did not meet Koreans after their summit day so did not talk with them after it, but are sure Koreans were not at all on the route they claim to have been on. 

"They cannot substantiate their claim with picture because their pictures will show the wrong place" - King


Zeglen & Bianchi - 25 Sept 1989

Koreans were on normal route and crossed Nangpa La in both directions. Could not have followed route they claimed because very difficult and very dangerous avalanching there. Italians saw no track via Messner approach. They left Cho Oyu across Nangpa La. No Chinese beyond Northern BC = Chinese BC, well away from mountain.

Saw their track very nice track up mountain via Tichy route Koreans on summit 3 Sept - 1st met some at Bianchi's.


Sigi Hupfauer - 20 Sept 1989

Does not believe Koreans could climb new route they claims so quickly especially on such steep face, and altitudes given for camps don't correspond with sketch over Schneider's contours.

Agrees not at all likely Koreans using their tactics of fixed camps and rope made climb of route they claim.


Oswald Oelz - 21 Sept 1989

He agrees not at all likely Koreans, using their tactics of fixed camps and ropes, they climbed the route of their claim.
ACCIDENTS: Slight frostbite to summiters; one Sherpa unhurt in fall onto crevasse

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5610m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 600m above normal site, moraine of Linshing Glacier
C1 just below West Ridge
High point on West Ridge.

9th Oct 2 men went up but found bad snow, snow deep (above knees) and storm coming. They went down to BC 11th Oct. 2 others went up but some problems; too dangerous to force route higher.

Return to Kathmandu to south along W Ridge western extension, all above 4000m. First time foreigners went by this difficult way constantly up and down (water problem), which took longer than normal route followed on approach.

SPONSOR: Avila to Summit Himalaya 1989 to Ganesh IV
APPROACH: Setung->Huidung->5 days from Huidung through thick jungle
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  near glacier
ABC on glacier
C1  at beginning of South Face
High point at SSW Spur.

Everyday snow and rain. Fixed 600m rope above C1 from C2 tried twice to climb spur on face via French route from C2 but very dangerous with almost daily avalanching. Highest point reached during night of 5/6 Oct. Started from C2 at midnight and at 5:00 am turned back because snow too dangerous.

SPONSOR: 1989 British Langtang Expedition to Langtang Lirung
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site for lower BC
C2 on SE Ridge where route gets onto ridge
C4 at Swiss snowhole.

Neither this or the Swiss Langtang expedition would have succeeded without the other: British put in lots of fixed rope at first, Swiss came along and put in more high up which British too tired to do. C2 to C3 the crux of climb: rocky ridge requiring fixing rope. Had several long periods of very unsettled weather. Declan MacMahon went up one day ahead of Rees-Jones and Howard; Rees-Jones and Howard turned back an hour or so from summit because of strong wind. Very safe route from objective danger. Climb was more difficult than expected from looking at photos. 

Only 3 left at end because they were the only ones who could stay away from home so long.

BC at left side of Lirung Glacier
C1 on SE Ridge.

Ridge is very difficult. British had arrived first and fixed ropes; were very cooperative. Snow conditions no problem: mostly snowed on lower part of mountain. Swiss left BC 13th Nov. 

C1->C2 fixed 600m rope by British. Would have taken Swiss much more time if British not so very cooperative. Swiss put in 300m above C2 & 700m in gully below C1. "British people were very, very nice."

TERMNOTE: Summited NW Summit
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Khumbu Glacier east of Kalapattar
C3 at small cave
High point at NW Summit.

Route just below C2 very steep and difficult snow like sugar (used ice axe as shovel) and many cornices. In the end Dujmovits climbed alone. Others ill, unmotivated or psychologically unprepared for Himalayan conditions. Team had fixed ropes to 6800m. On 1 Nov Dujmovits alone up from C2 and reached C3, fixed 100m above C3 and slept in C3. On 2 Nov he went to NW Summit in 4-1/2 hours. As he was alone too dangerous to go beyond NW Summit. Very disappointed not to go beyond because is possible to reach Main Summit in 2 days. Very strong winds constantly. Total 1700m rope fixed by this expedition.

BC at Barun Glacier's south side, SSW of point 5750m on Schneider map
C2 between points 6730m and 6480m.

23 Oct, 8 members (all except Passelo) left C2 at 7 am and went to pass before ridge at 6600m. Here Grandjean down sick; Siegenthalar to top; Frossard to 7000m with Siegenthaler and stopped when ridge became difficult and snow conditions dangerous. Bugnard, Chavannaz, Pollet, Ruffieux G. and Ruffieux M. reached pass late and stayed at pass to watch Siegenthaler, when he got to summit at 3 pm. Then all but Chavannaz descended as they saw Siegenthaler coming down ridge while Chavannaz waited for Siegenthaler. All to C2 night of 23 Oct. Left BC 31 Oct.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing serious except Grandjean developed blood pressure problem at 6600m

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7050m due to strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Yamotari Glacier
C1 at left edge of another glacier
C2 above icefall below 2 towers
C3 right below 1st tower on a subsidiary ridge to S Ridge.

2 towers are difficult to get to mountain; between C2 and C3 another most difficult section and fixed ropes here. Total 1800 ft fixed, 1500 of it between C2 and C3. Getting around 2 towers continuously technical climbing. Had temporary camps above C3, moving tents upward. 21 Oct at 6140m. Weather was perfect in these days until we reached 7050m at top of summit wall, just one day below summit, where winds started up. Stayed 2 nights but wind continued without stop and even got worse. Went down on 29th because of wind, low supplies and time running out. Had excellent snow conditions.

Next time will fix the wall and in bad weather go down quickly.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Pangpema
C1 below first snowfall
C2 at second snowfield (same as Japanese 1980 C2)
High point at North Face.

24th Oct Monier attacked main difficulty of route between 7000 and 7200m; reached 7100m and fixed 50m rope in his descent. Down to BC. Waited there till 20 Oct, when went to C1, 30th to C2; 30 cm snowfall during night of 30/31 (this his only 2nd summit bid). Waited for snow to stabilize, then 3rd broke tent, which he had planned to take up mountain again down to BC to wait for wind to abate. But wind did not drop high up and on 7th decided to give up. Should have arrived earlier at BC. 

This his first autumn season in Nepal, Had planned to climb alpine-style from C2 taking this tent with him. None of other team members went above BC.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m due to wind and fatigue
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at high BC site at glacier's junction
C1 at 6200m at Chago Glacier
High point on North Face.

Went to 7000m about 27th but down and back again by Frank and Jackson, bived there and down next day in snowstorm. Austiguy and Thorburn reached Makalu La on 4th where bived on windy night in exposed place and down next day. Frank and Jackson on 6th up to 7000m for summit bid but wind drove down next day. 

Johnson and Collister of British team to C3 on 11th or 12th; they got to 7600m and Collister reached 7000m and down to 20th because of wind and slight illness. Now porters coming and climbers tired.

Johnson and Collister went together to 7500m, where Catalans had their C3, on 14 Oct afternoon. 3 Catalans and their Sherpa went up to C3 same time. On 15th Johnson left C3 at 2:30 am, Catalans left at 3:00 am (they had talked of climbing together). Johnson followed North Ridge to 8100m, part way up the Kukuczka step - step was developing slab rock with bad snow on it. He tried 3 ways to get up it but snow was not safe any way he tried: "I had a gut feeling I was in a bad place" and turned back at 7:30-8:00 am. He was alone as Catalans and he had taken different lines above C3 and 30 minutes before he turned back one of Catalans fell into a crevasse and that discouraged them in knee-deep snow and they turned back at about 7900m. Collister got out of tent later in morning because his feeet were cold, followed Catalans, met them at 7700m and they told him of snow problems.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8000m due to windslab avalanche danger
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at high BC 
C1 at Chago Glacier
C2 below Makalu La
C3 above Makalu La on North Face
High point on North Face.

Main problem was wind from east dumping snow over S Face on to N Face. 1st summit bid from C3 28th Sept and 2nd on 8th Oct. 1st reached 8000m and 2nd 7800m but wind slab avalanche danger turned them back. Both bids made by Valles; 1st with 4 Spanish members of other team and 2nd with 2 members of other Spanish team.

15 Oct 3 remaining members to C1. 17 Oct Larma and Zamarbide to C2 and 19 Oct to about C3 (but camp not there) so bived. 20 Oct biv slightly higher still looking for camp. Much wind and cold (Larma frostbitten thumb) and no tent or biv sack so impossible to cook in wind. Down on 21 Oct. Left BC 27th Oct.
ACCIDENTS: None to Oct 10 when Valles left BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m due bad conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at high BC site (glacier's junction)
C1 at plateau of Chago Glacier
C2 on northwest side below Makalu La
C3 at 1 hour above Makalu La
High point on North Face

Tried to go to summit from C4 four times. 1st on 27th Sept to 8000m; then 3 Oct (but could not reach Makalu because of wind slab danger following big snowfall after 27 Sept); 8 Oct when got to 7900m; and 15 Oct to 8100m in good weather but still dangerous from windslab and deep snow. On 15th one man fell into crevasse and were many avalanches; also was very cold: on 8 Oct was -35 degrees near 7900m in 100 kph wind so very cold fingers and toes. Before 15th Oct attempt had decided this was the last one with little time left and much effort spent. All except one had at least 2 nights in C3.

Pierre Beghin came to this expedition's C3 in descent, unable to talk very coherently in his exhaustion; he spent night in their tent.

Michel Dacher climbed in 1st and 3rd attempt with this team; 3rd time one American with them.

This team was first to arrive and fix ropes, which others used.

ROUTE1: S Face up; NW Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southwest of Barun Pokhari
C1 just below point 5860m in Schneider map
C4 a series of bivs.

In first half of Sept only Beghin and Cadot were climbing and they reached 6600m on 16th Sept and again 21 Sept with Gherson, who descended in that night with headache while other 2 slept there for first time. 22nd Beghin alone to 7100m fixing 200m rope. 23rd all to BC for rest before summit bid. 27th Sept 3 members to C1, but big storm arose and down to BC 28th. 1 meter fresh snow fall 28-30 Sept. From BC 2nd Oct 3 members to C1, which was badly damaged with sleeping bags in 10cm of melted snow but could dry them in sunshine. 

3 Oct Beghin to 7100m and other 2 same altitude 4 hrs later and slept here. 4th Oct Cadot and Gherson down tired and cold, while Beghin up alone to 7700m, where bivouacked with minimum equipment (tent inner lining, 1 tent pole, stove, gas, pot, tea and coffee but no food, 2 ropes, pitons for very difficult technical section of 25m loose rock at 7300m which Beghin thought most dangerous section and took 2-3 hrs to surmount despite fear would have to give up). Biv 4th Oct alone at 7700m. Wind rose at night and carried spindrift snow in cold. 5th Oct Beghin climbed most difficult part of Yugoslavian route at 8000m-8150m where was powder snow on rock and ice, quite unsafe. Above 7600m was impossible to descend this route because of snow condition of this snow on rock. Above 8100m not so difficult and now had no more rope. Biv at 8200m on 5th, tired. 6th Oct reached W Pillar top and on up via S Face like Yugoslavians. Started on 6th Oct at 8:30 am and on summit 2:45 pm, was very cold and Beghin very tired and at end was 50m cliff of bad rock and here got some frostbite of 1 thumb; cold and strong wind and cloud. Stayed at summit 3 minutes. Left tent at last biv. On 6th descended in knee-deep snow with crust in places, arriving directly for tents he could see near Makalu La; was taken by avalanche 200m, head first, lost walkie-talkie; reached tents at 6:00 pm where found Carlos Valles and others, hoping for their own summit bid. 7th Beghin down alone via couloir, in last 400m snow crusted and again windslab avalanche took him down 400m, over 2 seracs, lost cameras, lost ice ax; stopped at gentle slope and joined normal track and reached 6400m camp of British and later high BC at 5:00 pm where 2 trekking friends awaited him. On 8th down to Beghin's BC.

Fauquet arrived BC 6th Oct and 7th Oct he and Ghersen to C1. 8th these two reached 7100m; then 7300m and turned back, windy and they were discouraged.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8000m due to wind and snow
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at glacier's junction
C1 at Chago Glacier
C2 also Chago Glacier
High point on North Face.

Dacher and Studer to 6600m 11th Sept and pitched C1 but did not sleep there. Juan went to 6200m with Spanish (not Catalans) and also down to BC. Same day Zaugg and Schertler not feeling well and down to British BC. Zaugg and Studer on 13th to own BC and Juan up with Spanish to 6200m slept there. Then heavy snowfall and Juan down 14th. 16th Dacher and Studer, Zaugg and Schertler to 6200m and slept there (Spanish C1). 17th Dacher and Studer to 6600m while Zaugg and Schertler down to BC, where Juan still was and were joined on 18th by Dacher and Studer.

21st all 5 members up to C1 (Schertler, Juan, Zaugg, and Dacher and Studer) to C2. 22nd weather fog and a little snow so all down to BC. Zaugg made movies at 6400m before descending. 23rd Juan, Schertler and Zaugg left BC because snow conditions too difficult for their strength (Schertler went home while Juan and Zaugg to Thai beach). 

Spanish asked Studer and Dacher to join forces and according to note from Studer up to 7000m on 25th and 26th to Makalu La and 27th to 8000m and turned back at 10:30 am in fog and down to BC same day. 60 hrs snowfall with nearly 1m at BC. 

Studer left BC 30th Sept and flew home 7th Oct. Avalanches only few meters each side of camp at 6600m. Dacher remained with Spanish for his last chance on Makalu. After Studer left BC, Dacher went up to 7000m to retrieve gear and then left mountain. On 17th Oct, Dacher returned to KTM.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to windslab avalanche danger and high winds
OTHERSMTS: Attempted Kangchungste (Makalu II) (MAK2-893-01); climbed Chago (CHAG-893-01) and Yaupa (YAUP-893-01)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Tangmar, south-southwest of Barun Pokhari
ABC at high BC
Makalu high point at 7500m on North Face
Kangchungtse high point on a summit atop West Face.

After 13 Oct Collister and Griffin went up Makalu to point where route emerged above Makalu La (this season Makalu La was too dangerous and route taken went south of La and doubled back slightly, then onto North (or NE Face). About 15 Oct reached about same point as Collister and Jessop on 9 Oct. No accidents, etc. Abandoned it not so much because of wind, which there was but dangerous windslab.

Kangchungtse not attempted after 13 Oct. 

Had no fixed camps at all, but did not leave tent at ABC's shelf from time to time. First went to ABC on 30 Aug while others up north-northeast of BC; this was acclimatization and recce - "everybody did something different." 1st 3 weeks spent looking around. Saunders and Sustad started from 6500m (well up Chago Glacier) on 1:00 am 26th Sept and reached 7600m at 8:00 pm, then went to Makalu La; had done new route on West Face of Kangchungtse; hoped to return to biv at 6500m but weather diverted them to Makalu La, where biv from 2:30 to 5:00 am of 28th without sleeping bag or other gear. Took whole day to get back to 6500m in very poor visibility and another day in 6000m, all in storm conditions. 

Irvine and Jessop got to 6200m at start of SE Ridge of Makalu at same time Saunders and Sustad were on Kangchungtse (late Sept).

On normal route of Makalu, numerous times just below and to C3 at 7500m but never beyond by time S and W left BC on 13 Oct, worn out and discouraged. 4 left at Makalu but they were leaving BC on 20 Oct.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to dangerous wind slab
OTHERSMTS: Attempted Makalu (MAKA-893-02); climbed Chago (CHAG-893-01) and Yaupa (YAU-893-01)

SPONSOR: 1989 Yalungkang Expedition of Won Ju Chiak Alpine Club
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual site on Yalung Glacier.

Sho Kang-Ho had typhoid in KTM and left one week later thus rest of team, caught up with them at glacier before BC. Most difficult section was very steep part between BC and C1. From C4 very long and steep but no place for camp above and much stonefall. 

Only one summit attempt which was successful. Others sick and tired so no other attempt afterwards. 13th Oct 7 am, 3 men started up from C4 and were on top 3:55 pm with no fixed rope above C4. Total 4240m rope fixed above BC. Summiters slept C4 on 13th and on 14th down to BC. Expedition left BC 16th Oct.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Korean and Nepalese on summit; 1st Korean attempt

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at road
C1 at North Col
High point on North Face.

At 7600m placed deposit camp 7th Sept and then couldn't return for rest of Sept because of snow and in Oct it was wind. Brown did manage to reach 7600m camp on 13th Oct from N Col and from there took gear across face to 7700m to get out of wind. 14th Oct took gear at 7800m further across face; winds got worse during night of 14/15th so on 15th down to ABC, 17th to BC and left on 20th Oct. 

Jan Harris left N Col on 13th giving up climb because he was run down; had done many trips BC-ABC and several trips to N Col and above.

Maurice Wilson's body has been at ABC since 1986, when Spanish brought him there; just a pile of bones, perhaps 25% of total body. Americans buried the bones this autumn.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to bad weather and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at road
C2 at left edge of Japanese Couloir
High point at C3 site.

Made C2 early 5:00 am of 25th slept until 2:00 pm and on up to C3 site in early afternoon but strong wind and arrived at site at 4:00 pm. "Weather changed" and we went down to C1 because avalanche danger and now snowing. Never returned to C2 because bad weather continued and permit ended 15th Oct. Waited in C1 and ABC nearly 2 weeks, then abandoned climb.

Should have lots of rope (3000m) to succeed in such weather conditions and more members.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m due to deep snow and bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
