BC at end of road
C1 on North Face
High point on N Face.

All 3 climbers went to N Col on 31st Aug and back to BC same day. Much snowfall. Again up from BC on 5th Sept, 6th Sept to 7800m where made a camp and slept. 7th Sept down to BC with bad snow conditions, winds and not fully acclimatized. 

Next 12 days in BC with snowfall most days and frequent avalanches. 20th Sept to ABC, 21st in ABC during snowfall, 22nd to N Col and back to ABC because bad snow conditions. 24th Diego and Hans to 7800m (Joos not well and down to ABC) where slept, planning to go 8400m and on to top. 25th Joos up very early from ABC to catch up with others and saw others leave C1 very late. Bad weather came in and when Hans and Kammerlander reached 8100m and climb finished because above 8100m very dangerous with wind slab and crust over deep snow making climb very slow and down to ABC. 26th to BC leaving ABC. 28th cleared ABC. Jeep at BC for other group arrived 30th Sept and this team used this, leaving BC 1st Sept for Nyalam.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to snow and wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at road
C2 at left edge of Japanese Couloir
High point at C3 site.

Tried 4 times from ABC for summit bid but never above C2 because of some snow and a lot of wind. 2 members were in 2 attempts, other 3 members all 4 attempts, sometimes climbing with Jaccoux group. Pasang Gombu Sherpa carried loads to C2; he was shared with Jaccoux. Last attempt on 3-4 Oct. Gave up after this because enough time had been spent: had wanted to do Paris/summit/Paris in 2 weeks and had already spent months in mountains. Team experience was very good (had been able to go to 7800m so quickly and never below ABC without any problem). 

Escoffier had no trouble going up when track was good. Sometimes problem descending in bad snow (motor nerves in brain damaged in motor accident 2 years ago).

Escoffier: did no real climbing to 7800m, moved with ski poles; had some trouble descending; "a little disappointed" but will come to Everest again but on Nepalese side.


Norbert Joos - 9 Aug 1989

Escoffier on Everest: attempting fastest trip Paris/Everest Summit/Paris.

Acclimatizing in special chamber in France (near Chamonix). His baggage taken into Nepal and China by Jaccoux.

"It won't work - I hope it doesn't."  
"Just a show - not mountaineering."

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8000m due to winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at road
C1 on NE Ridge ("the unclimbed ridge")
C2 on N Col
C3 on buttress leading to N Ridge
High point at N Face.

Never got more than 24,000 ft on NE Ridge in 3 attempts to go up ridge but waist-deep snow and set off avalanches from 13th to 24th Sept. Kept building up supplies in C1 in Sept after having fixed rope by 12th, hoping their supplies would go on to higher camps. 

Decided to abandon NE route about 25th Sept and to go to classical route with Goodwill team. By early Oct, N Ridge looked safe because winds had blown away snow but now winds unbearable. Snow was down to knee-deep; temperature very low and winds c70 mph and blew all night long.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8300m due to wind and fixed dates
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at road
C2 at North Col
C3 at buttress to N Ridge.

3rd Oct Vincent to 8200m while two had gone before him to 8300m. 1st summit attempt actually was on 24th Sept after period of snowfall and snow slab avalanche danger (was with Kammerlander and Wellig). After this, wind was the problem. Had to leave ABC because yaks ordered for 6 Oct and flight from KTM booked for 14 Oct. 6 left early after 1st summit bid failed.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8600m due to wind and cold
ROUTEMEMO:
C4 at North Col
High point at 2nd Step.

Did carries to Col camp for long time bafore establishing camp: were stocking supplies there. 1st time C5 was slept in was 21 Oct because winds: 100 mph gusts (60 mph sustained). 21 Oct was summit attack by Tejas and Litherland, on 22nd biv at 8200m after late start without tent trying to reach C6, where Spanish summer team's tents were. 23rd reached Spanish tent which was usable and that was last calm day with winds starting at 3:00 am on 24th. Got to 8600m at foot of 2nd Step, got frostbitten in cold wind and turned down 24th. 

Horner and Ongden Sherpa to C5, 25th down in screaming wind. 26th abandoned N Col camp, 28th cleared ABC and left BC 29th Oct.
ACCIDENTS: Rabold stroke (?) and Slade CO2 in tent; Litherland fell 20m but not hurt

SPONSOR: Zagreb Mountaineering Expedition to Mount Everest
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at road
ABC near point 5560m NGS map
C1  at bottom of Changtse West Ridge (near point 6080m NGS map)
C2  100m above Australian White Limbo's camp
C3  at bottom of Great Couloir.

Had an Advance C1 which was depot and rest place, but snow cave, and 100 carries to C2 as an advanced ABC, so time to build up supplies there. Rope above C1 to C2 had to be replaced every 5-6 days because of avalanching. Very dangerous route for avalanching. All 6 members who reached C3 were in avalanches. At highest point man fell 200m from high point down to C3 and reported on walkie-talkie that someone would be killed if tried to go higher. Left BC 19 Oct. Difficult to walk at BC because of wind.
ACCIDENTS: Kregar fell 400m and broke ribs; Sveticic fell 100m and broke knee

SPONSOR: Marc Batard Autumn 1989 Annapurna I Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to objective dangers
ROUTEMEMO:
Went quickly to the face but too much snow, dangerous crevasse area where snow covered them from sight; also dangerous seracs falling. Left BC 7th April was in Pokhara yesterday morning, Kathmandu later same day. Another reason to abandon Annapurna for Everest is that he has had a problem with his knee for six years & there are doctors at Everest base camp: "better to go to Everest quickly."

Hirsh did not go on to face. He is coming to KTM with baggage, will arrive KTM about 12 April & will then go to Khumbu to join Batard (actually arrived KTM 10 April).

SPONSOR: Jovan Poposki Autumn 1989 Everest Lhotse Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face.

Bozic and Groselj arrived BC 15 April. Started together from C3 to Lhotse summit on 30 April. Left C3 at 12:45 am. Bozic stopped at yellow band, down to C3 to warm his freezing feet, up again to 8200m, waited there watching Groselj descend from summit. Groselj reached summit at about 2:45 pm without oxygen in very good snow conditions except no snow in couloir, very strong wind (others unable to reach C3 from C2 on other expedition), extremely cold summit covered by cloud. Descending couloir very bad; fell 10m into soft snow. Very tired; cannot remember details. Up to 7800m used fixed ropes (Yugo and US). Returned to C3 together at 8:00 pm. Next day 1 May to BC. Bozic realized Groselj was straying off route and moved to left to meet him.

No Sherpas above C3 for Lhotse.

SPONSOR: Bulgarian Annapurna I S Face Winter Expedition 1989
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to heavy fresh snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on west side of Annapurna Glacier in Annapurna Sanctuary.

BC lower than planned because 20 Nov 20 cm snow fell and porters could not go to planned site. Route used above C1 swept 3 times by avalanches (no one hurt). Was dangerous route but more direct to 6600m than previous Bulgarian route. Reached a camp site at 6600m but no camp established here. No camp below 6600m because no place to put a camp. On 16 Dec did not put camp here but fixed rope to this moving camp as they ascended with 2 biv (7500m and 7800m where there are places to camp). But after descent to BC after 16 Dec, more than one meter of new snow fell. Some members did go up to ABC and C1 only to clear these camps. With new snowfall much avalanching carried ropes away. Had fixed about 1200m rope from 5700m to 6600m.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due to bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
19 Dec making route to C4, then down to C2 because strong wind and cloudy. C2 little snowfall and down further. 23 Dec again to C3 and deposit C3 gear there and down same day. 4 or 5 times carrying gear to C3, but some carried below C3 because again strong wind and cloud and some snowfall.

After C1 established, no one stayed at BC. Fixed total 2000m. All rib fixed with double rope on very steep mixed rock and snow on South Face of rib and at big serac at top of rib.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5200m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
High point at flat place between 2 sections of icefall.

Snowed and rained for 72 hrs when arrived at BC. Profit's fixed ropes under 1m fresh snow: "crazy" says Lukie. To reach start of climb, must go through chest deep snow with hard crust after strong winds began. Were only 2 men climbers: Cousteix had cereberal edema and Beulne stayed with him at Marpha; they arrived at BC late. Doctor BC only, so only 2 men to break trail. 

At this time of year need skies. On 3rd Dec Besson and Lukie tried to go up and went only into icefall; to reach col with only 2 men in such snow conditions and new snowfall impossible. Ridge above N Col in good condition. Then porters to BC had had to wait 5 days at BC and on this retreat from BC one porter killed by avalanche off W Face on 28th Nov. They used much food at BC; sent cook and kitchen boy to Marpha for more supplies; they got lost trying to find French Pass; had to sleep out and Naike's feet froze.

Beulne and Cousteix arrived in Nepal late and flew to Jomsom, Cousteix sick at Marpha; arrived BC 2 Dec (Beulne) and 8th Dec (Cousteix). Expedition left BC 9th Dec and had trouble getting out in deep snow.

Only two members did any climbing on Dhaulagiri, for one member developed serious altitude sickness and another stayed at base camp with him. So with no climbing Sherpas they were too weak a party to break trail through chest-deep snow in a prolonged period of new snowfall. The NE Ridge above the North Col appeared to be in good condition, but it was impossible for only two men to even reach the col in such snow conditions. (It might have helped if they had brought skis). 

The two Dhaulagiri climbers, Besson and Lukie, plus Beulne, who had been with the sick man, did go over to nearby Mt. Tukuche and successfully scaled it by its NE Ridge.
ACCIDENTS: 1 serious altitude sickness; 1 porter killed at BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7315m
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at snout of glacier south of up Gote Khola ridge/rock spur south of Pt 6014m
High point on NE Ridge.

Had always planned to attempt E Face to NE Ridge. Yoder left expedition from BC 21 Dec after all 6 had made stash; left to get another stove to replace stove had blown up; returned to BC same day and decided to go to KTM to try to extract funds from Brill, who had not produced promised money and [Yoder] left BC 22nd Dec for KTM. 

Back up on Mtn on 21st Dec by Bulcock and Nuru Wangchuk; other Americans were already up; kept moving gear up into higher camps. Then Bulcock, Cain and Millar decided 23 Dec to go down and stop climbing because they were very tired and had had enough. Bulcock and Millar left BC 24th Dec. 

Then 9-day snowstorm; Barber, McGrath and Nuru were in C3 on 23rd; had decided to keep pushing on up. Cain stayed at BC C2 until 3 Jan (stayed to take photos and meet others in their descent, but left to fly out of Nepal on 8 Jan to return to work). Now at BC were only cook and kitchen boy. After snowstorm stopped 1 Jan, Cain could see nothing of C3 (or high stash), rocks on ridge or any other signs of expedition except C1, which was still in place (C2 normally not visible came came was "around the corner"). Yoder and Bulcock went from KTM 6th Jan and reached BC site 8th; cook and kitchen boy had dismantled camp and left site with gear on 6th; could see no C3 or sign of life.

Group were more a collection of people wanting to climb Dhaulagiri than a team. Brill went on approach march but did not go to BC and left Nepal 31 Nov. Yoder would take walkie-talkies if doing climb over again, but otherwise would not change tactics. Yoder only member with any experience in Himalayan climbing.


US Dhaulagiri I, Winter 1989

Bodies found 1000 ft above BC - had been killed by avalanche - seen by police who went up after same of their clothing seen in Jomsom was really running expedition. Brill and Nuru were developing business together. Brill "not motivated" to climb and had decided several months in advance not to go to Dhaulagiri - took trekking group around Annapurna.

Climbed the approach to East Face, then traversed at about 6000m to standard NE Ridge route and placed highest known camp at 6400m on ridge. All members (except Brill, who never actually went to base camp) carried loads to cache in a snowhole at 7315m on ridge on 19 Dec. On 23 Dec Barber, McGrath and Nuru Sherpa were in camp at 6400m. for summit bid while other members were either in base or had left for Kathmandu. Severe 9-day snowstorm struck a day or so later and men on mountain never seen alive again. Nor could their camp and cache above be seen when weather finally cleared. By 2 Jan only Nepalese cook and kitchen helper at base, and they dismantled camp four days later. Bodies of avalanche victims found later by police at 4000m.
ACCIDENTS: None except disappearance of Barber, McGrath and Nuru Sherpa

SPONSOR: 1989-90 Tearyun High School Alpine Club Winter Langshisa Ri
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Langshisa Glacier
C1 at same site of New Zealand team in spring 1986.

No snow below 5600m, weather good and full moon. Fixed rope from 6000m, where dangerous blue ice started, to summit; face very steep. Yang only to 5200m and 3 others only to 5000m; all members had headaches. 

Kim Bo-Youl and Dawa Sherpa left C1 4 am on 14th Dec and reached top 9:19 am, returned to BC 5 pm. Kim very tired but Dawa Sherpa very strong. 

15th Dec Lee Dong-Myung and Ang Kami up from BC but weather turned bad with black clouds arriving and climbers turned back and expedition ended.

Cho Soo-Young and Park Soon-Sek arrived BC 16th Dec same day expedition left BC; so with Kim Tae-Soon now arriving in BC, total 6 Koreans climbing.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing serious; Kim Tae-Soon developed altitude sickness on approach march

SPONSOR: 1989-90 Korean Winter Himalaya Langtang Ri Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at Japanese depot camp
C2 on SW Ridge's north side
C3 on SW Ridge's north side.

SW Ridge very sharp knife ridge with many steep snowfaced walls; fixed rope for 1000m from C1 to half-way between C2 and C3. 

Summit party started from C3 at 5:50 am, on top 1:50 pm, back at C3 4:30 pm and to C2 7 pm. Left BC 10th Dec.

Kim did not get above C1 because of headache.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to powder snow
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on northwest shore of Tilicho Lake
C1 at NE Spur (which leads to North Ridge)
High point on North Ridge.

A foot of loose powder snow on top of shale on spur. Got near site for a C2 but decided not worth continuing with such snow. Only two people got onto mountain at all: "didn't want only pain," others just not interested in climbing.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to death of Sirdar Ang Lhakpa
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 on East Face 
High point on SE Face.

25th Dec all Koreans in C2 with high-altitude headache so high climbers were Ang Lhakpa and Ang Tshering, only were above C2 making route to C3 to be pitched at 7900m. Ang Tshering reached 7600m and Ang Lhakpa fell 200m from 7800m down face at 3:20 pm (Ang Tshering saw him fall and came to rest). Avalanche took away C2 tent in which there was no one because climbers were out trying to reach Ang Lhakpa but then big snow avalanching carried away body and it not found. After his death, all Sherpas refused to climb any more and members therefore also abandoned climb. Had planned Sherpas would stock C3 and then an alpine-style summit bid from C3 by 3 Koreans and Ang Lhakpa. Team never intended to attempt SW Face and did not do so.

Belgians suggested 2 teams climb together on 18th Dec but Koreans they talked to did not understand and did not agree. Belgians cut fixed ropes and seized new rope and this made Sherpas angry (Koreans also angry) and Sherpas attacked Belgians; Koreans did not join fight but separated Sherpas and Belgians (Lee was not at camp where fight took place).

This team and Belgian-French party climbed on SE Face to the right of normal line used successfully by Austrian-German team in 1978. Highest point reached 7800m was gained by Ang Lhakpa Sherpa alone; he then fell 200m and a big snow avalanche immediately carried away his body. Other Sherpas refused to continue climb, and Koreans too gave up.

SPONSOR: Cho Oyu Nepalese Himalaya Belgium Expedition 1989
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to dangerous serac avalanching
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lungsampa Glacier at bottom of face
C1 at Polish C1.

Constant serac avalanching on face night and day. Same route as Poles to 6000m; impossible to climb direct line below 6000m where are very big crevases on a direct line. 4 km long route if follow Polish route above 6000m and expedition had tents only for 2 camps; tried to climb right ridge of face. Very difficult to decide to stop climb becasue ice in good condition and technically not excessively difficult. Summit bid started 15th Dec and reached C2. 16th 4:00 am started up again but snowing and clouds and no chance for success it seemed, and will power not strong enough. Turned back at 7200m and down to C1 same day. On 18th at BC decided serac avalanching too dangerous. At C2 during night -30 degrees but dry. Wind strong but not possible.

Decision to abandon climb influenced greatly by presence of Korean expedition who had arrived at Belgium BC about 12th Dec to climb SE Face despite their permit was for SW Ridge. Koreans made no attempt to climb their permitted route. Koreans came to Belgian route, used Belgian fixed ropes without asking and made C1 same site. Sherpas did the climbing on Korean expedition.

17 Dec in BC. 18 Dec Hubert and Maincent to Korean's C1 to talk to Koreans to try again to arrange sharing route. Koreans refused to talk so Belgiums said would next day remove own rope and this day 18th cut on Korean rope at bottom of route (on 19th Korean's Sherpas replaced their rope and Belgians took down their own short section of rope. Koreans fixed entire route). On 19th evening (6:00 pm) 3 Koreans (including 2nd leader) and 7 Korean Sherpas came over to Belgium BC to fight: 2nd leader said to Hubert and Maincent, the only Belgian team members in BC, "I kill you" and 2 Koreans with sticks and 2 Sherpas with fists attacked Hubert and Maincent. Maincent, who argued and resisted, was more seriously attacked and bled from on temple from stick. Both Hubert and Maincent legs had to use ski poles to help them walk afterwards. When blood seen by Korean's Sherpas they were afraid and when Hubert returned to their camp; fight lasted 1 hour. Hubert and Maincent left BC at 9:30 pm leaving their 2 Sherpas at camp, fearing Koreans would return and again attack in their larger members; reached Gokyo early in morning and then continued on down. "I never imagined such a thing could happen." At time of fight, Belgian's party at BC were only Hubert and Maincent and 2 Sherpas; Lane and Nyssens had left on 17th as originally planned they would.

Maincent was tied with a rope around his neck connected to his hands behind his back; he fell over and was able to free his hands from insecure knots.

Team had hoped that big serac wall would not be very dangerous in winter time, which is why they chose to climb in winter season, but constant serac avalanching on SE Face night and day forced abandonment of climb. They made their attempt via a line to the right of the normal route.

SPONSOR: Marc Batard Lhotse S Face Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7000m due to direct route too dangerous
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Chhukung
C1 on S Face of Lhotse/Lhotse Shar (Polish autumn 1989 C2)
High point on South Face.

Batard went immediately to acclimatize on Lhotse S Face because Polish autumn expedition's ropes went there and in perfect condition. Tents were still there at C2 (C3 and C4 tents were collapsed and unusable). Started up face on 26th Nov and went directly from Chhukung to 6250m on face and back to BC same day. 27th at BC for rest. 28th afternoon went to Polish C2 at 6200m and slept there. 29th up to 7000m and back to BC same day. Decided to wait for Profit: too dangerous to climb alone on direct route (too dangerous for Batard) and to use Polish route too easy with Polish ropes in place. Profit wanted to climb Polish route, Batard would also and go faster than he. If Profit going top direct route, Batard not interested in climbing with him because Profit slower and it would wear carrying too much gear and summit not possible. Profit, who did not invite Batard to join him, said he was not interested in Polish route. They met at Namche on 1st Dec and Batard did not return to Chhukung; abandoned idea of climb. Batard cannot do what Beghin or Messner (or Kukuczka) can do: climb slowly steadily with heavy load; Batard can only go "very high and very quick."

Batard declared he was not interested in following the Polish autumn 1989 route and using their ropes but only in making his own new route more directly to the summit than the Poles line. But he found his direct line too dangerous for a his kind of solo bid and abandoned his attempt after having reached a high point of 7000m in only two days climb. "I cannot do what Beghin or Messner can do, climb alone slowly, steadily with a heavy loads; I can only go very light and very quick." He left the mountain before Profit and Lucas began their climb.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due to continuous strong wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Chhukhung
C1 no fixed camps
C3 at routes and bivouacs
High point at South Face.

5 times on face: 1st with Lucas, other times alone:

1. 17th Dec 6:00 pm from BC climbed all night and all day 18th via new route and reached biv at 6750m at 6:00 pm 18th, stayed 2 nights and left some supplies. Down via Polish route (and ropes) to bottom of face in 4 hrs and to BC. Down because clouds and snow coming. Lucas went home.

2. 28th Dec 1 pm from BC, climbed all night up Polish route; reached Polish C4 (7300m) for 1st biv, where arrived 3:30 pm 29th. Big problem with wind, which almost blew tent down face at 3:00 am and had to make snowhole. 30th all day in snowhole because of wind. 31st down to BC starting 4:00 pm when wind abated and reached BC 2:00 am on 1st Jan.

3. 12 Jan from BC 8:30 pm, bottom of face 1:15 pm 13th climbed all night and stopped 7:00 am 13th 5560m because very strong wind. Back to BC same day - Polish route.

4. 19th Jan from BC 10:00 pm, bottom of face 1:30 pm 20th and up very quickly: 7300m at 2:30 pm 20th on Polish route. Slept in snowhole again because of wind. 21st and 22nd night also slept there. 23rd down at 10:00 am, bottom of face 3:00 pm 23rd was in very good condition but impossible to climb in very strong wind.

After Lucas went home, Profit climbed only Polish route for maximum security "which is very importent for me." 1st time alone on face was not to reach summit but to carry up supplies. 2nd and 3rd times alone on face were attempts to reach summit.

No falling stones or ice on Polish route, but some to its right. "Face is very big - 3500 meters. Takes long time to fix rope if you are a big expedition and get very tired." Exposed to wind and in spring and autumn a lot of snow. Can be climbed if no wind or no snow; necessary to spend 3 more days above 7300m if an expedition, Profit would have taken in ascent 4 days total:
 
  1st to 7300m
  2nd to 7600m
  3rd to 8000m
  4th to top 
  5th to 7300m
  6th to BC 

Would like to return to Face. In BC late Nov and start climb early Dec - very safe period, no stone, ice good. Would return to Profit-Lucas new route. This time spent days looking at face, deciding route. 

Profit and Lucas attempted the great South Face by a previously untried line to the left of Polish autumn 1989 route, and in 24 hours of continuous climbing gained 2600 vertical meters to bivouac at 6750m. But then they traversed to Poles' fixed ropes and descended when a snowstorm approached. Lucas went home while Profit stayed and went up the face alone three times via the Polish route, for it was much safer for a soloist to use the fixed ropes. His plan was to climb the face in four days bivouacing at 7300m, 7600m and 8000m in the ascent, fourth 7800m. He had to spend two to three hours to overcome difficult section where he kept slipping one or two meters ("this was most difficult problem I had ever encountered and I was afraid I couldn't solve it"). He managed to reach the NE Ridge at 7800m at 3:00 pm on the 10th, when it started to snow. He was exhausted and with snow falling; he decided against pushing on up to the summit and instead descended. Climb was now over.

SPONSOR: S Tirolean Himalayan Expedition to Pumori
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6950m due to objective obstacles (serac and crevasses)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at bottom of big lake
C1 at glacier at top rock rib due south of point 6576m
High point at SE Rib.

After BC, 5 days acclimatizing, then started climbing. After reaching site for C1 on 21st, came down to biv at 6000m because of dense fog and snow threatened. Down to BC 19th, 21st in good weather BC to C1 where slept. 22nd summit bid; reached 6950m, where was big serac and crevasse which stopped climb via East Ridge. Returned to C1 and 23rd to BC and climb finished because permit only for this route. 

High point reached by 2 members; 2 others, Stocker and Stricker, stopped 6780m. Thought they were on normal route. Left BC 24 Jan.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to George Curry's death
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at bottom end of lake
High point at start of buttress.

Stayed at BC few days then decided to go up one afternoon to look at the mountain see route and how snow condition: 5 members climbed for 2 hrs. On 28th when at 4:00 pm Curry fell, Nations and Harrison had reached the high point and turned around when Curry on 30 degrees ice, easy ground, started sliding; never tried self arrest in 500 ft slide and then went out of sight. Did not call out or respond to Harrison's shouts to him to stop but did not appear to try to stop (had crampons and ice axe). Team was unroped. Curry slid all the way down mountain. Found him only next day. Slid/fell about 2000 vertical meters; body in one piece but unrecognizable. Wife was part of search party on 29th. Certainly did not survive fall; was there watching crossing patch of ice on which Curry had slipped. Body taken to scree at bottom of SE face and then off falling stone and ice after sun hit face, covered it completely. 

30th decided to continue climb and went out again to look at route. Did not climb up but looked up from around base. 31st got up to go up but no one wanted to climb. "Our hearts weren't in it." Could easily avoid the objective dangers.

ROUTE3: E Ridge up; SE Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  across river from Pheriche at Na Wagla
ABC between 5096m and 5110m on Schneider map.

Attempted NE Buttress first, got to 5500m on 4th Dec by Etherington and Schneider in 3-day attempt from ABC on 2nd Dec. Abandoned this route because of slow progress in deep powder snow. Back to BC on 5th Dec. At same time other two members made attempts on North Face twice and got to 5350m on 2nd attempt on 6th Dec; turned back by extreme cold and wind slab. 7th Dec Etherington and Schneider from BC to ABC for attempt on E Ridge (same as British 1988 Duff); 9th Dec 3:20 am from ABC and reached 5600m on ridge; 10th to 6140m where bived next to crevasse on glacier. 11th 8:30 am left without gear and got to top via bad wind slab on summit ridge at 12:45 pm and back to last biv 3:30 pm and 12th to BC via SE Face near Japanese Couloir same day. 

12th Dec Chippendale and Emerson left BC and went to lake underneath SE Face. 13th back to BC because of heavy snow previous day. 15th to same point 5172m. 16th climbed SE Face to 5700m where biv on ledge too small (Emerson too cramped and moved up). 17th went into Japanese Couloir (climbed Japanese 1985 route probably) and reached Japanese biv at 6140m when found nut from Etherington's ice axe. 18th climbed summit pyramid by slightly different route from others descent route; got to 10m below summit (as did others) via summit ridge (on East Ridge) (didn't go up last 10m because of unnecessary great risk - would have been fatal to climb from wind slab) at 11:30 am and down same route to last biv. 19th to BC.

Lobuje East climbed by Etherington and Schneider. Left BC 16th Dec; one night in Lobuje village; 17th to base of E Face couloir; 18th climbed from biv at 5200m up couloir and reached top of mountain at 4:00 pm and to biv at 5300m on normal route; 19th back in BC. 22nd other two left BC to try Lobuje East and got to 5200m; 23rd to bottom of couloir 5400m where exhausted and back down. 

Pokalde climbed by Etherington; left BC 22nd at 5:15 am and reached 11:00 am via normal on North Ridge and down to Namche where joined Schneider; other 2 arrived 24th Dec in time for Xmas.

"Alpine style, clean, fast and light" says Emerson.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st ascent of E Ridge; 1st British and German to summit

ROUTEMEMO:
C3 above Great Shelf.

Planned all climing finished 13th Dec but because of cold and wind climbing prolonged. 13th up to 8300m but very strong wind and cold defeated this summit bid and all to C3 except Jin and 2 Sherpas, Ang Dawa Sherpa and Tchiring Thebe Lama to C4. 20th the 3 men 4:30 am started up, 2:30 pm cloudy and windy and worried about returning late but kept going up and reached summit 4:05 pm (if turned back at 2:30 would be dark by time reached C4 anyway - had headlamps). 5 mins rest and photos at top. At 4:14 pm leader at BC talking with sirdar; base and sirdar stopped talking and Kim tried to talk to summit Sherpa but no answer; men in C4 also tried to contact summiter but also received no answer all night. 21st search by men in C4 and C1 but no trace. Probably 3 summiters fell down N Face. No avalanching and could not be seen 21st morning in clear but windy weather. No snowfall during windy night of 20th.

1st summit bid leader and Sherpas used oxygen at and above C4 and other members except Jin used it climbing above C4. 

2nd summit bid Jin used oxygen sleeping in C4 and climbing above C4, but Sherpas used it only sleeping.

Kim finds it difficult to accept that Jin is dead, that he is not just late coming back from N Face.
ACCIDENTS: 3 fatalities on summit ascent; Kim Sang-Ho severe altitude sickness and stayed below BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5750m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO: Too much snow and serious avalanche danger. 14 May to BC and decided 17 May impossible to continue under such dangerous snow conditions.

SPONSOR: Polish International Dhaulagiri E Face Exped. to Dhaulagiri
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at NE Col
C2 on NE Ridge
Biv on NE Ridge
Depot on NE Ridge.

For 1st 2 weeks separated out of Italian BC because of porter problems and moved to normal site only when Germans arrived and could use their porters (and now less snow). On 24th Wielicki went to summit from biv tent at 7000m (found from previous expedition) at 4:20 am and got to top 10:50 am and back to biv at 1:20 pm and down to BC same day (2 members were with him as far as biv and back).

30th April other 2 members made deposit at 7450m and that night tent crushed by snow; had to cut it open to get out and for them climb finished (Schleypen left BC). Gniadek not well now. 

Baeyens started 9th May up on normal route with Dujmovits of German team, using depot to sleep in enroute and got to top later than him and came down exhausted. 

9th May 10 pm Wielicki started from NE Col; had to spend 2-3 hrs at 7800m trying to overcome difficult ice section on which kept slipping 1-2m (most difficult problem ever encountered; feared he could not solve it) and reacehd ridge 3:00 pm on 10th, when it started to snow; now decided not to go on up because of snowfall and was exhausted; retreated to depot/C3, surprised to find 2 people there and went down to biv where reached 8:00 pm and slept there; for first time in his career felt someone were with him; believe this is from great stress (not just difficulty) and looking for companionship.
ACCIDENTS: Shleypen slight frostbite; Gniadek back problem

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at 2 snow caves and tents slightly above NE Col
C2 where NE ridge starts getting steep 
   (1 big snow cave 20m onto E Face and 3 tents)
C3 at NE Ridge.

29th April Sirdar Wangel and Walde went from C1 to C2 and Ralf from BC to C2; all reached C2 area; Wangel was ahead, just a few meters from camp, when he set off slab avalanche and was carried 200m with avalanche down E Face; too dangerous to search for him on face and no sign of him. 

At beginning of climb very good weather but later much snowfall with some avalanche danger & spent lot of time doing nothing. 11th May Ralf and Ingrid Baeyens of Polish team left C4 for top at 5:00 am and Ralf on top at 11:00 am and Ingrid at 1:30 pm. On last part of ascent, from 7500m to 8000m, Dujmovits and Baeyens went onto N Face for safer climb.

Joos and Dacher were one day behind summiters but Dacher turned back at 7000m on 10th and Joos got to area needing 2 ice axes but had only one and turned back at 7200m (other ice ax and other gear Joos says, should have been available from summiters but they stayed an extra day in C3 and that ruined the plan). Walde too was going up and got to 7200m. 

Six members and Schleypen from Polish team left BC 6th May having decided climb was over for them (Schleypen had frostbite). Walde wanted to try again but no one else did and Polish team also leaving. Left BC 13th May.

BC southwest of peak
C1 5 hours above BC on ridge north southwest side
C2 at same ridge beyond a col, before West Summit
C3 on plateau surrounded by big crevasses.

Two summits: W Summit and Main Summit; went to W Summit above C2 and then down; from C3 climbed very steep blue ice traversed to E Ridge and then to summit. "Very technical" climb above C3. E Ridge had some very soft snow, some rock and some hard ice and "very difficult climb." Total 3600m rope fixed from 200m below C1 to summit all the way. 

All the members date of birth of this expedition originally given in BS (Nepali Year)

NPMAF = Nepal Police Mountaineering & Adventure Foundation.

1st official ascent. Rumored that British climbers (and possibly others) summited in earlier years.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5670m due to difficult route, lack of experience
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lirung Glacier at shepard's stone huts just halfway up slope to SE ridge
   east of point 5229 SE Ridge.

Spectacular hourly avalanches off East Face. Established C1 5 April but then went to Ganja La Chuli (Naya Kanga) on which established 2 camps (7th April at 14,000 ft and 8th April at 16,000 ft) and 9th April all members except Kohn and Wedmore to top (Wedmore not yet in Nepal). After this climb 4 left team as planned. 

Others returned to BC 11th to 12th April. Yardley, Kohn and Kendall went to another small peak because Kendall and Kohn clearly unable to climb Langtang. Yardley then joined Langtang climb while Kendall and Kohn stayed at BC. Chauvin, Doherty, Bill [Yeo] and Pheasant established C2 on SE Ridge on 14th April but did not sleep there. 16th Chauvin and Doherty to sleep in C2 (fixed rock ridge above C2) but down to C1 with view that route too difficult for inexperienced climbers in group and with only 5 days left to attempt Langtang because of client's program, decided to abandon climb. 18th up to C2 to bring it down to C2 and on 20th C1 cleared. Left BC 24th April, arrived Dunche 26th. It's an excellent route for experienced climbers; 6 on this team were qualified to do it but had to look after others. Had unusually deep snow but route safe if stay well away from East Face and its avalanches. Need 4 weeks to climb Langtang Lirung with lot of works needed at 18,000 to 20,000 ft.

Most of the expedition's members were inexperienced in the Himalaya, and the leadership decided this mountain's southeast ridge was technically too difficult for them. "It's an excellent route for experienced climbers and six on this team of 20 were qualified to do it, but we had to look after the others. We had unusually deep snow, but the route is safe if you stay well away from the East Face," where there were "spectacular" avalanches every hour. It would have taken four weeks to climb the route successfully and safely, Wilcox estimated.
ACCIDENTS: None except Kohn's intimidation by high mountains

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at low site 
C2 at Naike Col.

Made low BC because higher one too dangerous from avalanches; much bad weather. 3 times up to C1 and C2 and driven down by heavy snowfall and avalanche danger. 4th attempt by De Stefani and De Leo to C1 21st April, 22nd to C3 on direct route, not normal route. 25th bivouac at 6700m; 26th start at 5 am, 11:10 De Stefani on top while De Leo had problem at last 150m. Strong wind and De Stefani on top only 10 min; 12:30 return to biv; plan was to descend to C2 but De Leo unable to go below C4 that day and on 27th to BC. De Leo ran out of strength; feet frostbitten when he took off his boots.

Papa reached C2, 4 other members to C3 only. 1 Tamang above BC to C3.
ACCIDENTS: De Leo frostbitten toes & fingers (De Leo's first time in Himalaya)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5600m due to heavy snowfall, dangerous avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at above Samagaon
High point at Naike Col site.

After C2 much snowfall and avalanches; big avalanche "brushed" C2, very dangerous. Impossible to continue in new fresh snow every day and dangerous avalanching. Did not actually sleep in C2 but in C1 and next day up to C2 to bring down C2 and after that continous bad weather. Left BC 5 May. 

Americans had fatal avalanche, Italians frozen feet.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5200m due to fatal avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC higher normal site
C1 on medial moraine of Manaslu Glacier.

After 21 March, when 5 people in C1, snowed from evening of 21st till evening of 25th when diminished but never really cleared. C1 having problem keeping camp together with 2m of snow. On 26th improved weather let BC people to plan to try to go up and those in C1 to make route to C2 with BC people to resupply C1 food. But 27th in fact weather closed in again and unable to make route to C2 and team in C1 return to BC. 7:30 am BC team left for C1 and at 8:45 am C1 group left for BC. At about 9:00 am a slab broke off above C1 party when C1 team at 4700m - climax slab which broke down night to dirt - 100m long. At 9:45 am Zangbu Sherpa stumbled down from C1 and reported avalanche with people buried by avalanche (all members had avalanche beacons). Stockmyer also not buried but saw Schertz get buried but very deep (1-1/2m) dense snow and took 20 mins to uncover him but already dead; Zangbu dug himself out (buried to neck); Stockmyer went for Jackson and others from BC joined in digging her out; she equally deeply buried for 1 hr, found dead. Nima Wangchu found where Zangbu had been and he also dead. Evacuated bodies to old C1. 28th Haigh and Goodman left immediately to KTM with others to remove bodies for cremation. Haigh and Goodman hope to leave KTM immediately with "wife" of another member in KTM (she had been trekking) to await return of rest of team. Haigh and Goodman arrived KTM 4th; no word yet from the others.

15 April: Trekking agent says all other survivors returned to KTM in good health.

BC near Mingbo
C1 at start of SW Ridge (traditional site)
C2 at crest of Yellow Tower (traditional site).

Been to BC earlier than 13th March, then went to Island Peak which only Haszko failed to climb. Huge amount of fixed ropes from many years ago as well as recent climbs. 4th April summiters had 7 days climb: 5 up and 2 down: had bad cloudy weather and others saw them towards upper slopes and then disappeared and thought to be dead where as had climbed to top half hour before dark and descended that night to a bivouac in topmost serac band at 20,000 ft. 

2nd summit party took 6 days to climb with only 1 day in descent with biv in natural ice cave at start of mushroom ridge. Last biv reached at noon, left at 3:30 am next day and on top 1:30 pm.

Very slow because Simpson had hurt his foot 2 days before leaving England, had toothache and sciatica. More difficult climb than Delaney had expected: worrying about route: "descent horrendous abseiling down those rocks."
ACCIDENTS: Murphy frostbitten toes & Phillips frostnip; Durran failed to acclimatize

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at same site as top and Chamoux teams
1st C1 at North Col for North Buttress attempt
2nd C1 at normal route
C2  at normal route.

Abandoned N Pillar route because of danger followed by storms; set off on alpine-style ascent of standard route on 9th May. Weight loss fatigue and sickness saw only Groom and Dignan arrive at 2nd bivouac at 7100m. On 11 May McDowell and Dignan set off at 3:00 am for summit. McDowell arrived at summit at 9:05 am - an amazing solo climb from situation of the biv. Dignan suffering fatigue refused to turn back until finally at around 4:00 pm he turned back at over 8100m just short of summit and made it back to biv at 7:00 pm in "dark" (fax report by Rick White).

Groom: in the 2 weeks after BC arrived, had to look at W Buttress and Groom 22 April reached 6000m and decided rock fall too dangerous and back to BC where other 3 waiting. They went to have look for themselves but not above C1 because of heavy snowfall and strong winds (reached C1 on 1 May and down to BC 2 May). Decided on "alpine" ascent of normal route and waited for good weather. 9th May all 5 men to C1. 10th set out for C2 and Rick White and McDowell turned back at 6500m tired and uninterested and Ball turned back at 6840m with headache. Groom and Dignan reached 7100m, where pitched another 3:00 am on 11th and Groom and Dignan went for to carrying nothing and Groom in perfect weather and went past false summit. Dignan struggled with fatigue and altitude and gave up at 8100m. Groom got to C2 at noon, waited for Dignan who arrived and collapsed at 7:00 pm and both spent night. Dignan very tired during descent but altitude problem gave and both back in BC 12th. Everyone left BC 15 May.
ACCIDENTS: Groom stomach ulcer just after Apr 22; Dignan altitude problem

SPONSOR: DAV Summit Club Cho Oyu Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at 1 hour below Tichy's camp
C2 on ridge.

Moved C2 away from ridge after big wind blew away 4 tents there (& if anyone had been in a tent, member would have been blown away too). 26 May summiters on top within one hour's time but not all on top together; only 50m fixed rope total on route: not difficult route. 2 members left early for personal reasons: Deiser & Schefzic. 2 members stayed in BC only because of disinterest & age: Kellner & Sontheimer.

20th May 1995: Ralf Dujmovits, leader of Spring 1995 Cho Oyu expedition was told by Porsche on 4 Feb 95 that the summit party of 19 May 1990 did not reach summit; they got to rocks just below summit plateau at 8100m & then turned back because there was a lot of snow and could not see crevasses known to be there.

24 Sept 1996 - Sigi Hupfauer believe the party on the 19th of May did not reach the highest point "and for me this is not the summit" - 1/2 hour is not long enough to have gotten to it (he read Porsche's reply).


Liz Hawley - 12 Nov 1996

According to Haerter in June 1900, this expedition sent two parties to the top, but I heard this spring (Spring 1996) that in fact the first party did not go all the way, and this September one of the members of the second party, Sigi Hupfauer, whom I have know for years, confirmed that the first group did not go to the highest point; a member of the first party admitted this earlier this year to another German I know. So I am deleting Haerter's five alleged summiters of 19 May, 1990, from my list. (But keeping the party on 26 May.)
ACCIDENTS: Tschofen twice had cerebral edema (only serious problem)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to ill health
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Gorakshep
BC at small lake west of Kalapattar
High point at SW Ridge.

Brevik left party 1 April because already "uncomfortable" at altitude of 1st BC and no reason to stay. From 2nd BC, 2 members carried loads for C1 and 1 reached very nearly to its site. Climbed along east side of ridge beyond Pt 5628 and finally on this ridge. Ljoen turned back at 5700m because of altitude and Rosvoll at 6000m because very tired. Olsen was there in 2nd BC with problems of altitude, head cold and stomach trouble. All 3 stayed in BC. 

Rosvoll waited to try more climbing but other 2 did not and would not let him climb alone, so climb abandoned 8th April. Route climbed was not difficult except for loose stones, but above 6000m would be difficult knife-edge snow ridge with steep sides to point 6186m.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to expedition declared finished by leader in KTM
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  towards SE corner of big lake
ABC at bottom of ridge pillar in southeast side (pillar that ends at snow plateau)
C1  at top of this ridge
High point at East Ridge.

Many crevasses between C1 and C2 and around C2. Yanagihara stayed in BC with balloon communications. C1 slow to make because French had a lot equipment for skiing and parapente. Tardivel tried to go top but no cooperation from Sherpa, so no one to take his photograph on summit, which was very important for a professional. Tardivel and Robert planned to go up on 11th May after Tardivel had 2 day's rest at BC, but now balloon over Everest had crashed in Tibet on 9th. Balloon photography was main aim of expedition and leader in KTM ordered team to leave mtn. Tardivel's mind was entirely on his skies and parapente and did not cooperate about balloon filming.

Iwa-to-Yuki Annual claims that Catherine Tardivel (31) was part of the team as a guide.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing serious; Hatano who didn't feel well from altitude used 1 bottle of oxygen at high BC only

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to fatal accident
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  towards SE corner of big lake
ABC at bottom of ridge pillar on SE side (pillar that ends at snow plateau)
C2  at top of this ridge
High point at East Ridge.

Route completed to C2 at 6600m on 28th March by Sherpas while only Mori in C1, Kato in BC, Kitazawa going up from BC to ABC and Matsuda up from ABC to C1. On 28th morning 8 am on radio Mori coming down that day to BC; at 12:50 pm Nima Temba now in C1, Mori's equipment in tent but no Mori. Matsuda going up from ABC to C1 was asked by BC to investigate. Matsuda arrived C1 1:40 pm and decided to climb into crevasse and found Mori 170m down in crevasse dead, no body pulse; body very cold; could not remove, very tightly jammed. Climb finished and next day brought down C1. Body left in crevasse (dangerous to descend in crevasse). Team left BC 1 April.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6375m due to bad weather, members exhausted, and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  below smaller of 2 lakes on NGS Map
ABC at huge stone at top of moraine
C1  just above Lingtren Pass on East Ridge
Biv on East Ridge.

From ABC climbed rock spur followed by Lenser in 1962 to Lingtren La on fixed ropes; snowy weather. From C1 3 members climbed alpine-style on ridge, which was quite difficult in unstable snow, many cornices & some rock pitches. Made biv this night of 16th May. 17th hoping perhaps to go to top, are likely to have a 2nd biv. Wind changed from north to now out of south with clouds, and then snowfall from south. No fixed rope here so retreated to C1 in very little visuability Slept in C1. 18th more bad weather so down to ABC removing fixed rope in descent and 19th all in BC. Climb now finished: Tired, bad weather and time running out. 4 members had left BC about 16th May because of fixed departure date from Nepal.

Route farther right than usual route; much safer but longer; on this route Italians had no snow avalanches or falling seracs as usual route.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to bad snow conditions and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at west bank of Lungsampa Glacier east of Gyazumpa
C1 at Ngozumba Glacier in bank of ENE of point 5720m on Schneider map
C2 at glacier above and north of point 5695m
C3 in crevasse on open glacier below U
High point at lower part of West Face.

Lost lot of rope gear and trying to force route through first icefall, so went up eastern side of rock buttress on loose scree with hard bedrock and fixed these; then 200 ft steep sort of chimney to grassy meadow and snow gully just to east of Pt 5695m and traversed up on to glacier where put C2. Then encountered 5 km-wide second icefall constantly having seracs falling. 29th April to 10th May walked searching for route through second icefall acceptably safe and had people missed by 50m by massive falls.

10th May 6 men went up from C2 to rock buttress-island just east of Pt 6515 and crossed this and dumped gear there for C3 which was established where wanted to put up a new route. 15th may onto 60 degrees ice just above bergschrund (rotten ice) trying to put camp at about 7400m on W Face. Night of 17th May 4 days of snowfall and generally bad weather with tremendous avalanching in area - trails wiped out, fixed ropes covered; temperature now rose considerably and snow became very sticky. 21st May 5 men up from C3 planning to go to high point of fixed ropes already there at 7100m, established C4 at 7300-7400m and 2 for top from there, but 5 men early in morning were avalanched at bottom of bergschrund at 6850m. One man got completely buried but dug out by Kenny who was on same ropes; then down to C3. Other 3 tried to reorganize on this slab avalanche they been "absorbed into" but they too down to C3 later same day. Now with unstable weather, avalanche danger and manpower scattered, decided to abandon climb.

SW Ridge too dangerously corniced to attempt.

Antolik wants to return to Gyachung Kang and its W Face.


BC established on 24th April

After the excitement of KTM and the problems of our hasty departure from the troubles here we are now safely set up in the BC, just a few miles from the mountain. We arrived here together, having met up with Major Kit Spencer, his two Gurkha soldiers, Sarah Arathoon and Mick Kenny at Namche Bazar on the morning of Sunday 22nd April. We saved two days on the walk in from KTM by extending the usual trekking legs and by making use of the excellent weather Nepal is currently enjoying. Further time was made up by reaching BC, from Namche in 2 days instead of 5, the cost of this inevitably was a day of sore heads as we struggled to acclimatise. Fortunately the pain did not last long, except for the leader who was involved in a clinical trial for Boots Pharmaceuticals and obviously drew a very short straw in the selection of painkillers.

Base Camp is sited at 5120m on the moraine above the junction of the Lungsampa and Ngozumba Glaciers. We have spectacular views of Cho Oyu which is 8 kms to the north but can only see the top 800 feet of Gyachung Kang which is hidden by a ridge coming down from Cho Oyu.

Work on the 25th centred on organising our stores and food and on making BC as comfortable as possible for our month-long stay. Kit Spencer, Sarkey (our Sirdar) and Lalit reconnoitered the route from BC across the Lungsampa Glacier and along the moraines on the north side of the Ngozumpa Glacier to find a safe way to the first icefall which guards the route to Gyachung Kang. On the 26th we all ferried our first loads along this route. Glacier travel is always tortuous and although the distance from BC to the first icefall is less than 6 kms it took us 3-1/2 hours to comlete the journey. We carried loads of between 20 and 25 kgs and have established a temporary camp at the foot of the 600m high wall of rock and ice. Last night Andy Hughes and Greg Hill stayed at the camp and today are beginning to find a route through the crazy mass of towering rock and ice blocks. The route will then be marked using fixed ropes so we can carry equipment and food further up the mountain to the base of the second icefall and ultimately to the base of the southwest ridge. I hope that C1 will be established tomorrow and in preparation for this Dave Orange and Chris Barnes are joining Andy and Greg this afternoon to help them secure the route. The rest of the team are carrying more loads to the temporary camp.

The fine weather enjoyed on the trek has changed since our arrival and a pattern of fine, sunny mornings to about 11 am followed by wind and light snow showers in the afternoons and evenings seems to be the norm. Temperatures during the day vary between O degrees C and 28 degrees C and at night fall to -10 degrees C.

Everyone on the team is well and working hard. The food is good and our Nepalese staff are supporting us well - long may it last.

SPONSOR: Kamoshika Dojin Everest N Face Winter 1983-84
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m due to high winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Rongbuk
C1 at Central Rongbuk Glacier.

Yasuhira Saito (Gaurishanker) - 4 Aug 1984

Saito was member of expedition. Climb abandoned at bottom of Hornbein Couloir. No place for tent in winds and rock fall danger.

Very cold very strong winds, 3 Japanese and 1 Chinese frostbitten but none very serious. When team arrived at BC mountain was white, but slowly became blacker and blacker.

Mrs Takahashi returns to attempt in winter 1985-86 (postponed from this winter).

Team used 13 Chinese "assistants" above BC.

Michiko Takahashi is also known by her maiden name, Michiko Imai, leader 1979 autumn Dhaulagiri II-III-IV-V traverse.

SPONSOR: Japanese Everest N Col Autumn 1985 Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8200m due to bad weather, member's death and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
Planned solo ascent on N Face: by leader Tsuneo Hasegawa after others reached top via N Col-N Ridge and provided support for Hasegawa's descent.

Shinichi Ishii killed by avalanche which he started at about 6900m and which buried him.


Shambu Tamang, Spanish-Nepal Everest - 28 Sept 85

Japanese team this autumn were attempting Everest by two routes simultaneously:
N Face (Australian 1984) and N Col-NE Ridge.


Letter from Tsunemichi Ikeda, Editor in Chief - Nov 11, 1985

It was the 11-member party, led by Tsuneo Hasegawa, to make a dual ascent by North Face and NE Ridge. The leader Hasegawa intended a solo on N Face while the others siege NE Ridge. The latter party was expected to support the leader's descent from the summit. They made a rapid progress and made C5 at 7750m and ropes were fixed up to 8200m by Sept 10th. But on 17th, Shinichi Ishii (37), a photographer and a climber of the NE Ridge party avalanched when he was descending from North Col. His body could not be found. The whole plan was abandoned by the accident and bad weathers.
ACCIDENTS: Shinichi Ishii buried and killed by avalanche which he started at about 6900m

APPROACH: from Lhasa by road to BC
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7315m due to strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  closest to snout of glacier (Central Main Rongbuk)
ABC at Central Rongbuk near small lake
C1  opposite Lho La at northern cwm
C2  right of arete
C3  at snow slope above arete
High point on North Face.

Attemped 3 routes from the north. First tried to reach West Ridge via a north arete, then a line on North Face left of Great Couloir, and finally on North Face farther left again to North Ridge.  

Attempt on first route (W Ridge via N arete), abandoned because of severe avalanching, which swept gear away.

1st route: BC(05/08,5250m),ABC(15/08,5820m),C1(20/08,6250m),C1.8(6780m),C2(03/09,6700m),
  C3(08/09,6900m),xxx(10/09,7240m)

Second route (N Face left of Great Couloir) also abandoned after avalanching, and most members by now had stopped climbing.  

2nd route: BC(05/08,5250m),ABC(15/08,5820m),C1(20/08,6250m),C2(20/09,6850m),
  C3(22/09,7240m),xxx(23/09,7315m)  

On third route (N Face to N Ridge), very brief attempt abandoned with no net altitude gain achieved; climbers pinned down in C3 for three nights by strong winds, and they retreated via N Col route established by Japanese team.   

3rd route: BC(05/08,5250m),ABC(15/08,5820m),C1(20/08,6250m),C2(20/09,6850m),
  C3(06/10,7315m),xxx(06/10,7315m) 

From C1 traversed by ski to base of arrete, dump made there and camp called C1.8 established on shelf by Rheinberger and Bruce at 22,250 ft with fixed rope to it - tent at C1.8, too dangerous for permanent camp. True C2 (slightly lower than C1.8) in a crevasse. Until now early Sept unsettled weather with frequent snowfall. Night that C2 was established severe avalanche down arrete went over C2 (taking a bit of equipment) and C1.8 completely taken away. Huge slab avalanche buried 2 members in snow cave of C3 but were dug out. This caused complete change of plans because of avalanche danger from constant avalanche activity. 

Abandoned route and went for N Face left of Great C Couloir. To 20 Sept made new C2 high in North Cwm at 22,500 ft and C3 at 23,750 ft on N Face occupied about 22 Sept by Farmer, Bruce, Andrews and Van Noorden. Weather again bad and Andrews developing edema, set off an avalanche in descent while Bruce infected liver. Andrews severe frostbite and evacuated to NZ. Had now lost 5 tents and 5 sleeping bags and 2 members at this time and Allen bad tooth. Doctor busy. 2 more decided to leave, Brooks bad stomach = 7 left, and then 2 more left, so by Oct 6 only 5 willing and able to have another go and yaks due Oct 12.
 
On 6 Oct climbed face left of previous route to 24,000 ft where put 2 tents - bad weather meant 3 nights there in high winds. 9 Oct traversed left to N Ridge and down to N Col where met Japanese N Col route. Descended from Col into East Rongbuk Glacier to Japanese C3 where spent night of 9 Oct. On 10th on down to BC. Reinberger, Farmer, Norman, Anderson and Van Noorden were these remaining 5 climbers. Left BC 12 Oct and back to Lhasa and on eastward.

Maximum altitudes:  
  Route 1 - 23,750 ft crest of W Ridge above C3 on top of shoulder triggered
            huge slab avalanche on about 10 Sept
  Route 2 - 24,000 ft by members who had established C3 on about 23 Sept 
  Route 3 - 24,000 ft- 6 Oct

Had small supply of oxygen (7 cylinders) for possible summit bid that never got higher than C1.

21 Dec summit party of Kim Jong-Ho, Park Dong-Seok and Ang Rita reached 8300m; Park used Italian oxygen mask which froze in -50 degree C temp, so they gave up and returned to C4. Ang Rita took no oxygen and Kim had not yet begun using his. 

The next day 22 Dec Ang Rita descended to C2 while Kim Jong-Ho and Park Dong-Seok up again without oxygen use, but carrying 1 bottle each for use above South Summit. They moved slowly and at 8500m only at 3:00 pm after 9 hours climbing and gave up and back to C4 and to C2 23 Dec. 

24 Dec Kim and Ang Rita (to C4 on 23 Dec) planned summit bid, but wind too strong and did not leave C4. 25 Dec they went down to C2. All members to BC. 

Up again 28 Dec, but wind prevented reaching C3. 28 Dec-8 Jan stayed C2 but daily wind prevented climbing, some days even leaving tents except Kim up to C4 on 6 Jan, found tent broken and down same day. 7 Jan Park to C4 to deposit new tent but strong wind and nose and ears slightly frostbitten. All to BC 9 Jan and 5 climbing members to Namche, 2 in BC with Sherpas to BC 19 Jan but Icefall required 6 days repair. Reached C2 31 Jan, 10 days stayed but wind too strong although 8 Feb Kim Jong-Ho and Park Sung-Woo to C3 in tent for 7 days and down to BC 15 Feb. 

Bad weather throughout Jan and Feb defeated other summit bids.

Found body of one Indian climber frozen to ice above C2, below Lhotse face.

1986 US Everest North Face Expedition 
(received Aug 1986 from Al Read who received this from leader)

The 1986 US Everest North Face expedition reached 25,500 ft in its attempt to make the second ascent of the Great Couloir of the North Face of Mt Everest. Bad weather, avalanche danger and exhaustion delayed and then ended the team's attempt to place the last camp (C6) and a try for the summit after its time expired.

The eleven member team reached Lhasa by air on March 9 and BC at the foot of the Rongbuk Glacier by jeep and truck on March 19. C1 was established a week later and C2 (20,000) and C3 (20,500) on the main Rongbuk Glacier north of the North Face by late March.

The route from the foot of the face to C4 (23,500 ft) was obstructed by a bergschrund at the start and made more difficult by 2000 ft of blue ice. Spring conditions differed considerably from the Styrofoam-like snow in the fall of 1984 when the Australian team made the first direct ascent of the couloir. The team spent a month placing 18 fixed ropes before occupying C4 on April 19 and another three weeks putting up C5. After 5 attempts to establish the last camp, the time expired and the team turned back, reaching BC on May 24 and Lhasa two days later.

Apart from one climber who suffered frostbitten fingers and had to return, a case of snowblindness, and much respiratory sickness early in March and early April, the members of the expedition were generally healthy.

The expedition members were Todd Bibler, Carlos Buhler, Dana Coffield, Mark Jenkins, Doug Kelley, Andy Lapkass, Michael Lehner, Joe Murphy, Sandy Stewart, Ann Whitehouse and Brinton Young.

BC at Rongbuk Glacier
C2 at base of spur
C3 halfway up spur
C6 near bottom of Hornbein Couloir.

Had rest period between C3 and C4. Then left BC on 3 May for summit attack by Endo, Nagao, Okadome, 2 Sherpas and Matsunaga on 4 May. 4 May to C2, 5 May to C3, bad weather and back to C2. 

7 May up again from C2 8 May to C3 and C4 on 9 May. Miss Nagano in not good condition and returned to C2 7 May but had climbed to South Col twice before then. 10 May 01:30 hours started from Col: Endo, Matsunaga and Pemba Tsering. At 9:00 hrs reached 8600m. Now very cold and strong wind and had taken too long to reach this point. so turned back. Climb finished.

Endo made this second Everest climb to make it possible for Miss Nagao to become the 1st woman atop Everest without using oxygen.

The three-man team attempted 2 routes from the south side, climbing without Sherpas, oxygen or fixed camps. First they tried to climb the West Ridge and spent the latter half of April attempting to get onto the Lho La, which they finally reached via snowfields near the Khumbutse ridge on 27th April. Next day they moved up Everest's West Ridge and bivouacked at 7100m, 100m down on the SW Face, which they descended into the Western Cwm and back to BC on the 30th. Next day turned their attention on the normal route via Lhotse's West Face; strong wind and snowfall delayed their progress but on 11th May two Polish members began to push from BC which resulted in their gaining a high point for Everest's summit of 7800m.

On the 14th May the 2 Poles, Lwow and Karolczak, went surreptitiously to the summit of Lhotse and back to their bivouac. They considered their Lhotse ascent good acclimatization for another go at the West Ridge route, but Karolczak now developed stomach illness and Austrian member Putz had dropped out of the climb because of an old back injury. 

On 24th May Lwow went alone up through the Khumbu Icefall to try to solo the normal route, but the following several days brought heavy snowfall, he was able to get no higher than 6700m; he was very tired and it would have taken him more days to reach the summit alone than were left in the climbing season; he returned to BC on 27th and abandoned the struggle on the 28th of May.

Japanese agreed expedition could follow Japanese route after 1 May so first tried to climb to Lho La and 3 times were on rocks via Yugoslav route with 3rd time on 17 April got to 50m below Lho La where couloir blocked final climb without 200m more fixed rope which Poles didn't have. 23 April went to left of Yugoslavia route up snow fields near Khumbutse ridge and 27 April bivouac at Canadians camp on Lho La at 6000m. 28 April biv 6900m on ridge and 29 April reached shoulder and bivouacked 100m down on face at 7100m. 30 April descended iced SW Face to W Cwm to Japan C2 and down to BC through Icefall. 1-3 May rest at BC. 4 May 3 members BC to biv at C2 in Cwm about 6700m. 5 May biv on Lhotse face at 7300m then bad weather (wind and snow) and C3 to BC on 7 May. 11 May 2 Poles BC to C2, 12th to C3, 13th to biv 7800m on Geneva Spur. On 14 May actually both Poles went to Lhotse summit and back to biv but officially stayed 14th in biv. Thought Lhotse climb = good acclimatization for W Ridge. Returned to BC 17th and then leader got stomach problem. 24th Lwow alone up through Icefall which was "difficult" and slept at 6700m. Now heavy snowfall and 2 more nights at same biv. 27 May down to BC through much changed Icefall where however he had placed marker flags. 28th 15 cm more new snow at BC and "it was finished" because Lwow very tired and would take 4 days to go to summit but only 3 days of season remained.

Did acclimatization climb to 1m below Lhotse summit rather than up Everest SE Ridge because couloir on Lhotse gave protection from wind.

Had definitely intended to return to W Ridge route, but Karolczak's illness precluded this.
ACCIDENTS: Putz back injury (stopped his climbing); Karolczak stomach illness

Later in 1986, a team of young mountaineers from the Catholic Univ began the second Chile attempt on Everest. Above the North Col at 7000m and at the precise moment when the depot for the attack camp was being prepared, loosened piece of the cornice struck Victor-Hugo Trujillo and he fell nearly 700 vertical meters. His instanteous death put an end to this attempt. 

Source "Everest, The Challenge of the Dream" by Rodrigo Jordan Fuchs, pg 110.


Paul Firth - 13 December 2007

Account forwarded from Argentine sources:

"The 16th August 1986, when Trujillo was a bit higher than the northern 'Collado', he got to near the side that crumbled under his weight. As he was not tied to the rest, he fell 700 meters and died due to the fall. His body was rescued and buried by his friends in a beautiful place in the same valley where the Advanced Base Camp is located. He is still there."

Troillet had wanted to do solo ascent of Hornbein Couloir and Loretan and Beghin wanted to climb Great Couloir, but heavy snowfall in Aug made them decide to climb together to make track. Climbed nearly same route as Japanese 1980. Beghin set out for summit with Loretan and Troillet but was defeated in two attempts by sleepiness and got no higher than 8300m.

Troillet wanted 1st solo Hornbein and Beghin and Loretan wanted to go up Great Couloir but Aug bad weather (heavy snowfall) and all 3 decided to go on same route to make track. 3 climbing members only went to Hornbein direct nearly same as Japanese 1980 route.

3 went together from ABC to 7800m, where made snow cave and in couloir Beghin too sleepy and return to cave while they other 2 went to top. Met again at cave. Same day as they returned, Beghin started in evening alone but at 8300m at 11 pm in Hornbein again sleepy and returned to cave (which was empty) and slept there and next morning to ABC at 5800m just below Changtse ridge on Main Rangbuk Glacier. BC at 5500m where Jeeps stop.

No Sherpas, oxygen, no ropes at all, no sleeping bags on summit push. No accidents. No idea why Beghin so sleepy except were climbing at night to avoid avalanching.

Hornbein not difficult but lower part of face very dangerous from avalanches says Beghin.

Loretan - 25 Sept 86

Everest Aug 1986 took no tent and sleeping bag. Took shovel for snow caving and climbed during cold hours, rested in warm hours by climbing at night. BC to BC 41 hours but risk is greater. If altitude illness or broken leg, finished with only 2 people with only 2 people in this technique.

This very light alpine-style makes possible more difficult routes and longer traverses can be done on 8000ers.


Graf - 30 July 86

Loretan, his girl friend Nicole, Troillet and Beghin at BC 2 weeks now already.

N Face to Lho La to SW Face arriving bottom of Khumbu Icefall in Sept/early Oct if HMG agreed, but apparently did not, since some gear they would have sent for Nepal side has not turned up.


Erhard Loretan (interview: 24 Sept 86)

Exactly 41 hours from BC to the summit of Everest and back to BC.

28 Aug 11 pm: "we climb all the night until 11 am 29 Aug at 7000m and at this place we make a small snow cave and we spend the afternoon drinking a lot and eating, no sleep and at a 9 pm, we start again and go to 8200m; it was very cold and we made another snow cave and we rested for three hours (from 2 am to 5 am). We stay one hour, 20 minutes, at the top and then we go down in three hours."

"From the first snow cave at 7800m to the second snow cave at 8200m, I was very tired. After that, I felt fine."

For me it would have been better to go almost non-stop. Spend an hour two in the snow cave for drinking, and then go non-stop.

APPROACH: Half via Kathmandu, half via Lhasa->Rongbuk Glacier
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7770m due to frequent heavy snowfall, winds
ROUTEMEMO:
Breashears - 3 Nov 86

Dawa Norbu who summited with Bonington was killed by slab avalanche 17 Oct descending North Col - cremated at Rongbuk nunnery.

C4 established by Breashears about 20 Oct with 3 Sherpas. Loads had been dumped there but occupied only by this team. Winds about 80 mph that night drove them down next morning. Later that week tent at C5 shredded by winds and no one even reached it again.

15th Oct push to go up again. 4 Sherpas reached North Col and stayed till 17th at C3 there but 17th descended in high winds and Dawa Nuru killed.

2 more attempts to regain Col on 20th and 22nd Oct but conditions of slab avalanche had worsened and Col primed for massive slab avalanche and not regained.

23rd Breashears decided too dangerous to resume climb and Sherpas declared they would not go up again as had others. 23rd Oct climb abandoned. 

Oxygen used for sleeping at C4 on theory they would continue up to next day - only use of oxygen was by 4 men night of about 2 Oct.

No accidents except one fatal avalanche. No serious illness or frostbite. 
13 Sherpas and all 16 members went above BC.

Holzel was not permitted by leader Andy Harvard and deputy leader David Breashears to take metal detectors above ABC at 21,300 ft but let him take them that high to keep him busy. Andy and David sensitive to criticism.

1 crampon found from 1930's Chinese expedition

Dawa Nuru, Thami, killed by big hard wind slab avalanche from North Col
C3 on Col
C5 at 7500m
Trying to put in C6 in mid-Oct when winds were high 
Planned to leave BC 29th


Newsletter, Mt. Everest BC

From Lhasa it was a two-day bus ridge (via Gyantse and Shigatse) to Xegar, the romantic Shekar Dzong of early Everest literature. Here we stayed three nights and were able to climb the Dzong.
 
From Xegar an interesting day's truck ride over the Pang La, rising gradually into the mountains brought us at last to Everest. There is a difficult river crossing at the entrance to the Rongbuk  Valley, then a steep rough ride up to the Monastery (where again restoration is in progress) and beyond to our BC on the moraine of the Rongbuk Glacier.

With four Sherpas, David Swanson led our first train of yaks up the East Rongbuk Glacier to ABC at 21,300 ft on Aug 28. He wanted to see the mountain at close quarters before having to return on Sept2. Frantic sorting of equipment and high altitude rations occupied the next few days days and today a second yak train went up with Mike Weis and Mike Yeager, to be followed by another in a couple of days time.

The C3 has now been set at 23,200 ft. Everyone seems to be acclimatizing well. We have been suprised, and somewhat dismayed by the heavy volume of snow on the mountain. We are hoping season winds will help to remove some of it.


BC - Sept 15, 1986

We have now been established in BC for two and a half weeks. The monsoon is not yet over and the weather is harsh, but that hasn't prevented us from setting up and stocking our approach camps.

By Sept 4 we had 40 yaks loads delivered to our ABC at 21,000 ft and on Sept 5th five members reached the North Col, which will be the sight of our next camp. The route up to the Col was reconnoitered in chest deep snow by Mike Weis, David Breashears and Nima Temba, following the line of an enormous avalanche which had carried and killed one of the young Chileans, tearing through their line of fixed ropes.

On the following all members began drifting back to BC for a puja ceremony of blessing, which the Sherpas had arranged for Sunday 7, as being an auspicious day in their calendar.
 
During this period in BC, our first group of trekkers arrived under the leadership of Jed Williamson. The more energetic among them were able to visit our advanced camps in the next few days, while Jed himself agreed to stay on as a full member of the expedition.


Oct 1, 1986

More than a week of fine weather has greatly improved our fortunes and our spirits. Our way to the North Col is now re-established, after a five day storm, and we are able to make regular trips up there ferrying loads and getting a substantial camp organized. We need to be as strong as we can on the Col as this is the camp from which our film teams will operate.

We have also had good luck recently breaking trail above the North Col. Camp 4 at the sight of the early British Everesters C5, has been established and stocked at 25,600 ft. Efforts have been made to locate C5, at accomodate the first summit teams, and thereafter the search teams looking for artifacts from the 1924 British expedition. The camp is located high under the Northeast Ridge.

To ensure that climbers remain fit and frest for the hardwork that lies ahead high on the mountain, they are being rotated back to BC for short rest periods. The coughs and colds that plagued the members in the early weeks of the expedition are almost a thing of the past.
 
The team has been further strengthened by the arrival of Dave Cheesemond, straight from the American expedition K2. Almost immediately after his arrival in BC, Dave headed for Advanced Base, where he will assist David Breashears and Mike Weis with film duties.

On Sept 19 George Bell and Donna de Varona arrived in BC. Donna is the on-camera host of the hour long ABC Sports special we are shooting about the first American woman to go to the summit of Everest (keep your fingers crossed). George will produce and write it. It was a pleasure to see Donna out shooting within hours of her arrival, paying scant regard to her sudden elevation in altitude. Donna even made the trip to Yak Camp at 19,000 ft with hopes of getting to Advanced Base, before being turned back by a snowstorm.  George also got footage for NBC News. Today Show and worked on sequences for the historical documentary with David Breashears and Andy Harvard. George and Donna left BC on Oct 1st.
 
BC remains a place of unexpected sociability. John Roskelley was here with a group of trekkers that included several old friends. They were bound for the Lho La, the pass that looks into Nepal.
 
The good weather has also enabled our neighbours, the British Northeast Ridge Expedition, once more to make progress on their route. The "Air Over Everest" group across the parking lot have attempted two test flights with their first saw speed skier Steve McKinney launch into uncertain wind condition, culminating in a spectacular and uncomfortable landing. It was, Steve told us, what is known in the trade as "beaking" - when the nose of the glider and pilot impact the ground somewhat forcefully. Lucky for Steve, his customized helmet allowed him to get away with superficial bruises and cuts.

 
1986 Mt Everest - 26  Nov

October in the Himalaya was marked by unremitting high winds and heavy snows. Almost daily storm clouds moved up the valley, dropping few inches of snow on our base camp at 17,000 ft and dumping much heavier falls high up. Sue Giller remembers reading four books in five days, while occasionally peering out her tent flap at Advanced BC only to see her chances of making the summit buried in an apparently endless snowfall. This was a typical feeling for most of the team members who were on the mountain in the first half of the month.

The frustration was compounded by the fact that virtually all members of the expedition had made great progress in early Oct. After nearly two months in BC, and a week long hike, Audrey Salked reached ABC.  All three of the women climbers - Sue Giller, Mary Kay Brewster, and Catherine Cullinane, were well acclimatized and ready for a push to the upper slopes. Indeed, Mary Kay and Catherine set personal altitude records by reaching 24,500 ft one morning under a bright sky of fast moving clouds. Accompanied by three Sherpas, David Breashears had established C5 on Oct 4.
 
On Oct 12, the Air-Over Everest group decided to leave the mountain. Led by Heidi Benson, the team was ultimately frustrated by heavy snows on their route.

On Oct 16, the British team - our neighbours in BC for two and a half months - determined that they had had enough of the weather and began to retreat from Everest. We remembered Joe Brown's cramped birthday party in the British BC, and the friendship we had made with the British climbers, and we were sorry to see them go. Clearly and early winter had arrived in our part of Tibet.

On the next day, one of our best loved Sehrpas, Dawa Nuru, 32, was killed in a small slab avalanche at 22,000 ft while descending from the North Col camp. David Breashears pulled him from the debris of snow and ice. Two days later, Danudu, as he was known to all, received a proper Buddhist burial, with cremation and prayer performed at the Rongbuk Nunnery. His death surprised and deeply saddened all the members of the team, and put us on alert to the danger of avalanche in the col.

In the days that followed Danudu's cremation, attempts were made to hike above Advanced BC to reassess the avalanche danger. The prognosis was not good. On Oct 23, leader Andrew Harvard, made the decision to call off the expedition.

The team spent nearly a week getting of the mountain and packing up gear in the BC. The sadness over Danudu's death and the frustration of the expedition were inescapable, still there was a sense that no other team could have done any better under a similar conditions. Everyone performed well, and a few climbers went higher than they had ever gone before. When it was time for the trucks and jeeps to leave BC, we reluctantly split up: half the team headed for Lhasa, the other half for KTM.

On Nov 2, Andy Harvard carried the first Earth Run torch through the streets of Lhasa.

On the same day in KTM, David Breashears consoled the brothers of Danudu and offered the assistance of the expedition in helping Danudu's wife and three young sons.

Despite Danudu's death and the weather which prevented any of the women from trying for the summit, moreover, leaving us unable to conduct a thorough search for Mallory and Irvine at the 28,000 ft terrace, there was a positive feeling about the expedition. It came out of the heartfelt conviction that we had done everything that we could on the mountain.

We knew there were risks. Danudu knew there were risks. Still, we went and he went with us. I think everyone of us would go again. And almost immediately, there was talk of going back. It was this enthusiasm for the experience that most of us will remember.


Peter Hackatt - 28 Oct 86

Got to pinnacles just little below where Boardman and Taskar disappeared; snow and more especially strong winds. All Ok. Left BC 20 Oct.

SPONSOR: Escoffier's Expedition to Everest and Lhotse
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8600m due to bad weather and late arrival
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 in Western Cwm
C2 on Lhotse Face
