Mutschlechner down on 15th to BC with tooth problem and others up to use Swiss tents at C3. On 16th Messner and Kammerlander again up in strong wind, risking failure in wind stronger than at camp. Other time Messner started for any summit. In couloir had strong wing at their backs which helped push them up but made descent difficult (but couloir technically easy to climb), almost all of face was hard snow. Team was "perfectly" acclimatized from Makalu climb.


Paoletti - 17 Oct 86

Messner and Kammerlander on way to top left C3 at 8:00 am; at 7:00 am had radioed impossible wind but by 8:00 Ok and got a push from wind on their backs.

Was very cold at summit.
Made no C1. 
Leave BC 18 Oct for Lukla flight.

Tent and journalists arrive KTM 20th.


Moreto Paoletti - 16 Oct 86

Lhotse summit reached at 1:45 pm Messner and Kammerlander from C3. Good weather, irregular wind. All are very well. Descending to C2 where will sleep tonight. BC tomorrow.

22 chopper from Lukla to KTM.


Paoletti - 15 Oct 86

C3 - Messner, Kammerlander and 4 Sherpas, 7400m.

Today very strong wind; may have to descend to BC if cannot sleep they well, but Mutschlechner had to go down to BC with dental problem.


Paoletti - 14 Oct 86

Messner, Kammerlander and 4 Sherpas. 
Arrival at C2 6400m today.
Hope C3 7200-7400m tomorrow and in 3 days from today hope for top.
Weather not very good but snow has fallen off face so avalanche not so dangerous.
All in good health.
ACCIDENTS: Messner slight frostbite on wrists from wind-driven cold

SPONSOR: French Military Expedition to Lhotse Shar-Lhotse
TERMNOTE: Did not attempt Lhotse
Abandoned at 8300m due to wind and no more strength in team
ROUTEMEMO:
BC below Chhukung Peak, west side of Lhotse Shar Glacier
C1 at rocky party (on face)
High point at biv in cave.

This time only 50m above last expedition's high point and line is possible. Problem to C5=none. They began from 7800m. This time put ropes to 8300m. Could not move above this bivouac point because of wind that blew up during night. Only 4 climbers did most of climbing work besides Wielicki and Hajzer (Dasal, Konopka, Osika and Pawlikowski) and then were exhausted after 50 days. On 30th Wielicki and Hajzer descended to BC because of wind and now no other strong climbers able to continue. Now also getting cold. Left BC 1 Nov.


From "Kazdemu Jego Everest", Dasal

Czeslaw Jakiel was killed instantly by an early morning (5 am) ice-block avalanche shortly after leaving C1 for C2. Jakiel was with two others who escaped injury.


To Ministry of Tourism
Mountaineering Section

Report about accident on Sept 15

Just after we established Camp 2 (at 6200m on Sept 14), we had 2 members in C2, 2 members in C1 (5750m). Our programme for Sept 15 was that, from BC will start next team to C1 (Czeslaw Jakiel, Walenty Fiut, Alois Brugger). They began walking from BC at 5:30 am crossing the Lhotse Glacier. At 6:20 am they have started to climb by snow stones slope towards the south face of Lhotse. After few minutes they have seen a big avalanche, it began very high on the right side of south face. They tried to escape, but avalanche came very quickly. Alois Brugger had fallen to the small crevasse. Walenty Fiut fixed his ice axe and kept himself. Czeslaw Jakiel walked last and they didn't see what he was doing, that moment. After avalanche came and Alois Brugger tried to find out friends. He found Walenty Fiut about 100m below, he was injured but alive and 20m for Czeslaw Jakiel, unfortunately he was dead, probably due to strong hit on his head (whole on back side). In the meantime avalanche pression had reached BC. Olev friends took binoculars and they have seen somebody running between victims. Immediately they started to rescue them. That accident have seen two members from C1 and they went down too. About 1 hour after accident, all members (except Kurt Walde and me) reached that place and began to help victims. They put Walenty Fiut on the board with diagnose...he has fracture left leg and hip and probably ribs. He was in very bad condition, before he lost consciousness and after he has been in shade. Alois Brugger was well. Members again have checked Czeslaw Jakiel, but he was dead. At 9 am they send Sardar Ang Kami to Namche Bazar for helicopter. Me and Kurt Walde reached accident place at 11:30 am. We decided to carrying Walenty Fiut to BC and secure Czeslaw body. BC we have reached at 4 pm.

On Sept 16 we carried Walenty Fiut 20 minutes down, BC where we found good platform for helicopter, it was about 5100m high. Their we made a biv. Afternoon we have gone to Czeslaw body and we have made a funeral. We left him in about 15m deep crevasse and fill up up ice, snow and stones, close to accident place at 5300m below the south face. On Sept 17 at 9:30 am we have got a helicopter rescue, we put Walenty Fiut on stretcher and he flew with leader towards KTM (11:30 am).
ACCIDENTS: Jakiel killed by avalanche on Sep 15; Fiut broken leg from same avalanche
ACHIEVMENT: Highest point ever reached on S Face

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7360m due to terrible winds, dangerous icefall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Yamotari Glacier
ABC at moraine of Yamatori Glacier
C1  above icefall in Cwm, below West Face
C2  on SW Pillar at very narrow place
C3  in crevasse above 2nd serac on SW Pillar
C4A behind top of SW pillar (100m down in a crevasse)
C4B in crevasse before summit wall.

Too much wind which made high technical climbing impossible. Technical climbing begin 1st Dec. Long walk from BC to ABC; C1 difficult rock of W Face to begining of W Pillar. Route was combination of variation of French & Czech routes climbed to top of W Pillar. Above top is glacier with crevasses. Wind fierce & hard ice to pillar & steep glacier. Windy so could not climb for each day. Fixed total 3500m rope, which takes a lot of work but needed in windy weather. At high point stopped because of danger from fierce gusts of wind. C2 tent blown half off ridge. Other member blown off his feet at glacier & saved by having held on to fixed rope. Very difficult route. Fixed 700m in icefall (300m vertical gain) and 1000m on high steep glacier.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6502m due to dangerously unstable serac barriers
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at normal site
C2 at normal site in snowholes
High point at 6500m at top of Dutch Rib.

They spent 3 weeks on the N Face, making C1 and C2 in snowholes and pitching C3 at 6500m at the top of the Dutch Rib on 9th May. C3 was stocked during the following few days (9-12 May), but it was never slept in. 13th Duff and 3 went up with personal gear to C2 and 14th to C3. On 14th May, when Duff, Woodall, Nowack and Gray tried to move above C3, just a meter or 2 above the camp they got onto a serac barrier that was extremely broken and dangerous. It would have been safe enough, Duff felt, for 2 people going up and down once, but some of the team's client members were not sufficiently experienced for a rapid ascent. It would have been necessary to fix the rope to 1 more camp, thus requiring 20 passes through the barrier; this would have been unacceptably dangerous (and bad for business - members were paying clients). So the climb was abandoned. Snowholes very good idea for C2. All members reached C3 as did both Sherpas, but it was never slept in.

SPONSOR: Shizuoka Mt. Party Society of Nepal Himalaya 1991 to ANNS
ROUTEMEMO:
BC east of beginning of SW Ridge
C1 below ridge
C2 on SW Ridge
C3 on SW Ridge.

Only 1 summit attack: others in no good condition. Ridge mixed snow and rock; difficult because right side, left side ice and wind blowing. Left BC 26 Oct. 10th ascent.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing very serious but 2 members with some altitude problems

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8130m due to lateness in the day
ROUTEMEMO:
BC 100m apart from other French Dhaulagiri team on glacier
C2 at North Col
C3 in NE Ridge crevasse
C4 on NE Ridge rocks
High point at 30m below top.

Didn't reach exactly on summit but stopped 30m below it: stopped to make photos for sponsor which took 1 hr, so decided not to go to top because wind rising and wanted to be back in camp before dark. Slept in C4 for 3rd night; now all down: before all 6 members reached 7100m and 2 Sherpas with Le Balch and Imbert to C4. 

4 went down at 7100m because too tired to go on up. 1 Sherpa started for top on 6th but did not reach members high-point because too cold. Now climb finished.

Le Balch has slight frostbitten toes and reached C2 only on 11th; boots too tight. Big problem for him to walk and came to KTM before rest of team, who went trekking.

SPONSOR: Caravan to Dream 8000 x 8 - to Dhaulagiri
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal BC area
C1 at NE Col
C2 on NE Ridge
High point near to NE Ridge.

2 members reached 7100m in work to prepare route for Wanda R.; at 7400m was Japanese camp which Poles were permitted to use. On 15th very strong wind, 18-20 degrees cloudy and snowing, so left tent and full range of gear there at 7100m and down to C2 and next day to C1. Then all to BC waiting for Wanda, who was expected to arrive 20 Oct or there after. Malinowski went to Marpha and Jomsom to enquire from KTM about Wanda's whereabouts. Now every afternoon snowing, cloudy and winter temperatures had set in and life at BC difficult. With continuous snowfall feared impossible or very expensive to get porters to evacuate loads via passes. Also getting time to return to Kathmandu to organize winter Manaslu expedition. On 28th Gasienica-Jozkowy to depot and brought it down. Left BC 31 Oct and met Wanda at Marpha. Jedlinski left BC 4 Nov with porters with loads. Wanda and Gasienica-Jozkowy went to BC.

Wanda arrived at BC 7 Nov, day after all had left BC, including BC staff; had had no news of Wanda, who was due to arrive on 20 Oct and if had not evacuated equipment then, all would have been lost because one week later porters could not cross passes. One member had expected to go back with her to Dhaulagiri: she met party at Marpha on 2nd and took time to organize return to BC. After arrived at BC, on 8th snow began following and continued with heavy snowfall on 10th, and would jeopardize Manaslu and left BC 11 Nov, reached Marpha only on 14th with 3 bivs.

BC at normal site
C1 at North Col
C2 on NE Ridge
C3 on NE Ridge
C4 on NE Ridge.

1st summit attack succeeded and then weather deteriorated (snowfall, strong winds) so had to give up. Left BC 23rd Oct after 2nd attack 11-18 Oct; but 2 attack parties got no higher than C3.
ACCIDENTS: Nakajima and Keepa Sherpa slight frostbitten toes; Yoneda injured fingers from rockfall but now OK

APPROACH: Kali Gandaki->Saking->W from Saking along Ridge
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8000m due to strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
1st BC to East Dhaulagiri Glacier, southsast of point 6014m on Japanese map
C1 at NE Col
High point on NE Ridge.

From 1st BC climbed icefall but steep and dangerous. Climbed 1 day in icefall, then decided too dangerous with rainfall daily: reached 4500m and returned. Then moved BC to normal site from E Face ascent from there and 3rd Oct looked at face which had no snow; this not good: water falling down face. 

Went on to east at same altitude as col to see face and decided not to go onto face; climbed NE Ridge. 15th Oct 1st summit bid made by both Endos and a Sherpa reached about 8000m in five days but very strong south wind and Endos down to C3, Ang Phurba to C1. 

2nd bid up from BC 22nd Oct 24th, reached C3 but again strong wind and down on 25th and climbing finished. 

Other 3 members to C1 only. Left BC 30th Oct. Ridge not technically difficult.

BC at normal site
C1 at Col
C2 at NE Ridge.

31st Aug accident in icefall: Canameras fell into crevasse when unclipping from one fixed rope to clip another one; fell 8m and both arms and one shoulder injured so he and Soler left BC 6th Sept with porters carrying him. 

Only 1 summit attempt by remaining 3 members: Corominas, who left C3 2 am (Gonzalez left C3 at 8 am but turned back at 7800m because strong wind) could reach summit but needed a bivouac: delayed departure at 2 am because wind and very cold and expects French climbers to go up after couple of hours and French changed his mind). Corominas reached summit at 2:45 pm, so slow because of winds and snow 25 cm deep so trail-making slow; returned C3 at 6 pm. Were only 2 climbers after C1 because of Pruna's edema.
ACCIDENTS: Canameras accident in icefall; Pruna edema at C1 Sep 8

SPONSOR: Expedition Mountain of Winds to Dhaulagiri I
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to team exhausted
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C2 at NE Col
C3 on NE Ridge
High point at NE Ridge.

Laot alone from C4 2nd Oct and reached 7800m; tired, strong wind and very cold, so turned back to C3. By now others also tried or slightly sick so climb finished. 5 all in BC and left 6th.

SPONSOR: 1991 Morioka Alpine Club Expedition to Tukuche Peak
ROUTEMEMO:
BC east of point 5087m, beginning of ridge east of French Pass by a junction of NW Ridge and ridge to point 6829m.

Did not fix any ropes so others did not make summit attempt because route difficult towards top. Were many crevasses near junction and 200m below top hidden crevasse on summit pair climbed roped together and belayed each other.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5300m due to lack of rope
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near glacier southwest of mountain headwaters of south branch of Dogari Khola.
C1 on rock between 2 ridges running south from point 5395 on Japanese map.
C2 on ice slope north-northwest of C1.

Intended to put C2 at 5500m but ran out of rope before reaching this height and camped at 5300m. Did not dare to go on because very steep ice, too dangerous to continue without fixing rope here. Climb finished. Not enough time to try another approach. Descended on 21st: Dawa Temba to BC, Buhr and Dawa Norbu to C1. All in BC 22nd and left BC 23rd. Excellent weather.

Were trying to get onto Putha Hiunchuli's W Ridge from south, which meant crossing several ridges. They did not reach the W Ridge.

SPONSOR: CAF Samoens Expedition to Tukuche and Dhampus
ROUTEMEMO:
1st BC at East Dhaulagiri Glacier southeast of point 6014m on Japanese map
C1  at NE Col
High point at NE Ridge.

Only 1 member on top: Delerce and Nawang started from C1 with successful climbers but turned back at 6400m because Delerce "feels bad" with headache, etc. 

1 Oct Moatti, Huglin, Delerce, Coffy and Bravard and 2 Sherpas leave C1 but too much wind and cold and give up only 100m above C1. Tukuche climb finished.
ACCIDENTS: Fournier altitude sickness (started BC 5 days & left expedition)

SPONSOR: CAF Samoens Expedition to Tukuche and Dhampus
ROUTEMEMO: From Tukuche went to Dhampus; used same BC and made no higher camp. Left BC 3rd Oct.

OTHERSMTS: Hanging Valley by Scott, Wallace and McMahon on 23 Oct
ROUTEMEMO: S Buttress 500m so rock grade 4.5, then 800m snow-ice. Entire route was French T.D. 28th climbed it & had bitterly cold (-25 degrees) biv on rock without sleepimg bags. Cullen in support in C2. Reached top of South Summit at 4 pm after having left C1 at about 6:00 am. On 29th reached BC at 2:00 pm.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to unstable soft snow ahead
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southwest of Manang and northeast of start of North Ridge
C1 at start of spur to North Ridge
C2 on spur.

Saw from 7200m that above them on summit ridge were big snow mushrooms, cornices and left unstable snow so turned back. Not really sure what spur/ridge they were on but think they were on spur to North Ridge.

Left BC 25 Oct.
ACCIDENTS: Steiner had bad headache at C1 and never went higher

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 4730m due to lack of water supply
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  northeast of Machhapuchare (furthest porters would go just below SE Buttress)
ABC just below SE Buttress
Biv on ridge linking Annapurna III and IV.

7-19 Sept spent finding route to ABC and waiting for monsoon rain to end. 19th-29 Sept rest, get more food and gear, and tried to find snow for water but couldn't find on ridge, which was technical rock climbing to fair degree. Taken team's plastic jerry cans intended for carrying water. Rock slightly rotten but no more than Canadian Rockies where they climb a lot.

When LO had to be escorted out by team's only staff member, BC looted.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to dangerous snow conditions reported by Swiss above 7200m
ROUTEMEMO:
BC same as Swiss this season
C1 on glacier west of North Ridge
1st C2 
2nd C2 at 1 tent beside Swiss C1 (and 1 tent 200m above).

Porters dumped bags halfway from Samagaon to BC and took a week to get all to BC. First tried to climb Yugoslav 1983 Autumn route via N Face and to put C2 on face, but after 3 days search for a pass through many crevasses and seracs, on 15th found it and pitched C2 on glacier plateau. Route on to face not good: Yugoslav couloir very dangerous rocks and alternative they attempted further to west swept by avalanche so abandoned this face. 

Decided to try Swiss route this autumn and to do so was necessary to move C2 and began moving gear to C1 and also on snowfield 200m above Swiss C1. 23 Oct 2 members went up to see route above to C3 6400m. 24th Oct reached but same day decided to abandon due to dangerous snow conditions above.

Climb now abandoned. Left BC 1 day after Swiss; Spaniards themselves say they left on 25th.

SPONSOR: Sapporo Hokuryo Alpine Club Annapurna III Expedition 1991
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6800m due to wind and lack of strong manpower
ROUTEMEMO:
16th Oct planned for summit but wind and dense fog/cloud/white-out preventing seeing way ahead foiled plan. 1 member and 2 Sherpas in C4 on 15th Oct afternoon: on 16th stayed in C4 till afternoon, there weather still bad so down again on 16th. Waited in C3 3 hours, weather still bad so down again on 16th C1. Climb now finished. 

Saito only member strong enough to climb while others suffering from altitude or head colds.

Fixed ropes from C1 to C2 where many deep crevasse; route stayed to right of icefall this area under rock wall from which few rocks fell, not dangerous; rest of route to C4 easy.
ACCIDENTS: 1 Sherpa fell in crevasse and cut his face

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to unsafe rock
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at standard Fluted Peak BC east of Fluted Peak on west bank of glacier
C1 at east bank of glacier, west of south end of South Ridge 
High point on west side of South Ridge.

Made C1, down to BC (Wood ill and others not so well either). 

Started up again. Now only 2 members. On 21st Baqai and Foster to C1. 22nd up and down carrying loads and on 23rd Foster to C1 with doctor. 24th doctor down (climb was too much) and Foster up alone to see how high he could get and to establish C2 at perhaps 6100-6200m. Stopped at 5800m because of rockfall, loose rock with no snow or ice, too slow progress alone and steep route. 

Left BC 29th Oct. Had descended to BC on 25th.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5500m due to dangerous route
ROUTEMEMO:
15 Oct organized dump/depot camp at foot of glacier at 4500m and then Annapurna South glacier icefall 16-18 Oct. Left this high point, went across the Tent Peak climbing a bit up it for view of Annapurna South, but couldn't find safe enough route. Icefall was collapsing and big hanging serac walls of Himalchuli and face of Annapurna South's North Ridge. Icefall in center really requires ladders. This was guided climb with clients. 2 fast climbers might make out all right. Stayed on in area climbing Tent Peak and trekking in area after removing fixed rope in icefall and clearing dump camp. Quite safe route once one gets above icefall on to ridge. 

Could get to ridge in a day if already acclimatized and moving feet and light and if more snow and snow bridges in icefall (was very dry in wind - October).
ACCIDENTS: Diprima serious altitude sickness before BC; nothing else

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6120m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 15 minutes right side of normal C2.
High point at small rib on North Face.

Porters went only to Miristi Khola camp (TBC) from which members had had to ferry loads to normal BC. Could not climb on Dutch Rib because rib was covered by hard crust over loose snow. High point was on very steep small rib, very unstable loose snow under crust, very dangerous. Back to C3 on 13th, down to C2 and discuss with other members, all agree too dangerous. 

All members except Watzke reached C2 during climb; Watzke to C1 only. Big avalanches sent members running from BC on 4 Oct; came from face while eating breakfast and all fixed ropes between C1 and BC taken out. Left BC 17 Oct.

SPONSOR: Hokkaido Central Workers Alpine Federation Annapurna I Exp. 1991
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6450m due to avalanching
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at North Annapurna Glacier moraine.

Climb abandoned following snow avalanche that buried one member at 8:35 am on 1st Oct. He was dug out and not injured. On 3rd at 9:30 am very big snow avalanche hit BC and ABC, many tents broken and equipment lost at BC. Left BC 8th Oct.

SPONSOR: First Moscow Expedition to Himalaya - to Annapurna I
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 1 km south of Polish BCs (near last lodges).

Had no stationary camps: prepared places for tents, put them up for 2-3 nights and then moved them as he fixed good sections of rope and could move higher; used Polish ABC as their ABC. First tried Japanese route but problems: On Sept 30, Egorov and Karpenko hit by rockfall. Karpenko's leg broken and Egorov's back injured. Rescue/evacuation took 3 days. 

Shinov on 16th Oct at 7100m on 14th day on wall got altitude sickness and took another 3 days evacuation because as ropes fixed high up, lower ropes removed; after this evacuation 2 members had bad throats. So only 4 strong climbers left but really exhausted as down to BC for rest after 2 weeks on wall but wanted to continue on Japanese route; however decided to climb easier route and Poles agreed OK to use their route (Bonington).

On 22 Oct these 4 members to ABC at 5000m, 23rd in own tent at 6150m at Poles C1, 24th to 6800m at Polish C2 with own tent. 25th 1:00 am all 4 up to 7300m, without tent (to use C3 Polish tent) and reached 7300m 6:00 am now very cold and stayed in tent. 26th 9:00 am strong wind and still very cold but started up and 2 members on top at 2:00 pm and other 2 about 15 mins later; left summit 3:30 pm (video films raising Russian and Nepalese flags) and descended to Polish C3 at 7:30 pm, moving slowly to kick legs often to increase circulation of blood. 27th down from C3 at 10:00 am and at 6100m late afternoon, very tired. 28th evening arrived BC.

Senatorov left BC 27th evening. Actually was no BC because on 21st porters had cleared it. Used American Annapurna South BC. 4 summiters left BC 29th with Elagin and Ianotchkine.
ACCIDENTS: Egorov and Karpenko seriously injured by falling stone; Shinov serious altitude sickness

ROUTE1: W Face up (to 7900m); N Face down
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7900m due to route difficulty for solo climber
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal North Face site - same as USSR.

After base camp established, next day to 5600m on Tilicho on glacier to see Annapurna I West Face ("but could not see area which became 3rd biv site - could see it only from 2nd biv and it was big surprise for me - good surprise - very easy snow field there").

Returned to BC 21st. 22nd to C2 of USSR on N Face; went with Sherpa and tent and make camp that night. 23rd he up to C3 and then down to C1; up to see how he is performing at altitude ("to test"). 24th to BC. 27th from BC he and sirdar towards bottom of W Face with load: sirdar said glacier too difficult and did not go all the way, but Sveticic goes on and next day reaches bottom of face. Taking mountain tent with him from BC, Sveticic camps alone from evening of 27th; first biv on 27th at 5100m, 2nd and 28th at bottom of W Face at 5450m at 8:00 am and immediately goes onto face in clear weather and pitches tent at 6200m; this section 55 degrees so not easy but snow in good condition; arrived at 6200m at 3:00 pm and slept there that night. Route to this point was not far of big rock fall area. 29th start up at 7:00 pm; this day very difficult climb because snow now replaced by very hard ice; arrived a B2 biv at 5:00 pm at 6400m, where only small area for biv. and slept here for one night. 30th started 9:00 am after night of strong wind and as he climbed wind continued with very strong gusts: this day easy climb but strong wind all day; made biv after climbing snow in good condition at 7300m at 1:00 pm stopped early to have an easy day). 31st "very difficult day for me." Because could not see logical way to go up; went up 100m, search for the way, traverse along snow, and up near and up more; reached 7800m and biv; started this day at 6:30 am and arrived biv. 4 at 6:30 pm: slept here. 1st Nov started again at 9:30 am in strong wind from top; now very tired; fingers and toes to go up again next morning. 2nd Nov too tired and toes still very cold: weather good with no wind: good weather for top but also good weather to go down: "no cloud so possible to see the way"; started down at 6:00 am and reached site C1 on N Face; from biv traversed 300m to normal N Face route and then down, more directly than normal route, to Dutch Rib, down the rib to C1 site, where arrived 10:00 pm (5200m). 3rd Nov down to BC but no camp left. Sirdar, cook and LO had left few hours earlier taking all gears and good food supplies away with them. Sveticic had 3 matches left, made some tea, put petrol he had in bottle he found, put string as wick and kept burning all night and next day so to have cooking possibility. 4th Nov stayed at BC resting (fingers and toes thick now OK) & 5th Nov from BC to Lete where kitchen boy stayed while LO and sirdar gone to Jomsom to send message he is missing. Now on 5th he realizes toes not OK: blistering.

"Is not finished - I have to go back to do entire climb, made 2 mistakes - should have returned to BC after going to face for next and good food and should have gone up from bottom of W Face with very light load; load he took was too heavy - getting to bottom of West Face was difficult over difficult glacier. Had no problem with altitude - problem just was difficulty." Another mistake: should have radio so others can know where he is.

"If I can get money, maybe I go to Makalu W Face - first need more training."

Solo effort on West Face to left of Messner's route lasted from 28 Oct, when Sveticic began ascent of the face, to 1 Nov, when he became too tired to succeed; had taken too heavy a load of supplies with him, he later decided. To 6100m found good snow conditions, but difficult hard ice for next 700m, then easy terrain and good snow but terrible winds to 7200m. From this point "very difficult day for me because I could not see a logical way to go up," had to search for a good line and gained 500m. On final day strong winds continued, his fingers and toes very cold, he was very tired and was now moving very slowly; stopped his ascent at 7900m and returned to bivouac. Next day 2 Nov, he moved down very rapidly in excellent weather and traversed over to normal site of C1 on North Face.

BC same as other Polish expedition
C2 same as Jarosz (and Chamoux).

This team fixed all ropes for both team except (Perrina from other Polish team, who worked all the time with this team - was the only strong climber except Denamur from other team). Very difficult sections with overhangs at 7200-7300m. Great respect for Bonington team, whose route followed to C1, then variations of Chamoux and their own. Problem of hard ice and falling stones. 20th Oct early night Wielicki to C2, reached C3 where Stefko was already. Stefko left C3 at 4:30 am, 21st and Wielicki at 6:00 am and went on top at 11:30 am and Stefko at 11:50 am, having met other team's member in his descent from unsuccessful attempt. Left top 12:00 and returned to C1 in full moonlight. 

2nd summit party (who did not really climb together) left camp 22nd early morning (Pawlowski 4:00 am, Schleypen at 3:00 am and Wanda at 6:00 am); [after summiting] Pawlowski to C2, Schleypen stopped above C3 and Wanda Rutkiewicz made biv at 7700m on summit ridge. 

23rd Valez, Baeyens and Sprutta to top also from C3.
ACCIDENTS: Patynowska very weak; not edema but perhaps climb too difficult and lost much weight

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to avalanching
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site.

Deposited supplies for C3 at its site in cave, but when Americans returned, all gone in avalanching. Big avalanche hit C1 from east summit & broke all tents on 14th Sept. C2 in caves & avalanches came over but no danger. Lost much food in C3 cache. On 22nd Sept Spanish tried to reach it but did not get high and decided too much avalanche danger with 3 avalanches that day.
ACCIDENTS: Banet pulmonary edema (returned to Kathmandu & later to BC)

ROUTEMEMO: After 8th Oct some new snow, cloudy and wind. Stopped at 6900m on 14th Oct in 2nd summit bid that day by two summit teams and climb finished. Sounier up to clear camps only after that. Left 17th Oct.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7285m due to unstable snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C3 above Dutch Rib - above normal site at safer spot.

Planned to go to summit on 20th after rest day at C4. Avalanche fatal to Koreans on 19th partially buried Culbersons in their tent. Americans had dug out base of serac, which protected them from full fury of avalanche. US members at C3 helped dig out Korean & Sherpa bodies which were near C3. 3 US members at C4 left at 4 pm & went down to C2 & then all down to BC for 3 days. Few days later went C3 but still looked unstable & wind had picked up and was causing slab avalanche. Big avalanche hit C1 in mid-Sept and wind blew tent with one member (Fay Johnson) in it uphill and tore tents; one member buried.

BC at northwest corner of lake.

Fixed 1300m rope from below C1 to C2 and left for French. Not so much snow on route.

SPONSOR: Polish International Expedition to Annapurna I
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Bulgarian BC north of Machhapuchhare BC, just south of Tent Peak.

After 21 Sept strong wind and fixed ropes in couloir cut twice by falling ice or stone in 55-60 degree couloir. From C1 to C2 very complicated mixed snow, ice and rock. Between C1 and C3 very hard rock. Had permit for Polish route but changed because of falling stone and ice and leads to middle summit. Even glacier complicated with many stones requiring zizag route towards ABC. Fixed total 3000m. 

1st summit party Denamur and Stepien left C3 6:00 am 20 Oct; Stepien feet beginning to freeze at 7500m and returned to C2; Denamur continued to summit alone and without walkie-talkie; his footprints seen by Wielicki of other Polish expedition when he reached summit late morning of 21st, thus Denamur reached summit during night or early 21st morning and then footprints showed descent of North Face (he had taken plenty of food, gas, feather jacket and biv sack without previous notice). When expedition left BC 20-30 Oct he had not reappeared. No more in summit attempts because food supplies finished. Had planned to stay at BC only till 20th or latest 23rd. Did not sent anyone to look for Denamur, but if no word of him by 1st Nov may send helicopter for rescue/search. There are other teams on North Face.


Wiliecki

Denamur and Stepien were sent up to clear their C2 (C3 was Wielicki) but went on up to C3 without permission of Wielicki. There was no contact with them for 3 days from 18th morning, when they radioed from C2 they didn't know where they were going today; they actually went to C3 that afternoon/evening spent 19th fixing up C3, 19th night started for top but after 1-2 hours returned to C3 because cold. 20th Stepien started up at midday, Lowas after Denamur and never saw Denamur that day; got dark, Stepien lost the trail above so made biv at 7700m, hoped to resume ascent next day but in morning of 21st (had frosbitten toes) and met in his descent at 9:00 am by Wielicki; he was very strong but mentally confused. (Wielicki talked with him in detail). Denamur did not take extra provisions, according to Stepien. Expedition knew Denamur missing on 21st from Wielicki but sent no search to north side.

Senatorov, USSR South Face leader on 3 Nov: Jarosz left member with frostbitten toes behind when Jarosz left BC. Member was cared for Senatorov and Wielicki teams.

Cherny, USSR North Face summiter on 24 Oct: He and Arsentiev saw no trace whatsoever of Denamur - no new ice axe, no rucksack, no body, nothing. Any tracks would be blown away in 2-3 hours by wind. 20th and 21st very clear days and leader and Arsentiev's US girl friend watched with binoculars for movement high on mountain and saw nothing.

Arsentiev on 15 Nov: On 23 Oct he saw 2 people on summit. They did not descend north side. On 20 Oct at summit he found 2 Polish coins on the snow and brought them back; they had been left there on 23rd, he has been told by Wielicki. He saw nothing else anywhere on North Face except 2 old ice axes, which he and Cherny used because their own had been lost. There was a huge fall of ice above C4 on 23rd.

Slava Sveticic, Yugoslav on West Face on 15 Nov: On 3 Nov found raised footprints on snow from bottom of a couloir at about 7900m during his traverse eastwards to normal route, which he descended. They were in an area where no climbers go.


Statement signed by Jaros about 5 Nov 1991
(in Ministry of Tourism files)

The 20 Oct 91 about 6 H in the morning Gabriel Denamur from Belgium started from C2 South Face (7300m) climbing solo on the top. He took no tent, sleeping bag, stove gas and did not came back to the C3.

Next day 21 Oct 91 started from C3 two members from another expedition from Poland led by Krzysztof Wielicki saw fresh foot marks of Gabriel Denamur which had crossed summit and gone towards north side.

The 20 Oct 91 in the north side two Russian members Cherny and Glushkovski staying in C3 (6450m). Next day 21.10 they continued climbing in alpine style C4 6900m, C5 (7300m) 22.10 bivouac 23.10 (7900m) visibility was very good, fine weather. 24.10 reached on the top about 10 H and nothing saw.

In C1 (5000m) since the 20.10-25.10 Sergei Arsentiev leader of Russian team waiting and looking by binoculars north side summit and climber team and nothing saw also.

From south side reaching on the top since then Gabriel reached on the top until 23.10.91 another members and nothing saw also.

Since then we haven't news from Gabriel Denamur. Gabi missing 20.10.91

C1  at site usually used by 2 climbers (mostly by leader as his ABC)
C3  at top Dutch Rib
Biv on col between middle and main summits.

Started from BC 19th to C2 but camp broken so to C1 and then 20th up to C3. 21st made 1st of 3 bivouacs; left 24th at 10 am and on summit 1 hour later. Very windy so footprints blown quickly away; 1 hour on top then descended to 7300m. 25th down to C1 descending in dark to reach C1; BC on 26th morning. Cherny left BC 28th because slight frostbite fingers and wanted lower altitude; other 2 left BC 30th with porters.

Saw no sign whatsoever of Denamur; found no new ice ax, no rucksack, no body, nothing; any track blown quickly (2-3 hrs). On 20th and 21st very clear and from C1 leader and Arsentiev's US girl friend watching with binoculars high on mountain and they saw no one.
ACCIDENTS: None except Cherny slightly frostbitten fingers

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to fatal avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at normal site
C2 at top of Dutch Rib
C3 on North Face
High point on North Face.

C4 intended for 7600m but on 19th Sept reached 7500m when big slab avalanche started from above those moving up and carried them 1000m down mountain; 2 members and 6 Sherpas carried down but 2 only 300m (Norbu Tagby injured in lower left leg, Sonam Tshering uninjured). Bae Seung-Youl was at C3. 1 member was alive and Americans gave mouth-to-mouth resucitation but he soon died of internal injuries. Lee Seong-Jee killed instantly as were 4 Sherpas: Jangbu (body not found), Dawa Sange (Everest 1990 summit), Lhakpa Tendi and Tenzing; bodies, covered by deep snow by Bae and left on avalanching slope.

Climbing ceased and left BC 22nd Sept. Made route for other teams. 2 other big snow avalanches 11th Sept; broke tents at C2 and 15th ABC hit - 3 tents taken away. In both cases hit by winds from avalanche no one hurt.

Leader intends to lead another team to Annapurna I next year to finish climb started by those who were killed.


Matt and Julie Culberson - 7 Oct 1991

Koreans never did any lead climbing, made Sherpas do it all, pushed Sherpas to climb where and when they (Sherpas) thought it dangerous, denounced Sherpas as lazy.

Americans put in some rope for Koreans.
ACCIDENTS: Ko high blood pressure so stayed most of the expedition at Leyte; fatal avalanche

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7900m due to snow, wind, exhaustion, and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site for C1 (Swiss and Italians BC here this autumn)
C1 Naike Col
C3 at North Col
C4 on NE Ridge.

Bayona and Belmonte tried for summit on 6th Oct from C4 and reached 7900m; snow knee-deep so very tired (and tired from previous day's climb to ridge and not good sleep that night). So down to C2 on 6th. 

Another summit party reached only C3 on 7th Oct, but very strong winds so down to C2 on 8th and stayed there till 10th, when snowfall and wind sent them down to BC and climb finished. 

Now expedition had not enough time to wait for better weather, very tired and 3 members avalanched on 26 Sept not summit material afterwards.
ACCIDENTS: Antoni Llasera, Frederic Puig and Joan Vila hit by slab avalanche on Sep 26, slightly injured

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to exhaustion
ROUTEMEMO: Climbed alpine-style from C3 having descended to BC for rest. 21st pushed up from C3. 22nd Graham and Selland to 7800m and turned back: wanted to put C4 higher, followed a ridge to a false summit was where should have gone but one man getting sick and both exhausted so back to C4. Weiss had gotten almost to C4 but had pneumonia or some lung problem and had gone down to C3. Others not now in condition to go up so climb finished. Very long route and with no Sherpa support (even cooking done by Americans). Sherpas stayed at low BC because exhausted by time for strong summit bid. Should have had more rest days earlier in climb. "Incredibly safe route for an 8000m peak." Had beautiful weather.
ACCIDENTS: Dobkin altitude sickness; Weiss pneumonia and lung problem

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Meta (deserted village)
C1 at bottom of small SW Ridge to Pt 6981m on Round Annapurna map
C2 on West Face before Pt 6981m between 2 ridges
C3 directly below NW Ridge leading to Pt 6981m.

From C1 climbed face between SW & NW Ridges leading to point 6981 (summit) on Round Annapurna map: W Face to NW Ridge. All 5 members went to C3 on 20th but Dal Santo not well enough on 21st to go top (not altitude problem) so descended instead. We are very happy because we are not professionals but climb for pleasure. Summit party started up from C3 at 3:30 am on 21st and were on top at 10:30 am, spent 30 minutes on summit and down to C2. Next day in BC 22nd. Left BC 24th.

SPONSOR: Nepal Police-Imari Japan Joint Expedition to Cheo Himal 1991
ROUTEMEMO:
BC 2 hours beyond Birstange, north of Pangal
C1 on rock face of south-southeast ridge running from Himlung past Panbari
C2 at top of this rock face
C3 at snowfield east of point 6341m
C4 at north end of snowfield.

Could see mountain from BC. Himlung and Panbari Himal spent 10 days trying to find on east side of big icefall which is below east side of ridge running SSE from Himlung past Panbari Himal. Finally made route to west side of icefall on rock face of east side of this ridge; rock falling from face hit most Nepalis and Imoto, but not seriously hurt. From C2 down 200m on snow face into N end of icefall and northwards to snowfield east of point 6341 of KMTNC Annapurna area map. Tried twice to go to top from C3 but too tired and made C4 towards end of snowfield. Rockfall again down face of 6700m at 2:30 pm, turned back because had no ropes and too late to finish climb in daylight. 

13th Oct 1st summit team started at 5:00 am, Phul Bahadur and Dambar at 6:00 am and 2 Japanese and 3 Nepalis at 6:30 am; had decided anyone reached point 6700m before 1:00 pm could continue to top and 1st party at 9:00 am here and 2nd 11:30 am, 3rd group at 2:00 pm and descended from here; summiters slept in C4 which reached together (2 parties - 1st waited at top for 2nd party) 4:30-5:00 pm 13th while 3rd party at 7:00 pm. Fixed 7-9 ropes on final ridge, 22 ropes C4 to ridge; total 55-60 ropes (each rope 45m).

14 Nov 1991 - Al Burgess, leader of British attempt on Cheo, is confident this expedition climbed right mountain. 

Expedition's altimiter showed summit to be 7080m high which is 260m higher than official altitude.
ACCIDENTS: Nishioka leg injured by falling rock on S Face from Pt 6700m

ROUTEMEMO:
BC as same place as British
C1 as same place as British.

Did not climb from W because this ridge became a face and leads to another valley. Followed British route: have long way to high camp into another valley. Took one British Sherpa and followed their climb. Returned BC 4 Nov and left BC 5 Nov.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing (Thevenins slight altitude sickness at BC only)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  just east of Damodar Kunde
ABC northeast of BC
C1  at steep sand/gravel dose at bottom of icefall.

All foreigners except Edward Odell, the team doctor, stayed at BC throughout climb because felt effects of altitude. Team mad trekked from Pokhara 8th Oct, from Jomsom 15th Oct. 20th Lhakpa, Ang Kitar, Ang Jangbu and E Odell left BC and reached ABC at 5:30 pm. From BC to ABC terrain is wide steep sloping desert sand/gravel. 21st Oct Odell stayed at ABC while 3 Sherpas went on up and camped under icefall at 20,000 ft. Left ABC 2:30 am and reached C1 at 3:00 pm. 22nd Oct 3 Sherpas left C1 at 2:00 am and on top at 7:45 am. Climbed icefall in 2 hrs fixing rope here to top of icefall at 20,500 ft. From icefall snow and ice ridges very steep - no avalanches but very strong wind. Returned to BC at 7:00 pm. Fixed rope on final 200m to summit because it was windy on sharp rock ridges; this only rope fixed. 5 clients had thought in KTM they would climb but Sherpas were so much more energetic than they were in BC, they felt exploration was enough.

BC and its lake are over two 17,000 ft passes from last camp at Gurrnatanti and very rocky taking porters as far as lake because heavy snowstorm could block passes.


Bhrikuti (6364m)

A British-Nepalese joint team, led by Elaine Brook and co-led by Lhakpa Sherpa, claimed that they made the first ascent of this peak by the SE Ridge on Oct 22, 1991. Three Sherpas (Lhakpa, Ang Zangbu and Ang Kitar) reportedly reached the summit at that time. However, when the HAJ (Himalayan Association of Japan) and the Tribhuvan Univ. Joint team first challenged this peak in 1982 Spring; they climbed all high peaks comprising main range. This fact is apparently denying above British claim [of 1st ascent]. The HAJ-Nepal joint team approached Bhrikuti, believed to be 6720m at that time and placed BC on NW Face via Dae village.
ACCIDENTS: None on mountain (all foreigners and Ang Kitar had altitude problems)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near lake Yuligolja
C1 near point 5661m
C2 on SW Ridge.

Reached ridge beyond C1 and found Japanese ropes which showed the way along easy rocks. Could have used these ropes "but not necessary, too easy there." From C2 followed left side of ridge to summit. Ridge 55-degrees steepness and climbed this steep part from C2 to top in 6 hrs without loads and without fixing ropes. Fixed no ropes during entire climb. Had strong cold wind on summit day. Left BC 11th Nov and took 4 days (had taken 7-1/2 days from Jiri to BC). Porters said they knew the way but did not and time spent finding correct way (should taken 6-7 days).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to illness, lack of time, few climbers
ROUTEMEMO:
BC 30 mins downhill from Japanese in green meadow
C1 same as Japanese
C2 above Japanese
C3 same as Japanese
High point at C3.

First climbed several peaks in area including Naya Kanga and Tsergo Ri for acclimatization for alpine-style ascent of Langtang (after this stage Maclean left for home). "With fixed ropes dangling in front of you" therefore hard not to do standard style climb; also route more difficult than expected and team now only 3 men. Turned back at C3. Strong winds and lack of acclimatization and one members gardia and weren't climbing in true alpine-style ("we were climbing on someone else's back"). Climb was "serious" but not too difficult to handle. 1st Nov back to BC and now members got diarrhea in turn (water source had become stagnant pools and though iodine added, perhaps this the cause). By 5 Nov realized not enough time to make successful summit bid and walked out via lakes in one-week return to KTM. Timothy Banton and Stephenson made climb of 29-31 Oct; James Grey went to 6000m alone 5 Nov to see how high he could go in one day and returned to BC. Left BC 9 Nov.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at lower BC site
C1 at some team's BC.
C4 at North Col
High point at North Col (C4).

Planned summit bid from C4 on night of 5/6 Oct, but wind made impossible to move up. Forno had taken wrong boots so he descended to C3 while others on C4. Pennati and Ang Thile Sherpa tried to go up with tent to make C5 but after 50m gave up and all down. Forno and Ang Thile down to BC, helping an exhausted Spaniard to get down. Other Italians to C3 on 7th with hope to go up; 2 did go to C4 on 8th (Blanc and Spazzadeschi). 

9th Forno left BC and all others reported they were descending but Blanc and Spazzadeschi said they wanted to try with Swiss.

All 9 remaining members left BC 13th Oct. Blanc and Spazzadeschi did want to try for summit bid but reached only C4 and then turned back because of winds. They had arrived at C4 on 8th Oct and stayed there till 12th and down.
ACCIDENTS: None until Oct 9 morning when Forno left; nothing afterwards

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at same as Italians (normal BC site).

Pitched 2 C3s: 1st 6900m on 6 Oct. but had to put it lower because exposed to wind. Now big problem with winds and 3 times reached site of C4; because of winds and ice had to retreat 3 times. 4th time successful with big stones and ropes (170 km/hr/wind). Wind was only real problem: began on 6th Oct and blew all the the time. Summit bids by all who tried to go to C4 were planning to go on to top but 1st 3 groups failed to pitch C4, 4th group set up C4 and slept there one night and then winds drove them down. 5th group were 2 of 5 who made C4; started 0:15 am from C3 on 25th and reached top 11:55 am and down to C3 (one C4 tent had been brought to C3, other C4 tent was destroyed by winds). 26th to BC. On 26th 2 others up to C3 but retreated next day; now snowfall began and was windy. 27th Oct decided climbing finished. Left BC 31 Oct.

SPONSOR: Tochigi Workers Alpine Federation Expedition 1991 Langtang Lirung
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7150m due to deep snow, strong winds and team exhausted
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lirung Glacier, north of Gyalsham Gompa
C1 at below ridge
C2 on SE Ridge
C3 on SE Ridge
C4 on SE Ridge.

After C3, Sherpas in "no good condition" to carry loads and only one carried to C4 only once. 26 Oct C4 pitched but slept in; other party arrived C4 on 29th and slept there. 30th made summit attack by Nagatsuka and Yanagihara to 6900m. Then Nagatsuka became blind in both eyes from altitude (could see 30 cm only). Next day his sight Ok after reaching BC 31st at Oct (slept in C4 on 31st).

2nd attack on 2 Nov from C3 by Nomura and Ogawa. 3 Nov 4:30 am started from C4 and reached 7150m at 3:00 pm; turned back because too late for summit and safe return. Slow progress that day due to deep snow and strong wind. Returned to C4 to sleep and to C2 next day.

3rd attack by Ichimura and Oishi who arrived C4 6 Nov to go to top on 7th but on 7th Ichimura and Oishi in "no good condition" and strong wind (Ichimura heavy coughing/sore ribs and Oishi tired), so now climbing finished. 

6 members had tried for summit, one gone home because his time to be out of Japan finished and other one had serious tooth infection. Between C2 and C2 dangerous from falling stones and when snow is present, avalanching. Route is difficult: sharp ridge with soft snow. Left BC 10 Nov.
ACCIDENTS: Muroi serious tooth infection; Nagatsuka nearly blinded from altitude

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at normal site.

Wanda Rutkiewicz and yaks arived at ABC while other members arrived only on 10th after more acclimatization. On 15th climbers deposited gear at 6700m and all down to ABC that day for rest. 18th all 8 to C1 and Wanda on up to ice tunnel-depot at 6700m. 19th all to C2. 20th all except Wanda down to ABC to C2. 24th all towards C3 site but Wanda was behind the others, couldn't find their trail and made biv in snowhole 100m below them. 25th 2 to top, while Wanda passed C3 and up to 7700m and back to C3 because of strong wind and poor visibility; that night, 3:15 am (NST) she left C3 in fullmoon light and slight wind and reached [the top at] at 10:45 am. In her descent chose wrong couloir far from her C3 and alone so impossible for her to make trail in deep snow to traverse to C3, so went on down and finally reached expedition's C2 (passing a body in a tent - whose?) and 27th to ABC. On 27th 2 Spaniards going up from ABC to C1 as she passed them; they were heading for top. Wanda left ABC 28th am and with 2 members reached KTM night of 29th. One member had left ABC on 26th, 2 members few days earlier.


Fernandez and Quetglas - 13 Oct:

De Leo reached summit 25 Sept and when descending met De Dea at 8100m going up - De Leo asked De Dea to help him descend: De Leo very tired and frostbite beginning in his fingers and toes, so De Deo turned back at 8100m to help his friend; "psychologically Guido was on summit."

Fernandez, Quetglas and Tirtha Tamang went up to C2 on 27 Sept. 28th Quetglas left C2 6:00 am Chinese time and arrived at C3 9:00 am with very cold toes. Went into Japanese tent, which was empty at the time because Japanese were going to summit, and used Japanese cooker, etc., to heat water to warm his feet. The C3 established by Wanda and Christian was now gone. Stayed 3 hrs until sun was on the face, then at 12:00 up. Met descending Japanese at 8000m at about 3:00 pm, and reached summit at 5:00 pm; returned to C2 and slept there.

Fernandez on 28th to C3 with Tirtha Tamang. 29th both to 7800m, then Ferandez developed stomach trouble and both to BC same day and climb finished (this was same day USSR and US climbers reached summit). Quetglas and Fernandez then went to Xixabangma, where they joined Spanish team, but no summit success.

De Dea claims to have reached summit bid but did not - Wanda by telephone 1 Oct.

Grenier says on 5 Oct only Christian and Sergio on summit on 25 Sept.
ACCIDENTS: De Leo frostbitten fingers and toes (white); 1 Sherpa altitude sickness

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to very strong wind
ROUTEMEMO: 29th summit bid stopped by winds and slept ABC. 3rd Nov tried again but reached C2. 30th Oct C3 and 1 tent at C1 destroyed by wind (C3's only tent blown away but found 3 Nov near C2). Left BC 6th Nov.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Kangchung's correct location
ABC NNE of Nangpa La (near "g" of Gyabrag Glacier)
C1  east of of Glacier
C2  on ridge (never slept in)
High point at C2 site.

Perhaps did not push hard enough but even at BC 2 tents broken by wind-strong wind every day starting in late morning at night blew very hard. Route is very long with little altitude gain. Tent placed at site by Wuertenberger who did not sleep there on 28th. He again to C2 on 4th Nov, wind too strong for further progress and he retreated same day with tent. Kitchen boy on same day to C2 on his own to retrieve coffee pot, etc.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m (lower summit)
ROUTEMEMO:
Easy climb. Took more direct route from C2 to C3. 2 climbed very quickly, were very strong and Japanese Sherpas had made route and were lucky that winds had abated when French ready to try for top. Reached 1st summit they came to which in clear weather proved not to be highest.

Left BC 30 Sept; left quickly because of frostbite.
ACCIDENTS: Slight frostbite in toes by summiters; 2 others slightly ill

ROUTEMEMO:
ABC occupied after a week because of altitude sickness of 5 members. 1st summit bid on 29th by all but 1 member who went no higher than C3. Up from C4 on 29th and got to summit plateau at just over 8000m. Kennedy turned back (knew something wrong but did not realize what and then unaware feet freezing). Dietz and Clark not much higher and back tired. Had started 8:15 am Nepali Time; other 4 to top. 1 Oct Kennedy got high altitude sickness in C4 and others tied him to a line and told him to go down to C3 which he managed to do; had gotten dehydrated and therefore frostbite and HAPE. Kennedy and all down to C1 and Kennedy to ABC. 

Clark on 4th tried solo attempt from C1 to C3; 5th tried for top from C3, reached plateau again and down because of cold and wind. 

No more climbing: had called for yaks to be at ABC on 6th and left ABC 6th including Clark. Left Chinese BC at about 9:00 am Nepalese time and arrived KTM midnight 10th.


Cynthia T. Kennedy, Jerry's wife - 10 Nov 2005 (letter to Miss Hawley)

Fourteen years later, Jerry still has open wounds on his feet that require daily tending.
ACCIDENTS: Kennedy serious HAPE and frostbite on Oct 1; Clark serious frostbite

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at between 2 lakes, northeast of Gyazumpa on Schneider map.

Fixed rope: 100m icefall below C2 and 120m just befor C2, 400m between C2 and C3, 730m C3 to C4, 320m between C4 and C5 and 80m above C5. Above C5, stayed on ridge and into gully stayed on border, from west and of gully climbed/traversed on Tibetain side for 200m before rejoining border ridge to summit and gully is 70m deep from eastern lip to bottom - gully was mixed rock and ice and snow (rock not hard, would shatter, but found some points where could fix bolts). This area's N and S faces were rock 3000m from top of ridge down to very steep snow and same snow on top of ridge. Very steep rock faces also in section beyond gully in another step before final climb to summit. On Tibet side of gully is couloir. Far west side of gully was a shelf which used in traverse. This traverse was most difficult part of entire climb and was very difficult - faces 80 degrees perhaps in this area. After C4 established, all down for rest; first to go beyond C4 started this section on 15th Oct to see route and fix ropes. On 18th Oct on attempt made from C4 to top but when reached 7900m (beyond gully) realized now, at 1:00 pm was too late to reach top and return in daylight and to climb after dark "very hard work" so decided to cancel this attempt. 

On 19th next summit party take from C4 equipment to make C5 (this removed C4 to make C5) - arrived at C5 site at 3:00 pm and fixed 100m rope before spending night at C5. 20th Oct left C5 at 8:00 am and reached summit around 11:00 am and down 12:50 pm. Besides 5 summiters, doctor also tried for summit and reached 8000m; tired and fingers begining to freeze (he was surgeon) so turned back and he returned to C5 at 1:30 pm with 1st 3 summiters. All slept in C5 that night.

21st C5 tent left there and took sleeping bags to descend to C3 and 5 summiters slept in C3 but doctor hit by falling stone when he had climbed up 15m to get out of gully; he was not wearing helmet and hit on forehead (had not expected to need helmets above C3 and none taken up there) and lived only a minute (had several inches deep wound). Had to leave body in sleeping bag on shelf in gully because impossible to carry it down to C3 (trying to move body, Pershin got frozen fingers and used oxygen that night in C3; finger tips are black now but will heal now).
ACCIDENTS: Timofeev hit by falling rock & top of head wounded (no helmet); Pogorelov had painful nerve problem in one leg, rested in BC one week and resumed climb; Pershin frostbite; doctor's fatal rock fall

APPROACH: From Nepalese side of Nangpa La
ROUTEMEMO:
BC west of point 6296m
C1 near "c" of Gyabrag Glacier on Schneider map.

All members reached C3 and also LO. 

LO Kamal Bhandari, Manang instructor, tried for top on 4th and 5th reached 7300m, turned back tired and beginning to have edema (hands and face swollen); other 2 members not above C3 (tired). 

After Cho Oyu climb went to Thami where met trekking group and with them made a camp at Nangpa 16th Oct. 17th Oct climbed Cho Rausang (6600m) by West Face: not very difficult and from top have fine view of Tibet and Cho Oyu. Climbers were roped together but no fixed rope. Face entirely snow except for 30m of ice.

BC at below Kangchung's correct site
C1 across Nangpa La
C2 at same US C2 this autumn.

After C2 made, descended for rest at BC. Skripko and his USSR teammates reached summit 5:15 NST and in ascent met descending Americans and slept in American camp at 7500m. Skripko frostbite on all toes probably during night of 29/30 Sept.

Skripko certain summit date was 29th since it was day after Mojaev's birthday.
ACCIDENTS: Skripko frostbite in toes on both feet but probably will heal

ROUTEMEMO:
Only one of the Hong Kong Chinese members did any climbing: Lam reached 8150m with Tsindin [Chuldin] Temba on 28 Sept. One other got altitude sickness, left BC for lower altitude and returned to BC. Team's C1, C2 and C3 were below Japanese camps, hence their need to have C4. Left BC 1st Oct, 2 days before Japanese.

This team was on Japanese permit and shared ABC but ABC were separate party.
ACCIDENTS: One member altitude sickness; nothing else

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to deep snow and exhaustion
ROUTEMEMO:
4 Sept summit attack from C4 and reached 7800m by Chen Chiu-Hsia, Wang Chin-Jung, Wangchu Sherpa and Gelje Sherpa. 

7th Sept another camp pitched because C4 too low and 1st team took 10 hrs to reach 7800m. Could put C5 only 100m [higher] because waist-deep snow meant it took 5 hrs to pitch this camp. 7 Sept another attack by Chen Chiu-Hsia, Wang Chin-Jung, Huang Su-Wen and Karma Sherpa from C5 but reached only 7700m before thick clouds and snowfalling and Karma double shoe broken so back to C5 only. 

9 Sept 3rd attempt by same 3 members only from C5. Reached just 7600m with very deep snow, new snow falling and were very tired. Left ABC 13 Sept and flew to KTM from Lhasa. 

Were many avalanches on face so climbed direct route above C3.

Use of oxygen - 1st attack team during descent to C4.
                3rd attack team in C5 after return from attempt.

Jakob Riechen arrived at ABC with one Sherpa. Reichen had a Nepalese trekking permit only and all gear/supplies they had were what they carried themselves; on 25th Sept he left for Spanish-Italian-Polish team's C2 at 1 am and reached summit with Christian Kuntner (who started from higher camp) at 8:45 am.


Reichen - 22 May 2002  

He crossed from Nepal via Nangpa La illegally to Tibet and climbed Cho Oyu without Sherpas or oxygen. He met Christian Kuntner and Wanda Rutkiewicz on the mountain and went to summit the same day as they.

Japanese party arrived at summit 28 Sept after Europeans, who probably reached only 1st Summit. Left BC 3 Oct.

Hong Kong Chinese were on same permit and shared same ABC, but on mountain were separate and are not included here.

Sherpa summiters:
  Nima Temba (Lukla), already scaled Kangchanjunga (3 times)
  Mingma Norbu (Beding), aleady scaled Everest (N), 1990 Xixabangma
  Pemba Norbu (Namche), already scaled Everest 1977, Lhotse 1983

BC near lake
C1 only for deposit (not slept in).

Only Nakamura and 1 Sherpa to top. Other 2 climbing members too tired when arrived on 16th Oct at C2 to go higher. 6 hrs C2 to top and back to C2 (4 hrs C2 to top) on 16th.

BC near lake
C1 at small rib at start of climb
C2 at top of rib.

Dangerous above C2 to col (serac falling) but easy if one goes very fast. On descent from col, German Breuer was coming behind Gunnarsson, but no one saw Gunnarsson start his fall: could have been hit by ice block, could have misstepped. Fell from 6700 to 5300m altitude & found body in 5 pieces at bottom, where much avalanche debris collects and will be covered by more debris soon. A third summit party was a day behind Gunnarsson but gave up final attempt after his fall.

Joe Simpson in "This Game of Ghosts" states (pp 309-310) that Gunnarsson was struck on the head by a falling ice block 100 ft above C2 and fell hundreds of feet down. Accident was witnessed by German climber.

BC near lake
C2 at top of a buttress (normal site).

Fixed rope from C1 to C2 only. Route led to big pass and then towards summit around seracs, etc. ("not a good ridge"). After C2 established, all to BC. Summit push began 12th Sept. To C1 that night by 4 members and 2 Sherpas. 14th all 6 to C2. On 15th Feruglio, Laurenceau, Roche and Dawa leave C2 at 3:00 am because snow conditions better: at 6:30 am sun is on SE Face and reached top at 11:00 am together and all Ok. But at 7:30-8:00 am avalanche hit Marigot, Saidi and Gyalzen at about 6600m when small avalanche came from face down small gullies; had left C2 6:30 am because Saidi and Gyalzen slightly sick from stomach. Roche told them to stay in camp, but Marigot came up from C1 and urged Saidi and Gyalzen down (roped together but Marigot not roped to them, was 15m from them). Marigot stayed on face waiting for summit party but radioed to Everest BC about avalanche and 4 Sherpas. Pivot and wife (Dr.) reached Pumori BC 9:00-10:00 am, saw 2 bodies on face from Everest BC. Bodies at same altitude as C1 but very dangerous to go to them because of dangerous unstable seracs. Next day bodies covered by more avalanches.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6950m due to falling seracs
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site near lake
C1 at top of rib
C2 on SE Face
High point at SE Face.

During night at C2 wakened by falling serac every 2 hours coming from route above camp via chute. Would have to move very fast across this area which would not have been able to do. So on 8th Nov after going up a bit to take pictures went down and climbing finished. Additional factor was the wind. This was self-supporting group of friends on very limited budget. As they approached BC, they met same climbers coming away who spoke of technical difficulty on Pumori and found in BC area memorials to climbers who had died on it. This was rather unsettling.
ACCIDENTS: Labrousse sick (on antibiotics, dizzy at C1 and went down)

SPONSOR: Terramar Foundation Expedition to Himalayas - to Pumori
ROUTEMEMO:
BC above lake and across hills
C1 only for deposit (never slept in).

Went to Island Peak before making BC for Pumori & 5 reached top on 4th Oct. 

1st summit party returned C2 5 pm; problem with strong wind blowing powder snow, driving snow into faces "really horrible." 13th Oct winds less severe but there still C1 to C2 steep & very icy. C2 to shoulder not technically difficult but dangerous from big avalanches 4-5 times daily (4 am on 13th Oct high avalanche & another 10 mins after summiters had crossed avalanche area): "we were very nervous" but nonetheless climbed. Saw one falling to his death (not caused by avalanche but lost his balance).

On Island Peak Avardo slipped and broke one rib before attempt on this peak and was exhausted immediately.
ACCIDENTS: None on Pumori; on Island Peak Alvardo slipped and broke one rib before attempt on this peak and was evacuated immediately

ROUTEMEMO:
BC same as British and Germans
C1 same as British and Germans
C2 same as British and Germans.

Saw fatal accident of Icelander due to exhaustion and were careful not to push selves to limit. Did not make a 2nd attack on summit because of danger above C2. Was very happy cooperation with other teams on mtn and who would go up when very good weather. Had moved quickly up on mtn for fear weather would deteriorate. 

On 11 Oct were 3 members: left camp at 4 am, 2 members reached col and up ridge to 6900-7000m and stopped there because wanted to save strength for safe descent, especially in view of Icelander's fall. Waited here for Koeblinger, who reached summit alone at about 11 am and rejoined at C2 after he was seen descending. He arrived at 2 pm at C2. 

Other 3 members went only to C1. Were afraid of dangers on upper part of route and Mueller and Ruffiner left BC on 8 Oct.

SPONSOR: Cani Gou Alpine Club Expedition Pumori
ROUTEMEMO: Only 2 on top because others tired. Only Murat to C1: other 9 reached near C1 & turned back because of altitude problems. Left BC 26th Oct.

BC near lake.

Pitched tents at C1 and C2 on 2nd and 3rd Oct. On 6th Oct Finkbeiner and Roepke left C2 4 am and 10:30 am on top and in BC 3 pm. Went first to fix ropes above C2 and see route. On 9th summiters (Breuer and Icelander Gunnarsson) from C1 at 4:00 am to top at noon and back to C2. Breuer reached C2 at 4:00 pm while Gunnarsson fell just above C2; went down East Face and body found by Roepke on 10th in pieces; brought down by avalanche on 10th. On 10th Breuer reached BC after the avalanche which brought body down. Left BC 13th Oct.

BC at normal site near Mingbo.

After made C1 and 19th down, 2 days in BC and directly to top then. Left BC 22nd, slept in C1, 23rd in C2 after technically difficult route, and 24th took 2 tents on to make C3. 25th to top and slept in C3. BC on 26th. Left BC 29th morning. 

Members were clients. Chotel to C1 only: old and not technical climber.
ACCIDENTS: Mangel sick; one member slightly frostbitten toes (black but will heal)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near Mingbo
C2 on SW Rridge.

South face too dangerous from big rocks falling so went to SW Ridge for entire climb of normal route. No problems on climb: 2 did not summit because one was sick and other not capable enough climber. 6 members left before climbing finished because their climbing had finished. Joos summited a second time because his friend Marugg had been silently sick earlier and now wanted to go to the top. Last 4 members at BC left it 20 Oct.
ACCIDENTS: None except Lochmatter lung problem (he said inflation)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near Mingbo normal site.

Bellasio only to C2; extremely tired. Summiters to top from C3 and slept there that night. 3 French expeditions used Swiss fixed rope and had no climbing problems.

Left BC 6 Nov; had acclimatized on Kalapattar before going to Ama Dablam.

BC near Mingbo normal site.

All members reached C3; beyond there some had trouble with technical difficulties. 

Lecompte summited with Buisson and Males of French-Italian expedition.
ACCIDENTS: Cosson slightly frostbitten toes and fingers; nothing else

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to difficult route, wind, lack of strength, equipment and time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Nuptse Glacier below and south of ridge
C1 at small plateau north of this W-E ridge
High point at C1.

BC was below and south of Ridge that starts between points 6543m and 6823m. Climbed up this ridge to small plateau north of this ridge where C1 pitched. Went no further because agency had not provided enough equipment for more camps, Sherpa sick and Lekman slightly so. Sherpas said 2 months needed to climb such difficult route which descends and again ascends. Lekman reached C1 on 21st and went to BC same day. Again to C1 on 24th and found tent and its contents had been blown away and retreated to BC (Sherpas had made C1 3 days before Lekman 1st reached it).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to winds
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
High point on West Face.

Expected more support from Nepalese team in exchange for American's oxygen but they did not carry gear to C2 as expected. Made C3 and had high cache at 7600m top of yellow band; pitched C3 10th Oct. Oxygen cached next day but never slept above 6500m. Didn't need to sleep higher till making summit bid. 13th started for C3 with plan to summit later that night but winds strong and sign posted at BC indicated that icefall would be closed on 16th, so took down all gear from C2 and C3 to C1 then found it to be open longer - gave up. Team had reached BC late because because planned climb of Cho Oyu from Tibet fell through and they decided to try Lhotse after that.

Lhotse very dry and lot of bare rock and blue ice. Whole of Lhotse Face "blinking blue ice." Icefall huge crevasses; so with partner and rope Athans would have gone for Lhotse summit but not alone (Athans not soloist, likes sharing experiences with someone else).

Arrieta, Azcona, Lasarte and Ulazia intended to scale Lhotse and arrived at that BC 27th Aug, established C1 2 Sept at 6000m, C2 6th Sept at 6500m by 4 members. 15th Sept down to BC and 16th Sept to Pumori directly to C1 (French reported 15th good conditions on Pumori despite accident later in the day). 

Goni and Zulaika arrived Lhotse BC 4th Sept, but Zulaika got sick and both down to Pheriche. They returned to BC 17th for Pumori and tried for its summit 24th Sept and reached 100m from top, snow very deep, they were tired, moving slowly, cold in clouds. 

Meanwhile successful Pumori men returned to Lhotse BC 20th Sept and made C3 23rd Sept at 7300m and down to BC because of wind. 

Try for summit: left BC 28th Sept & 30th Sept up to C3 but too much wind to move up from C3 on 1st Oct as planned so down to C2. 3rd Oct again to C3 and 4th reached yellow band at 7650m: now only Arrieta and Azcona and Azcona now feeling unwell (no food) and climb finished for all except Arrieta who stayed at BC with Spanish Everest. Tried for summit on 10th Oct but did not get above C2 because of wind and he too gave up. 5 members left BC 7th Oct.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at bottom of Icefall
C1 at Rongbuk Glacier below Khumbutse and below North Spur from West Shoulder
C2 about 250m below West Shoulder
C3 at east end of West Shoulder
High point at West Shoulder.

Started fixing route on 4th Sept and finished it 18th Sept: same route as successful Poles 1989 Spring up over Khumbutse and down couloir to Banglark glacier, using 1500m of rope. From C1 fixed rope from bottom of N Spur to middle of spur. C2 placed in crevasse for protection from strong winds. Climbing shoulder very difficult because half-meter deep powder snow. 3 Oct went down according to plan: returned to 7200m on 11th Oct, but couldn't reach C3 because of wind and abandoned attempt on W Ridge and expedition ended. 

2 members left BC 5 Oct (had had enough), one member left 13 Oct (Lwow had decided expedition finished) and last 2 members left BC 17 Oct.

On 15 Oct Lwow and Klimine of USSR-US expedition left BC and reached 6700m (USSR-US C2) on the normal route, slept there and 16th brought down equipment. Lwow had hoped to go on up but wind of 15/16 night and 16th morning prevented upward climb so now on 16th Lwow abandoned Everest.

Lwow says German nor any member of this team climbed Pumori, but Mal Duff says one member did about 1 Oct.

SPONSOR: Himalaya 1991 Expedition of USSR - to Everest
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 by Kopeika
C1 by Davis & Boukreev (removed after C2 established)
C2 at bergschrund at bottom of Lhotse Face (by Balyberdin & Boukreev)
C2 on Lhotse Face (made and used only by Kopeika group)
C3 on Lhotse Face (made and used only by Kopeika group)
C4 at South Col (pitched by Balyberdin group).

Camp made at S Col by Balyberdin, Boukreev and Cooney group on 30th Sept and down to BC next day because of acclimatization needs. These 3 rested at BC 3 days and all 3 started up 5th Oct and went to C2 at 6800m; 6th Oct to S Col; 7th Oct started from C4 8:00 am. Boukreev reached summit at 3:00 pm and returned to col 6:00 pm while Balyberdin on top at 5:30 pm and back at 8:00 pm. All down to BC 8th Oct. Boukreev found on summit a small cross (3") in snow; cross left by Spaniard day before. This group rested, Cooney left BC 9th Oct (was enough for him in his 1st time in Himalaya and he headed for Thai beach to rest there). 12th Oct Balyberdin wanted to do one day ascent and started at midnight and at Geneva spur 11:00 am, but met Kopeika who descending from col said very strong wind above col and both descend to BC that day. Boukreev continued up and 13th Oct 8:00 am at 8300m and turned back because of very strong wind; reached BC 5:00 pm 13th. Balyberdin on 17th Oct 6:00 am up from BC to go to C2 to clear this camp but now saw weather improving so decided to go for top but his crampons and 2 heavy down jackets no longer in camp; 11:00 am in C2, 8:00 pm reached S Col without crampons 11:00 pm at 8300m - now wind changed from coming from west, now from south and now above rocks and hard snow: without campons impossible to continue; waited till morning in sleeping bag in snow till morning and then down; no frostbite at all; down to C2 only because must have crampons to go through Icefall in one day (on 17th Sherpas removed ropes and ladders) so big problem." On 19th at 5900m drop his rucksack and manages Icefall without crampons and reached BC in 1-1/2 hrs by very indirect route. 20th Balyberdin and Klimine go up to retrieve his rucksack. This group never used oxygen.


Kopeika group (Kopeika, Giutachvilli, Klimine, Kulishova and Mazur)

Made C1 at 6100m on 25th Sept; 26th to 6800m; 27th BC. 1O Oct to 6800m; 2 Oct established C3 at 7300m; 3 Oct 3 members slept at S Col and 2 members slept at C3. 4th Oct all to BC (normal acclimatization). 7th Oct all 5 to C2; 8th Oct 2 members to C3 and another 1 member to BC; 9th Oct 2 members to C4 and other 2 members to C3; 10th Oct 2 members to C4 and Giutuachvilli and Mazur to top using oxygen during climb and back to S Col 9:00 pm and slept there. 11th Oct Giutuachvilli to C3 only (very tired started form col down only at 2:00 pm). 2 members on 12th Oct tried to go up from col but very strong wind and went down instead and met Balyberdin in descent. 2 members and Balyberdin stayed in tent from C4 at 7500m waiting for good weather but weather bad and 15th Oct a member to C2 and 16th C3 to clear C3. Their climb now finished.

May he will come again for 1-day climb said Balyberdin but must have 1 year rest and think about it. Boukreev wants to try in 1 day: BC-summit-BC. "It's possible but good weather and good rest before and every time I have no good rest in this autumn's attempts.

Greg Davis spent 2 nights in C1 at 6100m then went down and left BC about 4 to 5th Oct. Why Balyberdin cannot say (according to TASS's KTM correspondent 11 Oct, Davis had trouble with altitude above 6000m, was in KTM 9 Oct and left 10 Oct). Mazur agrees Davis had altitude problem.

Mazur 29 Oct: Balyberdin did not pay Icefall toll demanded by expedition and made own route close to bottom of W Shoulder, from which there was avalanching "constantly." 1 avalanche took out 4 fixed lines at 6:30 one morning in late Sept. Then Balyberdin gave some supplies (oxygen?) to Nepalis and was allowed onto Nepalese Icefall route. There also was avalanching from S Col to C2 bergschrund area. "Russians take great risks." B & B's ascent on 7th was not solely to acclimatize for speed climb: wanted to reach summit.


Mazur - 29 Oct 1991

Greg Davis told Mazur at Everest BC he had gone to Gorakshep and Pumori BC for about 3 days but had not climbed Pumori, as he has been reported he did to Ministry of Tourism. Mazur wonders what he did for 3 days at base camp. Mal Duff, British Pumori expedition leader, says an American from Balyberdin's team did reach summit about 6 Oct.

[Balyberdin told me 27 Oct Davis did not climb Pumori].
ACCIDENTS: Nothing expect Kopeika lungs and chest problem

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8200m due to exhaustion
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at South Col.

Squires reached 7700m and then abandoned climb on 2 Oct; found climb too hard. 4th Collins, Lock and Groom reached col on 4th Oct intending to go to top that night. Weather had been stable till winds picked up that afternoon (Russians had gone to top in conditions Groom wouldn't accept). Spaniards stayed at col. On 6th reached 8200m following Spanish climbers, then turned back affected by altitude and buffeted by wind. Groom had been in avalanche and broke/bruised ribs and twisted knee and perhaps rebroke his nose 20th Sept on Lhotse Face at 7600m and fell with it to 6600m. Now realized foolish for him to make another attempt. Lock and Collins down to C2 to rest, tried to go up again but gave up at C3, realizing how tired and unmotivated they were. Left BC 11th Oct.

Pratt joined Australian group as requirement of a agent who held permit, originally for Spaniards, but he was entirely independent of Groom's foursome on the mountain. Pratt reached S Col 7 or 8th Oct and stayed on hoping for another summit bid.

C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at South Col.

After C3 established, strong winds prevented more progress till end of Sept. 3 Oct 5 members made summit bid and reached S summit. No route opened beyond there, powdered snow there and hadn't enough oxygen and rope to climb Hillary Step so returned to C4 with Gomez staying at col and others on down. 

4th Oct 5 more people up to col. 5th wind so wait at col. 6th go for summit: 6 Spanish climbers up from C4, 5 reach nearly top of Hillary Step. Here on descent Vidaurre cannot see (because wind's effect on eyes) and Gomez, helps him descend. Top is big cornice. Gomez did not ask Vidaurre to wait while Gomez went to top; his friend was weeping in distress and begging for help. In summit bid of 6th, Ortas carried oxygen to 8500m and left there 2 bottles: he did not expect to go to top and carried for his teammates, who used these bottles in ascent. On 6th it was not windy till above S Summit. 7th Oct very strong wind and summit impossible then and climb finished and did not try for Lhotse summit. Vidaurre left small cross at summit which Russian summiter found and brought back.
ACCIDENTS: Garces 2 toes frostbitten on summit day

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Rongbuk
High BC C3 at East Rongbuk
C4 at North Col.

Took 2 weeks to get to N Col fixing ropes in strong winds (if no wind, reach in 4-5 days). Almost everyday and night, clear but windy. C4 established 28th Oct by 2 members, Ang Rita and Ang Nima with other 2 members carrying loads but not staying at col. 29th rested at C4. 30th was windy still but Brandolin and Ang Rita reached only 7100m and back to C4: to go higher "we fly to Kathmandu or we die." 31st wind and cold (-25 degrees) persisted so no attempt to go up; all 4 down to C3. 2 Nov all to BC for 1 week's rest and to buy supplies of food at Sheay. 10th Nov start up to high BC (C3) in 2 days: Bonin, Lima, 3 climbing Sherpas and 1 cook to C3; arrived C3 on only day of snowfall 11th Nov. Now colder and stronger wind. 16th Nov Bonin down to BC. 17th Brandolin tried solo attempt with a member along to film but wind stopped them at 6800m and returned to C3. 18th 2 members and Ang Nima down from C3. 20th 2 other Sherpas down (cook and Phurba) and finally Lima, Brandolin and Ang Rita down when yaks came; after 17th no one attempted to go above C3; many tents destroyed by wind. Left BC 26 Nov and arrived KTM 28 Nov.
ACCIDENTS: 1 Sherpa very badly infected tooth (went only to ABC & then back to Kathmandu)

SPONSOR: 1st Nepalese Woman Sagarmatha Expedition to Everest
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8760m due to winds
ROUTEMEMO:
C4 at South Col
High point at South Summit.

French women arrived BC late Aug, 10th Sept and began 15th Sept. At BC Pasang Lhamu's husband said no climbers from any expedition had right to try summit before Pasang Lhamu tried. Europeans had not signed any paper to this effect.

Pasang made her 1st attempt on 30th Sept.
