Turned back by chest-deep snow and fear of avalanche (Fukuda and Okabe stopped at 7300-7400m). 3 members were climbing on oxygen in order to climb quickly but Okabe had problem with oxygen apparatus (French masks) so turned back.

2nd bid on 31 Aug by Suda, Okabe & Ang Dorje; started 3:30 am from C2 and reached 8050m at 4:00 pm and again too much snow after climbing over snow-slab overhang, which thought was summit. Above this very deep soft snow. Ang Dorje had turned back at 7600m. Again Japanese members climbed on oxygen. Left BC 6 Sept (Sokumi left BC 31 Aug to return to work).
ACCIDENTS: Fukushima pulmonary edema; Chandra Gurung (cook) unknown illness at Japanese BC, died at Chinese BC

ROUTE2: WSW Ridge of Firnkopf-W Ridge of Saipal
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at North Saipal Glacier
C1 at moraine on east side of North Saipal Glacier
C2 at moraine on east side of North Saipal Glacier
C3 at small ridge where it joins NE Ridge
C4 on NE Ridge.

This easiest route on Saipal. 500m fixed rope between C2 and C3 mixed rock and ice 45 degrees (not so steep); this only section fixed.
ACCIDENTS: Doctor altitude sickness at C3 (not serious)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at North Saipal Glacier at start of Karsang Khola
C2 on NE Ridge (same site as German's camps)
C3 on NE Ridge.

Germans came a week later than Swiss-French, came up there fixed ropes and put camps at same sites. "A little human problem - 2 expeditions on same route is little problem." Big snow and wind storm on night of 12th and for 2 days impossible to move in fog and avalanche danger. Afterwards very clear and all white. 15th to C1. Now 3 times tried to get to C3. On 24th Oct Montaz, Zoller, Tendi Sherpa and Rinzi Sherpa from BC to C2, 25th Montaz, Zoller and Tendi from C2 to biv at 6500m, and 26th to summit. Zoller had stomach problem and stopped 1 hour before summit (6900m) from main summit. Montaz, Zoller and Tendi slept at biv 26th and on 27th to C1. All members left BC 28th Oct.

APPROACH: via Manang (left over Mesa Kanta Pass to Kali Gandaki)
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO: Could not reach main ridge because of slab avalanche danger. Tried to make route to main ridge but Abert fell a short distance. Had intended to go to top on 6th Nov, but 2 hrs short of main ridge turned back.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to difficult head wall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at normal Annapurna I North Face BC's site
ABC below a ridge running south 500m about thing upper head wall=S Face
C2  below upper headwall
Biv at only ridge possible without hammock on S Face.

Had more camps than perhaps normal because wanted to do new route and were looking at mountain that normally need 2 high camps. 1st climbing problem was to gain S Ridge and forced serac and southern end of this ridge. Fixed 250m to C1 at beginning of snow ridge, the S Ridge. Lost 6 kg and up of food to crows (Tibetan ravens?) at ABC. Ridge not technically difficult: no cornices. Upper head wall next which is 1000m high and ends at snow plateau. Loose shale rock with only 2 small ledges but ice fields and snow fluting. No campsites. Fixed ropes between 6000m and 6300m and then accident: Dower 12th Oct was soloing above fixed ropes when he fell at 150m (fixing rope not yet finished) and fell 50 vertical meters broke arm and fractured/clipped his pelvis. Hickie and Helmore got him down and Ridoutt rushed to Jomsom to summon chopper which removed him from BC 16th Oct. Now remaining climbers very tired and Dower's unnecessary risk cost the others the summit. 

Resumed climb on 16th and fixed more rope. 20th Oct summit bid from C2 but climb on head wall harder than expected and got only to 6500m. Steep shaley rock and snow flutings = dangerous and steep route. Had no sleeping gear with them and getting dark so bivouacked in open at 6300m and down to C2 on 21st; no food in C2 and now Donnini now acute altitude sickness (and put on Spanish oxygen) and Ridoutt retreated with hemorrhage, so now only 2 fit climbers (doctor non-climber really and busy with sick members). C3 needed a snow plateau. Decided to stop attempt to climb on 22 Oct and went on again only to strip mountain (decision taken at C2).

BC southwest of point 4738m
C1 near Gustang North Ridge - East Glacier west of this ridge
C2 below SW Face of Dhaulagiri V
C3 below Dhaulagiri VI West Ridge
C4 at bottom of SE Face of Churen East Peak
C5 on SE Face of Central Peak.

From C5 one team to Central Peak and one to West Peak 9:30 am and returned to C5 1:30 pm and slept there; Central Peak party started from C5 5:10 am and reached summit 9:20 am and returned C5 1:50 pm and slept in C5; difficult climbing from C2 to C3 because had to traverse a peak; next most difficult part was descending from C4 to C5 on way to C5, where was steep ice wall covered by snow on part of it and on part bare ice; fixed total 1700m rope.

2 members who did not make a summit had altitude sickness and remained at C4 2 nights, descended 15th Sept; waited at C2 till summit parties arrived and all together to BC.
ACCIDENTS: Climbing Ghustung Ridge, 1 member hit in leg by falling stone but climbed later; 2 members who did not make a summit had altitude sickness and stayed at C4 2 nights, descended Sept 15

TERMNOTE: Did not reach BC
ROUTEMEMO:
Left KTM 18th Sept by road to Tansen. Trekked via Dhorpatan, Tarakot, Tarap Khola, Tarapgaon, Kagmara La and Jagdula Khola and back to Hurikot and Jumla. Could not reach BC area because Jagdula Khola's steep slopes and rock cliffs difficult for porters. Good path on west side of Jagdula Khola to point roughly opposite point 15,750 ft on trekking map, Jomsom to Jumla and Surkhet. 

Fixed ropes along khola cliff for porters and made a camp after this section but then 10 porters left in snowstorm that lasted 3 days and other porters also wanted to go back. So decided best to give up: way very difficult for porters but OK for Sherpas, but need more Sherpas and more time. Perhaps a boat to cross river. 

4 or 5 on return climbed Dudh Kundari via E Ridge to sharp S crest. Put a high camp between BC and summit - 1300m to sharp high camp at 4700m to summit by 4 members on 17th Oct (BC near Jagdula Khola).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5500m due to dangerous snow conditions
OTHERSMTS: Kagmara Ri (a hill above Kagmara La)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC just below Kagmara La on its west side
High point at N Face.

10th Nov recce day from top of Kagmara Ri (5370m) on opposite side of Kagmara La on N and had magnificent view of N Face of Kagmara I and hidden valley below the face; decided to approach valley from between Kagmara La and mountain. 11th climbed to top of icefall at 5300m, climbed into valley; was waist deep snow. 12th reached N Face and tested snow which was unconsolidated and too dangerous. Made no biv or camp above BC; snow which was left by heavy snowfall in early Oct which stayed in cold weather.

SPONSOR: 1990 Korean Sambaidulgi Alpine Club Nilgiri N Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at North Annapurna Glacier SE of mountain.

BC lower than planned. Put here because from this place could see entire route. Route above C3 was on back side of photo on SE Face behind small ridge. Between ABC to C1 falling stone and snow avalanches. C1 to C2 very hard technical climb. C2 to C3 difficult 200m rock then knife ridge but above that not so difficult.

1st summit team left C3 8:00 am and on top 12:00 noon and descended to C2. 2nd team 2 hrs C3 to top. Used 1600m fixed rope total (from 4900m to C3). Much snowfall and avalanching but climbed quickly because of low food supplies. Left BC 11th Sept.
ACCIDENTS: Minor injuries from falling stones; 1 summiter fell 100m

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5600m due to dangerous conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at half-hour east of Khola in valley
C1 west of Kande Hiunchuli
C2 southwest of Patrasi peaks
High point at Patrasi peak.

Tried to go to Kande Hiunchuli up its NW Ridge. All men members climbed NW Ridge 5600m. Could see there was much dangerous fall of ice (seracs) on entire steep horseshoe shaped face on W slopes of Patrasi peaks; made biv at 5200m 4th Nov; on 5th Nov to small summit (for recce of route to Kande Hiunchuli or to complete climb). Saw rock ridge of Kande Hiunchuli bad rock and very long across point 19,530 ft returned to camp/biv and back to BC. 

Next tried peaks S of Kande Hiunchuli and made camp to 5100m 8th Nov on SW Ridge of point 19,600 ft. On 9th Nov reached point 19,600 ft and along its N Ridge to another peak not on map just N of point 19,600 ft which was 6000m high altimeters; same day retreated to Pt 19,600 ft and down on easier ridge leading SE from point 19,600 ft and thence NW to camp at 5100m and 10th Nov returned to BC; one member half-way to point 19,600 ft and other 2 members to summits on 9th Nov. 

11th Nov left BC and trekked north via Chaudhabise Khola; women members went to smaller peaks around BC area. 

Could have reached Kande Hiunchuli summit via all the south ridge peaks but long way and this team now did not have enough time; would have needed 1 or 2 camps more.

SPONSOR: Japanese Women's Climbing Club (Jyoshi Tohan) Dhaulagiri I Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site (4 expeditions there together)
C1 at NE Col
C2 on NE Ridge
C3 on NE ridge.

Summit party left C3 at 4 am and on top 1:05 pm; weather clear and snow conditions very good, but "little strong wind." Route "not difficult but very long way." 

1st expedition to arrive fixed the ropes, but Japanese added 1500m to make easier, diversions around snow bridges.
ACCIDENTS: Kimura slightly frostbitten toes, fingers, nose and cheeks; Miyaska constant cough that left her weak

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at NE Col
C2 on NE Ridge
C3 slightly below most expeditions C4 on NE Ridge.

Buhler and Dainius got to BC (3 days ahead of Lowe) and both went out onto glacier 29th and Buhler immediately got acute bronchitis with high fever and Dainis fell in to crevasse and wrenched knee (tore ligaments) and both out of action. Dainius decided to stay on at BC without climbing at all. Lowe and Nuru went to look at E Face from NE Col and put tent at 6400m; decided E Face not on autumn route because of avalanche danger in autumn. Buhler now really sick and left BC to Marpha on 9th Oct escorted by Lowe and Nuru almost to Marpha; Buhler on to Jomsom and Muktinath with expedition cook while others returned to BC on 10th and rested at BC 11th and 12th. 13th Lowe and Nuru up to C1 and were stuck there by 3-day snowstorm with wind; up to C2 on 17th Lowe made C3 on 18th while Nuru down to BC; Lowe left C3 at 7:00 am on 19th entirely alone, cut across N Face and back to ridge to top 2:30 pm. Afternoon snowstorm blew up and had difficulty finding way down and reached C3 at 9:00 pm (had forgotton to take his head lamp and was no moonlight; was "very concerned" about his situation). 20th down with his small high-altitude tent and in another afternoon snowstorm pitched tent at 6000m, in morning of 21st reached BC, with slight frostbite. left BC 22nd or 23rd.

Buhler returned to BC 18th Oct to find Dainius had been hiking around and eager to climb. 19th Buhler rested at BC and 20th Buhler and Dainius with Nuru started climbing and reached C1; 21st rested, 22nd up to C2 and back to C1 to sleep; 23rd rested at C1; 24th moved to C2; 25th up ridge 1000 ft to 6750m and down to BC (a test of Dainius' knee and Buhler's health). 26th and 27th rested at BC. Dainius was slower in climbing than Buhler and went his own pace but knee OK. Now "weather extremely cold" and obvious now it impossible to keep toes from freezing (water froze at BC) but nontheless up again. 28th all 3 to C1; 29th to C2; 30th to C3 and on 31st to summit. Buhler left C3 at 4:30 am (in 1st 4 hrs frostbitten toes); other 2 at 4:15 am and all climbed together, reached other's C4 on 1st hour and on via Lowe's route to summit; on top at 3:15 pm together; perfect weather with only slight freezing and clear skies; only few minutes on top after Buhler photographed Dainius with Lithunian flag; "it was a hard day" and down with tricky climbing high on mountain down long serated summit ridge an 7 little gendarmes to be gotten around; "took all my concentration" to manage this section "putting my feet right" so as not to fall, which is easy to do. Buhler led descent, very tired and hungry and concentrating hard, feet frozen and Nuru hypothermic and feared he would die; Buhler feared if they stopped, Nuru would loose his balance so in good moonlight and slight wind kept moving, leaving Dainius behind at his own pace; Dainius last seen at 8000m at 5 pm. Buhler and Nuru reached C3 at 8:30 pm with frostbitten feet ("I'm sure Dainius was terribly frostbitten"). Dainius never turned up; Buhler and Nuru totally exhausted and feet frozen but waited till 11:00 am for Dainius and then decided if feet thawed more would be unable to get down and set off at 1 pm and down to C2. 2nd Nov to BC. No sign of Dainius but left tents and food, etc for him. Buhler and Nuru left BC 4th in chopper; no idea what happened to him.

* Nuru to summit of Cho Oyu with Komarkova.
ACCIDENTS: Serious frostbite by Buhler and Nuru (should heal); Dainius Makauska disappeared

SPONSOR: Yak & Yeti Chamonix Expedition to Dhampus
ROUTEMEMO:
BC just below and east of Dhampus Pass.

29th Oct all members started for top from BC at 6:00 am and after 1-1/2 hours Blary and Chambart had headaches and turned back at about 5400m and back to BC accompanied by Dequeker while all others to summit at 12:00 noon. Went along ridge almost its entire length, starting almost at pass; about 1 hr on top with no wind or clouds. Route and top entirely rock and no rope needed to be fixed; returned to BC 2:30 pm and on to lower camp 4500m yak pasture same day. Monzat and Dequeker stayed 2nd night at BC and 30th both to summit at 10:00 am, BC 12:00 noon and on down to Tukuche village with all members same day at 7:00 pm.

"Just a walk" up - not at all difficult technically.
ACCIDENTS: None except altitude sickness of Blary and Chombart (headaches)

ROUTEMEMO:
C2 a little below NE Col
C3 on NE Ridge
C4 on NE Ridge.

From C4 on 5th Oct at 6:30 am to summit, which reached 1:30 pm in weather clear and cold and little wind; not so difficult technically except below C1 where many crevasses. Ridge averages 45 degrees and fixed 500m rope on ridge and Swiss put another 500m on ridge and other teams more in crevasse section. Other 3 members not to summit because not in good health. 5th Oct bid was 2nd one; 1st bid all 5 members and sirdar C4 1-2 Oct, but wind too strong and descended. 5th Oct summiters rested 1 day in C3 and up again.

SPONSOR: Athens Alpine Club Hellenic Expedition to Dhaulagiri I
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to poor health and Sherpa's disaffection
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C2 at NE Col
C3 at start of steep section of NE Ridge
C4 at beginning of summit rocks (end of snow ridge).

12th Oct rested in C4, 13th started for summit and reached 7600m and gave up: Vroutsis with frostbitten fingers and toes (2nd degree) and Lambris coughing and feared pulmonary edema. Down to C3 in early afternoon, just as big 3-day snowstorm began and impossible to move for 3 nights and 2 days (other team's climbers bogged down too). 16th Oct all down and 17th all in BC. Now all members not feeling well and little help from "Sherpas." Sirdar announced he had finished climbing 10th Oct (wanted more money?) and other 2 "Sherpas" also gave up climb and said weather getting worse and time to go home; "it was a mistake." Doctor strong but had to accompany frostbite cases to Kathmandu. Entire team left BC 24th Oct.
ACCIDENTS: Brokos frostbitten toes in C3 but not serious; Vroutsis frostbitten toes and fingers which probably will heal

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to exhaustion, bad weather (snowfall)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site (1st to arrive this season)
C2 near NE Col
C3 on NE Ridge
C4 above NE Spur
High point at C4.

Moved C1 because original site too low. C4 reached on 29th and 30th by 2 members but team very tired because no Sherpas helping them and they were first climbers making route to Col; again to spur with other Spaniards. Japanese, Swiss did some lead climbing, but Swiss also were bankers and sold route to Italian-Czech and Greek teams. "This mountain is for climbing, not for making money - this is not mountaineering." 13th Sept 3 members carried 100m down avalanche but injured (were hit at 6400m).

BC at SW of point 5182m on Dhaulagiri map
C1 on NW Ridge
C2 on NW Ridge.

24th Oct 3 summiters left C2 at 6:00 am and reached top at 2 pm; very deep (waist deep) snow, avalanching and crevasses so must slowly probing for crevasses. Last part to top 70 degrees. Very strong cold wind (-35 at summit). Climbed without full acclimatization because wanted to finish quickly before weather became worse. Very tired during 24th Oct ascent but never thought of turning back ("she is very obstinate"). Kept good appetite. Sherpas very important to her success; without them, not successful.

Leader of Greeks to Cho Oyu in Spring 1991 said there is grave doubt in Greece of her claim of success and she has been expelled from Greek Alpine Club.

C2 at NE Col
C3 on NE Ridge.

From C4 summit party on 6th Oct moved directly to top, not indirectly via ridge to its top as many teams do. 

2nd summit party on 8th Oct (Mon and Visentin) and reached top of ridge at 8100m and turned back by wind. 

Novak and others in C4 on 9th Oct, but not to top because of wind (Japanese got frostbite that day, 9 Oct). 

On 12th Oct new deep snow and avalanching that day.

East Face not attempted: dangerous avalanching after new snowfall.

BC at normal site
C1 near NE Col
C2 on NE Ridge
C3 on a subsidiary ridge to left of main ridge.

Easy climb from C2 to C3; fixed rope because were some small avalanches. Shared rope-fixing job on mountain with other teams.
ACCIDENTS: Dubach and Hirt slight altitude sickness above 7100m and 7400m

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to dangerous conditions and exhaustion
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Annapurna Sanctuary
High point at couloir in variation of Bonington route.

Much soft snow and snow avalanches daily twice in C2 and C3 areas and more frequent rock falls after 9-10 am but climbed mostly in day time. Early one morning tried couloir to left of Bonington route but each of 4 times minor accident. 3 members fell 50-100m in snow avalanche, lost much equipment (1 km fixed rope and depot of other equipment carried away on 2nd Oct). 11-25 Sept snowfall every day after 10 am. Tried Bonington route ice ridge first but soft snow so went left to couloir where avalanches, so again to Bonington ridge but now members very tired. On ridge route reached 450m on Oct 11th. 8 members only above C1. Sherpas only to C3 ("I don't want to die" from danger above C3). 18th Sept ice hit 1 member's plastic helmet and made big hole. Snow avalanche took away 2 tents a C2 on 2 Oct when it was unoccupied.

Want to come again to same route but arrive in Sept for climbing in October.
ACCIDENTS: 4 members fell but returned to climb; 1 member and 1 Sherpa hit by rock ice, avalanche (one Sherpa left team)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to insufficient rope
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C2 on glacial plateau below serac face
High point at serac face.

C3 planned for 6500m but not possible to reach that site. Climbed to 6400m in face of seracs twice. 21 Sept fixed 400m rope to this spot and slept in C2; during that night falling seracs took away rope, pitons, etc. Plateau where C2 pitched received one or two avalanches daily. 22 Sept down to BC. 6 days in BC during bad weather with some snow. 30th Sept good weather and up to C1 by 2 members. 1 Oct up to C2; 2 Oct stayed in C2; 3 Oct again climbed serac face to 6400m saw impossible to go farther: needed 700m fixed rope but didn't have it. Very steep and difficult big seracs. 

"Very nice mountain but very dangerous."

SPONSOR: 1990 Korea Hanorum Alpine Club Annapurna III Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC below point 5076m on KMTN map
C1 just above point 5076m
C2 at snowfield northwest of point 6743m
C3 between crevasses southwest of point 6743m.

1500m rope fixed from BC in very difficult rock climb avoiding icefall and seracs. Many crevasses below C3 and around it. Above C3 very steep ice face to summit ridge (East Ridge). By 11 am had climbed only 1/3 of way to top and leader ordered them to return because they would be too late on summit. Rope to 6700m had already been fixed in previous 2 days but now making more direct route to summit and face too steep to place a camp. 

5th Oct 2nd summit bid began from C3 at midnight. 11:30 am reached East Ridge at 7360m-7370m, summit at 13:18, 14:00 began descent in clear but windy weather and back in C3 18:30. Kim and some Sherpas had made first summit bid also.

Route may be same as Swiss 1980 Autumn.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6440m due to lack of strength of team
ROUTEMEMO:
BC south of Khangsar just below east of rock 
C1 at bottom of spurs running west from NE Ridge.

Avalanche danger from Tarke Kang (1 big one came down), so pitched C1 well to east of it. After 5th Oct put 200m rope up face of N Ridge, then to BC. Deslandres got sick and went to Manang aid post with J Neyret, leaving only 2 climbers. J Neyret returned after 3 days and up to C1 (all 3 climbers) and up onto face to fix more rope and reached 6000m. Then 1 day snowfall. Stayed 1 day in C1 while 30 cm snow fell. Next day 14th Oct to BC to wait out avalanches, 1 day in BC. Deslandres now returned from Manang but not very strong. 17th Oct 4 climbers again to C1. 18th fixed rope to 6100m, 19th rested in C1, 20th fixed rope to 6400m, 21st Deslandres to BC and others rested in C1. 22nd Beatrix and P Neyret left C1 for top but at end of fixed rope P Neyret too tired and cold so he stopped. Beatrix wanted to go on up alone but bag of food fixed on face now fell down face when handled so he down also to C1. Now Beatrix only climber willing to continue but now not interested in solo attempt from C1 (had no Himalayan experience). With no Sherpas and only small team of members were now tired. Face snow and ice 50-60 steepness and difficult.

Note: This team thought they were climbing Glacier Dome, but were actually climbing the 7069m peak east of Glacier Dome (now called Tarke Kang II).


Lower BC 2 hours from water source so moved from C1 to C2 very long (4 hrs) and difficult; many crevasses and dangerous (route on fall and avalanches). C3 to top very long but not so difficult. 

Two summit bids: 8th Sept by Baek, Yoon and Sherpas Sarki and Ang Dawa; Yoon altitude sickness, got very tired; turned back at 6800m. 

10th Sept 2nd bid from C3 by Baek and same Sherpas; started 3:40 am and reached 12:40 pm and down to C3 4:40 pm and C2 6:00 pm. Climbed quickly because had to return to work. 

Lee left KTM yesterday having gone quickly ahead on return march and to studies. Very lucky with weather: heavy snowfall on 11th Sept. Left BC 12th Sept arrived KTM 18th Sept.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to route too difficult without fixed ropes
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  on grass southwest of mountain
Low ABC on grass between moraine on edge of holy lake
C1  at beginning of snow ridge
High point at West Ridge.

Ridge was mixed snow and ice. Nepalis did not go above ABC because Sirdar was sick and descended; others not climbers. Heavy snowfall took much time to reach low BC and to make route higher; ridge is very steep, thus needed a lot of fixed ropes and no time to fix them. 3 who reached high point could have gone higher without fixed ropes but others could not have gone in support and this too risky - "main problem was time."
ACCIDENTS: Sirdar returned to KTM for intestinal surgery

SPONSOR: Okutama Sangaku-kai Nepal Himal Expedition 1990 to Numbur
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at west side of Dudh Kund Glacier near lake at Yuligolcia
C1 at northwest end of glacier
C2 on SW Ridge
C3 on SW Ridge.

13 Oct to BC for rest. 15 Oct up again by Masuda, Saitoh, Pasang Sherpa and Gyalzen Sherpa to C1, 16 Oct to C2, 17th to C3 and 18 Oct to summit at 10:45 am (left C3 6:00 am) and returned to C2 while Chiba and Minegishi to C3 for their own summit success on 19th (left C3 also at 6:00 am and on top 9:15 am) and down to C1 same day. Route not difficult technically but fixed 2500m rope for safety and speed. 

Sugimo left early to return to work.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to heavy snowfall and avalanches
ROUTEMEMO:
C3 above North Col on NW Face of North Peak
High point at C3.

We spent 2 nights in C3 with many avalanches and 3 Oct we go to BC and climb finished. Left BC 6 Oct. Followed normal route and camps at normal sites except C3 which was above big serac and therefore little above normal site. Many avalanches much deep snow with daily snow fall. Fixed only 150m rope in different places.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to fatal fall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC   near gompa at Pungen Glacier
Biv1 at deposit
Biv2 near bergschrund
Biv3 at bottom of rock face
Biv4 at snow ridge
Biv5 in last section of small ridge
Biv6 on glacier.

On 28th Sept made deposit on Pungen Glacier at 4800m or 5000m (had no altimeter and only Manaslu trekking map); only left equipment here. 2 days at BC. 1st Oct went to deposit, slept there and took equipment from it and went up "all 7 climbing members together and remained together." Above 6th biv wanted to climb not a ridge but corner of SE Face-E Face. 3 members climbed part of this rock and reached 7200m from where they fell to death near site of 6th biv. Climb immediately abandoned. 3 bodies buried in crevasse. 8th Oct 4 survivors to BC. Route "not so difficult" first part of face to night of dangerous because many ice avalanches. Had good weather and warm-hot sun from 6:00 am. 3-4 more days to surmount rest of face. "It's a real route." 

Found black rope (Yugo or Czech expedition's?) just above 3rd biv. This only trace of other climbers.
ACCIDENTS: Fatal fall; no altitude sickness, all members had scaled 7000m peaks elsewhere

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to stormy winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC same Korean's southeast of Tilman's Col.

14th heavy snow fall and very windy (from northwest). Started up on 16th from BC and made 1st biv on glacier below Tilman's Col at 5400m. Now trouble with Sherpas who had not brought gear to Col - and reached 5600m on 17th and on 18th at Col. On 19th reached their "hidden" mountain itself and began climbing slope which got steeper in due course becoming SW Ridge; made camp at 6200m (by all 3 climbing members) but northwest winds stormed so fiercely that decided to descend to camp at 6200m camp. Whole night and next day storm continued, so abandoned attempt. Northwest winds from Tibet blast Langtang Ri, which is unprotected.

Had problems reaching BC over glacier and deposited goods 6 hours before BC.

LO died on 18 Oct - was sick and chopper requested. Tourists actually came in and he ran to chopper at Kyanju and collapsed at 3750m. Never was at BC, died of heart attack? Climbers learned of his death on 23 Oct from villagers. Liaison officer's name was Gopal Bahadur KC.

French Langtang Lirung's LO was told expedition Langtang Ri's LO had intense stomach and pain in kidney area: Langtang Lirung's Ms Mathiew, 7 Nov 1990.
ACCIDENTS: None except LO's death and slight general illness of Koechler

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6250m due to Sherpa's death
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on west side of Larkya La (1 hour walk from pass)
C1 directly above (due north of) Larkya La
High point on SE Ridge.

First tried to get into S Face directly but found huge icefall a big as Khumbu Icefall and very active (icefall should have been crossed going to face directly at 19,500 ft, but make no attempt to do so). 28th Oct decided to get to S Face via SE Ridge, which leads onto S Face and made C1 on 28th; 29th Burgess and Dawa Wangchu (Kharte near Kharikhola) went on recce to see if feasible to SE Ridge and decided it was and back to C1. 30th set out for ridge (and summit if possible, but this a "long shot"). Burgess, Golden, Whiteley, Nobles and Dawa Wangchu left C1 at 4:00 am; Nobles turned back after an hour (trouble with crampons and not entirely well) while other 4 continued. At 11:00 am were about 200 ft below SE Ridge and here Whiteley and Golden 300 ft behind Burgess and Dawa Wangchu. Dawa Wangchu was now leading and put in ice stake and Burgess climbed up to him and from there Dawa was to go on up and put in ice stake that would be better anchored. Dawa anchored rope and came down his fixed line and tied on another rope to fixed rope but became disconnected from fixed rope (probably rope broke after he had untied a knot Burgess had put there to tie off a flaw in the rope). Dawa fell 800 vertical feet (1000 ft in distance) but was still alive having ended at bottom of a section of very dangerous ice cliffs landing in deep snow. Burgess reached him in 30 minutes: he had massive head injuries (fractured skull) and bleeding from skull profusely and coughing blood. Burgess stayed with him 3 hrs, got him standing, could see but couldn't speak; tried to pull him down steep snow slope and got him down 60 ft and then Dawa disconnected his harness and took off gloves and turned away from Burgess and lay down signaling Burgess to go. Burgess left him. Now ice and ice cliffs will soon take him all the way down (he probably would have died in next half hour).

Now did not consider any more climbing.

Don't know whether SE Ridge would "go" - couldn't see how steep its sides are.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to lack of rope and time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Tsangbu yak hut at SW end of Langtang Glacier
ABC further up glacier moraine at start of snow
C1  on SE Ridge (space only for 1 small tent for 2 people)
C2  on SE Ridge (at end of difficult rock part)
High point at C2.

Took time to fix ropes in gully to SE Ridge for C1 and also was snowfall and members had stomach trouble. In some parts of gully 1 meter snow (at BC about 30 cm snow). Beginning of difficulties began just above ABC at 5000m; had not realized before that couloir in so steep (55 degrees, not 45 degrees) and required fixed rope for descent. Thus ran out of rope for fixing above C2. In any case ran out of this; fixed about 1000m of rope (some from France, some bought in Langtang and rest old ropes on mountain). Were too slow in couloir and above in difficult rock and ice. Need one week more and perhaps 1-2 more members (technically difficult for Sherpas).

Ridge itself is safe but BC and ABC exposed to avalanches from couloir. After snowfall there was lot of snow moving down couloir but no big avalanches.

Was very cold wind and several members had frostnipped nose and fingers. Above C2 dangerous and difficult to climb in a lot of fresh powdered snow on camp. 5th to 22nd Oct snow conditions were impossible. Winds a problem in last week of climb. Not a problem really with others on route, but not right to give so many permits at price HMG charges.

Was snowing where arrived at mountain and snow coming down W Face so made no attempt on face. C1 tent left at site when down but in final push, took tent (had only one tent) and took it to C2. 18th Oct to BC to rest and up on 21st taking tent from C1 to C2; summit next day.
No problems with other teams; British were very kind and let Swiss use their fixed ropes; on 22nd climbed to top with one German expedition member.

BC at 2 hours above other's BC  - at foot of SW Ridge
Biv 1 at British C1
Biv 2 at British C2.

Had no fixed camps. First, went to S Face from BC to lake due south of face and made depot, while 2 Boleschs climbed to 5700m on face, fixing 300m of rope till noon; now warmth of sun destroyed snow's crust and big danger of avalanches of ice and some rocks. Big ice chunk hit Rainer on arm; all the time small avalanches. Went down to morriane and discussed situation and decided face too dangerous and were too slow climbing to accomplish climb during night time; 60-70 degrees hard rock climbing above and "looks very good" route. Rainer and wife went to British on SW Ridge and asked if could join them and they agreed.

All 4 members returned to BC same day. 2 days rest at BC, then took equipment to C1. Peter got sick (flu) and went down to Pangboche. On 15th Oct other 3 members up to British C2 and Rainer worked hard with Harper to fix mushroom ridge which his wife ferried loads from C1. 18th Rainer and others 2 down to BC, where Peter was now, in stormy weather. 21st all moved up again, Peter to C1 and other three to C2. 22nd Peter to C3 (in slightly different site from British) while other three went for summit. Rainer to summit (last 250m steep rock) while other 2 waited for him below and then all 3 descended. 

Peter remained in C3 but they on down to C1 and one day (22nd). 23rd they to BC while Harper and Jeff and Peter Bolesch up; Peter started at 8:30 am (one hour after 2 British) passed Jeff (who turned back) and reached summit at same time as Harper.

Detail of Summit

22 Oct 1990: Mr Rainer Bolesch (leader - German) started from C2 at 6 am and reached the summit at 12:30 pm; stayed on the summit for 10 minutes, took photographs only and later descended to C1 and stayed overnight.

Note: Mr Rainer Bolesch had accompanied with his wife Eva Maria Bolesch and Joerg Zengerle from C2 towards the summit on 22 Oct but only Rainer Bolesch had managed to reach the summit and the other two members had waited 250m below the summit for Mr Rainer and later three of them came together to C1 and stayed overnight.

23 Oct 1990 - Mr Peter Bolesch started from C3 at 8:30 am and reached the summit at 11 am, stayed on the summit for 1/2 hour and took photographs and later descended to BC which he finally reached at 5 pm.

26 Oct 1990 - Once again Rainer Bolesch along with his wife Eva Maria Bolesch (German Nurse) and the other climber Joerg Zengerle started from C2 at 6 am and three of them managed to reach the summit at 12:30 pm stayed on the summit for 1/2 hour, took photographs only and later descended to C2 which they reached at 2:30 pm.

Note: this was the second time summit for Mr Rainer Bolesch (leader).

27 Oct 1990 - Three members which had stayed on C2 overnight, reached the BC.

28 Oct 1990 - left BC.

01 Nov 1990 - Mr Peter Bolesch and Joerg Zengerle arrive Lukla/KTM.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to snow conditions, lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Mingbo
High point at beginning of great tower.

High point reached at beginning of great tower was too much snow; half meter snow on normally snow-free rock. It was too dangerous and had to leave on 15th Oct. It would take at least 10 days more to have successful climb to mushrooms and early section. Down to BC on 11th Oct cleaning camps in descent.

 3rd Oct - placed C1 but did not occupy it
 6th Oct - occupied C1
 7th Oct - took C1 to 6000m where set it up as C2
 8th Oct - to BC 
10th Oct - to C2
11th Oct - to 6200m and then abandoned attempt
12th Oct - left BC

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to bad snow conditions, lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC above Mingbo
C2 on SW Ridge (normal site)
C3 at Yellow Tower.

Stopped at 6100m because of danger of snow and was still warm weather; had no time to wait for drop in temperature. 10 members and both climbing Sherpas reached C3.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to lateness for safe descent
ROUTEMEMO:
BC above Mingbo (usual site)
C1 on SW Ridge
High point at SW Ridge.

C1 was only fixed camp, rest of climb no tents left anywhere. Climbed as 2 parties with Auble and Townsend in one party, who made summit bid on 12th after climbing continuously from 9th with 2 bivs. On 12th reached 6600m and turned back because did not want to descend with technical difficulties in the dark; made this attempt with Wilson. All three of them down to BC and climb finished.

Had not realized until back in KTM that regulations required them to stop climbing on 15th Nov. Other 2 members reached high point of 6300-6400m (normal C3).

Other members turned back on 24th at 6500m because of strong winds; then Bahadur managed to reach summit and has only very slight frostbite. Much new snow in not good condition made climb difficult and old rope deeply buried.

So many expeditions on same route at same time not good. No place at BC for tents, no place on sharp ridge, have to wait for others to go up and thus for acclimatization too little time.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6890m due to rock striking McCormick
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  near point 5295 on National Geographic map
C1  in middle of 1st icefall
C2  at top of Col on West Ridge
Biv on West Ridge
High point on West Ridge.

From BC climbed along ridge N from Pt 5295, then west to left of Pt 5412 a glacier; then skirted 2nd icefall to bottom of col and up 1000 ft of 70 degrees ice to col and fixed 1000 ft of rope here. Col at 21,300 ft they figured (=6492m - map says 6479m), where finally joined W Ridge and put C2, all 3 members together. On 5th Oct McCormick and Nowak down to base of col for more rope and all met at C1. 7th Oct all rested in C2. 8th all 3 got through 1st rock stop, dug snow cave a 22,500 ft (6860m) and slept there. At 4:00 am 9th got up and left by 6:00 am and were going for summit when Nowak knocked off loose rock in shale steps only a rope length above cave and it arced downwards and hit McCormick who looked around and up from a very protected spot rock smashed his glasses and blood formed behind his eye. Climb immediately aborted, Nowak lowered Van Meter 1st and then McCormick. Reached C2 by 4 pm. To BC on 10th and left BC 11th. McCormick to Lukla in 2 days. McCormick was able to stumble down did not go into shock. Lucky to be alive.
ACCIDENTS: McCormick eye injured by falling rock

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near smaller lake
C1 on SE Face.

3 members and 1 Sherpa to top and Denais stopped 50m from it, very tired. "Condition on mountain very good" but it was very cold.

ROUTE2: S Ridge up; NE Ridge-SE Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC below smaller lake to SE of mountain
C1 atop a rock rib at snow lane on SE Face (normal C2).

Fixed ropes on normal route up SE face with idea of acclimatizing here and then going to South Col and South Ridge and use normal route via NE Ridge and down route they'd fixed. On SE Face was in such good condition were able to pitch C1 on 24th. 25th C1 stocked. 26th Lapkass and Kendall up to sleep in C1 and on 27th 3:00 am started up from C1, fixing rope and climbing went very fast and just carried on to summit via East Col and NE Ridge and descended to BC on same day.

Confident now that climb for clients was quickest and safest way to top. 28th Jennings and Radford to C1 for summit on 29th but had restless night and spent extra day at C1. 29th J Lapkass, Schneider and A Lapkass to C1. 30th 10:05 am Jennings and Radford to C1 for summit on 29th but had restless night and spent extra day at C1. 29th J Lapkass, Schneider and A Lapkass left for top. Schneider stayed in C1. 30th 4 men to top at noon and back to C1 at 5:00 pm, clients exhausted. 31st to BC (Schneider to BC 30th afternoon). 1st and 2nd Nov rest days. 

3rd Nov 00:05 am A Lapkass from BC to S Col and S Ridge, on top at 8:00 am and down normal route to BC at 11:30 am in solo traverse. French and US worked well together.
ACHIEVMENT: Andy Lapkass climbed three times; also made 1st solo traverse and 3rd solo ascent (Nov 3)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near smaller lake
C1 on SE Face on route from larger lake towards S Ridge
C2 on same
C3 on S Ridge
C1 on SE Face.

Two teams (one by South Ridge and the other who didn't like that route when they saw the ridge, went he normal way) climbed simultaneously: 

S Ridge: started on 25th Oct and reached top. 3 Nov Nawang Thile Sherpa and Frachon to top; Coupez, Prouvost and Penneman to max 6700m because of strong wind. Pennenan's fingers badly frostbitten (will lose one finger) and he was evacuated by helicopter. S Ridge too difficult technically for most members.

Normal route (SE Face to NE Ridge): used American's fixed ropes and to top:
2 Nov - Cour, Gadel and Latrubesse
3 Nov - Buisson, Jacq, Jouannet, Chapus & Durazzo and Kami Sherpa
7 Nov - Prouvost and Coupez
ACCIDENTS: Penneman frozen fingers; Gadel slight frostbite on one toe

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at S (bottom) end of big lake and its samll neighbor lake
C1 at S Col of Pumori.

C1 established only on 15th because of heavy snowfall and after Domenech fall "not high morale." Route to C1 was SW side of big lake up face to col on S Ridge. Above C1 followed S Ridge, a little bit on its eastern flank. Moved slowly after C1 because of deep snow. On 24th reached 6400m only in deep snow and returned to BC. 

On 27th (3 members left now - 2 members came to KTM with Domenech, Minguella flew to Spain with him while Josep Castellet stayed in KTM) packed up all gear to to go to KTM but 27th night good weather (before 27th snowed everyday from 10:00 am) so suddenly decided to climb again. 28th morning started up and reached C1 where slept. 29th left C1 at 2:30 am; snow not so deep now (before had to use pail to get rid of very deep snow, now snow below knee). Reached top 1:45 pm by which time was windy and foggy, and returned to C1 about 5:00 pm. 30th to Pheriche.
ACCIDENTS: Domenech fell Sep 6 carrying gear to C1, broke both legs

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at left side of lakes
C1 on SE Face above and west-northwest of lakes
C2 at Col of S Ridge
High point at C2.

Snow above C2 dangerous: big snow mushrooms. 2 nights in C2 for Ishii and Mimura, 1 night for Hashigawa who went down on 18 Oct with altitude sickness and went to BC 18th, Pheriche aid post 19th and recovered there with medication (no oxygen) and Gamov bag.

Ishii comes back to Pumori for solo ascent of same route (no mushrooms if very good weather) in Autumn 1992.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6150m due to dangerous snow conditions and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Lobuje Glacier near small lake
ABC near Kalapattar (east of KP and SW of big lake)
C2  just below Pt 6188m at SE Ridge-S Ridge junction
High point at C2.

Climb halted at C2 because too much snow already and avalanche danger too great and no time to wait for safer snow conditions. So Negri descended 16 Sept and climbing ceased. Team left ABC 17 Sept and BC 18 Sept. Castelnuovo and Spreafico on 15th back to C1 because no room for them at C2 and they "preferred C1."

BC  at left side of big lake
1st C1 at col on S Ridge
2nd C1 on SE Face
C2  on SE Face.

10 days at research laboratory at Lobuje. Then attempted to climb S Ridge from SE via snow field above lake. Reached 6500m and then gave up this route because of deep snow and avalanche 10th Oct. Down to BC. 

Changed route to SE Face. 7 hrs from C2 to summit and return to C2 in very cold strong wind. From C2 at 3:00 am, on top 8:00 am and again in C2 10:00 am and BC 2:00 pm. Difficult climb in C2 area because wind cold.
ACCIDENTS: 3 men some frostbitten toes that will be OK

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  southwest of smaller lake
C1A on SW Ridge's right for ridge
C2A on South Ridge
C1B on SE Face
C2B at col.

After BC established, went in pairs to climb smaller peaks (no permits) and then back to BC about 12 Oct. Perkins made C1 on 24th at about 6000m on SE Face, 25th to col and made C2 at 6400m and to top along NE Ridge next day. 

Woolridge and Cox did nice route on NE Face of Mehra and also climbed Island Peak and Polkalde, but Cox did not set foot on Pumori and Woolridge had bad night at South Ridge C1 from altitude sickness. Gibson also only to C1 on Ridge route and enthusiasm marred. Avalanche left debris around normal route's C2 but did not damage.

"Splintered" expedition of pairs of climbers.
ACCIDENTS: Perkins slight frostbite; Woolridge altitide sickness

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at south end of small lake below big lake
C1 north of big lake.

After arrived at BC, stayed there 10 days to acclimatize and on 27 Sept began on route above. On 26th slept in C1, 29th to summit and back to C1. Started from C1 at 3:00 am, on top at 1:45 pm, very windy so down after 30 minutes return to C1 at 5:00 pm. From C1 climbed SE Face to Col on NE Ridge and along ridge to summit. "A little difficult snow" below C1 and fixed 600m rope to C1 (this only rope they fixed).

OTHERSMTS: Climbed Island Peak and Parchamo (20m of top)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Lobuje village
ABC at point 5529m on National Geographic map, just east of larger lake.

12th Nov 7 am started climb with biv gear; up series of ridges to col 6576m on NE Ridge, where arrived at 11:00 am, left gear and ate and on to summit at 2:15 pm; 4:15 pm back in C1 (on top 10 mins in very strong wind). Perfect snow conditions. Had been with friends on Island Peak which he climbed to top in 3 hrs, after ascent of Pachermo to 20m below summit.

Had no permission for Pumori.

SPONSOR: DAV Summit Club Expedition to Pumori
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near smaller lake
C2 at shoulder of SE Spur.

C2 had to be a bit low for safety from avalanches so some older and less experienced members could not get to top. Not enough rope available for C3 on col (they would have need this rope in area of crevasses on steep section where upper lip is several meters higher than lower lip).

1st summit started from C2 at 7:00 am (very cold night and 1st on top was Hoelzler at 1:00 pm and Zintls about 2:00 pm. 

2nd summit party started as 5 members and 3 turned back at col (6580m), 2 with very cold feet and 1 was too slow to reach top and return in daylight. Remaining two Donner and Staiger reached top. 

13th both Klinks tried for top from C2 but could not go above col. Team left BC 16th.
ACCIDENTS: 2 members got slightly frostbitten toes; Moenig also ill (chest)

ROUTE1: SW Face up; W Face-W Ridge down
OTHERSMTS: Climbed Xixabangma (middle summit) on 3 Oct by 2 Swiss at 10 am, by Polish at 6 pm via South Face
ROUTEMEMO:
After arrival at expedition's BC, acclimatization climb to 7000m done by all 3 men on normal route (to C2) and then to expedition's BC on 8 Sept. Started up only on 19th having waited for snowfall to stop; started on 19th at 11:00 am and at 2:00 pm were base of face where had rest & meal. At 6:00 pm started up (at sunset/dusk) had personal biv sack and half of a thin mattress, 1 gas stove and 1 gas cartridge; each had candy bars, nuts and mineral drink powder; cache was down-type suits but took no sleeping bags; 2 ice axes each, crampons; 2 30m rope X 7mm; 10 pitons and 4 ice screws ("upper part looked more difficult route than normal route, no crampons" - Kurtyka) but actually used only 1 or 2 pitons and no screws; up the face, which was reached at 7:00 pm, via a couloir which is about 1000m high & covered in snow and acting as a shute, requiring climber to move a meter or so to right or left; top of couloir started to get much steeper and became mixed rock and snow; at 7500m, 3/4 of way up face, stopped to heat water and rested an hour. 

On 20th from 10:00 am to 4:30 pm on face; at 4:30 pm reached SE Ridge and on SW Ridge they took 2 hrs to gain 20 vertical meters (mixed rock and snow with some snowfield in poor snow which was very deep and loose); at 7:30 pm stopped at small flat place 50 vertical meters below true summit where cold (too small to lie down). Stayed 12 hrs at this spot at 8150m because Voytek needed to sleep and difficult for him to go non-stop without food, water and sleep in his first experience of this kind of climb (says Swiss). 

Next day, 21st, to top at 8:30am in not very cold, clear morning with no wind; stayed 1/2 hr on top and then started down. Came straight down to C2 via direct variation of normal route others on mountain at this time were following. At C2 Hungarian presented 1 tin of beer and congrats. At expedition's BC at 5:00 pm after visiting other's camps enroute; waited for yaks to arrive and left expedition BC 26th and 27th to Nyean.

Most difficult part: steep snow and rock just above couloir, also 20 vertical m; total of 4 sections of 20-30m that were technically difficult.
 
Fixed no rope: used rope and pitons only for belays - had taken 2 ropes in case of rapelling.

Would not recommend route for anyone who cannot do quick ascent; if snowfall would be dangerous avalanching.

How they could succeed when others on normal route failed? "You have to have the mental push" says Troillet.
ACCIDENTS: Troillet serious pulmonary edema on Aug 30 down to Zangmu hospital

SPONSOR: Al Filo de la Impossible to Cho Oyu & Xixabangma
ROUTEMEMO:
Chinese BC at normal site.

13 Oct to 6200m and slept there but down on 14th with new snowfalling. 17 Oct again up and biv at normal C2 site. Tamayo found temperatures too cold for him and went down 19th while others up to top and to BC same day; cold winds were problem.

2 members only few days in ABC and then to Lhasa and returned to Chinese BC on 22nd and climbing members to BC on 23rd.
ACCIDENTS: Some frostbite by 3 members which will heal

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to lack of experience, not eating well
ROUTEMEMO: After C1 down to BC for logistical preparation, 20 Sept to C1 but in the night Mich had serious tooth problem in bad night for all, so on 21 Sept he went down and other 3 made for C2 and sleep there and then down in bad weather (fog and little snow and little wind) to ABC. Mich's tooth infected and he had to leave for treatment; other 3 in ABC 8 days because of bad weather; no movement on mountain by anyone and Italian Lenti group went home. 29th 3 members from ABC to C2; 30th after not good night start for C3 but do not make C3, biv at 7550m near C3 site; others spend night strong wind and very cold. 1st Oct again up in summit bid in crusted snow; at 7800m wind gaining strength and little cold, 1 member not so well, other's toes beginning to freeze, so go down to ABC at night, very tired. After 1 day Stedile decides finished for him and he goes to order yaks while othe 2 go up to clear higher camps. Men tired and experiment with synthetic diet unsuccessful (couldn't keep this food in stomachs).

ROUTE1: W Ridge-W Face from N (Tichy var)
SPONSOR: Italian-French Expedition Allibert to Cho Oyu
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
Between 8 and 17 Sept much snowfall; had to make more direct than Tichy route above C2 because normal route was too dangerous; above C3 big couloir with great snow avalanche danger and climb above not possible. Four French members have stayed on only to bring down camps but not to try for summit. C3 reached only once, on 17th Sept for 1 night only.

Larry of French group and Mich of Piazza group returned to KTM on 27th Sept with all of Lenti's Italian and Spanish members.

After Lenti group left, went up to C1 and tried to get to C2 but everyday snow fell; reached just below C2 and Sherpas never reached C3 to clean it. French left ABC 29 Sept.

BC at correct site of Kangchung
C1 on rocks below Spanish 1984 C2
C2 near 1984 at C4.

Reached C1 via Nangpa La and followed Spanish 1984 Autumn route to C3 and from there more direct route to summit tried by others this autumn. 3 members and Ang Phurba left C3 at 6:30 am and arrived at top 1:30 to 1:45 pm (reached true summit after going long distance to reach it); route "long but easy"; windy days in Oct had blown Sept snow away.

Ang Phurba to Everest top with 1985 Spring and 3 nations Spring 1988.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to client's decision to quit
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at last yak huts Lunag, below Kangchung
C1 across Nangpa La
High point at Gyabrag Glacier.

23 Oct Hunziker tired and hungry on beautiful day and said he would not return over this glacier again; so climb finished with having done no more than high-altitude trek to point east of Pt 6600m on eastern side of glacier. Hunziker and Edenhofer were clients of Joos. Edenhofer had not planned to go above BC. Joos made no attempt to climb alone because of his responsibilities as client's guide.

BC at same as Catalans this autumn
C2 at same as Catalans.

Reached summit from C2. On 6th left C2 at 2:00 am and on true top at 12:00 noon and back to C2 4:30 pm. On 8th started at 3:00 am, on top 2:00 pm and back to C2 7:00 pm in dark. Had no headlamps; bright moonlight on ascent.

Made no attempt to climb SW Ridge.
ACCIDENTS: Sherpa sick (coughing blood, so weak in summit bid and turned back at 7500m)

SPONSOR: Ask Tours & Visotnik Cho Oyu 1990 Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7850m due to weather and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near Gyazumpa
C1 at small plateau south point 6500m at bottom of its ridges
C2 at point 6500m's on SW Ridge
C3 at icefall above point 6500m
C4 at saddle just N of "U" of Gosum on Schneider map
C5 at flat saddle on SW ridge just east of 7600m peak ridge
High point at SW ridge.

Difficulties began from C2 (between below C2 had fixed ropes), very steep snow and rock and point 6500 and dangerous and all fixed rope C2 and C3. Very strong winds above C3 from Tibet constantly. Above C5 tried to keep to SE Ridge on northern side of ridge to snowfield where ridge got very steep to go up couloir (or perhaps to go up on Tibetan side to another snow couloir). On 13th reached snowfield and spent night in small tent with no ground sheet. Had been unable to see way above. Next day clouds and winds worse and worse and temperature dropped, becoming extremely cold so retreated to C4 and abandoned climb with such terrible weather. Fixed total of 2500m rope, mostly from C2 to C3 and some (200m) from C4 to C5 to cross the ridge. 

Route is possible with more time (including better phase of moon affecting weather). Left variant on to Tibetan side is easier than variant to right side.

3rd Oct, 1st summit bid stopped 8000m by strong wind. 4th Oct, 3 members to summit from C2, Wlasich and others from C3; Austrian left C2 6:00 am Chinese time and other 3 left 10:00 am with Austrian; reached true top at 6:00 pm and down to C3 and C2 (Hungarian 2 had been in Chinese BC when C3 established).

7th Oct party left C3 at 9:30 am and on top 15:00-15:30 hrs and down to C2 to leave space in C3 for next summiters; they were 6 Hungarians, but Nagy turned back because frostbite developing.

Last group left C3 9:30 am, on top 17:00 hrs and down to C3 (Szendro arrived at C3 at 21:30 hrs in slow descent in strong wind and with artificial leg from teenage accident). 

10th Oct 3 members tried for top, but stormy and very cold and reached only 7600m.
ACCIDENTS: Koncz snowblinded on final descent day; Nagy slight frostbite

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at yak huts Sanshochopo under East Face near small lake
C1 at top of rock pillar, SE Pillar.

Did new route on SE Pillar's face to SE Ridge. Some really difficult steep rock climbing in last pitch on pillar. Before getting onto pillar had to fix 200-300m to traverse pinnacles to save time when proceeding to climb pillar; fixed no rope on pillar. Pinnacles began at 5300m and pillar also began at 5300m. Biv on 25 Oct by 4 members. On 26 Oct all to summit up SE Ridge: one step at start of SE Ridge found old ropes and here joined other people's route (this step in at top a couloir leading to SE Ridge. Started climb on 26th at 8:00 am and on top at 1:40 pm via not very difficult ridge (4 pitches of ice climbing but good snow and ice conditions on 50-60-degree slope and fixed no rope here. Only 2 on summit while other 2 lost time on rock step, were 1 hour behind summiters and stopped ascent at about 6300m. Summiters back in C1 at 4:00 pm and all slept that night at C1. 27th 3 down pillar and Fuetterer stayed in camp and on 28th tried again for summit. Fuetterer reached about 6350m in snow pitches and down to BC same day.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due dangerous snow conditions and route difficulty
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at bottom of East Face beside glacier (just north of point 5110m on Schneider map).

Too much snow on very technical climb, very steep. 14 Oct 10 cm snow at Pheriche. 15th teams split in 2 parties to determine whether East Face or North Face better. 1st 200m above BC 200m of artificial climbing. Next 2 days spent trying to surmount tower but impossible and too dangerous to progress with prevailing snow conditions. Snow sticking to rock slabs. 21 Oct 4 climbers went up with supplies for 10 days to top but after 2 days very hard climbing gave up, Gicquel believes (he left BC 23rd).

Team wanted to change route but liaison officer refused.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 50m above USSR BC on west side of Lhotse Glacier
C2 at series of bivouacs
High point at 2 points on South Face.

1st attempt of couloir and to left; stopped at 7600m; 2nd went right and much wind so extreme right to Kukuczka C5. Had wanted to acclimatize on Lhotse Shar to 6800m once or twice but Spaniards did not agree (why don't understand) so climbed on Polish route but one day big wind slab came down when were at 6200m. Were well acclimatized when started up own route (Polish route very dangerous from avalanche).

1st attempt on own route began on 6 Oct from BC; reached 5800m for 1st biv (too dangerous to go up couloir in day time so slept here all day - had arrived at 9:00 am). 8:00 pm of 6th started up again and climbed couloir all night in good moonlight and stopped at top of gully at 8:00 am of 7th. This place very dangerous because with sunshine stone fall began - were hit by stones but not seriouly hurt; pitched tent and stayed one day there before attempting difficult rock and ice, made better places for tent. 8 Oct at 11:00 pm again up (ice made better places for tent). 8th Oct at 11:00 pm again up (ice soft in day so impossible because of difficulty) and arrived at Russian fixed ropes and reached 7600m at 8:00 am where pitched tent 20 minutes below Russian C5. Slept one night at this biv and 10 Oct decided not to use Russian fixed rope since not alpine-style to do so and also winds strong so decided to go down; also now discovered a possible new route to right. Descended to BC on 10th in 5 hours by Russian ropes with plan to abandon route to left. 16th Oct began up again and reached 5800m biv place and 17th to a new 2nd biv at slightly different site on right at 7200m onto face at noon. From here began difficult rock and mixed at "extremely difficulty." 18th climbed long day and surmounted all the difficulties but wind became strong; biv at 7400m at 8:00 pm. 19th wind "terrible" which pushed powdered snow avalanche upwards so went quickly to Kukuczka C5 looking for protection and biv there at 7600m under rock. 20th am stove broken and dangerous to use and wind "impossible" and decided to go down via Kukucza route; started at 12:00 noon and at 6500m at 5:30 pm [biv] in good crevasse. 21st to BC.

Both went to return to face in '91 or '92.

SPONSOR: Mataro Expedition to Himalaya - Lhotse Shar
ROUTEMEMO:
BC east of Island Peak's point 5357 on National Geographic map.

Badiola and Valles made bivouac at 7900m and on 7th Oct as planned during climb; no C5 because with no Sherpas. Spanish members had worked hard and some not well acclimatized. 3000m rope fixed from C1 to C4 up difficult route. C2, C3 and C4 were snow caves because of strong winds; lots of snow ridge with windslabs, which they carefully avoided. Reached top at 11:00 am in clear day in strong wind (which caused Soviets on Lhotse S Face to freeze feet during biv without tent). Spanish bivouacked in small tent, which was blown into Tibet with sleeping bags, etc.; only 1 pole left of biv. Summiters went down to C4 in snow cave; Valles no frostbite, but Badiola slightly frostbitten toes. Last 5m to top 90 degrees ice and very technical climbing and necessary to rapell down this section; top had big cornices.

Macia turned back at 7500m on 6th Oct because not well acclimatized. Had been climbing on 6th with Valles and Badiola. She was only other member to go above C4.
ACCIDENTS: Only 2 members have frostbitten toes which will heal

ROUTEMEMO:
Route actually climbed was essentially same as planned route with variations no more than 50m to right or left. Most important variation was between C5 and C6 because falling rock and ice pieces on planned route and poor belays and where as to left of plan steeper but safer and good belay; difficulties: 150m below C1 and technical route from C4 all the way to summit; a vertical rock with avalanches of snow and ice and rock. Above C4 problems were loose rock, technical difficulties, ice covering on rocks made belays difficult and fierce winds began on 13th Oct. Fixed total of 4 km of rope. Had planned one group to climb in alpine-style but on arrival saw could not do so on their route with prevailing snow ice conditions and some did climbing via couloir. This way but could not get above 7600m because of danger from poor belays and falling things.

On 11th Oct snow cave made by and occupied by 4 members. Very cold and windy hence no tents but cave. Fixed ropes above C6 (to 7900m only). Had to fix ropes above cave and 13th Oct all 4 men tried to reach summit and went above 4 fixed ropes but too windy and frosty and big mushrooms overhangs which made belay difficult (some fell 20m with snow but not hurt) so turned back just near summit. Only 4-5 ropes below top) at 8460m. On 13th Oct 3 members arrived at snowcave and 7 slept there. 14th first group very tired from climb of 13th without oxygen and a member (head cold) down only 150m and put tent there for night because visability nil on most difficult part of route and no fixed ropes here (doctor got bad frostbite) and 15th on down to C3 and 16th to C1 after reaching fixed ropes. 14th 2 members remained in cave; from cave not possible to follow others route and on 15th 2 members reached for better route: traversed to couloir and up a little (2 ropes) and back to cave, knowing couloir would go. 16th Oct Karataev and Bershov at first thought they would descend W Face but were informed by BC no one there. Left cave at 8:30 am (waited for sun, befelled by no oxygen and under estimated distance of summit). Took 2 ropes and 1 bottle of oxygen for later use - took much time to reach ledge (rock covered by snow on last 20 minutes below ledge and then hard rock) which got to 4:00 pm Karataev sick with flu, moved slowly and joined Bershov only at 5:15 pm 30-40m below summit. Had used oxygen on hard rock in morning for 3 hours. Finally on top about 6:00 pm together, stayed few minutes in strong wind with gusts from different directions.

When descending felt he was a bed sheet on clothes line; Karataev now got pneumonia and frostbite (lost his glove and took moment to put on another one). One returned to cave at 2:45 am and other at 4:45 am and had to wait radio on stove just turned off so as to report safe arrival. First made liquids to drink (spent some hours), other slept till evening. Began descent 18th morning and reached small cave and met by Turkevich and others who helped them in descent. Turkevich could have gone to summit but turned back to help Karataev and Bershov. A member and Turkevich were strongest of team and did very hard work making route. On 18th descended only to point previous men, made cave there at 8150m. 19th to C4 and 20th one member to C1 and other 3 members to C4 only.

1st summit bid by Turkevich on 7th Oct with 3 members (to C4 also and a member who got pneumonia and down) who went to nearly to snow cave. Started from C4 without tent and other biv equipment; no fixed rope; reached difficult section and found good route; got to 8150m; spent night of 7th in small cave; on 8th could not reach C4 and group from that camp went up and made temporary camp for them all.

Cesen: his reputation very good, but why he came down S Face difficulties? Beghin and Profit could climb only 1 km/day.
ACCIDENTS: Members pneumonia; several frostbite cases with 2 serious

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7050m due to fierce winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Tangnag, south of Barun Glacier
C1 at top of small mountain south of Makalu 
C2 at SE Buttress
High point at SE Buttress.

Fujita got altitude sickness night they arrived at BC and had to be evacuated by helicopter to KTM. Returned to BC 8 Oct, after Shimakata and Sherpa had made C1 and C2. Now winds became very strong for a week, lessened for few days and again period of strong wind. Shimataka to BC 10 Oct. 15 Oct both members and Sherpas up to C1 and reached 6600m on 16th and driven back to C1 by wind. At C1 3 days and down to BC but this time tent at C1 broken by wind. 22 Oct again up by all climbers to C1 and stayed there 18 days. Above C1 route exposed to wind, which even blew away fixed rope on this section. Down to BC 9 Nov; had abandoned idea of reaching main summit but hoped for SE Summit on 12 Nov. When Fujita and Moti Lal could get only to 7050m on 8th, then gave up all attempt to climb.

Would like to try this very good route in true alpine-style, 2 members with no Sherpas or fixed camps.
ACCIDENTS: Fujita pulmonary edema; 1 Gurung slightly frostbitten fingers

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at northwest corner of lake 5448m on National Geographic map
C1 at West Col.

From C1 went to see what fixed rope needed and continued on to summit. Found Swiss Expedition's steps just below last difficult section. Had lot of sickness amongst Nepalese staff with 1 Sherpa and cook and porters sick; porter (Aurobinda Kubir Rai) died near Amphu Laptsa and sirdar had to go down to him (death from illness not exactly known perhaps altitude). 3 members also on medications for 5 days and never above BC.

2 Swiss members were sirdar's friends who spoke with Aubert by phone in Europe but whom French had never met until just before Mera La on approach march.

Porter who died was named Aurobinda Kubir Rai.
ACCIDENTS: None at mountain; 1 porter died of illness (AMS?) on approach

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7900m due to fierce winds and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal high BC site
Deposit ABC at start of glacier
C2 at Makalu La - 3 tents
C3 at same as Catalan - 1 tent on NW Ridge on right side of Messner route
High point at C3.

At first wanted to follow Catalan route but too dangerous and went to Makalu La. From C1 to C2 1000m fixed rope. Tried three times to go high: once only to C3, other times not above Makalu La and 3 times camps destroyed by wind. Last time was on 13th; 14th down. Not so much snow but big problem was with the wind.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7900m due to high winds and exhaustion
ROUTEMEMO:
BC same as French this autumn
C3 100m below (on Tibetan side) of NW Ridge
High point at NW Ridge.

Followed normal route to normal C2 then took line safer from avalanches. After making his own C2, went down to rest at BC. Left BC up again on 19th Sept to C1; 20th to C2 and C1 on 21st (had carried load to C2) and 22nd down to BC for more supplies and 2-day rest. Then bad weather (snowfall) 25th and 26th so 4 days at BC. 27th to C1 and 28th to C2. 29th up to make C3 at 7800m on the ridge and on up to see which was best line to take ("I wanted to find a good way"), but Kukuczka route very steep rock and ice mixed. Stopped at 7900m, descended to C2 (left C3 in place). 30th down to BC for rest. 1-3 Oct at BC. 4th Oct up to C1; 5th to C2; 6th to Makalu La (normal C3) and slept French tent (day very windy and could not climb higher). 7th Oct returned to his own C1 and 8th to BC. 12th Oct to C1, 13th to C2. 14th morning big storm of new snow and old snow in strong wind and C2 tent destroyed by wind and so down ("of course"). Now bad weather with fierce wind and C2 tent destroyed and he was "very tired." 

Were many people on route from BC to C1 and he climbed this very easy ropeless section with them. From La to C3 with French on 7th. Used no fixed rope - "I want to try again by Messner Couloir" to La.

C1 tent broken into by black birds and 2 weeks food taken in mid-Sept.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6900m due to dangerous snow condditions and avalanche danger
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at left side of Baruntse Glacier east of point 6035m on Schneider map
C1 below East Col (slept in this camp 2nd Oct)
C2 half way between West Col and summit on map.

5 Oct in 1st summit bid made trail in deep snow to 6770m and back to C2. 6th Oct went for summit but had to turn back at 6900m because could not climb along ridge and Hinku South Face snow too soft which made impossible to put in security.

BC just out of southeast end of Hunku Tang Glacier
Deposit south of big lake Chamlang Tso.

North Pillar not possible to climb because it rises from big lake. Made deposit camp 8th Oct and then through Mera La and climbed Mera Peak for acclimatization. Reached its summit on 11th Oct. 12th to Chamlang BC and 14th Ottl and Weisner left BC (these members had not gone to Mera Peak) because of altitude sickness while other 4 stayed at BC with 30 cm fresh snow falling. 15th Oct 4 to deposit camp and 16th onto NNW Face to 5900m and back to BC after finding snow too deep. 17th Oct rested at BC and all 4 18th climbed to deposit camp (or C1). 19th 2 men climbed NNW face to 6200m to C2 where left big tent and on 20th went to C3 at 6600m at ridge. From here believe they joined Japanese route to summit on W Face. 21st 2 men to summit at around 10:00 am and down to C2. Next day all 4 in BC. 

Slight difficulty on 50-55 degrees ice (some 70 degrees) but nothing serious and used 2 ropes only for rapelling down. Women were load carriers for their men; not enough time for them to climb since Mera Peak finished later than planned because of snowfall and 2 members had left. Left BC 23rd Oct and returned via Amphu Laptsa to Khumbu.
ACCIDENTS: 1 member slight frostbite; women 3 days high fever; 2 members altitude sickness

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC   at Barun Glacier's east side around from normal high BC
C1   at Chago Glacier where it gets steep
Biv1 at Chago Glacier steep section
Biv2 at Chago Glacier before entering Messner couloir
Biv3 at Makalu La (high point).

From C1 started alpine-style climb (but Sherpas made deposits). Had 3 bivouacs above C1. Spent Oct 3rd to 15th at C1 acclimatizing with brief rest at BC for 2 days. 

Expedition divided into separate climbing groups led by Vadasz and Ritchie. Vadasz group had 7 members at start (Burch, Farkas, Jonelis, Riggs, Schapera, Vadasz, Mrs Vadasz) but Jonelis went home and Farkas transferred to Ritchie group.

Vadasz group made three bivouacs at 6650m, 6980m and 7400m. High winds stopped group on Oct 18 at 7400m. Oct 18th instead of going for summit when down at 1 pm when winds did not drop from 60 mph (with gusts up to 100 mph) and then went down to C1 to watch winds. When winds did not decrease but increased decided to stop. In BC waited even longer and watched winds.

Ritchie group got no higher than 23,000 ft (7000m) in couloir on 16th Oct and turned around because of wind, logistical problems and lack of strength. This party had 1 of the 3 Sherpas with them. They made own fixed C1 and C2 (their camps at same altitudes as Vadasz's group bivs) moving a day behind. 

Both groups left BC on 25th Oct. LO refused to allow expedition to trek out over the cols (Sherpani Col, West Col and Amphu Laptsa to Khumbu) since this was not in the plan.
ACCIDENTS: Jonelis and Stevens had viral infections and left early

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to loss of equipment in storm
ROUTEMEMO:
BC just SE of Barun Pokhari
High point on SE Ridge.

Avalanche on night of 27-8th Sept took 1 tent 50m down and other tent disappeared and C2 and at C3 wind and snowfall broke both tents and buried them in snow. No climbers injured although all tents occupied. This finished climb; much equipment lost. 

From C3 to C4 "a little difficult" in strong wind. At C3 every day strong wind and snow often. Members and Sherpas made C2 and C3 together, but C4 pitched by Nepalese only; fixed 3400m rope to C4.
ACCIDENTS: 1 Sherpa slight frostbite and returned to KTM; Miss Kim altitude sickness

ROUTE1: Kukuczka Rib direct to NW Ridge
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at glacier SE of point 6130m.

7 members left BC Sept 27 because their time ran out. Rest of team rested in BC to Sept 29, when 5 members and 4 Sherpas left BC to make another summit bid. Sept 30 to C1, Oct 1 to C2 (2 Sherpas down to C1). Oct 2 C3 made by 3 members and 2 Sherpas. Oct 3 Zamora Barra noticed feet freezing and stayed in C3 with 1 Sherpa while other 2 Spaniards and Lhakpa Sherpa went for top starting at 3:30 am in deep snow. Climbing last couloir's 150m took more than 5 hrs in chest-deep snow; arrived on summit at 4:10 pm climbing final sharp snow ridge 20m (strode ridge like riding a house); back to C3 6:30 pm and slept there. Oct 4 all 5 men reached BC. Oct 11 2 members to KTM by helicopter and quickly to Spain and hospital where Bros stayed few days and Zamora one or 2 months; others left BC 7th Oct.

This 1st 8000m summit for Lhakpa Sherpa.

1st summit attempt was on Sept 17.


Prunes - 5 Oct 1990

Returned KTM early Oct (3 & 4 Oct) because 4 had to go back to work and 2 had wives trekking in Nepal. French member never reached BC because of news from family at home.

BC  26 Aug 5900m
ABC 29 Aug just under 7000m
C1   5 Sept 

9 Sept reached ridge at 7500m. Intended set a camp at 7600m but then bad weather and summit attack team wanted a higher camp. 16 Sept C2 7800m just below North Face couloir. 17 Sept 1st attack from C2 at 2 am by Angles Soler, Capdevilla and Sorolla Oliva. Weather too bad; snow deep to waist and could see nothing; at 10 am had climbed up couloir and reached 8050m; 3 pm reached foot of last wall at 8240m and snow to chest and they returned to C2; next day 18th all in BC.

2 more summit bids prepared by 7 members and 3 Sherpas. 1st group to C2 on 23 Sept and on 24th took 2 hours to more 100m traverse in chest-deep snow and 2 avalanches so retreated. 2nd group never reached C2 because all again to BC.

27th 6 members left BC. Others hoped to make attempt in early Oct.
ACCIDENTS: Zamora serious frostbitten feet; Bros slight frostbitten nose and toes

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8350m due to strong winds, deep snow and fatigue
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
High point at SW Face.

23rd Sept started climb but every 2 days snowfall and avalanches; 12th Oct tried for top; Park and 2 Sherpas left C4 at 5:00 am and at 7800m Gombu Sherpa toes frozen and turned back. Park and Pasang Gombu Sherpa reached 8350m at 3:30 pm and turned back because of wind and fatigue. 2 to 2-1/2 hrs more to top (had headlamps). No C5 because weather report was for snow 13th Oct and snow did came and destroyed all 4 tents at C2. Park returned to BC 14th Oct, others up but snow very deep and took 2 days to C1. 18th Oct others had problems with deep snow on 19th and wind: found C2 buried and retreated. Left BC 24th Oct after clearing C1 and some gear at C2.
ACCIDENTS: Gombu Sherpa big toe frostbitten; Pasang Gombu frozen finger

ROUTEMEMO:
1st C3 on Pillar
2nd C3 on Lhotse Shar
C4  at South Col
High point at via S Pillar.

On S Pillar, put C3 at 7100m on 12th Sept and during following 7 days fixed ropes to 7700m slightly to right of pillar. In this period 2 Sherpas hit by powdered avalanche and was left dangling on ropes and another was hit in ribs by falling block of ice (but resumed climb later on and reached col (Ang Rita from Thami, but not THE Ang Rita). On 19th avalanche covered the ropes, which could be pulled out, but the 5 clients were getting apprehensive about going up those lines so route changed to S Col (LO gave permission before ministry agreed).

US team claims that Batard team made extensive use of US C4 equipment without permission. Batard left quickly with others while Karl Huyberechts and Annie Dubois left without food at BC; US team fed them. US changed to S Col route by moving gear from pillar C3 directly across to Lhotse Face where pitched another C3 at 7400m (members traversed across, Sherpas down to Cwm and up). Col reached on 28th Sept and on 29th summit bid by Lowe and Culver reached only 100m above Col; Col now this morning abandoned by team because of strong winds. 30th Sept all to BC because of wind even at C2 and some snowfall. 

On 2nd Oct Nelson with a US Sherpa, Lowe and Culver at C4 to make summit bid but had pulmonary edema on arrival and down sick.

On 4th Lowe, Culver and Salino of De La Ferriere expedition left C4 together at 9:00 am when wind stopped suddenly. Lowe pulled ahead of others and reached top about 1-1/2 hours ahead of them. [Lowe summited at 12:30 pm and Culver at 2 pm.]

Lowe reported tricky climbing beyond S Summit so Aprin and Ang Temba took ropes and left Col with De Camp and his 2 Sherpas from Batard expedition 5th Oct at 3:45 am; Aprin fixed ropes below S Summit and Hillary step. French Sherpas and Ang Temba on top 10:30 am, Aprin 10:40 am and De Camp 11:45 am. Aprin and Ang Temba to C2 same day.

On 7th Oct next summit bid from Col: Lowe and Fuller left Col later than successful climbers and turned back (Lowe not on oxygen to 8100m only, Fuller to 8350-8400m and down because felt lonely, unable to catch up with others). Gibson, Krasnokutsky and Pinzo Sherpa left Col at 5:30 am and were on summit at 2:30 pm, used fixed ropes and moving cautiously with Pinzo carrying extra oxygen for Gibson; she had total of 3 bottles available. Pinzo reaching summit at 12:30 pm? All summiters down to C4 and Lowe and Fuller to C2. Gibson and husband to C2 on 8th and BC 9th Oct. 

Sherpas up on 9th to C2 and some to C4 on 10th to clear camps. All off mountain on 10th evening and 5 members left BC 11th (others had left on 8th and 9th).
ACCIDENTS: Nelson pulmonary edema; Williams cerebral edema

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7770m due to bad weather and team exhausted
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Bonington route.
 
3 members and a Sherpa spent 2 nights in C4 and down on 13th Oct because of wind. Then in BC snow coming and men tired.

3 members to C3 and C4 only; other members not above C2.

C2  in Western Cwm
1st C3 at top of West Shoulder
2nd C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at S Col.
 
21st Sept from Cwm climbed directly to top of shoulder, not in curving line of US 1963; did not go above C3 because several days snowfall brought half-meter fresh snow; strong wind followed and feared danger of avalanches and wind in Hornbein Couloir and also now realized team not strong enough.

27th Sept changed route to normal route and 1 member slept at Col on 30th Sept hoping to go to summit next day but wind too strong and all down to BC. 5th Oct up to C2 (3 members and 3 Sherpas). 6th Oct from C2 to Col; 1 Sherpa went back, 1 Sherpa at Col in support and 1 Sherpa to top next day with the 3 members; at 4:00 am Stremfeljs, Jeglic and Lhakpa Rita (his 1st high summit) start up. 1:10 pm Mariya and Andrej Stremfelj summit; 1:35 pm Janez Jeglic on top; all down to C3 at 7:00 pm (Lhakpa Rita on down to C2). 

7th Oct Mazzoleni and Arjun Tamang arrived at Col in evening and 8th reached 8100m (Tamang) and South Summit (Mazzoleni) and turned back because strong wind; no more attempts for top although one Sherpa to C4 to bring down tent on 9th or 10th, but winds so strong he could not pack it.

BC 15 to 17th Oct by most of team (10 members). Sterni felt (or feared?) recurrence of problem with vertebrae broken last year and left BC 24th Sept, At same time 2 others left: Dr Infanti had to return to work and Petronio found mountain too big.

Mrs. Stremfelj: remarkable that after so many years, Everest climbed on same day by two married couples.

Jamnik 26 Oct: no attempt was made to reach Lhotse summit; "When they finished with Everest, that was finish."
ACCIDENTS: Jamnik ill in Kathmandu; Sterni suffered recurrence of last year's vertebrae problem

ROUTEMEMO:
C1 same as Nepalese army expedition Spring 1990
C2 high in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at Col.

1st summit attack from C4 by 3 Koreans, 1 Japanese and 1 Sherpa planned for 11:00 pm 1st Oct. Cancelled by strong wind and team did not leave C4.
