2nd attack 6th Oct. Left C4 00:20 hrs 4 Koreans (Sugiyama who turned back just below S Summit and down to C3) and 2 Sherpas (3 Koreans at summit 6:00 am and Sherpas at 8:00 am). 

3rd attack by Ham Sung-Hun alone from C4 at 5:00 am at same time as US summiters but not climbing together; Ham going up for photos, not summit. 4:00 pm French descending gave him gloves near S Summit. Another French team saw slide marks down SW Face. Body not seen by time team left BC. Also on 7th Oct, Yanagihara and Nima Rita go up to 8300m to search, taking rucksack for Ham. 

More members not in summit bids because not enough oxygen. Team left BC 9th Oct.

Almost all teams switched to S Col route; this "no good" - thinking only of summit but "climbing important"; Japanese and Koreans fixed all rope, worked hard to make route and others came along to use what they had toiled to fix (others teams gave no money for this except for Icefall route).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8320m due to winds and climbers exhausted
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 at Bonington C3 on SW Face
C4 a little below Bonington C4
C5 same as Bonington C5.

9th Oct left C5 gear and site but too much wind and camp not pitched. Down to C2. 11 Oct to BC too much wind. No members again to C5 and only Sherpas to C3 and C4 to bring down gear.
ACCIDENTS: Gomez altitude sickness and stopped climb; 1 member hit by falling stone but not hurt

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to deep snow
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at "corner camp" at bottom of West Ridge of Changtse.

Trying to climb without sleeping bags, etc., but knee-deep to waist deep snow. After C1 established biked into East Rongbuk, skied to Lho La and climbed 3 peaks in area.

Came down from biv at 7800m beause of prolonged snowfall. Weather good for couple of days, then big storm followed by high winds; brought down BC 27th Sept and left BC 30th. Only 4 members did any climbing on Everest (no climbing required to reach C1 which is on glacier) but other 2 members climbed one or more of the subsidiary peaks, Chenzheng, Guangoning and Lingtren, during acclimatization period.

Reveley left early because he didn't like the look of Everest and as a doctor, he was helping Spaniards who had fatal avalanche.

Super Couloir = Japanese and Hornbein Couloir
ACCIDENTS: Teare stomach trouble prevented his climbing on Everest

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8750m due to strong winds and time running out
ROUTEMEMO:
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at S Col
High point at S Summit.

"I had almost the feeling of being at the top so I was happy and sad at the same time" - Pelaudeix on reaching S Summit only.

1st summit bid by Asselin, Bordet, Cauchy, E Dutrievoz, P Dutrievoz and Pelaudeix and 5 Sherpas who made C4 but could not go higher because of wind and clouds (Bordet did not sleep at Col and Asselin went only 200m above Col and then all down). 

8th Oct Pelaudeix and Bordet reached S Summit and down towards main summit with 1 Sherpa Phurba and Cauchy to 50m below South Summit. Turned back by strong wind. Left Col at 6:00 am and 1:30 pm reached col between S and Main Summit. 

No more summit bids because of following days wind became increasingly strong and yaks coming on 10th, had seats on Lukla flight on 15th and Japanese-Korean team had left and were no longer maintaining Icefall route.

2 members left BC 2nd Oct because they there was no hope of success.
ACCIDENTS: Dutrievoz cracked rib in icefall; Meurisse had stroke at Lukla on return

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8500m due to winds and oxygen regulator failure
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 in Western Cwm
C2 on Lhotse Face
C3 at S Col
High point at SE Ridge.

Did not make a camp at top of icefall: slept there on 14th Sept and next day into Cwm. 17th Sept up to 7200m, site for next camp for acclimatization and down to Cwm camp; then down to BC for rest. 19th Sept Sherpas up to established camp on face on 20th and at Col on 21st while members wait in BC. Sherpas back to BC on 25th. 2nd Oct to C2, waited 3 days in fine but very windy weather; from C2 up on 4th Oct; Veronique, Annie [Dubois from Batard team?] and 2 Sherpas and on first fixed ropes below C3 Annie got sick (stomach trouble) and she down while Veronique and 2 Sherpas to face camp, where Veronique rested 2 hrs and then onto Col with 1 Sherpa. Slept at Col 5/6 Oct night. Sherpa got headache but early 6th Veronique started alone; left with oxygen col at 1:00 am and climbed to 8400m, where oxygen regulator started giving trouble; left oxygen and went on witout oxygen but started getting very cold and fingers begining to freeze so turned back at 8500m, stopped 2 hrs at Col camp and was in BC at 5:00-6:00 that evening; climb finished. 

Annie Beghin had gone to see her husband at Lhotse BC and Veronique could not make another bid because of wind and no more oxygen left. "I am very sad" and angry about regulator and crying on descent from Col; Annie constantly worried about Pierre.
ACCIDENTS: 1 Sherpa bad headache; 1 member psychosomatic illness

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7000m due to bad snow conditions and strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at base of Japanese Couloir
High point at Japanese Couloir.

2 attempts to climb Japanese Couloir: 1st on 18th Sept by 3 members reached 6800m, then snow started falling and down to ABC; 2nd attempt on 28th Sept night after snowfall finished.

Reached 7000m where snow conditions bad: crested deep snow; 3 members again made this attempt; 29th Sept to C1 to sleep; now winds were strong and yaks arrived BC 7th Oct.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6900m due to fatal avalanche (emotional effects)
ROUTEMEMO:
Chinese BC 28 Aug
Intermediate
ABC under Changtse and under North Col.

Group that had accident were fixing ropes to N Col at 6900m; in group were 5 men Gomez-Menor, Scaldo, 3 Nepalis; Gomez-Menor and Ang Sona were highest fixing ropes and those below did not see how avalanche started but it carried men 200m to crevasse with these 3 lost; fell into very deep crevasse with much snow on top of them; very hard for survivors who saw ropes going into crevasse and they tried to dig; expedition decided to stop climb: snow conditions bad and big emotional distress (could see ropes leading to dead men) and to change route would mean big problem with liaison officer. 

Left ABC 22 Sept and had to spend 3 days to get injured 2 men (Spaniards deep cut in bottom from ice as and rib broken and had inhaled snow; Chowang Rinzi Sherpa had inhaled snow and pulled knee and ankle ligaments, plus shock). All members to ABC except doctor; only 2 above ABC (those hit by avalanche on 1st day venturing above ABC).

Official documents say fatal accident occurred on 14th because of confusion.
ACCIDENTS: Doctor had cerebral edema at BC; 3 killed and 2 hurt in avalanche

ROUTEMEMO:
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at South Col.

Members reached S Col 18th Sept but slept in for first time on 23rd. Batard by helicopter to Gorakshep 19th Sept and started up from BC 22nd and slept in C2. 23rd to S Col but windy and snowing and down to BC same day. [1st summit attempt by Tournaire, Janin, Pelle, Decamp failed at 8300m on 22nd].

2 days to Lobuje to meet Italian research group there and they tested him and decided to collaborate about physchological testing and Batard use of radio. 27th back to BC. 29th Batard left BC to climb direct to top in one night and day; this day others were at S Col now (Christine Janin, Erik Decamp, Pascal Tournaire, Bernard Germain, Bruno Gallet, Olivier Besson and 4 Sherpas). Batard reached C2 by 9:30 pm but windy and cloudy so at 11:00 pm decided to wait in C2. At 3:00 am awoke and started up at 3:15 am; at 7000m Decamp told him by radio weather too bad and Batard turned around and was back in BC same day.

3rd Oct Batard from BC to C2 for 2 nights waiting for strong wind to ease, as it did on full moon day/night of 4th Oct. From C3 at 6:30 am on 5th and on summit 4:50 pm of 5th. Christine and Pascal also from C3 at 2:30 pm and Batard met them at Col and (Pascal just above Col); Christine on oxygen from Col, Pascal from 7500m and all 3 to summit together. 3 stayed at top together 10 mins in very cold and windy weather. Batard began digging snow cave 2m below summit on west side. Batard very tired at 8500m and above and at 3:00 pm started freezing fingers and nose (was not on oxygen at all) and "when I reached the top I was not so good." 1 hr to dig cave and was inside 6:00 to 6:30 pm; "too much risk, is better to go back"; returned to Col at 9:00 pm and stayed there that night. 6th Oct at 7 am left Col and 4:30 pm at Lobuje.

6th Oct Annie Dubois tried for summit (with Veronique Perillat of Annie Beghin's team) from C2 but turned back after 2 hrs [from below C3].

6th Oct "Babu" Sherpa who had waited at Col for Batard for Lhotse, went to Everest summit alone at 9:00 am with oxygen.

Batard wants to try Everest-Lhotse next spring or autumn of necessary and use oxygen from 8500m to top and digging cave (but not sleeping or probably not descending). Disappointed not to have succeeded in this time, but "I am prudent."

One-legged member LeBissonnais reached S Col.

Batard did not oxygen at any time on ascent or descent.
 
Regarding [physical] quarrel with Sherpani, see Batard's "declaration" in his Everest spring 1991 file.


Batard - 17 Dec 1990

"Huyberechts claimed he failed to reach summit because all tents taken down, but actually this not true - he was too slow - he has since retracted this claim."


Ministry of Tourism - 5 Oct 1990

Top 11:00 am today
- Nawang Thile Sherpa, 40
- Sonam Tendu Sherpa, 29
- Erik Decamp, 36 started at 3:00 am from C4, stayed on top 1 hour

On top 4:30 pm 
- Batard, 38, mountain guide 
- Pascal Tournaire, 31 
- Christine Janin, doctor, 33


Batard - 18 Sept 1990

Returned from Xixabangma 17 Sept without success; reached 7600m and then too much snow (all other members stayed at Xixa).

Batard goes by helicopter from KTM tomorrow morning to BC. His team of Sherpas, Decamp and Michel Pollet have made the way to the Col already and "if the weather is good I start up after tomorrow. I need 3 days of good weather." If successful, goes quickly to KTM and Paris.

Batard had gone to Xixabangma for acclimatization reached 7600m there and left Spaniards before their climb finished; arrived KTM 17 Sept to go to KTM.
ACCIDENTS: Only Batard frostbite nose and finger which will heal

ROUTEMEMO:
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at South Col (placed camps only, slept in on 20th).

Strong winds prevented earlier summit success. De Bos to C4 20th to make summit bid but wind too strong to try.

On 29th Muller and De La Ferriere at C4 for summit bid (many others there too from other expeditions) and again winds sent them down next day.

1st Oct 5 members in C4 and also down on 2nd. 

3rd Oct Salino in C4 and on top 4th; left C4 at 9:00 am, 3 hrs after wind stopped, and climbed to left on rock, avoiding deep snow and cornices; on top 2:45 pm. Salino slept in C4 (US's Lowe to C2 direct). Oct 4th summiters ran out of oxygen about S Summit in descent. 

On Oct 6th at C4: Roches (2), Pivots (2), Desez and De Bos, Dorje and Ang Phurba from Rolwaling for summit bid. Annie Pivot waited near S Summit for her husband to go to top; 2 Sherpas also today without oxygen (used it previous night). At S Summit in descent met Korean who died (De Bos gave rucksack with oxygen mask and Bernard Roche gave gloves and Batard's Belgian member and A Pivot). Annie Pivot stayed at C4 that night using oxygen for 1st time; too much wind on 8th and finally down; on 9th and no more attempts.

Both Roches flew from Col at 4:00 pm (not from summit because wind too strong) and arrived at BC by double parapente in 15 minutes.


Chevalier & Muller

Left BC 2 Oct and by chopper to KTM 4th. Were on 2nd team, had made several attempts and reached Col but not above because winds - all at BC C2 and above to C4.

De La Ferriere at BC because tired after summit bid 29th. Lost 2 precious days in big argument with Batard over use of satellite. This may have cost her becoming 1st French woman atop Everest.

SPONSOR: Keimyung University Alpine Club Himalchuli Winter Exped 1991
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7540m due to length of route and bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at east Pokhari
C2 on SW Ridge
C3 on SW Ridge
C4 on SW Ridge
C5 on SW Ridge.

Ridge very long from C1 and sometimes steep snow face. Fixed 1800m rope BC to C5. Did not go beyond W Peak because long route to E Peak with many dangerous crevasses. 19th Dec 3 members started from C3 and reached C5 at 2:00 pm and Lee Suk-Hwan alone to W Peak which he reached 3:00 pm. Other 2 stopped at C5 because of strong wind. They saw route from C5 and W Peak so long and dangerous and needed 2 more camps to reach E Peak. Now bad weather: snowfalling so decided to abandon idea of going to East (Main) Peak.

TERMNOTE: W Pillar route abandoned at 7300m due to winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC west of Barun Pokhari
C1 on normal route for acclimatization
C2 on normal route for acclimatization
C3 on normal route for acclimatization
Biv 1 on West Pillar
Biv 2 on West Pillar
Biv 3 on West Pillar.

Acclimatized on normal route to Makalu La, where wind so strong tent probably destroyed soon after departure on 21 Dec. Then Wielicki went to pillar alone; from BC 27th Dec started 2:00 am from glacier, 11:00 am from bottom of pillar and biv at 6100m because of heavy load at 4:00 pm at good protected place. 28th Dec 9:00 am up again reached 6600m at 2 pm when started to snow. 29th Dec down from 6600m to BC. 2nd summit attempt again by Wielicki alone on 4th Jan. Started from BC at 3:00 am and 3:00 pm reached 2nd biv at 6600m, where had left tent. 5th Jan to mixed rock and snow, very long and complicated, dangerous and difficult in descent; 4:00 pm reached just below 7300m where there were many ropes and therefore easier; couldn't pitch tent in strong wind. Had planned to go to top and return to 3rd biv in same day; so down to BC on 5th with clear skies but impossible winds. No problem of technical difficulty but winds getting stronger so no use waiting longer. Left BC 11th Jan after decision to quit on 9th or 10th Jan.

OTHERSMTS: Climbed Island Peak and Lobuje East
ROUTEMEMO:
3rd Dec from Thyangboche to C1 5800m.
4th Dec to summit and biv at 6600m (very cold night with no biv equipment)
5th Dec to Thyangboche.

Passed US expedition who were at C1 on 3rd Dec and at C2 on 5th and "had Cadillac expedition"; McDermott was entirely alone from Thyangboche to Thyangboche.

Noble and Anker of US expedition stated on 18 Dec 1990: "McDermott spent night of his ascent, 4th Dec in US C2 getting warmed by sleeping between Anker and Bateman; McDermott would have frozen if he hadn't; had big blisters on his toes from frostbite (but not black); was not warmly dressed and had no gear with him at all; had tea in US C1 on his way up mountain; made use of others to do his "solo" climb." 

Norwegian-Swedish team saw a soloist on summit.

Ascent was illegal.

BC near Mingbo village
C1 at start of ridge
C2 by 2nd team only
C3 after mushroom ridge by 1st team who went to top 2 Dec.

Started for ABC on 30th Nov and from C1 on 1st Dec. From C1 is where climbing starts; C3 at usual C3 site and reached at midnight after 18 hrs on 1st Dec by first team. 2nd team on same day reached only at 6000m and bived there, reached 6100m on 2nd Dec and established C2, and on 3rd started up but one member not feeling well at 6200m and both turned backand slept at C2 with summiters on 3rd Dec. 

1st team had underestimated length of route above C1: mountain more difficult than expected. No fixed ropes, no garbage, no Sherpas. Left BC 7th Dec. 

Westby reached C1, decided against going higher; least experienced member.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Scandinavian ascent in Himalayas in winter

OTHERSMTS: Climbed on Lobuje East from 2 routes for acclimatization
ROUTEMEMO:
BC above Mingbo
C2 on ridge.

On 8th Dec Reed was with successful pair at C3 to try for climb; extremely cold (-10 degrees) and windy and climbing in shade and Bateman mildly ill with altitude problems.
ACCIDENTS: None except illness which kept Marjorie Noble in Namche during Ama Dablam climb

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to route too dangerous without fixed rope
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at normal North Face site, where sun reached
ABC at North Face
High point at top of Dutch Rib.

From BC to W Face climbed 600m onto a ridge and descended to beginning of W Face on 1 Dec. 2nd Dec 6 members made ABC on N Face at 5750m but near this camp found pegs and boots of an earlier disaster and also falling seracs. Sveticic 2nd Dec to 5200m at bottom of W Face to watch what happens there (where nothing happened - no falling ice or rock and sun on face in afternoon). Planned a camp at 6400m above Dutch Rib on N Face; 4th Dec 2 members went to fix rope at last part of rib and serac field, but big avalanches came down both sides of rib and huge serac fell destroying top section of rib; 100m of ice is hanging above rib. Members ran down mountain (not hurt only afraid - "something like earthquake") and returned to BC. French route had big seracs fall near ABC at 5750m. All now back to BC: not possible to make safe descent via N Face and sent message to Lete for porters to evacuate team and left 9th Dec; that night 40cm new snow fell and had to give boots, etc. to porters and members and Sherpas went ahead to shovel away snow. W Face solo ascent without fixed ropes and in middle section if this face not possible to descend without ropes over this 80 degrees rock which is very smooth and no place to put pitons. BC atmosphere not good with all the plaques to dead climbers.

Approach march took 3 days from Lete through difficult steep terrain and had to fix rope on W Face. All US members reached 5000m, all others at least 5100-5400m on N Face carrying loads.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7950m due to frostbite and anoxiya
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Tulagi Glacier's side
C1 above rock wall on glacier
1st biv
2nd biv at just below summit plateau in crevasse (protected from wind).

From Xmas to 3 Jan prolonged snowfall and BC low so did not get well acclimatized. First had to ferry loads himself from camp at 3800m below glacier because porters feared Glacier and left loads here. Monier and 2 Kitchen boys carried loads (arrived lower camp 17th Dec). 21st Dec Monier began climbing 800m rock wall that required 140m of fixed rope added to ropes already there and usable. Planned to go to C2 on 25th Dec, but lousy weather and did not find good route to C2 site at 6500m so left load at 6200m and down to C1 and 26th to BC. Then long period of really bad weather began 28th and lasted till 2 Jan Monier tried for top; reached C1 on 3rd; 4th to 1st biv at 6500m after collecting load at 6200m. 5th 2nd biv at 7300m in crevasse (out of wind) 100m below summit plateau. 6th started 1:30 am and at daylight (7:00 am) reached about 7950m at begining of climb of last tower (at last plateau). Tower begins as snow with it's last 50m rock. Started climbing this snow slope but took off gloves here for a moment and saw finger freezing and realized in unacclimatized state of hallucination (many people with him, talked with old woman who said she was 100,000 yrs old) since 7700m; "my legs would have taken me to top but I was descending and sleeping"; falling asleep so impossible to stop moving to rest. At 7:00 am -50 degrees and wind 80 km/hr, so turned back and descended to 6000m, which reached at 5:00 pm without problem, but unable to continue to C1 because headlamps batteries frozen; fell into crevasse 3m at 5 pm and made biv outside with 2 sleeping bags; now frozen little fingers had big blister and some problem down fixed ropes but began for biv at 8:00 am. Spent 2 hrs in C1 and reached BC at 5:00 pm. Climb finished because of frostbitten hands and feet also getting frozen from Kangchenjunga 1987 frostbite.

Did not acclimatize by going up to 6500m or so before summit push because felt with moon's change of phase, feared change of weather to the worse, so had no time to do so.

"Summit was not most important thing - most important was experience of loneliness, of achieving my philosophy of loneliness and this I achieved and am satisfied." Plans to bring small team of 3 or 4 members to Kangchenjunga N Face, perhaps in '93. "I reached my limit climbing alone this time."
ACCIDENTS: Monier frostbite (especially right little finger) and apoxia

ROUTEMEMO:
BC near BC (normal site).

Had many camps because of taking a lot of equipment & slow progress on bare rock (problem for making water with no snow). Ridge is not very difficult but continuously "serious." Rodolfi managed with his one artificial arm up fixed ropes.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing serious; one man slight frostbite on finger

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to wind, depletion of food supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lunag (below Kangchung)
Depot only, on moraine on east side of Gyabrag Glacier (east of "c" of Glacier)
C2 below serac before normal C3
C2 at bottom of NW Face
High point on NW Face.

Wind a strange kind in Dec with unexpected very strong bursts out of calmness; could not put camp along main trail to Nangpa La because Tibetan officials passing that way. Put only deposit at 5450m under rocks for fear Tibetans would take any visable tent; came here on acclimatization climb on 7 Dec and again on 15 Dec. 16 Dec proceeded to C1 site which was 100m below normal C3 site and where made snow and left cache cave. 17 Dec back to BC because not yet acclimatized. Left BC 23 Dec and slept at C1 25 and 26 Dec, planning summit push from here, but this was impossible because of wind. Waited a day and wind still blowing and made descent difficult back to BC on 27th. Left BC again with sirdar (who had been with him on 23 Dec trip) 4 Jan. 5 Jan to depot site; 6 Jan rested. 7 Jan Walde alone to 7250m below normal C4 at end of big serac at beginning of NW Face. 8 Jan started early in morning in snowstorm (very strong wind) and turned back at 7500m and spent night in new cave at 6750m where had had tent at C1. 9 Jan down to BC. 15 Jan both men left BC (now no people on trail) but got only to 5700m, little beyond Nangpa La, where slept and 16th went only to 6800m, saw storm clouds coming and turned back and climb finished. Left BC 19 Jan; no food or no money to buy food again.

"Incredibly long way" from BC and depot - maybe 20 km.

Total at BC: Walde, two sirdars and cook; LO and cook stayed at BC, sirdar only on glacier, did no real climbing.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to avalanche danger
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at higher normal site, safe and running water and 2 shelters
C2 at Naike Col in snowhole in deep snow
High point at serac band.

Had to wade through 5m snow to get to C1; high point was in area between C2 and C3 where most people get killed and "you could see why" with serac band there. All 6 were in C2 on 6th Dec and 2 went up that day pushing route and had fixed one section; snow was even 2m deep on slope they had to cross; turned back at 6000m because of avalanche danger down couloir had to be crossed. Left BC 10 Dec.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6800m due to route difficulty and lack of motivation
ROUTEMEMO:
BC in Annapurna Sanctuary (normal site)
C2 at bottom of face, at top of icefall
High point at South Face.

Quit on 7th because tired and cold and motivation level was extremely low; had some snowfall that also discouraged them; extremely difficult technically at mushrooms: "overhanging cauliflower."

ROUTE1: W Face up; SW Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC   at normal site abve Mingbo
C1   at base of West Face
Biv1 (even with normal C2)
Biv2 (lower than normal C3).

After establishing BC, went to Island Peak to acclimatize. 18th Dec 2:00 am Warner and Dunmire left C1 for summit: took 4-1/2 hrs going to left of rock band immediately above C1 to reach base of route. Climbed up rib in center of W Face and biv 100ft above big orange rock after pretty steep and unconsolidated rock mixed with bare rock and same ice pitches. Biv at 5:30 pm in platform they carved out of ice and snow. 19th Dec climbed to top of seracs in technical climbing and biv 20th Dec climbed through rock band to right side of Ama Dablam. 21st Dec cold morning and late start about 9:00 am and on top at 11:15 am and on down to C2 at 9:30 pm; no one in C2 but Americans had told about food (lasagna dinners) and fuel they had left there and Italians had suggested use of their big tent. 22nd Dec to BC. Had beautiful weather fixed no ropes. Biv gear included Bible, biv tent and sleeping bags.

BC  little north of true Dzasampa
ABC just south of "U" West Khumbu Schneider Map
C1  just below serac at start of face.

1st C1 at Pt 6448m on Schneider map, but it was destroyed by wind and then new one pitched at 6700m. Tried for summit from this C1, taking tent and pitching it at 7100m on face at top of serac; from 7100m went direct up face and fixed much fixed rope, joining normal route at 7850m and continued 22nd to summit in strong wind pushing summiters to true summit. 22nd Jean Luis Meunier reached 7200m and Berthaud and Du Puoy reached 8000m and turned back tired. Had lost much time trying to find route and with many tents destroyed in one week of fierce wind (which blew away loose snow and packed it hard). 22nd very clear but by 3:00 pm clouds coming up from S Face and obscured Everest summit.

Brazilian named Sergio appeared and joined their climb, but moved more slowly than French and stayed on normal route on 22nd; he came from Nepal, had no permit and was alone.

BC  before Nangpa La
ABC camp French 2nd ABC at foot of mountain
C1  at French camp site
C2  at French camp site
C3  at French camp site.

Beck went to Cho Oyu because easiest 8000er. Had only $1000 from entire stay in Nepal. Followed normal route almost all the way. Went to true summit as did French.

Beck was entirely alone until he met up with French expedition; did not even have yaks to BC.

Unauthorized climb; did not apply for permit because couldn't afford one.
ACCIDENTS: Numb toes from cold; slipped 100m on Apr 19 but not hurt

SPONSOR: 1991 American Khumbu Himal Expedition to Ama Dablam
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6475m due to difficult ice, lack of time
ROUTEMEMO: See Evan Smith account. On 13th tried to summit, got 250 vertical feet above C3, struck really hard, brittle water ice at 50 degrees instead of expected snow cover.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6036m due to bad weather, lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Mingbo
High point at C2.

Left BC 6th April. Mexicans arrived in Nepal very late, reached BC but did no climbing, says trekking agent.

According to American Evan Smith, Mexicans were refused permision to climb by LO as not being on membership list. Deepak here says it was because there was no gear for them.

Team climbed mostly if not entirely on Irish and other Americans fixed lines.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to bad weather, lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Mingbo (low site becauase no water above)
ABC at traditional site for ABC
C1  at traditional site for C1
C2  at traditional site for C2 on SW Ridge
C3  at traditional site for C3 at hanging glacier
High point at 6400m at C3.

25th March saw begining of 1st of snowstorm with wind that flattened tents at BC and almost decided to go to Pangboche but instead set up mountain tents; this on 25th was worst of the 5 serious storms in night. 31st weather fine, then threatening, then 4:30 pm started snowing heavily and strong wind. 2 members took loads to C2 and had terrible time getting to C1 at 9:30 pm completely exhausted. Then followed more carries to C2 but not occupied/slept in till 10 April because of reported snowfalls. C2 occupied on 16th by Harrington, Moriarty and Falvey of Irish expedition. 11th because very windy high up and Harrington and Falvey down to BC (were cold and exhausted). Finlay and Schifrin up to C2 from C1 while Moriarty stayed at C2 that day and all 4 of Bol American team arrived at C2. 12th much colder yet and all 7 in C2 started up for C3 with good progress initially, but technical problem made movement slow and arrived after 7:00 pm. 13th Bol American members left early going up. Finley not strength to go up. Schifrin ready to summit with Moriarty when Bol American team returned to C3 with decision that impossible to get to top without night out because of difficult ice. So all descended, with Finley and Schifrin to C1 that day in order to clear that camp next day.

Cleared away a lot of Thorndike trash while entirely cleared all their own.

BC south of small lake below big lake
C1 at top of a buttress
C2 just before col on East Ridge.

Feijoo started for top at 3:30 am with other 2 but after 1 hour turned back to C2 because going too slowly. Others on top 12:50 pm in clear weather until just before summit, when became cloudy. Most days clouds came at noon and sometimes small snowstorms (from 3 to 20 April). Feijoo not strong and only 2 men to fix ropes, which they did alternate days. Reached C1 site 17th April.

Other 2 members arrived BC on 15th April and reached C2 23 April, but did not try for summit.

OTHERSMTS: Climbed Island Peak (by Farrell and Shea)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at normal site above
ABC before ridge narrows
C1  at point 5826m on NGS Map
C2  at Black Tower (usual C2 site)
Biv at top of Mushroom Ridge by Murphy
High point at fixed C3.

Corrigan and Murphy made all the camps while Farrell and Shea climbed Island Peak to top. After C2 2 members made down to BC to meet others, then it snowed 24th and 25th. On 27th Murphy and Moriarty left BC but sick at C1 and down to BC on 28th. 28th other 2 members went up and reached above C2 on 3rd and ran into storm and back at BC on 5th. Corrigan and Murphy left BC 30th and in C2 in 31st and stayed there 2 nights with another snowstorm. 2nd both left C2 upwards and bived in snow cave already there at 6100m on most difficult terrain (had biv bag). 3rd continued fixing route and another biv on top of Mushroom Ridge at 20,500 ft. 4th Corrigan breathless and snow at end of fixed ropes, so down to BC same day while Murphy up to top alone (left 2nd biv on 8:30 am and on top at 3:30 pm and down the head wall to Ama Dablam glacier in darkening night and bived at 22,000 ft. Got frostbite on 2 toes of left foot during night. 5th to C1 and 6th to BC. Snowed on 6th morning, final descent miserable. Left BC 8th April by helicopter for KTM.

Other 4 climbers on the way to C2 to day hoping for summit via a biv with top on 11th, said Murphy and Corrigan. 

Moriarty's account of later activities: 

7th April - all at BC.

8th April - Murphy and Corrigan left in helicopter; Moriarty and Shea left BC and arrived at C1; Falvey and Farrell also.

9th April - Shea and Farrell down with stomach trouble (which plagued teams). Moriarty with Sue Harrington of Evan Smith team crossed ridge and made C2 but got into terrible storm and back to C1; Falvey stayed at C1 [stomach trouble?].

10th April - much snow but these 3 got to C3.

11th April - Falvey and Harrington to BC; Moriarty at C2; Schifrin and Finley and 4 of Bulgarian team also arrived at C2.

12th April - Moriarty, Finley, Schrifin to C3 with 4 of Bol American team with Moriarty in biv sack.

13th April - Route above C3 very little snow; Bol American team went up above C3 but Moriarty and 2 other Americans did not try; had too little supplies for bid and too far from top. Moriarty decided climb finished and was back in BC same day and BC had been cleared that day.

14th April - BC to Namche for Moriarty to join other members.
ACCIDENTS: Corrigan extreme fatigue; Murphy frostbite (will heal); all had stomach trouble

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to lateness in the day and member's exhaustion
ROUTEMEMO:
1st BC at base of North Ridge at point 5087m on National Geographic map
2nd BC at Mingbo SW Ridge
High point on West Face via SW Ridge by all 4 members.

Climbed on the lower part of NE Face 1000m and put in fixed ropes. Then decided seracs had grown since Kennedy and Buhler had been there 1985 and were now too dangerous. So 21 and 23 April decided to abandon route and ask permission to change to SW Ridge. 

Took down ropes and on 26th April turned around to Mingbo which reached 27th. 30th started up and reached 5950m. 1st May to 6600m at 3:30 pm; couldn't get back to camp if to top that afternoon and clouds building so back to C1 at 8:00 pm. Now very tired and had gotten very high and decided to abandon climb and down to BC on 2nd. Left BC 3rd. Filmed to high point (by David despite illness).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to bad weather and dangerous conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at low site because no water higher
C1 on SW Ridge
High point at SW Ridge all 3 members.

11th May reached 5400m and dumped loads 16th May explored ridge 6000m. No snow or ice on 1st section and 17th down to BC. 21st May 1st attempt for non-stop summit push and reached 6600m and then thunderstorm came and back to C1 and next day weather not good and on down to BC on 22nd. 

24th another summit bid, climbed all day and night and 7:00 am 25th at 6400m, at bottom of a ridge stopped by bad ice like sugar into which cannot fix pitons so down to BC. If not this problem would have reached top in 4 hrs. Route was in very dangerous condition with much bare rock or bad ice. 9:00 pm 25th reached BC having cleared C1. Waited one extra day but weather bad and not time to wait long: had fixed flights from Lukla on 1 June and from Nepal 5 June.

9 May very severe storm descending from C3. One man snow blind and some frostbite in very cold and windy weather and tents zippers didn't close, so sleeping bags covered with powder snow.

2 members to ABC, got altitude sickness and left after days to ABC.

Ruiz and 2 from Swiss Eiselin group reached top before Greek group (from and to C2 on 8th). 

Greek party to true summit and so did the other, whose footprints Greek followed. Mtn covered in snow while going up, but bare rock down.
ACCIDENTS: 3 Greeks frostbite which will heal; 3 altitude sickness

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at true site of Kangchung
Biv at true site of Dzasampa
Biv south of Nangpa La
Biv where Gyabrag Glacier turns south
Biv at standard ABC
High point on West Face.

Interested to consider climbing face east of "pa" in Nangpa Glacier of Schneider map, but after arrival at BC, found face was all blue ice which would have been possible to climb but required more equipment (including lots of ice screws) than had with them. Farrar went up on 23rd to make ABC but only 3 hrs from BC they were hit by heavy snowstorm, had to biv and overnight. 1m of snow fell, it continued next day and took party 11 hrs to struggle through 4-5 foot deep snow to BC. Houchin at this time down to Thami to resupply, snowed in at Thami one day and on down to Namche; also had bronchitis. Back to BC 28th. Farrar had limited time and with snow conditions as they were, he left BC on 28th. On 30th Bowen and Houchin and 2 Nepalese porters moved up to place just south of true site of Dzsampa. Stayed there and on 31st moved loads farther up Nangpa Glacier intending to climb either Messner or normal route. 31st again snowed but moved up on 1st (2 Nepalis, not really capable of handling these conditions and sirdar Kippa Sherpa had disappeared, so only 3 Americans now) to 5660m, just below Nangpa La, after deciding not to try Messner's icefall bad snow conditions. Another 4 inches of snow fell on night of 1st-2nd. On 2nd crosse Nangpa La and spent night at 5660m again, this time where Gyabrag Glacier turns south at "U"  of Schneider map. Snowed again this night; had been carrying 35 kg loads and Ron's bad back giving trouble. Saw mountain plastered with snow and evidence of avalanching. Stayed there all of 3 April and that evening decided there was too much snow and would not go further. 4th all 3 men down to BC in one day in trail of a yak train. Sent mailrunner to Thami for Yaks on 5th and they were expected 5 days later.

On 28 March, yaks carrying resupply were able to get only 1 hr below BC because of deepness of snow.

On 6th Houchin, Kippa and 2 porters (1 Sherpa and 1 Gurung) went from BC to just below Nangpa La to make another try on mountain. Were stopped by snowstorm 30m below Nangpa La with one tent having been left beind. 7th went around glacier and reached standard ABC at 6000m on face across Gyabrag Glacier from pt. 6600m on Schneider map. 8th Houchin alone went up 100m on face in acclimatization climb in snowy and windy weather and back to camp - stayed in camp during bad weather of next two days and then weather was still bad with snow every day and strong wind at 6000m. Had hoped to go up to standard C1 site on 11th, but when clouds rolled in at 8:30 am, finally abandoned climb. Got back to BC on 12th having had problem with crevasse area south of Nangpa La. Met other member at Namche on 13th.

BC between 2 lakes below West Face of Lobuje East at base of rock village 
Biv1 above south lake on unstable moraine debris above 200m vertical cliff
C2 on pillars lower angled section.

From C1 climbed chimney leading to ramps and gullies. 7th May fixed a pitch and rested a day or 2 at C2. Did a pitch a day because of frequent snowfalls and occasional rest days up series of ramps and 2 large ledges on pillar. Then above ledger pillar goes straight to NW Summit and followed pillar or left side of it. 8 pitches from C2 to beginning of snow at 19,000 ft. On summit push 20th May left C2 at 5:00 am and returned at 9:00 pm.

Did not cross deep crevasse to true summit. This the only line to true summit directly.

BC at road (new site 2-3 hrs further from ABC).

Beautiful weather on 27th: little wind and clear till 4:00 pm. Left C3 3:00 am 27 May and 1st reached top at 3:00 pm (last summiter on top 4:00 pm) and back to C3 7-9 pm, some very tired and Weisenberger serious altitude sickness. 28 May to ABC. 29 May for Lhasa and flew to KTM 8 May.

20 May Tauber's hat got brown mark from lightning, which burned metal button on his cap - was on a ridge at 6420m about 2:30 pm.

Team used 2 Tibetans to C1.

Ruiz had been very ill from altitude in early days of expedition and very nearly quit, but kept with it and got very much better. On 8 May left C2 very early and passed Greeks to reach summit and before Greeks did - had left at 4:00 am.
ACCIDENTS: 1 member frostbite which will heal; summiters altitude sickness early in climb

ROUTEMEMO:
Perfect snow conditions when team was there but lot of new snow fell just after departure. 

7 May Jezler climbed alpine-style from C2 which he had left on 5 May. 7 May he pitched his own tent 7200m; on 7th to fore-summit at 8000m and down to 7200m. 8th to C1 and 9th BC. He did not go to the true summit because of the fog which he feared to move in.

Expedition had very strong winds which blew down long tent with 50 kg gear inside - also electrical storm 10th May.


Alex Bricker 

Unfortunately we had a deadly accident, one German member, Horst Wasmann is missing on the mountain. Together with a Swiss friend [Zemp], they tried to come down [with 2 Spaniards] under very bad weather-conditions from Camp 4 (7400m) to a lower camp. At the altitude of approx 6400m he fell down to the North-East Face of Cho Oyu. The date of the accident was Saturday, 11th May 1991 at 19:30 Peking Time. 

[Wasmann was completely disoriented with altitude sickness. Zemp, who was ahead of him, heard him fall. Team search 12th and 13th and found only cap and ski stick.]
ACCIDENTS: 5 members frostbitten fingers or toes but probably will heal; 2 altitude sickness; Wasmann fatal fall

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5500m due to dangerous icefall
ROUTEMEMO:
Low BC at Kyummu Khola on old flat terminal moraine
ABC at base of icefall
High point at snow slopes at left side of South Face.

Dismissed porters at low BC, 1 hour short proposed BC for climbers but dangerous for laden porters, who had few shoes & there was snow on ground and on west facing faces (knee deep on west side of ridge descending to Lower BC). Very dangerous face. Did acclimatization climbs to 4800m on nearby ridges 20 to 22 March, then snow fall, to ABC 26 March. One night at ABC. Decided to do route on left side of S Face, which has ridge down its middle and thus went up SSW Face and to left of this section of S Face. 28 March rested in heat till 5:00 pm started up at 6:00 pm and climbed up to snow slope at 9:30 am. Now LeSeuer decided didn't want to continue on this face exposed to ice cliffs for 6-8 more hours of climbing - ice cliffs had not fallen while New Zealanders were there but very dangerous potentially. Returned to ABC through icefall which had changed a lot (wouldn't want to be in this icefall in daytime). Reached ABC at 12:30 that night and spent rest of that night in ABC. Reached BC at 8-9 am on 29 March. Left BC 2 April with porters who came up to BC. Arrived KTM today on night bus from Pokhara. 

Sirdar Chowang Rinzing said he led 2 illegal ascents of Cho Oyu.

Did not go to the mountain at all - too busy with geological research.
No climbing in BC.

Sarti & Gradstein were interested in going to climb Bhrikuti, but not enough time to spare for 2 days to the mountain, an attempt at climbing & 2 days back to center of geological work, which was their reason for being in the area (and for getting a climbing permit enablimg them to be there).


Letter from Massimo Sarti - 9 May 1991

The main reason of the unsuccess was insufficient time. As I told you our mission was scientific so that most of our time was dedicated to that. Our attempt to reach the Brikuti base camp through Narsing Khola failed because of our underestimate of logistic requirements such as food supply, unavailability of water, men support and length of the trip. Brikuti is extremely far away if approached from the SW Ridge.

On the other hand, our geologic goals were all accomplished with fantastic and unexpected results.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5900m due to avalanching and constant snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
High point at Dutch Rib.

After 1st April much snowfall. 15th April tried to reach C2 together with Germans but 4 men down 50m with small avalanche. 17th made C2 but 19th April more snow for several days so on 22nd decided to give up after snow once again in afternoon of 21st. Now no time left for success - avalanching, strong wind at high altitudes and waist deep snow where snow piled up by wind. All members to C2 except Canal who had to leave early. Left BC 26th and trekked through Manang.

ROUTE1: W Face Center (snow slope above SW Pillar)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near Puchhar.

Most difficult section from 5500m to 6200m: 80 degrees (6+ grade) bare rock - fixed ropes all the route from C1 to C5; some avalanches from C4 area, but dry snow and not big avalanches (this when new snowfell). More difficult rock climbing than Lhotse S Face, which mixed rock and ice and higher than Dhaulagiri - very strong winds and very cold.

Dedi's hand broken when he was moving rock to make C1 site; he stayed at BC. In difficult rock section near C1, he fell several times but was attached to fix rope and fell only few meters and not hurt.

Summit teams: 
  10 May - left C4 from 8:00 to 9:00 am; very fast very strong
  climbers on summit from 10:00 to 11:00 am, returned to C6 1:30 pm.
 
  13 May - left C6 at 7:00 am, on summit from 11:00 to 12:00 am, 
  returned to C6 3:00 pm and C5 7:00 pm.

Expedition left BC 17 May.

Route: W Face Center to snow slope above SW Pillar.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6415m due to continuing dangerous snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site of a low BC
C3 on NE Face
High point at NE Face.

Snowed 1st April to 16th April everyday; of 40 days at and above BC, 29 days snowfall and strong wind and very dangerous frequent avalanching. On 6th April Dellatorre and Dawa hoped to go to summit with one biv, but Dawa developed altitude sickness only 15m above C3 and had to retreat to C3. 7th Dawa still sick and heavy snowfall, so down to BC in dangerous snow conditions. Wanted to make another summit but bad weather to 17th. On 18th Barbieri & Giovanoli up but only to 6200m and again heavy snowfall, fog and strong wind, so same evening back to BC and climb finished.
ACCIDENTS: Bay altitude sickness only (at 5000m); Dawa also at 6415m

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5750m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C2 before traverse to Dutch Rib
High point start of traverse to Dutch Rib.

BC most dangerous place on route: ice falling off Tilicho South Face. Huge serac came down and wind from it blew tents away at BC. After C2 established, three times half-meter fresh snow, which same on top of thin layer of ice in a basin below and right of Dutch Rib and much too dangerous to traverse this basin. All members reached C2.

BC  at normal site
ABC at icefall top at NE Col
C1  at snow cave at start of ridge
C2  on NE Ridge.

Took 2 weeks to place ABC because of frequent snowfall and avalanches. Fixed entire icefall. 3 May Mathorne and Christensen left C3 for top but turned around 5 mins because of cold and toes starting to freeze. 

8th May Ritzau, Smidt, Voldstedlund and Korsgaard left ABC for summit bid, but Korsgaard and Voldstedlund turned back on 11th at 7200m because one had headache and other had never interested to go to top. 12th Ritzau down from C2 because not strong. Smidt on to C3 on 12th and stayed there 13th to rest. Snow very deep (almost to hips) and worked hard 12th night to put camp in order. 14th left C3 at 8:15 am and on top at 12:45 pm in cold but clear and windless weather that morning.

Between Marpha and BC stuck in big snowstorm for 6 days.

BC to ABC 7 km apart and never down to BC for one month. With no Sherpas most members exhausted by establishing ABC from such a distance from BC.

SPONSOR: Korean Api Kyoung Shin O.B. 1991 Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Api Khola
ABC on glacier at bottom of wall
C1  on west wall of NW Ridge
C2  on NW Ridge.

At time of summit push C1 and C2 broken by wind and push began from ABC on 27 May at 5:00 am and reached top at 4:15 pm. 

No more summit bids: destruction of tents by wind and no time left. Winds had driven climbers down to BC after C2 pitched and attempts to mount summit attack, so afterwards aborted by winds. Left BC 29 May.

Best way to BC is from Nepalgunj to Darchula by bus via India.

C1-C2 big wall of rock with some snow; 50-degree slope 800m high; fixed rope up this wall all the way, but on 27 May some sections had been blown away by winds.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 4100m due to too much snow, icy and windy
ROUTEMEMO:
BC northwest corner of Tilicho (site reached by one member but no camp pitched and no climbing done).

Stopped at 4600m next of Mesokanto Pass, farthest porters would go on 16th April. Jacquier went onto BC site with sirdar on 20th April but did not make BC. Very cold and windy and deep snow beyond Mesokanto Pass to BC, so not possible for porters to carry loads to BC and in fact no BC established. Went to Jomsom 21 April and Neuenschwander and Chamot left there 22nd while others two are leaving soon with baggage.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned due to snow enroute to BC (did no climbing)
ROUTEMEMO:
Jomsom-Kagbeni-Tangbe; at Tangbe, people said necessary to go to Tsarang, where a valley leads to SE to Bhrikuti (Damodar Kund and its Khola). Left Tangbe on 20th on which weather, changed to rain, then snow and cold strong wind - crossed four 4000m passes between Tangbe and Tsarang, which reached on 23rd after 1-1/2 days of snow. 24th also bad weather and 25th evening at Tsarang decided not to go farther. Tsarang is 3500m altitude and BC would be 4800m & way not possible for poorly clad porters in such weather. On 26th stayed one more day at Tsarang but left there on 27th to retraced steps to Jomsom. Arrived KTM 2 April.

Bhrikuti is ESE of Tsarang, farther north on border than location given on Nepal central sheet map of HMG. As seen from Tsarang, it looks difficult with difficulties all on the North Face.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at low site
High piont below North Col.

3-14th April nearly continuous snowfall with 2-3m of snow with avalanching on ridge of route. Had reached C3 site on 3 April but snow conditions afterwards delayed progress. 15th snowed again but on 17th tried to go above C2 for 1st time. More snowfall again. On 21st returned to C2 and more attempts to go above. Reached 6100m only in deep soft snow which was consolidating. Would have had to wait quite some time for better conditions. No wind at altitude Irish reached. Date to leave BC was 2 May; actually left on 30th April.

SPONSOR: S Tirolean Himalayan Expedition 1991 to Manaslu
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to bad weather and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site (Manaslu Glacier)
C1 on Manaslu Glacier
C2 on Manaslu Glacier
C3 on Manaslu Glacier
High point at 40-degree slope of Manaslu Glacier northeast side.

On 10th May Hans Kammerlander, Freidl Mutschlechner and Karl Grossrubatscher left C3 at 5:30 am. After half-hour Friedl turned back because previously frostbitten fingers getting numb (-35 degrees windy weather) and returned to C3. Karl turned back at 7200m because had not brought his ice ax and now realized it was needed. They had seen weather not good and not trying for top. From BC saw Karl around C3 tent. Because cloudy at 9:00 am and no longer could be seen. Hans turned back at 7500m because of cold and windy. Saw Friedl near C3 tent and Freidl asked Hans at about 9:00 am where is Karl? (Freidl had been sleeping). They looked, around and saw Karl's body c100m to C3 & very near tent found ice ax with glove in it's strap - Karl's neck broken, but how? Gentle slope with some snow in good condition. He was very strong & professional climber. Perhaps he went up serac above tent, but no sign of body's falling in snow - little blood on temple but only neck broken. Body put on top of closed crevasse which in warmer weather will open. Hans and Friedl then took down to C3 tent and went to C2, took this tent down. Fog coming and going so down slowly in poor visibility. Left some gear below a steep section; others next day would recover this and they towards C1. Their ice axes were singing with & hair full of electricity. 100m above C1 there was a small hill and they were on skies roped together; Friedl asks Hans to wait for better visibility. Hans ear popped but no lightning seen; ear felt like biting on it and he dropped his rucksack and dropped himself into snow - pulled on rope but no response. He scooped out snow and lay in his shallow cave (about 4 pm) but before went to Friedl who did not move, stayed only a minute, made his shelter cave and later again to Freidl and now saw he was dead. Hans immediately to C1 despite snow falling and stayed there above that night - stormed all night. 11 May Hans to BC and 3 other members, sirdar, 2 Sherpas and kitchen boy up to C1. Members to Friedl & left him where he lay. Took C1 to BC & all activity finished. Left BC 13th May.

3 burn marks on Friedl's head & cap. Hans 8m distant from Friedl and little lower than Freidl, who was at highest point of small gentle hill.

On 21st April saw oil on  water from snow - from Kuwait's oil wells burning? Afterwards fresh snow did not have oil again on water.
ACCIDENTS: Grossrubatscher fatal fall; Mutschlechner killed by lightning

ROUTE2: S Ridge up; NE Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on north side of Punggyen Glacier southwest of Kharka
C3 on glacier before East Wall/Face
C5 on South Ridge (series of bivouacs).

After C2 took time; about 10 rope-lengths above C3 on east wall where USSR climbers fell in 1990; finished their old route but now too much snow and avalanching. Down to BC after reaching 7200-7300m 28th April E Face. 

Now 3 men from BC climbed alpine-style with no fixed ropes, no fixed camps, no O2 to S Ridge. Started 1st may from BC, went through C1 after drinking there and climbed through night to saddle if possible but bivouac 10-12 rope-lengths before saddle at 6500m; 2nd night at Polish saddle 7000m. 4th May daytime climb on S Ridge and bivouac before steep rock ridge at 7400m. 5th May very difficult and dangerous traverse to bivouac at 7850m. 6th May to top; left last bivouac at 6 am, on top after 10 hours (last ropes to the top very steep and dangerous snow avalanching) and carrying all gear in order to traverse and descend normal route and bivouac at 7900m. On 6th May on normal route which was NE Face ridge. 7th May down slowly because tired and did not know route to 7100m following old ropes sometimes and Italian BC 8th May where 2 Soviets met them and own BC early morning 9th May. Left BC 10th May.
ACCIDENTS: None although some left early (not strong)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due to wind, difficult route, exhaustion, etc
ROUTEMEMO:
BC above glacier near glacier's junction
C1 north of point 6180m
High point at West Face.

Very strong winds after 7th April and tents broken. Fixed 500m rope up from C1 and below C3 about 1000m of rope and 800m more to 7300m to top for a small ridge and start of very steep section. After reached 7300m wind strong and blowing much snow on to route. Now very cold and feet begining to freeze. Others not able to forge ahead. 

12th May S Panzeri and Spreafico were only climbers techinically capable of moving fast enough and they tried again but feet gave a lot of pain and turned back. 

All members reached C2 but only Spreafico and Panzeri brothers reached C3 (plus Ferrari for 1 night). S Panzeri and Spreafico want to come again and finish route up "very good granite" above hard ice; ice 60 degeees (below C3). 

Negri arrived at BC 24th April because had had ski accident; he reached C2 and then knee swelled up and had to stop.

Oxygen used only by sick Sherpa who had pulmonary edema.
ACCIDENTS: 1 Sherpa pulmonary edema; 2 members start of frostbite; Negri arrived at BC late because had had ski accident (he reached C2 and then Knee swelled up and had to stop)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8150m due to winds
ROUTEMEMO: April went up to C2 site and left cache and then down to ABC to rest. Then it snowed and down to BC. 11th up to C1, where spent 5 days because of winds. Up to C2 and spent 1 night with howling winds. 13th down to ABC for 3 days. 16th to C1 but only 1 day there because of winds even there; down to BC. 23rd to C1, 24th C2, 25th to 7600m, where spent 2 half days. 28th winds stopped at 6 am and got to 8150m 5 hours later. There winds blew up and Burleson had only 25m of 7mm rope; saw old fixed lines but unusable (pulled right out). Burleson now alone (Sherpas went only as high as C3 and waited there) so turned back and down to C1 knowing this was end of climb. Discouraged by wind, but very happy with the climb because really well, getting fast and not concerned about others. Much easier route than those on north side of Everest.
Climb was technically difficult: mostly very exposed snow climbing. Fixed rope in couple of places above W Col (total of 300m); also fixed to W Col.

BC at Japanese BC near glacier's junction
C3 at Makalu La (around corner out of wind, highest point on Makalu attempt).

"Had so much wind even at BC." 29th April reached 7640m summit of Kangchungtse. Had trouble with kerosene for stove and heard from Burleson about ice on rock above and already 2 nights at La, so De Bos and Willekens, the only people then in C3, went to Kangchungtse summit. Turned back and down to C1 after Kangchungtse ascent. 30th down from C3 and no one else up after that. Sherpas had cleared some camps and De Bos and Willekens cleared most of the rest.

SPONSOR: Slovene Himalayan Expedition to Kangchenjunga & Jannu
OTHERSMTS: Climbed Kangchenjunga Central (KANC-911-01) and Kangchenjunga South (KANS-911-01); climbed Talung illegally (TLNG-911-01); attempted Jannu (JANU-911-01)
ROUTEMEMO:
All members went to same BC. Kanch South climbers then went to Talung while Jannu climbers acclimatized on Kangchenjunga Central Summit. Kanch South reached at 10:30 am of 1st May, having left C3 at 10 pm on 30th April and climbed Polish route; 3x50m fixed rope 7 difficult climb on mostly rock; returned to C3 at 10 pm. 1st May (took no stove but had 1 litre thermos of water, biv bag but no sleeping bag); stopped only 1 hr at 8200m to rest. 

Main summit pairs left C4 2 am 1st May on top 1:25 pm and back to C3. On 2nd May Frantar and Rozman from C3 to C4. 2/3 May left C4 with 1 oxygen bottle; no one knows where left C4: planned to leave at 10 pm of 2nd May, but probably left later; were seen at 8000m at 8 am; wind very strong; last seen at 8100m at 11 am and then clouds came over them. One had 1 oxygen bottle and one of them moved only 100 vertical meters in 3 hrs while another went up 50m and returned to the other and then both seem going up together. At 4 pm they radioed they were 150m below top, they were cold, one wanted to descend and one wanted to go on up, woman was becoming snowblind but it was she wanting to go up (ambitious to become first woman a top). Both agreed to descend. Last radio contact at 7 pm and reported (speaking with difficulty) they did not know where they were "lost completely" or where to find C4; were having trouble pushing radio's buttons. Bodies found on 3rd and 4th; probably fell about 8:00 pm; definitely fell.

Rutkiewicz did not reach summit because she was too slow, spent too much time and energy on photography with much equipment, had no climbing plan. Skarja made no agreement (as she claims he had) to give her 2 summit attempts and after fatal accident climbing finished.


Rutkiewicz - 15 May 91

Left BC 9 May

WR to C2 on 4 May
BC to rest  4 May

and then learned porters called for 8th at BC, but WR had paid $8800 and received promise to wait for her to make 2 attempts.

Yugos had asked her to help in search/rescue. 

WR to BC to ask someone to help her with obtaining porters when she finished her 2nd attempt. WR started up on 8 May reached C2 - all learned on 8th from BC no staff to wait for her; only 2 porters for one day would wait. Down to BC on 9th, where 2 porters (and ill Ewa) were only people left.

30th April - Stremfelj and Prezelj reached South Summit by new route so planned without oxygen and in one push of 6 days and down normal route to C3 at 7300m on Great Shelf - had made acclimatization climb of Talung.

1 May - Rupar solo ascent to Central Summit from C3 via Polish route without oxygen; started 30 April night; descended same route to C3 on 1 May.

1 May - 2:00 am Bozic and Groselj started from C4 (7600m) to main summit by normal route using oxygen and on top 1:30 pm and down to C3 and 2 May to BC (5500m).

2nd May Frantar and Rozman arrive C4 and 3 May tried for main summit (one on oxygen) at 4:00 pm radioed reached 150m below top and one decided to go down and one up; leader said both should come down (now late and windy) and they agreed and would radio again about 6:30 pm. At 6:30 they reported didn't know, where they were and where to go; Frantar snowblinded and it seemed they had frostbitten fingers. This last contact.

4 May Rutkiewicz alone going up to C4 - 100m below C4 she found Rozman's body battered body must have fallen more than 800m); she returned C3.

5 May Drazan and Juhant up from C3, put Rozman body in crevasse and 50m below C4 found Frantar's body also body battered; put here body in crevasse. Down to C2 and 6 May to BC and expedition finished unless Rutkiewicz tried for top again.

Jannu - tried face in alpine-style from 28 April - reached 7050m in 5 days. Stopped by wind and snow and resounded in 2 days and no additional attempts. Extremely difficult and in daytime sun produced waterfalls.

Others in 18 May KTM; leave 20 May if team arrives as planned.

20m-high serac 7200m on Kangchenjunga impossible by Sherpa.
ACHIEVMENT: New route to south summit; 1st Yugoslavia ascent

SPONSOR: Slovene Himalayan Expedition to Kangchenjunga & Jannu
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7050m due to bad weather, frostnip, etc
OTHERSMTS: Climbed Kangchenjunga (KANG-911-02), Central (KANC-911-01), South (KANS-911-01); climbed Talung illegally (TLNG-911-01)
ROUTEMEMO:
Went to Kangchenjunga BC 12th April and to acclimatize and went to C2 on Kangchenjunga. Also pitched tent and stocked it with some food, etc. and from this tent started climb at 4 pm on 29th April. Took biv sack, stove and gas, 2 sleeping bags and 2 ropes. Fixed no rope on climb. At 9 am on 30th April rested at 6400m for 6 hrs. Then on up to 6800m where stopped at 9 pm on 30th. 1 May 8 am started up again; left biv gear at 6900m expecting to reach top that day but at 7050m stopped at 2 pm bad weather (winds and avalanche of new snow). Waited at 7050m 9 hrs for better weather when snowfall and avalanches stopped. Down to 6900m at 1 am 2 May stayed until 9 am. Now down to 6600m in 3 hrs, there snowfall and avalanches then after another 2 hrs to biv at 6550m at 4 pm in big crevase. 3 May 1 am down & at bottom of face at 6 am, to tent at 5430m at 7 am. Climb now finished. 

Slight frostbite, very tired and lost 10 kg each (had eaten only 200 gms biscuits). Entire face "extreme difficulty plus" with 5 pitches more difficulty (2 ice, 3 mixed rock and ice). Route possible: if weather good "we would be on top on 1st of May in evening." Ice couloir up center. Jannu in clouds every day of entire expedition's climb: Jannu had the worst weather.

APPROACH: From Gangtok->Taggu by road (long rte->BC via 3 passes)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Green Lake
ABC at glacier junction of Zemu and Twins Glaciers
C1  on South Face of NE Spur
C2  ont NE Spur
C3  at wide snow ridge which NE Spur 
C4  on NE Spur
C5  at top of NE Spur
C6  on North Face.

NE Spur very difficult: snow monsters, "up-down zig-zag," so much fixed ropes. 16 Indian climbing members (Indian leader to C1) and 14 Japanese climbers (Ogata to C6). Northern approach in spring did not reach BC even after digging yak road taking month extra to get to BC.

14 March we left Gangtok by 4 mini-buses and 7 auto trucks with members and high altitude porters.

There are two routes for approaching BC at Green Lake in the Zemu Glacier. One of them is along the Zemu Chu (river) from Lachen and the others are a roundabout way the Northern area from Tanggu. Three high passes stand the roundabout way that Lugnak La, Thieu La and Tangchung La.

The route of our approach to the Base Camp had been set for roundabout way our overall leader. I was anxious about snow condition of these high passes for yaks in middle of March. As a consequence it follows that it took the team 44 days to transport for expedition loads from the road-head to the Base Camp at Green Lake (4935m). If it were not for snow on the high passes, we could reach to Base Camp from road head only 4 days. The advance party arrived the Base Camp on 31 March and last party arrived on 26 April such being the case. 

As advance party selected a site for Advance Base Camp on 1 April. Carrying of supplies up to ABC started on 10 April. The route to ABC led up the Zemu Glacier from Base Camp. ABC was on a glacier where the Twins Glacier joins to the Zemu Glacier at an elevation of 5200m.

After ABC, we started route making for C1. The first obstacle was in the form of an icefall. This icefall stands in just below the Upper Zemu Glacier where it was about one hour from ABC. At that point the East Face of Kangchenjunga, which until then had been hidden by lower part of NE Spur, came into full view for the time. This icefall technically speaking was not as bad as the one of Everest but was far more dangerous due the constant hazard of ice avalanches and falling boulders. The members and high altitude porters had often narrow escapes from the bombardment of stones and ice avalanches.
 
On April 16, 6 climbers who stretched 13 pitches of fixed rope across several crevasses and ice walls. They reached an elevation of 5600m. The next day, they extended the route 9 more pitches up an ice plateau on the Upper Zemu Glacier where we pitched Camp after several days.

On 19th April, both the leader and some members reached C1, we had view for reconnaissance to find a climbing route for East Face of Kangchenjunga. The East Face was very steep with ice and rock mix face and was dangerous due to the constant hazard of big avalanches. We judged from that view there was no feasible route up from the top of the Upper Zemu Glacier.

The same day a huge icefall at the just below the snow plateau broke down and route was cut to pieces. We changed make of fixed rope to the flank of NE Spur on the following day. 

C1 was set up at the South Face of the NE Spur on 20 April at the height of 5700m.

After Camp I we had to gain the crest of the deadly NE Spur. The South Face of the NE Spur rises up almost vertically for about 300m from the flat glacier basin, and the steep face with fluted ice-gullies was swept regularly by avalanches. The route from C1 was traverse of the South Face.

On April 21, Yoshida's party stretched 20 pitches of fixed rope across several ice gullies and broken rock face. They extended the ridge an elevation of 6150m. The next day they extended 2 more pitches up an ice wall, and they came out on the NE Spur. From there the NE Spur that there were towers piled upon towers, cliff upon cliff, huge vertical columns which tapered like spires and shining curtains festooned with icicles, hanging down the precipices from the cornices above. There were great bulges and chasms wrenched by the wind and cold into fantastic mushroom shapes which had the likeness of night monsters. The fixed ropes were flung all over the place to secure the members and high atitude porters from falling into the sheer depths below. We had found old fixed ropes on the ridge presumably belonging to the 1977 and 1987 Indian expeditions. We stretched 34 pitches of fixed ropes from C1 to C2. C2 pitched a strip place the cornices above on the NE Spur an elevation of 6300m on 27 April.

On 28 April, Nazuka's party started route making for C3. From there the NE Spur also there were huge vertical mushroom shapes which had the likeness of monsters. There were cornices which could not be climbed in any way. They passed through a natural tunnels to surmount there. They extended the route 9 pitches up on the rugged ridge from 28 April till 30 April.

On 1st May, Yoshida's party stretched 9 pitches of fixed rope across big crevasses and several huge ice cliffs, and they reached an elevation of 6550m. They extended the route 10 more pitches up on the snow rugged ridge on the following day, and they reached an elevation of 6880m. C3 perched on a snow slope where the 5 pitched below the highest reaching point of the 2 May and elevation of 6800m on 4 May. At that point the NE Spur came into widely snow ridge with no technical difficulty. Below one looks down a steep slope at the Upper Zemu Glacier and the Twins Glacier.

On 4 May we set up C3 at the height of 6800m we had reached the previous day.

On 6 May, Ogata's party reached a point of the NE Spur where there were huge ice cliffs at 7250m. We strung 14 pitches of fixed rope up the snow ridge for two days.

The next day Oda's party succeeded in reaching a point of C4 at the height of 7450m. They strung six and half pitches of fixed rope up the NE Spur. 

On 9 May we established C4, and Nazuka's party stayed the first night at C4. Next morning Nazuka's party started on the route on the NE Spur derived from the Junction Peak and rope were fixed all the way. The route from C4 was up a snow ridge with very steep arete, and this the arete culminating at the highest point the NE Spur. From there the arete below one looks down the North Col on the North Ridge and beyond North Col there is a view of Nepal Himalayas. After four days work to complete this route, 4 Indian climbers reached C5 at the height of 7800m on 14 May. The next day they have set up C5 with two high altitude porters.

On May 15 Pasang Sherpa, Khem Raj, Sharki Bhutia and Lopsang Tshering went for reconnaissance to find a final camp. They reached old camp site of Indian expedition in 1977 and 1987 at height of about 8000m. They returned back to C5. The same day's morning, Sato and I [Ogata] started the labourious work to carry up the luggage to C5 and we reached C5 at noon. We met four Indian members just the same time.

They told us about the ascent route for the summit which can be seen from the reaching highest point on today. I thought that they have caught an easy going way of thinking for attack to the summit.

The next day they had thunder clap of accident. They made a start from C5 at just 4:00 am. Four Indians members reached to the old camp site of Indian expedition, they deposited their carrying loads at the place, and continued up the summit of Kangchenjunga at their own discretion with one oxygen cylinder to each of the members.

During their attack Pasang Sherpa tragically fell off to the North Face side and was missing.
Though the accident upset the plan considerably, I have made again plan for attack to the summit.

We went into mourning for Pasang Sherpa at each camp on following day. We regained the final stage of our expedition with heavy hearts.

On 23 May, seven Japanese members who were constituted into a support party and on 24 May the summit party, they went up to the North Face, and reached an elevation of 7950m on the North Face. They established C6 at this point, and now they were getting the full blast of the westerlies. Nazuka and Imamura stretched 7 pitches of fixed rope in the snow gully at the rear of C6. The support party returned, leaving Hideji Nazuka, Hirotaka Imamura and Ryuzo Oda at C6. When they tried to fix their oxygen regulators they found that there were two sets only. We discussed the best attack plan by walkie-talkie between C6 and BC, and we decided that Nazuka attempt an attack of the summit without oxygen.

On 24th May, they made a start at just 4:00 am in biting cold. Oda was carrying two oxygen cylinders and Imamura was carrying one oxygen cylinder they started climbing. They added another 3 pitches of fixed rope for safety on the descent. Very soon Imamura collapsed owing to the some trouble on the oxygen mask that Imamura was not getting any oxygen flow. He left his oxygen cylinder and he began climbing again without oxygen. At 8:15 am Oda left one of his half used oxygen cylinder to be used on the return journey. They slogged on and on, in deep snow and fierce winds. Sometimes the winds were so strong that they were pushed of their feet. At 10:57 am Nazuka reached the West Col on the main ridge of between Main Peak and Yalung Kang (West Peak). From there the summit ridge of Kangchenjunga becomes traversed a snow and rock mix face the Yalung glacier side, he escaped to some partly fierce winds. He climbed along the Yalung Glacier side of the summit ridge to the main summit. It was 11:50 am when Nazuka stood on the summit of Kangchenjunga. He remembered the promise the team had given to the people of Sikkim. He left the last 7 feet untrodden. He took pictures and came back the same way he went in carefully, and he returned back the West Col at 13:00 and then he met Oda. Imamura had not yet reached the Col. Imamura reached the West Col climbing up the summit ridge. Very soon Imamura joined Oda. They finally stood up on the summit at 15:23, and returned back C6 in darkness at 22:30 in the night.

Next early morning the second summit party, consisting of Coy Commander SD Sharma, Subedar Kanhaiya Lal and Sub-Inspector T Smamla started from C6 to summit. They reached the summit of Kangchenjunga at 14:30 and returned back Camp 6 in safety at 19:48.

Because of the time and weather constraints most of the members both Japanese and Indians had to sacrifice their chance to summit the peak as to support their colleagues in the best mountaineering tradition. Thus six members could reach the summit.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing except Pasang's fatal fall; Ogata fell 20m but not hurt

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7900m due to bad weather and team's lack of strength, etc
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 at Batard's snow cave on Lhotse Face
C4 at South Col
High point at South Col.

Started going up W Shoulder 24th April and reached US 1963 C4 site at c7400m on shoulder; by now only 3 members still climbing and felt not strong enough (2 had left and Pickering had stopped) and Sherpas to C2 only (scared of W Ridge and plan was to move very light weight).

Other teams gave no objection to switch to S Col route and while awaiting HMG permission moved up to Col. 2 May weather both windy and storm front coming in) and Groom down to BC on 2nd while Coulton and Dignan now down to C2 on 3rd and BC on 4th. Left BC 10th May.


Sachit Pant, HMG - 15 Sept 1991

Permission to change route refused because of the number of other teams already granted permission.

BC at normal site
C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at Col.

Sherpas [from First Sherpa Youth Expedition] made 3 unsuccessful summit bids with first one on 24th and got to SE Ridge above SE Face "when defeated by wind" as on next two tries. On 2nd try got near S Summit; 3rd really not an attempt (did not get out of C4 tents); this 3rd bid was about 2nd May. 

Athans and Matous left C2 on 5th May for Lhotse summit and reached C3. Steve developed bad headache and used oxygen that night and 6th went down to C2 and Athans stayed at C3 to wait for Sherpas to mount their 4th Everest attempt. Athans and 3 Sherpas to C2 on 7th and to top on 8th, starting together but Athans fell behind struggling with video camera. Athans had left col at 2 am and Sherpas on top at 9:00 am and Athans 10:00 am on top (Sherpas waited at top for Athans) on cold and windy day. For Sherpas this was last summit bid; they were burned out.

Lhotse very dry and lot of bare rock and blue ice; whole of Lhotse Face "blinking of blue ice." Icefall huge crevasse. So with partner and rope Athans would have gone for Lhotse summit but not alone (Athans not soloist, likes sharing experience with someone else).

BC at normal site
C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at Col.

Took 12 hours to reach summit because of deep and dry loose snow; for every step took, slid back half a step; it was "mind-boggling." Started out on oxygen but about 9:30 am it ran out (leaky bottle) and carried on without it. Wendel back at C4 from C3 on 14th and went no higher and on 15th to C2 with Wangchu Sherpa. Goff climbed an hour with Viesturs above C4 and turned back tired, cold feet and not going fast enough; not mentally prepared for summit push. 

Amy Wendel got to C3 twice (1st time got sick, 2nd time not motivated). All members reached C3. All left BC 18th May. Nepalese expedition said they would not maintain icefall beyond 18th May. 
Wendels were disappointed and Hall Wendel wants to try again. Viesturs will bring fewer Americans and hire more Sherpas. Had stocked C4 for 12 people (all members and 4 Sherpas) and that needed too much hard work from guides (Wendels carried no loads). Will pitch C5 next tine for Wendel's ascent.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7900m due to wind and lack of strength
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 in Western Cwm
C2 on Lhotse Face.

Kessler and Joos up 2nd time to 7200m but again down as on 14th because of wind. 5th May to 7200m and 6th May to Col, but down on 7th to BC May (used Athans' tent at col) because of wind and Joos developing frostbitten nip on nose. Called off climb on 13th because winds and tired. Other 4 members were always one day behind Joos and Kessler and never reached col because lead men radioed no point in coming up. 

Expedition had permit for S Pillar but made no attempt to climb it. Asked at BC for col permit, never received answers but this fact did not affect climb.

BC  at road
ABC at North Col
C1  at North Col
C2  on North Ridge
C3  on North Face.

2 members and 1 Sherpa to N Col in April for acclimatization then back to KTM to pick up baggage (20 from France and other items from Japan) and to rest. 27th April left KTM with 5 Sherpas; Chinese customs problem, back to KTM for papers; crossed on 28th and on to BC and ABC on 3rd, which was too fast for Sherpas to acclimatize and sent them back to BC. Decided to cancel highest camps to save time. Down to Shegar on 18th May for rest while Sherpas ferried loads to C2. Returned to BC 20th May and up mountain for ABC 22 May. Left C3 at 1:30 am of 27th and got to top 1 pm; climbed in almost full moonlight and then clear morning with little wind - Futagami little later than others. 1:45 pm started descent in fog in same as reached top. Nukita 150m distant from top with 2 Sherpas just behind but Phinzo reported did not see Futagami. They returned to summit and found his footprints 20m from summit. Phinzo went to edge and said he saw traces of where body had fallen. Nonetheless left rope fixed case he came back and returned to C3 at 9:30 pm; light flashing all night; left stocked C3. Nukita down on 28th to ABC, 29th to BC and arrived KTM last night while Sherpas are packing up and coming to border 3 June.
ACCIDENTS: No problem at all until fatal fall, until then "everything went perfectly"

ROUTE1: A couloir just W of N Col-N Ridge
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8300m due to extreme cold
ROUTEMEMO:
No more fixed camps but at least once
Biv used tent at others camps
High point at North Ridge.

Skied up to 6500m to "casual couloir" east of N Col leading to N Ridge. 3 summit attempts: 

(1) 1 May - left bivouac and C1 that night at 8100m, which had reached at 11 am; had to stop instead of going straight through to top because of wind and snow; had bivouac sack but very light load; snowed all night and got very cold; down to C1 2 May and ABC 3rd. 

(2) 10th May from ABC to C1, 11th to 8000m in 11 hrs; really windy; had tent and sleeping bag which slowed him; down to N Col that night because couldn't get own tent up; used Mike Perry's empty tent at col; ABC in 11th. 

(3) 17th May from ABC to C1; 18th stayed at C1 because of snowfall; 19th from C1 at 7 am to 7900m at 2 pm and bivouac here with tent; 20th to 8200m and bivouac here; 21st from here at 3 am and reached 8300m in 1 hr (not carrying anything) but now "the cold was incredible" and down to 8200m where met others in their camp but not to go on down but to go up with them on 22nd; Brice and Taylor tried for top but Anderson did not go up in the extreme cold; Anderson down to 7900m, where stayed in British tent; 23rd to C1 and 24th to ABC; never actually climbed with anyone else.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8200m due to no permit to climb
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 in ice cave on Lhotse Face
High point on SE Ridge.

1st May started form BC at 6am and reached 8200m at 6 pm; turned back in bad weathar that started at col (slight snowfall but big wind) where others were waiting for improvement; went alone to 8200m and then stopped (was also very cold) and down to BC; arrived BC 6 pm after having left bivouac at 8200m at 5 am on 2 May. Now decided not to continue climbing because expected permit not granted. Permit was actually granted (French ambassador was so informed) but Sonam of Thamserku Tkg and Ang Tshering of Sherpa Society gave a lot of money ($5000+) to Sachit Pant, a Tourism Ministry official, to induce him not to give written permission.

Will not try to climb again in Nepal. Will concentrate upon Alps and spend more time with his children and will make training film about climbing. For his group for Everest for Autumn 1991: will suggest Pakistan or S America. "I have climbed Everest twice and I am happy" and has no more patience with Nepalese. On his return to France, he will inform authorities about 2 members of Sonam-Ang Tshering family working there illegally and (left BC 5th May) discuss with French trek organizers from using these agencies.
