Sonam and Ang Tshering are brothers; another brother Tendi works with Ang Tshering and he sent Batard a fax in France saying that if Batard did not employ their agency to represent him, he would not get his permit for Everest this spring.


Miss Marie-Annick - 4 July 1991

French ambassador was told on phone by tourism secretary that Batard would be granted Everest permit this spring. Batard had already left KTM for Khumbu but Maurice Uguen was still in town pressing for permit. Neither ambassador nor she talked in ministry.


Bikram Pandey - 26 June 1991

Trying till 28 June to get permit for Batard for autumn 1991. Pandey asked Batard to let him try for permit and Batard agreed recently but asked for outcome very soon.


4 July 1991 - HMG has formed committee and their attitude is not very favorable, so telling Batard today [chances] for permit are not good.


Ang Tshering (Sherpa Society) - 25 June 1991

HMG has formed a committee of Tourism and Immigration officials to investigate Batard's activities. Fear his statements in France can harm flow of French tourists to Nepal - this is Tourism minister's ideas.


Sachit Pant, Tourism Ministry - 9 May 1991

Batard will not get permission for Everest for this spring, and permit he already had for autumn 1991 has been suspended and its restoration uncertain.

Batard's photographer Maurice Uguen in April met and photographed Prime Minister Bhattarai and Ganesh Man Singh and spoke with both about pending spring permit. About 9 trekking agents informally met with PM who asked if they wanted charges of bribery of Tourism Ministry officials to go to Special Police Dept - they said they did not. Still, if Tourism gave permit when application had been filed only in April, bribery charges would become loud and clear.

Autumn permit suspended after charges of Batard's beating Sonam Sherpa's wife (Pasang Lhamu) last autumn.


Chris Hawthorne, Australian Everest - 8 May 1991

Batard left BC early morning and got above C3 on Lhotse Face but got blown down to BC - about 1 May.
Waiting for permit to make another try.
Maurice and doctor at BC - other climber.


Bikram Pandey, Amtrek - 2 May 1991
Batard Everest:

Sonam's letter of no objection applies to autumn 1991 not this spring. Sachit Pant of Tourism learned that Joint Secretary Pradhan had agreed orally to give Batard permit and immediately objected, raising possibility of bribery. There was a charge against Batard of "man-handling" Sonam's wife (Pasang Lhamu) as well as not allowing her to try for Everest summit last autumn.


Pandey - 14 May 1991

Joint Secretary actually put his full signature on Batard's application, giving permission, but Pant refused to let permit be typed out, told Secy that Sherpas would protest to the Secy and Pant could not be responsible for consequences; so Secretary held Batard file.


Batard - 22 April 1991

Tourism Ministry official to Bhola Rana of problem now about Batard's permit for Everest and Lhotse for this spring is that there is an allegation that he has been getting a lot of permits in recent years without waiting by bribing a tourism official who now is Joint Secretary in Tourism. Prime Minister Bhattarai says if permit is approved, he will send case to Special Police to investigate.

SPONSOR: Meiji University Alpine Club Qomolangma Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to extreme difficulty of route
ROUTEMEMO:
1st C1 at Kangshung Glacier
2nd C1 at East Ridge
High point at East Ridge.

Very difficult and dangerous route to 1st site of C1 which had to place well below snowfield planned for this camp (and where it was later placed): very sharp rock ridge with many snow mushrooms. From 1st to 2nd C1 same problem plus huge crevasse on ridge. Above 2nd C1 more severe problems and took 4 days to reach 6400m; everyday could make only 2 or 3 trips with ice and snow becoming very loose in daytime; sharp ridge with steep ice face. "I don't think it is possible" to climb this ridge in reasonable time and becoming increasingly dangerous with pieces of mushrooms breaking off - even in colder weather would take very long time and Sherpas don't want to climb this route. Would have taken 1 or 2 more months to reach NE Ridge. One member joked they might reach summit by end of the year; stopped climb before some got hit by falling ice or had bad fall. 

Left BC 16th May. Sent 2 Sherpas to Karta on 7th May to bring porters, who are very difficult people demanding higher and higher wages and want to walk only 2-3 hrs daily.

BC at Rongbuk.

De Marchi and De Stefani in 1st summit attempt made biv 7950m 4th May and on 5th reached 8350m and put camp there. 6th May stayed at C4 and on 7th De Stefani got cerebral edema and down that day with help from others. 8th reached C2 with De Stefani barely conscious. 9th to C1, 10th to Swedish ABC and their doctor (De Marchi exhausted and both feet frostbitten; De Stefani also frostbitten toes and will loose parts of 2 fingers). 11th Tibetans carried De Stefani to BC and Jeep took him and Thomaseth (to help him all the way to Italy) while De Marchi stayed at ABC few days longer. 

On 14th May Banali and Sulovsky to C2, 15th to C3, 16th C4 and same evening fixed 40m above it. 17th left C4 7 am, took 2 hrs on 70m of rocks above (3m of it took most of this time: vertical rock) and Sulovsky on top 3:25 pm and Banali 15-20 minutes later. Weather clear till 2 pm when clouds came over and on top was snowing but no wind; 7 pm back to C4 and on down to C3 at 11 pm with only one ice ax between them (one dropped during ascent). 18th in C1 by 6 pm. 19th all in ABC and 20th in BC. 

Above 3m vertical route was small couloir also very difficult. Route was much more difficult technically even to C4 than De Stefani expected, but fixed only 70m of rope (above C4).
ACCIDENTS: 2 serious frostbite cases (De Stefani and De Marchi); 1 cerebral edema (De Stefani)

COUNTRIES: Australia, France, New Zealand, Norway, USA
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at road (normal Chinese BC)
C1  at North Col
C2A on NE Ridge (old C2 site)
C3A at foot of Pinnacles on NE Ridge 
C2B above N Col
C3B just below North Ridge.

8th May Barker tried for top from C2 and got to 8400m without oxygen (no members used oxygen) and turned back because too cold and down to C2. 

On 5th Taylor and Brice to NE Ridge C1 and 16th to C2 at foot of pinnacles. Brice got sick so stayed 17th in camp and 18th down to ABC. This the end of NE Ridge attempt because running short of time. 

20th Taylor and Brice to N Ridge C2 with 2 Sherpas and 21st to C3. 22nd made summit bid: Taylor and Brice climbed only 100m and turned back because of cold and 2 Sherpas, Ang Babu (Everest top 1990) and Chuldin, to summit with oxygen at 11:30 am; Sherpas and Taylor down to C2 on 22nd; Brice to ABC. 23rd ABC evacuated and left BC 26th. 

Terrible winds: of 50-odd tents not one that doesn't need repairs; winds up to 120 km/hr at ABC and lost every tent. Redmond unable to make any attempt at paragliding.
ACCIDENTS: Lemaire serious frostbite in toes between C2 and C3 on N Ridge

ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at South Col.

Dropped loads at C3 22 April and then down to Pheriche for a week's rest as planned. 2nd May M Richey, Chauvin, Rugo and Wilcox reached C4. Evening of 1st and 2nd May 100 mph winds. 3rd May switched to "survival mode" and 2 frostbitten Australians taken into US tent and put them on oxygen; only about 11 am could descend and all down to C2, Then 1 week rest at BC. 

9th May again up: Scott, Laforest, Sinclair, Wilcox, M Richey and Rugo to C2 (Chauvin turned back to BC tired from C1, others stayed at C2). Richey, Scott, Wilcox, Rugo, Laforest and Tshering Lhakpa left with them for summit (3 other Sherpas also, in support carrying loads). Sinchair to C3 only and Tshering Lhakpa turned back just above C3. Wilcox, Richey, Rugo and Laforest on C4 at 4 pm, assumed Scott had turned back, but at midnight had radio contact with BC and learned Scott had not arrived at any camp. Foursome had planned to go to top that night but now turned attention to finding Scott, who turned out to be lost at top of Geneva Spur and got him to C4 on oxygen and postponed summit attempt by one day; were really tired anyway so spent day resting using oxygen occasionally all day. Scott down on 14th. Midnight of 14th 4 left C4 in excellent weather for top while Sinclair up to C4 on 15th. Was still clear and low winds when got to top. Rugo ran out of oxygen in descent and arrived at C4 only at 6:00 pm and Wilcox at 7:00 pm, when wind and clouds had started closing in.

SPONSOR: International Mountain Guides (IMG) Everest N Face Expedition 1991
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at road
C3 at standard site
C4 at North Col
C5 on North Ridge
C6 on North Face.

Second Step is quite steep ("no way Mallory and Irvine climbed that route") and someone had left the ladder there which was very helpful. Month of April (that many high winds and took long time to manage to put in C5) had 4 summit bids. [On 1st bid Simonson, Dunn, Politz, Sloezen, Ang Dawa and Lhakpa Dorje summited on 15 May.]

2nd one on 16th 4 members [Hahn, Huntington, Perry, Rheinberger] and 2 Sherpas [Ang Jangbu, Pasang Kami] got to First Step, turned back because of winds and all down except Perry, who stayed at C6 and summitted alone on 17th. 

3rd group 6 members [Edwards, Frantz, Okita, Van Hoy, Whetu, Wilson] on 21st tried for top: Whetu and Okita went up to top with oxygen while other 4 without it turned back because of cold. Wilson was member of this 3rd group; stayed on at C6 three more nights and went to top alone on 24th, this time using oxygen and again one more night at C6.

15th May summiters in chronological order: US Wilcox party; Simonson and 6 in order shown above (Simonson 12:30 pm NST); Ed Viesturs from south, who met Politz already on top; Swedish expedition's Sherpas.

Lhakpa Dorje summited Everest with Canadians in 1982; this was Ang Dawa's first expedition to any mountain.

Much hypocracy about climbing Everest alpine style: Robert Anderson and Marcus Schmucks's team talked about their alpine-style climbing, but they were given food and oxygen by Simonson's team and they used his team's tents.

BC at normal site
C1 at top of Icefall
C2 in Western Cwm
C3 on Lhotse Face
C4 at Col.

Sherpas made 3 unsuccessful summit bids with first one on 24th April and got to SE Ridge above SE face "when defeated by wind" as on next 2 tries. On 2nd try got near S Summit; 3rd really not an attempt (did not get out of C4 tents); this 3rd bid was about 2nd May. 

Athans and Matous left C2 on 5 May for Lhotse summit and reached C3. Steve developed bad headache and used oxygen that night and 6th went down to C2 and Athans stayed at C3 to wait for Sherpas to mount their 4th Everest attempt. Athans and 3 Sherpas to C4 on 7th and to top on 8th, starting together but Athans fell behind struggling with video camera. Athans had left col at 2 am and Sherpas on top at 9:00 am and Athans 10:00 am on top (Sherpas waited at top for Athans) on cold and windy day. For Sherpas this was last summit bid; they were burned out.


1 Feb 2006

Nima Tashi is claiming summit success with this team. Apa Sherpa today confirmed that the only summiters were Sonam Dendu, Ang Temba and Apa himself. He is very certain about that.
ACCIDENTS: Lhakpa Gyalu broke leg April 2-3 in icefall collapse at 3:30 pm

ROUTEMEMO:
Technically difficult route (1) from C1 to C2 and (2) from C5 in Hornbein Couloir: (1) section 60-80 degrees ice with stone fall on 50m section (had to climb early here) (2) difficult rock.

3 summit attempts:

1. Bidner and Mingma Norbu from C4; 7th May at C5 had problem with oxygen and stopped.

2. 15th May Fagrell, Fredholm, Mingma Norbu and Gyalbu from C5; at 8650m Fredholm's oxygen finished and he descended. At 8800m Fagrell's oxygen finished and couldn't breath and half hour or more to top on ridge and windy on ridge, so Fagrell stopped while 2 Sherpas went to top and returned to Fagrell; all 4 slept at C5.

3. 20th May Cronlund and 2 Sherpas from C5. 2 Sherpas dumped their oxygen bottles (full) at top of Hornbein Couloir as planned and descended. Cronlund went on as planned to summit; on Cronlund's descent he was in hurry because getting dark (at 7:00 pm darkness would come) and he went wrong at snowfield and could not find top of fixed ropes at top of couloir. He decided to stop where he was at 8600m with moonlight. He went around in circles most of night but 7:00 am he got up from having fallen asleep. All toes had frozen but may not loose any parts of them. No wind during night but in morning it was blowing and he had difficult time getting down to C5, from which one member climbed up to meet him at 8500m and help him to C5, where he stayed and where there was more oxygen.

Now expedition decided to withdraw from mountain. Cronlund's ordeal through night of 20th was enough and expedition had succeeded.
ACCIDENTS: 1 Sherpa's hand broken bare from falling stone; Cronlund frostbite

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8550m due to wind, destruction of too many tents
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at North Col
C3 just below North Ridge
High point just below First Step.

Very strong wind above col and very cold. 2 members up to 8550m on 15th May in summit bid but cold wind forced retreat and couldn't continue because too many tents destroyed. C2 destroyed 8th May (was 1 tent) and C1 alredy destroyed and replaced by cave. The 2 members left ABC 12 May carrying 20 kg each of all gear needed for summit bid. Team left ABC 16th to leave Tibet and 18th from BC. All members brought their own tents, sleeping bags, etc "just like with Alps." 

Lang tried to climb new way to N Ridge via couloir directly south of ABC (without going west to N Col and start of N Ridge). Lang was alone. Started from ABC 1 May and reached 7100m in couloir. 2 May got to 7600m and then weather changed dramatically: wind, snow and very cold and could occasionally be seen moving slowly. 3 May got to 7900m still in couloir; died at this biv. No one went to him because of weather. 7th May could again see his biv and a sitting fixed sleeping bag but face not visible. Have given 4 May as date of death but really didn't know when he died; he was good climber but too impatient to wait for good weather (had been to 8550m on Everest via S Col 2-3 years ago on international expedition, had succeeded on Gasherbrum I and II and was now trying to do the summit).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8650m due to bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 at bivs above near top of Japanese Couloir
C3 below Hornbein Couloir (2 hours below, 3 tents)
High point at West Ridge.

From BC 6th Sept 1st summit bid and stopped at 8200m because very cold. Boyer, Chamoux, Campredon, Parmentier, Rakoncaj, Rossi, Sichap, Dorotei, Tournaire and 2 Sherpas so back to C3. Then down in bad weather. 

Next summit bid 13th Sep from BC and got on 16th Sep to 8600m at 3 pm, too high for biv without frostbite with no oxygen; had no rope [Dorotei to 8300m, Boyer to 8450m, Rossi and Chamoux to 8650m, Rakonaj and Camredon to c8600m, Tournaire and Parmentier to c8600m].

Here technically difficult at W Ridge. Down to C3 on 16th and 3 of them to BC on 17th while Parmentier stayed in C3 with plan to solo to top in good weather. From 17th to 24th snow fall daily and very cold and windy (constant snow). Parmentier 17-18th in C3, 19th up and pitched small tent at 8200m, 20th up in Hornbein's deep snow. At 1 pm his track seen to 8400m, then cloudy and no further contact on sighting (21st briefly clear and even track not seen). 

22nd up from BC Chamoux, Campredon and Rakoncaj in 3rd summit bid and C1 very windy and down to BC next day and climb finished. Last members on mountain left Chinese BC 27th. Snowfall had brought avalanche danger (which probably took Parmentier).


Lluis Belvis (Spanish Everest) - 20 Oct 1988 (regarding Parmentier's death)

Members of this expedition found Parmentier at 7700m about 50m beside his tent. They speculate that he had been unable to find the tent and froze to death (unable because of bad weather probably). Body found in early Oct.

SPONSOR: Slovene Himalayan Expedition to Kangchenjunga & Jannu
OTHERSMTS: Climbed Kangchenjunga (KANG-911-02), Kangchenjunga Central (KANC-911-01), Kangchenjunga South (KANS-911-01); attempted Jannu (JANU-911-01)
ROUTEMEMO: From Kangchenjunga BC, 19 April Marko and Stremfelj left BC for Talung and made biv at 6500m up NW Face to west slopes. 20th to summit by Marko and 50m below by Stremfelj because strong winds and back to BC: left BC 8:30 am, on top 12:00 pm and with good snow conditions but high winds (had been some hard ice between serac below biv and crevasses also, below with just one bridge) and back at BC 5:00 pm same day, very tired.

BC at glacier northwest of Talung and southeast of point 5520m on Yoshino map
C4 below couloir which climbed.

After making C4, bad weather (snow and strong wind) so all down to BC. 2 days in BC, then 8th Oct to C1, 5 members and 2 Sherpas. 9th Oct 1st team to C4 and 2nd team to C3. 11th Oct 3 members and 2 Sherpas towards summit in strong cold wind (-25 degrees at C4). Sherpas turned back at 8100m and at 8300m a member hit by falling stone which penetrated his hat and down to C4 with a member to help him. Iriarte was ahead and unaware of Bereziartua's accident so carried on to summit, which reached at 1 pm. On 11th Urbieta arrived at C4 while others of 2nd team stayed in C3; climb finished now. 

Others including Sherpas not in good condition, leader injured and weather not so good; many falling stones in couloir, route not technically difficult and safe to C4.

22 days to reach BC from Dharan because of earthquake damage to road and trails; 5 days to KTM from BC.
ACCIDENTS: Leader hit by falling stone which left him unconscious 10 minutes

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to snow conditions at late time in spring
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on west side of Lhotse Glacier
C1 at saddle between Island Peak and Lhotse/Lhotse Shar
C2 on SE Buttress
C3 on face from Buttress
xxx at C3.

Arizzi and Cormier unable to go to C2 and left early. Took only safe line by going far to right onto SE Buttress. Alpine style in good clear weather without snow on face is safe direction. Messner put C2 - made an intermediate camp which at end was called C3. Messner had hoped to place C3 at 7500m and from there for attempt on summit with one bivouac at 7800-8000m. At beginning almost all sick with only 2 Poles and Kammerlander working. Lost a week to 10 days here and when bad weather came at 13 May were not in position. Profit and Kammerlander went up to C3 after Messner and 2 Sherpas had placed summit gear at this camp. 

Profit and Kammerlander started from BC 10 and 12 May to C3 on 13th for summit push on 15th. Profit in early May had done to traverse left from C3 with Hajzer and they reached to Polish route. On 13th night snowfall began and Profit and Kammerlander down to BC. Now every day fell.

2 Poles [Hajzer and Wielicki] started from BC on 12 May up Polish route, carrying all gear and did approx 500m/day and in 4 days reached 7100m on this route but now weather stopped them, did risky traverse to C3, where slept night of 16th and to BC on 17th. 

Lucas and Profit tried again via SE Buttress. Left BC 18th in slightly better weather. On 19th in C3. Lucas tired and down immediately; Profit tried traverse but too much snow there and he also down. Neither slept C3. Was again snowing and reached clear and windy weather for 3-4 days to clear it.


Cormier - 29 Apr 89

Left Lhotse expedition BC on 24 April because too much fighting amongst members. Face has no snow and is very windy. Route is via Lhotse Shar with long traverse above 7200m to Lhotse Face Polish route. Route too long and not interesting.
ACCIDENTS: Kammerlander injured leg but continued to climb; Losso slight frostbite

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5200m due to shoulder injury
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Messner BC site
C1 at beginning of NW Face 
High point at C1.

Everyday snow, wind storm and cold. Went to C1 but did not sleep in tent he pitched there on 24th April. Because of heavy snowfall, had fixed 20m rope and came down to BC same day. Had to stay in BC 5 days because of storm, falling stones and many snow avalanches which came through C1 and broke tent. 

30th April returned to C1 on first possible day and found tent broken, so down to BC. Tried to fly by parapente but blown only 1 minute and wind caused crash landing at 5000m (same place where had been on 23rd and had successful parapented to BC with same wind problem that closed but again opened parapente). Shoulder dislocated in crash landing. He relocated shoulder against rock and reached BC after 5:00 pm in beginning snowstorm. 3 or 4 May up to C1 to bring down gear there. In descent one piton came out from face and he fell 15m from 4800m and bruised his back. Cook had came part of the way to help bring down the gear and they came slowly down together to BC (but cook not helping Patscheider to descend).
ACCIDENTS: Patscheider dislocated his left shoulder and later bruised his back

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7170m due to bad weather and team's lack of strength
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 none
C2 at C2 normal site - NE Col
C3 at 50m above start of NE Ridge
C4 at end of snow ridge and 100m below start of traverse
High point at top of snow ridge.

On 6th May [Purto and Casassa] down from C3 at 6400m to C2 because cloudy, snowing and windy; leader Purto to BC, other 2 climbers [Casassa and Ang Phurba] in C2. 9th May one member [Valle] up to meet Casassa in C2 and on up to C3 and then retreated because bad weather. 10th May 2 members [Valle and Casassa] to C4 (Purto not well enough now to go up) and 11th May up only 20m and down to C2. Climb finished because few climbers now too tired to continue. Arrived BC 14th May.

Casassa decided he was finished, Valle wanted to try again but Purto not strong enough and Sherpas didn't want to go up. Had already had 3 attempts for summit and needed time to recover.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to much snowfall and illness
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Annapurna Sanctuary
High point at East Pillar.

2m+ snow at BC where team arrived there; almost continuous bad weather till 8th May. 1st 2 days very heavy snowfall continued. Most days snow began at midday. 5th May put C2 in place and down to C1 with the plan to go back up next day. Had lot of illness amongst members. 3 times one member went to C1 to go up to C2 but never was able to make it and Griffin had to go below BC with chest infection. C2 actually first occupied on 7 May and in next days were getting supplies up in order to go for summit from there. 4 members went up to C1 14 May for summit bid, 2 ill and down and 2 actually got to C2 and then also down on 15th. Weather still not settled and 1 of them left BC 19th. 

On 11 May high point of 6000m had been reached on 1st route. 1st route's pillar had apparently been tried before and locals said a tent had been found which had been placed by 3 Japanese who were never seen again. Route in bad condition till end of climbing period and illness meant could seldom get more than two on mountain at same time.

Griffin and Tinker tried alpine-style go at the Japanese route: started from BC on 19th and climbed at night, only time weather cleared and reached 5800m 21st night, sat there because of snowfall and 22nd to BC.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing serious but lot of minor illnesses

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to team too small, not enough rope etc., and too much snow
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at normal site
High point at C2 normal site.

Too small a team, not enough equipment and too much snow on glacier. Wanted to do Dutch route, but too difficult 80-100m icefall that way. Returned to BC 4th May. 5th May cleared C1 and 6th May left BC.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at NE col
C2 at start of ridge
C3 at end of ridge
High point at C3.

Spent one month in BC because an agent refused to let Italians climb at same time on same route despite fact Italians only 2 men in 1 tent. 4 days in C1 because snowing. Bad weather continued after C2 established but did make C3 and waited there one more day; but too much snow for night traverse to C4 site (too much avalanche danger here) so went down to BC on 3 May from C3 and climb finished. All 3 men climbed together; 2 Spanish and Ang Rita Sherpa.

COUNTRIES: Australia, Hong Kong, New Zealand, Norway
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Meme Pokhari
C1 at snow flat area on SW Ridge which here was mostly rocky
C2 at base of large snow basins
C3 at base of ice cliffs.

Lots of bad weather between 9th and 15th and again heavy snowfall on 27th, when 3m snow accumulated and was necessary to go down 3m into hole to enter C2's tent; on 29th night fixed ropes through ice cliff in bid to go to top and of these Gangdal and Bayne bived at 7000m, the high point reached in bad weather that day, while others down to C3. 

On 30th Gangdal and Bayne to summit and down to C2. 31st Brice and Mercer left C3 at midnight in thunder and lightning storm which provided good light and were on top 7:30 am of 1 June and back to C2 at 11:00 am; no more attempts because some not acclimatized and others too tired.

SW Ridge is long and somewhat technically difficult route; fixed 3500m rope.

Joint commercial expedition by Himalayan Kingdoms (UK) and High Country Expeditions (NZ).

SPONSOR: 1989 Nagasaki Asagiri Club Expedition to Lamjung Himal
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5950m due to bad weather (deep snow and wind)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC 6 hours south of Chame
C1 on SE Ridge
C2 at Col of knife ridge
High point at SE Ridge.

C1 to C2 depots at 4930m and 5000m because very long way between camps since no place for camp before site they used; made route halfway to C3 site, 200m to C3 and then no more due to bad weather, deep snow, high winds. 3 times went up to climb and three times forced down by weather. Left BC 24th April.
ACCIDENTS: Miss Yumiko altitude sickness at C1

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due to Suarez's death
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site above Samagaon
C1 on glacier
C2 on glacier
C3 above glacier on east side
C4 on ridge.

Climb going very well and planned summit bid on 8th or 9th May. Had all supplies necessary with them for C5 and four were strong. Suddenly Suarez was no longer just behind as they arrived at C5 site. "It was a clean expedition and everything was OK." No idea why he fell; he was just arriving at C5 site, only couple of meters behind others when he disappeared. He fell at 1:30 pm; slope was not steep (30 degrees) and he was on hard ice with both crampons OK; fell 500m and killed by fall ("head and everything was broken"). Could see his body from C5 site, reached him 2-3 hours later and buried him in crevasse at 6800m same day.

19 May: Brown believes Suarez fell because of cerebral edema and dehydration. Night before his death Suarez had headache. He and other Spaniards were not taking lots of liquids to hydrate themselves. Iraola also probably had edema and hypothermia on day Suarez fell.
ACCIDENTS: Quinterio slipped 150m but not hurt; Suarez fatal fall at 7100m

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6030m due to fatal avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lirung Glacier (500m above normal site)
C1 on SE Ridge.
High point at C2 site where snow field began on SE Ridge.

C2 site reached only on 18th March because one week heavy snowfall. Fixed rope to this site, then down to BC for rest. 4 members and 2 Sherpas to C1 on 18th March, so in BC 8 Japanese now. Each day in fact some members carrying loads to C1. 

On 21st March 8 Japanese and 2 Sherpas carrying to C1 with 4 to stay in C1; these 4 were Nishimara, Kuwashina, Matsumoto and sirdar. At about 4900m (1 hr walk from BC) avalanche at 10:43 am hit 4 members: Futami, Hisamoto and Kuwashina swept away; Matsumoto hit but not injured; Nishimura also in group but not hit. Avalanche started by small ice which hit snow slabs and slab came down; avalanche carried 400m down and over 20m ice cliff; 10 men in line on 21st; 1st 2 not touched and last 4 not touched (Nishimura last man).

10:43 avalanche struck Matsumoto, Futami, Kuwashina and Hisamoto; if 1 min later Nishimura dead. At 11:00 Nishimura found Futami's body (left arm stuck out of snow); sirdar found Kuwashina's body. At 4:30 pm Nishimura and 2 Sherpas left BC and arrived KTM 22 March 11:30 pm; others still in BC to search for Hisamoto whose rucksack and goggles found, until 15th April if necessary. Helicopter 28th or 29th March to bring bodies to KTM; families of dead arrived KTM 27th March.

BC at north end of Tilicho Lake
C1 at snow slope just below point where spur meets ridge
C2 at junction of spur.

Laot reached summit because is very strong climber but had difficulty returning to C1 because of snow and cloud. Was very windy that day, which was why Baillet and Ongel Sherpa turned back at 6920m. 

Technically difficult: 1st section of spur of snow-covered ice. C1 to C2 60 degrees and ice slope with 30m of 80 degrees. Last part of route again steep (50 degrees) snow-covered ice to 6800m, where is ice in difficult rocks.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due to snow & wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC below north side of East Ridge
C1 on East Ridge
C2 at plateau before East Pinnacle
High point northeast of East Pinnacle.

After made BC, had heavy snowfall so C1 only possible 10 days later. Fixed rope in couloir to get onto ridge and on ridge itself which very difficult rock requiring 300m rope. Had depot at 6250m where slept one night while moving gear. Route to C2 was north of E Ridge, just before ridge goes steeply up to E Pinnacle. From C2 tried twice for bivouac from which to go to summit (biv to be at about 7500m), but snow and wind defeated both attempts.

SPONSOR: Citta di Oggiono Expedition to Dhaulagiri
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at NE Col
C2 at beginning of ridge steep slope
C3 3/4 up slope
C4 at normal site.

No more on top because bad weather coming after 11th: everything set for Forno & Mandinelli to go to top, but would have had to wait few days & news came that Tibet opening. Wanted to climb Everest from Tibet, their original goal.

Snow very bad; much snowfall few days before 11th May & slab avalanche danger. Highest point of Dhaulagiri is really all rock & many photos by "summiters" taken below this point.

Argentinians left terrible mess of rubbish including medicine at BC.
ACCIDENTS: Zani fell in crevasse and hurt chest

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to alititude sickness
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 at NE Col
C2 on NE Ridge
C3 on NE Ridge
High point at C3.

7 Belgians climbed on Dhaulagiri. Le Bon and Mousny established C1 and C2 and Dewint and Moreau enlarged C2 and made next camp. In high camps used standing tents of Argentine and Chilean teams. 19th early morning down from C3. Dewint and Moreau had intended to go for top but Moreau got altitude sickness and slept all day, so these 2 the only in C3 on 17th; down to C1 (Moreau, who was brought down by 2 Sherpas on 20th) and to BC (Dewint). Others who were already down had decided not to go up again. 

Van Doorsselaere arrived from Makalu on 22nd but felt much too great danger in crevasses on glacier in warm weather and breaking snow bridges. Dewint discouraged by avalanching. Left BC 22 May in fog and snowfall; Le Bon and Moreau had left BC 21 May. 

Dewint and a Sherpa discussed going up but Sherpa's motivation was to earn money from gear he could bring down and then avalanching and glacier's condition convinced Dewint not to go up.

SPONSOR: Argentine Expedition Himalaya 1989 - to Dhaulagiri I
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7180m due to constant bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at base of icefall between Tukuche and Dhaulagiri I
C1 above icefall
C2 at NE Col
C3 on NE Ridge
C4 on NE Ridge (summit of rocky ridge)
High point at C4.

Everyday storms: snow and winds up to 200 kph occasionally. Was great experience but maybe too early arrival (was very cold and stormy) and team not so strong. C4 destroyed twice by wind, C3 also destroyed by snow. Were worn out going up and down because of destruction and replacement of equipment. Fixed rope all route from C3 and C4 and a lot of route from BC to C1. Left BC 26th April.

Expedition had originally been 9 members with 4 from Buenos Aires who organized it and 4 from mountains who are stronger climbers. When Argentinian currency devalued 60%, only half members could come and they were the people who had worked hard to organize it. None of those who came were sufficently strongly motivated to go for top on his own with couple of Sherpas.

SPONSOR: Korean Premonsoon Cho Oyu Exped Edelweisse Alpine Club 1989
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to crevasse and stonefall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Gyazumpa 
C1 same as Swiss C1
High point at 6600m on buttress.

Crossed icefall to C2, which placed on farther West Buttress than planned because planned buttress too dangerous from stone fall and strong wind. From C2 to C3 was icefall; above C3 at 6600m found 8m wide crevasse. Tried to go round crevasse but falling stone from bare rocks; climb finished. On 9 May one stone hit left arm of Cho and thought it broken.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5940m due to rotten rocks and Culver's decision to leave
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Kyashar Glacier between Kusum Kanguru and base of S Ridge of Thamserku
C1 at lateral moraine of Kyashar Glacier at base of East Face
C2 on East Face towards S Ridge
C3 just beside S Ridge (no room on North Ridge to camp).

Vos kicking steps in rock on 50 ft section powdery rock. From C2 all technical climbing and from here fixed rope (up entire route above). From C3 down to BC to rest (had colds). 13th from BC to C2, where almost smashed by large boulder that came down 1.5m from tent. 14th to C3, ate lunch started climbing S Ridge. Aprin climbed 500-600 ft (found Korean's rope) and got to stack of flakes totally loose; too dangerous and it simply came away. Culver had said he would quit by 16th. All snow and ice gear useless because only rock and had completely used up rock gear. Seems to be a pattern of glacier melting and rock bare on Nepalese mountains. 

Aprin would have tried on alternate line on smooth rock face, but Culver determined to leave.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6740m due to poor snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Ama Dablam Glacier ENE of mountain
BC2 at Churo (normal West Face BC)
C1  at normal site from SW Ridge
C2  on SW Ridge
C3  on SW Ridge
High point on West Face of normal route.

26th April reached high point of 5700m on NE spur leading to N Ridge; fixed 250m rope but found route too technical for most members. So abandoned NE on 26th without having any bivouacs or camps on this route and sought permit for SW Ridge and went around to Churo (no water at normal SW route BC and Americans still there).

29th April-3rd May made biv at 6350m at normal C2 site. Only 4 got there: 4 members rested 4-10th May at BC. 9th May up to biv site which really was C2 (3 up to C2, one member stayed at BC). 11th May other 3 members moved onto W Face from SW Ridge. Pickering stopped at 6600m because of altitude sickness/nerves while 2 members carried on up to 6740m at 4:30 pm and then turned around because of late time, snow sugary and called it quits. Too risky on last 60m in sugary snow with only ice seracs. Groom felt cold in his amputated toes and fingers (frostbitten on Kangchenjunga a year and a half ago).
ACCIDENTS: None; 2 members left early because of home-sickness

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6460m due to unsafe route without greater supply of rope
ROUTEMEMO:
BC as same as US-UK expedition's BC (new and higher normal site)
High point at base of West Face from SW Ridge.

High point reached 11:30 20 Apr. Had used up all rope, but blue ice above let them "not feel safe soloing." Stopped climb because of this and face that had loose rock above C2 which led to decision not to go through this area after carrying loads to any C3, but to go alpine-style above C2. There was some rock fall from this, but helmets were good protection (and very much indeed in spring time).
ACCIDENTS: Ostgaard serious eye trouble and left BC Apr 14

ROUTE2: SW Pillar-W Face up; W Ridge-W Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Nangpa Glacier at Kangshung (long way from foot of mountain)
C1  on glacier
1st biv directly at bottom of SW Buttress
2nd biv on buttress
3rd biv on buttress
4th biv where buttress joins normal route on west side.

Buttress that was attempted in Aut 1987 by Udall's American expedition was original objective, and Buhler and Zabaleta took a look at them, but they were too difficult for a 2-man team, too dangerous and "so far from the summit."

So went for Poles 1986 SW Buttress. Did some acclimatization climbing before their push up the buttress. After had established C1 on 25 March there was a storm for 5 days in BC. Then acclimatization climb to 6000m. Started alpine-style push for summit on 4 April, got to top on 8th from 4th bivouac at 7480m and back to this biv to sleep night of 8th there. On 9 April descended NW Ridge (normal route in Tibet) to 5840m (via Nangpa La); was "incredibly cold" and Buhler worried about frostbite but did not suffer any.

On his return from Cho Oyu, Buhler told PM Shrestha in Tourism Ministry he had broken his promise not to cross border into Tibet. Shrestha not deeply concerned.

Kearney got pulmonary edema below BC and was at BC only 31 March to 4 April when other 2 were in Tibet.

Sirdar Lhakpa Dorje sick a lot and left the expedition early, back just at end.
ACCIDENTS: None (Kearney sick and did no climbing)

SPONSOR: 25th Anniversary Mountain Travel Ama Dablam Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to route difficulty, lack strong commitment and time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at high site above Mingbo airstrip
C1 on SW Ridge
C2 at 2nd tower on ridge
High point at Mushroom ridge.

No fixed ropes or pitons to be found in place from previous expedition to end of Mushroom Ridge (C3) because they are constantly cleared by Sherpas. A lot of snow at BC area but ridge looked reasonably clear. All up to C1 on 28th (O'Connor and Sherpas day before), stayed 29th again C1 also while O'Connor and Sherpas fixed ropes above to the Pinnacle with little snow on ridge; fixed rope to Yellow Tower and made a dump before Yellow Tower where some expeditions place a C2. Put this team's C2 atop the next tower on 30th, but down to C1 same day. 31st snow started falling and down to BC. Snowed all next day and night and 2 members decided to leave BC for villages to let weather clear, but didn't clear for 4 days. 

Back up through deep snow returning to base on 5th April, where was 2 ft of snow, with winds clearing snow off the ridge. On 6th started making track above BC; got to C1 on 7th. 9th C2 occupied, 10th tried to reach C3 without success (O'Connor ill). Dead body (Charles Eckenfelder) found just above C2 (Spring 1988 Canadian). 11th O'Connor to C2 while others again up with rock falling and morale low. 12th O'Connor, Selzman and 2 Sherpas went up the couloir and beyond other's high point of 2 previous days and on along Mushroom Ridge in stone fall period to very close to C3 site and ran out of rope (Sherpas by now had stopped coming up). Pretty steep green ice and more of it above which would take 2 days to fix and party not skilled enough to make ropeless fast ascent. So time running out, morale weak and skill insufficent for going for it without fixing. Anyway next day it snowed though could have carried on, but "team had run out of steam." In descent Selzman rode a rock 60-70 ft in a rock slide.

SPONSOR: Japanese Mountaineering Group Ama Dablam Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5900m due to rockfall danger and lack of fuel supply
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on Ama Dablam Glacier
C1 on North Ridge
High point on North Ridge.

Before making C1, at 5450m rock avalanche damaged fixed rope; replaced rope but very dangerous climbing this area and some members didn't want to climb here; kept on going. 26th April to BC and kerosene finished (very expensive in Namche and money finished). Much falling rock from base rock and several times members very nearly hit in this dangerous areas at 5450m and 5700m.

OTHERSMTS: Climbed SW Smt of Langshisa Ri
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Langshisa Kharka
ABC towards Langshisa Glacier
C1  on West Face of southwest part of SE Ridge
C2  on South Face of main peak.

Very steep snow face above ABC to C1 at end of (plateau atop) face to Langshisa Ri's SW Peak. On 16th April Park and Nima Tamang to top of SW Peak (6154m) by mistake; down in bad weather to BC. 

15th April again up to C1, next day 2 men made C2 on main peak's S Face; started from C2 at 3:30 am, top 11:30 am, 12 left top, arrived BC 11:30 pm.
ACCIDENTS: Park fell 3-4m in descent from SW Peak but not hurt

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to winds and snow
ROUTEMEMO:
BC east of Gyazumpa on wedge of Lungsumpa Glacier
C1 below point 6500m on S Ridge
High point at S Ridge.

1st week very strong wind and impossible to go above 5900m because wind would blow one away. Schaer broke his leg on 18 April when at about 5300m when loose boulder trapped him and had to carry him to Gokyo for helicopter. Had spent a week before accident but unable to get higher than 5900m with winds. Lost a week taking Schaer down. Then back on same ridge and reached 6200m on way to C2 site at 6500m, then Koechli got sick (typhoid?) and Fischer left with him; left BC 27 April. Tried going up one more time but winds strong and deep snow above C1, so "it's enough." "Biggest problem was the wind" from southwest.

Rock buttress above thame on N Face Kwangde Nup followed line directly up crest to mixed section below headwall. Biv on ice ledge below headwall climbed 7 pitches on vertical headwall and back to high biv in one day. Steep rock (5.10, az) and mixed climbing. Rappeled down route. A good route but rock is only moderately sound.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6900m due to bad snow conditions and team not strong
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Panch Pokhari
C1 at west side of West Col
C2 just northwest of point 6730m.
High point at bottom of SE Ridge.

After BC fixed ropes at West Col on 5 May and next day all 12 reached C1. 7 May seven persons reached 6450m enroute to C2 then retreated, with all 12 down to BC that night. 9 May 3 members [Wilfert, Wilmes and Schmidt and 3 Sherpas up to C1 and 10 May to C2. 11 May Schmidt and Wilmes tried for summit and reached 6900m and returned to C1 because of deep snow with crust. Also both not in best health with colds and cough, exhausted by this tiresome slow progress. Left C2 at 6:30 am and turned back at 1:00 pm. 12 May back to BC with gear. No chance for further attempts because others also not in good health and no improvement at BC's altitude.

Came out via Amphu Laptsa which was difficult.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6860m due to route risk problem and little time left
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  west-northwest of Barun Pokhari
ABC on moraine northeast of Sherpani Col
C1  between points 6260m & 6480m on Schneider map
C2  at snowhole in crevasse in flat snowfield before South Ridge really starts.

Had biv site before C1. On 3 May made summit bid from C2. Left at 5:00 am reached high point at 11:30 am. Ridge there started narrowing greatly with soft snow on one side and heavy cornices on other, so decided not to risk this section and turned back. Possible alternative routes around this but didn't feel they had time to try. Had spent more time on approach march than expected.

BC at Jannu Glacier west-northwest of peak.

Did same acclimatization climbing on Merra Peak and to see 1st part of route, which is dangerous icefall not so difficult. Started 27th at mid-day with Kokalj to 5000m which is beginning of Jannu Glacier: together 1-1/2 hours walking and from there Kokalj did filming of Cesen's climb. Cesen began climb of face at 4:30-5:00 pm and then "I climbed all the way during the afternoon and during the night." In morning hours when sun is on lower part of face about 6700m is continuous fall of stones and ice pieces so climbed at night. Had some moonlight from very early morning. Saw very steep places here (70 degrees) with difficult rock. Then at about 6700m very steep ice and difficult rocks with very thin ice. Upper part crazy: Kokalj never climbed such difficulty in mountains and steep at altitude - cannot see far ahead in steep gully. "Crazy" part starts above 6800m. Rested occasionally for 15 minutes only. If not enough ice it would not be possible to climb this route - good rock (granite). Reached top in entire climb in good weather and no wind problem (south side had bad cloud and wind that day). But in afternoon a storm came up with storm and pretty strong wind. Descended Japanese route and made biv in upper seracs at about 6800-6900m. Was dark when reached biv point at 9:00-10:00 pm. 4 hours storm cleared during night. Started descent about 2:00 am 29th and reached BC at 12:00-1:00 pm of 29th when was very tired (took 4-5 hours to cover descent of 2 hours usually).

"I am satisfied." "I like to climb solo - it's quicker and there are fewer problems." Cesen may try solo ascent of Lhotse South Face next year or later.

Messner: "only quite safe line, a beautiful line" - the best of this season.


Spring 2000:

1999 Slovenian Dhaulagiri I expedition and Slovenian Lhotse expedition of Spr 2000 said Cesen's claim to Jannu summit is doubted since his Lhotse South Face claim totally discredited. 

Australian-New Zealand Jannu leader and other member 5th June said: They don't believe Cesen's claim because he had not enough acclimatization and time he gives for his ascent is not enough. In his report to AAJ, Cesen skims over many important details, especially very steep rock from 6900-7500m, which is very difficult technically.


Jannu - Spring 1989 by Tomo Cesen

For almost a year before setting out, my mind had been totally preoccupied with thoughts of Jannu. After all, its North Face is one of the most difficult in the world.

We established BC on 22nd April, at 4600m at the edge of the Khumbakarna glacier. The following day after breakfast, Jani and I approached the foot of the face. Its upper part was always clearly visible from BC, but the lower part presented a puzzle which I wanted to solve as soon as possible. The start of my route didn't look too encouraging. The face started with an icefall which, from our side of the glacier, looked like a mound of ice cubes threatening to collapse at any moment. I was, however more interested in the upper part of the face, where the eye was drawn to ice gullies and smooth, overhanging granite walls, interspersed with giant roofs - a fantastic sight. It soon became clear to me that I would need to change my initial strategy for tackling this upper part of the face but I knew before I left that it would be practically impossible to plan an exact route. The threat from falling seracs or from avalanches was not too great but the whistling of ice blocks and rocks provided convincing proof that the face was extremely dangerous. Most of this ammunition funnelled into couloir at the bottom of the middle part of the face. I needed little convincing to climb this section at night.

At dawn on the 27th April I was not over enthusiastic about the weather. It was cloudy. However, I still had half a day to prepare my equipment. We were having lunch when the sun rays eventually pierced the clouds. Its interesting how quickly one's mood can change. Around midday I left with Jani, who wanted to accompany me to the start of the glacier. The weather was fantastic and my mood matched it, but I was aware that the waiting would be hard for Jani, perhaps more difficult in some ways that what I was setting out on.

Alone on the glacier I felt a sense of exhilaration. This was good sign that I was already in control. I hung the pitons and a spare blade for the ice axe on my harness, put crampons on my feet and took the ice axes in my hands. I took some rope and of course a helmet but my rucksack contained only spare clothing, gloves, glasses, food and drink, sleeping bag and a biv sac; not much gear. I mused that to climb the North Face of Jannu in this way would be, if nothing else, a challenge.

After some 200m of initial warming up I came to the first ten-metre section of vertical ice. Four hours later the easier, lower part of the face was behind me so I took a ten minute rest. The valley below was already in darkness, but up here the light was still good despite the late hour. Thankfully the steady barrage of falling rock and ice began to ease off. Climbing this section of the face during the day would have been suicidal, but with the night came safety. The next 200 metres or so were very difficult; cramponing up a 70 to 75-degree couloir, sometimes on rock, sometimes on ice. At that point it slowly began to dawn on me what might be waiting above.

The new day came as I reached the end of the ice field. From here I had to move right to the next ice field which was separated from a final one by the first really problematic part of the route. Very steep ice and smooth granite slabs followed one after the other. I used the seracs at the beginning of the middle ice field to orientate myself on the face. There would be no possibility of protection as there were no cracks at all in the rock. I was glad to finally reach steep ice gully which led to the less steep ice field below some huge seracs, where I could take my next short rest.

A short rock step separated me from the final part of the face. Ice, rock, ice again followed by more granite slabs. The exit from this particular section was something special. A gently sloping slab barred the way to the last ice field and the vertical exit from the face. Without crampons and gloves, and some 6000 metres lower this would have been quite easy, but here it was another matter. I couldn't remove my crampons and besides, double plastic boots are not best suited to friction climbing. For a while I leaned unhappily with my hands on the slab and my crampons dug into the thin ice below. In order to gain better support for the tip of my crampons I carefully chipped at some smal crystals of ice with my axe. Everything went very slowly. I can hardly describe the feeling of relief at the top of the slab when my ice axe at last hit ice. Definitely not a pitch for the faint-hearted. For a while I stared upwards and took in an unbelievable view. Now at 7000m, I fully  realised what lay in store for me. This was the time to draw on those psychological reserves that I had trained for. There was no way back.

Above lay a vertical gully lined with thin ice, sometimes interspersed with a few metres of bare rock. The rock appeared good, although I didn't relish the prospect of climbing it in crampons.

The world around me receded. I became lost in total concentration: body and mind focussed; strength and balance pushed to the limit.

Now facing me was a series of near vertical granite slabs, each 30 to 40 metres high and covered with a 10 centimetre veneer of ice. In the thin air I couldn't climb these slabs without rest, and best described as hanging on my ice axe - was not pleasant. There were at least ten of these giant ice covered steps on this part of the face. The problem was that there were some easier options but they were not visible from below. This meant that I could only guess at the best route upwards. I was forced to use pitons on four occasions, but in the wide cracks I just had to climb free in crampons. There was either not enough space to remove them, or it would have been too dangerous. Fortunately the cracks sometimes allowed me to jam in a boot, relax the tension in my arms and take a short rest.

At the end of the rock there was always ice: hard black, green sometimes crumbling, but always very steep. At one point I had to pendulum a narrow ice gully had lost itself in blank granite slabs, with vertical rock above, left and right. I noticed a tiny crack above me and climbed slowly and carefully almost to the tip of this fragile ice tongue, taking care not to break it. I hammered in a piton, threaded the rope, descended a litte and started to swing, thus managing to reach the continuation of the gully to the left.

I was slowly approaching the summit ridge, despite extremely difficult sections which dogged my steps right to the last moment. Suddenly the end came as I almost stumbled onto the soft snow of the ridge. Although the summit of Jannu was very close, and the ridge leading to it presented no difficulties, I felt drained and told myself and told myself I had enough of this kind of torture. The weather, meanwhile, was deteriorating and it was 3:30 pm before I reached the top. To the south was a grey sea of cloud. The weather usually worsens in the afternoons so I needed to descend as far as quickly as possible.

A proper storm was gathering as I roped down onto the upper ice field of the Japanese route. I did not want to sit out in the middle of the a 55-60 degree ice field, but the heavy snowfall and strong cold winds soon forced me to seek temporary safety in a crevasse among the seracs.

That endless biv was one of chattering teeth and quivering muscles: of constant checking my watch and hoping that the weather pattern of the last few days would prevail. Howling winds swept snowflakes in all directions: fog, darkness.

In the middle of the night the storm finally began to abate so I decided to continue down immediately. From the crevasse I descended among the seracs for about 100m. It was the wrong way. To continue meant tackling a 15m vertical ice wall. I could not face retracing my steps, so I had no choice but to chisel an ice mushroom on the lip of the serac and abseil. In daylight I might have sought a better route but in the darkness I took the most direct line. Among the lower seracs I zig-zagged left and right in order to stay among them for as long as possible, and on the final section to the plateau I used the rope a few more times.

The ice fall in the jumbled mess of the Khumbakarna Glacier was a mere formality. I chose a much easier route than for my ascent, albeit a more dangerous one, but I told myself that if the seracs hadn't collapsed for a whole week, they'd last another hour or two. Then it was over. There was no more danger. The way ahead was easier. My concentration lapsed. My walk across the glacier resembled the walk of a drunk returning home from a night out.

Half way from BC Jani met me, smiling broadly. It had taken me 5 hours to reach BC from the foot of the face, where normally it would have taken just two. I was exhausted. After three days of great effort and with only a little food, my stomach was not ready for solids, so that afternoon we had a liquid feast and some of us suffered as a result - but that another story.

Some people considered that the North Face Jannu could not be climbed in the way I chose, what I was more confident than most that I would succeed. However, Jannu is only a part of what I believe in.


Tomaz Humar - 7 Nov 2006

Tomaz Humar's comments about Tomo Cesen's claimed ascent via the South Face: "It is possible Tomo did make the summit.... I don't say he did, but I don't say he didn't." When people can't do something themselves, they say no one can. Humar has seen the South Face, and he thinks Cesen could have gone all the way to the top alone. He was a very strong climber. Lhotse's South Face is not so difficult as Jannu's North Face, which Cesen also said he soloed. Humar also has seen Jannu's North Face and thinks it is possible that he summited. Tomaz also believes that the Jannu face is more difficult because of the greater danger of falling rock on the face.

At the end of the rock there was always ice: hard black, green sometimes crumbling, but always very steep. At one point I had to pendulum a narrow ice gully had lost itself in blank granite slabs, with vertical rock above me and climed slowly and carefully almost to the tip of this fragile ice tongue, taking care not to break it. I hammered in a piton, threaded the rope, descended a little and started to swing, thus managing to reach the continuation of the ice gully to the left.

I was slowly approaching the summit ridge, despite extremely difficult sections which dogged my steps right to the last moment. Suddenly the end came as I almosst stumbled onto the soft snow of the ridge. Although the summit of Jannu was very close, and the ridge leading to it presented no technical difficulties. I felt drained and told myself I'd had enough of this kind of torture. The weather, meanwhile, was deteriorating and it was 3:30 p.m before I reached the top. To the south was a grey sea of cloud. The weather usually worsens in the afternoons so I needed to descend as far and as quickly as possible.

A proper storm was gathering as I roped down onto the upper icefield of the Japanese Route. I did not want to sit out in the middle of a 55-60 degree icefield, but the heavy snowfall and strong cold winds soon forced me to seek temporary safety in a crevasse among the seracs. That endless bivouac was one of chattering teeth and quivering muscles; of constantly checking my watch and hoping that the weather  pattern of the last few days would prevail. Howling winds swept snowflakes in all directions: fog, darkness.
I felt it had all gone on far too long.

In the middle of the night the storm finally began to abate so I decide to continue down immediately. From the crevasse I descended among the seracs for about 100 metres. It was the wrong way. To continue meant tackling a 15 metre vertical ice wall. I could not face retracing my steps, so I had no choice but to chisel an ice mushroom on the lip of the serac and abseil. In daylight I might have sought a better route but in the darkness I took the most direct line. Among the lower seracs I zig-zagged left and right in order to stay among them for as long as possible, and on the final section to the plateau I used the rope a few more times.

The ice fall in the jumbled mess of the Khumbakarna glacier was a mere formality. I chose a much easier route than for my ascent, albeit a more dangerous one, but I told myself that if the seracs hadn't collapsed for a whole week, they'd last another hour or two. Then it was over. There was no more danger. The way ahead was easier. My concentration lapsed. My walk across the glacier resembled the walk of drunk returning home from a night out.

Halfway from Base Camp Jami met me smiling broadly. It had taken me 5 hours to reach BC from the foot of the face, where normally it would have taken just two. I was exhausted. After three days of great effort and with only a little food, my stomach was not ready for solids, so that afternoon we had a liquid feast and some of us suffered as a result - but that is another story.

Some people considered that the North Face of Jannu could not be climbed in the way I chose, but I was more confident than most.

BC at Pangpema
C1 on glacier in center of it
C2 at west cliff of NE Ridge under North Col
C3 on North Face
C4 on North Ridge
C5 on North Face.

Essentially Roskelley and Warth route. Went to N Col and then cut across face. Sherpas didn't want to go to top because dangerous and technically difficult. Left BC 25 May, the day big cyclone storm started. Indonesians got to C2 only, had been on trip so training exercise. Used 1 tank for each summit team. Was no more difficult then expected. 6 men of Rainier Guide Service on top is good record for service.

Wickwire and Roskelley came late and left early, were at and above BC only 2 weeks. Wickwire said he was too old for such a big mountain, Roskelley didn't like climbing with Sherpas.

26 March 97 - Viesturs said the team's summiters did not go to the very summit out of respect for its being sacred - stopped few meters below. Could easily have gone to highest point in lovely weather and good health. Spent an hour on top enjoying view.

ROUTE2: From Yalung Kang up; to Central and S Smts down
ROUTE3: SW Face up; S Ridge-SW side down
ROUTE4: South/Central Smts-S Ridge up; Yalung Kang down
OTHERSMTS: Climbed/traversed other Kangchenjunga summits (KANC-891-01, KANS-891-01) and Yalung Kang (YALU-891-01)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C3 at Great Shelf.

1st Main Smmit team went to C4 on 7th but slept in C4 and then to C5 on 8th and to top on 9th and back to sleep in C4. On top 3:30-4:00 found striped stick on top and autographed it. 

1st Central Summit group slept in C3 14th and left C3 at 4:30 am, dropped loads at C5 at 1:15 pm and on top at 5:30 pm. Returned C4 8:00 pm. 15th-16th to C3. 17th carried loads to South route C4 and down to BC same day.

1st South Summit group: from C5 on 15th at 7:30 am to 8:15 am - much difficult climbing on new route. On top 2:40 pm till 3:10 pm. Left full and empty oxygen bottles and flags. Down to C3. 

2nd Main Summit group from C4 on 16th at 8:00 am and at 2:00 pm in C5 and on top 5:30-5:45 pm. Slept in C5 except 2 cameramen to C4 (Moiseev and Troshchinenko).

2nd South Summit group: from C5 on 17th from 9:30 to 10:30 am (in intervals so as not to send stones falling on those below). On top 1:30-2:30 pm and in C3 8:00 pm.

29 April Central and Main Summits: started from C5 which they had to repair day before (28th) and 3 on central at 11:30 am while others moved more slowly without oxygen. All 5 started for Col between Central and Main Summits. On Main top all 5 at 2:20 pm and at 3:35 pm last one left main top. Back in C3 at 8:00 pm. All used oxygen part or all of this day, Khabibulin only for last 15 minutes.

Yalung Kang traverse group of Boukreev, Bershov, Vinogradski, Pogorelov and Turkevich left C5 on 30th (last one at 8:30) and 11:55 am on top and 12:25 began descent. In C5 at 2 pm. All on oxygen. Support group from C4 at 6:00 am, carried oxygen to C5; 3 of them (Souviga, Khrishchati and Shinov) without oxygen on top by 3:45. All immediately down to C4 where arrived 7:00 to 8:00 pm. Shinov and Dedi down to BC.

Traverse from West to South: had begun on 30th April with ascent of Yalung Kang and returned to C5 that afternoon. 1 May from C5 at 8:00 am and at 10:10 am were on Main Summit. Left Main Summit 11:10 am and were on Central Summit at 12:35 pm and left it at 12:50 pm. Climbed on the ridge, which was rather easy, without problems. On saddle between Central and South Summits at 2:10 pm met other traverse group. Reached South Summit at 2:45 pm. At 3:00 pm left South Summit and cleared C5 and C4 and arrived C3 at 7:00 pm. Entire climb on 1 May with oxygen. Had slept on oxygen previous night and used 2 bottles each on 1 May.

Traverse from West C4 to Main summit: 1 May Arsentiev, Klinetski, Souviga and Khrishchati (Souviga and Khrishchati without oxygen). Started 8:00 am from West C4, on Main summit at 4:30 pm to 5:30 pm and waited there for South-West traverse party. Met this party at main summit at 5:40 pm. Then was decided group from West C4 would go to Central C4 West were in Central C5 at 7:00 pm and slept there. 2 May they cleared Central C5 and C4 and brought it to C3 (were in BC at 11:00 pm ) not enough fuel in C3 to stay there).

Traverse South to West: 1 May started from South C5 from 8:40 and 9:15 am. Elagin, Koroteev, Luniakov, Balyberdin and Khalitov (the last three used no oxygen to South Summit, Khalitov used none all the way to saddle between South and Central Summits). Arrived South Summit 12:10 to 1:35 (Balyberdin was last). At 2:10 pm met West-South traverse group. At Central Summit 3:40 pm and left it at 3:50 pm for Main Summit which reached 5:40 to 6:00 pm. Down to West C5 at 8:00 pm. 2 May from C5 at 12 noon for Yalung Kang summit. All 5 used oxygen. On top 2:00 to 2:40 pm; 3:00 pm started descent: wanted to descend a gully, not same route as had descended. Down to C3 at 5:30 pm.

Final ascent: Cherny, Efimov, Ang Babu and Dr. Karpenko started on 3 May from West C5 with oxygen at 7:30 am to 8:30 am. Doctor went up 100m only and then down to C3. Other 3 to Main Summit at 11:30 am to 11:45 am and half hour there. Brilliant weather. Cleared West C5 and C4 and went to C3.

Total: 10 traversed and had already been to one summit before = 50 summits
Total: 85 summits by all 22 mountain climbers, 3 film group members, deputy leader Cherny and coach Efimov, and one Sherpa.

No accidents or frostbite; 1 case of altitude sickness during descent without oxygen but no serious effects.

Only 3 Sherpas went above C3 but 15 to C3 - members did much load carrying.

New route: 1) from 7800m (below C4) to South Summit
           2) from Col between central and main summits to main summits -
              really from C to M summits
           3) not sure about newness of route from West C5 to Yalungkang
              
BC evacuated to lower camp below BC from 30 April to 7 May.

BC right below Pandra Glacier
C1 on Pandra Glacier
C2 on SW Ridge above West Face
C3 on SW Ridge.

Had lot of sickness (chest and stomach) so were unable to mount as many summit teams as wished. All members to C1, 3 to C2, 2 members above C2 (1 got altitude sickness and down, the other to C2 on up to C3 and summit with 2 Sherpas. "Without the Sherpas we would never had made it to the top - we didn't have the strength, we would never had made it to the top." Not possible to collect enough strong members to make another attempt with support. Had reasonably good weather with mornings clear. Snow fell in afternoon and melted in mornings. 

Technical difficulties between C2 and C3: rocks requiring fixed rope and some ice. From C3 to top was not as Swiss had it; was knife ridge this month.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7700m due to Van Lint's frostbite
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal high BC
C1 on big flat glacier
C2 below Makalu La
High point north side of NW Ridge.

"A very beautiful mountain and normal route very beautiful to climb" so stayed on with Daniel for "real try to summit" while others wanted comfort and left. 1st try to reach C2 3 April because of the altitude and was too soon to reach it due to wind and snow. C2 small tent only. 23 Arpil Van Doorsselaere and Van Lint from BC to try for summit. 24th to C2, 25th took sleeping bags, tent, food, etc to make C3 tent at Makalu La. Started at 11:30 am on 25th heavily laden, last time following in darkness, but Van Lint, climbing with one crampon, did not reach La (Daniel had the tent). Daniel even went above La while Van Lint went down brief distance to find place for sleeping bag. Van Lint had frostbitten toes from previous night but didn't realize it till that night they reached C1.

"I don't regret any moment but I don't go back: There are so many mountains. I got almost to the pass, I know the way to the summit - for me its enough."

Made 2 depots above BC at 5800m and 5900m; depot 1 used only for few days but depot 2 slept in quite often. Blue ice all up Chago Glacier; no snow. Most members left BC 23 or 24 April to go to Dhaulagiri because sponsors insisted: chances of Makalu success poor because of winds which destroyed tents at BC, depot 2 and C1. At this time no one had gone above C2 which had been established by Bollaert and Kok and reached same day by Jos Dewint and next day by Van Doorsselaere and Van Lint.
ACCIDENTS: Van Lint frostbite and others illnesses

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8350m due to insufficient equipment for final section
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at junction of two glaciers
C1 at start of West Pillar
C2 at bottom of pillar's steep part
C3 on pillar
Biv at top of pillar
High point at bottom of final very steep section.

Big snowstorm as arrived at Barun La and many porters deserted. C1 first at 5800m but wind destroyed tent and made camp higher behind rocks. Entire pillar covered in ice, very bad conditions, strong wind, 1 man sick, 1200m rope fixed: took long time to make route route to C2. C3 set on 4 May but not slept in because storm coming up up and down to BC. Slept in 11 May. 

18th tried for top (all four members) and reached junction with SE Buttress in good weather at 6:00 am, five hours after left biv, and little above this found Czech body [Karel Schubert] from '76 spring, sitting placidly facing climbers who came up. This impressed us a lot, but kept on up, more than 50m - last near vertical section more difficult than they could manage with little rope and only 2 pitons left and too dangerous from avalanching of loose snow, so gave up. Batard had used ropes in most difficult sections [Spring 88]. 18 May 2 men slept in C3, 2 in biv. 2 to BC on 19th, 2 to BC on 20th and climb finished.

Rescued a (Belgian Van Lint) with frostbite.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to dangerous serac, climbers exhausted and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at glacier junction for Makalu
Biv 1 at moraine NE of East Col
Biv 2 at plateau south of point 6400m west of small col
C3  west of point 6730m on wide col/small plateau.

Alpine-style attempt. Spent six days on mountain, about 3-8 May. 6 members set out on about 3 May and made 1st biv. On 3rd day Luis Miguel, Lete Lasa, Golzarri Orue stayed at 6050m biv while Appelaniz, Gomez and Alfredo continued climb and bived at 6500m on 5 May and 6 May tried for summit, but reached only 7100m on SE Ridge just below big serac. Retreated because 2 very tired and serac dangerous and slept again at 6500m. 7 May returned to 6050m biv. Luis Miguel, Lete Lasa and Golzarri Orue spent 3 nights at 6050m biv. One day rested, next day tried to follow others to climb to top but winds too strong.

All six returned to BC via biv at about 5300m. Were in hurry: four had to return home for jobs and Montero Urgudo wanted to return to sick girl friend; Martin Cubillo had stomach trouble.
ACCIDENTS: None except Miss Martin's stomach trouble

ROUTEMEMO:
BC south of point 5527 on Schneider map
C1 at glacier south of Pumori Peak
C2 on knife ridge running north from Kalapattar
C3 on SW Ridge.

Fixed 3000m rope on entire route because other members not so strong. C2 to C3 difficult rock and ice climbing. Others did not reach C3. Japanese made route, Americans followed on same route. Other members of this team not to top because not strong and some snow fall. It was a guided climb.

BC due west of Kalapattar
C1 on SW Ridge
C2 on SW Ridge (normal site)
C3 on SW Ridge (normal site).

Lower part of route not normal way: arrived in snowstorm and couldn't see well. "Weather was so good for us, but winds so bad up high" in April.

We climbed the SW Ridge. Through a series of events, we ended at a base camp on the west side of Kalapatar, and so may have pioneered a new route on the first 2000 ft. From base camp we worked around the right of the triangular glacier and up a thousand vertical feet to the Kalapattar ridge through sections of rock and 60-degree to 70-degree ice. C1 was placed on April 7 at 19,600 ft on the first bit of flat ground. The route was unusually dry this season. We encountered mostly loose rock and mushroom ice between C1 and C2. The latter was occupied on April 13 at 20,400 ft. We intersected the regular route there. We traversed under rock towers through very loose rock and along sun-cupped ice and water ice before moving vertically onto better rock back to the ridge. We placed C3 at 21,500 ft on April 23. The route was littered with old fixed rope and hardware, some of which we cleaned. On April 25, Lucy Smith, Carol Snetsinger and Kathy Phibbs summited. Three days later, Diane Taliaferro and I also reached the summit.

Shari Kearney, National Outdoor Leadership School
Source from American Alpine Journal, 1990, pg 234

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7300m due to slow progress, low supplies and poor weather
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lhotse Nuptse Glacier east of Chhukung Peak
Biv 1 at beginning of S Spur.

Did acclimatization climb on Chhukung Peak and Marshall found he had 19,000 ft altitude limit left. Robinson climbed on Nuptse first day of team's climbing Nuptse, which started 7 May, and his back gave such trouble he couldn't move for several days but stayed on at BC till climb finished. 

Italians, Nuptse team reduced to 2 climbers with one just not ready for Himalayan climb. So 4 men climbed together (5 actually on 1st day) in alpine style. 8 May to 19,800 ft (Robinson climbed east pitches and went down with back trouble). Averaged 4 to 5 rope lengths a day (rope about 50m) in very hard climbing and 7th day got to top of Pillar at 6900m surpassing Jeff Lowe's high point. Canadians and Italians took turns leading climb, 1 day Canada next day Italy. From top of Pillar sat out a day of bad storm and Italians then decided to go down because of lack of food and fuel and weather conditions while 2 Canadians stayed but were now on half rations. 16 May good weather. Rested during day to leave at midnight for SE Summit and did get away at 1:00 am of 17 May. Climbed through night on easier terrain of steep hanging glacier (Pillar had been steep granite ala Yosemite, plus sections less steep of mixed rock and ice) and got into rocks, where realized would take at least 2 more days up very steep rock to SE Summit. In afternoon snowing so climbing ended about noon on 17 May. Got about 450m above top of Pillar.

SE Summit - 7804m 

Descended British 1961 route via a Pillar west of ascent route. Back in BC on 19 May. Slept 17th May at top of ascent pillar.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6917m due to cold weather
ROUTEMEMO:
Biv 1 at where Canadians had biv on 7 May and had stayed (not 6000m)
High point at top of Pillar.

In seven days got to top of Pillar with 2 Canadians 14 May. 15 May rested. 16 May Canadians started up at 3:30-4:00 am but Italians went down and 17 May in BC. Decided pillar was enough and relations not good with Elzinga (with Peter Arbic good relations). Pillar same parts not difficult but others quite difficult rock (but good rock) with 30% ice, 70% rock. "Nice route" in good snowless conditions. Came down Bonington route.

SPONSOR: Citta de Oggino Expedition to Everest
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site on road
C2 on North Face.

5th June whole team left BC with yaks and in 6th and 7th installed ABC; looked at Japanese Couloir but would need lots of fixed rope and did not want to spend time getting and fixing rope, so decided to go to N Face to Great Couloir. On 11th June had all equipment in C2 for summit push but did not sleep there. Rest in C1 on 12th and on 13th occupied C2. 14th weather bad: clouds coming from Lho La and turned back in snowfall from 7500m and slept in C2. Night of 14th/15th blizzard and had to descend quickly to ABC with avalanching. 15th night warm and glacier between ABC and C1 became dangerous. 

Weather bad until 21st, 1st day could see mountain again (covered in snow). Up to C1 22nd where one tent broken and others covered with snow. 23rd moved C1 downwards and on 25th tried to go up to remove C2 but unable and same on 26th. 27th finally to C2 and found one tent completely swept away but other tent recovered. Left BC 30th. In July weather was even worse; would have had to wait till Aug.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8530m due to bad snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
C4 at North Col
High point on North Face.

Too much snow and not enough wind in July and August. On 27th Aug down to ABC; other 4 men on 3 Sept arrived at C6 and slept there. Next day 2 men down, 2 men 50-100m up and they too down. All in ABC on 4th, defeated by deep snow on steep ridge.

Team had 16 men and 7 Sherpas but 1 was non-climbing cook at ABC.
ACCIDENTS: None (one member with frostbitten thumb that will heal)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m due to bad weather and deep snow
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at road
C4 at North Col.
High point on North Face.

Reached N Col twice and then from there to 8100m using Spanish C5 and C6 on the way; turned back from high point because lacked supplies and member strength with only the two Bulgarians doing high climbing. Lot of fresh snow and only 2 men, so no chance for summit, so turned back on 20th Aug, down to N Col that day and on down following day; was much snow and even rain at N Col. Spanish let them use their camps above the col and climbed together.

Leader reached N Col, other two Greek members only about 6600m.

Abergo and Casimiro of Spanish Everest 11 Sept 89: Greek member had not enough experiece or technical ability for this climb.


Everest Attempt: 

The first Greek Himalayan expedition had as members Kostas Kanidis, Kostas Passaris, Nikos Louridis and me as leader and Bulgarian Dinio Gueorguiev-Tomov. We got to Base Camp at 5200m on July 16 and acclimatized for ten days. We established Camps 1, 2 and 3 on July 26, 27 and 28 at 5500m, 6000m and 6400m. The weather turned bad. On July 30 Kanidis and I occupied C4 on the North Col but had to descend after 2 days of bad weather. The next ten days were bad. It was decided that Kanidis and Tomov should make an alpine style try from 7100m with one bivouac. They set out on August 18 with good weather but deep snow. They climbed to 8100m but returned from that point.

ROUTE1: W Ridge from N via Hornbein Couloir
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8200m due to high winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at road
ABC next to Yugoslav, Japanese and Italian BC's
C1  at foot of small ridge leading to West Ridge 1 Pole Spr 1988
C2  on small ridge
C3  on West Shoulder
C4  at top of West Shoulder
C5  at bottom of Couloir
High point at 8200m.

Sherpas left KTM 9th Aug and arrived BC 13th Aug. Much snow. Early Sept after C2 established avalanche took away 1 tent and all fixed line. On 14th Oct 2 Chilean members slept in C5 intending to go for summit on 15th but wind too strong and down to C3.

There were 10 members of whom 2 were Americans plus 4 additional members (trekkers?).
ACCIDENTS: None (Yugoslavs say some frostbitten fingers and pulmonary edema)

ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at southwest Col.

Did no acclimatization climbing because 3 climbers had all recently done 7000m climbs in very recent months in order to get a Dhaulagiri climb in best weather. Did many bivouacs on difficult pillar (grade 4 to 6). 7200m biv on hard ice, small ledges & at plateau had to make cave at 7350m because of winds. Started 11:15 am 6th Oct from 7350m and 7:00 pm on top in darkness & left there in rock pyramid some flags; so windy could not stand up; 10:00 pm on 6th Oct reached cave at 7350m. From BC only 3 men; others on expedition thought they might climb other route; 3 men did entire job of climb with 2 Russians who went for recce for 1991 climb and had equipment (Czechs' stuck on delayed ship) but for whom alpine-style climb forbidden till perestroyka arrived in USSR. Intent was pure alpine-style: 9m climbing rope, 1 7mm rope not for climbing (each 40m long) and 80m long other rope & this all; 30 cams, 30 rock pitons, 5 ice screws and some chocks; 2 ladders, 4 jumars, 1 tent, 2 sleeping bags (Denjan none) and 350 grams/man/day, so on descent no food because had not realized it would be "very hard," but was "very nice." A-2 rating of artificial climb.


Dhaulagiri Trilogy by Jiri Novak from Mountain Magazine, July/Aug 1988

Three months before departure my big chance came. Some key people in the expedition couldn't make it and I was made leader of what had become a "super light" team of eight climbers and two trekkers.

On 16th Sept a cosmopolitan group arrived at the green field beneath the West Face. Myself, Igor Novak, Tomas Skricka (the expedition doctor), and Zoltan Demjan were from Czechoslovakia; Marco Fogliatti and Sergio Antoniazzi from Italy and Jurij Mojsejev and Kazbek Valijec from the Soviet Union.

We had come to finish off the French Pillar to the summit, and attempt the Japanese Route on the South Face, but yet again the monsoon stayed late and bad was pushing us up against our deadline for leavinag on Oct 12.
