The first good break came on Sept 25th, and next day a team set out for the SW Saddle at 5100m and the day after that, a start was made on the Japanese Pillar. The latter team soon came up against acclimatization problems, and were forced to abandon their climb.

The climbers on the SW Pillar, however were fresha and fit from climbing in the Tien Shan, prior to departure for Nepal, and on Sept 28th, Zoltan Demjan, Jurij Mojsejev and Kazbek Valijev left the SW Saddle, carrying only 15 kg loads each.

Five bivouacs and 1700m of climbing got them to within striking distance of the summit, and on 6 Oct at 19:15 all three climbers reached the top. Descending the way they came the team reached BC on Oct the 11th after sixteen days of climbing!

For Zoltan Demjan, it was his third "eight thousander." He describes his experience:

"We were late in starting the ridge and the climbing was immediately difficult, forcing us to climb without mittens. In some places the metamorphised limestone was solid, in others it was crushed. The possibilities for hooking were good and some pitches were as magnificient as on Yosemite granite!

I did most of the leading, particularly the difficult pitches, but the big problem was with fierce gust of wind, blowing up the face, one of which nearly swept Kazbek Valijev away. The 600m headwall of the Pillar was the crux. In three days we climbed 16 rope lengths of alpine VI and A2.

The last 70 metres of the pillar I climbed in the dark, with the light of my headtorch gleaming in the clear water ice. We had only one rucksack with two sleeping bags, gas, two climbing ropes and one thin 80m rope.

On the bivouac above the pillar, my toes became frozen, but the hard climbing was below us, and there "only" remainded the three km ridge to the summit.

On 6th October at 7 pm we reached the summit and stayed there for 15 minutes, but I was so exhausted, I couldn't even summon the energy to film or photograph the others. Thankfully, Kazbek Valijev planted a small Kazakh flag in the summit pyramid to mark our passing.

The descent in the dark was unnerving. Would we find our bivouac? Would the weather hold? The others kept my spirits up, with their good humoured banter, but I was desperately hungry. Sometimes I could ago for two days without food, but not here. After all the leading, I was drained, so Kazbek and Jurij really looked after me, and got food into me quickly at the top bivouac.

The summit photograph would have to wait till BC, but not to worry. We were tired, wasted, but alive."

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to slab avalanche danger and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Kaireng Khola bottom of North Saipal Glacier
ABC at moraine of North Saipal Glacier
C1  at bottom of North Face
C2  just below a col on NE Ridge
High point at NE Ridge.

Had to abandon because snow conditions bad with snow-slab danger on north side and had to leave BC not later than 24th Oct north side very steep, but is possible to climb. Put C1 at bottom of face planing to try face but then slab avalanche came down. Team then shifted route to NE Ridge when snow was deep and slowed progress. Needed 1 more week and several more camps. NE Ridge to pass not difficult but above 5800m technically difficult, steep in one section, rock with 3 summits in 3 km from pass to summit (curving ridge). Only Montaz and Zoller did any climbing above moraine.

TERMNOTE: Did not reach BC
ROUTEMEMO: Never left Kali Gandaki Valley. Met Japanese team (Tukuche?) at Larjung & they said very bad snow conditions & wind during past 4 days had driven them away. So French made no attempt to go to base camp. 2 members had altitude sickness in Thorung La, where group trekked after abandoning climbing plan.

SPONSOR: Kathmandu Club Dhaulagiri I E Face Expedition 1988
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to heavy snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site (same as Japanese NE Ridge team)
C1 near NE Col (before Col reached)
C2 on NE Ridge (reached by all members 7 Oct)
xxx at C2 site.

After BC established, 10 days bad weather (15-24 Sept); much snow fall (1m) so conditions very bad with big avalanches. 7th Oct decided not to try E Face because very dangerous from avalanches, so started up NE Ridge and made C2 at 6600m but did not sleep there. 8th Oct again bad weather (snow) so all down to BC. Stayed in BC 2 days and then 11th Oct 5 members to C1 while Watanabe stayed at BC because very tired. 12th Oct more snow and all again in BC. 

Hirofumi and Masaki stayed on at mountain but others decided on 12th Oct to leave because of constant danger from snowfall. Watanabe left BC 12th Oct while others 3 others stayed at BC 4 more days and reported Hirofumi and Masaki returned to C2 15th Oct. All members reached C2 site on 7th Oct. No accidents up to 16th Oct, when most had left BC.

4th Nov Masaki and Hirofumi, who stayed on at Dhaulagiri, have now returned in good health but did not go above C1 after 15th Oct.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6560m due to bad weather
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at normal site
Biv at icefall
C1  almost at NE Col.

After C1 established, 9 days continuous snowfall and had to stay in BC. 28th Sep started up again and went to biv camp; next day to C1 to start making route to C2. After reaching site for C2, again snow and strong wind and down. Never slept in C2. Icefall difficult but not difficult above. C2 site reached by all 3 members and 5 Sherpas: Ang Pasang, Ang Kami, Danu, Lhakpa Tenzing and Mingma.

Left BC 9th Oct.

SPONSOR: 1988 Korean Himalaya Dhaulagiri, Tukuche Peak Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 a little below NE Col (south of col)
C2 on NE Ridge
C3 on NE Ridge
C4 on NE Ridge.

5th and 6th Nov tried twice to go to summit, but winds drove them back both times from about 7900m, so all down to BC. 11th Nov started up for top: 2 Sherpas and 1 Korean; in C3 on 12th Nov, C4 on 13th and 14th to summit in cold, cloudy but little wind. Left C4 9:00 am, on summit 4:10 pm and bived at 8:00 pm at c8000m in snowhole in down jackets. 

4 Sherpas in C4 on 13th evening with Choi because planned 2nd summit attack, but on 15th leader decided cancel that: one team already on top and Jomsom flight booked for 18th. BC to C1 dangerous icefall; above NE Col always wind. Fixed 700-800m rope (which had been assigned to Tukuche). 

Only 6 Koreans climbed because fire on approach march destroyed gas, high altitude food and equipment including rope and thus altered entire climbing program.

Tukuche summit Jun Jae-Young, Lee Sang-Hun, Park Youk-Kwang and Wangchu on 15th Nov. C2 on 6500m NW Ridge on Nepal Army route and reached NW summit. BC between Dhampus and French Passes at 4000+m and C1 5800m on NW Ridge. Went to NW peak by mistake: thought they went to main summit; found were on wrong summit after descent and discussion with Ang Dorje, who went to top with Koreans in Autumn 1985.


Dhaulagiri And Tukuche NW Ascent by Busan Joint Expedition

The expedition of 12 members was led by Cho Jung-Sul. They hoped to climb the north side of Dhaulagiri and Tukuche, and then they had traversed both of two peaks 27 km long ridge.

But unfortunately, the team ventured to do climbing suffered of great damages of 2000 kg materials by fire because of the mistakes of the employees on the way of caravan. They started with the thinking of burden, should finish quickly the climbing, because the foods and equipments are in short.

They established BC at 4700m on Oct 25th. Japanese team had been already evacuated. The day after leading party Ryu Il-Keun and Choi Tae-Sik rushed to C1 with two Sherpas. Fixed rope in 800m rock step and 150m snow plastered. At first, they followed previous party's (Japanese party) route. But the route turned out dangerous and then decided to changing route in order to avoid the avalanche.

On Oct 27th, they established C1 at 5800m and they found the foods and equipment left by Japanese team near the C2.

Although the bad weather they set up C2 and C3 6620m and 7400m.

It was more worse afer making the C4 at 7800m on Nov 5th. Ryu was confined alone at C4 because of traditionally poor Dhaulagiri weather - deep snow. Wind was strong and temperature dropped to -40 degrees C. 

In spite of bad weather Ryu and Seo Sung-Soo had left C4 toward the summit on Nov 7th but they had to stop the below the Rock Band in deteriorating weather. All members forced descended to BC.

On Nov 14th Choi and two Sherpas had left C4 for the summit at 09:00. After more than six hours of climbing they encountered the three peaks at 8160m. That was the last obstacle below the summit and finally they reached the top at 16:00.

They climbed slowly down to C4 but became to dark and they had to bivouacked below the rock band at 8050m without sleeping bag or stove. Choi had suffered frostbite.

Ryu and two Sherpas who waited for the second attack at C4 descended to BC escorting the first attack party. The team was given up the 2nd attempt because of bad weather and a lack of food. All members descended to BC at 22:00 on Nov 24th.

They used no artificial oxygen for climbing on Nov 16. Tukuche party Park Yuk-Kwang, Lee Sang-Hoon and Jeon Jae-Yong stood on the top of Tukuche northwest peak.

The team failed "the long traverse" but succeeded on the climbing of two peaks.

The member Choi Tae-Sik should cut the toe and fingers due to the frostbite.
ACCIDENTS: Choi frostbitten toes both feet, will heal; Sherpas slight finger frostbite

SPONSOR: 1988 Korea Dhaulagiri VI, Gurja Himal Expedition
OTHERSMTS: Climbed Gurja Himal (GURJ-883-01) and Ghustung North (GHUN-883-01)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  northeast of point 4100m, WSN point 4738m on glacier
Dep east of BC and east of spur south of point 4738m
C1  east of Deposit Camp
C2  at bottom of rock buttress reaching to N-S Ridge between 2 mountains
C3  on buttress
C4  at North-South Ridge.

26th Sept 5:50 am 2 teams started for 2 summits and on top of Dhaulagiri VI 12:30 pm and Gurja 12:43 pm; returned C4 from Dhaulagiri VI 17:00 hrs and Gurja 18:00 hrs same day; ridge to Gurja very difficult knife ridge atop steep walls on both sides (walls moving rock, snow and ice). Easy climb to Dhaulagiri VI. 1000m fixed rope C2 to C4 on steep sections. No rope fixed rope above C4; many crevasses below C2 (area where Spring 1988 climber died).

Ghustang North climbed 19th Sept by 3 members (Lee, Lee and Shin) from C2 up West Face.


Dhaulagiri VI and Gurja, Aut 1988 by Young Cheol Shin

Several Korean climbers from Wulsan (leader; Mr Young-Cheol Shin) planned a joint expedition with Nepali climbers with a great ambition of conquering simultaneously 2 peaks above 7000m - Dhaulagiri VI (7268m) and Gurja Himal (7193m).

The first attack began on Sept 26th at 5:52 am, Mr. Bong-Hee Nam (climbing leader) and Nepali member Ang Pasang started C4 (6750m) for Dhaulagiri VI, and at the same for Gurja Himal, Sang-Ho Lee and Seung-Hwan Lee, and the same time for Gurja Himal, Sang-Ho Lee and Seung-Hwan Lee (Korean), and Pemba (Nepali) also started.

The climbing route toward Dhaulagiri VI was led 300m down from C4 and then continued to knife ridge. Climbing carefully through very sharp and dangerous ridge, member Nam and Ang Pasang firstly gained the summit. It was 12:30 pm. Just after 13 minutes, another success was performed on the top of Gurja Himal.

As the second attempt, member Sang-Ho Lee and Seung-Hwan Lee again got to the summit of Dhaulagiri VI at 12:15 pm on Sept 27th.

SPONSOR: Czechoslovak Canoe Expedition to Himalaya Kali Gandaki 1988
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southwest of Mesakantu Pass
C1 at foot of rocky fore with buttress
C2 at center of rock
C3 at above rocky section on ice.

1st part of N Ridge is a steep rocky face. Above this was ice which was not so difficult as rock but same parts required exact ice technique. 1st summit attack on 18th Oct unexpectedly: team who had made C3 were expected to come down and be replaced by other team. Had had blizzard on 4th and 5th Oct leaving 1m snow but in mid-Oct weather cold but stable. 

1st team of Gribec and Horka established C3 alone (C3=1 tent) on 17th and on 18th started to summit in morning and reached top 6 pm (seen there from BC) without biv equipment. So late on top meant they had to spend night at or near top because route there too difficult to descend at night even with headlamps. Was windy and very cold so biv must have been exhausting. 

2nd team Palecek and Krachmar were in C1 that night and on 19th 6:30 am saw 1st team descending, this last sight of team alive. Went up quickly and arrived C2 while Smida and doctor with oxygen to C1. 20th Palecek, strongest member, to C3 while Krachmar waited in C2. Palecek on up wall from buttress, reached summit at 10:00 am and found there toys left there by 1st team. Stayed on top 15 mins and then descended while looking down during descent 600m below top and 300m side from route he saw 2 bodies of 1st team. Took a camera and other things from them, covered them with snow and marked place with upper part of their ice ax which was broken. Smida arrived C3 and Palecek confirmed their death by having fallen. Immediately abandoned climb except to clear camps. Left BC 25th Oct.


Letter from Bobak Jiri

On 18 Oct at 6 pm reached 7134m summit of Tilicho on 19 Oct at 6:30 am. Left the summit, slipped in the snow and found tangled in rope 600m below summit.

Mr Ludwik left base camp on 20 Oct in search of these two members but he reached the summit on 21 Oct at 10 am without oxygen. He stayed 15 minutes at summit while descending he found these two members dead tangling in the rope. He took photographs of the dead persons, but left the dead bodies on the same condition, and he came back to base camp on 22nd Oct. No more attempts, expedition abandoned.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6450m due to bad weather coming and time running out
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  northeast of Machhapuchure
ABC south-southwest of Annapurna III on moraine
Biv 1 at bottom of a spur
Biv 3 on horizontal ridge SE Ridge
Biv 4 on horizontal ridge SE Ridge 
Biv 5 at bottom of SE Ridge-Face (high point).

Alpine-style climb ABC started on 29th Sept with Cave, Perkins, Tattersall and Duff to 1st biv. On 2nd day only Cave and Duff went on up while other 2 down because of altitude problems. Duff & Cave down to ABC on 3rd Oct because big storm approaching; storm brought snow & wind. Now Cave & Duff had not enough time left. Other 2 not happy with the very long East Ridge with no interesting climbing involved. There were a lot of avalanches that nearly hit Fairley.

* Cook died on approach to BC of cold that suddenly became pulmonary edema (he died during night of 10/11 Sept).


Letter from Malcolm Duff - 11 Nov 1988 

You may well have heard that our cook died of HAPE at 13,500 ft on the walk-in. The first party suffered appalling conditions and at this spot decided to send down 14 porters who were likely to die from exposure. 8 other porters (superstars) were pitted out in expedition equipment and stayed in the group to help in the final 1-day ferry to BC.

The previous section of the route in is absolutely desperate (2 loads were dropped into a gorge directly below). Clearly evacuating of anybody by land is out of the question.

They had established BC on 10th (or at least some gear got there) when the cook who had responded to treatment by drugs, suddenly became worse and died approx midnight.
ACCIDENTS: Cook died on approach to BC

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site.

C2 pitched 20 Sept, but slept in only on 25th Sept. Had bad weather but were lucky to try for top one day earlier, then they (Aldai and Azcona) succeeded. 

Arrieta tried for top with other expedition and like them forced to turn back at 7700m by bad weather. 

4 members, C4 on 2 Oct, helped other Spanish team: "We put all our forces together" after avalanche devastated C2 of other team.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7700m due to renewed snowfall for several days
ROUTEMEMO: After C2 made and descended to BC. 9 days snowfall and a big avalanche hit C2 and carried away all food and equipment and all 3 tents. Other Spaniards gave replacemant equipment so climb could continue. Returned to C2 25th Sept and found everything gone. 2 men stayed there while others down for equipment. High point only 7700m because bad weather returned with more snow. Waited few days in C4 for improvement but did not improve, so down on 7th Oct to C1. Left BC 10th Oct.
ACCIDENTS: None; Morales lost way, avalanche over him but unharmed

OTHERSMTS: Had permit for Fang, but did not attempt
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near Miristi Khola (1/2 hour from Japanese)
C1 at end of glacier.

Members had acclimatized in Soviet Union on 7000m Kangtengri. Martis, Nezerka and Pelikan did all lead climbing, fixing ropes, making tent sites and moving up with their single tent very quickly. Summit day returned to C4 (not biv) at 16:00 hrs. Had been very cold and windy on top. Route was same as French. Upper part of route along ridge from south of summit was very difficult: very sharp ridge, several steps of technical difficulty and windy. Doctor Pelikan did not reach this difficult section but turned back because of fear of freezing his surgeon's fingers during bivouac that was obviously necessary (had no biv equipment except cooker, gas, sugar, shovel to make snow cave, which they made). Not so difficult elsewhere on route but 4 seracs presented danger in 4 places and only here needed fixed ropes below S Ridge. There were frequent avalanches so safest climb was quick climb. 

Two summiters Martis and Nezerka knew nothing of Pelikan's fatal fall till they were returning from top and saw signs of his disappearance; he might have thought to climb to peak between Annapurna I and Fang in honour of his daughter's birthday on 1 Oct; was very skilled climber. After 6th Oct, 10 members still on mountain to clear it and still might make summit bid.

ROUTE1: E Rib of S Face up; E Ridge-Glacier Dome down
SPONSOR: International Annapurna I South Face Expedition
OTHERSMTS: Climbed Glacier Dome (GLAC-883-01) and Roc Noir (ROCN-883-01)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC as same as Swiss East Ridge '84 foot of tent Peak on right moraine of Annapurna Glacier
1st biv - South Face
2nd biv - East Ridge.

Had planned to fix all route on S Face but big avalanche seracs changed their minds about route and now planned Hajzer and Kukuczka to make quick ascent of S Face route while others to ascend E Ridge. All descended E Ridge route. C2A and C3A made via Glacier Dome: C2A 6760m on 30th Sept and C3A 7150m on 1 Oct at foot of Roc Noir. Then all back to BC. 8th Oct Kukuczka and Hajzer started up from BC. 10th Oct on C2 on S Face, 11th Oct at 1st biv; 12 Oct, 2nd biv; and 13th top 4 pm at E Summit and descended E Ridge at biv 7500m; 14th to C2A. 

Navarrete summited 16 Oct via E Ridge route. Majer and Espinoza turned back just below summit. Navarrete fatal fall on descent.

"Weather: very strong ice wind, low temperature on bad ice, snow"; 60-degree ice walls from C2, 1st biv to C2 mostly fixed rope with grade 3 in some places, grade 4 in one place (with rock covered by loose snow), 15 pitches from C2 and 1st biv on icewall. Above 1st biv climbed together in hurry up 200-300m gully step to big snowfield. Ridge to 2nd biv which became C4A for other route. Route even to C1 very exiting: grade 4 rock back and icefall below C1 with 400m fixed rope which had to be replaced often. Did not go to main summit because had been to it in 1987 and more importantly were afraid of heavy clouds moving in. -26 degrees in tent at 2nd biv and strong winds, so decided to skip main summit and descend.

2nd route (4 camps) via Glacier Dome: 15 Oct from C3A Navarette, Espinoza and Majer up to Kukuczka and Hajzer's 2nd biv = C4A. 16 Oct 2 pm Navarette to East Summit of Annapurna I, Majer stopped 10m below summit because strong cold wind. Espinoza stopped 100-200m because altitude affecting him (altitude exhaustion). Same evening to C4A all 3 men and next evening to C3A in fog. Near top of Roc Noir descended slightly more direct way; in this section were very big cornices and one broke and Navarette fell (he was Ecuador's No 1 mountaineer). Majer and Espinoza down rock face, Espinoza fell 100m and lost gloves, so fingers frozen (also nose). Navarette fell from about 7450m and disappeared 4:00-5:00 pm. Espinoza fell from about 7200m at 6:00 pm. Espinoza and Majer did not find C3A till next morning and stayed there 1 night. Todd up from C2 18th: scaled Glacier Dome and later that day BC radioed to him to search for 3 missing men and he found 2; to C2 in 1 day and ABC in another day 20th. Espinoza was comotose when Todd met them. Left BC 22nd.

Dr. Korniszewski: Espinoza will lose top half of right thumb from frostbite. After he learned of Navarrete's fatal fall, he became paralyzed in his legs, had to be carried from Chamro most of the time to Surkhet, although few hours each day could walk slowly with 2 poles (sticks): psychological cause.


Expedition Round Up Expeditions 1988 - from Himalaya Club Newsletter 

Annapurna South face, 1988: Our expedition was organized by the High Mountain Club of Katowice and led by Jerzy Kukuczka. We reached the base camp on 30th Aug on the right morraine of the Annapurna Glacier. On the 2nd Sept advance BC was placed at 5200m. Two days later C1 (5800m) was established in a small basin between the slopes of Annapurna, Roc Noir and Glacier Dome. The route to this camp led by dangerous icefalls and very dangerous corridor between the glacier and rocks. On 12 sept C2 (6550m) was made on the lower part of the far east spur of the Annapurna South Face. On 11 Oct Hajzer and Kukuczka started from C2. They climbed via the nearly 2000m high spur mostly through 60-degree ice grooves. 15 pitches or so need careful rope protection. Climbing alpine-style, they made the bivvy at 7100m. Next day the difficulties of ice continued but in the upper part of the rib the ground became less severe. The pair reached the Annapurna East Ridge half way between the Roc Noir and Annapurna East. They bivouacked at 7500m where a tent was placed. On 13 Oct, 1988, the summit of Annapurna I East (8010m) was reached. Bad weather conditions thwarted the plan to continue the climb towards main summit. Hajzer and Kukuczka descended to the 7500m bivvy and spent the night there. On 14 Oct they continued the descent via the slopes of Roc Noir and Glacier Dome (7193m) and bivouacked once again at 6800m. Next day the base camp was reached.

The second team consisted of Espinoza, Navarrete and Majer who took a much easier variation.  On 15 Oct they reached the tent at 7500m and next day left for the summit. At 2 pm Navarette gained the top and in spite of wind and cold spent there about 10 minutes. I didn't reach the very top and waited for him a few meters below it. Espinoza had to give up some 200m before the summit. We descended to our tent and slept there. Next day (17 October) the weather was bad with strong wind and mist. Descending the east ridge we had route finding difficulties. In the area of the sharp ridge of Roc Noir, Navarrette disappeared, probably falling through a cornice. Lack of visibility prevented us from a search. Beneath Roc Noir Espinoza fell some 100m but survived. The night from 17 to 18 we spent both in snow caves without equipment. In the morning the tent at 7200m was reached and base camp informed about the fatal accident. A rescue team including Steve Untch helped the exhausted pair and went in quest of Navarette, unfortunately, in vain. The base camp was left on 22 Oct.

Ramiro Navarrette (39) had very good seasons in South America and belonged to the best mountaineers of his country. In Sept 1987 he climbed the Shishapangma (8027m).
ACCIDENTS: Espinoza fingers frostbitten and temporary leg paralysis after fall; Navarrete fatal fall
ACHIEVMENT: Climbed Glacier Dome en route to Annapurna East Summit

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to food and fuel supplies finished
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at normal site for NE Face
ABC at 4800m 
C3  at NE Face seracs.

In KTM before leaving for Manaslu, decided since team only 2 instead of 4 or 5, would be safer to climb normal route than NW Face. 

C1 pitched on 30 Sept but first slept in on 3 Oct. One summit attempt: Hori and sirdar Moti Lal Gurung went up and made C3 with Spanish member Juan and Ang Lhakpa Sherpa on 23 Oct. Next day on up and at 7500m Hori sick (had cold?) so in bad condition and turned back with Moti to BC some day while Spanish member and Ang Lhakpa made biv at 7800m and summited following day. Dangerous route: many avalanches (Spaniards stayed high during bad weather and were hit often, Japanese down quickly and not hit). Climb abandoned on day of Hori's descent because had brought only 2 weeks of high altitude food.
ACCIDENTS: Kurotaki had limbago and could not carry so stopped climbing

LEADERS: Antoni Lopez De Haro, Francisco Soler Dies
ROUTEMEMO:
C2 near Naike Col.

Spent many days at BC 1st week of Oct because of heavy snowfall and much avalanching; were two attempts in this period but got no higher than C3. Finally in successful attack made C4 on 23 Oct, biv on 24th and top on 25th. 1st attack ended where 3 Sherpas and 1 member carried 300m by avalanche on 3rd Oct but not injured (hit at 6800m). During avalanche period many crevasses filled so very dangerous because could not see crevasses between C1 and C2. Camps carried away but tents at C2 and C3 broken by weight of deep snow. No other summit attack after 25 Oct because health not so good and only 3 real climbers left. After failure of 1st attack many members went home (all of Lopez group left 8 Oct with Soler i Dies and Gonzalez and all but 1 Sherpa who had conflict with other Sherpas). Not technically difficult climb, says Agullo, but altitude is problem.
ACCIDENTS: Slight frostbite by Agullo; some members slightly battered by avalanche falls into crevasse

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6800m due to one member's frostbite and low supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  same as Koreans at foot of southwest ridge which joins South Ridge
C1  on South Ridge (had traversed across from SW Ridge base)
C2  on South Ridge
C3  on South Ridge
Biv on South Ridge where SE Ridge joins it.

Between C2 and C3 very difficult. After biv made on 29th, Gardzielewski became frostbitten and necessary to evacuate him. He and Soroka were 1st summit team and 2nd summit team had to help get him down. Now supplies dwindling and final section of climb above biv needed more fixed rope for quick ascent than they had. Climbing finished.

ROUTE1: N Face up; W Ridge-W Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at moraine near junction Gyabrag and Palung Glacier
C1 at Palung Glacier
C2 at bottom of N Face (bergschrund, ice hole)
C3 on North Face
C4 on North Face.

Long approach and difficult from BC to C1. C2 to C3 and above C4 to top most difficult with no place to put C3 lower. Some parts 55-60 degrees, avalanche 45+ degrees. Mostly snow and ice face. C3 to C4 very bad snow condition (powder snow with thin ice crust). Couloir from 7800m to 8150m of rock slabs covered with ice and snow - no avalanching. Some seracs between C3 to C4 but did not fall in very cold weather (C1 -25 degrees early morning) with 1 hour direct sun on face. Very windy on top but generally no wind on face. Fixed rope from C2 to C3; 1700m fixed. 

On 2 Nov Tomazin alone from C3 to top and down Tichy route in unprepared descent to 6000m where met Skarja at 2:00 am on 3 Nov. All 3 returned to BC 7 am.
 
3 Nov Groselj and Rozman made C4 4 Nov wind and snowfall kept them in C4 and 5 Nov to top via small traverse to Tichy route and descended same way. 

8 Nov Nadvesnik and Prezelj from C4 direct to top via couloir and descended couloir to C1 and C2, respectively. 

9 Nov Jereb and Robas from C4 to top via small traverse of 5 Nov and down to C2. 

Left BC 14th Nov. 5th degree average difficulty (French TD - tres difficult like classical north face route in Alps). One of last great Himalayan faces. Couloir is about vertical 300m high, starting from 7850m; last 10m is 90-degree rock.
ACCIDENTS: Some frostbite but all will heal
ACHIEVMENT: 1st attempt of N Face; 1st ascent of face; 1st traverse

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to disappearance of climbers
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at west side of Kalapattar above Changri Shar Glacier
C1 at plateau in upper Changri Shar Glacier.

Planned biv at 6600m with one very long day to this biv on 60-degree ice (no place for camp) and then go for summit next day. Giersson active in load carrying and overdid it: was coughing blood, left expedition 14th Oct and went to Paris hospital, where found had a fractured rib. By now had fixed all ropes they had (400m) from 5850m to 6000m on very steep ice gullies with rock below the 60-degree ice face to ridge. (Aisthorpe went to Pheriche on 16th sick with gastric flu and message sent by him from HRA post to BC saying they should carry on without him). 

2 remaining left BC on 17th for summit bid; were seen from BC by sirdar, cook and LO on 18th late morning moving up ice slope above fixed ropes. Last seen 2:00 pm 18th moving together at 6400m, then moved behind serac and never seen again. 19th 8:00 am Aisthorpe arrived at BC and spent day waiting for them to appear. On 20th he got up at 4:00 am and went to C1 to have a look, arrived at C1 expecting find them there but no sign of them there or above on route and did same on 21st. "No doubt bodies are in bergschrund." On 21st also walked around under SE Face to look. Not feasible for him to climb above C1 because of crevasses. Pair must have fallen roped together. Aisthorpe's highest point was about 6000m at top of fixed ropes. No chance others reached summit because route above serac clearly visible from BC (could well have been behind it an hour and then emerged back into view). Highest possible point for them to have reached without having been seen would be 6550m.

Australian Jeffery Williams reported seeing pair on summit afternoon of Oct 19 (AAJ).


Report Searching the Body

Four of us started to searching the bodies on 5th June. We arrived in Lobuje and spend over night there. The next morning we started at 7am and arrived at Gorakshep within 1 and 1/2 hours. We set our camp at Gorakshep and make a day tour all around the icefall and crampons. We were searching there for couple of days. Our detail route as given with a rough map.

Well first of all we had been to base camp and looking all around the ice fall, same day we climbed Kalapattar. The day was clear so we have had good view of both side of mtns and due icefall and crampons, but there is no sign of bodies, so we came back to camp that day.

Next day we had been climbing the black rock which is more higher.


Accident Report Anglo-Icelandic Pumori Expedition 1988

The Anglo-Icelandic Pumori Expedition established a base camp at west of Kalapattar, the site used by the 1986 New Zealand Expedition.

From 4th to 13th Oct, members established and carried loads to a high camp at approx. 5800m on the Upper Changri Shar Glacier. We also fixed about 400m of rope on steep ice and mixed ground on the West Face. Porsteinn, Gudjonnson, Kristinn Runarsson and Steve Aisthorpe all spent two nights at the high camp and two days fixing ropes.

On 4th October Jon Giersson had begun to develop pains in the chest and now, after talking with doctors at the Himalayan Rescue Association post in Pheriche, he decided to return to Paris. He left base camp on 14th Oct and we all spent the night together with Porsteinn. I began to develop sysmtoms of gastric flu. On 16th Oct I descended to Pheriche to speak to the doctor about this. As the doctor suggested that it would be 4-7 days before I would recover. I sent a message with Ang Nuru, our sirdar, suggesting that Porsteinn and Kristinn should continue climbing without me

On receiving this message on the morning of the 17th Oct, they left base camp at 10 am with intention of going to high camp that day, leaving the camp at midnight, ascending the fixed ropes, climbing together up ice to reach the SW Ridge at about 6700m, bivouacing there, then going for the summit on the 19th, then descending the West Face by asceil. The took from the high camp 2100 ropes, 10 screws, 6 gas cylinders, sleeping bags, down clothing, bivi bags and food.

On 18th Oct, while I was still in Pheriche recovering from gastric flu, Ang Nuru and Phu Dorje, watched Porsteinn and Kristinn through a camera with a telephone lens. They made steady program and were moving together. They were last seen at about 2 pm, when they disappeared from view behind a serac at about 6400m. They did not reappear into view the that day.

I arrived in base camp at about 8 am on 19th Oct and waited expectantly for the two figures to appear on the ridge and climbed to the summit. Nobody appeared from above the serac that day.

On 20th Oct I left base camp at 4:30 am and climbed to the high camp. There was however no sign of them in high camp. From the C1 I had clear view of the route, but there was not sign of life. I went back to base camp and went, in the afternoon, with Ang Nuru around to below the SE Face, but there was nothing to see on the afternoon of 20th Oct. I sent a message to the officer in charge at Namche Bazar police post requesting that he radio the following message to Kathmandu; "To Mountain Travel. Please send helicopter to Gorak Shep immediately - 2 members missing." On 21st Oct I woke at 4 am and again climbed to the high camp. I searched the Upper Changri Shar Glacier as far as possible, but found nothing. I then descended to Gorak Shep and waited for a helicopter. I also spent the 22nd Oct, waiting in Gorak Shep for a helicopter. When it didn't arrive I sent our Liaison Officer, Mr Bal Krishna Shrestha, with the same message as before to Namche Bazar. I spent 23rd Oct waiting expectantly for the helicopter in Gorak Shep. On 24th Oct at 11 am a helicopter arrived in Gorak Shep. The pilot explained that the reason for the delay was that there was a policy of not making helicopters available for searching - only for rescue.

After some persuasion, the pilot took me on a search above the Changri Shar Glacier and spiralled up the West Face to about 6000m. We could not safely climb any higher. I could see no traces of Porsteinn, Kristinn or their equipment.

It seemed certain that they had fallen from about 6500m on 18th Oct and that there bodies now lay in the complex bergschrund at the foot of the face. As I was the only remaining climber in the area and none of the our base camp Sherpas were equipped or experienced enough to venture serious risk to my own life. The crevasses on the Upper Changri Shar Glacier had opened up considerably during the last week and for me to move around on the glacier after the sun had begun to soften the snow bridges was very dangerous. After six very cold nights and a small snowfall, it seemed certain that any searching was for bodies only and, as such, further searches by myself seemed unjustifiable.

I returned to Kathmandu with the helicopter and tried to contact Jon Giersson and Anna Lara Fredrickdottir from the Mountain Travel Office. Eventually, at about 10 pm local time I spoke with Bjorn, Anna's husband and President of the Icelandic Alpine Club. I gave as much information as possible about what had happened to Porsteinn and Kristinn. On 25th Oct I spoke with Kristinn's father on the telephone and related the above incidents in as much detail as possible. In my opinion Porsteinn and Kristinn died on 18th Oct as a result of a fall down the steep rock and ice of the West Face of Pumori. Their bodies lie in the bergschrund at the foot of the face. I am a committed Christian and have committed them into God's care.

Much bad snowfall; alpine-style climb from high BC on 15 Sept and reached C2 that day. 16 Sept to C3. 17 Sep to top and down to 6700m in much new snow and 18 Sept to high BC in more bad weather and avalanching. Had to probe ahead like blind men 10 cm distance at a time to feel their way in fog and snow. On 17th night both had snow blindness because could not wear glasses and see. On 17th reached summit only by following track of French. Otherwise would not have been able find summit, which was near when weather closed in. Pushed on despite bad weather because had no time for second summit push. Not difficult technically.

No sign of [body of] Stefan Woerner or any tent; snow very deep.

Chinese BC 21st
High BC near Nangpa La (at sharp bend in route of Spanish 1984)
C1 at top of ridge running southwest (in direct line with M of Khumbu)
C2 under serac
C3 at top of seracs (end of serac section)
C4 at Spanish 1984 autumn C4.

1st attempt for summit 5 Sept. 2 members reached 7900m but knee-deep snow and tired; all down to high BC. 

2nd attempt by 3 men on 9 Sept. On 11th one back down while 2 to C3 and 12th to C4 and 13th to top. 14th all camps cleared.

Too much snow to see [body of] Stefan Woerner or his tent.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st 8000er by any one from their region

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to strong winds and Langmade's frostbite
ROUTEMEMO:
C3 just above rock band across face.

C3 tent completely destroyed during night of 17-18 Oct, so on 18th instead of making 2nd summit bid, went down all the way to the glacier (to BC) because no tent left and winds not abating. Now had no other high-altitude tent and Langmade had developed frostbite in fingers and toes.

Two bags of personal gear stolen by local people; LO and translator had quit. Got back everything by search of Tingri houses; paid Tibet International Sports Travel less than contracted for as a result.

Saw body (presumably Stefan Woerner's) wrapped tightly in a tent in a shallow grave at 7400m.

BC at Gyabrag Glacier (probably usual C1 site)
Biv 1 east of point 6446m
Biv 2 
Biv 3 under rock barrier.

2 climbers only. 13 Oct began climb and slept under serac after ridge. 14th crossed seracs. 15th slept at 7600m and on 16th Henschke alone upwards and reached highest summit.

On 16th saw 2 people going up from below rock barrier and probably reached summit on 17th.

Had trekking permit only therefore an unauthorized climb.

Dudek (Langtang Lirung) - Henschke is strong climber - was on same route as Poles in 1985 (Gardzelesinski, member of Langtang now was 1985 summiter).

SPONSOR: Alpine Expedition City of Lecco Cho Oyu N Face
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5700m at normal site
Italian BC at west side of Col 6517m for N Ridge route
C1 at normal route
C2 at normal route.

N Ridge route climbed to col 6517m and up Ridge to 6800m and down because new snow very soft and ridge steep and windy; avalanche danger too great. Saw 3 members turn back at col. 

Then to normal route which not difficult; from summit to BC same day. 

On N Ridge above 6800m much blue ice but not very difficult.

SPONSOR: Japan Workers Alpine Federation Tochigi Pumori Expedition 1988
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at north side of small lake ESE of mountain
C2 little below NE Ridge.

Fixed rope from 5700m to 6150m. Did not sleep in ABC; used it as base for fixing rope. Route slightly different from 1986 winter Japanese. In descent Yanigahara fell 10m into crevasse between top and C2 and spent night in biv at 5900m with Nomura; not injured and only very slightly frostnip 2-3 toes. Not difficult climb.
ACCIDENTS: Harmless fall in crevasse by Yanagihara; Nagatsuga slight illness at time of summit bid

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5300m near lake (normal site - same as Japanese Autumn 1988)
C1 at 6100m at same as Japanese on East Face
C2 same as Japanese on East Face.

6th Oct night 1 meter of snow and so only two strongest to summit. Last section of climb below top crevasse opening was swimming in deep snow. Good cooperation with Japanese, shared ropes. Route was 200m left of couloir dangerous from avalanches in autumn.

BC  east of Kalapattar's high point
ABC at moraine at base of snow
C1  at col on SW Ridge where it breaks up into 2 ridges south of summit
C2 (biv) ice cave on SW Ridge
Biv summit snow slopes at top of ridge.

Climbed ice face on east side of SW Ridge; 80-degree water ice just below C2 (at 6700m). 2 summit teams left C2 at 6 am and 7 am on 10th Oct (C2 had no tents but sleeping bags, etc.) Woolums and Vran fixed some rope got to top at 3:45 pm and on descent at 4:20 pm met Howes and Corvini moving slowly upwards at 400m below summit. 1st party to C2 at 9 pm while 2nd party on up about 50m and then bivouacked out of wind in small hole; went to top [next day] at 12:10-12:25 pm at 15 degrees centigrade and 50-knot gusts of wind and down to C2 at 10:00 pm. Corvini dropped the rope. Corvini developed frostbite over next few days having failed to remove his 4 pairs of socks for days.

Route has no great technical difficulties, but people die on it because they make their last camps too low.

SPONSOR: Himalayan Venture 1988 - British Expedition to Khatang
APPROACH: Tried N of Thanga a trail that does not exist->Lumding Kharke
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to bad snow conditions and lack of time
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  northwest of Lumding Kharka
ABC Tsho Og lake
Biv in icefall.

Arrived BC 8 days late because porters deserted them. Sirdar got onto track that didn't exist and had find the way through rhododendron forest. After BC did a recce of SE Ridge and found did not have time and resources for ridge with 300m rock step which was too formidable for present expedition, so turned attention to NE Ridge. 

25th Oct recce icefall to 5000m. 27th Oct 4 left ABC and camped at 5450m, 28th on to col at foot of ridge at 5720m and started to find Swiss ropes and went on up 45-50 degrees steep ridge mostly snow, at first quite good snow but became unconsolidated sugar. Got to 6100m at 2:30 pm in slow going and no site for camping and slight chance of completing ridge to top next day, so down to ABC. 

Another team went through icefall on 29th intending to put camp at col, which they reached on 30th and hacked out ice platform for a tent and spent night there. 31st on up ridge but encountered same problem when snow powdered and no protection possible; got to just little below 6100m and gave up. Climbing finished and all down to BC by 2 Nov. Very difficult ridge for alpine-style ascent.
ACCIDENTS: None except illness of Coulthard before BC

ROUTEMEMO:
Climbed Xixabangma first (to summit on 24 Oct) then to a "very fast climb" of Cho Oyu.

In the autumn of '88 Noboru Yamada who had already made seven 8000ers, summits, climbed above 2 peaks, which left him five more unclimbed 8000ers among 14 of them. He organized the HAJ team, led by him, comprised 4 members. They reached BC of Xixabangma on Oct 9 and carried their loads up to ABC for 3 days. On the NE Ridge (normal route) after they push up C1 (6300m) on Oct 17, C2 (6900m) on Oct 19 they fixed ropes up to 7350m. On Oct 24 all the members attacked the summit and except O. Shimizu (30) who gave up at the point of 7350m, Yamada, T. Saegus and A. Yamamoto (26) kept climbing until they made the summit at 13:50. On Oct 29 they withdrew the BC and took one day rest at Xegar then approached the Cho Oyu BC (4750m) on Oct 31. Pushing up on the normal West Ridge (WNR Ridge) route they placed ABC (5700m), C1(6350m) and on Nov 6 all the members reached the summit.

BC as planned (6 Sept advanced team arrived).

After C2 established much snowfall stalled progress. C2 to C3 most difficult: ice and snow very steep and sharp ridge. Fixed total 1400m rope. From C3 to top long time: 4:00 am to 12:30 midday because long distance and 3 overhangs. No time for another summit bid: flight home fixed.

Think their route is same as Japanese '88 winter but are not sure about upper part, where Koreans traversed to West Ridge.

SPONSOR: 1988 Korean Nepalese Himalaya Gyachung Kang Expedition
ROUTEMEMO:
BC as same as Japanese near lake.

Route changed slightly from plan because Japanese already climbing this planned route. Very difficult above C3; very steep ice face with no proper space for C4. Fixed 3000m total, 2000m from C3 to top. Had planned summit push day after C4 established but too much difficult ice step-cutting. No other summit bid after 24th because supplies running out. Route between Japanese 1964 spring & French 1986 spring expeditions.


Expedition Report/Gyachung Kang (7952m) by Hwa-Seok Yang
Taken from Sanak in winter 1988

Daejeon Seil Club, the first summiter to Ngojumba Kang in 1982, again made a great achievement on SW Face of Gyachung Kang this time. 

On Oct 2nd they advanced to C2 for 5 days and on 12th, C2 was secured at the foot of the Gyachung Kang Face.

Suddenly on Oct 17th, they saw a unfortunate Japanese climber falling down in his way of returning from SW Ridge leaving to the summit just 50m and they continued climbing with more indomitable spirit, so that they overcame the difficult route to fix the ropes. Especially toward C4, they had to climb up almost vertical face mixed with rock, snow and ice, which needed more time than expected. Consequently they could not find any suitable place for their camp after dark, and it was over 8:00 pm when they barely managed to sleep just in one tent blocked with ice. It was Oct 22. C4 was established at 7500m the next day.

On Oct 24th, member Yeon Heon-Mo and Shim Yeom-Bo started for the summit with Ang Rinji and Ang Dorji. After overcoming the mixed route with ice and snow (over 100m long), they arrived at the point connected from West Ridge to the summit. Due to very steep rock slope just below the summit, they had to make a detour of long and exhausted advances in the direction of Tibet, and after 5 hours and 20 minutes of struggles they finally reached the summit.

SPONSOR: Fukuoka University Alpine Club Gyachung Kang Expedition 1988
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7800m due to Baba's fatal fall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on north side of Ngozumba Kang Glacier (same as Koreans).

Joined French Spring 1986 route only at 7200m because of crevasse below, between C1 and C2. From C2 to C4 very steep and required fixed rope entire distance. 17th Oct summit attack by Ang Phurba, Baba and Kikuchi: started from C4 at 6 am; to 7800m easy climb because plenty of snow on rock and reached there at 12:15 pm; decided they should turned down because tired and Kikuchi planned to join 2nd attack party from C4 next day. Ang Phurba quickly reached C4 (1-1/2 hour). Baba probably reached traverse from C4, but now so cloudy no one there could see him; no fixed rope needed in easy couloir above C4. Kikuchi reached C4 10 mins after Baba was there and fell. 2nd attack party's Sherpas saw Baba falling below C4; he stopped falling near C2 near crevasse and was dead of broken head, etc. Now climbing stopped.


Tourism Ministry, 23 Oct 88

Mr Sinichi Baba, 1960, staff of Hare Co., Kiami Kokura Mihaki Saga of Japan, a climbing member of 11-member Nepal-Japan expedtion to Gyachungkang (7952m) reported to have slipped to death from 7300m on 17 October. He had started to climb to summit at 6 am that day but after reaching 7800m, turned back being very late and reaching near C4 at 7300m. Mr Baba slipped it is reported. Also reported, his body found near C2 (6300m) and his last rites completed there. Expedition being abandoned due to this accident. Leader of the expedition is Mr Uematsu Mitsuo, 1936, Fukuoka Hospital secretary.

1st attempt from C3 on 12 Sept; had waited few days for slower members to acclimatize and then 2 days bad weather. Left BC 9 Sept with half of group; 10th stayed extra day again C2; 12th first team on top. 13th second team from C3 to C4; 14th second team to top. Not difficult climb (easier than Gasherbrum II and Xixabangma) when much snow but snow may be dangerous when wind slabs are exposed.

Cormier parapented from start of summit plateau (8100m) to 5900m. Gouvy and Perillat glacier surfed (single ski but not mono-ski) from summit to C1 at end of snow very quickly.

Mono ski and short-alpine skier Bovero died suddenly of pulmonary edema in his tent at Everest BC while on acclimatization trek before climb.


Brumo Cormier - 19 Sept 88

Cormier arrived KTM today, Jaccoux and others on 24th eve (except Vincent)
Cormier flew by hang-glider
on 12 Sept 7 people on summit
   14 Sept 5
          ---
          12 = 2 guides
               3 Sherpas
               7 clients

Also on 14 Sept two Italians on top
4 frostbite cases and 1 dead at Everest BC
ACCIDENTS: 5 frostbite cases (very cold and windy since Sept 8); serious 1 toe and 1 fingertips; one dead before BC

ROUTE1: W Face-NW Ridge (did not reach ridge)
SPONSOR: 1988 Korea Alpine Club Kyung Dong O-B Ama Dablam Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to dangerous stone fall and avalanching
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Mingbo Glacier moraine
ABC C1 at Mingbo Glacier snow.

After C1 established, lot of snow and wind and many snow avalanches which left mountain all rock, so waited for better weather. 25th September 2 members [Hyuk and Jang] to bottom of ridge, but late every morning stonefall and from W Face snow avalanches. Again waited several days for improved conditions. Much equipment from BC and during retreat from BC.

BC at 4930m above Mingbo
C1 at arrete tower on SW Ridge.

Had expected to climb in expedition style but felt very fit and switched to alpine-style. 1st summit team 3 members [Christensen, Hjorth, Smidt] started on 6th, biv 5400m, 7th to ABC. 8th actual climbing started on ridge until were at 6000m and made C1. 9th in C1 resting. 10th to 6300m to C2 (snowhole where they bivouacked). 11th Hjorth stayed at snowhole while other 2 went to summit and returned to C2. 12th and 13th down to BC. 

3 members [Mathorne, Hansen, Nicolaisen] started up on 9th to ABC from BC. 10th to C1. 11th rest (Nicolaisen little sick from altitude). 12th towards to C2 but Nicolaisen sicker and all down with him to BC. 

16th Mathorne and Hansen again up to ABC, 17th to C1. 18th to C2 and 19th on top (5:00-10:30 am ascent), to C2 same afternoon and BC 21st. 

Left BC 24th. Hansen frostbitten toes during summit day (had had frostbite before so toes sensitive). No fixed rope; alpine-style. Smidt left BC 20th to return to studies.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Danish ascent on 1st Danish expedition to Himalaya

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to fatal avalanche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Lhotse Shar BC site, east of Island Peak
C1 at Lhotse Shar Glacier
High point at 6000m at west side of Col.
 
While making route to C2 Bourdais had fatal accident; wanted to put C2 at S Col 96220m) of Ch Polu. On 21st Oct Bourdais was hammering piton for rope-fixing when serac fell and caused avalanche; had seen seracs above but were not moving, did not look threatening. Avalanche carried him 200-300 vertical meters. Perrot had just time see avalanche coming and jump aside; not really injured. Climb finished. Body found and dead of broken head. One night had avalanche at C1 and had to hold tent down (22nd Oct); not safe place to be. Seracs were near Col; big avalanches were coming down Lhotse Shar and these sent wind and snow into C1.
Ridge not difficult and snow good. Summit push started after 2 days acclimatization climb and rest. Returned to BC 5:00 pm on 24th (had started from BC 1:00 pm on 22nd) and left BC 25th.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5700m due to too much snow and lack of equipment
ROUTEMEMO:
High point at 5700m by all climbing members.

No fixed camps above BC but fixed ropes above BC starting 5th Oct and fixed 700m (not steep but much snow). Made biv and then climbing finished: no tent and no sun in -15 degrees Centrigrade plus too much snow on what should be rock ridge for 1st 800m (1m loose snow here). Came down and sent sirdar to Namche for permit to go to normal route but no answer.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to poor health and time running out because Swiss forced delay
ROUTEMEMO:
BC next to Swiss
C1 next to Swiss on SE Ridge
C2 next to Swiss on SE Ridge end on biv.

Problem with Swiss: didn't want German BC next to them and had taken easiest line on their SE Face which was SE Ridge, where they had put their C1 and C2. Swiss wanted Germans to wait till 6th or 7th Oct when they had reached summit. Germans waited 15 days (Swiss said if Germans started before Swiss finished, Swiss would endanger German camps). Germans trekked to Kalapattar during waiting period. Germans had time only for 21 days so walked daily carrying loads to C1 and C2. One man to Swiss C3 on 25th Oct and on 26th slept there, 27th to C2, slept in C1 and 28th slept there. 29th Oct Swiss said Germans could go to C3 only next day. Between C2 and C3 Hof got stomach trouble. Now time and money running out; one week more on mountain needed.

OTHERSMTS: Island Peak (by all members over 5 weeks); had permit for Lhotse, but did not attempt
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at north side (base) of Island Peak
C1 at top of 1st big rocks where glacier starts
C2 at 1st big icefall (at top of it) on SE Face
C3 on SE Face
C4 on SE Face
Biv at near point where SE Ridge meets SE Face (snowcave).

1st team [Jelk and Brigger on 20 Oct] turned back at 7500m because of strong wind.

2nd summit team of Imboden and Ferrari [on 24 Oct] to 8000m where ridge is flat but narrow; turned back because feared fog would come and prevent finding C5 on return. 

4 days later Imboden and Willi made successful bid. 

Technically not difficult but altitude problem and necessary to be extremely careful on such an exposed route; above C4 is very steep. "We had enough trouble getting to top of Lhotse Shar." Ridge to Lhotse is very dangerous and difficult cornices and towers at high altitude. No attempt to go to Lhotse or Lhotse Intermediate.

"Had same problem with Germans" who wanted to climb Swiss fixed ropes; "matter of too many" cause for refusal to let Germans on ropes.
ACCIDENTS: Imboden frostbitten nose, toes and fingers but will heal

ROUTE2: NW Ridge up; W Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at east of Charchang.

1st attempt via W Face: biv at 17,500 ft at top moraine on 6th Oct. 7th onto glacier to 18,000 ft biv, 8th to 19,500 ft on W Face, 9th to 500 ft below summit when getting late and climb ahead looked difficult and all slightly sick (all 4 men to just above top biv; all but Parker to high point on this push) and returned to high biv. 11th all in BC. 

Walters and Selters went on up onto NW Ridge starting on 18th with biv (at col SE of Pt 5677) at 18,500 ft; 19th on up to 100-150 ft below top on summit plateau above end of Ridge biv. 22nd to top and down W Face to 19,500 ft platform of 8th Oct and route had been prepared by earlier push; 23rd from 19,500 ft to BC. 

24th Oct Collins and Parker up from BC to W Face route and bived at 17,500 ft; 25th to 20,000 ft biv; 26th to 20,200 ft and again Parker ill so down to BC.

1st push had completed W Face in a new route. W Face water ice, other route powder snow and lousy rock.

BC at normal site of higher BC
C1 at normal route/6500m bottom of West Face
C3 at Makalu La.

Patscheider made brief attempt to climb W Face but never actually was on face. Eitel party on normal route from northwest side without success. 2 Mexicans on normal route; Carsolio summited. Troillet and Loretan attempted W Pillar.

Troillet and Loretan's climbing:
  Arrived at BC 7th Oct. 
  9th to 6200m on small peak above BC. 
  10th to below W Face and climbed couloir to east side of W Pillar and 6700m.
  11th to 7200m on pillar to see conditions and down to BC; snow conditions OK 
     on pillar but winds slab on W Face made it unsafe.
  12th to C1 to bring down Carsolio and returned to BC at night. 
  BC rested and 17th up to couloir to 6700m for 4 hrs. and up again at 5:00 pm; 
     reached 7100m on pillar, retreated in strong wind and BC that midnight.
     18th onwards was strong wind everyday so on 22nd gave up and left BC 24th 
     when porters arrived.

Patschnieder to only 6800m at big crevasse at bottom of face; did not actually climb on face.

Elsa and Carlos Carsolio together:

Climbed point 6170m for acclimatization and spent night on summit (7th Sept). 11th Sept started up Kukuczka route and climbed to 7000m and slept there 2 nights (12-13th Sept) still for acclimatization. Snowfall and poor weather next and rumor there would be another earthquake.
 
25th Sept started from high BC at 5300m in first summit bid; climbed normal route; 1 night in C1, 1 in C2 and C4 on 28th Sept made bid for summit but very deep snow for breaking trail. Reached 8200m at 6:00 pm and returned to C4 and next day on down to BC rested, small snowfall and wind came and very difficult to climb. 

2 Spaniards and 2 Mexicans 5th Oct started up again from BC. C1 with Walde. 6th in C2, very windy; Elsa 2 nights, Carlos 5 nights. 11th Oct Carlos up alone, direct to C4. 12th on up in very cold strong wind and reached summit at 7:00 pm, very cold on top. Returned to C4 that night (doesn't know time, too tired). 13th downwards, Spanish gave him oxygen in C2 and to BC same day.


Letter from Hans Eitel to Miss Hawley - 15 Oct 88

Report from the expedition.
High camp Base 5300m on 21 Sept 88. 
Carlos Elsa Carsolio arrived the camp two weeks before Reinhard Patscheider started the climb on West Face solo.

26 Sep 88 - Kurt Walde, Claudia, Hans Eitel, Ang Gyalzen Sherpa, depot on 5800m.

28 Sep 88 - Claudia Inceichen, Hans Eitel, C1 6400m.
Reinhard Patscheider west face C1 tent on serac, Kurt Walde, N/W C2.

30 Sep 88 - Claudia Inceichen, Hans Eitel, Ang Gyalzen Sherpa C1 the next day Hans Eitel Camp 2 7000m solo and from C2 back to base camp. Claudia Inceichen and Ang Gyalzen from C1 to base camp back. Carlos and Elsa came back from 8200m.

From now we have many wind from Makalu La to the top of the mountain.
Reinhard Pattscheider solo on West Face 7000m, he finished, so E. Loretan and Jean Troillet not coming.

6 Oct 88 - Reinhard Patscheider started from BC back to KTM. All climbers must wait for better weather. The problem is now only the wind. Carlos, Elsa start again to the mountain.

7 Oct 88 - Erhard Loretan and Jean Troillet arrived the BC with 5 porters.
He brings the message I must go home.

8 Oct 88 - Hans Eitel started with 1 porter to Tumlingtar.

BC at high BC
C2 at Chago Glacier
C3 at Makalu La
C4 on North Face very near NW Ridge.

Kukuczka rib is good for one push, but with much snow this not possible. C4 were tents of Spanish and British. After C4 on 3rd Oct down in very strong winds which destroyed C2 and C3. Waited for winds to abate and had to replace camps. Winds low 12 and 13 Oct. 

2nd summit team started up from BC on 9th Oct and reached C2 on 10th. 11th one decided to descend because sick from heptitis so he descended while other 2 men up to C3. 13th to C4 and 14th to top. Kolakowski seen by his headlamp at 8:00 pm near summit (within 50m of top), then disappeared. Kopys waited for him at C4 till 12:00 noon 15th; wind now very strong and white-out during night so chances of survival very slim. 

3rd team in C3 could not leave tent because wind so strong on 16th (Kopys had gone to C1 on 15th). 16th 3rd party went down at noon; could not go up because terrible wind (in 3rd party were Kacuga, Kaploniak and Skierski).
ACCIDENTS: Kolakowski disappeared near summit; Aldaz hepatitis; Kopys frostbitten toes infected

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to cold, wind, fatigue and much distance still to cover
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Tangmar, yak porters between Shershan and Barun Pokhari
C1 at small lake north of Barun Pokhari
C2 between 2 rock ridges on glacier (south of summit)
C3 just below S Col.

After C3 established, some snowfall and change of season. All resting at BC several days. Then climbing above C4 snow in place knee deep, some steepness, very windy. 7 days to open route above C3 to 7000m really easy area but snow slowed progress with winds blowing away the track every day. From 7000m up more difficult with small couloirs and rock. Technically more difficult but less snow on steeper area, so easier to move. On 16 Oct deposited food and rope at C4 site but then decided to quit: team tired, very cold and windy, long way still to go. Perhaps on fast alpine-style attack could have succeeded. All members reached C3 and 6 worked on route above C3, but morale not good by mid-October.
ACCIDENTS: Nothing serious, but health generally not good

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8050m due to bad wind; climbers exhausted after 6 weeks at altitude
ROUTEMEMO:
C3 at Makalu La
C4 at North Face.

28th Sep Zamora and Canelles reached 7800m to reach C4 site. 1st Oct 3 members to 8050m and back because Matas got bad frostbite fixing a crampon in 1st summit bid. 2nd summit team only to Makalu La and then helped British climber Rick Allen to descend after his accident. 3rd summit team also only to Makalu La and then down helping Mexican climber Carlos Carsolio to descend following summit success and pulmonary edema (he used Spaniard's oxygen from C2 down). After that wind too strong for summit push to succeed. 

All members reached Makalu La. 2 members (Zamora and Canellas) to summit of Kangchungtse 27th Sep from Makalu La camp via S Ridge.

French and Andorran members left early for personal (family) reasons.

ROUTE1: Left side of W Face-N Face
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m due to high wind and avalanche accident/danger, snow, and too many others on mountain at same time
OTHERSMTS: Some peaks between Chago and Pethangtse
ROUTEMEMO:
1st push:  BC  at lower BC site
           ABC at higher BC site
           Biv at bottom of Roger Baxter Jones Couloir
           High point at North Face.

Bivs by Allen and Hinkes.  

1st biv on 20th Sep by Miller, Smith, Child and Allen. On 22nd went to Makalu La; at same time others to 7000m. Then big snowstorm and weather now cold which meant couloir now dangerous.

Hinkes and Allen then went to left ridge of couloir, crossed into cwm, bived at 7800m (Spanish C4). On 1st Oct at 4:00 am they went on up and got avalanched. Took 5 days get them off. Winds now strong and route avalanche-prone. Parkin, Scott and Prabhu along with Child, Smith and Miller had gone to Makalu La 29th Sep but wind and snow drove them down. Hinkes and Allen started from ABC 28th Sep. Smith and Child went up on 7th Oct but only to C1.

"So many others on mountain normal route was like a motorway and not many with any ideas of Himalayan climbing" - Scott.

West Face impossible: wind slabs and powdered snow.

Allen fell 400m because unconscious and Hinkes came to him and helped him down. Were at 8100m in summit bid on 1 Oct at 10:00 am. Had been climbing semi-alpine-style using Spanish fixed ropes to C2 and carrying tent (Spanish making their own and summit bid same day). 30 Sept 2 Mexicans had tried for top and planned another try on 3rd or 4th Oct.

None of this expedition had been on West Face till Allen left today by helicopter.
ACCIDENTS: Yates hepatitis and left BC Sep 24; Allen head injuries from avalanche

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to lack of morale
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Shershon
C1 at new high Makalu BC
High point at 6240m.

Lost much time waiting for doctor to arrive at BC, which he never did because very ill; he almost died at Nun and this was shock. Doctor reached Nun and then developed high fever for which he took so many pills that his liver stopped functioning and survived only thanks to a trekking doctor.

Made 2 recces of icefall of Lower Barun Glacier but too dangerous to go through it and decided not to take risk and changed route. Placed high camp near normal site for Makalu high BC. Stayed there 3 days to see if their help needed by Poles on Makalu and did some recce of way to S Ridge to highest point reached in series of recces from high camp. Gave up because hearts weren't in climbing with their doctor's illness, Makalu casualties and winds very strong.
ACCIDENTS: None (except doctor who never reached BC)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7000m due to route difficulty
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at West Col
High point on SE Ridge.

After C2 came down to BC on 23 and occupied C2 on 26th in summit push. Stopped when saw ridge was very steep sharp and dangerous for such a large group. Lot of wind on ridge; if wanted to finish ridge it would have taken 4-5 more days and technical materials not taken to mountain.

Crossed Amphu Lapcha 30 Oct.

BC at normal site
C3 at Great Shelf.

13th Oct 1st summit bid but route chosen led to very difficult rock at 8350m; Unno and Fukushima returned to C5 and next day to C3. 

16th Oct Unno and Nima Temba to C5; Fukushima not up again because only 3 bottles oxygen in C5 now. 17th Oct started at 5:20 am, arrived top 10:10 am in fine weather, light wind; descended to C3 on 17th at 5:00 pm and to BC 18th. Climb finished. 

Miss Kamura to C1 only: "tired." 

From 15 to 26 Sept spent time in bad weather and trying different routes, 1 to 11 Oct, BC rest.

ROUTE2: W Pillar (permit route, did not attempt)
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to bad weather and deep snow on W Pillar route
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on two glaciers' junction
C1 on normal route.

Team first began on normal route for acclimatization before going to W Pillar route (their permit route). French-American team arrived (route permit holders) and demanded Austrians vacate route. After big snowstorm, Austrians abandoned climb not wishing to attemp pillar route with so much snow.

Planned to go to SE Ridge but Swiss had its permit so interested in W Pillar and to do this acclimatize by going on normal route; also go to Makalu La to observe conditions. 13th Oct went to 6500m on normal route (normal C2) and pitched one tent as acclimatization camp and slept one night. 14th French-US team arrived and sent them off their route. Studer froze his feet in climb to 6500m and left. 17th again up to 6500m by Friedl and Marte and heavy snowfall started. Brought down tent on 18th and big storm continued so 20th left BC to return to KTM. Strong winds started up now also on 18th and these would make W Pillar climb impossible immediately and wanted to take no risk.

Studer & Morik (who did not climb) left BC 17th Oct.


Studer - 27 Oct 87

Rudi Mayerhofer = acting leader of Makalu, at Shakti.

Studer in KTM 5 days now; some frostbite in toes; leaves Nepal 29 Oct.
Rest of expedition should arrive KTM 28 or 29 Oct, but snow conditions doubtlessly means delay.

Report 4 dead on Makalu probably French-US team - ministry has garbled report.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7550m due to bad weather, broken C2 and porters ordered for arrival at BC on 28th Oct
ROUTEMEMO:
BC near junction of glaciers
C1 at Chago Glacier east of Central Spur
C2 just below last steep section of glacier below col
C3 just below Makalu Col.

After C2 established, down for rest and not all to C2 so far (not necessary to make C3 of no one to C2). Deposit placed at 7500m before camp established and fixed 1000m rope from C2 to C3 (200m above C2 to 200m below 3) for clients, more than normally would put. Started up from C3 on 18th Oct to make C4 but too windy and turned back; impossible to stand up. 

American and Canadian members got only to 7000m (all got to C2). Fauquet down to BC to set out problem with Austrians who insisted on comming on same route. Now bad snowstorm arrived 19th Oct. Pivot, American and Crosett in C1 during storm and descended on 21st Oct (Americans) and 22nd (Mike with shovels). Stayed in BC one day and made track to go up and reached C1 while Makalu II came down. Again up to C2 on 25th but couldn't find C2 because of avalanche: after 2 hrs probing found one tent under 180m of snow. 26th found 2 more tents and Sherpas came and cleared same rope and oxygen. Descended again while Sherpas up to C3 26th clear camp, which found completely broken.
ACCIDENTS: Fauquet down 100m with wind-slab avalanche but not hurt

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to big snow storm damage and dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Barun Glacier near small lake SE 
ABC at Barun Glacier near "e" of Glacier (on Schneider map)
C1  at 5500m at moraine west of "G" of Glacier
C2  due west of point and NNE of Baruntse summit
High point at C2.

2 slept in C2 till 19th Oct (2 till 18th) and then down during night of 19-20th when tents completely covered and snow kept falling. Then 1.5-2m deep snow (2m at C2) so not possible to resume climb; in fact had brought down C3 in retreat of 19-20th.

TERMNOTE: Team never reached mtn
ROUTEMEMO: Team climbed Mera Peak and then set out for Baruntse, but snow too deep in passes and they turned back without having reached Baruntse.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7600m due to strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4850m below Barun Pokhari
C1 at 6750m on saddle of SE Ridge
C2 on the ridge
C3 just under black gendarme
High point on SE Ridge.

Tried SE Ridge and reached saddle; put tent here and went down for rest. Most times up to saddle and on one day to 7300m to 7600m next day and again to BC (on 14th). Then came heavy snowfall. 22nd again to saddle but winds very strong and decided to abandon attempt. Everyday strong wind; they appeared not to be going to abate. Van Almen had stayed down.

ROUTE1: N Face (btw Japanese ramp and rock wall)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at north right bank of Jannu Glacier
C1 at 5600m top of first pillar under N face
C2 at cave (not on NZ route but near rock wall right of NZ route).

First tried new route to right of New Zealand route on North Face direct to top. On 6th Oct started summit push from BC and on 8th passed 2nd serac above cave and reached 6800m, then down because "that was enough" (one tired, one sick) risk of frostbite when tired. 

After that changed route to try New Zealand route and Beghin and Decamp upon 21st to C1, 22nd biv at 6300m above Wall of Shadows, 23rd 6800m in crevasse below big snow slopes leading to ridge, 24th to biv on ridge at 7300m and 25th summit at 12:00 noon. Few steps on ridge, not difficult but must be very careful. Back to same biv and 26th to C1. 24th had lot wind and was quite cold. Alpine-style ascent from C1 in final summit push on altered route.


Marsigny - 28 Oct 87

Attempt of central route N Face reached 6800m 11 Oct by Eric Decamp, Pierre Beghin, Marsigny.

Fixed rope to 6300m to C2 (1st ice cave)
Made 3 camps, 2 in ice cave
3 nights at C3 6600m
Very cold so down to C2
On 11th and to BC 12th
Pierre Beghin and Decamp want to try Dutch route (NZ route)
(left BC 18 Oct wth 2 Dutch) - stay KTM to 4 Nov.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m due to Farkas frostbite and lack of food supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal BC site (same as Belgians and Australians)
C1 at top of 3rd of 3 Steps
C2 1/3 way up 2nd Icefall
C3 at top of 2nd Icefall
C4 on shelf upper end of Great Shelf
High point on South Face.

Quite a bit of bad weather in early Sept. Alpine-style above C2 with cache at 7000m. Had intended to put 7200m but that would have been too far above C2. Started summit bid from BC 7 Oct and snow had eliminated C1. Oct 9 to C3, Oct 10th made C4. 11th Ongchu Sherpa, Farkas and Narayan Shrestha left for top while King stayed in camp since wind had taken way her down jacket. Stopped by bad snow conditions and crevasses before reached Austrian-German couloir and turned back at about 7900m and slept at C4. 12 Oct Farkas and Narayan again towards summit by new route directly up South Face (right of 1984 and Polish-Spanish climb) and got to 8100m. Farkas fell about 300m bouncing down South Face and climb finished. Fall did no damage but sometime during these attempts Farkas got frostbite in fingers and toes and possibly will lose tips of these. Took long time for him to get down and they stuck on mountain when began snowing on 15th and now food almost gone because 3 weeks supply stolen before reached BC. Stuck in Belgiums C1 tent 15th and arrived at BC 20th (had waited 2 days for snow to settle).

Smith brothers and Welch left 5 Oct out of boredom. Did go briefly to C1 but not climbers.

ROUTE1: SW Face (to right of main peak)
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8000m due to loss of all gear at C2 during bad snow storm
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 just below icefall - for acclimatization
C2 on Great Shelf
High point near top of Great Couloir.

Hubert attempted to solo South Summit on Oct 14. Forced to bivouac at 8000m by strong winds and heavy pack. On second summit bid Oct 22, Hubert went to C2 but could find no trace of camp. Huge snowstorm hit Oct 19-20 and either blew away or buried C2. All Hubert's down clothing and food for summit bid was lost, so climb finished. Hubert intended to descend from Great Shelf by paraglider, but too was lost at C2.

Hubert tried summit in one day from BC but lost his way in the night on South Face and biv about 7000m - 15 kg rucksack too heavy to go in one day. Was good weather: improved as they arrived at BC. Hubert left BC 2:00 am 14 Oct and biv 10:00 pm; had hoped reach top midday 15th and return to C2 in solo climb to top and next teammates at C1. Was to use parapente from C2, but too heavy rucksack and too windy so 15th all down (other 2 were already in C2 -a rrived there day before in support). Down to BC on 15th. On Great Shelf there was deep snow. Hubert again left BC 22nd after big storm without support of others. When arrived at C2 no camp could be found and all his very warm clothes food parapente and other essential gear: all under very deep snow or blown away by storm. So climb finished and left BC 23 Oct. C1 also disappeared (1 tent here, 2 at C2).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7500m due to cold, wind and loss of fixed ropes
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at site Pangpema - normal site
C1 at Kangchenjunga Glacier (temporary camp)
C2 at normal site above 1st icefall
C3 above 1st ice cliff (no debris of earlier camps seen)
C4 at North Ridge just before steep section with a snow rope ("bottom of the castle")
High point at North Ridge.

Fixed rope from C3 to North Ridge and down to BC for rest - 1-6 Oct. Trimble and Van Gelder up again on 7th to C2, 8th C3 and 9th to C4 on ridge having overcome all difficulties. 10th up ridge few hundred more meters when Trimble got altitude sickness and turned down for 5 days at BC before trying again beginning on 17th, but on 17th weather looked bad and was for 48 hours 18-19th. Up again on 21st and got to C2 at 8:00 pm, spent 3 hours digging out sleeping bags and took whole next day to dig out C2. 23rd up towards C3 in very deep snow and found avalanche had wiped all ropes on ice cliff and this last straw. Didn't have the equipment to fix new lines. Now 5 days of very high wind had come and not safe in cold and wind.

Did tests on viscosity of blood and changes that take place with altitude which shows blood definitely does thicken; tested drug that thins blood effectively.

Found G. O. Dyhrenfurth's ice axe and remains of his Sherpas who died in avalanche (pre-war clothing and small bones). 


Letter from Norman Dyhrenfurth - 25 Nov 1987

Chettan was crushed by a huge ice avalanche on May 8, 1930, and after more than an hour of artificial respiration he was buried near C2. My father's old ice-axe was indeed placed on his grave! Perhaps a recent avalanche brought his remains to the surface, and broke the ice axe as well. What a strong coincidence! I certainly look forward to receiving the two pieces. Knowing of no other climber climber killed at that place, it certainly must be Chettan.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8500m due to storms
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 to C2 is long hard, dangerous climb (from avalanches, so climbed at night). Bad weather intervened between C2 to C3's establishments. C3 to C4 intervals of bad weather and rope fixing; fixed total 5000 ft. 

1st summit bid 15th by Michael Graber and Mimi Stone from C4: reached 8500m and then driven back by winds. 

2nd bid left C3 on 17th Oct, got to C3 and there big storm came. 

3rd summit team of Schunk and Sherpa decided not to try at all; storm gave 7 ft of snow at C2 and tore out fixed lines, all tents in C1 and ABC buried in deep snow, so end of climb.

15 Americans total team.

BC   at normal site
Biv1 at normal C1 site
Biv2 at normal C2 site on 2nd plateau
C3   at normal C3 site
C4   at normal C4 site
C5   at left of normal C5 site (300m left).

Weather changed 1st of Feb with cloud and snowfall.

20th Jan started up from BC 3 members and made camp at C3 site, slept there on 22 Jan, on 23rd up 100m and then down to BC because Wanda not well and snow conditions bad (much fresh loose snow) and weather changing. Slept 23rd in BC. 2 members made C2 at 5600m on 23rd after 1 night biv at 4900m while made C1. 27th 3 members to C1 joining (Wanda and Michel). 28th 4 members to C2 while Michel descended. 29th same 4 people to C3, 30th traversed into couloir on very dangerous difficult hard ice with snow avalanche carrying stones and ice down couloirs and biv at 6500m near couloir; that night tent broken by falling stones and 31st to C4.

1st Feb 2 members not fully acclimatized and down to BC while and 2 members [Kukuczka and Hajzer] up to C5 in snowfall and 30-40m visibility up very hard ice like glass. 2 Feb tired so postponed ascent till 3 Feb. On 2 Feb 40cm snow fell; stayed on C2 (higher up wind blew it away). 3rd Feb after 5 hrs cooking started for top at 7:00 am. 3rd Feb half-meter fresh snow 2000m below summit but high up snow did not stay. In desent very big problem: on 3rd Feb reached C5 at 10:00 pm because extreme difficult to see way, couldn't find traverse for some time on 4th Feb, but did follow route eventually; slept in C3 on 4th and BC on 5th. 

2 members [Wanda and Wielicki] up from BC 6th Feb; to C4 on 8th Feb, but on 9th down again because of bad weather and Wanda not feeling strong. 10th Feb all in BC and climb finished.
ACCIDENTS: None but Palkiewicz had heart condition and stayed BC only 1 week as precaution

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5300m due to Brinkmann's poor health
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at foot of northeast side of Hiunchuli
ABC just below South Face of Annapurna I
High point at beginning of face.

With Brinkmann sick, Anker tried to see condition of climb and went alone to 5300m and then turned back because too heavy for him to carry alone. Anker had gotten to 6500m in acclimatization climb towards Fluted Peak but Brinkmann tried to go up on Annapurna I three times but never felt well. Had originally planned to be team of 4 but 1 had accident only 2 weeks before departure from Switzerland (other had accident 1 year before).


2 British back from Hiunchuli - 21 Dec 986

2 carried loads to ABC high on glacier and slept at least one night 26/7 Nov. Rene didn't acclimatize and snowfall on 1 Dec decided then to abandon attempt. Daniel went up and cleared gear and was in Dobang on 8th.

For South face attempt - were not sure which line to take.

Had originally been 4-man team but only 2 actually came and had no climbing Sherpa. Rene hadn't been to Nepal before and was "a bit overwhelmed by it all."
ACCIDENTS: Brinkmann ill for several days in acclimitization period of late Nov-early Dec (not altitude sickness)

SPONSOR: 1986-87 Korean Himalaya Winter Dhaulagiri I Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8025m due to frostbite and weather (especially high winds)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual site
C2 on NE Ridge
C3 on NE Ridge
High point at NE Ridge.

Route not via N Col because this way very difficult with many crevasses so climbed slghtly west of col. After C2 established, very strong wind and snow almost waist deep with tents broken and supplies lost. 2 weeks of bad weather - then good weather and 2 summit attacks on 24th and 25th Dec by Chung and Sirdar Ang Dorje. On 24th to 7800mm and on 25th to 8025m, but then very strong winds and very cold so turned back; somewhat frostbitten so their climb finished.

Chung and Ang Dorje frostbitten fingers and toes on 25th. Kim worse frostbitten toes 7 and 8 Dec and then to BC and Marpha for rest of expedition (took 3 days to Marpha because of deep snow). Then 1 coolie got frostbite. No illness or accidents although one snow avalanche almost covered 3 members.

Ang Phurba said he was sick and returned KTM early but really left for some other reason.
