ACCIDENTS: Ang Dorje frostbitten fingers & toes on Dec 25; Kim frostbitten toes Dec 7-8 (to BC and Marpha for rest of expedition); no illness and accidents although snow avalanche almost covered 3 members

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7000m due to illness and lack of food supplies
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at below normal site inside big ice cave with rock walls
Biv1 on North Face near NE Ridge
Biv2 on NE Ridge
High point on NE Ridge.

First went to N Col but many crevasses and so followed Korean direct route and to 6000m then down because heavy snow and slight wind. 9th Dec again to 6000m but 4 days wait because again snow and again to BC. 21 Dec up again but at 7000m Joan got a little altitude sickness so down to BC. Now had used most of food and fuel supplies but weather beautiful. No fixed ropes by this team had used Koreans ropes through badly broken crevassed area. Had only 500 kg loads on approach march.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m because no one left to climb
ROUTEMEMO:
BC   west of Himalchuli NW Summit near source of Myagdi khola
C1A on West Ridge
C1B at 4800m below big wall well protected
C2  on top of meeting of West and South Ridge to-from SW Ridge
High point at plateau.

Moved C1 to slightly lower site because of strong wind at first site; tried to move it on 18th Dec, but "broken" weather then and succeeded on 21st; 500m fixed rope from C1 to C2 because S side of the W Ridge was difficult. Had big Christmas at BC and then up again and made C2. On 29th put 150m fixed rope above C2 and reached 6200m on top of 1st serac barrier and slept in C2. 30th Dec planned to rest and make C3 on 31st but weather not good (wind and cold) on 30th and started down; past C1 when accident [fatal fall] occurred on W Ridge very sharp ridge but really easy terrain. Klincewicz and Panejko were only climbers feeling well and with him gone, no partner for Panejko to climb with since Barancewicz and Trzeciakowski not high climbers.
ACCIDENTS: Klincewicz fell 800-1000m from 4700m in easy terrain, lost his balance, fell into big couloir, many bones broken (carried down 500m and doctor met him there but died about 2 pm); no other problems

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8000m due to strong winds beginning and time running out
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  near Barun Pokhari (took son to BC)
ABC slightly north of glaciers' junction
C1  at beginning of steep section below Makalu La
C2  at Makalu La
C3  on NW Ridge on small col Messner's C3
High point at North Face.

Between making C2 and C3 was bad snowstorm and down to BC. Again in BC after C3 for resting and slow ascent by Cesa Bianchi and 1 Sherpa to C3. On 14th De Benedetti to C2 and next day down by ski from C2 to moraine on his first time in Himalaya. Cesa Bianchi turned down at 8000m after French expedition's Sherpas had taken his cooker for their own use at C3 on 13th and 14th, so too dangerous to go above 8000m without liquids and also had spent bad night of 13 and 14 Oct and furthermore Cesa Bianchi alone above 7800m for first time to be 8000m. Cesa Bianchi to BC on 16th and no further attempt possible. Problems of 13-14 Oct, strong winds beginning and time running out.


Vittorio Genna:

Stays now in KTM. Rescue helicopter flight to KTM because sickness.
Expedition returns 26 Oct; Genna goes home by 15 Oct.

BC at glaciers' meeting
C1 at 1955 French route
C2 at Col.

Had 2 C2s: 1st one above col in hope to go to top from it; pitched it 10th Sept but could make no summit bid because heavy snowfall and when returned it had been totally destroyed. At time of high climb, 2 [Messner and Kammerlander] reached 8000m on 21 Sept, but too slow and turned back at 8000m and down to BC, passing De Marchi and Ducroz below col and they reached 8400m on French route, not summit itself [on 23 Sept]. 

Messner, Kammerlander and Mutschlechner started up on 24th Sept from BC to C1; 25th to col's C3; 26th left C3 when sun reached col and followed direct route of Ruedi and Wielicki to top before noon in good condition.

Kammerlander skied from about 7500m down to end of glacier at about 5800m.


Ministry of Tourism via M Acharya - 27 Sep 86

Messner summits Makalu 11:30 am 26th
Started from C3 6:00 am and back by 1:30 pm
Kammerlander and Mutschlechner with him
3 in BC today 
Good health


Paoletti - 21 Sep 86

Messner and Kammerlander on at 8000m but turned back by deep snow and returning to BC (probably 22nd) and stay there 2-3 days and then try again. 
Yesterday C3 7800m.
All are well.
Too deep snow - too dangerous said Messner.
Leaves BC about 30 Sept - 1 Oct after summit.
Gabriel wants to go to Lhotse.
BC not radio - no new magazines from him.


De Marchi - 8 May 88 

De Marchi reached 8400m very near summit, then turned back because it was getting dark and difficult ridge above.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8000m due to winds and exhaustion of team
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at "Hillary BC"
C1 on moraine of Chago Glacier below Messner
C2 at end of moraine, below icefall of Chago Glacier
ABC/C3 at Chago Glacier
C4 on steep face to Makalu La
C5 at Makalu La
C6 on NW Ridge
High point on North Face.

After 13th Oct, strong, very cold wind and not possible to go higher. Renard waited in C5 till 17th Oct and then down when winds continued.

Pasang Norbu same frostbitten toes on 13 Oct but will heal; kitchen boy sick, went down to village and became unconscious but still alive; Wood cutter for kitchen (Kancha Gurung?) died below BC (became sick at BC); no other problems.

Collet used oxygen because of blood condition but not seriously ill - used as preventive measure.
ACCIDENTS: Pasang Norbu frostbitten toes on Oct 13 but will heal; kitchen boy sick, went down to village and became unconscious but still alive; woodcutter for kitchen died below BC; no other problems

ROUTEMEMO:
C2 at Makalu La (2 tents)
C3 at side of NW Ridge (left by summiters of 24 Sept).

Wielicki, Ruedi and Oelz intended to follow Kukuczka variant (a pillar) but difficult and dangerous with lot of snow and have to make big traverse to normal route so soon decided to go via normal route. Wielicki climbed with Oelz and Ruedi who joined Wielicki on 14 Sept at bottom of Pillar. 3 up Pillar to 6700m on 17 Sept, Oelz not feeling well and down. Ruedi and Wielicki to Makalu and down to BC (and after this expedition decided not to use Pillar). 21 Sept Wielicki led all the way through deep snow: left biv 3 at 7:15 am and was on top 3:45 pm had left Ruedi on last slope 50-60m below top and Ruedi could have been on top in 15-20 mins. Wielicki reached tent 7:00 pm but Ruedi never came. Messner saw traces of Ruedi on summit.

Ruedi died of altitude sickness - apparently spent night of 24th in snow cave at 8200m and next day probably fell. Messner arrived at his C3 that day, saw Ruedi and sent Sherpas to Ruedi and found him dead, sitting 30m below Wielicki tent on trail to Makalu La.

BC(10/09,5400m),MessnerC1(21/09,6600m),Biv2(22/09,7400m),Biv3(23/09,7850-7900m),
  Smt(24/09)


Pankiewicz group attempt:

Makalu had lot of snow (deep snow) which is not for everybody. Leader said would stop climb 20 Oct so to return KTM 27-8-9 Oct (leave Delhi 6 Nov). Probably Wanda will go to 7900m with 2-3 others and thence alone to summit. Wielicki left BC 1 Oct to go to Annapurna I with Kukuczka.

13th Oct Rutkiewicz and Pankiewicz started from Makalu La to reach C3 or with Cesa Bianchi to reach his deposit onto make new camp. At 7650m Pankiewicz turned back because of wind and had had pneumonia in Sept. Rutkiewicz, Cesa Bianchi and French expedition's 2 Sherpas together reached 7950m [8000m] where Sherpas pitched French C6. Cesa Bianchi did not find his cache so all slept in French tent (C3 apparently destroyed). 14th Oct fierce, very cold wind: all 4 down to Makalu La (Wanda wanted to move Ruedi's body but Sherpas refused and 4 needed for trek, so body still sitting 50m below Pole's C3). Climbing finished: wind terrifying on 14th.

BC(10/09,5400m),C1(20/09,6400m),C2(23/09,7950m),C3(04/10,7400m),
  Biv(13/10,8000m),xxx   

Jakubowski had stomach trouble and left BC 10 Oct. Pankiewicz had pneumonia in early-mid Sept. No other problems in Oct.

Except Jakubowski and Serafin, all Polish members reached Makalu La and spent at least one night there.


Marcel Ruedi & Oswald Oelz to Ross Munro, Time-life - 29 Sept 1986

That is what happened to Marcel Ruedi in March he was in third place in the world cup of 8000m peaks. He ws normal butcher, he led a regular life, trained, but had a normal family, everything, and just in his free time went to the 8000m peaks and that put him under pressure. Although he acclimatized very rapidly to altitude, this time it was too short. I mean, we left Zurich on the seventh of Sept on the 18th we were already at 7000m, and Marcel went to 7500m and that is just not enough time even for the best to acclimatize, We both felt sick and so we both went down to base camp. I still didn't feel good and I told Marcel, its too early for me. Marcel felt good after a short time and went with Wielicki (starting at 7700m) and they climbed to the summit (arriving there 4 pm, Sept 24). He was extremely strong and very very highly motivated. But I am sure that in the last stages of the ascent he developed severe, acute mountain sickness, particularly cerebral edema, which leads to bad judgement and things like that and that is why he bivouacked on the way down, at 8200m. (Wielicki descended to 7900m).

He survived the night... (on the morning of the 25th, Messner was at 7400m and saw Reudi moving slowly downwards, but later in day Messner saw no movement) but after that he had used up all his reserves and when (on Sept 25) Reinhold found him dead, he was at 7800m, (on a gently sloping plateau) and had some foamy blood coming out of his mouth, what is for me a sign of high altitude pulmonary edema.

Stone dead, he had bloody foam coming out of his mouth, which means for me that in the final stages he died of pulmonary edema. The problem on Makalu is that it's a long, long way back. Here was a guy who was so strong that you thought he could never be stopped. It was bad judgement, a bad idea.

(apparently the body was simply left where it lay)

He made sausages. He was an enthusiastic butcher, or charcutier. Ruedi was much stronger than me, he was an extremely strong man, but he did two and a half weeks after leaving Zurich, having climbed one of the highest peaks in the world this is by all means unreasonably, that is asking for trouble. He wanted to go to Makalu as quickly as possible so he could go to Everest and Lhotse. and then there would have been only two left.


Oelz - 30 Sept 86

Messner to Oelz by BC radio 29 Sept:

24th Ruedi and Wielicki: reached summit at 4:00 pm; had climbed from 7700m. Wielicki back to 7900m and Ruedi to 8200m that evening (tent at 7900m).

25th: Messner reached Mak La at 9:00 am and saw Ruedi (descending). Later that day saw no movement and saw Ruedi dead on 26th between 7750m and 7800m. Ruedi apparently took foam from mouth which tells Oelz pulmonary edema. Body left where it was.


Min of Tourism via Acharya - 27 Sept 86

Ruedi and Krzystopf Wielicki reached summit via NW side 24 Sept. Wielicki returned to C3 (7900m) but Ruedi bivouacked at 8200m that night - which descending from biv next am, Ruedi died near C3. No further details. Wielicki good health.


Oelz - 29 Sept 86

Ruedi and Wielicki left BC at 5400m for summit bid on 21 Sept, 2 weeks after Ruedi left Zurich. Ruedi had gone 7400m with Wielicki 17 Sept and to BC same day. Started up again on 21st from BC.

Oelz left BC 22 Sept; had fever and had not acclimatized well from 7000m with Ruedi and Wielicki on 17th.

Oelz leaves Nepal tomorrow.
ACCIDENTS: Ruedi died on descent from summit. Jakubowski stomach trouble and left BC Oct 10; Pankiewicz pneumonia in early-mid Sep; no other problems in Oct

SPONSOR: Australian Army Alpine Expedition to Khumbakarna (Jannu)
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6950m due to 1 member's death
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 4500m at Yamatari Glacier
Biv on 28 Oct at 6100m at lower plateau
Biv on 29 Oct at 6400m at South Ridge
Biv at 6600m at South Ridge
Biv at 6900-7000m at upper plateau (French C5)
High point at 6950m at French C5.

Put up tent at 6100m for cache of food and gear, slept there two nights between 10 and 15th Oct. Before this it snowed and rained all the time: did some acclimatization trips in region and went up the route a bit. This tent destroyed in snowstorm 17th or 18th Oct. Recovered only few items there so descended, got more gear and made another dump at about same altitude in snow cave 20th Oct and descended immediately for rest before summit push. 23 Oct reached this place and found everything taken away by avalanche. Down again and to Ghunsa where met French Nepal Peak expedition who gave food and back up on 28th Oct.

About 31 Oct all 3 members reached 6900-7000m and during that night, when planned to go for summit, Eggerton's health deteriorated: was very tired, vomiting, crying out for oxygen and water, so had to take him down. Got to 6400m where Eggerton collapsed and died. "We couldn't get him down fast enough" - died on the ropes. Body impossible to carry down so swung it over steep crevassed area and sent it down into crevasses.


NZAC Bulletin (Don French) - March 1985

The expedition was called "the Australian Army Jannu Expedition." Terry Tremble, of Melbourne, was the leader with Keith Egerton, also of Melbourne, and myself as the team members. Jannu, also know as Kumbukarna, is a 7710m peak in eastern Nepal near Kangchenjunga. We each contributed approximately NZ$5000 (including flights) with the NZAC also contributing $300 to expenses. Fairydown (Australia) assisted Terry with clothing and a sleeping bag which he found excellent.

The approach consisted of eleven days walking of which only two could be considered to be "leach days." We used 22 porters all being paid Rs 34 per day (one trekking party was paying Rs 100 per day). Our base camp was established in the Yamatri valley on Sept 4 1986.

A total of three attempts were made on the mountain's southwest ridge (the original French route). The first was abandoned due to deteriorating weather. The second, with its superior weather, unfortunately ended when our dump, from the previous attempt, was found to be buried by an avalanche. The dump had contained our full supply of mountain food plus a few items clothing, ice hammers, stove and fuel and seventeen "Mars Bars." Fortunately we were able to intercept a passing French expedition in Ghunsa (a important village one days walk from base camp) who gave us enough mountain food for another attempt.

This attempt commenced on October 26th when we climbed to the C2 site. The following day we climbed through to our neve camp at 6000m. Col des Juenes was gained then continued up to Tete du Butoir, 6450m for our third night. We experienced a lot of cornicing on this day. The fourth day saw us climb over Tete de la Dentelle and onto the edge of a plateau known as the Throne. We were confined to camp for two days here due to high winds. During a lull I was able to climb to 7000m on the summit block to establish our high point. Unfortunately Keith became ill, so on November 1st we descended. Keith died from pulmonary edema after just a few hours of descent.

Keith's death was the thirteenth this autumn in the Nepal Himal. He was very well known in Australian climbing circles and by many New Zealanders who have visited the Arapiles. Keith was a member of the NZAC.

With alpine/lightweight style ascents in the Himalaya you might be able to get more trips to the dollar, but this is at the sacrifice of safety and success. One has to balance these sacrifices against cost and ethics. I doubt if our expedition would have had success if other techniques were employed. Unfortunately our earlier ventures onto the mountain were hampered by poor weather, so considerable time had to be spent at base camp waiting for the monsoon to pass.
ACCIDENTS: Oct 31 all 3 members reached 6900-7000m & during that night, when planned to go for summit, Eggerton's health deteriorated (was very tired, vomiting, crying out for oxygen, water)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to Lopez's fall (team were old friends)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5250m right side of Lhotse Shar Glacier near East Face of Island Peak
C1 at 5200m at 200m above col 5700m north of Island Peak
C2 at 6250m on ridge south of SE Face (same ridge as C2)=ridge on S Face
C3 at 6800m on S Face (middle of S Face in ice on same ridge)
C4 at 7400m on SE Face (never occupied)
High point at 7400m on SE Face.

SE Face very easy: no problem climbing it (which reached at 7300m from S Face, which is very hard). S Face difficulty very step ice halfway up and above that rock - very steep 3000m. Fixed rope from below C1 to 7300m on entire SE Face; total 2800m fixed rope because very steep but snow stuck total. C4 site reached by several parties making route and placing loads 28th and on 30th Oct. Lopez and Sanchez went to C4 to sleep there and go for summit. Lopez only 10m below C4 when he fell. Planned to make biv or C5 at 8000m and summit 1st or 2nd Nov.

Lopez and Dr were at 7400m when Lopez fell entire face (2400m) on 30 Oct 5:00 pm. Doctor went to search and then had to biv in dark and cold, returned to BC next day with badly frostbitten 9 fingers. Lopez body not found by all searchers. Sanchez to KTM by helicopter; if no infection may not lose parts of fingers. No other problems.
ACCIDENTS: Lopez fell entire face (2400m), Sanchez went to search and bivouaced in dark & cold, returned to BC with badly frostbitten 9 fingers (if no infection may not lose parts of fingers), Lopez body not found; no other problems

SPONSOR: Japan College of Dairying Chamlang Climbing Expedition 1986
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Hunku Khola
C1 on moraine
C2 on West Ridge
C3 on West Ridge.

All knife ridge from C1 to C3. Last part summit very dangerous W Face because very steep. Climbed couloir on face (were on couloir on W Face from C3 to summit). 4000m fixed rope from 5450m to C3 because beginners in Himalaya.

28-9 Sept much snowfell so all waited in BC for 2 days.

Shinya sure his expedition and Koreans reached highest summit.
ACCIDENTS: Ongel and Dawa Sherpa slight frostbite; nothing else

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Hongu Khola 
C1  at top of icefall
C2  below South Ridge
C3  slightly below South Ridge
C4  on South Ridge
Biv on South Ridge.

29th Sept all members in BC because heavy snow avalanching. Difficult parts C2 to C3 ice and snow steep section needing 900m fixed rope rock 50m very steep (rock and snow mixed) and very difficult (found 10m of rope from 1962 Japanese expedition) section between C4 and biv where 6000m roped total between C4 and biv. All of mountain needed 2700m fixed rope. Korean's route joined Japanese 1962 route at Korean's C3: Japanese C3 was further down S Ridge.

Have no doubt Japanese in 1962 reached same main summit as did this expedition.
ACCIDENTS: None; avalanching broke tents but injuries

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to wind and fatigue
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5300m at glacier's junction near Messner's BC 
C1 at 6000m at Chago Glacier's side
C2 at 6650m at beginning of steep face leading to Col (Messner's C1)
C3 at 7400m at Makalu La.

Late Sept-early Oct tried to pitch C3 at 7000m but bad weather prevented this and finally put it at La. Waited too long to make C3 and therefore were unsuccessful. After 13th Oct too windy to go higher and by now 3 had slight frostbite. 26th Sept Erel tried to reach pass with Wanda Rutkiewicz but turned back at 7000m when snowstorm began. Lack of experience in Himalaya made slow progress in early days, then wind and being "pretty tired" finished effort.

2 members left early because they decided they they had had enough.

BC at 5100m at start of Chago Glacier 
C1 east of point 6170m on snow plateau
C2 at 6200m just below NW Ridge southeast of col 6550m
C3 at 7060m on NE Ridge (S of "H" on Schneider map).

1st summit bid by 2 members on 6th Oct, but strong wind and snowfall turned them back at 7200m. 9th Oct 2nd party successful. 

Route was same as Japanese 1976 (making C3 found 1 and half down in snow Japanese rope). Difficult knife ridge mixed rock and ice/snow below C3. From C3 to top mixed rock and used many rock pitons; ice pitons also; total 1800m fixed rope mostly C2 and above (200m C1 to C2) because they chose steep route.

Bad weather delayed expedition in reaching BC. C1-C3 established by 27 Sep; C4 established on 16 Oct after delayed by heavy snowfall. 

1st summit did defeated at 8000m on 17th Oct by wind, big snowstorm and incipient frostbite to Estiu, who was with Permanye and Ang Rita. Had pitched C4, after heavy snowfall in late Sept. First two had gotten no higher than C3. 

After further delays due to snowfall and high winds, 2nd summit bid made on 24 Oct. Final summit push found C2 and C3 destroyed by snowfall at C2 and avalanche from Yalung Kang. 3 men to C4 23rd Oct: Hugas, Permanye and Ang Rita. On 24th Hugas turned back at 8400m because very cold [while other two to the top at 1 pm].

Total 1200m fixed rope. Most difficult section below C1, where fixed rope 400-500m.
ACCIDENTS: Sherpa Lhakpa Nuru disappeared on approach march below BC (don't know where he went and whether he is alive)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6650m due to snow, wind and Hembise's frostbite
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at base of Cock's Comb, west of Nepal Camp
C1 in cwm half way between Cross Peak & Nepal Peak
C2 on South Ridge of Nepal Peak (a little on Sikkimese side)
High point at South Ridge of Nepal Peak.

C1 in Cwm which was dangerously threatened by snow avalanches: small avalanches came near C1 in center of Cwm. On 16th Oct turned down because rotten snow on ridge but did not have enough fixed rope at the time. 

Now Dominique Hembise had frostbitten fingers and toes and stopped climbing. Others could not carry on because frequent new snowfall and strong wind on ridge: great turbulance of wind from Nepal and Sikkim. Gave up climb because members discouraged by bad weather conditions. All left mountain 19-25 Oct.

Lazizi used oxygen at BC in beginning when he did not acclimatize well.
ACCIDENTS: Hembise frostbitten fingers and toes but they will heal; no other problems (except mild altitude sickness in start of expedition)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC   at 5300m at site of Swiss BC this season
Biv1 at Nangpa La.

Attempted E Ridge from Ngojumba Kang in September. Transferred to NW Ridge (normal route) in October.

After it became clear team could not succeed via E Ridge, liaison officer left BC 2 Oct to request permit for NW side (went to Namche to send radio request). No permit granted but Shiraishi and Hino left BC 5th Oct to make 2-man alpine-style climb from west. Moved up to 7200m in 4 days then stopped by bad weather for 2 days before going to summit. Found climb for most of route not technically difficult but were hampered by snow above ankles. Shiraishi gave up the attempt, but Hino reached top at 14:20 hrs, returned to 7200m at 17:55 hrs. 17th Oct bivouacked at 6750m, 18th at 5800m near Nangpa La, 19th at 5600m and 20th arrived at BC.

Expedition ask that ascent not be revealed in KTM, but are happy to have it reported in Iwa-to-Yuki.

Much heavy snowfall and distances between camps very long, so climbers tired. Put in total 1200m fixed rope from 5500m to about 6000m, 6100m to 6500m and 7200m to 7500m [on E Ridge route]. Asked for permit to change route to northwest side but not granted. 2 Oct liaison officer went to Namche Bazar to request change of route. Shiraishi and Hino went to northwest side, met Swiss at BC and made alpine-style ascent (no fixed camps). Left BC 5 Oct, arriveed Swiss BC 9 Oct, started ascent 10th Oct.

Shiraishi frostbitten fingers from climb via southwest, but will not lose any tips; no other problems.
ACCIDENTS: Shiraishi frostbitten fingers but will not lose tips; no other problems

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to fatal accident of Steiner
ROUTEMEMO:
BC   between Dzsampa and Karyolung
Biv1 1 hour before Polish 1986 spring ABC
Biv2 at NW Ridge
High point at NW Ridge.

Before 19th Oct did acclimatization climb of point 6296m. Started up from BC at midnight 19/18 Oct and arrived at biv site of 6000m at 8:00 am (as on Everest Aug 1986, rested in day time when warmer and climbed during cold). At 4:00 pm 19th started up again and made new route on face WNW of summit. Not difficult snow face (last part a little rock). Climbed till 1:00 am on 20th Oct to 7200m. Very strong wind and had to stop. 7:00 am 20th also very strong wind so decided to descend to 1st biv site. 9:00 am Steiner fell to his death.

Steiner fell (was behind Loretan). Probably strong wind pushed him off. Was at 6900m and fell to 6300m but still alive. Loretan put him in sleeping bag, went to Dupre who went up with warm clothes, food, cooker, while Loretan to BC and sent sirdar to Namche for helicopter. No helicopter in 2 days so Loretan up with more food and few hours after arrival Steiner died 23 Oct evening many serious injuries.

BC just east of south end of ridge running south from point 14,180 ft
C1 below West Ridge
C2 on West Ridge.

1st summit bid on 6th Nov from C2 failed because started late (at 8:00 am) and turned back at 6660m to C2. Next day Mayer started up at 6:30 am and Mueller at 7:00 am (Mueller tried from 6th Nov attempt and not sure whether he would go up again). Mayer on top at 2:30 pm and returned to C2 at 8:00 pm while Mueller moving very slowly got to top in 12 hrs (on top at 7:00 pm) and biv at 6660m with biv gear 8:30 pm. 8th Nov to C2 at 10:00 am and slept there while Mayer to BC same day. 

Ridge safe and easy ice climbing in good ice conditions. Used no fixed rope (found many fixed ropes from Japanese) except on one steep section below C2 at Sherpas request.

Actual approach via Chautara, Tempathang and Balephi Khola to Panch Pokhari. South Ridge and South Face are possible route, but face had many icefalls and dangerous seracs.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5700m due to snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  same as Korean winter 1985 (west of South Ridge btw A & L of Rolwaling on map)
C2  on SW Face
Biv on SW Face
High point on SW Face.

Wanted alpine-style above C2 and made one biv. Then had bad night from snowfall so 24th back to C1. More bad weather. Went up again only to retrive C2 equipment. Snow up to waist height. Must return to jobs at home on 13th Oct.

Wanted to finish climb of autumn 1981 Spanish team via same route.

Had many problems with police in restricted area; Gaurishankar really closed to foreigners.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  on west side of Lungsampa on Ngojumba Glaciers junction southeast of Dyazumpa
Biv on South Face
Biv on South Face
High point at 2nd bivouac.

Really 3 people climbing from beginning through out climb with some arriving at BC two weeks later than others. Problem of climb was the glacier and finding route across it through lot of snow and above it which of 2 icefalls could be surmounted (tried first western icefall, then climbed eastern one). Hence 18 days to make C2 after C1. From C2 26th Oct 5 members started up in alpine-style, but same day 2 members [Zabelata and Matous] retreated [from 6700m] while other three bivouacked at 6800m. Next day to 7100m and that night very strong winds (were hanging from ropes) so down. 27th 3 members to 6800m and 28th down. All in BC 29th and left BC 1st Nov. On face snow was in very good condition.

Planned to make a third bivouac at about 7300m atop difficult chimney on SW Pillar and go to summit from there.

BC  southwest of Langtang, west of point 17,456
ABC below of ridge on SW Ridge
C1  on SW Ridge
C2  on SW Ridge
C3  on SW Ridge
Biv on SW Ridge
C4  on SW Ridge.

Ridge very steep rock much snow some ice, very long; 50 rock pitons used; 3 km rope fixed and that not enough; fixed rope from C1 upwards. Easy from C4 to top but very steep above C3 and biv needed ("bivouac site eagle's house").

Sherpa fell, not hurt but left expedition; sirdar also had fall; during descent from summit Shin, Song and Yoon fell 100m, but not injured.

Found Canada fixed rope at 5500m.
ACCIDENTS: Sherpa fell, not hurt but left expedition; sirdar also had fall; during descent from summit, 3 members fell 100m but not injured

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to continuous strong winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at bottom of SE Ridge
C1 at bottom of couloir 
C2 at beginning of very sharp ridge
C3 at beginning of steep wall.

Route was as same as Japanese 1986 Spring on knife ridge. Had 2 C3s: 6000m on 12 Oct but moved it up to beginning of difficult ice wall. Planned alpine-style ascent from C3. Climbed the wall on 13th, then moved C3 up 100m. Then bad weather with much soft new snow followed on 17th by strong wind which lifted tent at C3; had to descend to BC. From 6400m ridge would have been easy, but wind did not drop. Left BC 19 Oct.

ROUTE1: W Face up; SW Ridge-S Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 4600m normal South Ridge BC site at Mingbo
Biv 1 at 5250m 
Biv 2 at 6450m
Biv 3 at 6812m at summit
Biv 4 at 6150m on South Face.

No fixed camps above BC: alpine-style climb. After 22nd went to see best line on face and how to approach face; found Peter Hillary had best way and from his ABC [used] a little of his fixed rope. 2:00 am 10th Oct Smid started climb alone at 5250m and biv at 6450m at 4:00 pm. 11th in 3 hrs climb reached top 11:30 am in snowstorm (could see nothing) and spent night there for photos early next morning. 12th descended to S Ridge with only short rope and 2 pitons and no one else on ridge in "terrible" descent and biv at 6150m on S Face (70m below ridge on face). 13th snow and rock face to snow slopes of face to bottom of face where at 10:00 am reached Yugoslavian BC and to own BC same day.

Only Koch twisted ankle bouldering at BC and went home. 

2 Swiss summiters together did slightly different climb: broken red line up and down to join Yugoslav S Face route (down Yugoslav fixed rope). Bivouacked at Smid's 1st Biv and then had their own 2nd biv at 6300m.
ACCIDENTS: Koch twisted ankle bouldering at BC (returned home)

ROUTE1: NE Buttress up; SE Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 5000m at base of SE glacier 
ABC at 5730m
Biv at 5900m below 1st rock band
Biv at 6100m top 2nd band
Biv at 6300m base 4th band
Biv at 6500m at top of snow mushrooms
Biv at 6600m half way up long gully to summit plateau
Biv at 6700m at on plateau to south of summit.

Just above Hinku Nuptse Glacier was 100m wall where fixed one rope for descent. Total 4 rock bands of 2 pitches each most difficult section was final snow mushrooms. 4 men started up on 22 Oct from ABC and reached summit in 7-1/2 days. One got tired and didn't get all the way to top. Waited while other three did and then all 4 descended to BC same day. On top at 11:30 am and back in BC 6:00 pm having skirted icefall at eastern end of Kangtaiga Glacier.

Had permit for Kusum Kangru but E Face not attractive and were tired after Kangtega so made no attempt to climb it.

ROUTE1: S Face up; SW Ridge-S Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC   at 5100m on east side of Kalapattar
Biv5 at 7000m right below summit on cornice.

1st to 3rd biv sites Scottish grade 5 steep ice. Spindrift avalanches all the time in this section funnelled down couloir and were very dangerous. Did climb true alpine-style except for 100m of 8m rope. Started off with bivy tent but it fell off after 1st biv so used snow caves or just platforms. Very pleased with climbing this difficult route both up and down and think it must be new ascent and descent routes (confusion about who has been exactly where on past expeditions).

Allan and Allen left BC 22 Oct. Other 2 members to make their own bid but not likely to repeat same route [retreated from 6000m due to high winds].
ACCIDENTS: None at all up to Oct 22; none later
ACHIEVMENT: Probably new routes up and down

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to lack of fuel stove and need to return to Spain
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4300m at west side of mountain near yak house 1 hour below
Deposit at 5200m at bottom of West Face
Biv 1 at 5700m on West Face (middle of face)
Biv 2 at 5950m on West Face (middle of face)
Biv 3 at 6300m on West Face at bottom of couloir.

11 days stayed in BC because bad weather. Went up to make deposit: started up 18th Oct and in 4 days made +4 carries to deposit while sleeping each night in BC. 24th Oct summit push began by all 4 members and 3 slept at deposit while leader returned to BC with altitude sickness. 25th 3 started for summit and reached 5700m and next day up again. 28th gas finished, impossible to melt snow and cook food (had been drinking only one litre/day) so despite all difficult climbing finished and only easy couloir to scale to summit, turned down because too dangerous to climb without liquids. Also were tired.

From 5700m were 500m very steep ice above 1st biv. Entire face is steep: could only sit in bivouac because no space to lie down although above biv 3 appeared less steep. Descended same route in 25 hours continous descent to BC.
ACCIDENTS: 3 members frostbite and leader's altitude sickness

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Mingbo
C1 at very bottom of ridge
C2 on first shoulder of South Ridge.

Made no C3 because too heavy to carry up tent, etc. and better to go very light and faster; before summit push spent few days at BC resting and eating. 21 Oct from BC to C2 directly (was 3 summiters of 22 Oct). 22 Oct at 1:00 am began climb to summit in early of full moonlight so as to return to C2 before dark; were on top at 9:00 am in good weather although very cold and windy and back in C2 at 4:00 pm; technically very difficult with much snow on mountain like sugar (not powder) and very steep rock steps. Were in BC 23rd night and Dutrievoz left BC 24 Oct to Lukla.
ACCIDENTS: No problems as of Oct 24, when Dutrievoz left BC; no problems later

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6550m due to exhaustion
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5300m on west side of SW ridge
   (west of point 5545 on east side of Changri Shar Glacier)
C1 at 5950m at snow shelf
C2 at 6250m on top of snow shelf
High point at 6550m at SW Ridge.

Route went under glacier shelf on west side of SW Ridge to a west spur of SW Ridge. After established BC "crowded around acclimatizing." After made C1, ferried loads to stock it and put fixed line to snow rib at 20,000 ft. 15th-16th route made across SW Ridge. Next week put in more fixed line above C2 and spent next 9 days fixing rope on difficult rock and ice. By then too exhausted to continue on up to upper snow fields above snow ramp. Should have changed style of climb to fast alpine-style ascent instead of fixing rope up. 3000 feet total - had done all difficult rock climbing.

Brailsford never reached BC because of severe high alitude sickness. MacDonald got absessed tooth and was out of action for 2 weeks (had tooth pulled at Pheriche).


Swenson - 4 Nov 

Roberts "flipped out" on the climb. Hadn't realized how big the Himalaya are: froze on them and had to be helped down the ropes on 26 and 27 Oct. This used up other members remaining strength.
ACCIDENTS: Brailsford never reached BC because of severe high altitude sickness; MacDonald absessed tooth and was out of action for 2 weeks

SPONSOR: Ryoho Climbing Club Himalayan Exped to E Ridge-Pumori 1986
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to Mitsuhata's accident
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5250m above Gorakshep, where planned to put it
C1 at 5700m at bottom of East Ridge
High point on East Ridge.
 
C1 to C2 broken snow, and same rock. Fixed 50 pitches rope from C1 towards C2, which planned to put at 6200m, but avalanche hit Mitsuhata at 2:00 pm on 6th Oct and climb over. He had been searching for site for C2. Other members went up again later but only to bring down gear and would leave BC 11 or 12 Oct. Mitsuhata left 10 Oct by helicopter.

Mitsuhata broke left leg when snow avalanche hit him 6 Oct and he fell 40m (a full pitch) till stopped by rope and other member helped him to BC, which he reached 7 Oct. Also had trouble breathing and used oxygen during descent to C1.
ACCIDENTS: Mitsuhata broke left leg when snow avalanche hit him Oct 6 (he fell 40m until stopped by rope, also had trouble breathing and used oxygen during descent to C1)

ROUTEMEMO:
1st BC at 4600m at bottom of West Face (usual site)
2nd BC at 5250m near lake at bottom of South Face (between the 2 South Ridges)
C1 at 6100m at snowhole 150m below shoulder of eastern South Ridge between seracs.

Each summiter climbed alone from shoulder snowhole since route on S Face fixed all the way to this shoulder with 860m rope. Face mostly snow and ice but rock also. Steepest was 65 degrees, average 55 degrees - UIAA 4+ to 5-. Difficulty on only 20m of rock, estimate of rock 3-4 UIAA. 250m total rock climbing on face, 250m ice climbing in upper part (into serac). Route on face led up a small ridge on left side of face (left of Jeff Lowe's route). Technically not so difficult and really didn't need fixed ropes, but Kovic and Benkovic felt.

Butkovic got pneumonia; Bago got frostbite and also bad digestive illness. Butkovic left BC 16 Oct with Berljaks. Berkovic left BC 19th. Other 4 left 20 Oct.


Berkovic - 24 Oct 86

1st BC at same site as Czechs for West Face (4400-4500m on South Face), so made a 2nd BC near lake just under South Face at about 5200m on 10 or 11 Oct.

Next day Bago and he fixed 450-500m rope; Alikalfic and Puzak fized 400m more to slope from ridge.

15 Oct midnight Puzak, Bago and Butkovic and he started from BC and 5 am Puzak, Bago and Butkovic went back down, but he kept on up with tent food stove 2 gas. He went up to end of fixed ropes, took last one because 80m steep section above, using rucksack as belay; did this twice; placed tent under seracs at ice hole 100m below shoulder at about 6100-6200m.

15th Alikalfic brought more rope to him and descended Berkovic he put in more fixed rope.

16th he started up 6:45 am and route now normal route to top. Arrived at top without any fixed rope at 11:30 am and returned to BC (2-1/2 hours from top to tent), arrived tent 3:00 pm. Left tent to moraine 1 hour only, down fixed ropes and arrive BC 6:30 pm 16th.

Leader and wife stayed at lower (1st) BC.
ACCIDENTS: Butkovic got pneumonia; Bago got frostbite & bad digestive illness; Butkovic left BC Oct 16 with Berljaks; Berkovic left BC Oct 19; other 4 left Oct 20

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to disappearance of 3 members
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Mani Pokhari
ABC at moraine near small lake
C1  on SW Ridge
C2  above ice barrier
High point at C2?

15th Oct 3 started up after period of bad weather (daily snowfall) to C2 which they planned to put at 6500m (Reiter in C1 could not see them). 15th evening very stormy and snow falling and on 17th Reiter down to ABC and BC. 24th Oct Reiter and Dorje to C1 and on 25th down with 2 tents. Vertical ice barriers above C1 fixed with rope.

Eisendle was supposed to trek to BC only.
ACCIDENTS: Probably fatal avalanche (fate of missing men and even how high they actually climbed are unknown since they had no walkie talkie); Reiter ill and therefore did not go up on 15th

ROUTE1: NE Face-E Ridge up; NE Face down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at bottom of NE Face, north of East Ridge
C1 at east end of East Ridge from north side
C2 on East Ridge
C3 on East Ridge
Biv very near old C3.

After BC established, every day rain so waited till 19th Sept for better weather. 20th Sept bived at 6400m and 21st made camp there but 22 Sept down for food. Then snowfall. Again up 27th but 28th down because snowing again. 2 times more tried this route (2nd and 7th Oct) but heavy snowfall and many avalanches. 20th Oct 3 climbers up same route with heavy deep snow but good weather, reached C2 21st. Oct 22nd to 7000m and deposit supplies, then down in cold winds. 23rd waited in C2 and a member cold to BC. 24th 2 members up to C3. 25th up very difficult rock (100m up only and back to C3). 26th little more up and 29th up in summit bid by 2 members but reached 7600m when turned back in wind and snow. Ascent too slow so dowm to C2 on 29th to traverse to normal route like Austrians. 30th on NE Face 7300m not possible to pitch tent so stayed night without tent and 31st to BC via ridge clearing all camps as they went. 

5th Nov final summit bid 3 members [Kukuczka, Hajzer and Carsolio] from BC and biv 5500m. 6th Nov 40m very hard climb on ice. 9th Nov arrived plateau with wind cloud at 8000m. 10th Nov very cold and Carlo's fingers and toes very cold, stays at biv while 2 members went quickly to top and returned by normal route to BC where arrived 12 Nov.

Many avalanches, but no one hurt by them. Climbers started avalanches from C3 to 7600m very difficult and from 7600m 100m very difficult place rock with sugar snow.
ACCIDENTS: Carlos bad frostbite in toes and fingers; will lose parts of fingers; Warecki got pneumonia and was evacuated from BC on 18 Sept

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Dodi Khola southwest of mountain.

More bad weather after 13th Oct. All route difficult: fixed 7000m total rope - mostly rock and snow. 1st summit attack on 26th Oct and Furno and Nima made route to top starting from C5 at 4:00 am while 2nd group left C5 6:00 am (2 started ahead of other 2 because too cold for 2nd pair to wait while first pair put in route up difficult rock face). Second pair even so went up more slowly because very tired. 1st pair returned to C4 at 3:30 pm while Imoto at 9:50 pm to C5. 25th Oct 6 members slept in C5 (Okada at BC) but on 26th only 3 were well enough to go up while other 3 descended to C3.
ACCIDENTS: Nakamura fell from about 7500m while descending from summit (fell about 2000m), body not found (many crevasses); no other problems

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7250m due to wind, cold and fear of serious frostbite
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual site above Samagaon
C2 above Naike Col and above big icefall
C3 on NE Face
C4 on NE Face
High point at C4.

C1 lost in bad snowfall which collapsed tent, so made new one at 5400m after many day's snow. Fixed rope in icefall. Lost C4 in slab avalanche which destroyed tent and gave slight frostbite. No real technical problems and put only 400m fixed rope (but that all rope they brought).
ACCIDENTS: Arbelaez fell in crevasse but rescued unharmed; 2 members slight frostbite; Sherpa cook got sick (ulcers?) and left expedition

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to strong winds, heavy clouds and fog
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4250m at Pungyen Glacier's moraine, southeast of mountain
ABC/C1 at 4900m at upper part of Pungyen Glacier at bottom of SE Face
C2 at 5700m on SE Face
C3 at 6550m on SE Face
C4 at 7200m above Col between Peak 29 and Manaslu
High point at 7400m SE Face.

Avalanches falling stones early proved new route planned too dangerous and went to Polish route. 25th Sept reached 6100m and 6200m daily and then very bad weather with 50cm to 1m snow late Sept and early mid-Oct frequently. 4th and 7th Oct reached same altitudes and C2 twice completely destroyed (no one hurt because C2 unoccupied). 8th Oct reached C3 site. Reached col between Peak 29 and Manaslu on 25th Oct after waiting for heavy snowfall 12-16 Oct to stop. Started up again 18th Oct in fine weather; biv at col 25th Oct and 27th Oct reached C4 site, waited 5 days here but winds so strong could reach only 200m more; down to C3 for rest up to col only on 1 Nov. 

Most difficult part was below col and above C3. Had fixed rope from 6200m to col entire section plus more in places below 6200m (how many meters total don't know because avalanches destroyed ropes; used up all 5000m of rope, perhaps total 2500m of route were fixed).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6500m due to death of a member
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at moraine at start of Madi Khola
C2 on Southwest Ridge
High point at site for C3.

Just above C1 was difficult rock. Small wall and seracs between C2 and C3 also presented some difficulties. Above C2 mostly ice except snow on less steep section. By fixing one or two ropes just above C3 site would have surmounted climbing problems.

Had 7 days rain on route to BC and during approach 1 Sherpa injured leg.

Were attempting new route, not same as 1977 Italian expedition. C3 would have been last camp.

Caslini hit by falling serac which caused him to fall 350m; was crossing couloir to descend to BC for rest. 2 others were climbing up at same time on same wall but were to right of where serac fell. Found body on 27th and buried it in glacier. No other serious problems.
ACCIDENTS: Caslino hit by falling serac which caused him to fall 350m; found body on 27th and buried it in glacier; no other serious problems

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to loss of friend and danger
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual site for N Face (same as Italians)
C1 at normal route's C1 site
C2 at bottom of a 500m couloir just above Herzog's "cauliflower ridge"
High point at 6000m top of couloir.

Wanted to do entire NW Ridge from bottom of it but too long, so took same route, using N Face route, to start of same ridge on route used by Vion's '81 French expedition. Grison climbed couloir to 6000m (top of couloir) and beginning of NW Ridge proper. 

News [of Grison's death] reached BC next morning and team immediately decided to call off climb because of great danger from serac between BC and bottom of couloir and loss of motivation following death of Grison.

Grison fell 200m from 6000m while starting return to C2 probably when fixed rope came away on 23rd; buried in crevasse.
ACCIDENTS: Grison fatal fall; no other accidents, etc.

SPONSOR: 1986 Fang Expedition Team of Khic Alpine Club of Korea
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5450m due to loss of equipment in avalanching
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Annapurna Sanctuary southeast of Fang
ABC at hillside before East Face
C1  on icefall on East Face
C2  in new icefall area
High point at C2.

16-18th Sept much snowfall and many snow avalanches and icefall around C2 "broken" (members in ABC and C1 these 3 days). Fixed rope and equipment between C1 and C2 buried by snow and could not be found. Think avalanche at night carried away C2. 20th Sept 2 members tried to return to C2 but big new crevasse opened on the way and could not reach site. Had fixed 2600m rope and 1000m of this now gone; ice screws and carabiners lost. E Face difficult steep rock. Could have climbed it with more fixed rope.
ACCIDENTS: Yoon Dae-Woon fell 6m into crevasse but not hurt
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Korean attempt and 1st East Face attempt

SPONSOR: Korea Seoul Alpine Assoc Exp to Gangapurna & Annapurna III
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7150m due to heavy snow and member's fatigue
ROUTEMEMO:
Team attempted to ascend Gangapurna N Face, traverse Annapurna III NE Ridge and descend Annapurna III N Ridge. Neither summit reached and no traverse made. Expedition split into two teams and attacked both peaks simultaneously. Later abandoned Annapurna III attempt and concentrated on Gangapurna.

Were able to make route safe from avalanches, which came down on both sides of route between C2 and C4, but plagued by frequent heavy snowfall. Used 1000m fixed rope C2->C3 and C3->C4 none, BC - (2x50m only). 28 Sept was summit attack day but heavy snow fell and had to descend (Cho and Ang Kami on 28th did not go above C4 but instead descended). C2 tent broken by heavy snow on 28th. No further summit bid because Koreans very tired and Sherpas did not want to climb any more (some were sick). All in BC at end of month and finally 3 Oct decided no more climbing.

SPONSOR: Korea Seoul Alpine Assoc Exp to Gangapurna & Annapurna III
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5300m due to shortage of equipment and heavy snow
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on west side of ridge northwest of Annapurna III.

Team attempted to ascend Gangapurna N Face, traverse Annapurna III NE Ridge and descend Annapurna III N Ridge. Neither summit reached and no traverse made. Expedition split into two teams and attacked both peaks simultaneously. Later abandoned Annapurna III attempt and concentrated on Gangapurna.

Annapurna III team needed more fixed rope and rock climbing equipment than expedition could spare from needs for Gangapurna, which was first priority. Had intended place a C3 at 6400m. Also had problem of heavy snow plus difficult rock climbing just below C2 on steep section; falling stone in this area. 2000m fixed rope put in between C1 and C2. On 25th Sept more heavy snowfall. All difficult parts of climb finished.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7900m due to high winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Messner BC
C1 at Messner C1.

Seracs at 7200m-7300m needed fixed rope on 25th Sept and down in bad weather. Now just Gabarrou and Pemba Norbu, a good climber who does not require lots of fixed rope. Again up 3rd Oct to C1, 4th towards C2 but having to leave loads, 5th to C2, 6th bad weather and stayed C2, 7th to biv, 8th reached ridge, see not possible to reach main summit on long ridge so go to peak without name and return to biv. 9th tried to go to main summit but very cold and very strong wind, so turned back and reached C2 at night. Would have died probably if had kept on climbing because of terrible winds.

Frequently falling seracs astonished Gabarrou at constant danger, but did not hit them.

Bouvard left early not because sick, but unwilling to accept this danger.
ACCIDENTS: Slight frostbite in toes of Gabarrou and Pemba
ACHIEVMENT: 1st ascent to this peak on ridge

ROUTE1: E Ridge (via Fluted Peak, Tarke Kang, Roc Noir)
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m on Glacier Dome due to dangerous snow conditions
OTHERSMTS: Climbed Glacier Dome (GLAC-863-01); attempted Roc Noir (ROCN-863-01)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southwest of Tent Peak in Annapurna Sanctuary
C1 at glacier at bottom of normal route up Tent Peak
C2 on South Ridge of Fluted Peak
C3 at glacier below Fluted Peak North Face
Biv just below Rock Noir to East Ridge 
High point at below Rock Noir's East Ridge.

From Tent Pk 5300m to Fluted Pk, fixed 2500m fixed rope for less experienced clients on expedition. Did not climb Tent Pk, but went up small peak between Tent and Fluted Pk and then scaled Fluted Pk and down its N Face 100m to glacier (200m rope fixed here) where made C3. C3 reached by 4 French and 4 Sherpas. Then Batard and 2 Sherpas went on to make route and if possible to climb Roc Noir, to put C4 on Roc Noir summit; but stopped by very bad snow conditions of sugar snow and turned back. 7th Nov tried to climb onto E Ridge, but here snow conditions stopped them very soon going west; turned east towards Glacier Dome to try to gain ridge but again too dangerous snow. Left BC 8th Nov.

BC at normal site
Deposit in moraine (rock)
Biv2 
Biv2 on wall left of cycle.

Started from C1 on 19th Sept with small tent and slept that night at 5500m. 20th bived at 6900m directly below E Annapurna summit, a good place, below big seracs with no problem of small avalanches (were on French route). 21st to summit from 6900m at 1:45 pm (left biv at 4:00 am, returned to tent at 6900m at 5:30 pm). Difficult from 2nd biv, difficult ice climbing (because big avalanche had carried all snow away). Had problem of descent and so put fixed rope at places (had total only 650m rope - cut it). 22nd  slept in C1 and 23rd to BC (day French member killed by loose piton).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to death of a member
ROUTEMEMO:
Lower BC under West Wall
BC at normal site
C1 at NE Col
High point at NE Ridge.

Weather very good, no technical difficulties.

21 Sept at lower BC, Muellender (who had lung infection) got sick. Had gone twice to 4700m on 17th and 20 Sept. Night of 20 Sept got sick again and was helped and carried to lower BC which reached 4:00 pm 21st, 7:00 pm unconscious, and 8:30 pm dead (not altitude sickness).
ACCIDENTS: Muellender (who had lung infection) got sick (had gone twice to 4700m), night of Sep 20 got sick again & was carried to LBC, he became unconscious and by 8:30 pm dead (not altitude sickness)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7550m due to wind destroying C5
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 3800m Thula Khola's east moraine
C3 at 6100m start of snow rib
C4 at 7100m above big seracs, left of snow rib
C5 at 7500m col giving across to West Ridge
High point on West Ridge.

Very difficult route climbed: rock BC to C2, snow above to ridge. At C5 wind so strong picked up tent after poles broken and lifted collapsed tent off mountain. Took 2 weeks to get to BC cutting the jungle, making bridges, fixing rope for porters who gave lot of troubles. 1 week lost here might have spelled defeat in late Oct. Winds were not problem on face route but at ridge were very strong. Did have snow fall, block avalanche problems, rock avalanche cut fixed ropes and just missed climbers on exposed lower section of route several times, rock section not so difficult but snow section was sugar-snow and rib treacherously soft. Above C2 some days only 40-50m gained. Wind had smashed C5. No time left on 3 months air ticket.

Total 3000m rope fixed on route. All technical climbing finished but after C5 destroyed by wind, would have taken 10 days to remount summit bid.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to dangerous snow conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal site
C1 just above icefall
C2 at Col
High point at snow slope below steep ridge.

Late Sept a lot of snow: 27 Sept more than 1 meter snow at BC, so stayed in BC for 7 days while snow kept falling. 2 Oct started up from BC and on 3rd reached C2 but camp in bad condition and avalanching going on. Stayed 4 days at C2 with one day 40 cm snowfall. 4 Oct tried to reach C3 site at 6300m but could not go above 6100m because very dangerous snow ("we swam in snow"), so down to BC 6th Oct and called off climb because no chance to reach summit. 1st Oct was big avalanche from top of Dhaulagiri and its blasts of air hit BC. Left BC 8 or 9 Oct.
ACCIDENTS: None ("We stopped before any accident occurred")

SPONSOR: Okayama University-Nepal Himalaya Exp to Tripura Hiunchuli
ROUTEMEMO:
15 Oct made route above Attack Camp, 16 Oct snowing, 17 Oct to summit. Planned second summit bid but one member's snowblindness aborted this. Difficult parts: C1 to C2 rock and snow mixed near a col; even more difficult were 2 pitches above C2 on rock traverse. 

Members went to Jumla from KTM by scheduled flight (sirdar and loads by bus to Nepalgunj and porters to Jumla). From Jumla trekked Hurikot via Goth (via Charikot on return) to Jagdula Khola.
ACCIDENTS: 1 member snowblinded; mailrunner fell on approach march; Ang Phuri 3 frostbitten fingers on 2 hands on summit day; other Sherpa sick and left team early

SPONSOR: RNA Expedition to Tukuche Peak Autumn 1986
ROUTEMEMO: Climb was part of a Royal Nepal Army training program. RNA major (a team member) thinks there is only one route on Tukuche and thus they climbed standard route.

SPONSOR: France-Nepali Joint Expedition to Gyachung Kang
ROUTEMEMO:
BC south of near junction of Lungsampa and Ngojumpa Glacier
C1 just north of rock spur's point 5695m
C2 northeast of point 6280m and northwest of point 6406m
C3 at bottom of rock chimney.

Very dangerous icefall above C1. Long route (5 hrs) from C1 to C2, then bergschrund at 6500m. Above C3 2 difficult chimneys and just below summit difficult climbing on bare rock. Route safe above icefall: no avalanche danger all route is steep (60 degrees to vertical). 

One party attempted summit on 11th May but very cold strong wind and gave up 100m below summit (were Flematti and Royer). Next days not so cold and wind not so strong although some fog and light snowfall.

One Nepalese member Khatri, climbed to C2 once; otherwise 3 Nepali members stayed at BC and asked French why they climbed; had been ordered to go on expedition: did not volunteer.
ACCIDENTS: One member injured his toe at night; slightly frostbitten fingers of May 11 summit party

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5200m at Dzasampa according to Schneider map
C1 at Gyabrag Glacier near "c" of Glacier on Schneider map 
C2 at 6446m
C3 at 6700m at base of icefall due east of point 6446m
C4 at 7500m at base of rock band in rocks at bad site.

Frush claims first American ascent on May 11. Claims that Smith and Schleypen of W German/USA expedition did not reach true summit on May 9 (they only reached summit plateau).

Between BC and C1 had 2 temporary camps for moving loads and local porters carried to C1 and then they went home to Thami and members were alone from C1 onwards. Then in a push established C1, C2 and C3 and fixed rope in icefall above C3, then retreated in deteriorating weather for rest and waited for better weather at BC. Made summit attempt from C3 on 7th, but high winds defeated this bid not far above C3 and no C4 put in place on this try. 2nd bid on 10 May, when did pitch C4 at 7:30 pm. Bacon and Schertz supported Frush and Hambly; Bacon and Schertz would have gotten to top if otherse in support of them, but none of others went above C4.

There is no doubt Smith and Schleypen reached actual summit from Swiss team on 9th May considering where they were seen by this US etc expedition and time seen, and doubts expressed by Swiss members. Frush will write Smith for photo of him with Chinese flag.


Frush - 28 Sept 95

Frush and Hambly did not see Everest and Lhotse because it was cloudy. We did go on beyond 1st bump in most interminable walk of my life taking 25 breaths per step to reach summit watched on 9 May, saw 1 man (or 2) from Woerner's expedition reach 1st bump on top of Cho Oyu early in morning and start down only 15-30 meters later. Woerner said Smith got to top of rock band, i.e., first bump, but Woerner hadn't reached that point - said 1st bump was good enough. Woerner's team claims were revised after Frush's claim to have been 1st American and Smith realized he could have been 1st American himself. At first Smith said he had no photos, then photos appeared but of different flags at different place.


Letter to Miss Hawley by Jim Frush - Sept 23, 1986

Enclosed are the photos I mentioned in my letter of August 23.

I hope that they resolve the question of who reached the true summit of Cho Oyu. The photos were taken two days apart in a period of relatively settled weather. There is no sign in our photos of the blue and white scarf that Jan Smith indicated he tied to the summit marker. It appears to me and others who have viewed the photos that they are of two different places. I have supplied the photos to Mr.Smith but have not received a reply.


Letter to Miss Hawley by Jim Frush - Aug 22, 1986

I wrote to Mr. Smith who replied he had no picture of himself on the summit.

Fortunately, he enclosed, however a slide that purported to show the summit marker. We were able to compare his slide to our photos and were pleased to discover that it appears, as proven by his own photo, that Mr. Smith reached only the false summit and not the true summit, located further back on the summit plateau. I'm having copies of the photos made and will forward a set to you within two weeks. And I have so notified Mr. Smith.

It appears necessary to get into this as Summit Magazine reported last week that Mr. Smith reached the summit. This report was submitted by Mike Cheney. Perhaps you would be so kind as to pass the information and the photos on to him, and ask him to correct the Summit article.
"Very easy" says leader. Only problem is political problem of border. Summiters found on top and took photo of Chinese flag and Tibetan woman's photo on a pole.
ACCIDENTS: Danielak after summit became ill and worried he had pulmonary edema; Terlikowski feared frostbite on 1 May and turned back from summit push but nothing serious

ROUTE1: E Ridge from S Face of Ngozumba Kang
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5100m near Gokyo, ABC 3 hours from Gokyo
C1 at same camp sites as Poles.

First tried to climb via S Face of Ngojumba and put a C1 at 6100m on 23 April and reached 6400m on 24th but then encountered chaos of seracs and crevasses which was very dangerous and decided to abandon this route (which French on Gyachung Kang actually did follow in lower part of their climb), requested change of route permit from HMG (got no answer) and went to Pole's route as above. Short direct route, technically more difficult than Tichy route but could be done by strong team without the 700m fixed rope put in by Poles. Very safe route without objective dangers and very beautiful ice ridges. On upper part was no snow this spring.

6 members left before climb entirely finished, but no reason for them to stay since summit teams were not supported from BC.

E Ridge appears equally difficult as Lhotse Shar. Lhotse traverse plus dangerous lower part of climb.

Frush claims first American ascent on May 11. Claims that Smith and Schleypen of W German/USA expedition did not reach true summit on May 9 (they only reached summit plateau).


Schleypen - 3 Nov 95

Confident he reached Cho Oyu's summit in 1986. Went to what surely was highest point of plateau (where there was pole with cloth, flags, as per Smith's photo), which took 30-45 minutes to reach from edge of plateau first reached - did not see Chinese metal flag (Frush's photo).


Habeler and Ruedi arrived BC on 21 April and 3 days later expedition decided 2000m fixed rope required for Ngojumba East Ridge to Cho Oyu plus 3 months time, so idea of trying this route abandoned and went to new route via 2 passes of 5700m to depot near Polish and US BC and did two ferries of loads (Habeler and Ruedi were first members to explore for new route). As for 1st time at depot on 28 Apr. 29 Apr went over Nangpa La and slept at Tichy camp near US. 2 May arrived at Poles ABC. 3 May Habeler and Ruedi left ABC to go as high as possible arriving at Poles C4 but a actually went to Poles C5 (Habeler and Ruedi C1) at 4:00 pm. 4 May stormy and very cold so all day in tent. 5 May left C1 7:30 am and on top 11:00 am. Stayed 1/2 hour in warm weather and very cloudy to south. Saw and photographed Chinese pole on summit "with lady on it" (hard to see pole on large summit plateau). Back in C1 1:00 pm, had tea and went on down. Nasty weather in which had trouble finding ridge to descend but continued to ABC at 7:00 pm.


Letter from Stefan Woerner to Miss Hawley, July 17,1986

What concerns Jan Smith's climb of Cho Oyu in my team last spring, I think there should be no doubt that he has been at the very top. Jan has sent me slides that can be only be taken from the top. One slide that I have not seen he has already sent to Jim Frush, showing the Chinese flag on the top. Please also receive a copy of the letter Jan Smith sent to Jim Frush in this matter.


Letter to Jim Frush from Jan Smith, June 21 1986

I reached the summit of Cho Oyu about midday on May 9th. But you'll have to take my word for it; I was on the summit alone. I'm not plugging Rolexes, so I didn't take any effort to photograph myself. I did photograph the summit marker and the view. Several transparencies are enclosed. One taken from the southern rim of the summit looks down on the area of our base-camp on the western edge of the Lungsampa Glacier. The blue silk scarf with white Chinese characters that you can see hanging from the summit marker is mine; I met my friend Rudiger Schleypen at the northern edge of the summit plateau; he continued on to the summit and I went on down to our camp where we spent the night. If it's important enough you should talk to Rudiger.

Slides: 
Cho Oyu summit stake, Jan's pack and poles
Sagarmatha, Lhotse view @105mm
View south-southeast down Ngojumba Glacier

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6400m due to cold afternoon snow and severe climb
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4555m at near Mingbo by Horner and Stevenson 
   (who arrived at mountain before the others)
ABC at bottom of the ridge
C1 on S Ridge
C2 on S Ridge
C3 at top of S Ridge at big mushroom.

20 April all members except Kleppinger started up at 6:30 am but wind was so cold returned to camp and waited for sun's warmth; started again at about 10:00 am but still cold wind which cleared ice sheet of all snow meant climb on this steep (70 degrees) section was too much for them. Spent night again at C3 and then down in deteriorating weather with snow every afternoon. Epic getting off mountain's snow and ice covering rock ridge. Rock itself between C2 and C3 very rough.
ACCIDENTS: Kleppinger had constant stomach problems & never got beyond C1

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6770m due to snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on west side of Lhotse Nuptse Glacier
Biv 1 on South Spur
Biv 2 on South Spur
Biv 3 on South Spur
Biv 4 in cave on South Spur
Biv 5 on South Spur
High point on South Spur.

Alpine-style attempt SE Buttress (between original British route and Cassin-Messner ramp).

12th May recce and left cache of gear 18,500 ft. Then snowfall and unable to go up till 19th when started up again and reached 19,000 ft. 21st moved up again and by 26th had just about reached top of spur and then gaing would have been "a lot easier" to SE Peak at 25,600 ft, but "got weathered off" and 3 days more climbing to this summit. Spur was very severe hard rock and snow made it impossible to climb. "Is fabulous climb, best in the area" - perfect rock (hard granite), steep, difficult, safe (only one rock fall during climb), technical climb to 23,000 ft where easy black rock, snow and ice begin.

Lowe and Twight plan to return to this route this winter.


Sandy Allan, Lhotse Shar - 25 Aug 86

Nuptse: 22 May Allan left Nuptse area and that day Lowe and Twight were well up Nuptse buttress. Were on their 4th day of their push (had taken 10 days food with them). Lowe now plans to return to KTM 3 June.

BC at Omega Valley
C1 just short of getting glacier running south from Omega
C2 just 300 hundred feet short of col at 5865m
C3 at snow cave on tongue of ice (hanging glacier)
C4 at bottom of crevasse on a serac near West Summit
C5 at main summit plateau in snow cave.

Ascent on right side of NW Ridge. Frost and Lowe climbed lower northwest peak; Hargreaves and Twight climbed main peak up steep ice face. Descent was by northeast couloir.

Roghaar and Frost worked on lower part of route after others went to Lobuje on 14th (and returned on 21st April) and pushed route to 17,000 ft to get onto glacier and 5 members (excluding Kendall) started up together on 23 April aiming for Col at 5865m. 24th reached near Col, 25th down to 17,000 ft and made another carry to 19,000 ft by 4 while Roghaar feeling unwell, descended and abandoned climb. 27th moved from col up rope on 2 pitches up headwall above ice tongue. 29th four members moved camp up headwall. 30th four climbed on ice gully and traversed into a notch between north and main summits to main summit plateau. Lowe had bronchitis and health deteriorating on 30 April. Surprised on 1 May to find very difficult ice climb to top up steep fluting, so Hargreaves and Twight went up for top with all of expedition's small supply of ice screws and rope while Lowe and Frost went to subsidiary summit (6685m) in easy climb and descended onto Hinku Nuptse Glacier at 19,000 ft on top 1979 route. 2 May summiters followed same descent route. All in BC 2 May. 

Lobuje East first by Hargreaves, Kendall, Lowe and Twight.

Roghaar left Nepal about 3 May.
Frost returned to KTM 9 May and leaves Nepal 14 May.
Kendall returns to KTM 11 May.
Lowe returns to KTM about 25-27 May and leave Nepal end of May.

ROUTE1: W Face up; SW Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Mingbo by Brugger & Walde and kitchen staff
C1 at moraine at bottom of Face (no tent - rock shelter)
C2 at behind serac at start of face.

2 men went direct to Ama Dablam and other 8 arrived at BC 9 April. Started on Hillary route. Was little snow, mostly climbed on rocks to left side of hanging glacier, over serac line. On 15 April at 2:00 am Brugger and Walde began summit push from C2 and got to top at 11:00 am and descended normal route on South Ridge to 5700m (British team's C1) and slept there. 16 April 8:00 am returned to BC. Difficult rock at 65-degree steepness (short sections 70 degrees). Eitel and Santer went to C2 only, others BC only; these 8 left BC 12 April.

On 10 April descended to BC for rest. On 14 April went from BC to C2 in 2-1/4 hours.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to avalanching and lack of time.
ROUTEMEMO:
On 8 April made fixed ropes to 6000m and down, but after 2 days abandoned climb because of wind and more importantly avalanches. Huge serac avalanches came down and in fact original route no longer possible and one must go on E Ridge. Came away from 6400-6500m area.

Then went to Ama Dablam.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8400m due to lack of experience and strength ("can't really blame the weather")
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5300m at normal site on Yalung Glacier
C1 at 6100m near top of the hump
C2 at 6700m a little way up second icefall
C3 at 7100m just below Great Shelf
C4 at 7600m 200m below normal spot which is at bottom of gangway.

Groom reached 8400m on 13 May in attempt to see how high he could get above C4; turned back when wind came up and skies clouded over. Rejoined Chemello and Van Gelder at C4 at 7600m.

C4 too low because the two climbers with Groom pushing up to C4 having trouble in deep snow and were not very strong up. On 13th May Groom went on up alone to see how high he could get; took no bivy gear with him and returned to C4 same day. Frost and Strohfeldt had given up after 26th April when bad weather drove all down to BC. Other three waited for snowfall to stop and then tried summit push. All but Groom had no Himalayan expedition experience and Groom turned back at 8400m because he himself "didn't know what to expect at 8400m." Had been agreed second push would be the last.
ACCIDENTS: None except Groom slight frostbite from 1-foot snow on gangway on May 13

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8100m due to lack of manpower, route difficulty
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at normal high BC site at glaciers' junction
C1 at east branch of Chago Glacier
C2 south of 6550m col at beginning of steep climb to Makalu Col
C4 on Makalu La
High point on North Face.

Early May very cold strong winds blew from Tibet so retreated to BC. Lot of wind throughout climbing period but little snowfall. Could walk from BC to C2 in tennis shoes. After made C4 again winds fierce and down to BC. 2 members left expedition (a member found this climb not for him). Other 2 members headed up again on 20th May but Wilcox got sick at C3 and went down 22nd May with one Sherpa. Gillette continued up with 3 Sherpas to C4 in fierce winds fixing 100 ft rope. 2 more days winds to 80 mph. Started up on 2 successive days with 4 Sherpas turned back while Gillette using oxygen carried on up alone to see where he could get. No wind now, perfect weather, but steep rock at high altitude alone struck Gillette as not wise and he turned back at 8100m (he had never been above 7600m before in his career).


Bouchard - 27 May 1986

Bouchard left BC 19 May. All down in BC. 4 people 4 oxygen not enough so 2 including Bouchard volunteered to give up theirs leaving Gillette and Wilcox for summit push leaving BC 21 May and getting to top about 25 May.

C4 about 200m above North Col = 7600m occupied about 10 May
C3 = 7000m 
C2 = 6400m

Chous may have left BC soon after Bouchard
Bouchard leave KTM 28 May
ACCIDENTS: Dube serious altitude sickness; Wilcox intestinal illness

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to altitude problem and 1 member's death
ROUTEMEMO:
BC on big ledge just above junction of Barun & Chago Glacier
C1 at Chago Glacier east of "g" and of central rock
High point on NW Ridge.

C2 never actually occupied but stocked with 32 man-days food and all equipment and fuel ready for climb planned to sleep there for first time on 12th April; all doing well and in good spirits. C2 to be occupied by 3 members; then Terrell got pulmonary edema that night and began to get him down at midnight and reached BC at 7:30 am 12th apparently much better but 3 pm started descent and required being carried. Got him to 16,900 ft by dark and trail too narrow to carry in dark; Sherpas summoned and next dawn began carry again but suddenly he became actually ill and died and was buried near where died. 2 members not acclimatizing well and Ken's wife had arrived with trekkers so now only 3 members returned to climb: on 17th to C1. Bruce sick again. 2 members to C2 on 18th and went on through to NW Ridge to 22,000 ft and then turned back though could have gotten to top (no technical difficulties) and slept that night at C1 - were "emotionally depleted" and had no support. Cleared mountain and left BC 20th April after giving their food to Makalu expedition.

* Illness was apparent edema but some puzzling aspects and this by no means certain diagnosis (to which Dr. David Shlim of H.R.A. agrees after talking with Ruggera).


Kangchungtse, Ministry of Tourism - 20 April 86

Terrell got altitude sickness at 5950m on April 11 at 2400 hours; taken to ABC at 8100 ft on April 12 by Ruggera, Madden and Langbons; arrived at ABC at 05:00 hours; Fortner, Ruggera and kitchen boy took him down from ABC towards BC and died at 5180 ft at 8:45 am on 13 April.

Not decided whether to abandon climb.

ROUTE2: New route on S Pillar (Face) (no attempt)
TERMNOTE: Primary attempt abandoned at 7000m due to Duff's injury
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5300m below SE Face on Lhotse Shar Glacier south of Island Peak
C1 at 5670m on a buttress
C2 at 6400m on SE Face in snow hole above rock barrier
High point at 7000m at SE Face.

First attempt on SE Face abandoned after Duff's injury. 

Allan later joined by Alison Hargreaves for second attempt on SE Face. This attempt abandoned at 6500m due to slab avalanches.

Original plan was for new route on S Face (this route never attempted).

7th May went up from BC, slept at C2 on 8th left at midnight and got to 23,000 ft at 6:00 am 9th May and Duff hit by falling serac, so both descended immediately and were back in BC 4:00 pm to Pheriche 10th. Duff left expedition and Alison Hargreaves joined Allan 15th at Dingboche after he had packed up BC; they then went back to try for top while Duff came to Kathmandu.
ACCIDENTS: Duff hit by falling serac on head on May 8 (bled, partly unconcious and left expedition, will have brain scan in London)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6050m due to bad weather and season finishing
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 4050m at Khyumbu Glacier
ABC at 4800m at west of glacier towards face of SW Ridge
C1  at 5600m on SW Ridge
C2  at 5800m on ridge beyond rock and snow peaks
Biv at 6100m 200m beyond Japanese peak 5970m 
High point at 6050m at bivouac.

From ABC to C1 2 couloirs. Took route slightly different from Japanese route, joined ridge S of Japanese point of joining it. Above C1 was difficult rock peak with 4 rock steps; then down and traversed to middle of 3 peaks, then several snow peaks. Beyond C3 was 300m saddle but very sharp ridge here and very steep on both sides and above (=beyond) saddle, steep rock peak (5970m), followed by rock and snow peaks an fixed 3000m rope from point 5970m. 

Fixed total 3500m rope, even snow peaks very narrow and ridge all up and down. Planned total 4 high camps above ABC but sites very difficult (sides of ridge 45 degrees hard ice) and 2000m rope fixed rope needed.

Komprej hit by snow avalanche in 1st couloir but not serious. Constant snowfall meant camps on ridge covered by wind driven snow and ropes often covered by snow. Had only 4 days without snowfall and often had trouble seeing route when were in low clouds. Then last week of climbing strong winds. With no Sherpas with them, exhaustion setting in, in such weather would have taken this team another month to reach summit. This mountain really too difficult for them.
ACCIDENTS: 1 member hit by snow avalanche in 1st couloir but not serious

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at East Annapurna Glacier, west of Annapurna II's SW Ridge
C1 above Glacier
C2 on rock (below East Ridge)
C3 at top of icefall (still below ridge)
C4 just above col between Gangapurna and Annapura III (where route joined East Ridge).

Same route and campsites as that of Poles in autumn 1985; others to East Ridge very nearly same route with camps at different altitudes. Between C1 and C2 broken seracs and crevasses made difficulties. Summit ridge: rock one side, snow other side: long way and needed fixed rope, which installed on rock side (S side). C3 to C4 difficult blue ice. Total 2000m fixed rope. Tricky finding route from C1 to C2.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7550m due to dangerous conditions
ROUTEMEMO:
Second attempt on Annapurna I by Bulgarian 1985 winter expedition. Team reduced to 9 Bulgarians and 3 Sherpas. High point at S on South Face.

Had to reestablish several camps several times because of heavy snowfall and C3 in crevasse which opened up. Required climbing on 7th April only and continued till 24th April when had been working above C3 for 2 days. After 24th again much snowfall & on 24th all down to BC. 6th May again up and discovered falling stones had badly damaged fixed ropes in at least 10 places. On 9th May decided to quit because of extreme danger when couldn't see where ropes were damaged. Went up to 7550m on 9th May (had been only to 7400m on 23/24 April). Had intended to make one more camp above C3 at 7275m (Pole's C5).

SPONSOR: Spedizione Citta de Lecco 1986 to Annapurna I
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6200m due to bad snow conditions and weather not improving
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4150m (usual site for North Face climbs)
C1 at usual (usual site for North Face climbs))
C2 at 4850m (usual site for North Face climbs)
C3 at 50m or so from usual site for North Face climbs
High point at C3 site.

Had to fix rope to C1, mostly a walk up from BC, because of much snow lying there. Decided to switch from NW Ridge to N Face route because ridge was all exposed rock, not snow-covered as anticipated and for which they were equipped.

On 25th April put all equipment for C3 at 6200m site but bad weather coming and did not sleep there. Now all down in BC during 4 days snowfall (30 cm snowfall daily). 29th good weather and 30th started up again. On 1 May all 5 from C1 to C2 and on the way all were hit by slab avalanche but went to C2 for that night but next day all down to BC to wait for better snow conditions. Then again period of frequent snowfall and then 2 tents at BC destroyed by wind. Went up to clear C1 and C2 on 5th and 6th May, but did not go above C2 because snow conditions too dangerous.
ACCIDENTS: None except bruised shoulder in avalanche

SPONSOR: Ohtani Himalaya Alpine Club Langtang Lirung Expedition 1986
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4160m beside Langtang Glacier (west side)
C1 at 4800m on plateau further up west side of Langtang Glacier
C2 at 5600m on SE Ridge
C3 at 6100m on SE Ridge
C4 at 6450m on SE Ridge but slightly flat area.

Very difficult mixed rock and ice knife edges above C2 required 900m fixed rope to C3 (total on mountain 2500m); otherwise easy route; rest hope for safety. Only 1 summit party because not enough food.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7400m due to bad weather and fixed date to leave BC (May 13)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 3900m at 1-1/2 hours from Samagaon
C1 at 5150m at 2 hours below Naike Col
C2 at 6200m just above white serac zone on NE Face
C3 at 6850m just below North Col
C4 at 7400m on rocky shoulder above N Col
High point at C4.

15th April to early May bad weather (thunderstorms and heavy snowfall). C4 pitched on 3 May and deserted on 4th. All survivors in BC 4th May except Baessler who got to BC on 6th and evacuated by helicopter 9th May with Wirthensohn. On 9th started up again, reached C3, looked for 2 dead men, another half-meter snowfell and on 11th abandoned climb.

Klaiber fell in fixed ropes returning to C3 after seeing he could not reach C4, no one saw fall, he just disappeared. 

May 4 Oberbichler fell descending from C3 because heavy snowfall (again fall not seen but he was found badly bashed).

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to bad weather, frequent heavy snowfall and wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Sanjung Kharka
C1 at Sanjung Glacier.

As per our letter dated June 9, 86 through Chibere Khola.
