Until 5700m, no difficulty. Between 5100-5600m, steep slopes with unstable deep and heavy snow. Up 5700m, long steep corridor (6000m, 45-60 degrees) with very deep dangerous snow.

BC at 4500m at Langshisa Glacier 
C1 at 5700m on plateau up against SW Ridge by all 5 members.

No technical difficulties from BC to C1, just long slog. 13 April did recce from plateau and next day and technical climb to summit. Left C1 at 3:30 am and 1st pair got to top after 9 hrs. Had 50m snow gully which was soft snow and thus slow but only about 40 degrees. Next was hard ice 45-60 degrees face with rock band through it which was moderately difficult. Had good weather on summit day.


Notes:

1)-> C1 up a snow-covered scree slope. Must be done early in the day. Much avalanche danger at the end of the day. (Time with 20 kg about 9 hours from BC->C1). At the top of scree slope is a col from where a traverse/gentle climb is made to the plateau. Either of two routes can be used: 
(a) around the bottom of the ridge which involves one "difficult" section on 
    which the Japanese fixed ropes, or 
(b) over a snowy part of the ridge which is straightforward but hard work.

2) C1 - windscoop beside rocks about 100 ft above the plateau.

3) C1 - summit->C1 14 or 15 hours. Up a steep snow gully (30-45 degree) then onto hard ice about 200m from the top, 7 pitches of 45-60 degree ice, long run outs.

ROUTE1: S Face of Ganesh IV-W Ridge
SPONSOR: 1986 Sogang Alpine Ganesh Himal III Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to bad weather, series of accidents
ROUTEMEMO:
This mountain previously known as Ganesh II until re-surveyed in early 1990's.  

C3 was on E Ridge of Ganesh IV/W Ridge of Ganesh III. Immediately above was very sharp ridge with many big cornices, had to frontpoint while traversing this difficult section. Beyond that very dangerous rock and this problem combined with strong wind on 9th and 10th May defeated summit bid by 2 members who were still 2 km from their summit at their highest point. No technical problems beyond but summit too far away. In their descent they were exhausted but no support because support team had accident (Sherpa broke leg) and they jettisoned everything including food and tent for Choi and Park Chung-Sang in their effort to get Sherpa down. Took Choi and Park 4 days to BC with no food, no C2, no support.

Lee Tae-Yul's shoulder injured when serac avalanche broke tents and struck him, putting him out of action; Kim Chul-Han's arm injured by falling ice block and he also out of action; Ang Tshering's leg broken. Park Chung-Sang slightly hurt leg in 10 m fall but kept climbing although Choi now led their climb.

9th April to 14 May only 4 clear days, all others cloudy (could not see route) and much snow.
ACCIDENTS: Lee Tae-Yul's shoulder injured when serac avalanche broke tents & struck him (put out of action); Kim Chul-Han arm injured by falling ice block (put out of action); Ang Tshering leg broken; Park Chung-Sang slightly hurt leg in 10m fall

ROUTE1: NE Ridge from E of N Col
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7650m due to snow and icefall conditions (too much for 2-man alpine ascent)
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at same place as last autumn for East Face climb
C1 at snow hole on plateau (same as last autumn)
C2 one tent on NE Ridge, which had joined at 6500m
High point at NE Ridge.

Not a single day without clouds from 7 or 8 am and snow in late morning. Climbed mostly at night after first week. When arrived BC there was 2m deep snow at BC. 2 May from C1 to 7000m in acclimatization climb towards normal route and back to C1. 8 May started summit push and 9 May reached same high point as last year and little higher, then down because of slab avalanche danger and down to BC on 10 May. 

15 May again up and 18 May to 7300m tent in very strong wind. 20 May down because snowfall and gas gone. 23 May all way down to BC through dangerous icefall (Kregar tummy trouble). Again more snowfall, both very tired and decided to leave Nepal 8 June.

Did not attempt E Face because they wanted finally to get to summit somehow, anyhow.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned on 4 Apr because of fatal accident
ROUTEMEMO:
Did no actual climbing. Fatal accident occurred during approach march on west side of Mesokantu La. Had left KTM 25th March and left Pokhara 26th March. 2 April made camp at 3800m. 3 April snowfall kept camp at same place but did some recce. 4th April planned to reach La, dump baggage and returned to camp; made deposit at 5000m (100m below/before pass) by 15 members. As returning to camp by 15 members, 10 members were caught by huge snow avalanche and carried down. 3 left on top when movement stopped and 7 members covered by snow. Wannenmacher freed himself immediately, 4 found quickly (3-5 mins) and heads freed, while Ebert and Springmann were found only after 10 minutes and gave no sign of life. Were buried next day at accident site. 

Decided not to cross pass for climb partly for fear of more avalanching, so went back to Jomsom and up to Muktinath, crossed through La and trekked through Manang.
ACCIDENTS: 2 members killed in snow avalance on west side of Mesokantu La on approach march; expedition abandoned

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6250m due to lack of time in tightly scheduled program
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 4450m northwest of mountain (came there from Tange eastwards)
C1 southeast from BC in the valley (same place as Japanese C1)
C2 south of C1 still in the valley on glacier
High point beyond pass on West Face.

30 April made attempt. 29 April reached pass leading to go another valley. Pass 6250m and reasonable place for a C2 or C3. Returned to C2 and on 30th April tried to go to top but too long: were about 1 hr from top and was possible to reach. However 2 people roped together fell and other 2 on other rope had to rescue them from crevasse and now was 5 pm and had been away from C2 12 hrs. Now too tired and it was too late to go on up, thus ended climb because no time left. Were on steep (55 degrees) snow and ice face. Always fresh snow and wind obliterating tracks.

Ferrand fell into crevasse 30 April; was belayed by other member but was hanging in crevasse and belayer could not move but no injury; rescue consumed too much time to continue to summit.

BC at normal site
C1 100m below North Col
C2 at beginning of steep rock ridge
C3 on ridge
C4 on ridge (end of ridge).

1st team started from C3 to top on 3 May with stove, etc., deposited at 7500m; went to top Hirtreiter and Haerter and slept at 7500m. 2 others [Schauer, Dehn, Ang Phurba] in this team turned back at 50m below top (were 1 hour behind summiters) because violent thunderstorm. 

On 5th 3 others went to top from C4. Had tried to mount summit attempt 22 April but bad weather (snow and wind) deposited this bid and all descended to BC

Welsh had stomach ulcer problem at BC and was evacuated 28 April.
ACCIDENTS: Welsh had stomach ulcer problem at BC (evacuated Apr 28)

ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at 3500m towards start of Myagdi Khola SE of point 5981m and east of ridge
ABC at 4800m Tsaurabong Glacier west of ridge
C2  at 6000m South Face
C3A at 6500m South Face
C3B at 7000m at East Ridge
C4 near East Ridge.

Moved C3 5000m up because 1st site too far from summit. Made C4 at 7200m on 4th May but now avalanche broke tent that night and 2 occupants to C3 and on 5th repaired fixed ropes. On 12th May 3 summiters made push to top from C3 at 4:30 am and reached summit at 3:30-4:00 pm (on 11th May Kim had started for top but not in good condition and returned to C3). When on top on 12th weather bad; wind and snow and hail. 3 men descended. 30 minutes lapse between 1st and 3rd - Kim, in middle, disappeared. E Ridge very steep and north side sheer drop. Ang Dorje say this rock ridge was difficult section with steep ice just above C3.

Kim Sung-Gyu disappeared during descent from summit. Sherpas did not see what happened (snow falling greatly limited visability). He simply did not turn up at C3. This only casualty. Ang Dorje thinks Kim fell just above C3 about 7:30 pm.
ACCIDENTS: Kim Sung-Kyu disappeared during descent from summit, Sherpa did not see what happened; he did not return to C3 (Ang Dorje thinks Kim fell just above C3 at 7:30 pm)

SPONSOR: Korean-Japanese Joint Expedition 1985-86 Winter to Tawoche
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at Pheriche
ABC at point 5160m and 5140m southeast of Tawoche Glacier on SE Face.

Koreans late arriving KTM and then bad weather prevented flights to Khumbu; arrived BC Jan 3 days after Japanese members had started climb. 5 Jan Japanese had fatal accident and stopped their climbing. 

Koreans resumed climb, went to BC 10 Jan. ABC occupied by Hee, Kim and Lee plus Ang Phurba. C1 only Heo and Ang Phurba, who went up small SE Face to SE Ridge and up final very steep rock. Fixed 600m rope as they climbed above point where Japanese members fixed rope ended to top: total 1600m fixed rope on most of entire route from ABC. Very difficult rock climbing, Heo and Ang Phurba say.

No accidents amongst Koreans as per Japanese party report of 14 Jan (Ohnishi).

4 Jan to 5600m below ridge. 5 Jan biv 5800m by H. Nakamura, Irisawa and Morizane. This highest point reached by Japanese members. Heo went later to mountain to try solo ascent but difficult route.

Korean members arrived Nepal late, were not all members he had met, did not bring equipment and mountain food (used gear brought by Ohnishi).

Kakomoto fell from point 10m below SE Ridge where steep ice met very soft snow. Fell 800m down steep section. Morizane rope burn on left hand.
ACCIDENTS: One Japanese climber Kakomoto killed in fall; none amongst Koreans

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Rongbuk Glacier
C3 below North Col on West Face of Changtse
C4 below North col
C5 on NE Ridge
C6 on NE Ridge below steps.

12 Aug summit attempt by 3 Nepalese members, Jordi Canals and Jordi Camprubi. Reached about 8600m at beginning of 2nd Step but turned back in snowfall and were tired, down to C3. Another party got no higher than C5 when bad weather (snow) and altitude turned them back. All down to BC. 

22 Aug started up again and reached C3. 25 Aug to C4, 26 Aug to C5 and 27 Aug to C6 and 28 Aug to top by 3 Nepalese, Carles Valles, Antoni Sors, Oscar Cadiach with support team to C5 and these supporters and Nawang Yonden to C6. Coming down 4 summiters C6 after 12 hours from C6. No further attempt because too much snow.

Sors toes frostbitten badly. Ang Karma fell 70-80m near 2nd Step but not really hurt 12 Aug. Valles bad altitude sickness from summit (needed oxygen at ABC) and used discarded 1/2 bottle during descent to ABC.

Valles in KTM 16 Oct 1990 said 3 Spanish summiters did not use oxygen at all.

14 Spanish members but 1 was only BC Mgr after getting sick at ABC. Leader was Conrad Blanch. Ernic Lucas left early to return to his work before climbing finished.


Tamaya, Spain (Italian Makalu expedition) - 15 Aug 85

Catalans reached 8000m in early Aug turned back by bad weather, lot of snow hope to go up again route, he doesn't know.
ACCIDENTS: Member's toes frostbitten badly; Ang Karma fell 70-80m near 2nd Step but not really hurt; Valles bad altitude sickness from summit (used oxygen half bottle during descent to ABC)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 8170m due to all exhausted, snowfall had required all off mountain and none had strength to go back up
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at 5300m at glacier
C1 at 6800m Bonington's 1st snow hole
C2 at 7090m new snow hole on ridge
C3 at 2 tents 
C4 at snow hole very close site of Bonington's 3rd cave
High point at 8170m top of 1st.

Had fixed route on 2 buttresses above C3 before making this camp, trying to skip this camp. Lot of snow from 28 April with few inches of snow every night there after.

Also went to North Col for filming and to prepare route of descent. Helped Basques from fatal accident.

Duff and two others at ABC, all in good health and strength, saw ghost for about one hour as he climbed from about 7150m to near this expedition's C3 where he disappeared behind in cluster of rocks. Assumed it was Sandy Allan at the time but later learned he was sick. Could only have been from this expedition but none that high in that area that day - was wearing red suit, a big man going very strongly - was size and strength of Peter Boardman who wore red windsuit when he disappeared in 1982 and Duff felt it was "Peter." A videotape being run again, says Duff. Peter's wife Hilary certain it was Peter and said she'd have to go and tell him to come home now.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7925m due to Chandler's illness and death
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Pangpema
C1 at same site as Czech's C1 (near boulders on far left side below 1st icefield)
C2 in basin towards top from icefall
C3 at Czech's C3 (2nd icefield)
Biv at halfway up rock band
C4 at top of rock band.

Stayed away from ridge: jet stream used to roar off that ridge. Would have liked to go to it from technical point of view. Used just two 250-foot ropes in all the climb for fixing route.

Whole mountain was glistering in ice, rock hard. Very highest snowfall but fierce winds which stopped progress in 2nd half of Dec.

Chandler died of cerebral edema. Bremer-Kamp and Tamang serious frostbite of fingers and toes: Tamang should not have been taken so high and Bremer-Kamp's frostbite due to job of getting him down alive (she was taken because he was eager to go up and it was useful having another load carrier).


David Peterson

Bremer-Kamp had frostbite, will lose at least all fingers and parts of toes. She in hospital here, she ultimately requires surgery.

We were all set for the summit "it was a gorgeous day." 15th Chris didn't show any signs of call see. We came up from 24,000 ft camp and we carried rather late night before. At 6:00 made biv in cave at about 26,000. Was a horrible night - "always is at that altitude." Chris was melting all water and thus getting less oxygen than others. Next 8:00 am late start: Chris sitting, not putting on crampons, being real slow inside cave. Stove was on but not burning. Lethargic - felt better outside and said would feel better if he just lay down. She sat besides him for a while in cave and then needed go out; then started getting white splotches on nose and Chris said better go down.

Chris said its such good weather we could go for the summit. This was summit day. Chris: "I can't see I'm going blind" and Cherie losing peripheral vision herself. Cherie and Mangal tried to get him up and he couldn't walk. By time got his crampons and roped up it was 1:00 pm. We fell in bringing him down on his feet. Chris wrapped [?] himself several times. Got down about 1000 ft at about 5:30 pm and settled down for night in sleeping bag on 3 platforms in snow and Mangal to brew water for Chris, tried with ice-axe belay but slipped down slope a little. Got him back up but got restless, rolling over and standing up on 35 degree slope and would have have slid all the way. Chris said I need help and had his hand outside the bag and he stopped moving and thrashing about; "used his lost little bit of energy."

He wasn't breathing, died about 8 that night. Cheri's feet frozen several days before but ignored; hands froze in rescue. Mangal's hand became bad the night of 15th. As with Cherie, using bare hands next day to set Chris's body sitting up in a hole so he could see view, his pack beside him. Then left at about 8:00 am and moved very slowly down. Mangal wanted to die and kept sitting down, critically dehydrated and Cherie hallucinating coming down glacier on 19th.

Could have gone to top on 15th. Next 4 days weather was so good - we were so weak, just like kittens. "Not allowed us to live - it just chose to take Chris." "The cerebral edema took me by surprise though I knew risks of such small party." Took Mangal high in order to help got supplies up high and he keen to go high.

Would go back to him? If I could go back with Chris I would - next year. 


Shrestha, Tourism - 26 Jan 85

Chris Chandler, Cherie Louise Bremer-Kamp and Sirdar Mangal Singh Tamang resumed climb on 7 Jan. After reaching 7925m on 15 Jan at 13:00 hours, Chandler suddenly got brain swelling and they had to descend. While Chandler brought down by others he died at about 25,000 ft. Other 2 got frostbite on hands and legs. Left body where he died and return BC 19 Jan at 22:00 hours.
ACCIDENTS: Chandler died of cerebral edema; Bremer-Kamp and Tamang serious frostbite of fingers and toes
ACHIEVMENT: 1st American and Australian attempt on any 8000er in Winter

ROUTEMEMO:
8th Dec Park Sung-Man, Shin and Song and 2 Sherpas try from C4 for top but very strong wind and reached 7500m. 9 Dec leader and same 2 Sherpas from C4 at 6:10 am and on top 2:40 pm; again strong wind and left 2:55 pm to C4 6:20 pm. Did not follow planned route above C1 because 3 big snow avalanches and no snow: all rock and hard ice, so moved eastwards up easy rock spur (Eperm des Jeunes) to snow face. C2 to C3 knife ridge but easy. 1400m fixed rope all route.

No accidents, except Shin got frostbitten fingers on summit-attempt day (may not lose any part of finger).

All members to C4.
ACCIDENTS: Shin got frostbitten fingers on summit attempt day (may not lose any part of fingers)

SPONSOR: GHM Ama Dablam N Ridge Expedition
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6600m due to lack of food supplies and ran out of strength
ROUTEMEMO:
Needed fixed rope to 6700m for descent but had not enough rope. 17 Dec Dobashi, Okada and Yoshida in alpine-style attempt reached about 6600m but too far from there to summit for that day and gave up climb. 3 men had made route from C1 and now very tired, very windy and food supplies running out since had planned summit for 14-15 Dec. 18 Dec route to C1 and 19 Dec to BC. Would have taken 3 whole days to go to C2 to top to C2. Snow conditions very bad, like sugar. C1 to C2 snow mushrooms, BC to C1 easy. Saito went to C2 once while Uchiyama and Kawaguchi to C1 only.

1 member went to C2 once while 2 members to C1 only.
ACHIEVMENT: 1st winter attempt on North Ridge; 1st Japanese winter attempt

ROUTEMEMO:
Most difficult part of route was 1st 1000m of ridge. All afraid of rock fall. Were only two teams working high on route: four members and too much for them to carry up equipment for so many camps. So C3 tent moved up as C5, so when 2nd summit team went up, technical difficulty made them unable get to C5 and they had to biv. Plus 2nd team acclimatizations differed: 1 member from Dhaulagiri I top but 1 member only 2 nights in C3. Rested C5 one day and 15th to top. Descending Kukuczka fell 4m and decided to biv at 7300m and not take chance in dark. Biv very hard so spent 16th in C5 and 17th in C3. E Face very dangerous from many avalanches; S Ridge is very difficult.


Kukuczka:

Arrived Dhaulagiri I ABC, summited
Left Dhaulagiri I BC 25 Jan
Arrived KTM          2 Feb
Flew to Lukla        8 Feb
Arrived Cho Oyu BC   9 Feb
Summited Cho Oyu and bived

Scaled his 7th 8000er, Dhaulagiri, 21 Jan 1988. If successful on Cho Oyu, will be first climber to conquer 2nd 8000er in Nepal in such short period of time after his 1st and first to do so anywhere in winter.


Tourism - 16 Feb 85

Kukuczka and Heinrich contacted BC at 2:00 pm and said they reached top yesterday very late so bived at 7920m last night. Today at 11:00 am reached C5 and will stay there tonight. Tomorrow to BC stayed on top 20 minutes, hoisted flags of Poland, Nepal and Germany and took many photos. At sunset had many beautiful sights. Weather cold (-25 degrees C) and strong wind. Kukuczka slight frostbite in fingers.

All leave BC 18th.


Shrestha, Tourism - 16 Feb 85

Kukuczka and Heinrich summited on 15 Feb at 5:30 pm and contacted by walkie-talkie to BC on top. Very cold, strong wind; took photos; will contact again from C5 they said.

At 8:00 am today they were spotted 100m above C6 descending and BC awaiting contact yesterday biv between C6 and top. Today sunny at BC, -4 degrees C there. Summit party took long to top because of mist.


Shrestha, Tourism - 15 Feb 85

Last contact 1:30 pm when 150m below summit, left C5 7:00 am for summit.


Banskota - 14 Feb 85

Berbek and Pawlikowski one coming to BC today. Were in C2 last night. Kukuczka and Heinrich bived at 7550m last night near darkness. Arrive C5 at 10:00 am today, summit bid tomorrow.


Banskota - 12 Feb 85

Yesterday C5 7600m SE Face at 5:30 pm by Berbeka and Pawlikowski. Two started towards summit 6:00 today and reached 200m below top by 11:00 am. Kukuczka and Heinrich C3 to C4 today.
ACCIDENTS: Heinrich hit by falling rock on leg and out of action 8 days; Kukuczka some frostbite of 2 toes but expects them to heal in time; Dmoch left expedition one day after arrival at BC because of heart problem

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6900m due to winds
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Meta
C2 on big rock buttress on West Face
C2 on face
C3 on face near West Ridge
High point on West Ridge.

8 Dec very windy and couldn't move. 9 Dec summit bid by all 3 members and Maila Pemba and reached 6900m when 80-90 mph wind stopped them (Rheinberger and Maila Pemba). Chapman and Martin turned back at 6500m. All to C1 on 10 Dec to stock up on food and wait for good weather while Chapman left expedition on 11th for work.

25 Dec - Chapman told by sirdar another summit bid made in mid-Dec stopped by snowfall and wind on 14/15 Dec and did not get above C3. 


Rheinberger - 3 Jan 1985

12th Maila Pemba returned to C1 where Rheinberger and Martin had remained.

13th all 3 to C3 where winds so strong had to make snow cave as next made to protect tent was not enough. 14th all 3 set out from C4, but after getting to about 500 ft above camp, temperature lower and wind still strong. Gave up and went to BC in up to 3 ft of unconsolidated snow; got down well after dark.

15th packed up because porters arranged for 16th to evacuate mountain.

Mountain itself technically "dead easy." Couple of dangerous spots including couloir of 2000 ft of 35-40 degree which fills with snow and vulnerable to rock fall from sides. Crevasses above C3 required rope and wind was problem.

2-3km long summit ridge from point it is gained. 


Mick Chapman - 25 Dec 1984

Rheinberger and Chapman to C1 10 Dec. Chapman and sirdar to BC. 11th Dec sirdar rejoined 2 at C1, he was reported to Chapman on his return to KTM.
13th Dec to C2
14th Dec to C3
Snowfall and wind stopped further progress
15 dec to BC
16 Dec left BC. 

All well, no illness or accidents. Arrive KTM about 1-2 Jan via Thorung Pass and Annapurna Sanctuary. Leave Nepal 5-6 Jan.
ACCIDENTS: None as of Dec 11, nor as per sirdar's report after BC evacuated

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6100m due to lack of food supplies and fuel
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southeast side of Tsho Og, 200m southeast of Japan 82 autumn BC
C1 start of climb, base of North Face (or NW Face)
C2 on face
C3 on face
High point on face.

BC abandoned on 18 Dec because struck by 130-kph wind and destroyed climb which was semi-alpine-style. 10 days of no snow but high winds, spindthrift and little rockfall. Real hazard was rock falling. Hit moraine approaching face. Maximum temperature at C3 was -20 degrees. Technically not an easy climb on steep face of ice or unconsolidated snow 1-1/2 ft on rock. Problem to find camp sites (didn't have equipment for hanging camps). NE Ridge looked beyond their capabilities on its jagged rock cornices and gendarmes. Descended to a new BC at 3950m on 29 Dec (at Lundung Kharka).


Banskota, Tourism - 31 Dec 1984

BC 13 Dec 4820m due strong wind BC moved down to Lumding Kharki 4000m 17 Dec
C1 20 Dec
C2 21 Dec 5350m
C3 25 Dec 5900m

Because of technical nature of climbing making it time-consuming, food and fuel supplies exhausted (had only 7 days supply). Abandoned 27 Dec after reaching 6050m by both members. In BC 29 Dec and left 30 Dec for trek.

-20 degrees daily temperature with gusting winds 130 km/hr and spindtrift avalanche regular occurrence.

SPONSOR: Den Den Kyushu Alpine Club Himlung Himal Expedition 1984
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to huge crevasse area
ROUTEMEMO:
Expeditions to Himlung prior to 1992 were probably climbing Nemjung.

Stopped by 100m crevasse 1 km long. Many crevasses in this area not possible to cross over or go round, so climb finished. Also stones in C2 area which hit Shigemori and Pemba Sherpa. Autumn season better time for this route; maybe not possible this route in winter. In winter would take 10 days go around crevasse area if at all: would mean long route around east end onto knife ridge above crevasse area. Had strong winds and snowfall as per Tourism Ministry report of 24 Dec 84. Expedition in 3 parties and planned 1st party to leave early, as Ikeda and Yamashita did.
ACCIDENTS: Stonefall stopped Pemba and Shigemori 5 days (this was all)

TERMNOTE: Success disputed by French leader and climbing Sherpa
OTHERSMTS: Climbed Middle Summit of Annapurna I (ANNM-844-01) instead
ROUTEMEMO:
Koreans claim one Korean woman and four Sherpas summitted Annapurna I Main Summit, which is disputed by French team. Apparently they climbed the Middle Summit instead (see ANNM-844-01).

The leader of the French team, Bernard Muller, said that they saw the Korean summit team of one Korean woman and four Sherpas too far from the summit to have reached it at the time claimed. The Sherpas with the French were told by the Koreans' Sherpas that no one got to the top.

Dutch Rib and sickle were most difficult section of route: blue ice and much of route above C2 difficult with no snow, all ice, says Miss Kim. Ahn says they moved up quickly because same route as in 1983 autumn and same Sherpas on this route several times. Also weather good and autumn 1983 crevasse now not so big. C1 to C2 very easy. Only Miss Kim slept in C3, 3 other members carried loads here and slept in C2. From C3 to C4 again 3 other (excluding Ahn) only carried loads and return to C2. 

Planned 2nd summit bid by Park and 2 Sherpas but when Pasang Norbu and Keepa died, cancelled 2nd bid. Both fell from altitude 7800m at about 4:30 pm when Keepa not well balanced on hard ice was blown off balance by very strong wind, pulling Pasang Norbu with him and fell 700m. Could see bodies but not reach because very tired and bad wind which continued next days.

Miss Kim's face wounded by strong wind blowing ice after she took oxygen mask off when oxygen finished at summit. 2 Sherpas slightly hurt by avalanche.

2 members and 7 Sherpas baggage by helicopter to Jomsom late 17 Nov and other plans to go to Jomsom 24 Nov. Helicopter carried loads to BC 2 after arrival but no one slept BC I before 27 Nov and no loads carried to C1 before 27 Nov.


Kim Young-Hwan - 21 Oct 85

HMG gave permission to Miss Kim to climb 6000m peak in Khumbu in 1985-6 winter but Korean Alpine Federation did not give their permission because of her apparent false claim to success on Annapurna I in 1984-5 winter.


Ang Temba - 12 March 85

Ang Temba (now going on Japanese expedition to Gurja-Dhaulagiri VI-Churen) was summiter on last winter's Korean Annapurna I expedition. They climbed to Middle Summit, which leader Ahn said was the highest summit. They could see another very close to them to the west and a third one to the east not so close. Ang Temba carried Miss Kim's oxygen bottles, she carried nothing. Sherpas used no oxygen; Miss Kim "not so strong."

Ang Temba again agreed with a sketch profile had summit middle peak. 


Bernard Muller, French Annapurna I leader - 27 Dec 84

Koreans: Saw them below summit at nearly time they said they on top. French Sherpas said Koreans not at top. Made summit photo at BC that was seen by French members there at BC. After success Muller and De la Ferriere saw them take 8 hours from C4 to highest point seen and 2 were hours at last from this point about 8000m to main summit. C4 was below middle summit. Muller wonders whether actually possible climb final route they said.

Koreans arrived BC about 18 or 19 Nov when French arrived C1 they had C3 established and before 1 Dec had climbed icefall below C4 and made C4 28 or 29 Nov. This is not a winter ascent.


South Korean Annapurna I expedition - Winter 1984:

Members Ahn and Miss Kim Young-Ja said on 17 Dec 84, after their team had returned to Kathmandu, that Miss Kim and four Sherpas had reached the summit on 7 Dec. (Two of these Sherpas fell to their deaths during descent.)

A surviving Sherpa, Ang Temba agreed on 12 March 85 and again on 30 May 00 that they had gone to the middle summit. (He agreed both times with a sketch profile of the summit ridge that it was the middle one way they had climbed). He said in 1985 that from their summit they could see a summit very near them to the west and another not so close to the east. The leader had told that the middle summit was the highest, so they went to it and then descended.

The leader of a French expedition also on the north side, Bernard Muller, said in December 1984 that they were not convinced that the Koreans team had actually reached the summit. The French saw the Korean summit party through binoculars on 7 Dec at a spot below and well to the east of the main summit quite near the time the Koreans later reported their summit party had been to the top. The Koreans had taken eight hours from their camp four to this point, and the French estimated that it would have taken the summit party at least two more hours to get to the main summit in the very strong winds that were blowing. Some French men who were at base camp after 7 Dec watched the Korean summiter and four Sherpas pose very near base for a "summit photo."
ACCIDENTS: Miss Kim's Face wounded by strong wind; 2 Sherpas slightly hurt by avalanche
ACHIEVMENT: 1st Korean and Nepal ascent; 1st winter ascent; Miss Kim 1st woman to 8000m summit

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7100m due to Lee's weakened condition and problems finding route
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at west side of NE Ridge
C1 very far from BC, southwest of BC
C2 just below North Face's big well
High point at North Face.

Lee climbed to 7100m with his sirdar; they gave up when they could not find a route above that point.

Approach to BC difficult because snow, hence BC lower altitude than planned. After made C2 had enough climbing gear but not fuel for many days to fix much rope on very steep route. 31st Jan took climbing equipment but no biv equipment and found very difficult to find route in heavily crevassed icefall area. In 10 hrs reached 7100m which think was last of steep difficult part of climb, but late weather closing in so descended to C2 at 8:30 pm. Then gave up climb because Lee at altitude too long and very weak and descended to BC. Weather bad during time on mountain. Wind and snow - everyday had to remake route.

SPONSOR: Japan Gunma Winter Annapurna I Expedition 1984-85
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7200m due to deep snow and weak manpower
ROUTEMEMO:
BC  at same site as autumn 1984 Swiss on grass field (below Bonington BC)
C3A at Bonington site (not good site).

Bad weather with much snowfall (but not wind) stopped ascent. All down to BC 3 Jan to wait for better weather.

9 days in BC and again climbed 13 Jan and reached 6700m on 18 Jan trying to get to C4 but afraid of snow avalanche and returned to C3 and stayed there. But 5 Sherpas now out of action so not very well. 19 Jan deep snowfall and that finished climb.

Not difficult route but some avalanche danger and requires strong team.
ACCIDENTS: Yamada at 7150m hit above knee by falling rock; Jan 17 two Sherpas hit by ice blocks on back and legs and one Sherpa fell but uninjured; 1 Sherpa fell into crevasse; 1 Sherpa frostbite in fingers

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6000m due to wind and falling seracs
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual site
High point at C2.

Muller and De la Ferriere were to go up from C2 in summit attempt on day Koreans had fatal accident, so helped Koreans.

Cloudy weather set in and very strong winds and morale not right then too had too many people at BC with distractions of film-making and illness; besides had just done Yalung Kang and difficult to do the big mtns so close together. 

Furthermore there was no snow but bare ice which difficult for 2 persons alpine-style climb. Besides enroute to C1 saw French body and at BC memorials to many dead. Plan was for Muller and De la Ferriere be only area above C2 and they returned to C2 11th Dec, but again very strong wind, cloud and some snow night of 11/12th and down to BC 12th Dec.
ACCIDENTS: Serac avalanche came down and its wind collapsed BC tents striking fear in those at BC; Pagny had trouble with heart and debated sending for helicopter (probably not related to altitude or climbing)

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6300m due to route problems, cold wind, loss of member's personal equipment, food shortage
ROUTEMEMO:
BC just below South Face on Khumrung Khola
C1 on left side of pillar beyond glacier
C2 on South Face below hanging glacier
High point at just below hanging glacier.

Half of days had bad weather from late morning: snow and wind. Gave up when found hanging glacier below proposed C3 site would require long route needing at least 200m fixed rope which didn't have. On 7 Jan Fujiwara slipped and lost his backpack which fell into crevasse. So that ended climb, but anyway had only 6 days food left.

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 6700m due to wind causing Ozaki to lose interest and Matsumoto getting sick
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at usual site
C1 at North Col by 3 Japanese in snowcave
High point on ridge.

Ozaki to BC on 4th Dec because very strong wind (completely different from earlier winds - blowing much snow like avalanche - kept filling cave - had to sleep in biv tent), so gave up because too uncomfortable and "I want to watch my son's face" (son was with mother below BC). Since now with new family, summit not such big ambition. Endo and Matsumoto stayed at C1 and on 6th Dec reached C2 site with loads slept at C1 (had spent 4th carrying loads from deposit below C1 and resting 5th). 7th Dec Matsumoto's face showed edema and too dangerous for Endo go up alone. Winter, so expedition finished. Even camp's tent was picked by wind with members in it on 8/9th Dec.

SPONSOR: Canadian Winter Himalayan Expedition to Tilicho
TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 5800m due to heavy snowfall
ROUTEMEMO:
BC southeast of Mesokanto La on moraine
C1 on small plateau at bottom of NE Ridge
High point at NE Ridge.

30th Dec started snowing: 3 ft of snow at C1 that night. 31st Dec 2 members who had came up with 2 other members on 29th, descended to BC while other pair waited for chance at alpine-style summit bid. Durtler and Horne camped between camps that night in storm and on 1 Jan all to BC since too much snow on mountain. 2 Jan high winds kept everyone in tent. 

Decided would have been at least another week before snow conditions permitted renewed climbing, but had to leave at least by 7 Jan to return home.
ACCIDENTS: 2 porters got severe frostbite requiring flight from Jomsom; nothing else

ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Tsaurabang, Myagdi Glacier, established at 3700m on 4 Dec, was destroyed by wind from an avalanche off the West Face on the same day and relocated on the same day 100m lower.

ABC behind big stones in 2nd location
C1  midway between ABC and NE Col near end of 1st icefall
C2  at NE Col
C3  on ridge just below step
C4 (A) on ridge just left of it on shelf under small serac in cave.

Porters refused to carry loads beyond Tsaurabang because of fear of avalanches and last pitch beyond Tsaurabang is very difficult for load carrying. 1st ABC destroyed by wind-carried stones and sand and another one placed 200m away (but not up) from it behind stones. Had decided N Face impossible and changed to NE Ridge route; decided on evening of 14th Dec because face very great danger of avalanche (and LO gave no difficulty). 20th Dec to 12th Jan almost fortnight of snowfall. 1st summit attack on 15th by Czok and Kukuczka got to 7800m at 1:00 pm at old camp; went down again because realized this rate of ascent beyond camp as too slow for summit in snowy weather; got to 7900m at 2:30 pm then to C3 on 15th and C2 16th. 2nd summit team 2 members reached C4.

Czok frostbitten toes beginning with avalanche on 20 Jan which damaged his overboots and became more frostbitten during 21st summit attack - other frostbite cases.

On 15th-16th Jan in horrible weather, strong hurricane wind and descended to C2 with Machnik having frostbitten fingers. Czok and Kukuczka moved up from C2 to C4 17 Jan. 20 Jan they were hit by snow avalanches, damaging tent. Moved C4 2m higher while Kuras in shock and frostbite from avalanche descended.


Czok - 8 Feb 1985

Told to Czok: Back at about 7500m near ridge [body] seen during 1st attack (probably died here). Perhaps Sherpa sirdar from expedition spring 1979; otherwise someone from 1950's. 

No technical difficulties on climb up. Of 23 days Kukuczka was on mountain 2 days clear which meant strong wind while cloudy days not so much wind but snowfall which was problem because deep and avalanching which lightly buried first C4. 21 Jan cloudy with light wind till on summit ridge when somewhat stronger. Left camp at 7:00 am and on top 3:30 pm: some places deep snow. On descent had to biv because couldn't find route and after wandering in dark so, made cave and waited for light and then no problem to descend. No further summit attempts because 6 frostbite cases. North Face impossible: strong wind and much snow.

6 members frostbite: Czok's toes black, others no so much frozen (fingers). Avalanches buried C4 but no one hurt.

Kukuczka arrived at ABC 30 Dec and left it with the team on 25 Jan.
ACCIDENTS: Czok frostbitten toes begining with avalanche on Jan 20 which damaged his overboots; more frostbite during Jan 21 summit bid; other frostbite cases

ROUTEMEMO:
BC   near small lake beside Yamatari Glacier
Biv1 on glacier (unnamed)
Biv2 at beginning of ridge
Biv3 on plateau below ridge.

No fixed camps above Base. After 2nd biv went down to BC for 2-day rest. 1st team from BC on 22 Oct and 2nd team next day to bivs at same sites. Alpine style ascent as no fixed ropes, oxygen, Sherpas or fixed camps, but did climb in two installments since not acclimatized in first push. Most difficult problem was wind. Technical difficulties with gendarme at top section and 100m ice wall across glacier above C1 and section of ridge with steep powder snow.

Rubin got altitude sickness at last biv with 1st group.
ACCIDENTS: Rubin altitude sickness at last bivouac with 1st group; nothing else

ROUTEMEMO:
BC same as Poles (higher than usual site)
C3 at foot of couloir.

All difficult, some really difficult: icefall starting at 7000m and rock from about C3 and C4. Last section so difficult that without fixed ropes had to go down normal route used by German-Austrian expedition in 1975. Both parties descended by 1975 route. Put 2100m fixed rope total.

BC same as Poles (higher than usual site)
C3 at foot of couloir.

Most difficult part is 50-degrees steep couloir, but no great technical difficulties. Some danger with seracs between BC and C2. Fixed about 200m between C1 and C2.

Two members left a little early after their summit success.


Bernard Muller - 12 Nov 84

Muller believes Baud probably reached summit on 10 Oct before Poles. Previous day's summiter had made excellent track, so he could move quickly, and he was back down before Poles (though he skied part of the way down).


Ms Gautier De la Ferriere - 4 Nov 84

Miss Gautier before above 6400m (Glacier Dome in autumn 1983). "Acclimatizing to 8520m? Yes, it was difficult but no more difficulty than the others."

She was late to top because bad weather after 11th to 17th and she had take antibiotics for tonsilitis early in expedition.

Muller and she established C3 on 5th but tired and felt not acclimatized enough and then bad weather. Other members called porters for 22nd. Gautier and Muller reached Peak 21st at 6:30-7:00 pm. Psychological pressure on them since same members had already left.

Now goes to Annapurna I in winter and hopes to try (1988?) for Everest via South Col. Now I like to go to Everest, the top of the world (but "I don't know now" about all 8000ers).

BC above Yalung Glacier on rocky greasy knoll
C1 at top if first icefall (called "the lump")
C2 on Great Shelf
C3 on 200 ft below cwm of cycle, a big rock feature between Yalung Kang & Kangch.

Fixed 200m rope above BC up first icefall in deep snow and then whole route fell off so the used Polish route to left of Beghin route here. Made dump at top of 2nd icefall on 24th Sept, but to acclimatize carried load to C1 for a while until ready to occupy C2 on 28th Sept. Put C3 tent on 5th Oct at 7500m, moved it next day to site he intended for it and then weather getting bad (high clouds and strong winds) and toes and fingertips freezing and back to BC on 12 Oct. Final push to top began night of 15 Oct, reached C3 on 17th in bad snow conditions. Started up on 18th Oct at 5:00 am with very cold toes in cold windy weather. Had to climb difficult rock band using Japanese rope there and at top of this at 4:30 pm where left rucksack as signal for finding route in descent.
  
Coming down rock tripped, fell head first but somehow hooked arm in Japanese rope and tore cartilage in knee but unware of it. Reached C3 at 9:30 pm hallucinating, no food or drink since explosion of cooker on morning. Kept falling down on 19th descent of 6 hours to C2 "in bad shape." Coudray [who was on Yalung Kang] was in C2 and gave food and water but went on ahead of Marshall to C1 - knee and toes giving trouble.

Marshall used French fixed ropes to top of 1st icefall but not above. Cindy to C1 one time when Marshall was there.

"I don't think I'd do something like that again." Interested in soloing to 26,000 ft but not worth the really big effort to go higher. "It was a long climb."
ACCIDENTS: Injured leg on fall during descent from summit

TERMNOTE: Success to NW Summit
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at Khumbu Glacier halfway between point 5456m & west of Khumbu Glacier
C1 near start of NW Ridge northwest point 6686m
C2 on ridge before point 6686m
C3 on ridge just before point 6686m
C4 on ridge before NW Summit.

Between C2 and C3 very narrow ridge and very difficult climb technically. Vertical crossing with deep powder snow covering cornices. Before C2 snow and 200m mixed rock and ice just below C2. C3->C4 very hard (difficult), very steep rocks and snow but good snow. Above C4 not so steep as before (and as picture shows) and only technical difficulty is very narrow last ridge and soft snow in places. Wind was problem from 10 Oct and had to go back to C4. 2 times tried for top in next couple of days and down to C2. Total 5 km of fixed rope along this long ridge because some inexperiencd Sherpas. No time to go to main summit: too far, too windy, not enough gear.

15th Oct - cloudy, strong west wind
19th Oct - clear, no wind
20th Oct - no wind
21st Oct - strong north wind across Lho La; lost 1 tent at C4

Climbed to NW Summit only; no attempt made on main summit.

ROUTE1: N Face up; S Ridge down
ROUTEMEMO:
C1 at Tsho Og
Bivouacked on face moving up approx 1000 ft (300m) per day from 29 Oct.

N Face climbed alpine-style from 29 Oct. 5th Nov descent via Swiss route (South Ridge) in two days.

Cholatse was difficult rock, ice and unconsolidated snow in upper half of face. Very steep face (70 degrees and vertical pillar).

Chunk of ice hit Freer on head, smashed her helmet and changed pressure in her head and gave her headache. Would have killed her if not wearing helmet; she was 100 ft from 2nd biv on 70-degree ice face leading to vertical pillar.

Also climbed new route on Lobuje East 6119m via E Ridge.


Todd Bibler - 6 March 1985

14-23 Oct trekked in area to look at route, visited Everest BC and Kalapattar.

24 Oct to 27 Oct from Cholatse BC climbed Lobuje East. Bibler and Freer went up East Ridge and down SW Ridge while other 2 went up and down SW Ridge.

28 Oct Cholatse climb.
ACCIDENTS: Chunk of ice hit Freer on head, smashed her helmet, changed pressure in her head, and gave her headache (would have killed her if not wearing helmet); she was 30m from Biv2 on 70 degrees ice face leading to vertical pillar

TERMNOTE: Abandoned at 7700m due to wind
ROUTEMEMO:
BC at west side of Lungsampa Glacier east of point 6500m
C1 on rock, west side of Glacier.

Had climbed by all technical problems but defeated by wind. Very steep ice which was brittle and broke much of route. Fixed 1000m rope on ice. Below C2 was difficult rock. Also danger from falling seracs and rock below C2.

Freser frostbite which will heal; Tic bruised by falling stone.
ACCIDENTS: Freser frostbite which will heal; Tic bruised by falling stone
